description:
I love they have tables outside of the busy restaurant and a takeout counter to make it an option for those who just couldn't squeeze themselves in the actual restaurant for a table. 

Couldn't squeeze ourselves in was exactly what happened. We made reservation the day before but even with the reservation, we still couldn't get our table on the time they wrote us down for... and we just need to go to catch our flight. That's why I am giving a 4 instead of 5 star review. Well... actually... I am taking one star out also because the shui mai was very dry and almost tasted like those supermarket frozen ones... kind of disappointing. But they are keeping the rest of those 4 stars because everything else was great. The sticky rice in the lotus leaves was probably one of the best I have ever had in California. The rice is fragrant, sticky, but not mushed together and too wet like most dim sum places would have it. Again, I love their tables at the atrium. I almost liked it there more than being inside the real restaurant. That ceiling waterfall was just great!
author: Sharon H.

description:
Ahh I'm slightly torn between 3 and 4 stars, but my experience was definitely 3 stars today. I've been to Yank Sing multiple times before for lunch and brunch as I am a huge dim sum fan, and my previous lunch experiences were pretty good. But also quite a while ago (at least a year ago). I ordered Yank Sing to go today and was sorely disappointed. 

$11.23 for one BBQ pork bun and an order of shrimp dumplings (4 piece set). The har gow were pretty small. They've mastered the art of making them consistently the same shape and form, but the flavor was just very average. Definitely not worth $8 for 4 pieces. The BBQ pork bun was made well, but the proportion of pork to bun was pitiful :( 

I'm gonna stick with Good Mong Kok bakery and other places in Chinatown from now on. I just didn't want to walk all the way to Chinatown since I work by the Ferry building. Definitely won't be returning for a weekday lunch.
author: Saachi G.

description:
The first time I tried Yank Sing in SF (a different location) I was pleasantly surprised how flavorful their dim sums were as well as their options for vegetarian. 

This time however is a different story. I still love their mushroom dumplings but everything else was just... meh. Maybe it's the time of the day I visited (closer to 1:30-2) and vegetarian dumplings have just been sitting there? I'm not sure, but even shrimp dumplings were very dry and not the best. I've had much better dim sums elsewhere and with much less price.
author: Yoon P.

description:
DELICIOUS egg custard tarts if you get them freshly baked and straight out of the oven.

It's not too sweet and fairly large. Even if you don't like the other dishes, you'll find the egg custard tarts here very appetizing :) 

Note: We usually get it to go.
author: Jenny H.

description:
Yank sing is pretty tasty but costs an arm and a leg... like for real. Is the one of the most consistently good places in San Francisco? Sure, ok. However, I don't think that warrants the price... which is like exponentially more expensive than most other dim sum places. Honestly, I think ton kiang, which is already expensive but much less so, is on par with yank sing. Other mentions include Hong Kong lounge and dragon beaux... all of which are around the same quality but are much much cheaper. 

The staff is really good here and the food is pretty good as well. They have the smaller dim sum with the thinner skin (my preferred style.) Its also clean and a great place to take tourists/ out of town guest that you would like to impress. I wouldn't say that there was anything particularly memorable but also nothing offensive. All in all, it's not bad.
author: Jocelyn K.

description:
First time trying dim sum because I always thought there weren't too many vegetarian options, but Yank Sing definitely has a lot and they are really good. The serving style here is a bit different - they come in carts and offer you food instead of taking your order right at the start of the meal so you end up eating more spontaneously. 

We ordered and shared the savory vegetable, mushroom, spinach, and pea dumplings. All the dumplings are great and have great texture, but the savory vegetable one stands above all. It is full of flavor, but not too spicy. I'd recommend not dipping it with any soy sauce or mustard that they give on the side because then you might miss the flavor. I also really enjoyed the mushroom dumplings - they are not as flavorful but the mushrooms are extremely juicy and still taste great. The spinach and pea dumplings are good too, but not as tasty (although they are a bit healthier). I would recommend dipping them in a little soy sauce or mustard. We also ordered the silken tofu and although I'm not a huge fan of eating tofu straight up, this tofu was extremely good. It was very soft and went down smoothly. The sauce that the tofu was in was extremely delicious - very savory, but not too spicy. It also didn't feel too oily. For dessert I got the egg custard tart (I actually ate it afterwards and it was cold) and I was blown away. It was my first time trying it, but it was so good. The crust was very flaky and tasty, and the egg curd was very soft and delicious. It was not too sweet, but you could still taste the egg. I highly recommend getting white tea to drink with all of these items. 

We ended up loving this meal so much that we went to the other Yank Sing location in SF a week later. The service could be a bit faster, but it is a great spot to come for lunch. Make sure to make a reservation before because it does get super crowded.
author: Sampath D.

description:
We had so many dishes: soup dumplings, siu mai, ha gow, bbq pork buns, spare ribs, turnip cakes, xiaolongbao, mango pudding... it's a pretty good place. Highlights were the xiaolongbao, bbq pork buns, and the mango pudding. The others weren't terrible. They're pretty good but the others were amazing!

Their tea is pretty good. Not too steeped because of how their teapot is. One bad thing is that we sat in the atrium and so 2 main carts kept coming around. So the lack of variety was a bummer.
author: Rose F.

description:
Yank Sing , 5 stars ! Always .
I have reviewed YS before .
Been loving this establishment for many years .
Always consistent, always delicious .
Service also , top notch .
Spacious room and atrium .
Originally on Broadway in North Beach ,
Many places for Dim sum , few are as good as Yank Sing .
author: Ellie O.

description:
Well, last time I came here was great! This time around, not so much.

It felt pushy. As soon as we sat down, they were shoving food at our face. Didn't even let us look at the menu before having food at our face. 

We ordered a chicken chowmein and the chicken was pink and red on the inside, not ok. Everything else was good but raw chicken is a hazard.

Would come back just for the dim sum.
author: Teresa Q.

description:
If the James Beard Foundation gives you an award for your dim sum, 

It probably means your dim sum is pretty good.

* * *

IMHO,

(I'm a Yelper so there ain't nothin humble about my opinion, but we will let the expression stand.)

IMHO, Yank Sing has the best dim sum in San Francisco.

* * *
Yeah yeah yeah, there must be over 100 places to get dim sum in the Bay Area.

Yeah yeah yeah, I am a stupid Texan and I have not eaten in all 100 places.

But I have eaten a hell of a lot of dim sum in San Francisco, in Hong Kong and in Cantonese Diaspora restaurants in London, Vancouver and Singapore.

None of the dim sum I have had comes even close to that at Yank Sing.

* * *
If you don't want to believe me on this front, consider that the place is absolutely massive, and it is almost impossible to get a table.

Most of the diners are San Francisco residents who presumably know something about dim sum.

If you don't want to believe me on any of those two other fronts, figure that the place is growing like a weed. 

I have been coming here for a decade. They keep adding more tables and more space to the original establishment and have opened up a nearby satellite.

You still can't get a table.

* * *

Samuel C's tips on making the most of your trip to Yank Sing.

1) Definitely definitely definitely make reservations.

2) IGNORE the menu.

The menu has maybe 50% of what they are serving.

What matters is what is on the carts. 

What matters even more is what is on the carts passing by you personally.

3) The atrium where the "outdoor" seating is for Yank Sing has the greatest indoor waterfall in the history of existence. It is a shower of water that falls from the center of the middle of the atrium four full stories on to a rectangle of floor below. It is breathtaking.

But Paradise has its price.

If you sit out by the atrium, you get a much much smaller volume of food carts than you get if you sit inside the actual restaurant.

Service is wonderful on the inside and middling to poor on the outside.

The waterfall is dazzling - but frankly I am there for the dim sum.

If it is a choice between food carts whenever I want them and a waterfall, I will take the food carts every time.

4) Their soup dumplings are famous.

There are nine million things on the carts I like better than their soup dumplings ...

But that just means the soup dumplings are only fabulous,

While the other dishes are mega-ultra-beyond-amazing fabulous.

5) I can't even count all the dishes I have had at Yank Sing that have sent me over the edge of bliss.

But shrimp shumai, mushroom dumplings, barbecued pork slices and shrimp puffs would be high on my list.

6) If you get egg custard tarts for dessert, you want them the nano-second they come out of the oven. 

A fresh hot egg custard tart blows away a regular on-the-cart egg custard tart. 

It takes 30 minutes to make those - so put in an order for them soon after you get seated. They will show up just as you are starting to get unbelievably full. Your meal will end perfectly.

7) The place is insanely expensive. 

If you find you have a deep liking for the place, start looking for bankers you can date.

* * *
James Beard knew his Chinese food. His childhood cook was of Chinese extraction. He spent significant amounts of time in San Francisco, New York and the Far East.

The James Beard Foundation gave the award to this place, rather than James Beard doing the picking himself.

But I have little doubt he would have approved of this choice.

I am actually glad I don't live in San Francisco.

If I lived in San Francisco, I would want to eat here all the time.

If I did that, I would get as fat as James Beard.
author: Samuel C.

description:
This place had four stars for their vegetarian dumpling option, two stars for service and three stars for ambiance.

The veggie options were delicious - there were four options, the curry one was my favorite. Incredibly flavorful and unique from any dumpling I've ever had.

I will recommend it to my vegetarian friends.
author: Nina V.

description:
Hands down the best dim sum place I've been to.

Cleanest of them all. The host and servers are all super friendly! Each and every one of them have greeted our table before offering what they have. "Hi, how are you, shrimp shumai?" WHY YES PLEASE!!! When you ask them for anything, they call each other on their headsets so they can get it right away. They were very attentive!

The food isn't as greasy, actually they taste healthier than other dim sum that I've tried between SF and LA. The food presentation is neat, table settings are nice, even the glass water pitcher is nice!

We really enjoyed the xiao long bao and fried bass. No MSG! I can tell because their fried rice didn't taste as salty and I didn't drink a gallon of water.

Quite popular, expect a line! I will be in it!
author: Kat A.

description:
Yank Sing takes Dim Sum to another level! They have a dizzying array of traditional dim sum, served by enthusiastic staff, followed up by waiters and waitresses who make sure everything is to your liking, and that you have all the accoutrements you need. 

The first thing we ordered were the Shanghai Soup Dumplings, the one's with the soup in them, Xiao Long Bao. They're wonderful. We then had too many items to listen here, but allll of them were perfect. We got to share the Peking Duck all around the table. Don't miss that opportunity!

Also, order the Snow Pea Greens with Garlic, brightly green, crisp, and fresh...just to make sure you get some vegetables. And save a little room for their dessert items. Custard Cups, Red Bean Paste Sesame Balls...amazing. 

It's not inexpensive here, but for what you get it's a great value. I love to go to Yank Sing (or more especially, to be taken to Yank Sing) for special occasions. It's a great gift to give... or get!  It's great to come here as your vacation "splurge" meal, ever-memorable.

Xiao Long Bao are amazing, 
here's a trick how not to burn your mouth:
https://www.zagat.com/b/youre-eating-it-wrong-soup-dumplings
author: James G.

description:
I made reservations for 11am via opentable 30 minutes before opening! As it turns out, I didn't need them but there was already a line of people before opening. 

They sat the line very quickly and I'll be honest and say I'm not use to such polite service at a chinese dim sum restaurant so it was a pleasant surprise! As soon as we sat down, carts came circling around the tables. We got potstickers, crab claws, shui mai, xlbs, Peking duck bao, steamed pork bbq baos, chicken feet, and shrimp rolls. 

Everything we got was super fresh tasting and you can tell that it was quality ingredients. The stand outs for me were the xlbs, shrimp rolls and steamed pork bbq baos. The xlbs here are better than the ones at Din Tai Fung in my opinion. The dumpling skin was nice and thin, the soup was not too salty like Din Tai Fung. The shrimp rolls were sooooo fresh and you can tell quality by how translucent that roll is! The steamed pork bbq bao was my favorite by far. The bao was so pillowy soft... I'm drooling thinking about it. I also thought it was super awesome that I could order the Peking duck baos by the slice so I could have Peking duck without having to order a whole duck!

If you didn't see what you wanted in the carts, the waiters will ask if there's anything specific you want and they'll ask the kitchen to whip it up for you. I thought that was so great that the waiters approached us and asked if there was anything special we wanted.

The most expensive dim sum I've ever had but I think it was worth it because of the quality and the service!
author: Maggie W.

description: Best dimsum. Always a pleasure to go. Every item is high quality. You can tell by how the siu mai looks and how the egg custard tart is served hot and is flaky. Love taking visitors from out of town here. It's a nice sit-down place. Probably double the price, but worth it In my opinion.
author: Young Y.

description:
Can't say I've ever had $60 dim sum before...but I guess there's a first time for everything. I was honestly in shock of the prices. Especially for a weekday lunch!

I had eaten at the to-go storefront nearby before and enjoyed it. But to charge 3-4x for the same items at the sit-down restaurant is egregious (especially when they share a wall!). To add insult to injury, there wasn't even a lot more variety. And they hustle you hard - I think I was asked if I wanted a drink over 5 times. It was noon on a Monday...no thank you. Saturday? Maybe.

I'll stick to Din Tai Fung (loyalist for life).
author: Alex L.

description:
I like the name of this restaurant. It sounds like ordering a bloody Yank to sing! 

Coming from LA I am compelled to compare the XLB to the one from Din Tai Fung, a SoCal favorite. You get almost full spoonful of flavorful soup in Yank Sing's version which is enveloped in heavier glutinous wrapper. The filling is tasty and seasoned fine. I still prefer Din Tai Fung but I was not disappointed. My favorite is not even a dim sum item which is the red cabbage salad with the duck fat vinaigrette. As many others have mentioned the prices are above average for decent dim sum but the service and location are worth the extra couple of dollars. It does get busy by 11:30 on weekends so arrive early or prepare to wait. There is street parking or validated parking in the adjacent parking lot.
author: Peter H.

description:
Came here with colleagues for lunch. We did make a reservation and glad we did! It was packed by the time we left. Within about a minute of being seated, the carts started coming around. Everything was great! From the broccoli to the sticky rice to the bbq rolls to the shrimp noodles ... every plate was tasty. Huge selection to choose from and all together, between 6 of us, I think we had over 15 different types of dim sum. The duck was particularly tasty! The egg custards for dessert were also scrumptious ... a very flaky shell and a rich custard filling. 

Downsides ... the price is pretty steep. Very steep, in fact. Higher than dim sum I've had in any other major city. Also, once we were done with the savory options, it took awhile for the dessert cart, despite someone requesting it came over. Same with getting the check.
author: Rachel B.

description:
We had a celebration lunch at work with about 30 people, so we went to Yank Sink, took up 3 tables, ordered a lot of food, and had a great time.

I'm a big fan of dim sum, and I have my favorites that I always get - like har gau dumplings and rice noodle rolls.  But at Yank Sink, I was able to try a bunch of things that I normally don't get - the chicken potstickers, pan-fried chicken bun, szechuan chicken, and the honey baked sea bass.

In my experience, potstickers at restaurants are usually pork or vegetarian.  Since I don't dine on swine, I usually have to eat vegetarian potstickers, and they just aren't that good.  So when I saw the chicken potstickers, I knew I had to order them.  I'm glad I did, because they were delicious - crispy and salty.

Staying with the "I don't dine on swine" theme - I always see pork buns when having dim sum, but this was the first time I saw a chicken bun.  They were pan-fried, slightly sweet, and the bread-to-chicken ratio was a bit high, but they were still enjoyable.

Moving on to the to the szechuan chicken - they were battered and fried pieces of chicken, with a spicy sauce.  Of course they were good, who doesn't like fried and battered chicken?

And finally the honey baked sea bass - I've never met a sea bass I didn't like.  Soft, tender, slightly sweet, and delicious.

Yank Sing, I hope to dine with you again!
author: Nadeem A.

description:
I first went to Yank Sing about a decade ago. It was just me and my girlfriend and I remember spending something ridiculous like eighty some odd dollars for dim sum. And that was before tax and tip! I guess that's the price you pay for some form of service when you go yum cha.

When Yank Sing popped up as an office lunch option, I decided to give them another shot. Our delivery order arrived via Caviar on Friday, January 26th a little after 12 noon.

*Steamed BBQ Pork Bun: A fluffy bread bun stuffed with nuggets of honey-glazed BBQ pork, 2 pieces ($5.90)
*Stuffed Lotus Leaf: Steamed lotus leaf parcel filled with glutinous (sticky) rice, and diced BBQ pork, shiitake mushrooms, chicken and shrimp, 1 piece ($6.40)
*BBQ Pork Fried Rice: BBQ pork, egg, long bean, scallion ($5.65)
*BBQ Pork Chow Mein: BBQ pork, onion, celery, scallion, beansprouts ($5.65)

I got the cha siu chow fahn (bbq pork fried rice). To my surprise, it was a good amount for rice for less than $6. Fried nicely and good flavor. Though next time, I'd ask for hot sauce as I like mine with a little kick. Good thing I had some chili oil at my desk. I tried my coworker's cha siu (bbq pork) chow mein and the noodles had a nice texture. A good thickness for me and chewy. I didn't try the lo mai gai (stuffed lotus leaf) or the cha siu bao (steamed bbq pork bun), but my coworker adored them. So much so, she wanted yank sing to come up again as a future lunch option.

With delivery, I'm surprised by how much rice I got at that price point. All I honestly remember from being at Yank Sing was the sticker shock. Glad my weekly office lunch gave me the opportunity to give them another shot.
author: Elena N.

description:
Amazing service and amazing dim sum! I came here with a group of six this weekend and our experience was great. We ordered 10+ dishes and everything was flavorful, beautifully presented, and delivered right away. My favorites were a lettuce wrap with pork, mushrooms, and pine nuts and dumplings with whole scallops inside. I had an egg tart with the flakiest crust as well, so don't skip out on dessert! The tea was light and fragrant (not bitter or watery like I usually expect), so that was a nice bonus! I definitely recommend getting a reservation though - the restaurant was packed.

As a plus, Yank Sing makes it own chili sauce - some of my friends put that on every dish! I'd love to know if they sell it separately to take home.
author: Chelsey B.

description:
Over-priced.  

The place is extremely busy at lunch.  

The best thing they offer is their xiaolongbao (see photo).  Still among the best xioalongbao I have had, here or in China, and probably the best in SF.   Paper-thing skin with hot, juicy filling.  Can't complain.  The walnut prawns were also excellent, but as my wife said -- I can make this at home.  Overall, the food was nicely prepared and tasty.  Haven't had a bad dish.  The Peking Duck is served by the piece, so if two or more of you go, each portion counts as one dish.  For that price, you can go elsewhere and get a whole duck!

The service was very good/excellent,  but the cost of a meal is way out of line for what you get.  It's easy to drop over $100 for two for a dim sum lunch!  

I'll look around in SF next time.
author: Jaime C.

description:
Hella good dim sum for a hella lot of money. I love dim sum but sometimes it is one of the more stressful of dining experiences. With seemingly an infinite variety of choices it can be overwhelming and I hate to fall back and just wait for the BBQ pork bun cart. Sometimes that language barrier gets in the way and I have to ask the server to repeat themselves praying I hear a familiar word in the description. Sometimes said server gets annoyed and rudely leaves after you just end up saying no the cart offerings. All that being said I had a hella good time at Yank Sing!

This was recommended by a cousin as one of her favorite places and considering she is an SF local we said sure despite the average star rating on Yelp. I think one of the major reasons people complain is that it's "lack of authenticity." It's not located in Chinatown but in the Financial District. As such it caters to the business crowds. You won't get the "Chinatown" feel with a lot of power suits around you and the lack of Chinese families waiting for a table. But you know what, I did that at my last trip to SF and THAT dim sum experience sucked sesame seed balls (see my review on Lai Hong Lounge). Is it overpriced for dim sum? A bit. Total bill for a party of 6 was $280. However this was basically our breakfast and lunch having flown in that morning at 9:00 and doing some touristy stuff to almost 1:30. In other words we were starving. 

Highlight dish was the honey grilled sea bass. I loved it. Tender flesh with a slightly sweet sauce with just enough char from the grill. Now I need to mention. Neither of my kids like cooked fish. I've tried frying, grilling, baking. At other restaurants they totally turn a blind eye to fish unless oddly enough if it is raw. But my bold one decided to take a bite of the sea bass dish. We ended up ordering two more plates which for sure pushed the bill but was worth every cent to see her enjoying a new discovery. There was also a second preparation of the sea bass as, wait for it, salt and f-ing pepper sea bass. We just flat out ordered two of those without hesitation. Both sea bass were so good I'm tearing up. 

Deep fried claw crabs were a hit. My sister's one request in this trip was crab. Her exact words were "I'm in heaven." 

Pan fried Turnip cake was superb. Moist yet not too soggy with ample amounts of Chinese sausage mixed in giving an almost bacon taste. 

XLB were done right. The soup dumplings were loaded with a delicious broth. 

We ordered some other standards like shrimp in rice roll, pork shui mai, BBQ pork buns, and Chinese broccoli with oyster sauce. Hit, hit, hit. 

One sad miss was the Peking duck. I've never actually seen this done as dim sum where they make a bun per person. My kids and niece ordered one each. As per my daughter "the skin and bun were good but the meat was dry." 

Service was exemplary which you would hope as a place pushing itself as upscale. Kind. Very attentive. Even if you told a server no thanks, they graciously thanked you with a smile. I also noticed the English spoken was pretty clear, again a by-product if location. They were also very efficient, if you asked a server for a dish they weren't responsible for they had little microphones that they spoke into to direct the correct server your way! It was like a Secret Service set up lol. 


Extra notes 

- If you are in a rush or don't want to pay too much there is also an Yank Sing Express for take out adjacent to restaurant 
-there is a parking structure and the restaurant does validate up to two hours 

This was a seriously a great treat for the family and despite the price we would do it again.
author: Jeff R.

description: Not a lot of variety as far as dim sum.  Used to be pretty good, but did not have a good experience this time. I asked the waiter why aren't the carts coming to our table?  Had to order off the menu.  Saw employee drag a bag of garbage through the restaurant....is that normal??? Had about 6 plates of dim sum for $61...way over priced!!!!
author: J. M.

description:
Yank Sing (Spear st) is a great spot for Dim sum in the study. I am writing this review after my third visit and the food quality of Yank Sing is very consistent and consistently very good. On this visit, we tried the shrimp ha gow, shrimp shumai (wifey thought they were dry but I thought they were perfect), lo mai gai, and fried pork buns (having tried both, my favorite is the steamed pork buns). Overall, I was very happy with each dish. 

This dim sum joint allows reservations, which is a big plus. 

It has a sterile and upscale ambience. I think there are three types of dim sum places in SF (or can be expanded to the bay area in general) as far as ambience is concerned: the likes of Lai Hong lounge (more casual), the likes of Yank Sing (kind of upscale), and the likes of Crystal Jade at Embarcadero (pretty upscale). Yank Sing for me represents the sweet spot of authenticity and good service.
author: Doruk B.

description:
Four sesame balls should not cost $12. Chicken chow mein should not cost $17.50.  A slice of peking duck in a little bao should not cost $6.75 each. Yes, EACH.

I could go on but what's the use? See my photos of the menu and you'll see for yourself. Yank Sing has incredibly expensive prices because of its location. The food is good, it's tasty, but it's not worth the crazy prices, in my opinion. 

So, why did I eat here? I was with my relatives and they wanted to eat here. We didn't realize until we had already received a bunch of dim sum dishes from the roving carts how much the prices had gone up in the last five years. We all laughed out of shock and frustration. We were too hungry to leave--we had two starving teenagers with us--so we stuck it out and then our heads blew up when we got the bill later. 

Our lunch cost $265. Add in a tip and it came to $305 for 6 people. That's close to $51 per person!! Crazy!! And none of us were full when we left.

LIVE AND LEARN. We're not coming back.
author: Peg C.

description:
Very good, but EXTREMELY OVERPRICED.

Beautiful room, excellent service with the serving carts, but a regular meal for two people came to $85.
author: Karen K.

description: Fancy dim sum with great ambiance and service.  Not your typical noisy and chaotic dim sum.   Great place to eat with family and friends.
author: Jennifer S.

description:
Yank Sing is good but I've had better dim sum before at other places for 1/3 of what Yank Sing is charging. I will say that I'm a fan of their hot sauce (try the hot sauce!) but not a fan of their prices. For dim sum, this is PRICEY. The bill for 4 people was $151 before tip and because their dim sum came in smaller than normal servings, we weren't as full as we usually are. 

What we ordered:
- Pork siu mye: Not bad, not as flavorful as I am used to though. I prefer my siu mye to have a yellow egg wrapper to lend more flavor but this one used a plain wrapper and it tasted just alright.
- Shrimp dumpling: Your normal hargow. Nothing too special.
- Beancurd roll: This was one of my favorite items here. There are 2 rolls and they are way smaller than the other dim sum places but the sauce is so amazing!
- Shanghai pork dumpling: $14 for 6 pieces. Kind of pricey but it tasted amazing! Better than Ding Tai Fung imo
- Sweet rice dumpling: These are like deep fried balls of mochi with a savory mushroom and meat filling inside. It's definitely worth trying out!
- Fried crab claw: Also one of my favorite items. Each plate comes with 2 crab claws and it's AMAZING. It's fried to perfection, the shrimp/crab paste has a nice texture, and theres a whole crab claw buried within. This plate also costs $14 and we ordered a few not knowing how pricey it was. Oops.
- Steamed spareribs: You can't go wrong with this dish! Bite sized spareribs steamed in some savory sauce... SO GOOD.

Definitely had sticker shock when the bill came out but I think it was worth a try. The waiters here are super attentive and their english is amazing. Parking was a breeze as well since they have a designated parking structure. 

Overall, I like this place but I won't come back anytime soon for their dim sum. I will come back to pick up a jar of hot sauce though. That sauce is amazing!
author: Shannon C.

description:
Yank Sing does an amazing business and they cycle people through pretty quickly.  The key to eating here is to slow down and wait between each option.  We ended up eating in 15 min with a 160.00 bill
We will be back!
author: Wendy C.

description: It's good but I've had better dim sum in Houston. For the price it's a bit too much but had a cheaper dim sum place in SF and this definitely was better than the typical restaurant.
author: Kevin L.

description: I don't know if it was an off day or what, but I came in on a Saturday when I was visiting and was sorely disappointed. The suimai was kind of dry, the carts weren't coming down our aisle for so long the table across from us complained. I asked for jasmine only tea, no blend, I got a blend. The selection was lacking. The Chinese broccoli was super cold and bitter. They were very nice to correct their mistakes quickly, but I had been highly recommended this place and it just fell flat. I've had dim sum in China, BC, Seattle, and Portland and I was told that San Francisco was the place to go but I was really disappointed coming here. Such a nice restaurant with lovely interior. Too bad the food fell flat. I guess I should have listened to my husband and just walked around until I found an open basement door with people milling about to find the good stuff.
author: Yvonne K.

description:
I would be lying to you if I told you I was a dim some Connoisseur.  All dim sum's taste really good to me and I don't know why!  They are either good, really good, or great!

I had high expectations of Yank Sing because of all the things that I have heard about this place. However, I have to say that I was a bit disappointed. The dim sum is here would fall in the good category but they are very overpriced, especially comparing them to all the other available great dim sum places around.

I have been here twice now and I don't know if I would go back for a third time but I may try one more time...
author: Jang N.

description:
At Yank Sing you can get some Deem Sum! Yes, that is how they spell it (damn, son). Anyway, the things that stick out about this place are:

1) Clean atmosphere with nice furniture and high ceiling
2) Efficient seating process
3) Quick service
4) Nice-looking tea pots

Note that I didn't say the food is amazing because it's really nothing to travel great lengths for. Albeit, it is very good and better than average dim sum. You must eat the dishes right as it's served or it'll taste cold/old fast. Obviously, get the xiao long bao, don't skip out on the egg custards, and if you want some peking duck bao, get there earlier than later or they will sell out.

If you park at the garage at the Rincon Center (where this Yank Sing) is, it's valet only on weekdays. Yank Sing will sell you a 2-hour parking ticket for $4.

3 stars overall because the prices are just too high for the value. I get it though, lots of white people here are willing to dish out cash and since Yank Sing has lots of demand, they can sell at a higher price point. If you want want better value dim sum, get lost somewhere in Chinatown.
author: Marlon T.

description:
Dependable for good service and fresh good dim sum.  Go on Sunday when rincon center is closed and the restaurant spills out into the atrium.   

Have been going to Yank Sing before they moved to this location.   They never disappoint.
author: Roger H.

description:
Wow this place I would categorize as fine dining dim sum. Offers high end dim sum with the price tag, but the flavors are delish! If you have a bigger party make a reservation because it is busy. 

It's located in the the business district. Don't get confused Yank Sing is indoor seating and looked like Yank Sing to Go has the seating that is outside in the lobby. 

They have the traditional carts but they also have waiters go around with dishes and you can order from them and it'll be delivered to your table.  They have traditional but also contemporary dim sum dishes, which I liked but wow, lets just say this was the most expensive dim sum for 2, but you won't be disappointed everything was on point.
author: Julie Ann I.

description:
Today, validated parking was FREE! Bonus! More dim sum for us!

Service was excellent today with our water glasses and tea pot being refilled multiple times without us having to ask. 

We started with a big basket full of Shanghai dumplings, the ones with the soup in it. The red vinegar and ginger nicely complimented all the flavors. Other dishes which made a brief appearance on our table but didn't last long included honey walnut shrimp, har gow, shrimp and chive dumplings, scallop shu mai, red cabbage salad and fried crispy taro. The har gow and scallop shu mai were packed so tightly with quality ingredients. Other places pack a lot of air making their dumplings appear bigger. 

Yank Sing doesn't disappoint and there's still a bunch of items on the menu to try the next time. Going after the lunch rush makes things a bit more relaxed and a leisurely way to graze and chat with friends. We were so full, we had to peel ourselves out of our chairs sans dessert!
author: Carlyn C.

description:
After "dim-summing" here from time to time over the past few years, I must admit, I've become more of a fan. Unquestionably, the prices are significantly higher than you'd find at a lower-end, no frills Chinatown kind of place, but the setting is definitely more upscale and clean. Always busy, this dim-sum-centric restaurant is both tourist and local-friendly. English is spoken here by the waitstaff, as well as the ladies who run the pushcarts throughout the restaurant, "hawking" their delicious delights.

What really cinched it as a 4-star for me was the very good service we received on this visit.  Specifically, I was having difficulty deciphering exactly what the numerous charges were for on our bill.  Believe me, it isn't an easy feat after you have ordered about 15 different dim sum items. When I asked one of the waitstaff (maybe a floor manager) about this, she explained in detail what each and every charge on the bill was for.  Moreover, she was very patient in doing so, and didn't seem at all perturbed or bothered by our request for a detailed explanation of the charges.  Let me tell you, this kind of response would be a definite rarity in most dim sum restaurants, particularly if you aren't fluent in Chinese!  
I was very much impressed by this!!  Additionally, Hubby is MSG-phobic, and the staff has always been upfront about which items contain and don't contain MSG.  For some with a similar phobia, know that even soy sauce contains a slight amount of MSG, but so does your can of Campbell's soup.  

You'll find all the vast majority of basic dim sum items here, and I really like almost everything.  However, since they have a huge tourist clientele, unfortunately, they don't have some of the very traditional items, like the Chinese steamed rice cakes (bhak tong go), which is one of my favorites.  

The push carts are another reason I like Yank Sing, and is a definite plus, as opposed to ordering off a menu.  There's nothing like visually seeing a dish to determine if it presents itself exactly like you expected. Plus, the push cart ladies speak just enough English to explain what goodies are on their carts.  

Downsides were the wait time, difficult street parking and somewhat limited variety of dim sum.  I brought the lack of variation of dim sum items to the attention of the waitstaff, and was told that in the summer, they should have more items rolling around on the carts, since they anticipate a bump from their tourist business.  Makes sense.  We were pleased enough with this visit to return again, and will, but sooner next time...
author: Lori N.

description: Yank Sing is very expensive for dim sum, but it is my husband's and my favorite. There are a few options here that you can't get anywhere else or that just make it way better (in my opinion) compared to other dim sum spots: the curry puff, duck bun (they bring you the bun and duck with crispy skin separately to diy and use as much hoisin sauce and scallions as you'd like), jin doy (their sesame bun is made with sweet potato), and stuffed crab claw. You can't go wrong with their fried rice, shrimp dumpling, gai lan (Chinese broccoli), steamed pork bun, stuffed eggplant, or siu mai. Today, the wrapper for the siu mai wasn't as fresh, but the waiters are very fast, efficient with service, and overall friendly. We don't come here as often because it's pretty pricey, but we never regret it when we do.
author: Crissy L.

description:
My sister in-law loves this place ...but for me, it's subpar and way too expensive for less than stellar dim sum.  One redeeming quality is that they take reservation.  But it's not enough for me to come back and spend money on lackluster dim sum.

If you're a dim sum enthusiasts, you will understand why this place will not likely to achieve a place on your go-to dim sum list.
author: Phg T.

description:
Ok!  I was hesitant to go to this restaurant because the ratings were not as good as others in the area...but,our group of five totally enjoyed the experience in an iconic 1950's Rincon Hill Post Office building. That was just the beginning. We ate in the inner dining room as opposed to the noisier plaza area that was very busy on this Sunday afternoon. 
Great meal ahead!  The many carts filled with various meat, seafood and vegetable dimsum and other small portions of good foods were all very GOOD. I could have passed on the overly fatty barbecued pork, but other than that the good service, nice environment, wide range of choices and great accompanying sauces were tops!
Would I return, YES...and if you want this kind of dining experience I recommend you give it a try. 
The show we enjoyed at the 42nd Street Moon theatre was also a winner. Yes, San Francisco IS an exceptional city to enjoy a wide range of life experiences on any day of the week. And on a Sunday we had no problems finding parking...ok, maybe a little problem finding a place to park on our second try after lunch when heading for the theatre.
author: Willliam O.

description: I like Yank Sing because it is a well-oiled machine, where you get the dim sum experience downtown without having to go to the Richmond. It is consistent and reliable, and authentic enough. You can't go wrong with the soup dumplings. I prefer this location because it is larger than the Stevenson location, and I feel like it is less cramped. It's in a historic building, but also has this weird dated mall vibe. It's kind of strange. But once you're inside the restaurant, it feels like a legit dim sum place, so it doesn't really matter. Make a reservation on OpenTable, because otherwise you're going to wait.
author: Derek B.

description: This is still my favorite go-to for dim sum. The atmosphere is luxurious compared to the hole-in-the-wall joints in Chinatown. It has a late 90's vibe--you can imagine this place as a setting in The Joy Luck Club. While a bit on the pricey side, everything tastes fresh and well-executed. You'll find all of the dim sum "greatest hits" on their menu. Personal faves include soup dumplings, steamed Chinese broccoli with oyster sauce, taro croquettes, steamed pork riblets with black bean sauce, crispy shrimp-wrapped crab claws and sesame balls! A word to the wise: make reservations or bear the agony of a long wait!
author: Jessica D.

description: This exquisite cuisine serves riveting food. Their service is a little low quality. Their family-friendly environment brings joy to families.
author: Vijay C.

description:
This place was amazing!! Was not expecting the high prices. About $80 for dim sum with my boyfriend. It was very very good. The service is fast and will find whatever you are looking for. The pork ribs were so tender they fell right off the bone. 
The Shanghai dumplings were so overpriced but you can really taste the quality of meat in the products. I'm used to cheaper dumplings with more questionable fillings. The green onion cakes were very good. I usually like them a little flakier but they were delicious in the spicy mustard. 
The pot stickers really help fill you up and are full of great meat. Take note that you can order half orders of the ones marked with a small symbol. May have saved us some money.
author: Ann A.

description:
We came for a wedding brunch.  I did not pay the tab so I cannot comment on cost.

The buns were fantastic!  They have a in house pepper glaze that isn't too hot and very tasty.  The Chinese mustard is a head clearer!  It's a bit puzzling why the restaurant isn't rated higher.  Maybe it's because I'm American and have different taste expectations.  The place was crowded so I am not alone in my opinion.  I'm not even able to tell you what we had as it just kept showing up on the table.
author: Michael S.

description:
I think the dimsum here is actually quite good albeit extremely pricey. In my opinion, the one thing that sets this dim sum apart from many cheaper places is that it's not oily at all and all the dimsum are very well wrapped. For example, the rice noodles rolls with shrimp are perfectly wrapped because the shrimp doesn't easily fall out and each piece has the right amount of noodles. The skin for the shiu mai and har gow never fall apart and are an absolute delight to eat. The only thing I regret ordering here was the green onion pancake. It almost looks like a donut, but it was so oily / heavy. The mango pudding dessert was quite nice. A layer of condensed milk is added and it isn't too sweet. 

If you can get over the fact that the dimsum here is quite expensive, the quality is actually quite good. I came on a Sunday lunch and the wait was about 30/40 minutes. There are lots of tables here and you have the option of sitting inside/outside where outside is still technically indoors.
author: Edward W.

description: This place is average at best and so expensive. If you go to Koi Palace or Dragon Beaux, both much better, you'll pay no more than $30-35, and that's ordering a lot. Yank Sing you'll pay $50-70 per person. Also, I swear most of their dim sum here is frozen. If you need a place near Embarcadero, then just come here, otherwise, save your money.
author: Billy S.

description:
Ate here on a family trip to San Fransisco. Probably my most anticipated meal of the trip :) Arrived at noon on a Sunday for our reservation and waited about 15 minutes before we were seated at a large round table with a lazy Susan, perfect for our crew of 7.  

All the food was very good. Some of the favorites were- peking duck, lotus leaf wrapped sticky rice, steamed and baked pork buns, shrimp dumplings, and of course fried sesame balls and egg tarts for desert. YUM. There were a few dishes we ordered that had gotten cold on the cart, but for the most part everything was delicious. 

If you've never had dim sum before- dim sum restaurants are usually louder/more chaotic environments as carts are rolled around the dinning room with a variety of dumplings and small plates to choose from. I am familiar with dim sum, but I can see how this would be very overwhelming for a newbie. If you are new to dim sum, I would recommend doing a bit of research online if you like to know what you are ordering/eating. I also recommend going in a larger group so you can try more dishes. 

Lastly, Yank Sing is a bit pricier than other dim sum restaurants. The upside is you know you will be offered a wide verity of quality dishes at Yang Sink. 

Highly recommend!
author: Ellie L.

description:
When in San Francisco, my spouse and I will jump at any chance to eat Chinese cuisine as there is a depressing lack of it back home on Maui.  We texted a friend who remembered the place he enjoyed so much, so here we were. 

ATMOSPHERE:
Located in an alleyway-like side street in the Embarcadero, it's not a huge place, but sports a good number of indoor tables along with a covered outdoor patio. 

MENU:
Dim sum and traditional Chinese (ask for additional menus). 

FOOD:
Peking Duck with Bun - $6.95, 1-piece.  I thought I was getting a plate of duck but instead received a single bao bun which I don't care for.  It was very mainstream and came with the traditional sauce and veggies.  

Mushroom Dumpling - $6.35, 3-pieces.  The server said they were shrimp and mushrooms but neither could be detected.  It had the taste and consistency of fish cake and needed shoyu for flavor. 

Chinese Broccoli with Oyster Sauce - $7.60.  AKA choy sum.  They were served chilled, a first for me.  Good portion, fresh and steamed perfectly but could've used more oyster sauce drizzled on top.  

Potstickers - $11.70, 6-pieces.  Pricey but they are of the larger variety and stuffed full with a savory pork mixture.  No sauce was available sans for shoyu, vinegar and chili oil.  

Honey Baked Seabass - $21.75, one tiny piece.  Holy pricey for the portion size!?  The small, boneless filet was insanely tender like butterfish and finished with a slightly sweet-savory honey sauce.  Very tasty but not worth the price.  

Minced Chicken in Lettuce Cup - $6.35 per cup.  That's right, just one leaf of an iceberg lettuce will set you back that much.  The chicken mixture was generous in portion size, tasty and included pine nuts, shiitake mushrooms and bacon. 

Shanghai Kurobuta Pork Dumplings - $14, 6-pieces.  Sold as their house specialty, be careful when consuming them as they squirt out juice.  It's best to pop the whole dumpling in your mouth.  Inside is a small helping of pork mixture surrounded by its steamed juices which were light in flavor. 

Chicken Feet - $5.85.  I got about four feet, chopped in halves and finished in a non-spicy chili oil sauce.  Tender and tasty but I've had better at Legend Restaurant in Honolulu.  

Pork & Shrimp Siu Mye - $7.60, 4-pieces.  We couldn't detect the pork, but the shrimp was visible.  Moist but bland.  Pass the shoyu, please.  

Egg Custard Tart - $12.70, 4-pieces.  My favorite Chinese dessert!  The crust was light, flaky and buttery.  The custard was filling was very good.  

Orange Jello - $6.35, 4-pieces.  I have no idea how they make these, but orange-flavored Jello was cleverly molded onto actual orange skins.  The Jello consistency was thicker and more gritty than traditional Jello.  The flavor was refreshing, almost like actual orange juice.  

SERVICE:
Everyone was so professional and patient, unlike your typical Chinese joints.  No pushiness or short-talk, but very welcoming and friendly.  

OVERALL:
Quality cuisine but very light on flavors.  Severely overpriced.  Great service.
author: Vince N.

description:
My team mates were dying to have this so I made a reservation on Open Table.

The restaurant was very packed during lunch but as we had a reservation we were seated almost immediately. Typical hustle-and-bustle of a dim sum restaurant, there were many people pushing around carts. We ordered quite a few dishes, ranging from shrimp dumplings, shu mai, fried shrimp, bean sprouts, pork buns, dan tats -- the works.

Honestly, not my favorite. Pretty over-priced and some of the dishes tasted not-so-fresh and rubbery........ I had to douse half my dishes in soy sauce for flavor. Service was nice and pretty quick, but other than that I probably won't return. Afterwards, my colleague also mentioned that the food quality had seemed to go downhill since the last time he went years ago, so....
author: Genevieve M.

description:
The moment I walked into Yank Sing, I knew I was in for Americanized dim sum experience. If you've ever visited Lai Hong in North Beach, the first thing you'll notice is its bustling with Asian families. Here... not so much.

When you sit down, you'll be given a menu listing out the prices of items being carted around the restaurant. If you've never had dim sum before where you take items off of a cart and they stamp a card on your table to indicate what you've ordered, I would strongly advise you to ask for the price of an item before you accept a steamer full of food. It's a pretty bad feeling when you pick up a plate of mediocre dumplings priced at $2 a bite. There are large plates (fried rice or noodles for example) you can order as well, but you'll have to wave somebody down and ask for that additional menu - it's not given to you by default. 

The food overall was just mediocre; nothing in particular stood out to me. Service was above average, but for the price, I would recommend Lai Hong or Dragon Beaux over Yank Sing. You'll find your experience to be a lot more authentic without having to spend a lot of money.
author: Austin W.

description:
Good for:
- out of Towners looking for a "nice" dim sum experience that's not in Chinatown 
- free parking on Sundays
-getting rid of that thick wad of CA$$$H in your pocket.

Bad for:
- broke folks :(
author: Janice C.

description:
What a great way to start wrapping up 2017...came here for the first time today! 

I've heard SO many good things about the dim sum here and I agree that it is delicious. Dim sum is something I would eat everyday for the rest of my life if I could and Yank Sing didn't disappoint.

Our group made a reservations for 12PM and were able to be seated right away even though we got there a bit early. I'd encourage a reservation given the place got packed come 12:15, and this is on a Tuesday! 

Carts came around quick and our first item was soup dumplings (XLB). OMG the best I've ever had. Awesome way to start the meal. Everything else was tasty as well and standard compared to other "good" dim sum places. Chicken feet and taro puff stood out as well for the flavors and texture. They have several teas to choose from as well and we went with chrysanthemum. :P

Only reason for -1 star is the price. Meal for 4 people was $125 before tip. We were expecting a "treat yoself" lunch so not too bad once we split it.

Now I'm ready for some one to take me here for my birthday! :)
author: Heather H.

description:
My boyfriend and I came here accepting it would be more expensive than your typical dim sum restaurants, and that's fine; however, for that price, we were hoping for better quality food. You're paying a premium simply for the atmosphere. 

XLB (4/5) - I surprisingly liked this and is probably the best XLB I've had; however, it wasn't fresh. 

Chicken feet (1/5) - I've had many chicken feet before and I think this dish should be a balance between sweet and savory. It's sweeter than most places. It also was cooked for too long to where it's just mushy without texture. 

Szechuan chickens (4/5) - very unique taste. I liked it but it's also very oily. 

Eggrolls (4/5) - I'm rating it high because it is the best Chinese eggrolls I've had; however, it is (1/5) compared to Laos/vietnamese/thai eggrolls or even against Filipino lumpia. 

Shrimp (1/5) - it's deep fried so you would think it would be crispy, but it's stale. Flavor was okay. 

Curry pot pie (1/5) - it's pale in comparison to other curry puffs I've had. The most unusual thing though is after trying all of the other items, my palette was very confused trying this. What's a curry puff doing in a Chinese restaurant? It tasted out of place because I don't usually associate curry with Chinese food. 

Pork buns (4/5) - fresh and yummy and extremely sticky. 

Atmosphere (5/5) - best dim sum atmosphere I've been to. 

Price (2/5) - food quality is just slightly better than other dim sum places, so it's not enough to justify the heftier price tag.
author: Jackson S.

description: Walked in Yank Sing thinking it's an ordinary dim sum place, but it surprised me with a large variety of dim sum dishes.  Their house special dumplings are not really the typical dim sum type of dumplings but they are really good.  Highly recommended.  Chicken feet is very good as well.  Everything else we order was average.  Customer service was exceptional.  It's definitely a $$$ place - two of us spent $100 here for lunch.  Great atmosphere and clean.  Overall, 4-star for me.
author: Andy C.

description:
First - make a reservation. This place gets hopping.
Second - make said reservation earlier in the day. We had a later res and found that the carts didn't make it to us as frequently.
Third - Come hungry, the food is delicious! Whether you are munching on crab claws, shu mai, potstickers, duck (GET THE DUCK) or an egg roll, you are going to enjoy this grub.
Fourth - Rob at least one bank before coming. Might need to hit two. Lunch for three set us back about $170 with tip. Yowzas.

Yank Sing is the classy, pricey spot for Dim Sum. Are there places that are just as good in Chinatown that cost a lot less? Yes. But when you want a tried and true, and your credit cards aren't maxed out, this is the spot.
author: Jonathan M.

description:
We came around 10:30 on a Sunday morning. The side door to the restaurant was propped wide open and they seated us (along with many other parties) right in front of the open double doors. It looked like they hadn't finished bringing supplies inside from the morning shipment before the restaurant opened. It was about 58 degrees outside and very windy, so we were all freezing. When we asked them to shut the door or move us to a different area, they refused to close the door and just moved us to the next table over, which didn't help in the slightest.

The dim sum was average at best and very expensive. You can certainly find better in the Bay Area for a better price.
author: Chris B.

description:
I had fond memories and great previous dine-in experiences at this place over the past 15 years.  I guess many many things have changed in SF and so did this place.  I brought my friend here for a Saturday lunch.  Everything here went downhill.

Food.  
Disappointed. 
This used to be my favorite place to get dim sum and xiao long biao in the city.  We ordered the shrimp dumping and the pork and shrimp siu mye.  The skin on both were very thick, dried, and very tough.  Skin texture was very hard and tough to bite in.  It's the "I couldn't even stab it in with my chopsticks" kind of tough.  The skin used to be very thin, moist, slightly chewy, and freshly steamed.  We also ordered the Peking duck, xiao long biao, and other stuff, but they were just okay.  Food tasted old, not fresh.  Also, I've had better xiao long biao elsewhere in the Sunset District for a much lower price and bigger portion. 

Customer service. 
Minimal to none.  
And sort of rude.  No table-busing or tea-refilling.  Finished and dirty dishes were left on our table till the end.  We had to box up leftovers with table full of dirty dishes with no space.  Mind you, it's a very small table.  One cart lady forgot to give a sauce that was supposed to go with one of the common dishes I ordered here a zillion times before.  When I politely asked for it, she gave me a lecture on that sauce doesn't go with that dish here and how they already mixed the sauce in beforehand.  She then went on herself for a minute or two and finally admitted herself that she was just forgotten to bring it out from the kitchen.  So she said she had to go get it from the kitchen (in a pissed-off tone).  I was like okay.  I'd just do without the sauce then.  But then she asked me if that meant I would want her to get it from the kitchen.  Ok, wait a minute.  Is this a trick question? Does that mean I should get up to go the kitchen to get it myself?  Hey but I don't work here.  How could one simply ordering a dish became so complicated?
Okay.  No big deal.  People could have off-days on job.  So I decided to move on without THE sauce.  She came back with the sauce herself a while later eventually, remarking "here is your sauce!"  loudly.  The whole scene made me feel very uncomfortable as if I was being an as***le to her, which I didn't.  

Other stuff.
Parking was confusing and tough.  People were fighting for parking downstairs.  There were cussing and f-bombs.  Valet or no valet parking was the question. Then, waiting and seeing no one to go to for picking up your car afterwards.  
Price wise, the whole experience was pricey like I remembered, but it's not worthy to come here anymore.  Our bill with tips was about $100 for seven items for 2 people.  I am very sensitive to MSG.  This meal made me very sleepy afterwards because of the MSG.  

Conclusion: 
My memory for this place is now full of disappointments, confusion, complication, and lies (about a sauce).  And I don't like being lied to. 

Seems like this place caters to Saleforce people and tourists only.  Enjoy your meal here if you're either.  If you're neither, stay away.

One star for the clean environment.  Another star for the waterfall outfront.

This would be my very last time.
author: Toasty H.

description:
1.  Yank Sing is good quality and is very consistent. 

2. They have a wide variety of dim sum and at least on weekends (don't know about weekdays) have many carts of dim sum going table to table. You can also order off the menu.

3. One star off for the price. This is more expensive than good dim sum should be. Our family has had just as good as quality (and sometimes better) for significantly less cost.
author: Marcus D.

description:
Yank Sing (sit down restaurant) has been our go to for dim sum in San Francisco for over twenty years and what we measure other dim sum against wherever we go.

They have all the greatest hits, but the absolute stand outs are the soup dumplings and the Peking duck cart!!! They have a huge offering (more on the weekends), so you will definitely see some items that you want to try, so hold back the urge to order everything with abandon within 10 minutes of sitting down and see what comes by. You can also order off of the menu for other Cantonese items such as chow fun.
 
Frankly if it weren't for Yank Sing To Go, I would be giving it a five star rating. The To Go arm of Yank Sing in Rincon just plain annoys me. The service is spotty, and if you stray from the narrow, limited menu good luck. They will forget your order. Stick with the sit down, come with some friends to increase the items you can try, and bring an appetite.
author: John C.

description: After a long hiatus, I came back. Having now tried other dim sum places, this now stands out in my mind as my favorite
author: Basil M.

description:
Some restaurants in life are just worth forking over a lot of money for. When it comes to dim sum joints, I usually prefer to pay less for A- quality than lose my wallet over an A+ experience. My uncle recently took me to Yank Sing, a favorite of his back when he lived in San Francisco, and I found this place to be the perfect example of an upscale dim sum restaurant that offers quality atmosphere, but only a slightly above average dining experience. 

Yank Sing is located on Spear Street within Downtown San Francisco's Financial District. I actually find this place to be very convenient for several reasons. For one, Yank Sing is nearby both freeways (i.e. Highways 80/101) and BART Stations (i.e. Embarcadero), and so getting here shouldn't be TOO bad. But of course, be prepared to face HELLA traffic on weekdays because everyone is going to and from work. Furthermore, I like this spot because Yank Sing actually has a parking structure THAT THEY VALIDATE! This is such a rarity in a city that charges egregious amounts of money for parking. If you plan on coming, I highly encourage you to make a reservation. We came around noon on a Sunday and would have waited HOURS if we hadn't called beforehand. 

As a dim sum restaurant (or deem sum??? as their menu spells it), Yank Sing will have pretty much all the stuff you are probably accustomed to ordering. For example, this place will have Hargow, Siu Mai, and even Xiaolong Bao. In terms of pricing, it's fairly expensive ($$$ signs!). Even though prices on the menu don't look that bad (everything is like 40-50% more expensive than other dim sum joints), it really adds up. We ended up getting an assortment of dishes, some of which I've highlighted below:

-HARGOW (7/10): Shrimp Hargow was quite good! The pieces were decently sized, shrimp was filling, and the outer layer seemed like it was steamed well. 

-FRIED TURNIP CAKE (9/10): I love the fact that the turnip cake was only lightly fried; it wasn't overly crispy, and it tasted SO GOOD with sate and soy sauce. 

-XIAOLONG BAO (7/10): Dude, I recommend just coming to dim sum restaurants for soup dumplings over Din Tai Fung anyday. The ones here tasted great! Meat was savory, and soup was a great compliment. I felt like pieces could have been bigger, and the dumplings weren't quite as hot as they should've been. Still fresh though?

-SIU MAI (7/10): Siu Mai was good but not spectacular. If you love this popular staple, I think you'll find that it's a good option at Yank Sing. 

-CHIVE DUMPLINGS (7/10): The same applied for the Siu Mai. If you're looking for another dish to compliment what you already have, chive dumplings are a great choice that's light and not overly heavy. 

-TOFU SKIN ROLL (9/10): This place has really good tofu skin rolls! The pieces were quite small, but they tasted GREAT! The soup filling inside was SO GOOD. 

-POTSTICKERS (9/10): Just like the turnip cake, I thought potstickers were fried really well. They give you at least 8-9 pieces, which is great if you're hungry. 

-ATMOSPHERE (10/10): If you only care about the ambiance, Yank Sing is definitely THE PLACE TO BE. I recommend getting a seat outside because you are in a GIANT OPEN AREA with a freaking waterfall that comes down from the heavens (jk from the ceiling). It's so cool! I feel like it's worth coming here once just to have that experience. It's unique, something you don't find at my restaurants in the city. 

-SERVICE (7/10): Service here was pretty aight when we came. Despite the fact that this place gets HELLA TRAFFIC, people working here are quite responsive. I love the fact that there's a separate station for the outside seating area, and so it's pretty easy to flag down workers when you need something. This place also serves dim sum on traditional carts, but given the smaller menu (compared to other restaurants), there aren't too many. 

Shoutout to my uncle for taking me to Yank Sing because I would never have come across this place (especially with the $$$ o my) otherwise. Although the food was decent and the atmosphere was fantastic to say the least, I don't think this place is worth the high price tag. You are probably better off going to other places in Chinatown that offer food that's just as good for a much lower cost. But hey, at least they validate parking? For those reasons, I give Yank Sing a "tolerable, sufficient for sustenance" rating.

Eat well and prosper,
author: Bryan W.

description:
Despite hearing about the higher price tag, I wanted to try Yank Sing out since it's so popular. And taste wise, everything ended up being pretty good. 

The service is another story. Okay okay, I know...I get that most Chinese places are not exactly known for their quality service, and this is kind of a given. This was on another level though. Service was super inconsistent, and Yank Sing was clearly inefficiently staffed for the busy weekend time. 

We got there at 10 on a Satuday and were seated promptly. It was still pretty empty inside the restaurant. Service was great for the first 30 minutes or so, with our water constantly refilled and dim sum carts regularly making their rounds. Towards the middle of our meal when it started getting busy, things went downhill pretty fast. We waited a while for a cart to come around, but we kept only seeing one that wasn't coming towards our table. So we ordered with a server. Then waited. And waited. Then saw our order of dumplings go to another table. We waved another server down about the order, who admitted that they accidentally gave it to another party. We got our dumplings after a little while longer, then we were soon ready for dessert. 

We ordered an order of lotus seed buns with a server. 15 minutes later, the restaurant was almost completely full, and we had no buns. We asked a server for an update, and he said "It should be 5 more minutes." Another 10 minutes later...still no buns. We asked the same server again, and he apologized, saying that it takes 15 minutes to make and should be out soon, which is fine, except we were waiting much longer than 15 minutes as it is. Another 5 minutes later (now about 30 minutes after we ordered), still no buns. We decided to just take our slip up to the front and pay our bill.

For two people, the bill was about $70. Definitely a higher price tag than other dim sum places, though to be fair, it's in Rincon Center, which offers a decently nice ambiance, and most of the other dim sum places outside of the Richmond area are pretty expensive too. Some items do have some particularly outrageous price points though, like the peking duck which is $6.75 for 1 piece of duck and a small bao, or the 4 sesame balls for $12. 

Four stars for the taste of the food (that we got anyway), knocked down to 2.5 or 3 stars with the price point and service coming into play.
author: Sara L.

description:
We came in an hour after opening on a Saturday and although they were already busy, they were able to seat us right away. We got a table towards the back by the bathroom where the food carts come out of. Finding this place can be tricky but just follow the signs leading you into a courtyard and look for the building that reads "Rincon One." Looking in, you'll see a bunch of tables set up banquet style in the middle of what appears to be a lobby and to the back right is where you check in. 

The food was great. They've got all the dim sum favorites from shrimp har gow, shrimp and pork siu mai, shrimp and chive siu mai, and they've even got delicious xiao long bao (soup dumplings). One of my favorites was the plump fillet of sea bass that flakes beautifully and melts in your mouth with a delightfully savory-sweet glaze. Crab croquettes and cold Chinese broccoli were a couple more of the dishes we tried, as well as a sort of kung pao type chicken and fried potstickers. We finished the meal with the egg tarts, which have always been a childhood favorite of mine. 

The service wasn't bad. They were all pretty friendly wait staff and the ladies with the carts did a good job circling around considering how large this place is. The meal for four set us back a couple bills but was def worth it for dim sum in the city. I'd def pay this place a visit for the sea bass alone on my next trip up to SF.
author: Jonathan Z.

description: Super expensive for an ok taste dim sum. I was expecting their dim sum to be made fresh not all hanging the cart and go around the restaurant kind. For the price vs taste, I don't think it worthy. I had way better dim sum half the price. Their best dish I had is chicken soup dumpling! They are so busy so always a line, long line so be prepare for that.
author: Ploi S.

description:
Food: B- Tastes only slightly better than your neighborhood dimsum joint. For the price point, not worth it.

Cleanliness: A+++++. No sticky soy sauce bottles. Everything is tip top clean.

Service: D- holy sh*t. For the price that I am paying for dim sum, I am expecting great service. It is safe to say that the service here may be worse than my go-to dim sum place. We couldn't get anyone to let us place an order of food. Food almost HAS to be ordered because the walk ways are so narrow, the carts cannot get through so you'll never get food. It took us almost 20 minutes to flag someone down to place an order. 30 minutes later, only half of our order came out. And some of the food that was delivered to us wasn't even ours. But we were so f*-ing hungry, that we took it and ate it anyways. Shoutout to Ed who made sure we got SOME of our orders and was the most attentive waiter. Everyone else needs to be better trained. Only upside here is that everyone speaks English so you don't have to worry about a language barrier like at other dim sum places.

Yank Sing, you thoroughly disappointed me. As someone who grew up in the Bay, Yank Sing has always been the shining beacon of dim sum food - it's supposed to be top notch. But, hot damn, this was the most disappointing dim sum meal I have EVER had....yeah, it even beats out the dim sum joint run by Americans for worst place.
author: Katy W.

description:
I had the take out version for lunch, but I don't see a separate review selection.  The line can get long during rush hour but it moves really fast so it wasn't that noticeable. I got the noodles but it just feels like it's  American or American Chinese to me. Oh and the price tag! My gawd, it's probably the priciest Chinese take out food I've ever had!

Maybe the restaurant is different, I can try it and see. 

I would not recommend the take out tho.
author: Lana W.

description:
The best Shanghai soup dumpling i ever had in SF 
Also shui mai and har kaw are won

Today we tried mango pudding for the first time. It was a little too mushy but not too sweet though it was good for overall.

Fried taro is one of my fav dim sum dishes and also a turnip cake here are so gooood
author: Tiratiwan L.

description:
idk about A-OK, just okay to me, but not as bad as meh

it's very expensive, without overeating, it can still be $30 pp for a quick workday lunch. it's super popular and the food is good, but the value just isn't there. it's very close to work so I end up here when someone wants dim sum without straying too far from the office, but it's not my favorite dim sum place
author: Bob U.

description:
Came here with a reservation from Open Table for a group of 6. Really enjoyed the rolling carts, felt like a real dim sum experience! 

We tried pot stickers, rice rolls, pork dumplings, soup dumplings, chicken feet, fried fish, siu mai, and turnip pancakes. The food was decent/average except the siu mai tasted really hard and chewy. 

We were seated in the open area, felt like we were sitting in a mall, so I didn't enjoy that.
author: Rosey L.

description: Came here for a family celebration and the food did not disappoint. Even with a long line to get in, the staff was super fast, friendly and made excellent food. The dim sum was great and it was worth the wait and the hype that my family was creating. So much so that you had to roll me out of that place after. Would come back again, really good.
author: Andrew M.

description: I went here on a weekend with 8 other friends. This place seemed to be bit more high-end dim sum place. The place looked very modern with white cloth tables, all glass window walls, and outside seating. The jasmine tea was served in all glass tea pot, and the tea was very aromatic. We ordered chicken lettuce wrap, duck wrap, hom bao, shu mai, gyoza, fried shrimp on a stick, crab balls, crab legs, steamed vegetables, short ribs, triples, egg tarts, sesame balls and so many other dim sums that I cannot remember. It was a very nice and different (somewhat westernized experience). I personally prefer a traditional experience, however I am glad I tried it.
author: Lisa O.

description: We've coming to this place for over 2years and it's truly one of our favorite places in SF!!! Confidently, it's the only restaurant that we keep coming back to. We love the serving style, their dumplings and the environment. Highly recommend trying it out.
author: Paniz K.

description:
I've been wanting to try this place for dim sum for a while and finally tried it this Sunday for lunch. The restaurant is located in Rincon Center, so it's a pretty big venue with seating both indoors and "outdoors" with a falling waterfall thing that looks sort of pretty. We had made a reservation for 12pm and ended up arriving 1 hour late and they still seated us relatively quickly so I was pretty grateful for that. The place is super duper busy and crowded. The same women walk around with the same dim sum items over and over and you choose what you want and they'll stamp it on your card. 

We ordered the shrimp dumplings, pork and shrimp siu mai, pork soup dumplings (XLB), panfried chicken buns, wrapped shrimp and pork, and egg custard buns. Everything tasted pretty good but I wouldn't say that it was an $80 meal although that's what it came out to be. The food is good and tasty but the money is more of an experience of eating there and something I would only ever do once. If you just want good and inexpensive dim sum and don't care about ambience and experience, it might be better to stick with other dim sum restaurants around the bay.
author: Catherine S.

description: Love this restaurant much. It is very clean and no gas smelling too. I love the shrimp dumplings and small pork buns...The service is superb. Very enjoyable experience !
author: Anna K.

description:
Place looks a bit crammed and you could easily think of it as a somewhat cheap restaurant. But rhen you see the prices for their dim sum, the linen table cloth and like 20 waiters running around. 
It's an interesting concept that they move around with little waiter trolleys with all sorts of dim sum and other foods. So you can pick instead of ordering;) 
I had a (small) fluffy peking duck bun ($6.95), 6 potstickers ($11.70) and 4 shrimp dumpling ($7.60).  
The taste was good, but not exceptional. And because they move the food around a lot before rhey "sold" it, it wasn't hot anymore.
author: Tim J.

description: We love to come here for dim sum. We really enjoy the food and the fun of coming here. Of course the price is expensive and the parking is hard.
author: Grace H.

description: We have always love the dim sum at Yank Sing since our college days, and now our son loves it too.
author: Darren I.

description: Yank Sing Dim Sum is excellent. Love taking visitors from out of town here. It's a nice sit-down place.
author: Royo Y.

description: Great food, family special event. Servers were so helpful in describing new things we hadn't had before. Really enjoyable food and experience.
author: Lynn C.

description:
Hands-down the BEST Dim Sum place ever! (Not to mention the very nice staff).
I'm totally OBSESSED with their soup dumplings, egg custards/tarts, and glazed pork buns!

Although Yank Sing is on the expensive side, it's great for whenever you've got guests in town.
This place is always REALLY crowded with a line out the door, so you should always make a reservation.
author: Elsa M.

description:
- $$$$$ expensive!!!
- Food good but about 3-4 times the cost of a regular dim sum place. 
- Soda/tea not included 
- Long lines 
- Crowded claustrophobic seating
author: Kilo F.

description:
TLDR - 

Can anyone tell me why Yank Sing spells dim sum "deem sum"?

For a really expensive dim sum spot, I was expecting something a little fancier. Service is maybe above the typical dim sum restaurant, but the ambiance here was more or less the same, so I'm not really sure what warrants a price tag of 2x the normal dim sum prices. The dim sum is good, but it's also not anything mindblowingly better than your average-priced dim sum spot. If it weren't for a work lunch, I honestly would probably never come to Yank Sing.

I came with a large group so we got to order a LOT of items. They have carts here so you can do it the right way and order from those, or if you're more comfortable ordering from a menu and waiter, that's an option too.

Most of the dishes were pretty standard, but there were a few that I especially enjoyed more:
* Baked BBQ Pork Bun ($7.35 for 3) - delicious bbq pork filling and super fluffy, slightly sweet bun
* Shanghai Kurobuta Pork Dumpling / Xiao Long Bao ($14 for 6) - relatively thin skin that holds the dumpling well, lots of soup
* Pork & Shrimp Siu Mai ($7.35 for 4) - very tender and flavorful
* Egg Custard Tart ($12.05 for 4) - incredibly silky custard; flaky tart

We also ordered:
* Steamed Rice Noodle Rolls ($9.15 for 3)
* Steamed Spareribs ($5.65)
* Shrimp & Chive Dumplings ($6.15 for 3)
* Shrimp Dumplings ($7.35 for 4)
* Peking Duck ($6.75 for 1 piece) - ridiculously expensive for 1 piece of duck and 1 bao, but at least the duck was good
* Turnip Cake ($5.65 for 3)
* Snap Peas in Chili Sauce ($7.35)
* Sauteed String Beans ($9.15)
* Honey Walnut Prawn ($13.55 for 6)
* Honey Glazed Walnut Salad ($12.05) - not something I've seen at dim sum before. It was basically a pile of purple cabbage in some sort of dressing with honey glazed walnuts. Nice and refreshing if you're looking for something lighter
* Szechuan Chicken ($9.70) - I feel like this isn't something normally offered at dim sum either
* Phoenix Tailed Shrimp ($13.55 for 4) - nicely fried/crispy and very meaty
* Sesame Ball ($12.05 for 4) - filled with yellow bean puree instead of the usual red bean but just as good

For 14 people, we ended up spending about $750 ($53/person). Honestly, the only reason I can think of for people coming here is to show that they have money to spend. The food was good but not spectacular or special, and the ambiance doesn't match up to the prices. Business lunches don't even really make sense for me here since the ambiance is the same as big dim sum restaurants in Chinatown. I guess if you're craving dim sum specifically in the Embarcadero area..

Do yourself a favor and go somewhere else for dim sum. You'll be able to order twice as much food elsewhere.
author: Jessie L.

description: I think this place is good. A little overwhelming but super good. It is super packed and people are like everywhere.
