author: Jazlyn H.

description: Horrible food. This restaurant is so dirty. They use the cheapest ingredients. Avoid as we both had food poisoning.
author: Cheval M.

description: Pricy but high quality and truly authentic dim sum! Pro tip: try to come as a group of 3+ just so you can order more and try more! You can't go wrong with their items, but the soup dumplings are a must!!
author: Cynthia H.

description:
I was on the search for the best Dim Sum place in San Francisco, and dragged my boyfriend all over town to find it. 

We originally looked in Chinatown but we missed the lunch time cut-off so the next day we reserved a table at Yank Sing (Spear Street location). The first thing I noticed was the Health Inspection ranking for this restaurant was significantly higher than a lot of the dingier places in Chinatown which made us both feel a little better about eating here. I've never had real dim sum before so this was an introductory experience for me. At Yank Sing, they serve their dim sum with carts and you basically just pick what you want as the cart passes by your table then they add it to your bill. We had the shanghai dumplings, beancurd roll, shrimp dumplings, egg custard tart, steamed bbq pork bun, and baked bbq pork bun. As I said before I've never had traditional dim sum before so I can't really give great input on the food. In my opinion it all tasted pretty good and the waitstaff was very helpful if you weren't sure what to get from the carts. The baked bbq pork buns are a must, the flavor and texture was great. I also really enjoyed the shanghai dumplings (it's soup inside of the dumpling which was very interesting).

Our bill ended up being around $70 but I felt like we were really paying for the overall experience as well. This isn't some questionable restaurant in a back alley, it's located in a nice building near the financial district. The restaurant was mostly tourists, families, and businessmen and women having lunch. It was very clean and I would say casual clothing but nicer casual clothing. Overall, I had a great experience and if you're looking for a nice dining environment come here!
author: Alexa M.

description:
Tried dim sum in Rincon with other Salesforce interns. The dim sum was solid, but wasn't exceptional by dim sum standards. The cha siu bao (bbq pork buns) tasted pretty good. The dumplings tasted average. One of our colleagues was a vegetarian, but there wasn't much he could eat besides mushroom dumplings. 

The waitresses tried to upsell sea bass and came to our table multiple times. The whole meal was also incredibly expensive, especially for dim sum. At other places, the meal would've cost $10 a head, but here it was $25 per person.
author: Nathan C.

description:
Being from the deep South, I can quote scripture and verse about BBQ, but dim sum is foreign territory and new to me.  When I read that Yank Sing had the best dim sum in town I decided that was where I'd get my indoctrination.  I'm nowhere close to being an aficionado that can declare Yank Sing the best, but it was pretty darn good and a memorable experience.  It was also expensive but I was dining alone and threw caution to the wind, sampling whatever I wanted.  I spent $80, but could easily have shared that with one or two others.  

I started with Shanghai dumplings, delicate little baskets with soup inside.  I had to repeat that to my server to make sure I'd heard it correctly.  Soup in a dumpling?  I gingerly loaded one onto a spoon, drizzled it with red sauce and slurped it into my mouth.  Wow, what an intoxicatingly delicious treat.  Despite eating alone I had no trouble enjoying all six dumplings by myself!  It was one of the highlights of my meal.  

Another highlight was the honey glazed Sea Bass, at $28 the most expensive item on the menu.  Don't let that scare you away.  It's tender and delicious and it's large enough to provide an entrée size portion for three people.  So worth it.    

I also sampled chicken satay.  Mine were tender and tasty, but a familiar item that didn't deliver the excitement of my dumplings.  Steamed pork buns were fluffy and stuffed with steaming honey glazed bbq pork, an appealing item to a Southern boy.  Stuffed crab claws were impressively large, but were slightly doughy and not crisp enough for my taste.       

The most disappointing thing about Yank Sing is the hours.  It's only open for lunch, from 11am - 3pm.  How I'd love to come at night with a group and sample even more treats on the menu.
author: Will T.

description: The best! Close to Union Square and the financial district.  Soup dumplings were the star of many great selections.
author: Ditch G.

description:
Dim sum 
Very clean in a mall with real Chinese dim sum

Relatively Expensive 2x price of typical Chinatown restaurant

The line was pretty quick and the dim sum tasty

My former Asian sister in law says 
"Where the white guys go for real dim sum"
author: Michael P.

description:
Food was good but not worth $150 for 3 people. 
We were shocked when we received our bill. 
We will not dine here again. Definitely over priced for the quality, service and amount of food we received.
author: S M.

description: My favorite Dim Sum place in the city!  A definite must when visiting the beautiful city of San Francisco.
author: Kimberly R.

description: Really great dim sum. However I went to a place as good and cheaper.  Lunch for two was $84.  Seems way to pricey for what you get.
author: Jeff C.

description:
We went here as a closer to a great weekend retreat with my girlfriends from the area. I don't think we could've ended the weekend better than to finish it off with dim sum. There is much to choose from but if you don't see something you're looking for and you know what it is, you can order from the menu. I like that they have fish varieties on their dim and all kinds of dumplings filled with anything you want. 

I did like the location of the restaurant. It was tucked away in the midst of a large commercial/financial building. It felt very much like I was in Hong Kong bc of the location. Also, The staff were very pleasant and the place was very clean. 

All in all a great restaurant and a must visit.
author: Kareen G.

description:
I'd give this place 4/5 if I were just thinking about the taste, but I'm knocking off a star for its price (because I'm probably never gonna come back again). 

I came here with one other person, and we ordered 2 xiao long bao, walnut shrimp, shrimp and chive dumplings, 2 chicken lettuce wraps, and shrimp rice noddles. That bill turned out to be $45 (with tax and tip) per person at the end. Yes the food was good, but for half the price, I can get almost the same quality taste at another dim sum place. 

On the other hand, there's no denial that the xiao long bao was phenomenal. The skin was soft and chewy, and the soup was on point. The walnut shrimp was meh, so were the shrimp dumplings and lettuce wraps. The shrimp rice noodles were nice.
author: Diane Z.

description:
I like Yank Sing. 

I've eaten a lot of dim sum over the years up and down the West Coast. I've had stuff elsewhere that's more interesting, and less. I've had stuff that's better, and worse. I've been to places that are less clean, but not more. Granted, I've not had more expensive stuff, but this isn't gonna break the bank, especially if you stick to the regular options - these run on average $2-3/plate more than other places. I tend to avoid the pricier specials. Yes, they charge for tea - so do lots of other dim sum places. It's a great place to bring friends who are new to dim sum and want the cart experience.

I'm happy to eat dim sum at other places too, so why go here? Several reasons:
I've never been disappointed in anything I've had here. 
The soup dumplings have always been excellent.
They take reservations, even for small parties on the weekend.
They validate parking for the Rincon Center garage (note: it's not a big garage, so it may be full at peak times).
It's clean. What's wrong with that?
Staff is friendly, accommodating and helpful. 

Minus 1 star for cost and lack of variety in carts - but you can request from the menu if you don't see your favorite roll by.
author: Elisabeth T.

description:
If you're going off of straight quality of dim sum, Yank Sing is one of the best places in San Francisco to get your fix for Chinese food. Compared to nearly every other Chinese food establishment, what sets Yank Sing apart is that their dim sum captures explosive flavors without making you feel like your guzzling down teaspoons of oil or lard.  It's rare to eat as much Chinese food as your wallet will allow without coming away feeling like a pork bun yourself. Yank Sing's dim sum just tastes so much better, purer and healthier than other dim sum establishments.

I just went there this past Sunday for me and my friend's weekly dim sum brunch. Weekend dim sum brunch is one of those classic "Asian American people doing Asian American things" that we try to incorporate in our lives as adults to make us feel more connected to our ethnic roots and to atone for the B's we may or may not have gotten many years ago in high school. Jokes aside, Yank Sing continues to have the best dim sum in the city.  Their steamed Shanghai Dumplings are the juiciest, most balanced dumplings you'll find without going to China. Their pork buns are a must order. What I love about Yank Sing's dim sum is that in addition to having traditional dim sum carted around, they also have smaller versions of their specialty dishes that make the rounds as well (I'm mainly talking about their fleshy cuts of sea bass that are plated beautifully). 

The vibes of Yank Sing are awesome--loud, buzzy, energy in the air of happy people knocking back dumplings with friends and family. The one downside of Yank Sing is that it is very pricey. Our meal this past weekend for two came out to roughly $75. Is the food worth it? Absolutely...it's the best dim sum in the city. But just keep in mind that it's not the place to go if you're looking for cheap Chinese food in large quantities.
author: Max S.

description:
My foodie 12 year old is a fan. He doesn't pay the bill, so that helps. He'd give it 5 stars. If I had to chose one reliably good, mainly seafood dim sum place (like for relatives from out of town), this would be it.

IT IS PRICEY.
IT IS GOOD. Even when you walk out and say to your bud "that was a little disappointing relative to my expectations from last time."

I must also mention that Yank Sing was sued by their employees for stealing their wages. The suit was settled, so presumably this means that it's one of the only places where you're assured workers aren't being ripped off!
author: Ann J.

description: I finally got to try this place after living in San Francisco for 6 years lol.  My friends go to this place all the time as they believe Yank Sing has the best XLB, and they are right.  The restaurant is in a big building that has a parking garage with validation.  The place gets so busy that they use the outside restaurant area as seating.  Fine with me since it means faster service and it's actually nice sitting outside with that water falling from the ceiling.  The workers have walkie talkies on them so they can communicate with each other.  Very organized if you're asking for certain dishes.  What I love about dim sum is that as soon as you sit down you start eating and that's what happened here.  Their shumai was a bit tough but not anything to really complain about.  My biggest complain about this place is the price.  Get ready to drop at least $35 a head.
author: Ted Y.

description: Still absolutely love this place. Went on a Friday afternoon at 1pm. Perfect time, after the lunch rush. The servers were right there. Still the best dim sum I have ever had. Friend turned me on to this place 30 years ago. Believe me anytime one pops up in my area, I give it a try. Unfortunately, they don't come close. If you ever get to the SF Rincon Center on Spear Street or even Stevenson Street, check them out, they are awesome. Everyone we have turned on to this place loves it.
author: Tina F.

description: Seated at the back of the restaurant and very few carts came by and the few that did were the same items. My table and the one next to us had no food on it at several points because we finished our dishes and no carts came again. Our waiter ended up having to ask us what we wanted to go get it for us, which defeats the purpose of having carts. Not a great dim sum experience at all.
author: Yvonne E.

description: Absolutely loved the dim sum! Just be aware that everyone on the table will be charged for tea unless you speak up at the START.   The service is fast and the dim sum is above average then most so I think it's worth it to give it a try!  The orange jello at the end is refreshing.  You really can't go wrong with any dim sum dish.
author: leimomi k.

description:
Yank Sing is the BEST Dim Sum I would say after I tried all the great Dim Sum all over the world including Vancouver, Shanghai, Taiwan and Los Angeles.

It's too bad that they no longer sell their Chili Sauce any more.
author: Julie L.

description: Delicious unique dim sum experience. Get here earlier get here late the hours are 11 to 4. If it's prime time the line will be around the building. A local hidden favorite a must do while in the city
author: Tricia R.

description:
Tasty and expensive dim sum in a large Chinese restaurant setting (inside) and open space dining area with a waterfall (outside). While I did enjoy the food it didn't necessarily blew me away - what blew me away was the bill at the end of the brunch. Three dollar signs on Yelp don't lie.

Service was unexpectedly nice but could have been more attentive. I like the free parking on the weekends - Rincon Center's garage gates are open so you can just pass through.
author: Sebastian F.

description:
Just held a private event for 100 people.  What wonderful food and service!  We received such positive reviews from all of our guests.  Food was generous for each of our tables of 10 people.  The atrium had a very upscale vibe and provided beautiful natural light for our photographers. 
Many guests had doggie bags to go when they left.  
Free validated parking was the best for all of our guests.  Only negative comment was that we were not informed beforehand that "reserved" parking was available to guests on the weekend.  We circled and circled the guest parking spaces many times before we found a spot.
Thank you Flora & Lina for taking such good care of us!  My only regret is that as the host and hostess we didn't get to eat much.
author: Marcia Y.

description: My friends and I are from Florida.  This is my first time having dim sum and it was fantastic.  Everything we had was delicious.  2 servings of Baked BBQ pork buns, 3 servings of Shanghai dumplings; curried chicken turnover, 2 servings of Szechuan chicken, and sautéed string beans.  Our serving are how many times we ordered the item.  Service is quick and on point.  The restaurant and bathrooms were very clean.  Price for 3 people, we ended up leaving extremely full, was around $45.00 a person.  I definitely recommend this place and would come back.
author: Rob G.

description:
First my first ever dim sum experience, it was everything I wanted it to be and more. Despite the discussion about cost, I think it was well worth it. We had reservations and when we arrived the dining room was already busy. Carts started rolling by almost immediately and we started out with BBQ pork buns, shrimp and pork siu mye, and Shanghai dumplings (these may have been my favorite). We added fried spring rolls and pan fried dumplings. I also ordered the Peking duck bun which was oh so good. For something a little sweeter, we selected the mango pudding and egg custard tarts, which I could've eaten 5 of, and a pot of tea. 

I loved watching all the food pass by and was sad that I was full because there were several other dishes I'd like to try. The trick here is to take a look at the menu first and get an idea of what you'll want to take from the cart.

The service here was efficient and friendly. Our water glasses were always full and we were hardly ever waiting until another cart went by. There's also a to-go next door to the restaurant and before you get your check, they ask if you want anything to go. Since we were headed to the game after, I couldn't take anything with us. 

I'm happy with my choice and can't wait to try more dim sum soon.
author: Courtney H.

description:
Almost everything we had here was delicious with a few surprising exceptions. All of the dumplings were pretty amazing as well as the eggplant and the barbecue pork buns. The real disappointment was the Peking duck with bun, which we found to be very bland, only ameliorated by the addition of soy sauce. The desserts were delicious, especially the egg custard tart.
We were surprised to be able to get a reservation and be seated right away at 10:30 AM on Sunday so overall it was a great experience.
author: scott h.

description:
I've been here twice now, and like most reviews have stated, it's hard to fall head over heels in love with this place when the prices are really quite expensive.

Pros:
- Great quality dim sum. No traces of MSG here!
- The XLB was fantastic.
- Lovely ambiance all around.
- Good service.
- Validated parking in the garage underneath. Always a plus in SF for me!
- They take reservations

Cons:
- Expensive
- Tea is $2 a person here. Some Chinese restaurants charge for tea, others don't. Depends on the restaurant, but just expect it at Yank Sing!

All in all, yes it is pricey. However, given that there are a lot of sketchy Chinese places that use an abundance of MSG that ultimately makes you feel like shit, I think it's worth it overall. Not a place I'd come to every weekend due to that college student budget, but it is definitely a nice treat to have every once in a while!
author: Mars S.

description: Very good dim sum place! All the dishes were delicious! The vegetables were great! All the pork and seafood were delicious!
author: Jonathan R.

description: One of my favorite places to come for dim sum if I want to impress someone and wish to drop $30 per person for dim sum lunch. It's not that the dim sum is the best. Most of it is fresh and not as oily as other places.  They do a really good job on the egg custard tarts, sticky rice and shao lung bao. The ambiance of the restaurant is nice and if you sit in the atrium, it's very pretty with the waterfall. We come here at least once a year for special occasions.
author: Ry T.

description:
The two times I've been here have been super memorable and delicious. This is definitely a good first Dim Sum place to go to if you've never been before. You get the whole experience and an array of plates that keep coming. I knocked off a star because I felt like they should be bringing in more different dishes, since the menu is so vast. We kept seeing the same carts come by and ask us if we wanted some of the same things again and again. Although most of the time we actually did say yes (because the food is really that good, I could eat the same dumpling plate and not be bored if I wanted to) it be nice to see more come by on carts and be offered than having to order. You can order a plate on the menu to come, but it's always nice to see how it looks at first as well. Very rarely did we see new items and if we did it was because someone ordered it specially. I also think some items are weirdly expensive. The four sesame balls for dessert are around 12 dollars! Don't come to this place expecting you won't spend a lot, but that compared to other items like the dumplings being cheaper does not make sense.
Any of the shrimp dumplings are great and so are the shanghai ones. The bbq pork buns are good if you order them so they come out piping hot! And the duck is a great dish to try something new. It comes with a bun and some veggies and spread so you can make your own 'sandwich' bun. This is by far the perfect place for large parties or even a date. You get a really cool experience with lots of new dishes. And unlimited tea!! Come early so you don't have to wait as long or make a reservation. They also have Yank Sing take out next door. So if you really liked a certain dish or wanted dessert elsewhere you can leave and head straight there. 
Highly recommend this place!
author: Melanie D.

description: What an amazing place! The food is delicious, you can really tell the ingredients are very good.
author: Gianluca V.

description:
The service was fantastic today.  From the welcoming hostess, to the cheerful dim sum cart ladies and our waiter.  

Most of the dishes we had were very good but as good as I remembered.
Still a 4 star.

We will definitely come back again.
author: Michelle A.

description:
This is a must go Dim Sum restaurant in SF! The restaurant is clean, fast service, you get a seat in normal busy hours in 15-20 minutes. I usually book my reservation one or two day in advance. There's also a take out session that you can bring steam buns back. Just reheated with a rice cooker.

Food: The steam bum is great, they come with red vinegar sauce and ginger. Must try their baked duck （北京鴨） and custard bun（奶黃包 ）.
author: Karen C.

description:
There is no question that Yank Sing is my favorite Dim Sum restaurant in San Francisco.

The restaurant itself is spotless and upscale. A wonderful dining experience.

The food is universally good. I have never had any dish that I did not like.

The only drawback.... it is very, very expensive. I would go far more often if it wasn't so expensive. A table of 4 was $75/person after tax and gratuity. That is probably twice as much as I would have felt comfortable paying.
author: Bill L.

description: You must visit this fantastic dim sum restaurant if you visit San Francisco.  Check the hours that they are open since they are not open for dinner.  It's pricey.  But well worth it.  We chose to sit in the atrium since it gave us more elbow room.  There is always something to eat for everyone.  They can validate your parking permit for free parking.  The customer service is excellent.  Empty dishes didn't sit on our table for very long.  Just make sure that you pace yourself so that you can enjoy every bite. We always eat here to celebrate special occasions.
author: Joyce S.

description:
By far the best dim sum I've had in California  
Our servers were very nice and checked up on us. Better yet they spoke good English. I'll definitely go back soon
author: Mayiab Vang H.

description: Had a delicious brunch in the atrium of the restaurant. Everything was delicious but our favorites were the soup dumplings and ribs. Pace yourself!
author: Paula B.

description: This location is within a courtyard that is junkie/hobo free.  This is THE place to get dim sum without that shit-smell that SF has become.
author: Ricardo O.

description: Awesome dim sum. The best Singapore style fried rice noodles ever! The waitress told me it'd be a 20min wait for the dish since the kitchen was busy, but it's worth it!
author: Jessica C.

description:
This is possibly the best finding place I've been to! They have a decent variety for vegetarians like myself. However, the service is very poor, and I found the staff particularly impersonal and impolite. They had run out of some dimsums I wanted to try.

What I specifically love about the place is that they have small portions, so I could try a lot of them even on my own!
author: J R.

description: I have to say this place was not bad at all. I love dim sum and came here for brunch. Everything was so delicious and fresh, service could be improved a little bit, but overall had a pretty good experience. I would come back for some more and bring friends as this place is good for groups.
author: Roman L.

description: Legitimately the worst dim sum in the bay area. Reheated, not fresh, frozen, and complete pieces of shit, what a sad excuse for a dim sum restaurant. The glory days of good chinese food in San Francisco are truly, and irrevocably over.
author: Raymond W.

description:
Man, this was so disappointing. I LOVE dim sum, but I was warned the food is OK here.

The 2 main reasons we went here are (1) b/c parking is validated on the weekend and (2) you don't really have to wait too long to be seated. 

If you want good dim sum, this place is NOT it...
author: Jen H.

description: The dim sum here is amazing !!!   Favorites are the shrimp dumpling and the mushroom dumplings.  Pork bum also delicious.    Loved everything we had and we had a lot!
author: Sheryl G.

description:
We came across this place on Yelp due to distance. The reviews makes it seem 3 stars but this is one of the best dim sum places I've been too. I have gone to my fair share of dim sum (yum cha).

This place is catered to Americans because it is located inside a high rise business building with validated underground garage parking. During lunch you will see many people taking their lunch in the quad area. If you in a hurry - don't rush because there is a to go place right next door. 

The typical price here is over $6 per dish. The usually dim sum plates are $2-$3. It was a bit pricey. Don't be alarm with the price because it is well wrote it. I ordered the standard dim sum plates.

This place is a must go if you want to spend a little more on some great Dim Sum. Like I said the standard dishes I typically order - har gow, chicken feet, shu mai, shrimp rice rolls, and BBQ pork bun; definitely need to order. They even have entree dishes in carts coming by (whole Peking duck!).
author: Joanna H.

description: Fabulous food and friendly service. This is a favorite dim sum go to place. A little pricier than Chinatown but worth it. They did something special for my daughter's 15th birthday. All the staff were super friendly. The food is tasty and fresh. Delicious seafood options. Many tasty vegetarian choices too .
author: An N.

description:
Lots of Vegan Options 
Our first dim sum ever! And a very pleasant experience! Especially because We're vegan. The vegan dumplings, eggplant basil and tofu were par excellence. We had the spinach, savory, pea sprouts and mushroom dumplings and each one was delectable. The staff was very attentive and helpful and considerate of our dietary restrictions.
author: Giri S.

description: My co-worker warned me about the food at Yank Sing 2 Go, the take out section of the restaurant (that the dim sum was too dry), but I still wanted to give it a try. I placed my order and paid with cash while most others paid with credit card. When calling my number, the employee asked me to show her my receipt (while she did not ask others to show her the receipt), which is fine. I showed her the receipt, and she took a look and grabbed it, and threw it away! I asked her politely that I need it back. What did she do? She literally threw back the wrinkled receipt to me!!!!! I feel very offended and discriminated at this restaurant!
author: Michael F.

description:
Yesterday, our family went to Yank Sing for Mother's Day Dim Sum Brunch. The restaurant is located in the Rincon Center Plaza. There is Validated parking in the parking lot. The restaurant is clean and decorated nicely. There is also atrium dining with a bunch of tables in the center atrium of the center. There service is excellent. Even on a hectic Mother's Day Brunch there is a full staff 3 or 4 hosts, servers, busser, and captains. 

The Dim Sum however is Americanized Chinese food. The Shu Mai is unrecognizable. My wife and I both looked at each other after taking a bit and said what is this? The beef and shrimp fun rolls were Ok and the steamed black bean pork ribs were good. We had two orders of the XLB's. The stuffed Lotus leaf was awful. 

The prices were steep, but we knew that going in. Pluses were the service and the free Validated parking. I don't think I would go back for the food. $168 for party of 4. Oh well it's mothers day.
author: George F.

description: Great Dim Sum.  Been going here for years and it never disappoints.  Rincon Center is beautiful.
author: Melanie H.

description:
Definitely the nicest and most delicious dim sum Ive had in the states. However, I don't think taste/experience is well matched by the very high prices. Don't get me wrong.. the soup dumplings were fabulous and the dumplings were clearly made with higher quality meats then your china town dim sum places... but for 5x the price? I don't know. The service was also mediocre at best. I know service really is not key in Asian eateries.. but for $$$ places.. it should be. 

In short, I would definitely come back if someone else was paying.
author: Kina L.

description: Nice dim sum.  The rolling carts are fun except nothing is labeled and the servers don't seem to know what they have either.  So if you actually see a menu and want something like chicken dumplings you might end up biting into mushroom dumplings... Which is not fun!
author: Kelly S.

description:
This is one the best restaurants in San Francisco.
Bar none. Terrific dim sum better than Hong Kong. 
Staff is great!
author: Barry W.

description: Must try if you are s fan of dumplings. Tried the curried chicken pot stickers , shrimp dumplings and barbecue pork buns. Amazing taste ! Good quality and tasty dim sum!
author: Aravind J.

description: Service is really good, but kinda over priced... it's located inside a building so you won't really see it if your driving
author: Sharon V.

description: Very good quality food, packed to the gills on Sunday AM. Sure you'll pay more than a place deep in Chinatown, but you'll also feel full and happy, not bending over with a stomach ache.
author: Christopher M.

description: The best Dim Sum. Everything is so good, hot and fresh. You will feel like taking one of everything it is so good. I wished I lived closer because I would eat here all the time
author: F M.

description:
Upscale dim sum restaurant in the Rincon Center. They have all the usual dishes and then some - like Peking duck ordered by the person. Fast service. Lots of seating. Free parking on the weekends at the Rincon Center. 

The only bummer is that they charge you $2 per person for tea (but don't tell you that at the time you order).
author: Rob N.

description:
Pricy but best place for dim sum if you don't want to go too far! One thing I love about this place is you can sit down and be eating within the minute that you sit down. Also don't forget to make a reservation! It's very easy on opentable. 

Yank sing probably has the best Xiao long bao (steamed soup dumplings) in SF other than the recently opened Ding Tai Fung, but that's in the South Bay and the wait is crazy long. 

Other must gets at Yank sing are the taro puffs, shrimp dumping and rice in lotus leaf (lo mai gai).

Their steamed and baked pork buns are ok, my favorite steamed pork buns in the city are at MY China. MY China has really good dim sum but there aren't many choices versus Yank Sing has carts and carts filled with different dishes for you to choose from. 

The bad thing is it'll cost around $30/person versus other dim sum places in Richmond will only be $15 for the same amount of food.
author: Rohenne L.

description:
Yank sing has been apart of our family for almost 5 years. We celebrate all kinds of events here; from birthdays to Christmas and love I every single time. Their soup dumplings, honey walnut shrimp and orange Jell-O are especially good.

When It comes to tasty food and friendly service this is when we come for Chinese food. Not always the cheapest meal but always worth it and we recommend it to everyone who comes to town.
author: Chase M.

description: The Mango pudding is not bad, and the pistachio ice cream is tasty too. The rest dim sums are fairly ok, to be honest...
author: Xu Y.
Wayne H.

description:
We had a great meal and the food was mostly fantastic.  I would absolutely be back.  Yes, it was pricey but I thought the overall experience was a lot of fun.  Besides, I know how hard it is to actually make all those little dumplings and I'm really not interested in eating sweatshop dumplings.  Also, it's a very expensive location.  Most of their profit probably goes straight to that.  My fav?  The goldfish dumplings*!

*No actual goldfish were harmed in the making of the goldfish dumplings.
author: Suzy G.

description:
Mortgage your house but go. It's not cheap dim sum  but certainly worth it. We usually go out into the avenues but this was a special treat. Tons of variety so decide what you want then wait and you will be tempted.. they give you a menu and then food delivery on carts (a must for me) all the steamed dumplings were fantastic the fish in Miso I am still dreaming about.  Asian coleslaw was  very yummy and baked pork buns outstanding. The Peking  ribs  were delicious but maybe a bit sweet for some.The duck pieces were big and juicy so one was enough. Also if you don't see something on a cart ask your waiter. 

. The pot stickers were no better than the 3 for a dollar in the avenues the fried shrimp just ok . The gai lang could have had more flavor but was very fresh.  I'm definitely going back bc there is so much more I want to try.

Going back for fish and coleslaw for sure...and dumplings and Peking duck
author: Kay T.

description: Hands down every time I come to SF I come to Yank Sing for dim sum lunch. First they take OpenTable which makes it easy to book a table. Next they validate the your parking up to two hours. We paid I believe $4 to have to restaurant validate it on our bill, but I think it would have cost$18. Service and carts come by quickly my favorite is the shrimp, pea shoot, shrimp and chive, and mushroom. Also got the Chinese broccoli. Yes this place is more expensive than typical hole in the wall restaurant, but the food quality and service are amazing.
author: Alissa W.

description:
Very delicious, but for the price, not that good.  Prices definitely went up since my visit 5 years ago. This time it was 2 adults and 2 children, and the total bill was $172! We did not even eat that much, and for quality/quantity to price ratio, places like Koi palace in Milpitas outperforms Yank Sing.

Nonetheless, aside from the xiao long bao which still needs improvement in recipe ($14/6 pcs!), everything was very tasty, held together greatly and was satisfying to the tummy. The highlight was the honey glazed sea bass, sooo delicate and lightly flavored.  I don't know if I can continue to indulge in this perfection the size of half a standard Rubix cube for $22.  Siu mai and har gow was delicious, but not that far ahead or different from many other restaurants. (~$7-8 per basket).  The piece of a single order of peking duck and bun felt like a rip off since it wasn't outstanding. 

Service is pretty good but almost not enough for a "$$$" rating level.  I may have been taken by surprise since we weren't given the price menu, so do check that when you visit here if you care. Maybe on the day where I don't care about how much money to spend, I'll return to Yank Sing and feast.
author: Tony V.

description:
My mama would slap me Madea-style if she found out I came here.  My son wanted to try this place when I told him they serve dim sum with carts here.  I figure it's just the two of us, no big deal.  

Well, let me tell you!  They're called Yank Sing for a reason.  YANK means they'll yank all the monies outta your pocket, and sing means they'll SING about it later.  Yup, this place is ridiculous, no wonder Asian moms get upset when they find out Yank Sing charges $17 for one piece of Peking duck (not pieces).  Don't get me started on the xiao long baos WTH?  Our bill was over $80 for one kid & one adult.  Never again, don't care how good it tasted - that's highway robbery!!!  

With all the dim sum places to choose from in the city, I blame myself for being the SUCKER!  Even gweilo's know better; they're savvy when it comes to authentic dim sum with reasonable prices in SF.  Head to the avenues for delicious authentic dim sum aka Hong Kong Lounge, Hong Kong Lounge Il, Ton Kiang, Shai Lai (formerly Mayflower), Dragon Beaux (Koi Palace owners), etc.
author: Christine R.

description:
Don't park on the meters outside!!!! There is a parking in the structure and you can get your ticket validated in the restaurant.  

Food was amazing!! This place is a Legit Chinese restaurant because they serve roast duck from head to toe straight to your table!  Dim Sum, cake noodle, fried rice... everything was good!! Oh and that tea in the glass is good if you are a tea drinker, yum!!
author: Sharlene E.

description:
Edgar noticed a $50 bill under our table after we walked out. He chased us down to see if we lost any money. My boyfriend was in the bathroom so I wasn't sure, but Edgar trustfully handed it over to me when I told him I'll find him once my boyfriend came out. Thankfully it was my boyfriend's and when my boyfriend offered Edgar $5 for returning the money, he refused! Thank you SO MUCH, Edgar. Glad there's still good in the world!

Now onto the food. Although it's pricey, I think it's worth it. This is my FAV DIM SUM. Solely because their shrimp noodle roll has cilantro in it and I've never had it like that anywhere else in my 24 years of life!!! Chicken feet, soup dumplings, egg tart, crab claw, silkened tofu, and shumai are also musts. The hakow wasn't good that day and I don't remember if they're always like that.
author: x'tine w.

description: Fantastic food! But the prices are crazy for dim sum. Not including the bill was almost $250 for 3 of us- and we ate less than normal.  The soup dumplings are awesome and so were a few other items- but I don't think $250 for 3 people, awesome.  This place is definitely for rich blood- and tourists that don't know any better.
author: Miranda H.

description:
This is a review for Yank Sing 2 Go. I ordered the Yank Sing Super. The Singapore noodles we're off. They we're greasy and the texture was dry at the same time, the meat was dry and the shrimp looked odd.It didn't taste right. I didn't eat the rest of the noodles and just ate everything else. After lunch my head started to feel like there was pressure on it. I was also having heart palpitations, and a fever. I was incapable of continuing work and left early to go home. Before I even got home I had to get off before my stop to vomit. 

I realized that I had food poisoning and that they served me old noodles. What kind of business serves old food to costumers? I'm never going back there again. Lee's Deli is probably a better option for cheap Chinese food to go than this place. Avoid this place at all cost.
author: Kaylan W.

description: The food is so expensive here . I odered the duck o thought is a plate but is only one piece I was like wtf. And the service is pretty bad
author: Clancy Y.

description:
Jack and I decided to have a Saturday morning lunch here, and it was worth every bit of it. We must have eaten $100 worth of dim sum for lunch. And oh boy, was it yummy!

We had a plethora of dishes ranging from their signatures Shanghai Dumplings, to their Peking Duck, to their infamous Minced Chicken Potstickers. OMG!  FABULOUS!   I can't wait to go back for those three dishes. 

Loved their BBQ Pork Bun, Snow Pea Shoots, Phoenix Tailed Shrimp, and Spring Rolls were MIND BLOWING!  And for dessert the Sesame Balls and Fresh Orange Juice Jello were very different, creative and perfect for the ending to a delicious lunch. 

Yes this place is expensive but so worth it.  I've been here before but honestly, it keeps getting better & better, IMHO. 

It was crowded. Don't forget reservations.
author: Janet T.

description: I hadn't been here in a couple of years. The prices have gone through the roof. Now, my friend and I were hungry and polished off sea bass, a half-order of shrimp/chives dumplings, soup dumplings, fried shrimp, Hunan chicken, walnut prawns and a large sparkling water. And maybe one more dish I've forgotten, $106 before tax. I was shocked. No way worth it.
author: Robin W.

description: Really good dim sum.  Much better  than San Diego's.  All the standards were delicious.  Bao,   shiu  mai, etc.   More delicate than your average dim sum.  I'll be back on  next  SF trip.
author: Mark S.

description: Awesome food!  Four stars are because the prices which are a bit high.  Perfect for special occasion with a group.
author: Andrew D.

description: I could have sworn I've reviewed this place already. I've been going here since I was knee-high at their old location on Battery, and my parents had been going to the Stevenson location since they were in college. Anyway, for dim sum this place can be kind of hectic and intense- you have people coming with carts rapidly and ordering rapidly. Get your game face on! It's definitely expensive for dim sum. There are only a handful of vegetarian options, sadly- I've only counted about 5 on the menu. I recommend the peking duck, the orange jello, the egg tart, and basically any of the steamed dumplings! But be advised it's kind of expensive.
author: Samir K.

description: Great dim sum, however they ran out of their siu mye dumplings and I don't ever think they made more. We got some rice with pork inside of it, pot stickers, and their special shanghai dumplings which were so good! We also got a pot of jasmine tea. We sat on the patio which was cute and refreshing in the nice weather. We asked for waters and it took some time and us asking again to finally get them, but afterwards the service was quick to always refill. Would definitely comeback to this place!
author: Hope N.

description:
1 star off: The dimsum is mediocre at best.  There is shumai, dumplings, BBQ pork buns, mango pudding, etc. but nothing unique.  You might as well go to the frozen food aisle at any Chinese grocery store and find the same items.

1 star off: The price tag is twice as much as other dimsum restaurants.  I don't understand why anyone would pay this much for mediocre dimsum here.  Sure, San Francisco is expensive, but there are tons of better dimsum in the city for much less.

1 star off: Everything is very Americanized.  The waitstaff...the customers...no one is Chinese.  Chinese people do not come here.  Even the tables and chairs are clean. *confused look*
author: Ally W.

description: Food super overpriced. $15 bucks for sesame balls? When they should be $3.00 max. Ridiculous...$20 for seafood panfried noodles and it wasnt enough to fill 4 people's plates. Service was horrible. Had to ask for tea multiple times after we sat down for 20 mins.  Another 15 mins to get 2 forks.  Dont even bother getting refills,  had to ask 8 times. At $2.00 charge per person for tea...wow. Bill came out to $192.00 and we all were still hungry after. Better to visit Millbrae Flower Lounge or Tai Wu in Millbrae or even Koi Palace in Daly City. Open your wallets cause this is a great place for suckers ...I mean tourists. It's a sign when not many asians were eating in the restaurant. Other dim sum places are $60 to 90 bucks for 8 to 10 people and you will be stuffed. Caveat Emptor
author: Brandon L.

description:
Recommended by my residence's "concierge fantastic" Mark.  I thought how much better a dim sum restaurant be, compared to all the dim sum restaurant we tried before.  The best dim sum I've tried so far.  My last best one was in Vancouver.  This one is better than any dim sum in area, including Koi Palace, Dynasty, Asian Pearl, the Kitchen, etc....   Warning, the price is double the other restaurants. 
Service is good for Chinese restaurants!  All of them are very responsive, and relatively nice.  Chinese restaurants I specifically judge the food much higher proportion than service, for obvious reason....  also because I am One....  and very familiar with it.
All the dishes are done very nicely, all dumpling wrapped tightly, you really can taste the shrimp,
Or other ingredients....  Not a whole lot of unnecessary fillings.  Not too sweet or too salty.  Really well done, for pre prepared food.... 
highly recommended....  for someone who don't mind paying extra for higher quality....   (China Live, see how this thing's done!!!!)
Will be back in future....
author: Steve D.

description: Good quality dim sum but very pricey due to the location. Overall had a nice dining experience here. I'll probably try their original location next time which cost less.
author: Andrew P.

description:
This review is only for the grab n go section. I've been hearing a lot of compliments about their dine in restaurant but I didn't have enough time so I decided to place a to go ordered. Unlike the fancy seating, the to go section is much smaller and the menu is very limited. I got a box full of chowmein and 3 three dumplings for 10 bucks. Really? Chinatown is only 10 mins walking away and u can get better food for half of that price.  
I have a hard time understanding how the menu work and the staff is not very eager to help out. 
May be I will try another visit for the dine in but no more grab n go.
author: Russ C.

description:
One of the best dim sum in SF!  The food comes around fresh on the carts and you select what you want to eat.  You can tell the quality here is better than the other dim sum places.  Hence- the prices reflects that as they also charge you for tea.  However, the service is great as my glass of water is always refilled without having to ask.  

Some must have are the shanghai dumplings, shu mai, fried taro, & sticky rice.  They also have specials such as sea bass for dim sum as well.  And their hot sauce on the table is the bomb!  Do yourself a favor and make a reservation ahead of time on OpenTable to avoid waiting in line.
author: Melanie N.

description:
Great food. Cart service. VERY expensive. My wife wouldn't let me see the bill. 

The only special occasion dim sum restaurant I've ever been in.
author: Harry R.

description:
I was a bit hesitant in eating here after reading the reviews, but thought I'd give it a try anyway.

Most of the dim sum was very tasty and not so greasy. However, every piece was served warm or cold instead of hot. As long as people are being seated, the food should be served according to it's standard.

The price seemed high, mainly because I was disappointed in the temperature of each item.
author: Leslie S.

description:
Ate here last Monday with my hubby before closing 
time and was glad we did . Was overwhelmed by the server showing all the dishes on a cart . It was a pricey lunch , but good service. Be a while till I'll 
be back ! Lol
author: Gloria L.

description:
Ok, I always feel bad when I give a bad or mediocre review, but I also believe I'm entitled to express myself when I pay for an experience.

I've eaten here so often over the years, and spent thousands of dollars not due to my own innate need, but rather to bring out of town guests or business clients to a dim sum place that's at least semi-clean, has a nice ambiance, and the staff are polite.  However, like so many experiences before, it fell short again.

The simple fact is barring the environment and friendliness, you get grossly overpriced dim sum with modest quality.

Today was such an experience.  Cold pot stickers, cold Shanghai dumplings, cold pork ribs with blood still in the meat...that said, I commend the fact we weren't charged for this as "Lena" handled it professionally and kindly.  Yes, it was 2:30pm in the afternoon, but I would expect a better experience from a reputable restaurant especially at these high  prices.
author: Robert C.

description:
Good stuff. I like the carts they bring to your table. Dumplings are awesome!
Long reviews are made by words written in the review. Everyone knows that.
author: Mohsen A.

description:
Always our stop in SF 
 fun to take friends for the special experience of a dim sum lunch
Always pleased with service 
Make sure you pace yourself , the carts come quickly 
So many delicious dishes to choose from
Don't get carried away with the first one 
More to follow right behind
author: Kathy C.

description:
I came here later in the afternoon around 1:30pm for some dim sum, so it was definitely a lot quieter than usual within the restaurant. The restaurant from the inside looks like a typical traditional dim sum restaurant. The first thing I noticed were that the prices were very expensive, but that was not much of a surprise due to its location and notoriety.

I was able to try lots of dishes including the peking duck, shrimp dumplings, chicken feet, etc. They were slightly above average in taste and techniques such as the shrimp dumplings having a nice thinner than usual wrapping. However, maybe due to being there later in the afternoon, all the dim sum didn't seem to come out very fresh as they were on the colder end. Especially for the price, this was a bit disappointing. In the end, I found the egg tarts to be the best here though. They're among the best I've ever had.
author: Joshua M.

description: Went to the to go side of yank sing and got the weekly special which was black pepper chicken. Ive had black pepper chicken from a multitude of places and this one was by far the worst, even panda express makes better black pepper chicken. Skip this place if you're thinking of it, your black pepper chicken might as well be called black pepper celery.
author: Alan H.

description:
Good dim sum but way pricier than what you would pay for elsewhere like Chinatown. It came out to about $35-40 per person. It's good for large groups. Just try to make a reservation beforehand if you can. The people that push the carts are nice and patient.

I thought the xiao long bao (soup dumplings) and egg tarts were exceptional. The other dishes like shumai and shrimp dumplings were good too but not necessarily worth the higher price.

Overall if you're looking for a really clean and slightly more upscale dim sum place with good service then this is an ideal spot to go to.
author: Linda X.

description: Still the standard for dim sum in San Francisco.  Yank Sing does everything well, the Har Gau has thin, non-sticky skins; and the Shiu Mai has flavorful meat stuffing with a small amount of orange fish roe on top.  It's also one of the rare places where Peking Duck is served by the piece from a cart.  The Puh-Ehr tea is hot and strong, as it should be.  Excellent!
author: Mike C.

description: Oh my gosh, this has to be the best Dim Sum in San Francisco. We always come back here. I love the bean cake balls, the puffed shrimp is heaven. All the food is good. My favorite go to place. Love the service.
author: Swan's N.

description: Great traditional dim sum.  Huge selection to choose from.  Location was a little odd at first but the seating out in front that sits in the common space would be very relaxing i imagine.  Service was also very good and prompt.  We'll be back next time we're in SF for sure.
author: Paul S.

description:
Delicious place. A little on the pricey side BUT service, location and food - were on point. Very popular spot, so make a reservation, especially if you're planning to go on a weekend.
Will definitely go back here when I return to SF.
author: Diego R.

description: Best dim sum I've ever had! Top quality food and very fast service. My favorite dim sum there is the steamed BBQ pork bun. Incredible.
author: Annie B.

description: Not the place I remembered!i I have been here many times over the years and was disappointed this time. The quality and variety is not the same as in previous visits. While still good not the five stars it use to be.  In fairness to them we did go in the early afternoon and they no longer had some items like Peiking duck. There prices are still high.  We will give it another shot next time
author: Ira B.

description:
The price is an unbelievable rip off. I have had dim sum all over and didn't expect the price that arrived to my table. Then thinking back on the quality, I was even more upset cause I've had better in sf and much cheaper. 

The workers completely would miss our table and would constantly need to be flagged out. The manager on the floor who was helping us kept laughing and kept trying to upcharge. 

This sucked and for less than 10 items the bill was over 200 dollars. 

Yank Sing should be Yank Suck.
author: Nats S.

description:
Yank Sing is so unremarkable to me. It's overpriced ($100 for 3 people), and there is very little variety in what you can order. I did really enjoy the soup dumplings--so much so that we sprang for two orders--but overall, I found it to be mediocre dim sum with a selection that was carefully tailored to suit a Western appetite. 

That being said, eating at Yank Sing is way more glamorous than eating takeout dim sum with a plastic fork in the middle of Chinatown (though I will argue the food is better), so if you need a conveniently located dim sum spot for a "real" meal, Yank Sing might be your best bet.
author: Kelly R.

description: My only qualm with Yank Sing is that it's a bit overpriced. Other than that though, I really do enjoy coming here. They've got all the staples of dim sum in addition to some more interesting offerings like scallop shumai and sea bass which is awesome but, of course, pricey. You can honestly find the same quality dim sum but at much more reasonable prices elsewhere in San Francisco (see Lai Hong Lounge), but at Yank Sing, you get a bit more of an upscale feel in addition to the ability to make reservations.
author: Charles L.

description:
Beyond delicious-

Yank Sing was recommended to me by a friend back in Boston and I can see why! It was my first dim sum experience and it set the bar extremely high. Although it was a little pricey for lunch, when we went ($100 for 4 people) we all agreed it was worth it. 

When the servers didn't bring over any vegetarian options, my sister was able to ask for something off a menu and it came within minutes. And after that people with vegetarian plates stopped at our table.

The staff is very attentive and friendly. Be sure to stop here if you're in the financial district!
author: Amanda D.

description:
This is my FAVORITE dim sum spot in the bay area. Yes, it's pricey, but I love the food and quality, so it's worth it to me. Make sure you book reservations via Yelp/call them direct/Opentable!! I LOVE that you can do that here since most dim sum restaurants do not take reservations at all. :) I've been here for many weddings and the food was good, too.

PROS:
-Delicious, tasty, and good quality dim sum
-Clean
-Great location. You can walk off your dim sum to the Ferry Building to get dessert. 
-You can easily make reservations online!! Love that.
-The dim sum carts come around fast so you get quick service.
-Hostesses are friendly and nice.
-Someone comes around to ask if you would like to also order take-out, which I did. 
-Delicious custard buns!

CONS:
-LONG WAIT if you don't make reservations. 
-Parking can be a challenge, but what do you expect in San Francisco? I always luck out & find street parking.
-It is pricey dim sum BUT, you get what you pay for. Worth it here.
author: Jennifer J.

description: The food was 5 Star, however, they really, really push the items on you way too fast. Hard to enjoy the meal and conversation with all the interruptions. Maybe a red/green disk like at Brazilian BBQ's would help. I will say though that his was by far the very best Dim Sum ever. Each item had it's own distinctive flavor and textures. So many other Dim Sum houses are muddled and just reputations on the same theme. These folks are masters at flavor profiles and extracting as much as possible in each bite.
author: Kevin M.

description:
Outstanding Chinese Dim Sum, located in the Rimcon building.  Authentic Chinese cuisine in the Financial District of San Francisco.  Order the Phoenix Shanghai dumplings (XLB).  The staff here provides some of the best Dim Sum service.  If you request something not available on your cart, they will call in your order using their radios.
This is the only place that provides choice of freshly made gourmet teas!
author: Richard H.

description: Amazing dim sum! Worth the wait. A little pricey but worth it. Everyone in our group loved it
author: Alex C.

description: Arrived around 1:00pm for dim sum. Party of 3 (including 1 baby in a stroller). Restaurant was busy, but we were seated immediately. The moment we settled in our seats the first of 8 dim sum carts that stopped at our table arrived. Food was very good. Overall satisfied with experience there. Staff was courteous and attentive. Food is very over priced, but expected considering it's in FiDi.
author: Jordan V.

description: Really good dim sum I love everything I got to try except the chicken mushroom dumpling. I try steamed BBQ pork bun, pork potsticker,pork and shrimp siu Mye, chicken spring roll, Szechuan chicken, shanghai kurobuta pork dumpling etc. really good service very friendly.very clean fast service.
author: Jazzy L.

description:
Came in for a brunch dimsum. The food as always is four stars. However all other things such as service, and price is all three stars and below are the reasons why. 

We were sat at a corner table where a lot of carts didn't come to for nearly 15mins. We just sat there waiting for  someone to pass us by. We finally told our waitress who sent one cart our way. It was also little hard to get someone to get our waters refilled. In general it is a little hard to get the workers attention. We wanted more lotus leaf but after notifying our waitress and still no lotus leaf after 10-15mins we asked for the bill.  I guess if you have two hours to leisurely dine in, this won't be a problem. 

As for the price, this is not your typical Chinese cheap dimsum place. There were two of us and the total was $70. This place is pricier than Din Tai Fung so be careful how many plates you order off the cart. You can lose track and it is a little hard to keep track since you choose from a cart that doesn't have a price tag on them. 

If expensive price tag and time is not a issue for you, this might be a five star restaurant for you. As for me who have a budget and places to be I just simply cannot afford to dine in for two hours.
author: Julia HR L.

description:
Expensive, mediocre (but not too bad...) compare to other dim sum places in the south bay. 
I guess that's SF (and in SOMA?) to you :P
They do have plenty of dim sum selection, but all in all this is one of the most expensive dim sum place I ever been? With a group we still ended up with $20+ each person. The lack of competition and location probably contribute to this.
author: Ya K.

description:
The 6 for 14$ Shanghai dumplings were good but that's the only thing that's good.

Service were horrible. Prices were horrible.

I came here with my boyfriend and the wait was maybe about 25 minutes. It was enough time for us to move our car 6 long blocks away from a meter and into the parking lot where Yank Sing validates.

We sit and begin to look at the menu. I wondered why we didn't get anything to drink so I asked for tea. We begin to order. My BF asks "is there any lobster claws" and the girl said "sorry can you speak English, I don't know Chinese." I'm not sure what made her hear Chinese because he isn't even Chinese nor does he look like he is. Anyways, she proceeded to dump different things onto our table such as the shrimp dumpling and other things. I tell her "no no, we don't want those, my BF is allergic to shrimp." Is this how you sell the dim sum on your cart, by dumping it onto our table without us saying we want it? I thought it was extremely rude.

Another lady passes by and we order Shanghai dumplings, shrimp/ cream cheese wonton, and two other dishes. Wonton was mediocre but the Shanghai dumplings were good. The two other stuff never came after a long period of time so we just decided to get the check and eat somewhere else.

The tea was $2 per person and validation was $4. The total for two things, tea, and validation came out to be about $37. We left hungry and lost our hope in this place. Outrageous prices for shitty service, never again.
author: Julian Y.

description:
I braced myself for an expensive meal after reading several reviews on here. I still experienced sticker shock.

Service was fast but my food all felt luke-warm rather than steaming hot off the cart. Something I was willing to overlook. When I went to order, I asked if tea was included or an additional charge. My server said there would be no charge. I was charged. When I asked another server who took my bill and explained what happened, he did not resolve it by taking the charge off. He just said I was misinformed and walked away.

The 6 pieces of xiao long baos came out to $14. Are you serious? I am from the land of Din Tai Fung (DTF, baby!) in Arcadia, this is BS. I also ordered an order of shrimp noodle roll for $9. The dishes weren't bad, but I don't understand the rave reviews. I must be jaded from growing up in San Gabriel Valley.

Uh...how did my meager lunch of 2 dim sum plates and tea run me over $30?
author: Elizabeth T.

description: We went here while on a trip to Napa valley and loved it.  We highly suggest making a reservation as this place seemed to be very popular.  We came here for dim sum so the waiters are constantly going around with different trays and you can take what you like.  The price of a meal can go up very quickly this way.  We enjoyed everything we tried.  The only annoying thing is that your meal is constantly interrupted as the waiters ask if you want anything from their tray.  The restaurant was located inside of a mall.
author: Rachel G.

description:
Decent service. You can make a reservation. Food is tasty. Parking is free. It is a little pricey.
2 to 3 times more than average dim sum restaurants.
author: R M.

description:
Easy to get to Dim Sum!

If you have not tried Dim Sum before, or if you are visiting San Francisco, craving Dim Sum but are not comfortable venturing into Chinatown, Yang Sing is the place for you! I live near Chinatown, so let me disclose that you may find better and cheaper Dim Sum there, but most of those places are not easy to find. Yang Sing is easy to get to and the setting is more westernized if you will. The service is just fine, but a word of warning, do not be intimidated by the frequent visits to your table by mostly ladies who will ask you if you want this or that item. Start with two or three familiar items and then work yourself through until you get your fill :-)
author: Afshin A.

description:
Excellent but quite expensive dim sum in a very large restaurant in an open space.  We went there with two friends and greatly enjoyed the food.  We were a little shocked when the bill came.  It being lunch, we didn't drink alcohol, and we weren't pigs, but the the bill was well over $200.  Deducting one star for the expense, otherwise it would be a five star restaurant.

As we were finishing up, servers kept trying to offer us more dishes when it was obvious that we no longer eating.
author: SandS B.

description: Mmmmmm honey baked sea bass. Soup dumplings. Shredded purple cabbage jicama walnut salad. The pot stickers are also really good but wish they had half portions. Pea shoot dumplings are meh. Hustle and bustle of the place is fun.
author: Penelope S.

description:
3rd time here today but I'm just really not a fan of this place.  Dim sum should be cheap! I personally don't eat a lot so I'd rather go to Hakkasan and have better quality food.  

Everything is just okay here as this is probably more for white People and tourists. If you want dim sum, there are places that serve the same kind of quality stuff for cheaper. Hong Kong on Geary lounge is probably as good as this place and cheaper.
author: C M.

description: Being a New Yorker, I am very spoiled when it comes to Chinese food and dim sum. Although a bit pricey, the dim sum offerings here are excellent and the ambiance is very nice. We had scrumptious dumplings, shumai, har gow, pork buns, shrimp noodles, fried prawns, spring rolls,etc. Truly delicious!!!
author: Laura B.

description: OMG visiting friends in San Francisco and the told us about this great Dim Sum restaurant. This was a fantastic restaurant, I would highly recommend it!
author: John W.

description: I ordered from them and it was certainly a five star. I went to eat in and my experience was not that great. I've had better dim sum in Oakland and I wasn't very impressed with the quality. Staff barely looked at me, as I was alone. They served me half orders which was fine but charged me for full orders. I won't be eating there again but I might order for delivery. Very expensive, as my bill was over $50. Ridiculous for some rice, 2 half orders and one shrimp noodle.
author: Ola P.

description:
I used to love this place. My last experience however makes me not want to return. Despite having a reservation we still had to wait for thirty minutes to be seated. The dim sum was over cooked and soggy with crunchy bits in the pork dumplings. The waiter forgot our drink order and had to be reminded after waiting another twenty minutes.

When the bill comes to $130 for an average order for two people with this kind of food and service it's a deal breaker.
author: Dana F.

description:
We have visited this place twice on weekends so far and both times ate so much that we rolled out of the restaurant. There was only a short queue both times as the place is quite large and they also expand into the atrium area when it gets crazy crowded. 

Food is served via push-carts that make their rounds in the restaurant. Be prepared for the less popular carts to visit often due to the lower take-up rate. Decent: xiao long bao, har-gow, siu mai, pork spare-ribs, lotus leaf rice, rice noodle rolls with shrimp (although it is $9.45). Do note that porridge is only served on weekends. 

Tea ($2 per person) is served in a huge glass pot. I find that I often have to ask for hot water refills in other restaurants but the one huge pot here will suffice for 2 people for one long meal. 

There is validated parking for 3 hours on weekends so be sure to take up that offer instead of parking on the street (not easy making the rounds to find street parking anyway due to the heavy traffic). Knocked off a star as it is sadly on the pricier end of the scale. Paid $90 plus tip for a lunch here for two recently.
author: Lindt C.

description: Such a special treat! The dim sum was delicious and the service was very good. We sat outside the main restaurant in the atrium and really enjoyed the ambience. We will definitely be back!
author: Christina S.

description: This has been the best dim sum in the city since I can remember. The dumpling wrappers aren't chewy and thick so the flavors really come through in a clean, delightful way that isn't heavy. And their house chili oil is the best I've ever had.
author: Aviva Y.

description: First experience here, and it was perfect. Seating was easy (come when it opens), location convenient, service was wonderful, food was delicious! Yes it's higher priced, but the quality of the food showed why. Recommend to anyone visiting or a local.
author: Crystal G.

description: One of the best dim sum place I have eaten in a very long time. But be prepared it is pricey
author: Cyn L.

description: What!!!???  You haven't been here? Don't go, I want them all to myself. Cart to go please
author: Steve S.

description:
Yum, yum give me some dim sum. Get there by 11am, park in the garage nearby. They validate. They serve a yummy tea. My bestie and I ordered tons of dishes. I only wish I snagged an egg tart on the way out. The staff were fast and efficient.

What we got: shui mai, pork buns, dumplings, to name a few. The food was plentiful. The place was busy.

Oh and that tea, I'll be thinking about that tea for a while. Go to Yank Sing if you're craving dim sum. It's a little bit on the pricier side but totally worth it.
author: Amy J.

description:
The service that Yank Sing manager, Michelle provided for our private party with reservations was above and beyond expectations, as she's both gracious and accommodating all while being very friendly and welcoming.

The food here is good, and the Shanghai Dumplings (Siu Lim Bao) are excellent, rivaling that of Din Tai Fung. 

Most of the Dim Sum here is priced a bit higher than your mom/pop Dim Sum To-Go or hole in the wall eateries, but this is in a high rent area and has an upper class feel to the aesthetics as well as the service levels which are also up a notch from the norm.  I think the prices are at least 2x more than what you'd pay elsewhere, but when you go to Yank Sing, in part you're going for the experience too. 

I have no complaints about the food quality nor quantity and all prices are disclaimed, disclosed on the menus, so nothing should catch a customer by surprise at all. 

Dim Sum will cost about $20 per person for light eating and maybe upwards towards $40 (or more) per person if you are liberal with how you order and gorge yourself a bit more with less restraint, so in all reality, not that much more than going to a Mexican Tapas or Japanese Sushi place on a per plate cost basis. 

I'd recommend Yank Sing as an elegant and nice place to have a meal. 

Parking is $4 for the Validation that gives 2 hours, otherwise I think it's $6 per 30 mins, so if you park, don't forget to get validated (and validated does not mean FREE, and they'll charge you there at Yank Sing for the validation, then you turn your ticket in at the garage for no additional fees and get to go on your way.  The parking on the weekdays is valet parking.  On the weekends, I believe it's a free validation, but you can check their website to make sure.
author: Rick S.

description:
My party of three came here on a Sunday during a short weekend in town. It is close to Park Central hotel, so we walked over around 1 pm. The place seemed pretty busy, but we were sat within ten minutes of waiting. As soon as out butts landed on our seats, the cart ladies immediately began pushing dim sum on us, as they do. Still, we were surprised that they didn't even ask us for drinks or anything first. 

Food was good, and great by Atlantan standards, since dim sum is seriously lacking in Atlanta. We tried the soup dumplings, pork bao, several dumplings, and several other dishes I can't recall. We ate it all! 

That said, the quality of the food was just not enough to overcome the fact that we had to wait ten minutes to get our check and then even longer for them to bring our card back. We watched as our check holder sat by the credit card machine, neglected by the many staff bustling past. Apparently only one person is able to run the credit cards here, which added to our wait time. I was quite baffled by this and it definitely ended things on a sour note.
author: Jung-In S.

description: This is one of the places I miss about SF. Lived here for many years and YS is still a "go to" every time I visit. Good quality ingredients, well balanced flavors and great selections.
author: Susan Y.

description:
Probably the tastiest individual dimsum plates that i have tasted. 

Downsides were they ran out of good stuffs pretty early (chicken feet, chiken butts, peking duck)

And I was seated outside, which had less dimsum carts, even though the view was great outside. 

We tried the chilli chicken, shrimp dumplings, pork dumplings, xiao long bao, chashu bao, spareribs in black bean sauce, soy sauce spareribs, salmon, egg tarts, etc. and every single dish was so good. 

The egg tart was so good that it was as good as 85 degree bakery egg tart.

They had the mustard which was quite rare for a dim sum place. Plus, they have multiple kinds of tea, which was also great.

Super expensive though. $250 for 3 people. Well I was treated so... no big deal.


TIPS: THey validate your parking ticket if you park in the Ringcon center garage.
author: Tung D.

description: Two separate locals recommended this place to us during our one week stay in SF.  Getting a reservation at a decent time was impossible so we booked one from the web  site for 2:45.  We arrived on time an were rudely rushed to finish our meal within 30 mins.  Why take a reservation if you have no intention to service diners properly?  Bottom line is the food is ok but over priced and the service we received was as bad as I have ever experienced.
author: Scott B.

description: Best dimsums in town. They have a lot of vegetarian options also- savory, spinach, mushrooms, and snappeas to name a few. They also have veggie noodles. Don't forget to try the egg custards. Super delicious. Service ja quick, with each cart coming your way, you just pick what you want. For drinks, try the jasmine tea. A very healthy brunch/lunch place for family. Outdoor seating is preferred when dining with a toddler/infant. The inside seating can get a little warm and congested for the babies.
author: Anisha Y.

description:
Great spot for lunch.  I'm a huge dim sum fan and Yank Sing did not disappoint.  Even though I am a huge fan, I remain completely clueless when it comes to ordering, but the dim sum process is set up to keep me clueless.  For instance, Yank Sing sat us promptly.  A waiter came by quickly and briefly and equipped us with tea and waters.  Then, he was gone.  I think he brought the bill, but I am not really sure it was the same guy. 

The ordering process involves a bunch of wait staff hauling around carts and just asking if you want some of what they are pushing.  This is pretty typical of dim sum.  I continue to order whatever looks good and whenever I hear the word pork.  Sure enough, it resulted in a successful lunch for me and Shari V.  We enjoyed the dumplings, pot stickers, fried shrimp and steamed pork buns.  The disconnect is between what is on my table and what is on the menu.  I'm not sure what's what.  Who cares frankly.  It's tastes awesome.

The process is pretty fast, but can be a little frustrating.  Occasionally, I would see a waiter with something I wanted, but this waiter would be halfway across the restaurant.  Because I have no idea of what I'm looking at and the language barrier between myself and the staff, I didn't have a good way of procuring this delicacy.  In the end, my patience prevailed and by just waiting 5 minutes, that very same dish would appear before me.  Then, I'd order it greedily and wolf it down.  This was the case with some steamed pork buns.  

In short, we had an excellent meal at Yank Sing.  Aside from being a fish out of water, the lunch went off without a hitch.  I'd go back for seconds anytime.
author: Chris B.

description: I have been coming here for years.  I've never been disappointed.  The food is fun, flavorful and abundant. The service is great and you walk away feeling happy about such a great experience.  It is pricey, be warned, a lunch for 2 can run way over $100.  But worth it in my opinion.  I love the spicy green beans, the dumplings, the pork buns - oh heck, why pretend?  I love it all!!!
author: Celeste R.

description: The place was nice. Very busy. Too hyped in my opinion. Way too pricey. I would pick Din Tai Fung over this place anytime!
author: Astrid R.

description:
We went for Saturday dim sum and were underwhelmed. 
The prices are not in proportion to their serving size or quality. 
Xiaolongbao is one of my favorite Dim Sum dishes,and these fell completely short fo standard. The amount of meat was sparse at best. I thought the broth was flavorful, but without the meat.. what is going on?

Everything else was mediocre and for the price, way small portions. That said you can certainly get worse in the city. 

The service gets an added star because they were very attentive.
author: Greg F.

description: Awesome location in the mall with tons of space and carts that roll around. The food was fantastic but so are many places in Chinatown and around the Bay Area, for much less. Great place when you want to splurge a lot on dim sum. However I don't know why you would want to.
author: Ke D.

description:
News Flash: San Francisco is an expensive place to eat.  Seems like a lot of reviewers have forgotten that.  New Flash 2: Downtown rents are higher than the avenues.  I'm sure there's a good reason, like location, but ok.

Yank Sing has the best Dim Sum in San Francisco that I've had.  The places in the avenues mentioned by others are pale comparisons lacking the quality, freshness, and disciplined seasoning that can be found in the best Dim Sum places in Hong Kong (where I've travelled extensively).  I don't understand how this is Americanized when it more closely resembles the fare you'd find in Hong Kong than the greasy messes found in the avenues.  

Keep in mind, you get what you pay for though.  Yank Sing is not a candidate for cheap eats, but it's one of the few places in the Bay Area (and only one in SF that I've found) that is on par with the great Dim Sum found in Hong Kong.
author: Nathan R.

description: Two days in a row- always a mandatory stop in SF since my first experience on ? Clay Street.  Terrific front desk and serving staff. Always gracious no matter how busy.  Never get tired of the favorites - shrimp dumplings and crab claw, but everything I've had is wonderful at Yank Sing.  Fresh, hot when expected, and flavorful.
author: David B.

description:
I'm a dumpling first-timer!

Not the first time that I've ever had a dumpling, but the first time that I've visited a legit dumpling restaurant that walks around with freshly made dumplings, appetizers, and small plates. 

We made a lunch reservation before heading over to ensure we would not have to wait. The service is excellent. There's consistently servers asking you if you'd like to try "this" or "that." It's a little dangerous because you want to say yes to everything, but like others have mentioned it's very expensive. I came here with my girlfriend for lunch and we had 4, maybe 5 plates and it ran us $50. 

The best thing we tried here was the soup dumplings. We were seriously stumped on how they were able to make them (dur, I googled it later that night.). They are perfectly packaged presents with a hot soup surprise center. Everything about it was a palate symphony.
author: Jade R.

description:
I've been going to Yank Sing as our slightly fancier dim sum go to for 20+ years, but had a terrible experience here this past Sunday. Nothing over the top, just enough of a crap experience that I won't be going to Yank Sing again. It was my grandmother's 86th birthday lunch (just her, my mom and I), and when you don't have a good time at a celebration it always stings a little more. We sat in the courtyard because she loves the fountain out there. 

2 main issues - 
1) absurdly long delays and sub-par variety on the food, at one point we'd had about 7-8 dishes and were winding down, but wanted a few more, and there was a THIRTY MINUTE wait until more carts finally came around, which is absolutely absurd for dim sum. When a cart finally came, the family across from us pointed at us and said "I think they're hungry too" because they'd seen us longingly looking around the whole time (as they did the same). Additionally, when I went inside to look for the bathroom I saw about twice as much variety and HOT, FRESH dishes, which we simply did not see in the 1.5 hrs we were there. Why not send some carts straight from the kitchen to the courtyard?!
