2)**They overcharged us by about 25%.** When we got the check they saw us looking at it quizzically and asked if there was anything wrong we said it just seemed there were too many expensive items on it (we'd glanced at the prices on the menu throughout the meal), they claimed we'd ordered two soup dumplings (which were $14), we explained we hadn't we'd ordered 2 shrimp dumplings (which were $6.5). They adjusted the bill for that mistake, but at that point I was curious, b/c something was clearly awry, so I wrote down everything we'd ordered and the price, and the subtotal came to $97, our first check the subtotal was $120, and the 2nd it was $114, so in either scenario we were pretty significantly overcharged. i didn't argue the price at this point, because I didn't want to waylay my grandmother any longer (she'd been ready to go since half way through the cart drought), and bring down the mood further, and still tipped 15% (below what I'd tip for good service of course, but I'm not going to be an ass about it). Anyway the whole thing just rubbed me completely the wrong way, I'm not going to have fun at dim sum if I think they're being dishonest and trying to con their customers, and that's the feeling I left Yank Sing with, this weekend. Hopefully Ton Kiang will never get up to the same shenanigans!
author: K B.

description: The only good thing about this place is how quickly you get seated. Service is absolutely horrible, you literally have to flag down the servers in order for them to notice you. Food is pricey for how mediocre it is.
author: Christi C.

description: This was my first time here after searching online for a great dim sum place to try in the city. Establishment was very large and the place was busy, busy, busy! This place is historic and everything tasted great. Authentic cultural experience. Service is quick and courteous. Would definitely recommend.
author: Tati W.

description: I've been eating here since before they moved to Spear street, so pretty much 100 years. The food is consistently excellent,  the service is what I expect from a large, busy but casual restaurant, prompt and polite. There's often a long wait for a table at peak hours, so come early or late  (or take a pager and wander until your table is ready). Particularly yummy are the steamed pork buns and the Shanghai soup dumplings.
author: Pamela M.

description: Amazing dim sum. So good, only place I will go for dim sum in SF. The pekking duck is a MUST.
author: Raychel J.

description: I love Yank Sing and I eat here every opportunity I can. I often take friends from out of town and they love it too.i have never been disappointed with the quality and service from this establishment. Highly recommend this restaurant for any occasion.
author: Philip V.

description: Over priced bad dim sum. Stay away! Paid 50$ for 4 dim sum dishes, all of them ranged from poor to bland. Service was also bad
author: Adelle G.

description: Best Dim Sum ever. Upscale decor, great prices and friendly service. If you like Dim Sum, this is the place.
author: Raymond G.

description:
In a moment of cultural confusion, someone recommended this as a good Chinese restaurant. When I say "Chinese" I mean "dishes," otherwise I specify noodles or dim sum, etc. so we were a little confused when we got here and saw no menu for dishes.
We sat down all the same because it had been a long time since we had eaten dim sum. The wait staff were fairly kind and the jasmine tea was actually quite good, but the food doesn't live up to the price tag, especially after eating a far more filling dishes meal for less than half the price with substantially more food just a few miles away later that day! 
The soup dumplings were probably the best item, but they were also the most expensive of what we ordered. The rest were all standard fare.
author: Charles G.

description:
Service: 4 stars
Food: 3 stars
Value for the money: 1 star

As usual, this place was packed and there was a long wait.  Fortunately, we had reservations and didn't have to wait that long (about 15 minutes).

In a nut shell, their dim sum is good.  They have a much smaller selection than other large dim sum houses such as Koi Palace in Daly City and Saigon in Sunnyvale.  We thought their chicken feet was extra good (slightly spicy) and they excelled at any noodle.  For example, their shrimp noodle (Ha Cheng) had a very thin noodle, large shrimp and sweet sauce.  The shrimp dumpling (Ha Gow) was firmly wrapped and the wrap was thick enough to not fall apart like a lot of places but thin enough such that it didn't taste doughy.  What we did notice though is that the filling for the Ha Gow our Sui Mai wasn't that flavorful.  So some of their dishes are a bit above other dim sum houses and many others are on par or slightly below.

Their service is good.  They are very busy so don't expect much attention but when you do get their attention, the servers are courteous and will get you what you want without displaying the attitude that other Chinese places give.

The prices are outrageous though.  $6.80 for 4 Sui Mai.  Most of their dishes average $6.80.  We didn't order tons of food and our check came out to be $116 for two people (with nothing left over).  Parking is expensive if you go on the week day.  They give you a discount on the rate but we still ended up paying $16 for 3 hours (after their discount).  Apparently the parking (with validation) is free on the weekend but good luck with the crowds.

I don't see myself coming back anytime soon.  For that amount of money, I rather go to Saigon in Sunnyvale which averages $50 for the same dishes we got and tastes just as good but without the great service.  If service is important to you then Yank Sing shouldn't disappoint.  If you haven't tried Koi Palace, I think the service is comparable with free parking and much better variety of dim sum.  If service is not that important, go to Saigon in Sunnyvale or try some other places in the city.
author: Lily L.

description:
After 12 years, we finally returned to this amazing spot!!! Yelp and most of the Internet didn't exist the last time we were here and I'm glad to be able to give it a 5 star review. This place has it all.. Amazing dim sum, great service, and a nice, clean atmosphere. It simply does not get better than this!
Have the cod if they have it and step outside your comfort zone. We did and we learned about some new favorite dishes! YUM!!!
author: Felix J.

description: Over-priced for what it is. Food was mediocre & walk-ins are low priority. This was an expensive tourist trap. Beware!!!
author: Athena C.

description:
This review is two part, since they have a traditional eat-in dim sum establishment and also a quick to-go area.

The restaurant:
I've been there a couple of times, but only when on expense or if someone else is paying. This place has decent quality dim sum, but expect to spend easily $30+ per person at lunch. 

Knowing that dim sum lunches shoul be $15-$20 max, their slight quality increase does not jive well with my wallet. 

The take-out:
Fast and efficient. Not cheap, not crazy expensive ($12 ish). You get a good variety, but the base of your combos will almost always be noodles, so be ready to carb up.  

There was one time that I noticed some metal pieces in my dumpling.  When I complained, they quickly took it back and gave me a new order. I probably should have taken a photo or something. Anyway, I still eat there, since what doesn't kill you only makes you stronger right?
author: Cindy C.

description: Things have changed for this restaurant. The food is terrible. It is not dim sum. This is all factory made and reheated. Expensive as hell. If you're looking for dim sum in the city. Go to Dragon Beaux. TAKE IT FROM SOMEONE FROM HK IF IT MEANS ANYTHING TO YOU.
author: Iohc C.

description: My all time favorite restaurant in San Francisco!! Food is incredible!! The staff is so friendly! We brought our 1 year old daughter in this morning for the first time in 6 or 7 months. She loved the food! While we were eating multiple waitresses kept coming over and waving and smiling at her! When we were done a waitress brought over jello and chocolate for her for being so good!! She loved it!! Every time we come into the city Yank Sing is a must!!
author: Trisha H.

description:
Find somewhere else.  Low quality and expensive. 
As a visitor, I found this place on a time out review as number 1 Dim sum in SFO. I've eaten at the best in Australia, Canada and mainland China. This place doesn't come close. The dishes arrived fast and efficiently but many arrived Luke warm. Many were over cooked. The egg tarts felt like a cheap suburban restaurant. So disappointed as this was my only Chinese meal in this famous food city.
author: Paul O.

description: It's official, my 15 year love affair with this place is over. Over the past few times I've eaten here it has been consistently off. The one major problem is that the dim sum options seem to have decreased significantly. It's the same items over and over. The frequency with which carts come by has also slowed. The quality of the food has gone down hill too. The prices however, remain high. Every relationship has to end sometime. I'll miss you Yang Sing.
author: Katenryan B.

description:
I'm from Boston and I'm use to ordering whatever at dim sum, and paying average $20pp. If this is your price range, you better check yourself, and be very selective with your orders unless you're ballin out of control. $12 for 4 egg tarts, $22 for a small piece of fish, $7 for 1 piece of cold subpar peking duck and a white bun. I'll admit the egg tarts were awesome, but everything else ($7 average) taste pretty much how I expect them to.

If you don't mind the price, the food was fine, tea was good, service was also good, the cart ladies were attentive as were the waiters/floaters.

Will I recommend it? No
Will I go back? Hell no
author: Andy L.

description:
The price they charge for tiny dim sum is pretty outrageous. We spent over $100 between 4 people and were still so hungry after eating everything. Worst of all, the food didn't even taste that great. It was pretty much a botched attempt to try making dim sum fancy. 

Since we ordered take out, I can't speak to the service. However, I would definitely recommend avoiding if you can. There are so many better dim sum options in the city!
author: Sophia H.

description: I've eaten a LOT of good dimsum in my life and this is hands down the best dimsum in San Francisco. My ultra snobby Chinese foodie father concurs.
author: Andrea O.

description: Every visit to San Francisco must include a visit to Yang Sing! I've lived in Hong Kong, been to Shanghai and this place has the best best dumplings! Freshly made and steamed/cooked to perfection our favorites are the Shanghai dumplings (Xiao Long Bao) and their coconut cream rolls for dessert (okay okay not authentic but really good). You will be seated amongst carts roaming the tables delivering all sorts of savories and sweets - you just pick what you want from the cart. If you ask any of the cart ladies for something specific they will drop everything and order it for you. Carts full of duck with fresh baked rolls, fresh steamed veggies (love the string beans), various dumplings and fish roam the place. With each order you receive you get a stamp on your check. At the end of your meal they will count up the stamps and you pay the total. This is not a cheap place so be aware. You can easily eat $70 worth of dumplings between two adults but it is cheaper than flying to Asia!
author: K J.

description:
My favorite dim sum in the city, if not in the entire Bay Area. 

Yank Sing is spotless and service is more than optimal. Servers at dim sum restaurants can sometimes be pushy and borderline aggressive, but the staff at Yank Sing is friendly, informative and definitely not pushy...all while still maintaining the hustle and bustle that is the dim sum culture. 

After going to Yank Sing, it's very hard for any other dim sum restaurant to compare. My absolute favorite dish is the purple cabbage and walnut salad. If I could, I'd get this every single day.
author: Mandy A.

description:
First off, this place is WAY TOO overpriced. 

I'm not from the area, but my Aunt took us out for lunch and she picked the place to get dim sum. Don't get me wrong, it was a great experience, but really, the food just costs WAY TOO MUCH! On top of that, there were so many dim sum items that were not available because they were not cooked yet - like their chicken feet. And by the time we were done eating, it still was not cooked. 

They have a restroom located on the lower level, with only one stall, and it's difficult to get into if there is a long line of women waiting for the restroom. The men's restroom is passed the women's, so the women would have to wait their turn in the staircase (I understand it's in SF, but it's just a little inconvenient) They do have an elevator to accommodate those who are unable to make it down the steps, but it just makes it a little difficult if you're stuck in that situation. 

It gets pretty noisy in there, which must mean the food's good! So if you're willing to drop the cash, it'll be worth it. Thank God I didn't catch the bill!
author: Hilary B.

description: We have always loved Yank Sing food.  The quality is definitely a cut above the average dim sum placed.  The soup dumplings are one of our favorite as well as the walnut salad.  They do try some interesting sauces and are progressive for a dim sum restaurant.  You guys are amazing.  Thank you!
author: Sasha K.

description:
2.5 STARS

Some things are left better unsaid. 

One of those things are telling people that I like the dim sum at Yank Sing. Like r-e-a-l-l-y like (I can just imagine some of my friends shaking their head at me). It's the only place I will go to for dim sum; well, actually it's the only place I can go to now because of my msg allergies/sensitivities. 

Yank Sing uses quality ingredients, the dim sum is well-constructed, and they do not add that msg crap(*). They also take reservations and they have free validated parking! NO where in SF offers this. No where.

BUT...

You will pay the price. Dim sum for two? $100-$120. Yup, the same amount that would feed a family of 10-12 at other dim sum restaurants. They even have the balls to charge $4 pp for tea. Ridiculous right?

This is why I keep my fondness of Yank Sing on the DL. No doubt I would get a tongue lashing from my parents followed by a lashing from the feather duster. Then again, I think bringing them to Yank Sing for kicks would be fun. My mom would probably try to roll the dim sum cart home thinking the bill was inclusive of it. Oh yes, SHE would!

Before coming to Yank Sing, DO make reservations on opentable.com as it's always packed. I like sitting in their courtyard because it's not as cramped as their inside dining area. (*)Even though Yank Sing doesn't add msg to their food, they do have some dishes prepared with pre-bought sauces (e.g. oyster sauce, hoison sauce, etc) that contain msg. So if you have msg allergies/sensitivities like I do, ask your waiter which dishes contain these sauces.

The menu is a bit Americanized but we were still able to get most of our dim sum fix: http://bit.ly/1uJYMXr.
*XLB: Shanghai Soup Dumplings (6 - $13.60)
*Fung Zhao: Steamed Chicken Feet ($5.35)
*Hai Gow: Steamed Shrimp Dumplings ($6.80)
*Paai Gwaat: Steamed Pork Spareribs ($5.35)
*Sui Mai: Steamed Pork & Shrimp Dumplings ($6.80)
*Wu Gok: Fried Taro Dumpling ($5.35)
*Fried Crab Claws ($13.60)
*Sesame Balls (2 - $5.65)
*Baked Custard Tarts (2 - $5.65)
*Scallop Dumpling (not pictured - $5.65)
*Phoenix Tail Prawns (not pictured - $12.75)

Everything we ordered for the most part was solid. The dumplings were filled with savory seafood and meat yumminess with good pleating technique. Fried items are crunchy and not greasy (Mr. NSS loves their fried items here). My favorite item is their XLB Shanghai Soup Dumplings. It's like a golden sack bursting with hot soupy goodness. I get wet dreams just thinking about their XLB. Best in the city hands down.

So why 2.5 STARS?

Well damn, IF I'm going to spend $120 for dim sum for two, the service better match the caliber of the food. Compared to their Stevenson location, the service SUCKS here (I hope management is reading this): 

(1) We arrived 15 minutes early for our reservations. After waiting in line, we checked in with the rude hostess (Chinese lady in her early forties with a pony tail). She told us we had to come back in 10 minutes to wait in line and check in again! WTF? We waited 5 minutes and checked in with another hostess with no issues.

(2) We got seated at table with this as our lovely view: http://bit.ly/1pbEHVn. With the $$$$ prices that Yank Sing charges, trash and dirty plates should NOT be plain sight in front of customers.

(3) The sesame balls and custard tarts we received were cold (they are usually served warm). We alerted one of the wait staff who then brought it to another waiter's attention and they started arguing with other staff in Cantonese about who should take their break first. Really unprofessional. 

(4) The sesame balls and custard tarts we sent back were re-heated in a toaster oven and sent back to us. If I'm paying 3x the price for this items, I want new ones NOT reheated ones.

(5) The staff in its entirety lack basic customer service skills, professionalism, and attentiveness. I could care less if this happened at S&T, Hong Kong Lounge or Great Eastern but this IS Yank Sing, yo. STEP IT UP!
author: Cherylynn N.

description:
Decent dim sum but would love more choices presented to us. A bit pricey compare to others. Services can definitely be better. We don't expect much with dim sum restaurants as they're usually more interested in just putting dim sum on your table and move on. Our teas and water never got seconds or refilled. 

Restaurant appeared clean and pleasant. Wishing services are better and more varieties were brought to our table other than the safe classics. Nice but not very memorable.

We've been there twice and think we'll try another next time we're in the city.
author: Q N.

description:
Really a nice place. This was our first time eating Dim Sum so we were a little confused at first but quickly got the hang of it.

All the dumpling dishes were fantastic. I am not sure you can not go wrong with any of the dumplings.

It all happens so fast kind of like a Brazillian steak house so be prepared to eat and be served quickly! If you are looking for Dim Sum in this area you wan't go wrong with Yank Sing.

The only thing that could have made it a 5 star is just a quick explanation of what to expect. But its ok we learned on the fly and will be again soon.
author: Johnny P.

description: Loved it. Fast service, fresh food, perfectly prepared dim sum. Amazing Shanghai dumplings. Highly recommend it.
author: Marc N.

description: I'm no dimsum expert, I've been to a few dimsum restauants in SF and a few in Garden Grove/ Westminster area. Each time i've eaten dimsum i've liked everything i've had but at this point in my dimsum expertise, or lack therof, I am unable to differentiate between quality and freshness. I thought Yank Sing was good, I had all the usual; dumplings, shumai, soup dumplings, pork buns, chicken feet and custard buns. Everything tasted good and fresh and I had no complaints. The inside is super nice, not a place you'd expect a dimsum restaurant to be. It's expensive but it's SF so if you've spent anytime eating in SF a reasonalble person would know it's expensive.
author: Nic J.

description: Incredible selection for vegans, vegetarians and carnivores. Service is quick and great for hard to please mixed groups.
author: Analizabeth D.

description: Dynamite place. Fabulous dim sun   Fun atmosphere. Apparently IRS everyone's favorite place based on who I've talked to and heard from. I agree.
author: Marc G.

description: We have been coming here for approximately 20 years, every time I am up in the city. I live in the L.A. area. Usually at least once a year. That's how good it is. Both branches , Stevenson and Spear taste wise are the same. Stevenson is smaller and more intimate. I have been to o lot of Dim Sum places all over the country, still have to find one with a taste level this good. I would like to pick a few dishes that stand out, but I am having great difficulty doing so. OK if I have to, just one..the coconut cream roll. Though my son will swear by the egg custard tarts. The variety is immense, patience is the key. Reservations recommended. So why not 5 stars? One word.. Price. You may get what you pay for but this is a bit over the top.
author: Ifti K.

description:
Really great location for Yank Sing with consistent food and top-notch service.

Went with the kids and after an unfortunate delay with our reservation (virtually everyone - even walk ins - who arrived after we did were seated before us because no larger tables were cleared), Michelle, the assistant manager, helped get us to a table and made sure service was great.

Soup dumplings were amazing as usual as were steamed pork buns and fried dumplings.  They were serving a number of special dishes for Chinese New Year including a really great Szechuan chicken and a couple of amazing desserts (one was tapioca and one had black sesame in it).

The server kept our drinks filled and checked on us regularly and we even got some red envelopes with chocolate coins.

Much prefer the Rincon Center location to the one on Stevenson.  Much bigger and easier to park.

Overall great experience.  Definitely try to have a reservation and let Michelle know if you have any difficulty!!
author: Bob K.

description:
Yank Sing for decades--literally decades--has furnished high-quality dim sum to SF in a pretty posh setting (white tablecloths, deep reds, slight golds and brassy accents--what you'd expect at an upper-end Chinese restaurant with Hong Kong influence and Financial District clients). It's probably not much use to try to describe either the interior nor the approach and ethos of Yank Sing on here, because it has scores of reviews already, legions of opinions. I think what is useful to note is how long Yank Sing has been in business--before dim sum was trendy, not just trendy everywhere but even before it became really trendy in SF--and the depth and scope of their menu. 

You'll find the standard dim sum favorites here: the various dumplings (their Shanghai dumplings aren't to be missed, and most of the seafood ones they do quite well on, too) plus the taro cake, turnip cake, sesame balls, egg custard tarts, and steamed pork buns plus some more esoteric dim sum and seasonal specials. They also have to-go orders which are not ordered per individual dim sum but by set meals (which include certain dim sum). It's a nice touch for those who don't want to dine-in but want the assured quality of Yank Sing. Now, on the issue of quality, overall it's very high but given the sheer volume they do, there can be a lack of attention to detail now and then, but rarely is it ever a real problem. There may be better dim sum in SF, yeah, but for the overall experience Yank Sing probably still has its crown and throne pretty much locked down.
author: Mike W.

description:
Yang Sing has great buzz with a nice atmosphere. It can get a little loud but that's the excitement of having dim sum and sharing a conversation. 

The Pros:
 Excellent service
Great tea pot
Chili sauce is excellent 

The Cons:
Little Pricey
Okay Dim Sum

Great place to take a business client or people for a fast work lunch as there service is fast and it has a great buzz.

Over all you will have fun and it has great people watching.
author: P C.

description: Expensive dim sum (it's SF, so it's expected)...especially when back home in Hawaii, you can get the same, if not better for a fraction of the cost.  However, their xiao long bao is delicious!  So, if you can get cheaper and better dim sum in your corner of the world, do it, but if you can't get decent xiao long bao, then run, don't walk here.
author: Kanilehua K.

description: The food is good, the service was good. The one thing I didn't like is, it seems if you show up towards closing time they run out of certain food, they shouldn't run out, have enough to serve until closing.
author: Cory N.

description: This place was delicious! The Shanghai dumplings just melt in your mouth, and the shrimp dumplings had so much flavor. The pork bao was another amazing dish.
author: John H.

description:
It has been a few years since we visited Yank Sing.  We arrived early for our Open Table reservation, but were seated immediately, albeit a small table.

Food was all delicious, especially the pork buns.

While a bit pricey, it is worth every bite!
author: Elaine P.

description: Beware $$$! If you are craving good quality dim sum with no msg this is your place however it's going to cost you 3x the price. I was skeptical about this place but was convinced to try it since it was a special occasion. We were able to get a reservation online at open table *recommended. We arrived and immediately see tables in the middle of the office building lobby which was very spacious but we were seated inside which was a little stuffy and uncomfortable. I would say service wise they were attentive especially with refills and clearing off the dirty plates. Now the food, we got 6 items and it costs us $70-before tip. This is with no speciality plates such as Peking duck, which was sold out by 1pm. My friend has been here before and stated they gotten a lot more with speciality plates for about $30 more. We got the har gow, shu Mai, BBQ pork buns, shrimp roll, and (crab claws, XLB $14/each) plus the $4 for tea. All of which tasted very good, you can definitely tell it is better quality but not the best I've ever had or life changing. We ordered 4 of the items immediately when we sat down and afterwards we waited an eternity (sipping adleast 8 cups of tea) for some new carts or speciality dishes to arrive, they were circling the same items. We sat next to a table who continue to pass up the same carts as well. Since we ate 4/6 items the first 15 minutes we waited the remaining 45 trying to flag someone down and get some food we wanted. We then pulled a waiter aside to 2 additional dishes that never came so then asked him for the check. We were expecting the bill to be around $50 and shocked about how expensive it was. To make matters worse as we walked we saw all the dishes we wanted being served to the tables in the lobby Smh. Never again.
author: Van N.

description:
*** JBF America's Classic (2009) *** #4 ***

Yank Sing serves Dim Sum on par with that in Chinatown, but in the convenience and upscale setting of the city.  They have both traditional dim sum items on their menu as well as some expanded menu options like xiaolongbao and PEKING DUCK. Yes folks, they have Peking Duck.  Do yourself a favor and save space for it, because I was disappointingly stuffed when the duck rolled by me on the cart.

They use a combination of carts and people carrying food around on trays.  Stand out items were the xiaolongbao and the har-gow (the highest quality shrimp I've ever had at dim sum).  We also tried the stuffed lotus leaf, phoenix shrimp, steamed pork buns, chive dumplings with shrimp, and peppercorn chicken.  All were delicious, used high quality ingredients, and I left quite stuffed.

Tip: There are two Yank Sing locations in the Financial District.  Make sure that you go to the right one, since we first walked to the other location (by typing "Yank Sing" into Google Maps) but they did not have our reservation, tipping us off that we were not in the right place.  They were happy to seat us anyways, but I really wanted to go to the "original" Yank Sing location, so we lost about 20 minutes in the shuffle.

Get there early and you'll have no problem getting a table (at 10:30 am it was only half full but by the time we left an hour later they were already seating people in the overflow area in the courtyard).  Our 10 am reservations were not really necessary, but it's not a bad idea to call ahead just in case.

A lot of people complain about the price, and while it's definitely the most expensive dim sum that I've ever had ($60 for 2, a bit more than double what I'd expect to pay in Chinatown), it's also the nicest ambiance I've ever had it in, and $60 still isn't a lot for 2 people to leave stuffed and happy.  A great way to start the day!
author: Flora H.

description: The most expensive dim sum I have ever had. However, we could not get enough of the xiao long bao. 6 of us went to town on ordering all our favorites. The only other place that had xiao long bao as good as this place is in New York, at Joe's Shanghai. I don't understand why other places can't seem to get it right. The rest of the dim sum was just ok. We had chicken feet, steamed spare ribs, turnip cake, taro gok, shumai, har gou, chicken lettuce wraps, etc.
author: Ann C.

description: Ok, in fairness, it's been ten years since my initial review of Yank Sing, and we've continued to accept their steepening dim sum prices and dine here a few times a year since that time. This weekend's experience has definitely changed our opinion about this restaurant. I'll cut to the chase - one of the orders of shrimp rice noodle roll had a big dead fly inside the to-go container. It was a repulsive sight - see for yourself in the photo. Our appetite disappeared, as has our interest in dining here. We demanded a credit for the dish, and the initial communication with one of their male staff members (apparent manager) to ensure we receive a credit has been very difficult - he doesn't have the strongest command of the English language. We're still awaiting confirmation from the restaurant that we will be credited for this. At a high level, their prices keep going up and their quality has dropped to an all-time low. We will not be eating here again.
author: Cort K.

description: Great dim sum! Parking is hard, and there might be a wait at popular times, but totally worth it. You have to be a bit assertive and ask for things you want but that's totally fine. The bill can add up quickly, so only take things you actually want or at least fully know what's in them so you can try. Would totally recommend it.
author: Gabriel W.

description:
This isn't your average Dimsum spot - it is situated in the financial district, and so the crowd that comes here is different from Dinsum places in Chinatown or Richmond.  The quality of the dimsum is really high quality.  You won't find any fat chunks in your shumai or thick flour on the shrimp dumplings (har gao).  Their Shanghai dumplings are top tier and honestly caught me by surprise!  Keep in mind though that the end cost will be about 25-40% (a party of two will spend about $70 here) more expensive than other popular Dimsum restaurants, such as HongKong Lounge II and parking anywhere in this area will be difficult! 

Overall, top tier Dimsum with prices that reflect it!
author: Mandy B.

description:
This was the best dim sum I have had in the city so far. I liked the atmosphere better than Great Eastern, which does not have carts. I recommend the Peking duck (the buns are not Beijing-style but I loved them anyway), the xiaolong bao, and the stuffed lotus leaves. The only disappointment were the curry crab wontons, which were dry and gritty inside. But one not so good dish out of many delicious ones can be forgiven.

Don't forget to bring your parking garage ticket to have it validated, and don't even try to get in on a a Sunday morning without a reservation. Even with one, we waited for half an hour to be seated. Walk-ins were told it would be a 1.5-2 hour wait, and judging by the crowd I'd say that's a conservative estimate.

We came here for the first time right before Christmas, and I think it's going to be a new holiday tradition for us.
author: Brenda A.

description:
Yank Sing is a staple for dim sum, but their quality on the standard dim sum platters, are below the par and on the pricey side! 

Their Siu Mai, Steamed Pork Dumplings, were flavorless and Steamed Pork Ribs with black bean sauce, was too starchy.  Their Ha Gow, Steamed Shrimp Dumplings, were good, but not great.  I would say the most commendable steamed dish, was their Steamed Egg Rolls.  That doesn't say much, however.  Do use their wasabi mustard and signature hot sauce!  It helps with the lacking flavors for each dish!  Their Steamed BBQ Pork Bun, was mediocre too. 

Do get their signature jello oranges!  It's quite creative and great to be eaten as a sweet tasting to the finishing palate!  (At least that has some sugary taste!). I have never paid for such expensive jello, nonetheless...$6 for 4 pieces.  

Service was of the norm.  It is a spacious dim sum gathering and they validate your parking ticket.

Pass this place for dim sum!  You have been forewarned!
author: Tiffany D.

description: Great dim sum, still not the best option for a vegetarian, but they had a few veggies and excellent sesame balls, yum,
author: Lee F.

description:
This Dim Sum restaurant is high priced dim sum. With high prices there should be high quality products. The restaurant is located in the financial district in SF. They also validate parking for 2 hours if you parked in the garage. 
The three shining dishes for me were the BBQ Pork Buns, crab steamed dumplings, and the Ham Sui Gok. Two very popular items are the haw gao (Shrimp Dumpling) and Sui Mai were very dense. The egg rolls good when hot with the sweet and sour sauce. 
I really enjoyed that they make their own hot chili oil and decided to buy one to take home since it pretty tasty and unique with the black beans. 
As for this place, I would only come for select dishes, but would not be my first pick of a dim sum restaurant. 

This a place that does have great atmosphere and good service.
author: Kim W.

description:
Food 5++  The best dim sum in Bay Area! I usually oder the steam dishes only and everything great!  XLB is so good too
Drink 4  Jasmin Tea is good, nice pot
Ambience 4 Clean. I appreciate that.
Service 4 fast
Price 4 Pricy but worth it more than cheap low quality dim sum
author: Tory T.

description: I dream of Dim Sum and Yank Sing does a wonderful job. We always stop there when we are in SF
author: Natalee G.

description: This place was a referral from one of my clients. Amazing authentic Dim Sum. I loved the shrimp.. can't recall the name of it. I did try the Peking Duck, duck overall isn't my thing, but everyone else really enjoyed it. Next time I find myself in San Francisco I'll definitely be heading back.
author: Erin Elizabeth R.

description: Out-of-this-world Dimsum! I've been to MANY of them in the US and Hong Kong. Nothing can beat Yank Sing (both locations)! The food, service..impeccable! It's the reason they still exist and Michelin Star recipient.
author: Bobby M.

description: Ordinary food  extraordinary price. Shumai taste and look like frozen dim sum from the Asian grocery store.
author: Pam P.

description:
Quality dim sum but SO EXPENSIVE. I'm originally from Hawaii, a place where Dim sum is a staple. So to come to a place that charges so much for dim sum was a little bit shocking. I know it's beautiful and well kept, but I was surprised by how much each plate costs. 

Besides the price, I'd say the food is very good. This restaurant is located in the financial district. It's very clean and they have an indoor area to the restaurant and a more open aired atrium seating area. The wait is long so don't come starving! We got there close to 10:15am and still had to wait about 40 minutes for a seat. 

The food came very quickly though, as to be expected from a dim sum restaurant. I especially enjoyed the fried shrimp and shumai. The egg rolls were okay, but I didn't like that they were filled with a lot of bamboo shoots. It wasn't my preference but they were good. Overall, a nice dining experience but definitely on the more expensive side.
author: Courtney O.

description: Xiao long bao dumplings are to die for here. If you don't know how food melts in your mouth because it's so darn good, xiao long bao dumpling is a must try. My top favorite food in the world after tasting this goodie.
author: Sarah S.

description: This is my GO-TO dim sum place.  Quality has been consistent for the past 10 years.  Line goes pretty fast for take-outs.  Pretty pricey, so I only come here when I have a dim-sum crave.
author: HQ S.

description:
This restaurant caters to predominantly American/non-asian ethnicities. It is nowhere NEAR authentic compared to other dim sum restaurants. The menu is extremely limited and the prices are pretty outrageous. Six Shanghai soup dumplings costed $14. Not even a Shanghai restaurant that caters to soup dumplings specifically would charge such an outrageous price for a plate of six dumplings. Having already eaten at other places for dim sum, this one was the most disappointing. If you're looking for a really authentic Chinese dim sum restaurant, I suggest you to go find somewhere else in the Chinatown area. This place is way too Americanized for my liking. For four dishes, we spent $55 including tip. 

P.S. I later on went to another dim sum restaurant in Chinatown (Powell St.) called Lai Hong Lounge and for about the same price I got like double the food. Will be writing a review on that soon.
author: Emily W.

description:
I've been told that a San Francisco must is Dim Sum.  I've also been told that a Dim Sum must while in San Francisco is Yank Sing.  Thus, I had lunch here on my recent trip to the Bay Area and definitely confirm the former two sentences.  The food here was delicious, plentiful, and flavorful.   Part of the fun of Dim Sum is watching a cart full of delicious food roll-up your way and then pointing and ordering in excitement.  

The must-order here, which the other reviews will confirm, are the Phoenix Shanghai Dumblings. Ohemgeee, these were incredibly delicious - super soft on the outside and when you bit into one, out pours the most flavorful and savory broth you will have ever tasted.  I would cross the entire Great Wall to eat these, they're that good.   The other dishes I tried, Peking duck, and the bao were also incredibly delicious and flavorful - I didn't want to stop eating.   

I've read some reviews that said this joint is a bit pricey, and, perhaps, it's a bit more expensive than most lunch/dinner spots that aren't super fancy.  But it's really not that bad.  I came here for a business lunch, ordered three different 'sets' of food, and the total was $17.  Not bad.  

If you're in for a San Francisco Treat that isn't Rice-a-Roni, Dim Sum at Yank Sing is an excellent and flavorful experience.
author: Joe K.

description: Took my friend here for dim sum and soup dumplings! Loved the soup dumplings but it was pretty pricey for what you're getting. Overall expensive but the place is very clean, great service and nothing like typical Chinese restaurants.
author: J N.

description:
The most overpriced dim sum experience ever, I would never willingly come back again because of this... but I guess the staff need some way to pay for their expensive SF housing. $150 for 4 people on Monday lunchtime.

Beyond the pricetag -

Being able to get the "cart" experience on a weekday afternoon is awesome. We popped the dim sum cherry for half our group. 

Being able to get non-traditional dim sum items is awesome. Their Xiao Long Bao (shanghai dumplings) and their Beijing Kao Ya (duck tacos) are very very good. Not a fan of their chicken pinenut lettuce wraps and their pork buns though.

Being able to get quickly served, waters filled, and never a shortage of staff for ad-hoc requests is awesome. Oh, and they all speak good English. 

Most of their dishes were pretty good, but seemed more fried/flavored/spiced/sugarcoated than what I consider the authentic versions. Weird red sour dipping sauce too. But it got you pretty full pretty fast.

Very limited selections on vegetables (only 1 greens and too stiff) and starch dishes (no noodles or rice). Didn't see any mini-pork ribs or a few other of my favorites, but we were sitting near the edge.

Pace yourselves people! Ordering too much too quickly will hurt your tummy and your wallet.
author: Katy Q.

description:
Great Dim Sum. This is the place. Bring your appetite. Suggestion, get wine menu as soon as possible, as the wait staff asks for beverages as soon as you are seated...then, they don't come back, they start bringing the carts. We had to flag her down.

Enjoy!
author: Reyn J.

description:
YAnk SIng has been famous forever. It has alwys been our "Go To Place" for the Best Dim Sum in the City.
 Our dear friends from Medford, Oregon cannot get close to the Bay Bridge without making the trek to Yank Sing. Yes, it really is that good!
author: Miami S.

description:
Expensive dimsum that gives you the quality that is on par of what you eat in Hong Kong.

I highly recommended their steamed shrimp dumpling, shu mai, steamed chive dumplings, scallop dumplings, turnip cakes, springs rolls.

However, their more expensive items, such as the highly famed soup dumplings, baked sea bass, peking ducks, were such a letdown.  The soup dumplings were very "dry", nothing like the ones you get at dintaifung or other local dumplings places.  Baked seabass is just simply expensive.  Peking ducks, its served cold.  How can it be good? It must be fresh out of the oven and served HOT and sliced immediately to enjoy the melted fat and crisp skin, so don't order it.

Order their stewed chicken feet if you can eat like Chinese, it is very good if you dare!

Reservation is highly recommended for this place.  Expect to pay at least 30 per person.
author: Ken H.

description: SO OVERPRICED!! If you are a dim sum connoisseur, do not come here. I can't believe we dropped $100 for 4 people for barely any food. I expected the food to be amazing, but it was not. Save your money and hit up a Chinatown authentic dim sum place. I am crying over our $50 we had to fork over for our portion. Another insult to injury, I questioned he hostess about our table and she argued with me that I got a text saying it was ready. Not only did she assumed I lied she insulted in Chinese thinking I didn't understand. Little did she know I was fluent and spoke back to her in Chinese. Be careful when you talk crap about your customer!
author: Jen S.

description: Great food. Very busy and noisy. Had my first meal with my late husband at their former Broadway location in 1965. Have eaten hundred of delicious dumplings there in these 52 years.
author: Brenda R.

description: This place is the M&M Times Square shop of dim sum. It's touristic and soulless, everything was extremely overpriced, tasted like it was frozen then microwaved. You want good dim sum better go out of SF to, e.g., Richmond.
author: Norcloud S.

description:
Delicious! They opened at 10am, and we got there at 1015am because we heard you have to get there early, and sure enough they were already pretty busy, but we still got a seat right away, no wait. As soon as we were seated they were all over us, and, seeing as we were starving, we just started taking things that looked good! 
Be mindful that things add up real fast and soon your bill is over $100 easy, but so worth it. Will come back to this place whenever I'm near! My friends also enjoyed this place very much!
author: Brad T.

description: Outstanding food and service -- supreme dim sum - Yes, it's costly, but the quality and superior taste is evident. There are plenty of places to go for inexpensive food - so if you are cost conscious, read about the prices in some fo the reviews before you go. Make a reservation for sure as this place is packed just after opening on a Sunday morning with a line already formed.
author: John P.

description:
I come here for dim sum EVERY SINGLE TIME I am in San Francisco, which is a lot. We also probably go more than once if we are in town for longer than a weekend. 

It's typical dim sum service, with employees who speak minimal English but are friendly and want you to try everything. At any dim sum place don't be afraid to say "no" if you don't want something. They definitely try to show you the same thing over and over seeing if you changed your mind, but just say no and pick what you want. It's delicious!
author: AmyRae S.

description:
Yank sing is the place for dim sum and walnut shrimp and beef noodles (I don't eat pork). But I heard all the pork dishes are delicious too!

If you are having a celebratory dinner, this is the place to do it. Make sure you make a reservation and you're nice to the servers!
author: Ameera D.

description: Place is extremely clean and extremely fancy. For a dim sum restaurant, it is a high class restaurant that is very high priced for good dim sum. I came to this place with 4 other people at 11:30 am on a Saturday and there was about a 20 minute wait. Staff here are friendly and is available when you need.
author: Gabe F.

description: I love this place. I always come here when I'm in SF. Tons of vegetarian and vegan options.but for meat eaters, they love it here too. Service is pretty great for Chinese fast moving restaurant. Good value too
author: Christine H.

description:
Delicious dim sums, expansive variety and great service. That said, Yank Sing is extremely overpriced and there are plenty of dim sum locations in SF that are equally good or better for a lot less. For three people and two beers, we paid $100 + for our casual lunch meal and ordered rather carefully since this was simply a snack before dinner. I'm not surprised by the average rating of 3.5 for this place and don't think I would go back.

Lastly, make sure to check your bill very carefully as they are known to overcharge customers using the stamp system. Keep a track of what you order off the menu and then vet it when the bill comes. Common sense stuff for most places but more so here!
author: Kabir S.

description: I LOVE the whole idea of little carts coming around and getting to pick your food by its description,and by how it looks. This is a great place to go for a quick, but guaranteed good meal. I love how the plates are small, letting you try much more rather than getting a couple huge dishes and not being able to try anything else. I highly recommend getting the purple cabbage salad... amazing. I also really loved the egg rolls and the dumplings! Overall really good place, it's not 5 stars because I didn't like that even though your table was full, they offered you food. Also they were a little slow on getting dirty plates off the table. Over all, thumbs up!!
author: Isabel C.

description:
Amaaaaaaazing food, possibly the best I've had in all of the bay, but since I can't afford to eat here very often I can't give it a full 5 stars. Not sure why it's so darned expensive! They even charge for the tea. If you're planning a meal here, plan to shell out about $40 per person plus tip. If you want alcohol then plan to shell out more. 

All that said, I'll definitely be back since the food and the ambience are seriously amazing :)
author: Ruheene J.

description:
Living in the DC metro area, I have pretty decent Dim Sum selections, but this was better... much better. One of my friends had made a reservation, but we weren't seated until almost 30 minutes after our reservation time. A bit of an inconvenience, but were at ease as soon as we were seated. The carts came quickly and our group of 10 people we went to town. It didn't take long for little plates and steamed items to fill every inch of the rotating tray on our table.

Among the plethora of items we got, my favorites were the Shanghai Soup Dumplings and the Steamed Rice Noodle Rolls filled with Chinese BBQ pork. Those two items rose to the top for me, but everything we ordered was pretty delicious. Even the house chili sauce was awesome! It wasn't packing heat like I'm used to, but it was damn tasty. In fact, it was so good that one of my friends bought a couple jars.

Overall, the service and food were excellent (after we finally got seated). This place makes me want to plan another trip to SF just to try other dim sum places.
author: Zach H.

description:
Check your bills very carefully!!
We were overcharged by $20 twice!!
(They take advantage of the dim sum stamp card system.  
They tried to charge us for 3-4 more di sum dishes than we ordered!) : ( 
I love this place because the food is delicious...but I do not like places that tricks customers!
author: Sunny S.

description: Here is why you screwed up royally today:   You checked us in for our 2:00 reservation but did not tell us that almost everything on the dim sum menu was unavailable!  Not to mention, there were just a couple of dim sum servers bringing a few scant items around on trays the first 30 minutes.  The selection was so boring and it took forever to get waited on...very few things were coming out of the kitchen for the entire time we were there.  And, $170 later for four people, we were VERY DISAPPOINTED in our experience today.  The servers and managers were all running around like frantic chickens.  We didn't get napkins and took a LONG TIME to get any actual food.  For the first 40 minutes, we counted only 5 different items available!  Then, a few scant additional ones after that.  BIggest disappointment!  I am going to start going to my alternate place.  BIG BUCKS, POOR SERVICE and NO FOOD!!!!  BYE BYE.
author: B S.

description: Came here for lunch with my boss and we beat the lunch rush. We got seated right away before 12pm. We had many dishes on the carts that came by and disappointed that we put in an order for more food but they never came back with it. The tea was good and placed in a beautiful teapot. I had the chicken feet, siu Mai, dumplings, pork dish, and Dan taat. They were all decent but seriously overpriced. Service was ok, but usually Chinese places don't have the best service. Only would return with coworkers and whatnot but wouldn't trek out here just for it.
author: Amanda C.

description: Good dumpling options for vegetarians. The pork soup dumplings were good as well. Pistachio ice cream dessert was delish!
author: Nikita P.

description:
Really curious about this place until they messed up our reservations. I called them a few days ago and a lady confirmed it. On our way there, (3 different families from different parts of the Bay Area, including 2 children) I decided to call them just to make sure that we can get a high chair. Lo and behold, our reservation was not there!

Talked to one of the hostess and she said that they've never took down our reservation and maybe I called a different location. I told them that I called for the Spears location and was confirmed. She then put me on hold and handed my call to another person. Both of them got quite defensive with the fact that they messed up my reservation. So I was thinking, "Hmmm... Did I talk to a ghost that day then?" I checked my call log and, nope, I did call them a few days ahead. 

You know what? People make mistake, so at least own it. I won't be so upset and will try this establishment again in the future if only they did that and stop blaming people and be super defensive. Too late now. Like Kevin Leary said, "You're dead to me now!"
author: C T.

description: This place is so good. Best dim sum I have ever had. Pricey but worth it. Everything they offer tastes amazing. Edgar was so kind to us today and made our experience that much better. Love coming here!
author: Bob F.

description: Good Dimsum place. Even though the foods are good, nothing special about the foods. Yet, the ambience is great.
author: Effendi S.

description: This was my first time visiting even though I've heard so much about this place before. I came for lunch with some coworkers and the waiters bring different trays around with lots of options to try. Everything was delicious! The sea bass was my favorite. We also tried the shrimp dumplings, BBQ pork buns, sesame balls, shanghai dumplings, egg rolls, spicy chicken, asparagus and a salad. There is even a to go restaurant next door! I will definitely be back!
author: Nicole P.

description:
Food was delicious
Service was good (English speaking)
Cost was a bit more than other dim sum places 
Compared to las Vegas or los Angeles
Clean - waiters, carts, floors & bathrooms 
Over all spend a little more for a better experience
Will return
Although the food did come out to $175+ for four people the food was good.  If you want to get your favorite dishes try to show up early and have a reservation.
author: Gustavo V.

description: The best of all Dim Sum places in San Francisco.  Very pricey, figure about $90 for two with tea.  But if you can afford it, you will not regret it, as their dim sum is excellent and much much better than other places I have tried.
author: Carol F.

description:
Food:  We ordered the shanghai dumplings, pot stickers, siu mye, phoenix feet, shrimp dumplings, pekking duck, custard tart and orange jello.  The shanghai dumplings, pot stickers and custard tart were the ones I enjoyed.  The rest were good.  My GF ordered the phoenix feet and spent the whole morning trying to devour that ;p - Be aware they put a lot of MSG, after a few bites, I was getting full.

Food rating: 4/5

Service:  First time in a dim sum place where the service was good!  Not pushy or rude as this place is catered to Americans, and they speak English.

Service rating: 4/5

Price:  It is pricey for dim sum.  Expect to pay at least $7 per dish, they are small but eventually add up.

Overall:  I had a good first impression here, food and service here was good.  Even on a Monday, this place gets crowded during lunch hours.
author: Elvin W.

description:
We had probably the best dim sum of our life at Yank Sing. I was completely delighted and surprised. We have eaten a lot of dim sum all over the country but had so many things here that we'd never had before.

First, the soup dumplings were unbelievable. I highly recommend. They come in a big steamer basket the size of a dinner plate with something like six or seven "purse" dumplings in them. We got the pork ginger ones. The dumplings have a burst of broth inside them, and eating them is like eating a most delicious spoonful of soup all wrapped up in a dumpling skin. Mind blowing.
-Spinach mushroom dumplings which look like green tortellini are wonderful.
-The plain old shrimp dumplings were the best we've ever had, with no corn starch binder flavor and a clearly homemade dumpling skin,
-Barbecue pork bun were the best we've ever had.
-The glass teapots were beautiful and elegant to look at.

We pigged out. We ate $60 worth of dim sum for lunch and honestly could have come back to eat here at least twice during our trip if we'd had time. We will be back for sure next time we're in San Fran.
author: Sue S.

description: Too pricey for dim sum IMO but the food satisfied my pallet. Between 5 of us it was $160+ tip....and we really didn't get a lot! I will say that the carts came by often and they were not slow to put more food in front of you!!
author: Rob M.

description:
It's one of those restaurants that I know will cost me an arm and a leg but I decided to go anyway because I don't want to be a dim sum lover who travels to San Francisco and didn't check out Yank Sing.

The service is excellent.  Everybody from the receptionist to the wait staff to the cart ladies are courteous and attentive.  The cart ladies all have radios and they can order items from the kitchen for you if they run out.  The lady just sold out of turnip cake when we wanted to order, she radioed the kitchen and it was brought to our table in a minute.

The table setting is nice, with chili sauce and hot mustard in serving containers.  Both the chili sauce and mustard are of very good quality.  The teapot is  contemporary in design and has a filter for the tea leaves so they don't get to your tea.

The food is very good.  The har gaw and siu mai are superb and so is almost everything else.  When we ordered the sticky rice, the lady cut it open for us and it came with a serving spoon (see picture).  The only disappointment was the pork spareribs.  It was really only ok, and the quality of the meat is not good.

This is a perfect place for a business lunch, especially if your company is paying for it.  For us it was a very enjoyable dim sum experience, but I probably won't pay an arm and a leg for it again.
author: Rob L.

description: Such a clean and beautiful place to get good tasting dim sum in the city! They have a to go place next door.
author: EMILY Y.

description:
Just overpriced corner store American Asian food either fried, smothered in sticky sweet sauce or both. 

This place seemed higher end and had great reviews, we were disappointed when all they had was casual Americanized Asian food. 

Two stars because the service was attentive and there were a good few dishes, the roast duck, the Peking ribs and the scallop su mai (which you can get just as good at any of a hundred places within five miles).

The bill was easily twice what we would have paid ordering exactly the same thing across the street.
author: Wayne B.

description:
I came here because my good friend from work brought me here for my birthday.  Due to a generous hookup that she arranged, we were able to get seated really quickly during the busy lunch hour and I was surprised by a birthday candle stuck in a bowl of mango pudding and two egg tarts around it.  I almost was in shock...does this happen in any Chinese restaurant?  Yes, it happens in Yank Sing.  

It's more upscale and refined an experience and maybe the translucent tea pots showing the color of the tea inside, fascinated a bit too much.  Anyways, Yank Sing dim sum lunch is an experience for sure.  Not only the regular dim sum stuff but also the shanghai dumpling(XLB) as well as the other offerings from their menu.  It definitely won't be cheap but once in a while, it's worth a splurge.
author: Ben H L.

description:
Not that this place needs another great review, but:

I am from LA. I am inherently lazy. All of my friends up here in SF are busy AND AGAINST ALL ODDS I MADE A TRIP BY MYSELF ALL THE WAY DOWNTOWN TO GET THESE SWEET SWEET DUMPLINS. 

I sit here, pre-bloat, basking in what can only be described as a pregnant glow. I will take this food baby back to LA and raise it as my own. 

Thank you, YS. Thank you.
author: Zach Noe T.

description: The food is really really tasty but it is almost extortionately overpriced.  I mean the prices are absurd. It's riding off of dumb tourists and rich businessmen showing off. You can get way way better value elsewhere.
author: Nick T.

description:
First Dim Sum Experience EVER!! And I LOVED it!!! 

You might wonder why I only gave this place 3 stars while saying that I loved this place! Well you see, it's actually my first sit down experience with all these servers walking by your table with a cart full of dimsum! 

We ordered Won Ton Soup which felt light and flavorful. We ordered Potstickers, which was good, but a bit greasy. We ordered two orders of Hargow (shrimp dumplings) which had a good amount of shrimp. And last had these fried shrimp rolls-so good!

It lacked two stars because I work at a hospital near Clement St in San Francisco. They're known for their little asian eateries that sell "To Go" food for the people who work nearby. Well if I went into one of those little shops and ordered every single thing I ordered at Yank Sing, my bill would have been less than $10. When we recieved our bill at Yank Sing, it was a bit over $50! 

The food was good, the servers were nice. We went after Church on a Sunday afternoon around 1pm and was seated right away. I believe I saw a

If you have money to blow, this would be a great GO TO place for asian food. But if you're poor like me, this would be a place to go for a special treat! LOL!
author: Darlene M.

description: I recently attended a Christmas season annual family lunch at Yank Sing, and I'm writing this review because our family had an extremely nice experience.  We have been attending these lunches for almost ten years, and this was an exceptionally well handled event, considering that there were 15 of us, including three small energetic children.  Last year, I wrote a critical review because our experience was not good, and I want to acknowledge how much the staff improved its service.  The food was quite good, and special efforts were made to accommodate various requests for vegitarians, the small children, etc.  It was almost as if the serving staff read my last review, and made an effort to address the disappointing service last year.  Bravo!!!!!
author: Nancy R.

description:
Yes, the food here is more expensive than most other dim sum places, but it's a clean, convenient, and accessible establishment, which makes it a good choice in my book. I recommend it for anybody driving into the city due to its great location (and nearby parking options), solid dim sum selection, and the ability to make reservations in advance (recommended since it's usually packed!). Note: Yank Sing is located INSIDE the Rincon Center. 

Some favorites on the menu: shanghai dumplings, pork siu mye, shrimp dumplings, peking duck, curried chicken turnover, mango pudding

If you're in a hurry or unable to make a reservation, Yank Sing 2 Go (next door) has many of the dim sum classics available. Just take your order to-go and have a seat at any of the available tables in the area. (During the weekend, seating in the area is much more plentiful than during the weekdays when you have the financial district lunch crowd competing for space.)
author: Aubrey B.

description: It's not a very good Dim-sum place, especially for who's from China or familiar with the Cantonese  Dim-sum culture & taste. Even though this place is decorated quite authentic like what's in China, their dim-sum variety and taste are pretty Americanized. There are a lot of traditional dishes, which you can find in other dim-sum place like Koi Palace, Asian Pearl, Saigon Harbor, Hongkong Lounge and many other Cantonese restaurants, you won't be able to have them here. So I wouldn't recommend this place, if you really want to try some authentic dim-sums. And I agree with some other yelpers' reviews, this place is over-priced.
author: Donald N.

description:
Food review: 
The dim sum is so fresh and flavorful. To start the shrimp dumplings had large flavorful shrimp. The lotus cakes were pan seared and had slightly crispy edges. The soup dumplings were tasty, but be careful it's hot! The duck with hoisin sauce, green onioin and bao was juicy and delicious. The egg tarts (oh mah gawd!) were perfect... flaky pie shell and soft sweet egg. The tea (jasmine) was amazing and superior quality. 

Recommendation: Make a reservation!
author: Donna Y.

description: The food was OK. But the Service experience was TERRIBLE. For a high class dim sum I expected better service. Had to wait so long for water and tea REFILL. We came to sit near the fountain but they said it was closed when they are still serving dim sum. The manager looked at us but did not say thank you as we left the building. You could use your money on better dim sum.
author: Kh L.

description:
Geez what can I say. 
I grew up with dim sum. Canto 100% here. Quality is superb I like that, but not enough to justify the prices. Really can't say I'd come back here since there are also good quality decently priced dim sum in Richmond and Daly City. But I get the bring your non-Chinese families here to try dim sum for first time customers.
author: Andy L.

description:
I never thought I would be back to Yank Sing until my cousin hosted a wedding banquet here just recently.  It was a 10-course meal, plus dessert and beverages.  Oh, I can't forget the open bar if one wanted some other kind of libations besides champagne, chardonnay and/or pinot noir.

The ambiance and our waiter/server, Ray, are the main reason Yank Sing earns a five star.  He was approachable, friendly, and very accommodating...totally cool.  Our table was short a snow crab claw (my brother sitting to the left of me did not get one).  Ray came to the rescue and served him one.  Because most of the courses were seafood, my husband asked for white wine and Ray again came to the rescue.

The wedding banquet menu started and ended with the following:

Five Happiness Cold Platter, featuring five spiced smoked beef shank, jellyfish salad, char siu and smoked duck...4 stars.

Snow Crab Claw stuffed with seafood mousse...5 stars.

Sea Scallops with Macadamia Nuts sauteed with XO sauce and toasted...delicious but a tad too many macadamia nuts...3.5 stars.

Winter Melon Soup with crab meat, dried scallops and seafood...tasty and had a hint of MSG...4.5 stars.

Peking Duck served with fluffy mandarin buns and hoisin sauce...4 stars.

Crispy Spring Chicken served with shrimp flavored chips...chicken was moist and flavorable, but shrimp flavored chips were between semi-chewy to semi-crispy...3.5 stars.

Imperial Lobster sauteed with ginger scallion wine sauce...5 stars.

Velvet Filet Mignon Tenders sauteed with sugar snap peas in XO sauce...4 stars.

Honey-Glazed Chilean Sea Bass with red pepper garnish...the piece de resistance...5 stars.

Fook Kien Fried Rice - a chicken shiitake rice casserole with shrimp and sea scallops garnished with chinese broccoli...4 stars.

Dessert:  Chilled mango pudding...4 stars; wedding cake - beautifully decorated, but was dense and dry (chocolate cake is not a fav of mine)...a disappointing 3 stars.

Beverages:  2002 Dom Perignon, 2011 Rombauer Chardonnay and 2009 Foley's Two Sisters Pinot Noir...5 stars.

Open bar:  The bartenders were nice, but my drink which was a Shirley Temple was flat...no carbonation in that 7-Up and it didn't have that lemon/lime tang.  A taste of my husband's margarita was weak...don't know what brand of tequila was used...2.5 stars on both drinks.

Even though with the minor disappointments of wedding cake and drinks from the open bar, my overall rating stands at a 5 star with other activities going on...photo ops and dancing to the music..."hey, get up and get down, get up off of yo seat; get up and get down, get up and move yo feet"...something like that.
author: Carol C.

description: Ehhhhh. I've heard from countless people and read online in many places that this is the best dim sum. I think not. The shumai, sea bass ( holy cow expensive!), and the egg tarts were all delicious, but everything else was just okay or not very good. I did not like their xiao long bao, long beans, turnip cake, and a few others. I guess I'll keep looking for great dim sum in SF because I still haven't found it.
author: Jen B.

description:
FOOD:
Really delicious dim sum. It is way over priced but still good! These dishes are my favorites: XIAO LONG BAO, HAR GOW, SHUMAI, & CHEONG FUN. The best one to me is CHEONG FUN-its rice noodle with shrimp and a sweet soy sauce on top. So Good!! Also I like the sesame balls with taro inside for dessert!

SERVICE:
Everyone is nice!

WOULD I RECOMMEND IT? Maybe, it is just expensive for what you get.
author: Kelley Y.

description: Phenomenal dim sum in a very pretty setting - inside an office building with a few other businesses.  Dim sum servers come by quickly and if you want something, grab it!  You may not see it again.  They serve a wonderful cabbage salad that was so refreshing and delicious - a great accompaniment to dumplings of all sorts.  It was a great San Francisco experience for my young daughter who happens to love dumplings.  Service was attentive and friendly.  It's pricey but the quality matches.
author: Kathy A.

description: This is their to-go option which doesn't have the full array of options. That said, it's not a bad deal. They have preset plates or you can get some items a la carte. Had perhaps one of the best cha siu bao (BBQ pork bun) here from their a la carte menu. It was light and fluffy and the meat tender and flavorful.
author: Sonya G.

description:
One of the best (if not the best) dim sum places in SF. Although some might argue this place is also one of the priciest dim sum places, I have yet to find a place that stands up quality wise to the dishes served up at Yank Sing. Shrimp dumplings, sticky rice, shanghai soup dumplings, peking duck, bbq pork buns, eggplant-- whatever you try you can't go wrong! Don't forget to save room for the egg custards (they are melt in your mouth delicious). Be prepared to spend $33-50 a person.

Tip: park in the underground parking and you can get it validated when you pay.
author: Casey B.

description: Again, I don't get it. How does this place only have 31/2 stars? Out of ALL of SF this place is by FAR the cleanest DIM SUM restaurant. Don't believe me? Check yourself. Secondly, it's the highest quality and still traditional. Yes there's long waits and the customer services needs improvement. But it should matter that much when you just want good, traditional, Clean DimSum. This IS the place.
author: Manny S.

description:
(Sorry for any typos in advance)

Dim Sum Credibility: I've been eating dim sum since a baby. I've eaten everywhere in SF Chinatown, SF Richmond District and Oakland Chinatown. My family even owned the building Tong Palace Restaurant which operates out in the Richmond District. I know how these restaurants operate behind the scenes and Yank Sing seems to be the cleanest and professional out of all. 

When you walk in you know it's going to be crazy busy BUT they have an efficient way of texting you when your table is ready. They also have a dim sum take out right outside so you can grab a quick snack while waiting. All of the servers are dressed nice and are very polite. Usually you have to sacrifice service and cleanliness for Chinese food but amazingly you get it all here. We never had a dirty plate or empty cup our whole meal which is huge if you eat at a lot of Asian restaurants. The decor and atmosphere is very modern and diverse. 

The food is definitely on another level of quality and preparation compared to all of the $2 dim sum places...And it's worth the money. From the Daan Taat to the Ho fun everything taste freshly made and makes you realize this is what these dishes should taste like. Make sure to try everything and drink a lot of tea. It will help with the sodium and grease which is to be expected wen eating dim sum. 

I would come back here for special occasions and when I want to treat my out of town visitors. Not because it's not the BEST but because I can't eat BAD like this more than once every two months. Keep this place in mind if you need quality a binge day. Lol
author: Byron C.

description:
Long long line regardless what time you go to the restaurant on the weekends. If you like dumplings I would suggest checking this place out at your time in San Francisco. When you enter the building it is a beautiful layout with seating outside next to the fountain and inside the restaurant itself.

You have the opportunity to order a la carte or pick up the food as the cart goes by.I would suggest ordering the a must try Shanghai dumpling (super good) and juicy remind me of the dumplings at Din Tai Fung and the spinach dumplings are a unique food to try.

Great place to go in a small or large group but make sure you have the time to wait in line.
author: Kunal T.

description: My friend and I went to Yank Sing for lunch.  We were surprised that there was no menu and that our selections had to come from whatever cart approached our table. We had four small plates and green tea.  The food was average. Some of the buns had very little filling inside and the sauces were questionable.  Our bill was $70 for an ordinary meal.  A local friend laughed and said that Yank Sing was a downtown tourist trap and that we could have found far better dim sum in many authentic Chinatown locations.  Save your money for real quality dim sum and go elsewhere.
author: Mark M.

description:
Heads up, be ready to spend $100 for 2 people on dim sum.
Is it worth it? Opinions vary, but what ever your opinion is this place is busy busy busy from opening to closing, Monday thru Sunday.
Yank sing has some of the better dim sum in the Bay Area. Why not the best? Because some days it is not the best. 
Get: steamed seabass $21, Shanghai dumplings, anything steamed 
Don't get: Peking duck $7 per piece , 2 pieces is half of a Peking duck at most places in the Bay Area. The skin is not crispy enough for my liking. 
Service: prompt, efficient 
Parking : street, or parking lot which they validate
author: Dub C.

description: They tried hard but fell short in many areas. Very poor management and operation. Minimum food options, slow service, not into detail and very expensive. They have many staffs but obviously they are lack of training and experience.
author: Wallace L.

description:
Best dim sum in San Francisco. 
Must have the soup dumplings, Peking duck and siu mai.  I also like their steamed BBQ pork buns.  
If you want to try something different, order the seaweed wrapped tofu. It's deep fried but it's good. 

Reservations recommended.
author: Margaret W.

description:
One of the best Dim Sum I've ever had including Hong Kong, NJ and NY. Very clean, great selection, good service etc. highly recommended!! 
 
Soup dumplings: 5 stars smaller size just right
Fried dumplings: 5 stars very moist!!
Shrimp  shumai: 4 stars
Peking duck: 4 stars
Prawn walnut: 4.5 stars
Desserts: 5 stars
author: Ji J.

description: One of the best dim sum places I've ever eaten at. The quality of the food was excellent, and the ingredients tasted fresh. None of the dishes were too oily. Aside from the food, I have to give props to the staff. I mentioned an allergy to shrimp, and they quickly made a note on the order sheet of my food allergy and made sure all staff who passed by knew about it. Overall great experience. Would come back again for sure.
author: Melody G.

description: Quality dim sum for twice the average price. Minus 1 star for the unauthorized pushback of a reservation and another star for terrible seating.
author: Shelby L.

description: Loved this place! Came for dim sum and was told this was the best place in town.  Easy to get to and a little bit of a wait but the food was good and plentiful.  Staff was nice enough.  I got full pretty fast.  The quality of food itself was great but I think I can find better.  Parking was easy and the shopping center it's in is also a nice walk thru if you have to wait.  Not From SF and it's the only place I've been to for dim sum so far... Hope to come back soon.  Definitely will try a different place next time and will update my review accordingly.  I recommend this place to anyone's going to SF.
author: Leilani Laisa T.

description:
This was delicious dim sum! I had several different dumplings of the seafood variety and all were excellent. I was especially pleased with the Shanghai soup dumplings, so very hot and juicy! 

Only thing was the prices were a bit higher than most dim sum places I have been to.

enjoy!
author: Steven W.

description:
Maybe I'm a pleb...but for the price and quality of food, I'm not impressed.

I finally came here with a group of friends. We were celebrating birthdays, and one of the birthday girls decided on this place. It wasn't terrible, but not great. Quite honestly, I like the take-out dim sum at Good Mong Kok better. 

Service was stellar. I hope that the staff gets a pay raise, because they were so good. Though, our tea went near empty a few times. It's odd that we can't indicate whether or not we want more tea by lifting the tea pot cover. I guess that's what the see-through pots are for.

Dim Sum wise, I've had better. In the states. It's not terrible, but the quality just isn't as wonderful. Examples: skins to the dumplings stuck together. Cheung fun didn't have that nice shine/shimmer for great quality ones. Things fell apart. And WHO does Singaporian Rice Noodles with lap cheung and NO CURRY!? Just WEIRD I say!

When you make a reservation, they don't let you sit until at least half the party is there which I found odd. Especially since there was a heavily pregnant woman in our group waiting. She had to sit outside next to the fountain, but at least there was seating at an area.

Some of the things I remembered:
Xiao Long Bao: It was okay, but skin could have been thinner, and more soup in the dumpling

Shrimp Dumpling (Ha Gao): It stuck to other ones.

Siu Mai: Lacked flavor...very sad

Cheung Fun: Both beef and bbq pork - was meh. No shimmer, and for the bbq pork, the pork literally fell out. We used spoons to get it on our plates.

BBQ pork baked bun: was better than most. I think they use honey as the glaze

If you're coming here, you're really paying for the service since most Chinese dim sum places are pretty terrible about service. Their service here was really good in comparison to other places, which is funny to me since they JUST settled a wage theft case. I guess they're on their toes about being good to the servers.
author: Lily W.

description: Delicious food, good service, comfortable seating, and relaxing atmosphere. A little pricey but the quality is worth it in my book. Best I've ever had
author: Aiko M.

description:
I had dim sum with my dad and sister today. The last time we had lunch with just the three of us was in 1988. We got happy meals and ate them in golden gate park :) 

Well, 28 years later we're dining on deep fried shrimp covered with shrimp, perfect salty crispy bites of sea bass, and the flakiest and softest egg tarts.  

We'll be back! :D
author: Jacquee P.

description:
Pros:
- Easy reservation process over the phone 
- No wait with reservation even on the weekend 
- Free parking with validation on weekends 
- Steamed and glazed bbq pork buns were amazing 
- Friendly service 

Cons:
- The rest of the dim sum offerings were just mediocre 


The dim sum was just okay here.  I've had better.  I don't even care about the prices (which I didn't even consider that high).  I did care about the taste and quality of the dishes.  Not bad by any means, but not as spectacular as the hype had built it up to be.

I'll come back for the pork buns, both the steamed and glazed buns were equally delicious.
author: Kathy C.

description: I've been going to Yank sing for 8 years and it is by far the best dim sum I've ever had ! It's such a beautiful restaurant great service so attentive , clean and that's important the other dim sum places I've been to in the city were dirty and the servers were so rude . Yank Sing is a place I alway take my friends and family when there in town . The foods alway fresh and delicious !! Have the chanhigh  dumplings  and  shrimp noodle dumpling and the purple cabbage salad those alway my must haves !!!!!!!
author: Catalina D.

description: Man this is a toughie because food and service and ambiance were superb but jeez is it expensive. I came here on a Sunday so street parking was free but they do have a parking garage right there and they validate. They also accept reservations which is nice. I didn't realize there was a dim sum place in sf that wasn't ratchet. It is inside this huge building and the outdoor seating is so pretty. Like I'm amazed this is dim sum. I got there around 1145 and the wait was half an hour for two. I got seated indoors and ordered various dishes. I am amazed.
