The people here are polite, they speak English, they don't yell, and if you want an item they don't have then they will use their mike and ask them to get it for you on the spot. Seriously the service is Ridic! Sometimes orders came in four and in like holy guacamole that's a lot. They understood and said how many do you want. I said two, so they split the plate and stamped a lower price. The best dish were the egg tarts! Comes in four but they let us have two. It seriously reminds me of Golden Gate Bakery but without the wait! Warm and flakey yummm! Also the Xiao long Bao are delicious!!!! The crowd is bougie and there are defs more Caucasians who like their dim sum. It is definitely not the typical rude canto dim sum places you usually experience. So I got 10-11 plates and with top it was 110. Be still me heart. If you average, I paid 10 bucks a plate??!!!! Well it was a celebratory meal so it was fine but still, this ain't gonna be my go to dim sum place. I applaud you Americanized but still authentic you.
author: Amy H.

description: Best dim sum in San Francisco. If you make a reservation, you better be on time or you'll have to wait a lot longer.
author: Mimi J.

description: On the weekends they set out tables by the water fountain in the Rincon center. It can be a bit chilly but it was really pretty. I liked it better outside because i felt it was more relaxing. Indoors get stuffy, crowded and really loud. The servers were nice and they were helpful. The food to me was mediocre. The reason being it's a mix of want to be Hong Kong style dim sum and american food. Nothing was really "authentic". The food over all wasnt bad but if you want the real deal of a dim sum experience this would not be the place to be. And a bit pricey too.
author: Leme K.

description:
Poor experience yesterday.
We have been coming to Yank Sing for 15+ years, but the place has really fallen off.
The reservations were handled poorly.  The food was cold. Service poor. And they even tried to overcharge me for a pot of tea.
The worst part of the experience were the prices.  They charge far too much. I am sure there are dozens of better places in San Francisco at much more reasonable prices.
We won't be going back.
author: Steve K.

description:
Yank sing is the Disneyland of Dim Sum. It is clean cheerful and safe.

There are many other places I would personally prefer to go if I had my druthers. Alas when entertaining guests from Massachusetts I figured a whole in the wall with sticky Naugahyde seats was not in the picture....you all remember Sam Wo don't you??? ( I miss that nasty old bastard waiter...he was the best).

Yank sing has good dim sum. Everything tastes fresh albeit the flavors are not as bold and unique as Hong Kong lounge or Tong Kiang.

The waiters and waitress are really great and are very patient. Service is impeccable.

We had the Shanghai dumplings that were good not great(should have been scalding hot soup inside not hot). The side sauce was mediocre flavored.

The Shrimp har gow was nice...great plump shrimp.

For the vegetarians the spinach dumplings and the mushroom dumplings were really good. The onion cake with sesame sauce was very tasty albeit greasy.

We finally had the coconut cream roll which was really a hit...go figure desert dim sum that is great.

Expensive yes....6 bucks for a teapot of jasmine tea....bend over sailor....wow.

3 people 66 bucks with tip...not cheap...but ya gotta entertain the visitors and put on a good face.

Take if from this gwai lo...take only your tourist friends here.
author: David G.

description:
WHY IS THIS PLACE SO EXPENSIVE? I feel like it should be illegal to price dim sum at their prices. Prepare to spend 3x what you normally would at a regular dim sum place. Food is not bad but definitely not worth shelling out $60 for 2 people when I can easily get better/more authentic dim sum for $10. 

Never trust a fancy Chinese establishment.
author: Maryann S.

description:
This was our first experience eating dim sum. We came with my auntie and I can't say enough how amazing the food was. We were treated with the utmost respect and all of the dishes were beyond delicious. I only wish that I lived in San Francisco so I could eat here on a regular basis!!!
Soup dumplings were amazing as was everything else. Be sure to order the orange Jell-O at the end of your meal!!
author: Tiffany S.

description:
The dim sum is consistently very good. The xiao long bao (Shanghai soup dumplings) are as good as they get: perfect thickness of the skin, plenty of tasty soup inside with a wonderfully delicious and tender meat filling. I've yet to break a single XLB (knock on wood) which is a testament to how well they are made! All the regular dim sum items are also very good (e.g., har gao, shrimp noodles, egg tarts, sesame balls, etc), and the seafood is always fresh. The only dish that needed improvement was the chicken feet. The sauce was a bit bland. Other than that, I have no complaints. And the service is very good - Americanized service, not your standard authentic Chinese service. ;-)

Make reservations using Open Table or you will be stuck waiting for lunch. The restaurant is very large and spacious, but it fills up every day. A bit on the pricey side for dim sum, but definitely worth treating yourself to once in a while!
author: Jaching H.

description:
********************* 1193 *********************

     Yank Sing has a perfect location, smack in downtown of Fidi and a short walk to the Embarcadero. The spacious restaurant is always packed for lunch and dinner. Reservation is always recommend here. Because the wait for lunch if you come at Noon, can be 30-45 minutes, for weekend Dim Sum can be 1 hour.

     The food is good for dinner, although Dim Sum is not the best in town, but a few dishes you can count on and overall it's a solid Chinese Restaurant you can show your visiting guests around. 

- Shanghai Xiao Long Bao is very good.

- Shanhai Bao dumplings is delicious.

- Lobster dumplings is a must try.

- Tasty Fung Chao chicken feet, nom nom

- The Peking Duck is good, but the Bao is to thick and not airy enough.

- The porridge is very good here, but they only serve on the weekends & holidays. 

    I also love the CHA tea in the beautiful glass pot here. My mom made me bought it for her awhile back :-)  The Spicy XO sauce is so good here too. You must ask for it. 

     It's a good spot for business lunch. It's easy to find the location and service is always good and efficient here. 

     If you RSVP with OpenTable, you always have priority than walk in. They also validate your valet parking from 10:30 AM-3 PM MON-FRI for only $4 if you park at the One Rincon Building.
author: Manda Bear B.

description: If you are ready and do not mind to pay $8 for a fried crab claw, or $3 for an egg tart (which is half of the normal size), then I believe the slow service and ok quality of the food will bother you. They were reasonably good before but price is totally out of control. I will not think about to go there unless I win the lotto or have someone fund the bill. Feel like just get robbed.
author: S L.

description:
Almost all the travel guides I read tell you to go to Yank Sing for dim sum.  So like lamb to slaughter, I followed suit and ended up in a restaurant though fine and well decorated, had kill your budget prices. It's located in the Rincon Center in the Financial District.   Be wary of restaurants that don't serve dim sum for breakfast and start serving at 11:00.  They figure it will be more gentle to bear when you see the bill and you rationalize that you are paying for brunch or lunch because who would want to pay so much for breakfast!   The cost for two people without tip was already a staggering $70.  They also did not have a menu on the table with prices nor did waiters bring any to the table.  I completely forgot to look for a menu seeing that I'm just some eating dim sum.  Wrong move!  Always look for a menu, especially in fancy establishments.

I have had far more beautiful dim sum in Hong Kong and China and it was definitely affordable.  Some places serve whole shrimp neatly tucked in the shrimp dumpling (har gow) which was not the case at Yank Sing.  Yes, the dim sums are refined but it will cost you.  They only carried 5 teas and it came in the see through glass pot and the leaves, held in the center.  Unfortunately, I had chrysanthemum tea that didn't do well in this fancy pot.  It takes a while to steep this tea, and most of the time it tasted like water with just a hint of chrysanthemum.  Forget the fancy pot; give me a regular tea pot, and some flavor steeped tea.

Staffs push around dim sum carts and all are proficient in English and most seem to prefer to speak English to all customers.  A stellar dim sum was the deep fried tofu mixture with seaweed wrapped around it.  It tastes best when hot, and the jello in the orange slices, clever, eye-catching and beautiful to look at.   The shrimp dumpling had overly sticky skin and stuck to my chopsticks, tearing it away from the filling.  The steamed rice roll was okay, but most of the dim sum had a sweetness to it which sometimes is bad when you want savory tasting seasoning only.  I had one piece of scallion pancake leftover and they packed it in a deluxe take over box that was hexagon in shape.  Give me a regular disposable container and slash some dim sum prices.

This is a onetime experience for me only and I would never do it again.  I have to remove one star for overly high prices and not giving us a menu to see how the dim sums are tabulated.
author: Lin Y.

description: Awesome dim sum. Don't be turned away from the weird office building. It's amazing! Loved the soup dumplings and anything pork we tried!
author: Veleta V.

description: Dim sum has always been a Sunday ritual growing up. It was our "family bonding time". I think most asian parents are really weird and awkward when it comes to family time. Well my parents at least.  Yank Sing is a really upscale dim sum place. The quality of good is pretty decent. I did notice that it wasn't oily at all.  Its a bit pricy for dim sum but I'll probably eat here again if i was in the area.
author: Kathy K.

description:
My favorite dim sum place in San Fran. There are more than one locations, I usually frequent the one on Spear Street. 
The soup dumplings are our favorite. 
It's a bit pricey for dim sum so not a place we come to often. 
Very clean restaurant, good friendly service.
author: L N.

description:
I am so disappointed with what has happened to this place. This used to be my favorite dim sum restaurant. Always a treat and always a good time when I came here. Unfortunately, that is not the case anymore. What used to be this amazing restaurant has now turned into a soulless money making establishment. 

Came here for dim sum with the family really excited to show my brother and his girlfriend one of the best dim sum places in the city. We started ordering the usual dishes, but as we kept ordering I realized a few different things, one the courses are extremely limited now; and two the prices are out of control. My gripe truly is on the prices. When you order some duck, and they serve it by the slice ($6.50/slice) you automatically fall out of your chair and want to give it back.  Who even does that? Second, how can any dish be worth $20 when HK Lounge is arguably serving it better at more than half the cost? 

Save your money and your time. And try HK Lounge or Dim Sum Club. This place is not worth it anymore.
author: Alex L.

description: What happened? This was always a favorite until today. When I saw that the place was half empty at 1PM I knew that things had changed. The food was awful. The steamed items were luke warm and tasteless. The duck was dry, the tea never brewed and the cost was absurd. Enough said...Yank Sing is not even close to what it used to be.
author: rick g.

description: i have been to yank sing on spear street twice. it was really good and they have awesome jasmine tea. the servers are also super nice and accommodating. we were really hungry and took everything from first few carts and saw that there were others that we would have liked to try, so i would highly recommend pacing yourself. also we sat outside by the waterfall inside the building and it would really cool. i also ate at the other yank sing, which is small and more intimate. we bought jasmine tea and brought it home for us and as gifts.
author: Connie C.

description:
This place is in some kind of food court area of what might be some kind of mall.  If you're walking on Spear St. there are signs pointing you to the correct location.  

The restaurant seemed pretty popular and had a 10min wait for two people.  What can I really say about Dim Sum though, there are people who like Dim Sum and there are people who have never had Dim Sum.  This place is great for both types.  

I took off a star for the strange location and because yelp only lets me rate an integer number of stars, but it's really a half star handicap at max.
author: Gary C.

description:
Solid dim sum experience and great to bring larger parties or visiting out of town guests for their first dim sum. 

My favorites:
-Shanghai dumplings (aka soup dumplings). I could eat these all day long. The soup exploded in your mouth with flavor when you bite into it. These are hard to execute, and they do it seamlessly every time. 
-Baked pork buns. You usually have to seek these out. I love the steamed pork buns too, but the baked ones here are the best.
-Shrimp dumplings
-Pork shu Mai 
-Peking duck
-Shrimp rice noodle

Go with a group so you can try everything! It is a little expensive but it's really high quality stiff and especially good for introducing new people to the fabulous world of dim sum. 
(Also doesn't hurt that I was seated next to Patrick Dempsey here once.)
author: Aggie N.

description: I love their dim sum and the food quality and taste is always very consistent. I have taken a lot of my friends here for peking duck and dim sum.
author: Mai V.

description: The dim sum was very delicious! My favorite items were the shiu mai and chicken feet. Best chicken feet ever!
author: Tina T.

description: Sooo overpriced for pedestrian tasting Dim Sum. Very hard to get out of there for 2 people for less than $30-40/person without cocktails etc. Setting and decor are like a cheap Chinese diner. At least the service is fast as they want to turn as many customers as humanly possible.
author: Trevor B.

description:
This place is EXPENSIVE. Every plate is at least $6, sometimes just for one serving. 

Common clientele: foreign tourists 

What you are actually paying for: slightly more attentive and polite service compared to usual Chinese restaurants 

Is it worth it? The food is decent but the bill is just alarming. $80 gets you 6 dishes for two people (and you know how small dim sum dishes are...) The table of 4 next to us had the waitress go thru their bill item by item because they were so alarmed by their final $170 bill. Can you imagine? That's 200 bucks if you decide to tip well.
author: Joanna H.

description:
I always have doubt whenever I'm having dimsum in US as I always think it's not authentic enough and I can get the better one in Asia for sure.  
But I would say yank sing is a place you can count on if you wanna have authentic dim sum. Not the best I ever had but it's memorable enough for me to go there if I'm in SF.
Do RSVP as the wait can be an hour or more.  Yes it's that bad. 
I love their char siew  /bbq pork bun and their siumai.
author: Irah H.

description:
Yank Sing sells itself as an upscale Chinese restaurant, where you can even hold pretty classy wedding banquets (One of my friends actually had her wedding reception here and the venue was definitely not disappointing).

This review is for dim sum only.

On service (4 stars): The restaurant has narrow alleys so the dim sum carts often can't reach every table. My date and I were seated at one of those hard-to-reach tables today, but the waitstaff often came to check on us to make sure that we got everything we wanted, which we thought was a nice touch. That being said, the waiter responsible for tea/plates was often pretty curt (but what do I expect?).

On food: 
- Honey glazed sea bass ($20): This was definitely a melt-in-your-mouth kind of dish. I loved everything from the nice combination of buttery flavor of the fish and the sweet soy sauce to the garnishes that complemented the sweet sauce with a kick (scallions). The only problem may be the price tag.

- Turnip cakes: Nicely done, with crispy outside (with pancetta-like pork pieces, too)! I would love it if other places all could do it exactly this way. 

- Spring rolls: These are okay but not great. The inside could have more texture, but the seasoning is nice and the wrapper is nicely fried.  

- Charsiubao: I thought I liked it more than the Koi Palace's! The inside is well, a little overseasoned but I liked the inside-to-bun ratio. The bun is also quite buttery so the dish has almost a decadent feel to it. 

- Shumai: This was a great rendition of the classic dim sum dish with high-quality ingredients.  

The food is really great here if you are willing to spend $$$ on it. I'd come here for special occasions, but this is probably not the place to satisfy your sudden dim sum hunger.
author: Wonhee P.

description:
I love the food at Yank Sing, I have been going for years!
It is one of my favorite spots to bring people who are visiting San Francisco.
I go there myself when visiting, now that I no longer live in SF.

With that said, I brought a friend to the Rincon location, boasting about the amazingness he was lucky enough to enjoy once we were seated.
And the truth be told, the food did not disappoint! The Shanghai dumplings were so fantastic, we had a second batch! The sea bass was incredible, and several other classics were awesome as well!!

The one criticism that I had, something that I have never experienced at the Stevenson location. Once seated the service was pretty terrible. The host at the front adorable and really pleasant, and then we sat down....The women pushing the carts around were like zombies. They would walk right by our table as I was flapping my arms trying to get their attention, saying :"excuse me, excuse me." It became comical. It was the strangest thing I had seen. It was really weird. We watched many items that we would have happily had put on our table disappear as they walked on by ignoring us. And not just us, I saw it happening all over the dining room. Maybe I just hit it on an off day? Because it was something I had never seen at Yank Sing, but I do not go to the Rincon location very often.

Don't let that stop you from going, I still believe this is quite possibly the best Dim Sum in San Francisco.
author: Kent T.

description: First time eating dim sum in San Fran! The carts come around fast! Was a bit overwhelming, but in a good way. I've had better dim sum in San Jose but overall It was a nice experience. Service was excellent. Coconut custard rolls were delicious, you can't find those anywhere!
author: M N.

description:
I would give it a solid 4.5.   We always make a point to stop by Yank Sing when in San Fran.  Price point could be considered a bit high but given the location (San Fran) and the quality of food, it's a minor point that could be overlooked. 

They offer typical Chinese dim sum but we always make sure to order soup dumplings (XLB).  Compared to Din Tai Fung's XLB, the dumpling skin is a bit thicker but the filling is on point.  It always come steaming hot and very juicy.  I prefer the dumpling sauce at DTF over Yank Sing.  The sauce at Yank Sing is this weird pink color and the correct sauce calls for black vinegar.  That is my only (minor) complaint.  

The service is quick and food comes fast.  The restaurant gets pretty packed so make sure you make a reservation by calling or on open table.  

Also, we like the Spear location much better.  It's MUCH bigger and they even validate your parking ticket when you park in the attached garage.
author: Susan L.

description:
Dimsum here is good, but $50 for 2 people?! Come on.

Besides the expensive check, service was excellent. It gets crowded at noon for lunch, but my boyfriend and I were able to walk in without a reservation and get a table. 

The selection here is good - you can order food on the carts or by the menu. We got our tea and food came out promptly.

Favorites:
* XLB soup dumplings
* Pork & shrimp siu mai
* Steamed egg custard buns
* Baked pork buns
* Honey seabass

It's a nice spot for lunch if you want to get fancy, but otherwise I'm sticking with my tried-and-true dim sum at HK Lounge and Lai Hong.
author: Vivian H.

description:
I'd give Yank Sing 4 stars for non-holidays... but would recommend avoiding it like the plague on holidays (Mother's Day, Christmas, etc) when it gets way too crowded.

We went on Christmas and, despite having a reservation, had to wait nearly 30 min for a table.  While service is normally very good, they were simply too crowded and ran out of many dishes. We asked a staff member for Chinese broccoli.  She returned about 20 min later to tell us they were sold out.  We waited for many of our usual favorites that simply never showed up.  We ordered steamed custard buns and it took about 30 min to arrive.  All in all, there was too much waiting for too few items.

Normally, the food quality and variety and the service are outstanding.   To appreciate Yank Sing at its best, go early.  

Be prepared to spend.  For a party of 4, we spent about $150 including tip.

Validated parking is a huge perk.
author: Lee K.

description: The is absolutely the best Dim Sum food in San Francisco. There Shrimp dumplings are delish! The Peking Duck I'd walk for miles for. Thank goodness Yank Sing on Spear street is open until 4pm on Saturdays! Plenty of street parking and a wonderful peaceful atmosphere. Staff are courteous and attentive. The BEST!
author: Annette M.

description: Perfectly fine but definitely pricey. We were unpleasantly surprised by the bill at the end. None of the food stood out as especially tasty.
author: B C.

description:
Preeeeetty expensive dim sum... then again, it's in the Financial District. 

The restaurant is really nice and one of the classier dim sum spots out of all the places I've been to. I probably won't be coming back bc this place is more business-y dim sum rather than a local spot (something you'd find in Chinatown).
author: Jo L.

description:
I used to only patronized Koi Palace, until I found out that their dim sum were not made on site anymore.  So I came back to Yank Sing.  It has been over 5 years!

Their steamed dumplings were superb!  The skins on those dumplings were thin enough to be translucent and chewy at the same time.   Koi's dumplings couldn't compare to these.

The only downside is the lack of selection.  They only have about 30% of what Koi's have to offer.  But at least they do their 30% well, so I am not complaining.  

And the price.....$113.00 for 2 adults.  We only ordered less than 10 dishes.
author: Samantha E.

description:
I love the STUFFED LOTUS LEAF at Yank Sing! They only use high quality ingredients inside the lotus leaf parcel so you can actually tell what you're eating (nothing mushed together with ground meat or anything) and the proportion of sticky rice to savory, delicious filling is just right! 

Other favorite Dim Sum items here:
+Shanghai dumplings
+shrimp dumplings
+pork siu mye
+turnip cake
author: Jenni H.

description:
Just reviewing the Sunday dim-sum here.

Lines are long.  If you arrive at noon you're in for a 30-45 min wait.

Dim sum is very good.  Kind of greasy but pretty much what you would expect.  The soup dumplings are surprisingly tasty, the radish cake is great, egg tarts are desserty, etc, etc.  All the classics are here.

Service is OK.  It can sometimes be frustrating waiting for the right dish to come by ... the servers don't roam with any sort of rhyme or reason so sometimes it can feel like you really need to pounce on someone to get the dish you want.

Prices are high.  Usually we end up at around 80 bucks for two including tax and tip.  If you live in the area, however, the convenience factor probably outweighs saving a buck or two.  The location makes it a five star for me personally ... why drive and fight for parking at a dim sum place 30 minutes away when there's a perfectly good spot two blocks away?
author: Richard K.

description:
Ugh, the food here is so good.
I cannot recall picking one thing from the carts that came around to our table that I didn't like or want more of (not a good place for a diet!).

I don't think this is the kind of place you might frequent for the amazing service or anything. The staff seems sometimes pushy and the dynamic is weird-ish. I have always had a reservation but I have seen people wait quite a bit for their table. However, despite all of the aforementioned - the food is pretty damn good. Postickers, pork buns, shrimp thingy's ...yeah, everything was so good and delicious. I think about eating at Yank Sing at least once a week and have to control myself because my waistline would be disastrous.
author: Nikki R.

description: Some of the best dim sum I've ever had. I was thinking about docking it a star because it is just so darn pricey for dim sum! However, I really enjoyed the atmosphere, quality of food and quick service. The xiao long bao are a must!!
author: Amy S.

description: We've been coming to Yank Sing for over 20 years and we used to frequent their original location near the Embarcadero.  The founding parents have passed and their son is now running the show and has dramatically raised the prices. Their xiao lum bao are easily twice the price of other higher end dim sum places. and the service has really gone down hill .  From busboys to cart pushers everyone is rude and frazzled and cranky like they hate their jobs.  I feel they are trained to try to rupsell their patrons. They were constantly trying to  sell me stuff I had no interest in.  The dim sum item my waitress was pushing on me multiple times as if she was short of her quota for the month was a black sea bass, it was steaked with bone in and modestly sized for over $20.  My wife and I take our two kids for dim sum often and when I got the bill here I thought for sure I must have gotten someone else's bill - it was $135!!!  There are many places just as good if not better for way less $$$
author: Ray L.

description:
Pros:
-Delicious food
-Wide selection on menu
-Able to make reservations online (seriously, I've never heard of a dim sum place that you could reserve a table for on open table)

Cons
-Overpriced: $125 for 11 dishes? I knew this place was priced higher than usual but that's ridiculous. 
-Service: Slow. Hard to flag down a waiter. Some of the same carts would pass multiple times before a new one would even come. 

Overall:
I enjoyed eating here a lot. I don't think I would come by again, unless for a special occasion, as I know I can get my dim sum fix for way cheaper.
author: Jennifer N.

description: Over priced, and no variety. We were here for 45 mins and the same food was going around the entire time. For someone who grew up eating dim sum every weekend, this place was fairly disappointing to say the least.  We ordered 4 items and our bill was $45.
author: Mary Anne C.

description: I thought the food was exceptional, tasty, fresh, with large dim sum offering.  Would return for special occasion but found parking garage very expensive, so that would impact my next time.
author: Lynn A.

description: Great sit down place for a real lunch.  Pricey but good selection and quality.  Once you get the hang of the rotating food carts it is a lot of fun.  Do not go if you need a quick lunch - their takeout is right next door and I recommend them as well.  Do not go if on tight budget- lunch will coat about $25 per person in my experience.
author: Annette M.

description:
Overated and overpriced. There was a long wait to get a table for five, even though we saw plenty of empty tables
The food was average-good, but not amazing... Definitely not worth the huge price tag. It's crazy popular, but i don't really understand the hype; look for a better deal elsewhere
author: Kevin L.

description: Great dim sum place in the Bay Area. Don't have to venture into China town. Food is very clean and fresh tasting. Best dim sum I've had. Great service. It is a little pricey, but overall a great experience. The Peking Duck buns are Amazing.
author: C N.

description: I've come here a few times because it's across the street from my office. The food is good, but it's pricey for dimsum. There are definitely much cheaper places that are just as good.
author: Cynthia M.

description: Came on a Sunday morning with 3 other people. Not sure why all the good reviews. We ordered probably 7 or 8 dishes since the variety is very limited and spent $125!!! Quality was just okay, but I have had much better.  Never again.
author: Ron W.

description: Food is OK. Service is terrible, waiter and bust boy looks at you and didn't come by to   pick up check. Had to call them over, had to ask for tea and water multiple times.
author: Beatrice L.

description: Anyone who doesn't give this place at least 4 stars is just hating.  Yes, it's pricey.  It's a tourist destination, true.  The parking can be brutal, absolutely.  But the dim sum can't be beat.  Everything is good.  I've never had a bad meal and I doubt I ever will.  Ok, sometimes the potstickers are luke warm and a tad mushy.  They still are better than just about anything else potsticker-wise I've ever had.  Yank Sing never has a bad day, just an unspectacular moment occasionally.
author: D. Templeton R.

description:
Yank Sing is a fine dining Chinese restaurant that serves dim sum, which an assortment of steamed dumplings and side dishes. It's very well-known and has recognition from the James Beard Foundation: http://www.yanksing.com/about-us/reviews/james_beard_09.html

At first glance to people who are unfamiliar with dim sum, it may seem strange as a breakfast/brunch option. Don't worry, you'll crave it for breakfast soon enough. It's the perfect meal to bring families and friends together. It's shared family-style so it's no wonder large families gather for dim sum every Sunday! The dim sum at Yank Sing can be a bit pricey, but I'd pay for the quality and freshness that they put out. They also have a superb wait staff as compared to other more homey dim sum restaurants. I have nothing against the classic, small, hole-in-the-walls, but I don't mind the extra customer service and food quality that Yank Sing offers.

Yank Sing has two locations and during my short trip to SF, I went to both...

The two locations are: the Spear St. location and the Stevenson St.. The Spear St. location is within a business building food court and it's very nice. The Stevenson location is smaller and not as popular so you may not see as long of a line, but there will still be a wait. Food is consistent between the two.

So were there any notable dishes? Absolutely. The Soup dumplings. I first discovered these Chinese delights in NYC's Joe Shanghai restaurant. It's well-known for their soup dumplings and I can still taste my first bite. Unfortunately, New Orleans has no such thing, but I've discovered them in major cities like Houston and more recently in San Francisco. Yank Sing has one of the best soup dumplings I have ever had. The dumpling casing is so delicate and very similar to a won-ton. It holds the perfect temperature of soup and dumpling within. Once it's in your mouth, it just melts...Be sure to add the ginger and red vinegar. It balances the flavors so well. It can be an acquired taste so start with just a touch!

Overall, excellent food and service.

Yes, the dim sum prices are pretty steep, but it's worth a try! Honestly, I would just go to Yank Sing for a few orders of Soup Dumplings (Xiao Long Bao) and some tea. That would be the perfect meal right about now...
author: Leslie L.

description: The food was good, but it was realistically twice the price it should have been.  $90 for dim sum for two with no alcohol but only tea (which they charge $4 a person for) is more than a bit steep.  In addition, some of the items were not even warm as if they had been on the cart for a long period of time.  Next time I will head over to China town.
author: John G.

description: Although pricey, this is our go-to dim sum spot. They have great service, a clean restaurant and the food is always on point. We love their hot sauce too. Remember to get the staff to validate your parking ticket if you park in the parking garage then you get free parking(a rarity in the City).
author: Carey T.

description:
I come from New York, which has some of the best Dim Sum and Chinese restaurants, but this was still some of the best Dim Sum I've ever had.

Ignore the fact that there are many many white tourists eating here, it is still very high quality and authentic-tasting Chinese food (and I did see a fair share of Asian families, which helped make the place seem a bit more legit).

I think I might be willing to give it 5 stars if it wasn't so pricy. Plus, they charged for tea (!) which is pretty ridiculous at a Dim Sum restaurant.

Anyway, my wife and I had a pretty good feast, but ended up spending $80 before tip, which is an unheard of amount of money to pay for Dim Sum in New York. Here's what we got, and in the order we got them:
- Steamed BBQ Pork Rice Roll
- Baked BBQ Pork Buns
- Steamed Chicken Dumplings
- Peking Duck
- Sesame Balls
- Pan Fried Pork Dumplings
- Sweet Chicken in Foil
- Pistachio Ice Cream Pie
- Pan Friend Chicken Buns
- Shanghai Soup Dumplings

OK, I'll admit it's pretty touristy that we got the Peking Duck and the Pistachio Ice Cream Pie, but they were both still pretty good. And those two probably went a long way in jacking up the price of the meal. Looking back at that list, I guess that is quite a bit of food...but it still feels a little expensive. It's a good thing I'm allergic to shrimp, since that severely limits the dishes you can order at Dim Sum, otherwise I probably would've dropped $150 and gotten a nice stomach ache.

Being half Chinese and not knowing how to speak any Chinese, it was a nice welcome change from the good places in New York where the waiters and staff don't speak a lick of English, so I was able to get a straight answer when asking questions about what we were ordering. Service here was super polite compared to most Chinese restaurants I have been to, which also made for a very pleasant experience.
author: Mike C.

description:
There are tourist traps and then there's Yank Sing.  Having received such consistently high praise over the years, I wanted to give them another shot as it had been over a decade since I last ate here as a child with the family.

Clearly, there was a reason for the long hiatus because every single dish was mediocre at best.  The theme across the board seemed to be the use of unusually lean meats for the style of cuisine as everything from the siu mai to the seen jook geun was dry.  Of all the items, the xiao long bao turned out to be the best of the lot.  My issue lies in the abysmal quality-to-price ratio.  The bill worked out to be ~$90 for me and my parents and we didn't order a particular large amount of food either.  Be aware too that single orders of certain dishes come smaller than most Chinese restos, eg. 2 spring rolls per order versus 3 at most places, so ask if you're ever unsure.

Admittedly, the venue is on the more upscale side for dim sum and the servers can actually speak decent English.  That being said, I just can't fathom how the place can charge such egregiously high prices for run-of-the-mill fare.  It's not even worth one try as there's nothing truly different or particularly well done here.
author: Eric F.

description: My first time having Dim Sum here on a Saturday. First off, the food is always delicious here, but the price is astronomical! I was shocked when we got the bill! For four people, the bill was over $200!! Just for dim sum and one soft drink. Secondly, we were disappointed that we were seated outside in the overflow (if you've never been at the rincon annex, it's a food court). Yank Sing sets tables out there for overflow. We had reservations and requested to be seated in the restaurant. Not! I don't like the idea of sitting out there as people are wandering around and it's as though you're not eating at a restaurant. The service was good, but I'm going to stick to eating in Chinatown for dim sum...delicious and cheap!
author: Cathy D.

description:
As soon as I read that TimeOut named "Dine on dumplings at Yank Sing" the third best thing to do in SF, I practically ran to the Embarcadero to give it a whirl. My review? Not worth the hype.

-2 Stars because my food felt like it had been sitting all day, and I truly only enjoyed 1/3 of my plate

What I ordered: The Deem Sum Platter. I wanted an assortment to sample their menu. 

What I enjoyed: The Steamed Pork Bun and the dumplings.

What I wouldn't order again: The Spring Roll, the Seafood Siu Mye, or the Custard Tart

Would I come here again?: Nope, not for these prices!
author: Kat D.

description:
Went to Yank Sing to redeem a Christmas gift. The food was amazing and the service was spectacular. The fried shrimp, shrimp dumplings and siu mai were delicious. The surprise dish was the baked chicken buns. We could have eaten so many more but we're too full. It is very expensive BUT for a special occasion, we would definitely be back. Service and food is Flawless!!!
Thank you Yank Sing!!!! 
Ed is an excellent server. His technique is beyond what we have encountered in our most recent restaurant outings. He didn't miss a beat. Since we also dined there for valentines weekend, it was super busy by 10:30. I am sad that the most recent review I wrote was lost. He was so attentive and gracious and his service is a lost art. We will be back and surely request Ed.
The entire staff is very good as well but, Ed stood out.
author: Veronica L.

description: Food was good but expensive. Also they charge to refill drinks, which is just crazy to me, plus the glasses are so small. We got seated in an odd lil table on the side so took forever to wait on the carts to come to us.
author: Diane A.

description:
This is the type of place you have to try at least once.  Their dim sum is definitely of quality but like all the other reviews have mentioned - the cost does not justify what you're getting. Nowhere will you find a plate of four egg tarts for $12  or a single dumpling split in half for $6. If you plan on coming, I would advise that you not come on an empty stomach but rather for a late afternoon snack (they're open until 4pm on the weekends).  The restaurant itself is nice and clean but the service is on par with any other Asian restaurant which was surprising.  I also found it unsettling how it seemed like every server's mission was to get as many plates of dim sum on your table as possible.

This place will surely impress people who have never had dim sum before but most definitely not your grandma who has had many years of dim sum in her lifetime.
author: Michele L.

description:
Dim Sum is just mediocre here. Not sure why it has so many good reviews. I've enjoyed Dimsum all over Asia and the Bay Area. This place is just another dimsum place that lacks real and complex flavor. 

The Hao Gaw and Sui mai are ok. While ingredient is good quality, it lacks flavor and execution. One thing they got right, XLB is good. You get 6 pieces for $14. Yup, pricey but the XLB has balanced skin soup ratio.
author: Kim K.

description:
Traveled to San Fransisco to see the sites and taste the food. Our first stop was here to try what I heard was great Dim Sum. My taste buds were not disappointed. Everything from the Shanghai dumplings to the chicken feet was great. 
We told the hostess we would be returning the next day to start our second day out right. They did not disappoint. She found a seat on a very busy Sunday. Who does that anymore? 
The honey Prawns and Walnuts had a wonderful glaze and ended our meal pure satisfaction.  
When we return to SF for fun or business this will always be our first stop. Their wonderful hospitality and great dim sum is a city treasure.
author: Dan R.

description:
Very average dim sums. Much better choices can be found on Clement and even Chinatown. Super over paid for amount and quality of food. Better go to Jade. Also will get a much better view. 

While a few items were outstanding others were not.
author: Irina K.

description:
Out of a recommendation from a couple of friends, we visited here for a late lunch (and that was definitely one of the problems - 1:30pm) yesterday with a group of friends who went up to the Bay Area for the weekend.  While some of the dishes were good, the other dishes were served luke warm to cold to us (especially the shrimp dishes that were priced at an unjustifiable $10+ per plate).  I don't care how well your service is.  At your prices, you should NOT be serving fried dishes cold, even if it's AFTER the lunch rush.  In addition, if you're going to be charging over $10 for those small dishes, then I better get giant tiger prawns!

The Shanghai soup dumplings were fine, but not sensational to, again, justified the price.  I rather have them made to order instead of having sat on a dim sum cart for several minutes (the cooler they become, the less the chance they will burst with broth at the first bite into them).  

Coming from Los Angeles, and from the heart of the San Gabriel Valley where there are chock full of dim sum palaces galore, I was not impressed.  The Siu Mai looked woefully thin and undercooked.  Most of the other dishes did not "wow" me at all, and at their prices, I have to be "wow".  If it weren't for the fact that we were limited in time (having to head to Oakland Airport to catch our flight in the afternoon), I would have insisted that we make the trek over to Koi Palace in Daly City for better dim sum at a much cheaper price.  Obviously, the selection there would have been much much better.

At Yank Sing's prices, they should change their approach and sell dim sum to order.  At least it would make more sense to get each dish piping hot and fresh for the prices paid for them.
author: Sklar T.

description:
I have been to Dim Sum restaurants from the US to China. 
Yank Sing has some of the best quality I have had. YOU have to give this place a try.
Wait staff was excellent too. 
This place is soooo good, I am going to take my mom there.
author: Robert L.

description: Food was ok but the servers were rude!  Didn't have our reservation!  Very expensive.  $60 per person with no alcohol. I won't be back.
author: Stephen H.

description: Best Dim Sum ever!!  This is fine dim sum dining.  I've had dim sum in Hong Kong, Vancouver, NYC and in many different places in Frisco and by far, the best place!!  Yes, this place commands $€£¥ but, you're paying for quality not quantity.  It's not a place to go get a quick bite to eat.  If you want to treat yourself and someone special, this is the place.  I'm from LA, and now consider this place a must whenever I come back to Frisco.
author: S. C.

description: So good!!!!  I have been eating dim sum for over 15 years... best place ever.  So fresh. Get the soup dumping. Sea bass. Shimp dumpling. You will be in heaven! !
author: Jenny S.

description: The food is reasonable but don't bother reserving a table as that just means you'll have to wait slightly shorter than those who didn't reserve a table.  You'll still expect to wait 20-30 minutes.
author: Geoffrey C.

description: Best dim sum restaurant in the Bay Area. Hands down. My family has been going to Yank Sing ever since they were located on Battery Street so you know it's that good. Such good quality dim sum and great service here compared to other restaurants where service is usually lacking or rude. It's definitely pricey, but it's definitely worth it in my opinion. You pay for good quality and tasty food. Recommendations to try include siu mai, bean curd, phoenix tail, snap peas, and their steamed sio pao pork buns.
author: Jade G.

description:
crazy expensive for dimsum, BUT it is in FiDi and free parking with validation. Food was standard dimsum, nothing struck out as creative but at least they do make their selection taste 'cleaner' less greasy heavy as some places in Chinatown. They clearly target the more American crowd, all the waitresses speak relatively good English. 

Come when they open at 10am and you shouldn't have trouble getting a table on a weekend.
author: Angela L.

description: Got here a but later around the 2:00 hour so I avoided the lunch time rush. Dim sum here is on part with the likes of din tai fung and otbers I have tried over the years. Not too heavily greasy but still on the pricey side though that's what happens in the San Francisco area being rent is relatively much higher here.
author: kevin C.

description:
Still the best dim sum anywhere in Northern or Southern CA, Shocking that anyone who knows food could give it less than 5 Stars. That attests to the unreliability of Yelp Reviews.

I would avoid weekends. Long waits, they run out of many items early and the atmosphere is very manic. They do take reservations.

Everything is terrific and they are always updating their selections with new offerings. The Shanghai Soup Dumplings (Xiao Long Bao) are a recent addition and are more delicate and better tasting than Din Tai Fung (Seattle and LA anyway, maybe not Beijing), the worldwide go to place for soup dumplings, though very pricey at 6 for $12.

As always, you get what you pay for and Yank Sing, while pricey, is still the Gold Standard for dim sum. Cannot visit SF without at least 2 visits here,
author: Fred M.

description: Ate here while visiting friends, and boy howdy, I am glad that I did. Most everything we had was spot on and amazing, especially the soup dumplings and the pork buns! While this is a higher end dim sum restaurant, its worth the price. I would highly recommend making reservations, because this place fills up quick and you wouldnt want to miss out.
author: Tara R.

description:
Excellent fresh dim sum and old school trolley. Much better than HongKong.
Highlight is the chicken feet and sticky rice
author: Justin W.

description: We had a very enjoyable lunch here, mostly ordering soup dumplings. They were so fast, my 2- year-old gobbled them up, and it was walking distance from the ferry building. We'll be back!
author: K. D.

description:
Been coming to this location, for about 12 years and never had a bad meal, always order too much food, because they make it hard to resist. They have the routine down, hit you fast and hard with as many plates and steamer baskets of their delicious dumplings as they can before you realize you have ordered way too much. Slather it up with their chili garlic oil and its as good as Chinese gets....I could compare it to Din tai Fung, my other favorite dumpling house, but Yank Sing has the speed and variety, and a pretty good Shanghai dumpling themselves....
Love this place.....
author: Jonathan R.

description:
Honestly, the spectrum for dim sum is "bleh, why bother" (in Chicago where I live right now.. wahh!!) to "I LOVE asian food!" (basically everywhere else).  Most dim sum places fall in between those two points and as long as the wait isn't ridiculous and the prices are reasonable, I'm perfectly happy.  This happens to be one of those places.  

Make reservations if you want to avoid an unnecessary wait and we parked in a nearby lot which you can get validated parking for if you eat here.
author: Monica H.

description: Yank Sing is the best! You get what you pay for. Shanghai Dumplings are unbeleivable.
author: Ice B.

description:
Good over priced dim sum with good service and lots of options that aren't available at most places during dim sum. 

We came here with ten people , ordered a ton of the usual dim sum items as well as Peking duck, Xiao long bao, noodles and the pistachio ice cream cake. We were stuffed by the time we got though eating most ever thing in the table. The average bill comes out to 40 to 50 a person but always worth it for quality of the dim sum !

Come early to avoid a long wait during the weekend.
author: Kelly Y.

description:
went there with relatives from out of town (they chose it via Yelp reviews)  i wouldn't have made this choice, but went with them for dim sum on a sunday morning.   ambiance aside (white table cloths, clear glass tea pitchers, etc)  the food was starkly bad in comparison to hundreds of other places of much less cost.   2 indicators of good dim sum (basic) are siu mai and ha gow.  both should be "light and resilient" with juiciness and  a good tooth/mouth feel.  the skins shouldnt be heavy or thick, the filling flavorful.  on all counts,  yank sing's are terrible!!!! the siu mai were relatively small, densely packed and tough to chew, with little to no juice/moisture in the filling.  the skin was on the dried out side, and was chewy not soft.   likewise, the ha gow...  wow, how awful!!!  little round balls of rice dough skin that was not soft or moist with a filling of shrimp that was also dense and tightly packed, lacking any juiciness or moisture, or much shrimp taste!!!  how utterly disappointing but also insulting at $7.60 each order!!!!  
we ordered 3 orders of their seabass (2 honey glazed, 1 salt/pepper).. these were 2" cubes of seabass, cooked okay --nothing really outstanding--- but the insult again was the price   each was $21.99!!  oh, my mistake. the salt and pepper seabass ---smaller chunks, not a 2" cube-- was like $16!!  entirely worth passing on.
i saw one woman with the cart of beijing duck, preparing servings of that for other tables.  there was already a plate of the duck with square pieces of duck with skin on it, that she could put onto a serving dish, one piece per serving, with a bun, and accompaniments.  what was interesting was watching her fiddle with the squares of duck/skin  re arranging some skin on different pieces of duck, as if to give the smallest piece of duck possible for a serving before putting it on the serving dish..   cant say how it tasted, but for the price,  ($6.75!!!!)  PASS!

all in all, it was what i suspected it would be..  a waste of money and time (forgot to mention, the carts of dim sum didnt come around very quickly and the total assortment of dim sum was VERY LIMITED..  compared to almost all other places I've ever gone...    

yank sing is probably only for 'yanks' ......  never again.
author: dee c.

description:
Pricy, but a delicious dim sum spot! 

I tried the chrysanthemum tea, soup dumplings, steamed & baked bbq pork buns, shumai, stuffed tofu wrap, daikon radish cake, steamed chinese broccoli, honey walnut prawns, pan fried dumplings, and har gao. Out of these, there were three items that I wasn't really satisfied with taste-wise: the pan fried dumplings, which didn't have much flavour, and the shumai & har gao, which were smaller and less juicy than what I get in most dim sum places. I am most impressed by the look and presentation of the tea (which wasn't free ;P), and the fact that they served soup dumplings, which isn't a typical dim sum dish. In fact, they served a lot of dishes that aren't typical of dim sum. Price-wise, everything was pretty expensive but this venue is definitely cleaner and nicer than majority of the dim sum places in the area, if not the country.
author: Jennifer C.

description: I have been going to Yank Sing for about 20 years. My family takes special trips out to SF specifically to enjoy weekend dim sum. Although it can be a wait (luckily they take reservations), and it can be on the expensive side for dim sum, it is worth it in my opinion. Servers are always attentive and friendly. Everything I've ever had is great there, but new customers should check out a menu ahead of time because there is quite the variety to pick from! I would highly suggest you try Yank Sing at least once...you won't be disappointed!
author: Morgan E.

description:
I'm an adventurous eater, or at least I like to think I am.  

So, when given the option to have dimsum in San Francisco, I jumped at the chance. 

We came in during a busy lunch rush.  Nearly all the tables inside and outside were full, but we got lucky to get a big table in the back, near the kitchen .  
Before I could even get a look at what was going on around me, we had food on the table.   (One of the members of my party had been there before and she is a master at dim sum.)  

I was greeted by a few plates of the baked buns with a pork mixture inside.  Quickly, we had some sea bass wrapped in sweet potato and then deep fried.   Some steamed buns, shiu mai, some birdnest looking thing, Peking duck and shrimp balls followed quickly.    

I began stuffing my face, as fast as I could.  Every bite was better than the previous ones.   I asked for some hot tea.   A beautiful glass teapot with loose leaf jasmine tea was brought to the table.  It is a perfect complement to delicious food.

Our party ate until we couldn't see anymore.   There was so much food that we didn't even try half of what I saw pass by us on the carts.  

Despite the number of people and constant movement in the restaurant, I had no problem hearing the other people at the table.  It was amazing to me.  I thought I wouldn't be able to have a conversation, but I was able to easily speak.  

I daresay that this was the best meals I have ever eaten.
author: Leslie W.

description:
Yank Sing is a fun place to go for dim sum.  It's a very large restaurant with a hustle and bustle that most dim sum restaurants can't compete with - food is passing by at a frenetic pace.  The dim sum is good to quite good for most dishes but it is about as pricey as I've ever seen for a dim sum restaurant.  Generally it will be $40-$50 a person, which is a bit outrageous.  However it's a fun experience and not something you are going to do on a daily basis.

Are there better and less expensive places in S.F. for dim sum.  Yuuuuup.  But it's still a place I go every once in a while, especially with a group.
author: Josh D.

description: This isn't your normal restaurant where the waiters come and ask what you want, and that's all. No. At Yank Sing, the carts of food come to you and you get to pick and have as much as you want until you're done. That way, you can have a taste of everything on their menu. I saw many adverts and reviews for this restaurant on the Cooking Channel and here on Yelp. It was the first restaurant I went to on my trip to San Francisco. We had planned tons of tasty places. And no doubt was this a great start. The workers are so eager to serve the customers that we received food before we even got our water. And don't even mention the food. Some of the best Chinese food in the country is in the city of San Francisco. Some of their best items are: pork buns, potstickers, Peking duck, fried shrimp, and the Mandarin dumpings. I loved the idea of just ordering until you are satisfied. It makes the experience so much easier. And being a real lover of Chinese food, it was unbelievable. A must have for any resident or tourist in the area.
author: Elliot F.

description:
Good food for a good price.  Recommended.  

Note to the owners:  STOP putting every take out order into a bag, most people don't need one and it's a waste of environmental resources as well as profits.
author: J D.

description: Other reviews said it was too expensive and Yes it is expensive! But its good. If you want to go somewhere clean and great service and don't mind spending double then go. We ordered 4 tea which is $3 for each person. We got 8 things the bill was $109.00. When i go to Portland Oregon food quality is same half the price. Still I'm glad i tried it the food was good.
author: Pooh O.

description: Yum yum yum.... Super tasty dim sum. Very busy on Sunday for brunch, with long lines. If you can, try using their take out window and get out of there. The food is really good and fresh, but the wait was crazy.
author: Emma H.

description: Consistently better than average. But perhaps a little "American-ized" and quite expensive. Love it but may also try some more local fare next time.
author: Lauren C.

description:
Short Story:
A good place for Chinese though be prepared to pay a premium especially when ordering a la carte!

Long Story:
I came here twice for lunch and this place is generally packed!  I ordered to go and got one of the combinations.  The service here is fast...it needs to be that way to churn out its food.  If you order any a la carte items it does tend to be pricey, so be aware!

I'll have to try out their restaurant next time I am there.  This review is for their to go spot.
author: Michael W.

description: Okay, I wanted to love this place because all of my friends do. Buuuuuut, let me just start by saying that the atmosphere feels more like a mass production factory than a restaurant. We came New Year's Day with a group and I didn't like where we were sat which was next to the kitchen in the back. Servers were running in and out the door and at the end of the meal they were refilling the sauce jars on the table behind ours. So weird to do while we are eating! This restaurant is almost too big and the food was just okay for a dim sum restaurant. We felt the prices were also very high, we paid over $50 per person w/out drinks and left still hungry.
author: Sarah R.

description:
Very good Yum Cha!

Delicious steam noodles. Will definitely will recommend anyone who looking for a family brunch.

Free valid parking underground.
author: Tick J.

description:
My favorite place to get dimsum in SF!

Cons: okay this place is pretty pricey. Maybe 2-3 times more for the same dimsum at China town 

Pros: 1. the food beats the price! It is just damn good! 
2. You can speak in English! Which means you know what you are getting. They have an English menu and also the staff speaks English pretty well. 

Although they offer a wide variety of dishes, I would not get the entree dishes such as walnut shrimp or something similar that is over ten bucks for such a small portion ( get these some where else). Instead I would just focus on getting dimsum such as the shrimp dumpling, shanghai dumplings, pork shi mye etc... Or a slice of peking duck, still pretty pricey but may worth for a variety. 

And end the feast with sesame balls! So gooood!
author: Stella L.

description: Service is good, but too greasy for my liking. Had the green beans, pork soup dumplings, sesame ball, shrimp noodle roll, & salt and pepper seabass.  Couldn't eat more than 1 piece of each item...
author: Stella P.

description: it was good lot selection dimsum over rated place its ok over rated overpriced thats my opinion
author: Jane D.

description:
Came here because it was ranked number one on this ranking for dim sum we had seen on a website.

Once we sat down, (there wasn't that many people) workers walking around our carts kind of just shoved the food in our face before we had the time to check out the prices.
 
Although the food was quite yummy, the portions are rather small compared the prices labelled. I mean, if one tiny slice of Peking duck with a bun is 6.05 dollars...something is going on here. It was still quite yummy though , but would I come here again? Definitely not.

We had three people, all of which are not very heavy eaters (got to about 2/3 of the way full unlike my usual being stuffed from dimsum) and it was around $30 per person. A total of 90 bucks without tips included. Jesus Christ! 

If you do end up deciding to come here anyways, foods I liked:

- the porridge 
- the one slice of Peking duck with bun
- mango pudding was alright I suppose 

And that's about it. Everything else was pretty average and tasted like any other dim sum place I've ever been to.
author: Angela K.

description: There's a reason this place is an SF institution. I made an early lunch reservation here and by noon there was a line out the door. They have takeaway options and an informal dining space if you don't want to make a reservation and sit in the formal restaurant, which has the traditional dim sum carts but it really loud and cramped. While this is easily the most expensive dim dum I've ever had, it was also the most delicious and didn't leave me feeling bloated and greasy. I think this could be a really nice splurge meal for a big group, but with two people it's tough to maximize the experience and try everything without exploding. I definitely want to try the takeaway soon.
author: Rachel A.

description: On your own and craving dimsum? In SF I discovered Yank Sing and I'm very happy about it. They have a small bar and yes, it can be done. The carts come to you as usual and the bartender is very helpful. Also the women handling the carts basically take an order if you don't see what you like. Great service and delicious dimsum.
author: Mark B.

description:
I must admit that it's been a while since I visited Yank Sing To Go. I was just surprised with the following:

* I normally order the Yank Sing Express Lunch Combo.
* Was surprised that they increased their prices by almost $2. It used to be less than $8 for this combo.
* The increase in prices also meant less food given/ served. The portions of their chow mein was ridiculously lesser than before. I wouldn't have mind if the price increase meant having the same portions of food.

I know - it's SF but I probably won't be back - the food is just way too expensive!
author: Darwin T.

description:
I just had a dim sum religious experience! Holy crap.

First and foremost, order the XLB. The skin was thin, but stayed intact as I pulled each one out of the steamer and put it onto my spoon. The pork was succulent. The broth was rich. After taking a bite, my mom looked like a child who had just been given a puppy on Christmas morning; a facial expression I'm certain was mirrored on my own face. My advice is to get two orders. We unabashedly ingested the first batch in about two seconds flat, then immediately wanted more, more, MORE!

You'll also want to order their shrimp cheong fun, which had a surprising and delightfully complex flavor, and their pork siu mye. Skip the potstickers.

A few other pointers:
- Yank Sing is expensive. It's worth every penny, but c'mon, you're in the FiDi, what did you expect?
- To those who are worried about long wait times: show up right when they open and you'll be seated immediately.
- They will validate parking for the Rincon Center parking garage.
author: Rachel L.

description:
Food is mediocre, not the best

Service is okay, hit and miss

They do have Parking Validation for Ricon Parking Garage

Some reasons feels like a better feature of McDonald
author: Andy W.

description:
This restaurant sort of presents itself as a very classy dim sum restaurant and it succeeds in doing so, as evidenced by the long waits that form quickly after they open at 11 in the morning. My parents and I were in the city for other business and finished at around 11:15am, so we decided to come here for their lunch. 

The food is DEFINITELY really good. My family has always been rather picky about the quality and texture of buns, noodles, and skins of dumplings (my parents tell me it's in our blood), and we loved ALL of the steamed goods they had to offer us. We got the steamed pork bun, shanghai dumplings, mango pudding, and other things whose names I'm still unsure of after a lifetime of eating them. Everything we got was delicious, though.

As other reviewers have mentioned, this delicious dim sum definitely comes with a hefty price tag. However, the service is exceptional for a Chinese restaurant. The waiters are all connected through an earpiece and microphone so asking one waiter for something is like asking all waiters for something and you get it quickly. In addition, their varied clientele means that all the waiters are pretty fluent in both English and Chinese, which makes it helpful for an American Born Chinese like me where I speak lots of Chenglish.

Helpful tip to people who DON'T live in the city: they have a parking garage (look for Rincon garage), and Yank Sing will VALIDATE the $30 parking fee. This might also account for their expensive prices, but as a South Bay resident, it's very helpful.
author: Maureen C.

description:
How have I not written a review for Yank Sing yet! My family has been coming here for many years for Dim Sum on weekend mornings.  The flavors are bright, fresh and clean which is tough to find in many Dim Sum places.

The soup-filled Shanghai dumplings are always a great way to start a Sunday morning.  My wife loves the various vegetarian dumplings on offer.  When my son was younger, I had to keep a close eye on his Peking Duck consumption since he had the habit of ordering more every time the cart passed by.  At $8 per 1oz slice it is fairly easy for a growing boy to consume $80 worth of the stuff!

My tip is to always call for a reservation even for same day reservations.  This will save you a 1+ hour wait on the weekends.  Yank Sing is a mad house with tourists and locals alike waiting for tables.

Yes, it is pricey so be prepared for $30-$40 with person without drinks...
author: Lance W.

description:
Plus one star for really amazing tea and the baked sea bass. While I get that rent is pricey, $80 for dim sum for two is steep when we had 5 items although one of the items was $20...

Hey, it's nice to know that 

1) Really literally everyone speaks English and Cantonese while some speak in Mandarin for ease of ordering. 

2) The restrooms are always clean.

3) The wait isn't really long...ever.

4) Your whole party need not be present prior seating.

5) Service is impeccable-tell one person you need something and voila a few moments later it's there even if via another person.

Still not at 4 stars since the food is just overall average...with the exception of the sea bass... ;)
author: Jennifer Y.

description:
Absolutely the best! Do not be deterred by reviewers describing the prices here. 

Delicious: Shanghai dumplings, all steamed vegetables dumplings with various ingredients and flavors, pork buns, sesame balls... I could go on. I have not had one item here I didn't just sigh over.

Atmosphere: Beautiful dining room inside, and very busy for lunch--yet it is large, so I have only waited once with a large group. With two people I have never waited. You can sit at the bar, which I did once by myself, but it feels less leisurely. These servers work hard and are helpful! You may have to raise your hand up high sometimes to get their attention, so do that, if you are not in the direct path of their cart. 

Just go!
author: Cleo B.

description:
Expensive but delicious, even for this vegetarian.

Not many items for vegetarians, but they were all good for me.  There were three kinds of vegetarian dumplings:  spinach (yum), vegetable (yum), and shitake mushroom (yum).  There was a vegetable roll rolled in a thick rice paper wrapper.  There was a delicious salad.  There were snap peas and Chinese broccoli (the broccoli was my least favorite).  The jasmine tea was great too.

Festive and fun.

My three other friends also ate scallop dumplings, pork shumai, fried crab claws, sticky rice with pork, and some other dim sum delights of which I'd never partake.

$45 per person.  Like I said, not cheap.  Still, a wonderful way to spend the last brunch of the year.
author: SalsaBoy S.

description: Some of the best dim sum in the nation. Also they have very nice options for vegetarians.
author: Soul S.

description:
Wow, another shocker:  I haven't reviewed Yank Sing until now.   I've been here so many times, how can I have forgotten this jewel?

I've been here strictly for Dim Sum and here's a few of my favorite items:  The Shanghai Dumplings are mouthfuls of pure joy.  I ordered yesterday the Seabass Roll for the first time ever and, while it's made to order, the resulting dish was sublime with some of the freshest and tastiest seabass, deep-fried no less, I've ever tasted.   My wife and I also order their Szechuan Chicken pretty much every time.   It's quite tasty.   We've had hit-or-miss experience with the Peking Duck.   When it's juicy and tender, it's truly delectable.   If, however, you come in on an off-day, you'll find the duck dry and chewy.   Other dishes we often get:  Potstickers, of course, Pork Shu Mye, Crispy Green Beans.   In fact, the list goes on and on...

We usually get tea to accompany our wonderful lunch, though I'll often decide to throw caution to the wind and get a glass of Chardonnay or two.    What the hell, right?  You only live once.
author: David O.

description:
We were a group of 7 and had a reservation for 12:30pm on Sunday at the RINCON Center location.  When we checked in, were told we would have the next table.

Over an hour later, one of our group had to insist on a table strongly as we watched tables of eight getting seated repeatedly for the last hour, as we had a four year old that was getting cranky (as well as some of the adults in our group).  The hostess was not happy at all.  But, we finally got seated in the center of the food court at a table set for eight.  My very strong recommendation is keep your reservation for 8 even if you have someone not able to join you.  For them to make the adjustment down to 7 is not something they know how to do, at least at the RINCON Center location.

Maybe had to do with the Chinese New Year celebrations, but they did not explain anything so it was a bit uncalled for.

Finally sitting down, the food was very good, but pretty Americanized.  We love dim sum and have had fabulous experiences through San Francisco and Los Angeles.  The food was good but we never saw the majority of the carts in the center food court area of this location. 

This restaurant was picked because of friends who loved the Financial District location.  They had suggested we go to that location, but the earliest reservation time was the RINCON Center, which might have been a mistake.

I would suggest instead just heading to Chinatown.  There are plenty of excellent options with no wait.
author: Emily B.

description: Weird location.  Inside a building of some sort.  You'll find the restaurant based on signs pointing around.  Luckily, parking on the weekend is free to come here.  Weekdays, you pay per hour.  Good food, but pricey.  When people said it's pricey, they are speaking the truth.  Very clean and higher quality of product.  Some dim sum places you question what meat you are eating.  Here the shrimp or pork had bigger pieces of meat versus the ground up mystery meat you're use too.  They serve peking whole, so someone is pushing a cart with a duck ready to be cut, along w/ warm buns and scallions.  They assemble and place the sauce on the side.  You'll see shocked once you get the tab if you're use to the prices you pay in chinatown!
author: Ivy T.

description: Being discriminated against your own race in this so call reputable dim sim restaurant, they will seat 2 people arrived without half of their party there that is Caucasian  but wouldn't seat someone apparently their own race with RESERVATION  and require us to have half our party there before we can be seated. Ended up we are almost done and the table next to us with the Caucasian couple is still waiting for their party to arrive which was seated earlier than us.  Can't believe this kind of behavior is acceptable anywhere in this country.
author: K W.

description:
Having not been to Yank Sing in over ten years, I was eager to return to try their dim sum.  In recent years, they've received a lot of notable press, especially regarding their "xiao long bao" or soup dumplings that Patricia Unterman raved about.

Their Rincon Center location (off Spear Street) is definitely their flagship and very popular with tourists.  The glass open-aired building with the indoor waterfall is impressive and Yank Sing is the epicenter of activity here.

We put down our name and only had to wait for about 15 minutes.  With plentiful tables both in the atrium and inside the main restaurant, the turnover appears quick.

Multiple food carts soon passed by and I was thrilled when the first food cart was their famed soup dumplings.  Truth be told, they are well aware of the positive press as that cart would pass by our table at least five more times throughout our meal.  Our dim sum: 

Har Gow 
Chives dumpling 
Dumpling #3 (tasted similar to first 2)
Fried taro 
Deep Fried Crab Claw 
Fried shrimp 
Bacon wrapped shrimp with green onion  
Xiao long bao
Peking Duck

Overall, we found the items at Yank Sing to be solid, with an occasional one that was excellent.  The xiao long bao, in particular,  deserves the rave reviews.  It was close to perfect and the thin skin is extremely hard to find in the Bay Area.  As well, it had a soup quantity that puts most dumpling places to shame.  

The crab claw was excellent as well.  Lots of fresh crab meat and a nice crispy fried exterior.  

Other than those two items, I thought everything was similar to what I'd find at other recommended dim sum places: Cityview (SF), Koi Palace (Daly City), Hong Kong Saigon (Sunnyvale), ABC Seafood (Foster City) or Joy Luck (Cupertino).

The real shocker of the meal came when I decided to ask how much an order of Peking Duck would cost.  The server comes to your table and asks how many slices you would like.  Little did I know, each SLICE of peking duck costs $5.40.  Are you kidding me????  How much is the entire duck?????  $100!?!  

Once I realized how pricey this item was, I perused the menu for other prices of dim sum items: 

A slice of honey glazed seabass (dim sum portion) -  $18!  Are you serious!?!?  How much does the entire fish cost?  $300?!?!?  

The famed xiao long bao -  ~$12 for 6 dumplings!  For reference, the more famous Din Tai Fung averages $7-9/order and they sell a truffle xiao long bao (available only overseas) that costs about $14/order.  Yank Sing may be among the better xiao long bao I've had in the Bay Area, but the price premium definitely changes my rating.  

The final sticker shock, of course, came with the total bill.  For 3 people, our bill was easily north of $100.  For lunch and simple dim sum.  We didn't have lobster.  We didn't have abalone or high end seafood.  Heck, the xiao long bao isn't even the crab meat versions many restaurants have.  With so many other options in SF and beyond, I can't justify those prices for dim sum. 

The service for such a pricey establishment isn't particularly stellar either.  We had to flag down waiters to remove our empty plates and bamboo steamers and after we asked for the bill and gave our credit card, the whole transaction seemed like it took 15+ minutes, even though the lunch crowds had clearly died down with the late hour.  

Take home message: Yank Sing is pretty good, but those prices are ludicrous.  Call it the tourist tax; foreigner fee; hype pricing; marketing premium.....just please don't call it a fair value.  I enjoyed my meal here, but at those prices, there are too many options and too many cuisines to choose from.

Yank Sing accepts credit cards, including American Express.
author: Randy F.

description: I grew up eating dim sum my while life so when my husband asked me to do dim sum, I was very hesitant.  Since we were in San Francisco, of course I have to give this place a try.  I was actually really good.  I liked the fact that the had soup dumplings.  It was good but I definitely won't go out of my way to go to this place again.
author: Rena H.

description:
We have eaten here before and although the experience is something you should do at least once, I find that after the 2nd time I don't think we need to go back here.

The food is very good, but I think the same quality can be found elsewhere for less in Chinatown.
author: E A.

description:
Delicious dim-sum, with 80's luxurious interior, 
And everything is going fast(I love it) but this place is bit loud I feel like traveling in China, Unique.
author: Laura S.

description: This is my second time here for lunch and I really like it! We came a little bit after 2PM. Thank god, no wait! The food is delicious, the waitress is very attentive, and unlike most Chinese restaurants, the atmosphere is clean and modern. We ended up about $50 per person feeling full and satisfied. Well, that is what we expected. We will be back for sure.
author: Yuan C.

description:
This is my favorite dim sum spot in the Bay area.  I'm surprised the ratings aren't higher, but oh well, more for me!!!

Love everything here.  The soup dumplings are amazing.  All the dumplings are amazing.  I wish they would open one in LA, so I wouldn't have to come all the way to SF to get my Yank Sing fix.  This is my number recommendation for any friends traveling to SF.
author: Denise M.

description: Ok quality but 2x more expensive than other comparable places.  For this price, you can easily get really high quality delicate dim sum elsewhere.
author: Xinchen Q.

description:
This review is for Yank Sing's famous Dim Sum

During weekend, the line at Yank Sing for their Dim Sum maybe longer than any other places but it worths the wait. From food presentation to taste, Dim Sum exceeds my expectation. I once was told that in order to judge whether or not a Dim Sum place is good s by examining their most basic dish, Har Gow (aka. Shirmp Dumplings). And from my experience, all the dishes were so great, not soaked in grease like any other places. So, if you are in San Francisco, put Yank Sing on the must-try list and you will not be disappointed.
author: Tai V.

description: Just another over priced dim sum place with average quality of food. The juice inside Xiao long bao is too greasy. The only dish (among others we've tried) that stands out probably is the sea bass.
author: Carrie Z.

description: Best BEST BEST Dim Sum I have ever had the pleasure of having and I have grown up on dim sum. The Sea bass dish was one of the best places I have ever had in my life. The jok soup was dreamy as well as the shrimp dumplings and shrimp rice noodle rolls.
author: Jennifer S.

description: Yank Sing did not honor our reservation. We were asked to wait "at least 20 minutes" and, when we mentioned that we shouldn't have to wait given that we had a reservation, the server just shrugged and said "everyone has a reservation here" without even bothering to seem apologetic. When I pay upward of $50/pp I expect to be seated immediately when I have a reservation. If the restaurant is having an exceptionally busy time I expect them to, at the very least, be apologetic about it. Other dim sum places in the city are far cheaper and I'm ok paying more at Yank Sing, but I expect service similar to what I get at any other restaurant where I'm paying​ this much. Ended up getting a a last minute reservation at Coqueta just a block or so away, which was honored with a big smile. I will not be going to Yank Sing again.
author: Shantanu S.

description: Great location if you are looking for an authentic dim sum restaurant in financial district.  We were referred to this place by our friends wanting to spent a Sunday downtown but also taking our son down to the ferry building.
