They validate parking for 3 hours which is great cuz we got to finish dim sum in an hour and had an extra 2 hrs to walk along the water front.  This was especially convenient since our son is only a year old and we prefer to haul his stroller along and can park the car for free.  The restaurant also serves dim sum in the atrium which provides a lot of room for my sons stroller, making it very family friendly.
author: Johnny C.

description: OMG!!! Easily the best dumplings I've ever had. Get here early cos they run out of certain dumplings pretty quickly. I can't remember all the different kinds we tasted but they were all delicious. Only reason I didn't give it 5 stars is because of the price.
author: Varun K.

description: Visited the restaurant today. Frankly very disappointed. This is supposed to be a dim sum restaurant and people with carts are expected to come around. It was a struggle even to get their attention. Never again, there are too many options in San Francisco for dim sum to submit myself to this miserable service again.
author: Manny M.

description: Dear Yank Sing, I want to thank you for the delightful meal and excellent service that Yank SIng provided to our association luncheon for about 150 people on April 29. I would also commend the professionalism and excellence in hospitality that Vera, who helped us organize and plan the meal, demonstrated from day one. I whole-heartedly recommend Yank Sing.
author: Jeanne A.

description: What a wonderful recommendation from a friend on the best DimSum in SF! We loved everyone who worked there & we were full but not overly stuffed when we left. Can't wait to go back!
author: Jessica K.

description:
I heard this place was expensive, like $25 per person. There's no price listed, so I just trusted what I heard. Holy cow I was wrong. I somehow ate twice that amount, without even having anything with special ingredients or the fish dishes. o_O

It's so delicious though. The skins on the dumplings are all super chewy but thin, and the fillings tasted very fresh. The shrimps are a good size but not mutantly scary huge. The fried dishes are all also very well done, without being too greasy or heavy (taro was especially awesome). The xlb is pretty good, and the baked pork buns are some of the best I've had.

Pretty much all the dim sum was as good as anything I've tried in Hong Kong. And yes it's soopah exbensive, but I guess it's still cheaper than having to buy a flight all the way to HK!
author: Monte H.

description:
No one goes to a dim sum restaurant for the service. 

From the start, it was "meh". We had a party of 6; the hostess said she could seat us, but we'd have to "give back the table in one hour"... Fair enough, dim sum doesn't take that long to eat, but she could've said it in a more professional way. 

As we were being seated, I couldn't help but notice that the hostess let all the servers know to bring food to our table ASAP. Kind of saying, "let's get them in and out". Not really complaining because it definitely got our food to us faster. 

One thing I will mention is the Peking Duck. It's $6 for just one piece of duck, but it was so worth it. Everything else was mediocre, but the xiao long bao (spelling?) is worth a mention. 

However, next time I visit SF, I'll skip this place and head to the dim sum restaurant President Obama eats at.
author: Elizabeth N.

description: Ate dim sum for light lunch. You can get carried away with picking up items as the carts make its rounds. Most everything chosen was excellent. The snap peas were stringy and hard to chew / swallow. Restaurant could have stringed / remove string from the snap peas before cooking. Free parking on weekends and validated parking week days. Place was reasonably clean. Crowded on weekend and need to get on waiting list. A little pricier than other lesser dim sum restaurants. Average about $5 for every item. Bill for 3 light eaters was $98 tax and tip.
author: Clifford W.

description:
This place would be a 5 star if it weren't so expensive. 
The dim sum is better that anything you could have ever imagined tasting anywhere in Northern California or the world for that matter. I've traveled to many parts of Asia and this is the best dim sum I've had anywhere.
Expect to pay about $25 -30 per person. Worth every bite!!!
If you're visiting SF, you have to stop by this place.
You won't be disappointed. Don't bother going if you're frugal because you won't get full and be wishing for more.
author: K T.

description:
Food:
No complaints here. As expected of an authentic dim sum restaurant, the food was prepared very well across the board. My favorites were their home-made Shanghai dumplings and the cheong fun (rice noodles, shrimp, and soy sauce). For dessert, the sesame balls and mango pudding rounded out my meal perfectly.

Service:
Again, relatively good. Since we came in on the 4th of July, there was certainly a large population of customers in the restaurant; however, the food was still promptly served to each table, and it doesn't take long to try all the dishes that you want. One of the most impressive points of notice was how coordinated the servers were. When one member of my party ordered something that the cart was out of, the server immediately phoned a different cart and smoothly presented the missing dish. Although most of the servers don't speak fluent English, they genuinely try to be attentive and helpful in any way they can.

Pricing:
As you would expect in San Francisco, the food is extremely expensive. Dishes run between an understandable $5 and a ludicrous $21 (for the sea bass). Most of the dishes are also relatively small, further compounding the costliness of the restaurant. We spent $30+ for 5 thin pieces of Peking duck, whereas a whole duck would be cheaper at other places. As good as the food is, I am still unsure as to whether or not it warrants the price. This is by far the main flaw of the restaurant and keeps it from attaining higher marks.

Overall Experience:
All in all, Yank Sing is truly a great dim sum restaurant for the Bay Area that offers an authentic taste of Asian appetizer style dishes. While the verdict is out on the high prices, if you are expecting and willing to spend big, I doubt you will be disappointed.
author: Connor V.

description: Absolutely the best authentic dim sum I've ever had. Lots of variety. A little bit of a wait sometimes but delicious food. You have the option to get the carry out which is just as fresh and gorgeous. Such friendly and efficient staff as well - promise you'll want to go back again.
author: Richard H.

description:
Best place for dim sum in SF. A little pricey but refined. Nice place to take someone you like.

Must try:
Skinny noodles with onions
Pork dumplings
Soup dumplings
Cabbage slaw salad with pecans/grapefruit
author: Livia K.

description: We've experienced dim sum at a number of locations throughout the Pacific Northwest.  None has matched the quailty, consistency and service of Yank Sing!
author: M K.

description:
For Dim Sum, the quality of the ingredients is impeccable. But even though they give you a price list and you go into it with your eyes wide open, the final bill is always way more than you thought it would be. That tiny plate you just snarfed down was $12.50.

Lather, rinse, repeat.

It happens so fast.
author: Brian B.

description:
Meeting some friends here for the dim sum on a Saturday morning.  The Shanghai dumplings were the only ones that really tasted good. The others were okay. Very disappointed with their har gao and shumai. Their chili paste/oil was good, though. Service was good, but a very long wait to get the check. 
Had a lot better dim sum somewhere else.
author: Fran S.

description: I've been eating at Yank Sing for several years. Went for dim sum brunch last Sunday and I wasn't disappointed. Service was great; very attentive staff. All the food choices we selected were tasty: BBQ steam buns, pork sui mie, soup, sticky rice with chicken in a banana leaf. We topped off the meal with egg custard tarts fresh from the oven. Some items were pricey but I expected that. Left stuffed but satisfied.
author: Gina R.

description:
I could never imagine dim sum to be so expensive until I took a look at their prices. 

Yank Sing offers high quality dim sum products, clearly containing fresh ingredients and also including a few less traditional items including miso sea bass. 
Some of the items I enjoyed here included their lotus leaf wrapped sticky rice, their miso sea bass, their various veggie dishes, xiao long bao (shanghai dumplings), and their mushroom he feng.

A few issues with the service:
As with some other dim sum places, the waiters / waitresses operate separately from the servers. In order to get food orders, help, and the like, you have to wave down a particular waitress, which can be hard to do when they cover more tables than they can handle.
We ordered noodles, which did not arrive within half an hour. We checked with our waitress only to find out that she failed to input our order. That was quite the disappointment, and we didn't even receive an apology.

Overall:
4 stars for the good food
2 stars for the prices and the service

A few things to note:
Be ready to spend $5-10 per dish, which is 2-3 times more than other dim sum places.
Parking can be validated in their parking lot! (It may still be difficult to find a spot in the lot however)
author: Michael L.

description:
Recommended by my buddy Christian, as good or better than Capital Seafood in Orange County, but a little pricey.  We got there a little late, so they were already out of the Peking duck bao, but everything else we had was great.  Plenty of carts to deliver fresh food from the kitchen, everyone was friendly.  We did have some issued getting our beverages refilled.  Id come back for sure. 

Steve out
author: Steve M.

description:
We got there at 10:00 am (their opening time) on a Sunday and already there was a long line of people waiting.  We didn't have reservations but we were able to get seated within 5 mins of waiting in line.  All the staff spoke English well and the restaurant, including the restrooms were very clean.  Everything we ordered was absolutely delightful. We loved the Shanghai soup dumplings!  We would have preferred Chinese broccoli with oyster sauce served hot instead of chilled.  There's nothing like a plate of greens with sizzling oil on top with sautéed garlic!  They charge for tea ($2 per person) which I thought was unusual (and not really cool) for a Chinese restaurant.   
As for price, yes it is very expensive for dim sum. $14.50 for six very small pieces of dumplings, etc.   
Expect to pay at least double what you would at other dim sum joints. 

Hint:  the take out counter just to the right of the restaurant has a great sampling deal. I think it was $14.50 for 11 pieces of their best selling dim sum.
author: E C.

description: This place has decent dim sum but their prices are 3x every other dim sum place.  It's made to rip off non-Chinese people.  When a lunch dim sum bill comes out close to $50 per person without ordering special fancy dishes something is VERY wrong.  Save your money and go somewhere else.
author: John P.

description:
Worse dim sum I have had in years. It is not authentic dim sum.  It is also the most expensive dim sum I have had.  Took out dim sum for 4 of us and the bill was $127.  My brother took the bart to come all the way over to eat with me and even he said it's the worse dim sum he has ever had.
I will never go there again and neither should anyone that knows what good dim sum is.  Ladies are rude too at the take-out counter.

I am from Honolulu where the dim sum is so much better, more authentic and reasonably priced.
author: Bev C.

description:
The quality of the dim sum is outstanding here!

Delicious, a lot of options, cart service and full bar. Loved it!

Definitely expensive (was $70 per person with cocktails and tax)....but it's San Fran and this is a very nice, upscale, spotlessly clean place..will be back during next visit.
author: Mary S.

description: so the food is great but the service can be a little better. last time i was here my waiter sam completely ignored me several times and when i finally  got his attention he was walking away as i spoke. i eventually got the attention of a woman named Kelly and she got him to finally give us our check. we only got a few small items but were there for over a hour because we couldn't get his attention but the food is so amazing it almost made up for it completely. the woman at the front are organized as well and very gracious
author: Veronica T.

description: Good dim sum but super expensive. I've never had to pay so much money for dim sum before. I guess that's normal in the financial district.
author: Tina C.

description: Service was good but food was way overpriced unless you are willing to pay a lot of money for Chinese food. I was visiting from Kansas and I meant to go to China Town to eat good dimsum for a fair price and didn't realized I ended up downtown San Francisco and yes I ended up shelling $130.00 for the FF: 1 ea combo fried rice, 1ea pork shomai 2ea shrimp shomai 1ea  mushroom  shomai 1 order hit tea 2 order  egg custard 1 ea project bun  anyways that what I pretty Uchiha ordered but I guess when you are eating at a Michelin rated restaurant it comes with the price.  BTW way to clarify 1ea means one plate. Dimsum comes in small plates containers and 4 pieces per plate average qty.
author: Capi C.

description:
I came to Yank Sing to have lunch with some members of my family who I have not seen in ages.  When my cousin and I arrived 10 minutes before they opened, a long line had already formed.  Fortunately my sister came even earlier, so she was third in line.  Our group also had a reservation.  Score!

Once we were seated, our server asked us what kind of tea we wanted.  What?  You just don't serve everybody oolong?  I love a place that serves more than one kind of tea!
 
When I go to a dim sum house, there are two dishes I use to rate the kitchen:

1.  Har Gau (shrimp dumplings)
2.  Siu Mai (pork dumplings)

I have been eating these two dishes since I was kid, so I am definitely qualified to judge their quality.

The menu at Yank Sing is comparable to most other dim sum restaurants, as far as the number of items offered goes.  What sets them apart is their ingredients.  Yank Sing uses higher quality meats, and you can taste the difference.  I certainly did in the two items above.

One of my other favorites is the deep fried taro root.  I like it served with the insides molten hot, fresh out of the kitchen.  It was served hot, but really hot.  It still tasted wonderful and also just a little better than at other dim sum restaurants.

Yank Sing also offers daily specials, but we didn't try any of them after looking at the prices.  This is not a cheap place to eat, but it is definitely worth it on special occasions.

My advice to future weekend diners: get a reservation, and come early.  This place is popular and fills very quickly.  If you are still in line once the initial wave of diners has been seated, you must wait for the entire restaurant to finish eating before a table opens up.  That will take a while.

If you don't want to wait for a table or would rather eat at home, there is take-out available next door.  But I confess I have never tried it.  I always leave Yank Sing full!
author: The Bottomless Pi T.

description: While this is definitely more on the expensive side of Dim Sum...it is also worth it 100%!  The food is really great quality and tastes delicious.  I have tried other Dim Sum places and something is usually questionable...but not here!  They are always crowded (no matter what day or time) for a reason - the food is amazing!
author: Josette S.

description:
This restaurant was recommended by our concierge at the Ritz Carlton.  It did not disappoint!!  The sea bass was amazing!!!  traditional dim sum, served from carts...
I kept reading other reviews about how pricey it was, our receipt was very reasonable.  Would definitely go back!!
author: Catherine C.

description:
Good food but hold on to your pocket book. 

Unless you want to shell-out $50 per person for lunch sans booze, I'd be very carful what you order and ask twice about the cost. It seems English comprehension is selective by staff and determined by the question. 

Pluses: it's unlikely you will get ill from the food and it's fast and can be fun.
author: John S.

description:
As long as you are prepared for dim sum on the expensive side, and (generally) a long wait...you will not be disappointed by Yank Sing.  We dined as a party of five (my wife and I and three kids under the age of 10)...and we all walked away LOVING Yank Sing, craving to come back soon, each of us incredibly satisfied and loving their unique and tasty dim sum.

We read the reviews about the large crowds, so we showed up early on a Sunday morning (with no reservation) around 10:30am, and were seated in less than 3 minutes.  The carts started surrounding the table and we happily dug into the best dim sum we have ever experienced.  

Friendly, helpful, attentive service. Carts endlessly came around and if you didn't want anything from their cart the first 2 times, they didn't incessantly ask you each time they rolled around.  Staff were attentive - and as soon as you raised your hand, someone appeared to answer your questions or serve you food.  

We must have tried a dozen different kinds of dumplings...our favorites included...shrimp dumplings, shui mai pork, bao, and chive dumplings were AWESOME!!

Worth a visit!  Get there early...and go wild...everything is worth trying, and is outstanding!
author: Gary W.

description:
When we asked our San Francisco friends where should we go for great dim sum, only one name was repeated over and over: Yank Sing. It's reputation clearly precedes it and after careful scrutiny on Yelp, a visit was clearly warranted. Also, it is a Michelin-star restaurant! Looking back, it was decent. It was good dim sum, stellar service, and a hefty price tag.

The menu showcases the same dim sum that you would expect. The steamed char siu bau was good with a very well-steamed, but not gummy bun with seasoned char siu pork that was well done. The fried wontons were still warm, but not excessively hot and had that crisp exterior that one desires. The taro dumplings were quite good, but could have used just another hit of salt, while the shrimp dumpling might have had just a tad too much.

Who doesn't like Peking duck? Well, Yank Sing didn't disappoint with a very well executed duck set between the steamed bun and green onions and sauce. Their Shanghai dumpling were fantastic, however be careful with the hot soup! The balance of flavors with the broth and bits of meat were fantastic. Definitely a must-have when you go.

Service is stellar and the wait for items were never long. It was quite a different experience form the neighborhood spots where yelling becomes more common then service with a smile. It was quite refreshing to not have the teapot or water glasses go empty and have food arrive in a nice orchestration to fill our stomachs.

Price is on the tad higher side, however isn't insanely pricey. That being said, it definitely is a little more than what you would expect. I guess you have to pay for the rent and all the extra service?

Definitely was a great place to experience and the food and service clearly are what you are going their to experience...The flavors might make you go eh? It was ok.
author: Chad Y.

description:
This is the bigger of the two Yank Sing's for dim sum.  Make a reservation as this place is hopping on the weekends.  This one is nice as they have indoor seating and an expanded outside area into the Rincon Center.  No wonder this is a dim sum institution because it is some of the best dim sum I've had!  

We had: 

Hao gao (shrimp dumplings, good standard always to start with)
Shui mai
Shiitake dumpling
Chow fun with shrimp (always a favorite!)
Greens (need to have this for vegetable balance)
Turnip cake (nicely cooked, good taste)
Sea bass (cooked oh so perfectly, fall away tender, loved this!!)
Taro (I always look for this, nicely fried and tasty)
Egg custard tart (this is the best egg custard tart I've had - yummmmy!)

Service was good and timely.  They coordinate well and are responsive to requests for specific dishes, water, tea.  I cannot wait to come back!!
author: Maile N.

description:
Summary: Overpriced dim sum in fancy setting perfect great for dim sum newbies with cash to burn.

I came for lunch with a few colleagues.  We ordered the typical dim sum items (xiao long bao, shao mai, shrimp dumplings, a veggie and etc).  Overall, total miss on flavor and texture.  The XLB, shao mai, dumplings and potstickers were very bland.  Based on that experience, I'd recommend diners to avoid items that involves ground meat.  Additionally, the sauce for the vegetable was too sweet.  It's hard to believe that Yank Sing was so far off the mark in terms of preparation and taste for basic dim sum.  Perhaps, they've decided to adapt their dishes to sheltered palates?  I am still scratching my head about their raves in the press and by food critics--yes, it's that bad.

I gave them 2 stars.  One for ok service and another for hot tea at the right temperature--hot.  

Definitely not worth the calories.
author: Amy J.

description: Wonderful dim sum just near the financial district.  great food in a bustling restaurant that you have to pay a bit more for this kind of quality.
author: Jeff G.

description: Awesome food but super pricy! Ive eaten at alot of dim sum places but the food here definately beats the rest. Service was outstanding. Beautiful place to eat dim sum. They also provide validation for parking. They do provide pricing for the dishes so you're not surprised when you get the bill. For my boyfriend and I, we spent $80 just for lunch. It was a splurge but worth the experience.
author: Vy V.

description:
I haven't been to Yank Sing since way back in my SF party days with my posse. We would meet up here on a Sunday afternoon about 2pm, after seeing each other the Saturday night before about 2am closing down the clubs, if not 3:30am after a late night bowl of noodles.  

That was before Yank Sing and Yank Sing2 (the take-out little sister, not to be confused with Swing Out Sister, the British singing group of about the same time) moved to Rincon Annex, which used to be the old Bulk Mail processing center for San Francisco. Now it is a boutique food court with a 3 story dripping fountain in the middle surrounded by a marbled wall atrium. 

Yank Sing was always known by the hardcore Chinese Dim Summers (not to be confused with the hard core Wannabe Donna Summers, R.I.P.) as over-priced and not that great, while the Business and Caucasian crowd thought it was the best Yum Cha experience this side of Hong Kong, where most had never been, or if they had, went to similar over-priced places. Maybe that is why it is called Yank Sing, because it makes Caucasians howl with delight?

Yank Sing has white table clothed tables with white butcher paper covering them, so they can quickly clean up all the spilled grease for the next party of 4. The space is elegantly appointed in a simple but quality wood and mirror decorated motif, that says you are not at a traditional Chinatown Tea House with the FOBs from Kowloon where you can't hear yourself talk, because everyone else seems like they are shouting at once in Cantonese.  

Our party of four waited 30 - 40 minutes for our table, at Noon the day after Christmas, known as Boxing Day in the British Commonwealth, which Hong Kong used to be a part of until 1997.  We got an LED/Buzzer to hold in wait, like at Elephant Bar or The Yardhouse. 

Once seated, service was very brisk, as dumpling carts descended on us with a battery of Pushers, Pimping Har Gow, Shiu Mai, Fun, Crab Claws, Chicken Feet, XLB, etc. The food was hot and tasty, and in the beginning, the service was great. We got a big clear glass pot of tea pretty quick, too.  

But later the service waned a bit, sort of like those Hostess bars in Asia, where the prettiest girls sit with you for 30 minutes, then they disappear and are replaced by the motley crew, as the A team sits with the next new customers. 

Finishing the dumplings, dung, and bao, we looked for a dessert cart, but it was MIA. So we stopped a waitress and asked for 2 Jin Doi and 1 pudding, and about 20 minutes later, we got 4 Jin Doi but no pudding. Oh well, they were nice and hot, like they should be, and covered in sesames, not just sprinkled. 

This place is expensive! Our bill for 4 was $118 before tip, and we had no alcohol or drinks, besides water and tea. And the parking in the Rincon is very expensive, too, fortunately, Yank Sing validates. 

Now that I am a little older, I don't eat 3am noodles followed by 2 pm the next day Dim Sum, like I used to. Sadly, it is more like 12 noon lunch and 6 pm dinner. But it is good to know that Yank Sing is still around as an option. I just need to find that Noodle house that is open until 3 am, like Hon's Won Ton or Great Eastern used to be.
author: Wanugee N.

description:
We chose Yank Sing based on A locals referral. It was a great experience with several all-time-best dishes. Steamed pork buns and custard tart were amazing.
It filled quickly at 10:00am Sunday morning.
author: Bill J.

description:
I saw the high ratings and decided to give this place a try.  I was considering relocating to the Bay Area and wanted try out the local culture.  I am Asian and used to eating good Asian home cooking from mom growing up.  She worked as a chef at a high end American restaurant but made great Asian food at home.  She is now retired but I cook as well so my standards are pretty high for food quality and know what good Asian food should taste like.  

I think the food here for the most part is okay, satisfactory.  In particular, the steamed shrimp dumplings, steamed bbq pork bun, and crab claw were rather mediocre.  The fried sea bass was particularly good.  As for the bill, I ordered 4 items but were charged for 6 items, two of them at $13.00 a piece.  So the bill came out to $50.00 instead of $24.00.  $50 for a meal for one before tip?  I was in a good mood and didn't feel like arguing with them so I paid the bill but it is obvious they cheat you here by adding extra items you never ordered.  And they add high priced items at that.  Food was so so, overpriced, and being cheated brought a bad experience to the place.  There was also MSG in the food as I had a minor headache afterward.
author: Pete H.

description: Yank Sing is overpriced dimsum but you can't deny the quality for its optimal location in SF. I definitely would go again although if you're looking for an authentic Chinese experience, I would go to Oakland or Alameda! It's clean and right next to Embarcadero.
author: Jovian C.

description:
We loved this place! Granted, it was expensive, but until we find another place that has the same quality and service and is just as clean and enjoyable as this place, we'll be back.

The shrimp dumplings are to die for! They are tender and delicate. The pork sticky buns were much more flavorful than the pork steamed buns. The Sea Bass was great also (but our favorite similar fish is still across the street... the Black Cod at Ozuma).

The food comes around with dizzying speed, we were high on food and fat on soy sauce within 20 minutes. We can't wait to come back with our grown kids, they'll love it.
author: Cary A.

description: Fantastic as always. I wish they would sell their chili sauce in airplane appropriate sizes.
author: Autumn S.

description:
Honestly, I"m not sure what all the hype is about. I have to admit the XLBs (Xiao Long Bao) are really good, but this place has nothing on the XLBs at Shanghai Cafe (in New York)..

There was a bit of a wait, but luckily we had a reservation for our team. They are pretty intense about you not flaking on your reservation because seating is definitely in-demand...but if you're coming with more than 4 people, MAKE A RESERVATION and DON"T BE LATE. (They will definitely give your table to someone else)

Siu Mai - Shrimp/Pork is not very ground up..so I didn't like how chunky it was, some people like that though..

Xia Jiao - Shrimp Dumplings - were pretty standard in terms of taste, may have been slightly more shrimp in there than the ones you would get at all the other "high end" dim sum places.

Xiao Long Bao - The only thing that is worth ordering more than 1 of...

The team liked the spring rolls here...I didn't try it, but I guess that means they were pretty decent.

Coconut Mochi - They have MOCHI ROLLS..this was interesting to try. I don't know if i'd order it again..

Egg Tarts - These flakey buttery egg tarts were right up there on my list of best egg tarts. They're smaller than the ones you get at Golden Gate Bakery..but they are reaaaalllly yummy. 

Next time I'm here, I'll just order Egg Tarts and XLBs. :)
author: Jennifer S.

description:
Yank Sing is the same experience that you would have in a Chinese Dim Sum restaurant, just in English and much more expensive. Yank Sing is catered to the people willing to pay more and aren't so experienced with Dim Sum. For one, their website spells it as "Deem Sum". Maybe it's a play on words, I'm not sure.

The food, I'll give, is decent. Food is served tapas style, so small portions. The best item on the menu was probably the Shanghai dumplings (Xiao Long Bao, or soup dumpling). I've been looking for a good one in SF, and this one is not bad.

However, be prepared to pay about three or four times the price for the food! I'm not exaggerating. I came with a friend, and the two of us racked a bill of about $60. We ordered about four items and drank only water. One vegetable side (Chinese Broccoli) went to waste as it was awkwardly and intentionally served cold. It isn't as tasty cold as it is hot. The bitterness of the broccoli overpowers the will to eat it.

Another note on the cold food, if the restaurant is not crowded, stay away, because the food going around in carts may have been resting for a while. This was the case with two of the dishes we had.

Two words of advice. Don't come here hungry, or you'll rack up a tab. And don't be intimidated to explore a more authentic restaurant in Chinatown or Clement! I'm really not sure how this place is Michelin recommended.
author: Landy E.

description:
Vegetarian dumplings are the most difficult to make tasty - this place does it just right. Loved all the combinations of the vegetarian options  - its so sad that this is a lunch only place :(

I am never going to miss Din Tai Fung :) I am now a believer in awesome vegetarian dumplings.
author: Akshaya M.

description: Dim sum was delicious.  Restaurant was nice and clean.  The most expensive dim sum I've ever had!
author: Nina P.

description: This has been my family's favorite dim sum place since it opened in the early 90s. I've been going since I was a kid and it is still so amazing! If you love dim sum this is your place! It is pricier than other spots but totally worth every cent!
author: Alice D.

description:
I am impressed with the level of professionalism the hostess group and servers bring to the restaurant. I came here a few months ago with the fiancee and were seated quickly. (OH, AND YAY FOR RESERVATIONS! EVEN FOR 2 PEOPLE!)

They must use their walkie system to tell the XLB lady when a new table sits down because that is literally the first thing they bring to your table. And they make it well. Although, I've had better at Din Tai Fung and other Kingdom of Dumpling on Taraval. 

Service is on point here. They actually care; probably because their customer base is not 100% Chinese. There are many tourists and non-Asian folks that eat here, and for good reason. Their food quality and service are some of the best. 

All said and done, it's too expensive for me to come often. That is 1 of the missing components of the meal - a bill that matches the quantity of food we had. Also, maybe it's because of their customer base, I feel the dim sum was not as piping hot as you can get from some other places farther in the residential areas. Something about jumping out of the way of a steaming basket while it's being put on your table and making sure you're not burned by the steam or dripping water makes the experience so much more authentic.
author: L M.

description:
Before coming here yesterday, we made advance reservations for 12:30pm on Opentable.   We raced over to the Embarcadero, parked in a nearby lot on Howard, and arrived to check in at exactly 12:38pm.  Instead of getting seated for our reservation, we were told to wait in a HUGE, non-moving line of at least 75-80 people.  Yes, even with so-called "Opentable reservations" we still had to wait in line to get seated, as if we didn't have a reservation at all.  What a joke!

This place and how it handles 'reservations' is a joke, I don't care how good the food is.  The fact that people were still standing in that long line like lemmings when there are so many other good restaurants in SF nearby makes me question their intelligence. It also encourages Yank Sing's disingenuous, dishonest 'reservation' system.

I've already lodged a complaint with Opentable to remove Yank Sing from their reservation system.  It's just a ploy to get people to come and then wait in line with the rest of the schmucks without reservations.  We also saw a lot of people sitting around at tables waiting for food.  Given the reported slow service of this place, we knew we would be there for hours and hours just to get lunch... so we left.  No thanks.
author: Dave N.

description: I'd read mixed reviews but have to say our table of 6 had a fantastic brunch. Service good and not at all pushy. Yes it is expensive but it was tasty so who cares! Soup dumplings were divine but ridiculously priced. Overall, highly recommend.
author: F S.

description: Lovely dim sum restaurant in the financial district.  Enjoy entering through the old post office.  Good selection of tasty dishes.  Clean with helpful service which is rare for a dim sum restaurant.  Pricy.
author: Daniel L.

description: This place is delicious! But be prepared to wait! We came after church last Sunday and there was a huge rush. We put our names in and waited about 45 minutes for our table. But it was well worth it. Their dim sum is delicious and I absolutely love the soup dumplings. They have a variety of different dishes to try. The place is clean and the staff was very attentive and friendly. They also validate parking if you park in the lot. I highly recommend this place and can't wait to come back and bring the whole family!
author: Jocelyn S.

description:
In reading through reviews I thought some yelpers were being harsh, but after one dim sum experience at Yank Sing you'll be hard pressed to find me back here. We arrived at 2pm and the place closed at 4pm. Perhaps a bit late for prime dim sum, but the place was still packed and there seemed to be many roving carts weaving in and out of the tables. Imagine our disappointment when all they came around with over and over again was the same shrimp shu mai and dumplings. Wasn't sure if they were ignoring our table, but this definitely lacked the variety I was hoping for in such a fancy dim sum joint. 

We eventually gave in and decided our options would be to starve or eat shrimp. After a few rounds of shrimp, we finally got our hands on some Shanghai dumplings (good not great), but the lack of variety and the price made this place a total bummer. I'd rather eat at some hole in the wall dim sum place with poor service, but quality food, over Yank Sing. 

btw- Another reason to avoid this place- The bill came out to $50 for 2 peeps with 5 total orders shared between the two of us (some orders with just a few dumplings).. Rip off!
author: Ritu K.

description:
Met my former boss (she's retired now) for lunch today.

The BEST dim sum experience.

Everything we tried was over-the-top delicious.  Its such a fun experience as you select from the carts of steaming hot delicacies.

We had the absoulete best dim sum, classic pork shu mai, shanghi dumplings, steamed pork buns, sesame balls and mango pudding.  Did I forget something?  Lol.

We really enjoyed our lunch. I can't wait to come back.

Price wise: Expensive- YES
Worth It.                       YES
author: Janet T.

description: Our Dim Sum favorite place in SF, but it is pricey. We've eaten at both locations and the food is excellent. Service is almost too fast (I'm sure they do that to run up your bill:-) I had not even put my purse down, much less ordered drinks, when they were lined up, offering food. But it is a wonderful dining experience, and the food is fabulous. The soup dumpling are outstanding. The Rincon Annex location is easier as you can park underneath, probably could park there and walk to the other location (weather permitting - it was raining when we went).
author: Blondie P.

description:
The servers, insistent. 

The food, passable. 

The price, astronomical.

I left this restaurant a veritable pauper, having inhaled a small amount of food which the receipt insisted was nearly priceless. 

My growling stomach disagreed...
author: David S.

description: Decent place if you are craving fast Chinese food but their selections are pre-set on the menu and you can't make any substitutions. Food is edible and you are in and out fairly quickly but it's so disorganized and chaotic. I would walk an extra few blocks to get something better though.
author: Dusty N.

description: The food and service were excellent as always with the Shanghai dumplings being a stand out!! Only complaint was that the jasmine tea was quite bitter.
author: Hari J.

description:
This review is for a wedding in the Atrium.  I'm posting the review here because Project Wedding does not allow more than 2000 characters.  Hopefully, this will help a lot of Asian brides-to-be.  One review on project wedding really helped me, so I'm passing along updated info.  

Overall: The Rincon Atrium is the best place you can get for an authentic Chinese style banquet that still offers a westernize feel.  Our guests were very impressed, complimented us, & thanked us for inviting them to such a beautiful wedding.  Further, we got rave reviews about the food, decor, event timeline, & how everything was well executed.  

Another thing to note is we originally planned for our wedding to take place at another Chinese restaurant that also caters.  This plan fell through when our guestlist grew.  Since we could no longer have it at the restaurant, we tried hard to keep them through catering.  We looked at the Bently Reserve, Julia Morgan Ballroom, Decathlon club in Santa Clara, & various hotels that allowed outside caterers.  With that said, I'm so glad the plan fell through b/c we got Yank Sing! It would not have been as magical elsewhere.

Although the atrium space is beautiful, a lot of extras were needed to give it that "wow" factor.  One thing to remember is, Yank Sing is VERY stringent on negotiations.  

The Breakdown:

Daisy Hung: She is Yank Sing's event coordinator.  Yes, Yank Sing is so popular that they have their own event coordinator.  She is absolutely great, & we're so happy.  She also speaks english, unlike some other restaurants where they can't communicate with some vendors, Daisy was able to.  She is very responsive, and since she ONLY deals with banquets, she is very knowledgeable.  Her recommendations on the timeline was so appreciated as our original timeline probably wouldn't have worked without her recommendations.  

Atrium Fee: $4,000.  Our friend had it a couple years before us and it was $3,750.  However, in 2012, it's $4,000.  We get the waterfall though. 

Clean up fee: $500.  No way around it, just pay it.

Corkage Fee: $15 a bottle.  We purchased our own wine (Riesling, Chardonnay, Merlot, and Cabernet Sauvignon) and paid the corkage fee.  We also purchased Hennessy Privilege from Costco and paid the corkage.  All alcohol was served at the bar.  No bottle of cognac at every table for us.  The guests complimented on the wine and said it went with the food.

Bartenders & Beverages: $2000 tab = three free bartenders. $1500 tab = 2 free bartenders.  $1000 tab = 1 free bartender.  This was fine.  It was good that Yank Sing has their own alcohol and we just went with the per drink option.  $7.50 low end / $8.50 middle / $9.50 premium.  $4.50 per bottle of beer.  $2.50 per non alcoholic beverage at the bar. Corkage is separate and does not count towards the tab.

Soda & Ciders: Mandatory $6 per bottle per table.  We had Cider & 7-up, that's $12 a table.

Cake Cutting Fee: Yup, Chinese restaurant that has cake cutting fee $2/pp. 

Chairs: We got our chiavari chairs through Yank Sing's preferred vendor, Especially Yours. See Especially Yours review.

Linens: We used their linens.  Otherwise there are extra costs associated with using different color linens.

Candle Fee: $160 to get your candles checked out, since Yank Sing is a historic building.  We just use lighting and minimal candles. They have these votive candles that can be used.  Check out "enhanced lighting" review.

Food: The menu ranges from $578 to 938 per table.  Veggie plate was $40 a plate.  They are accommodating to moving things around the menus and customizing it so it worked.  For example, upgrading to abalone, adding lobster, switching out prawn dishes, etc. 

Pre dinner reception: $1.50 - $2.50 per dim sum (like one har gow).  We decided to have a dessert bar instead and brought in cupcakes, candies, cheeses, and croissants.  This doubled as a pre dinner reception.

Tax and Gratuity: 8.5% tax in 2012, and 18% mandatory gratuity.  The bartenders made it out like a bandit that night! Double tip!

Cost for an extra hour: we didn't use this but there is a cost associated with this.  I think it's several hundred dollars.

Parking: There is a small garage downstairs that fits about 60-80 cars.  The place fills up quick! So use street parking .  Usually you'll find something within' a 3 block radius.  Street parking and meters are free after 6:00 pm.  

Two events can happen at the same time.  They can rent out the inside restaurant to another party.  They won't tell you this unless you ask.  The inside space typically doesn't rent out until the month or two before the date. 

To raise the sweetheart table costs $600.  We skipped this option.

Service:  The service is TOP NOTCHED for a Chinese style banquet meal.  Bartenders walked around to serve our wine, and they were VERY accommodating.  Our guests kept on complimenting us about the service because they were not used to having a Chinese restaurant be good
author: Carrie-C N.

description: We are obliviously happy until we got the bill at the end--$103!! For 9 dishes!  Totally overpriced! An order of xiao long bao with 6 piece was $10. Two fried shrimp/crab balls were $14 and it is mostly shrimp. The food was alright but do not worth the price. In fact, the table next to us saw our predicament and left early. Do not come unless you have money to waste.
author: T4 P.

description: I personally think this is a place to be seen rather than to eat. The food is pretty good but way over priced! There are other places in San Francisco that offer better Dim Sim at a more realistic price. If you book a table, you have to have everyone present before they will let you in. There is no place to sit, you have to find somewhere in the mall. This is an up market restaurant and believe that they can treat you anyway they like. They can keep it. If you need to be treated badly and then pay through your nose, this is the place for you, not me.
author: Meng L.

description:
'YANK' Sing. Notice the word, Yank as in Yank your chains, Yank your money, Yankees.....Yank the best place to eat at....sorry Yank...

Things worth ordering here...XLB and the tea.

There were three of us. We ordered cold Siu Mai's, the shrimp thing they boast on their menu, mushroom dumplings, egg rolls, ribs in black bean sauce (super sweet?! Ack!!!! When has it ever been that sweet?!)....we also ordered 2 7-ups, 2 cokes and a pudding...our bill? A staggering over $100 (I was not allowed to see the whole bill but I did see a one in there). This is not only disgusting but highway robbery! This bill makes it hard for the food to be enjoyable and/or easy to digest.

Will I go back? NO!

Will I suggest to F/F?! NO!

I am all for good eats but that amount that we paid should have fed at least 10 people here is Monterey Park or Chinatown!!!! And all the food would have been kick a$$ awesome!

Historical Yank Sing is a historical place that one should just stop and grab reading material...there must be a better place to enjoy rather than this overpriced (only thing decent XLB) establishment.

I did very much appreciate the boyfriend for bringing me here but I did tell him no way in hell are we eating here again!

Between Zuni Cafe and this place......I can now see why the locals all hang out at the super duper burger and pizza parlor on market....
author: Silvia C.

description:
For taste, you cannot beat this place.  For service, you cannot go wrong.  For  price...um...this is not sustainable.  You have been warned.

Sea bass and soup dumplings were my favorite.  Wallnut shrimp was my gfs fave.
author: Stuart B.

description: Excellent choice for dim sum outside of Chinatown. Staff is friendly. They have a great selection of vegetarian options. The mushroom dumplings were a favorite. The tea comes in a beautiful glass pot for the table. Really enjoyed the other 3 types of veggie dumplings pea shoots, savory, spinach. The chicken mushroom dumplings were also very yummy. We also enjoyed the eggplant and shrimp with rice noodle. Though the sauces on the latter could be better. That's my only suggestion for what could have been better. I have to admit we don't do the other traditional pork or other dishes so cannot comment on those. We finished the meal with the egg custard tart which were delicate and warm.
author: Laura R.

description: Delicious and many steps up from the usual dim sum.  Love the walnut salad, Peking duck, Shanghai dumplings.  Also, many steps up price wise.
author: Rachel M.

description:
I went to Yank Sing with friends for lunch two times with two different groups of friends on two different days. On the first day, maybe because we kept talking, the dim sum got a little cold and was not that good. The soup dumplings did not seem to have liquid soup inside. On the second day, the food seemed to be much better: hot soup inside the soup dumplings and the dim sum was hot and fresh.

On both days, the waiters were very professional and gave excellent service. The restroom was clean.  

Overall, the level of professionalism is always excellent and they could give customers the confidence of having a business lunch there.  The prices they charge are high.  This is not an everyday dim sum place.  I would just go there only for important occasions or to let friends try their food because this place was mentioned by Michelin (but no stars yet, as far as I know).  In other words, to me, this falls under the "take your business clients there or once in a lifetime for myself is enough" category.
author: W. L.

description:
Yank Sing hit all the high notes to kick off our anniversary week in San Francisco!  They were very busy and we were very early for our reservation, but they welcomed us warmly and seated us right away. 

All of the six dishes we ordered were very good. The highlight was the crab claws the likes of which I have not seen. They were meaty, flavorful and served with the perfect sweet-and-sour sauce.  I am also a sucker for shanghai style juicy buns known as Xiao long bao.  These were done perfectly with just the right amount of vinegar to accompany them. 

Service is nothing if not efficient. Simply ask for something and it will magically appear at your table within minutes!  What a great find!!
author: Ann L.

description:
This is a nice setting especially in the courtyard. This is fancy dim sum and pricey but high quality. 
Had the honey baked sea bass. This was delicious, thick and moist. You will want to eat several of these but watch out at $20 per plate it will add up. The soup dumplings were good but there are other dumpling places in the city just as good and cheaper. Ha gow was great. Big pieces of shrimp and soft wrappers.  The pork buns were meaty and delicious. Too bad they only come two to a serving. The duck was good as well as the foil wrapped chicken and pork dumpling. The fried shrimp was crispy and meaty. The only bad item was the Chinese broccoli. It is served cold and it is bitter. Skip this. Top it off with sesame balls.
author: Bacon G.

description:
Tai gui le! (too expensive)

The dim sum here is tasty and not greasy like dim sum often is, but $140 for four people, when we didn't order that much and nothing fancy, seems steep. Nice setting, service felt a bit rushed.
author: James M.

description:
Some of the best dim sum I've had this side of the Pacific! I like that Yank Sing is not one of those greasy run-down cantonese shops that a dim sum experience usually consists of. Don't get me wrong, I still like those run-down places since the food is good. But Yank Sing is nicer dim sum, if you catch my drift.

The food is not as greasy as other places and definitely better made. The selection is very good as well. One complaint I have is that all the carts never find our table. But then again, I feel like that happens to me everytime I go for dim sum.
author: Sherry L.

description:
Although some Dim Sum places leave me wondering what to order, I feel completely comfortable ordering a ton of small plates at Yank Sing. 

I like sitting outside at lunch time, ordering from the carts that pass by. You can choose a couple, eat and then gauge your fullness for rounds two and three. Sound like a lot? Well start off small....

I like the dumplings, Lobster, Shanghai or Shrimp. The BBQ pork buns, while hot and fresh. The Stuffed Crab Claws, Taro Root Dumpling and the fresh lettuce cups. 

It's a great place to bring people, each ordering what they like and sharing. When you are ready for dessert, I like the Orange Jello made in Orange Rinds, the Sesame Balls and the Tarts. 

It's pretty easy to start stacking plates and fill up, so my suggestion is to invite a couple friends and try a variety of dishes. You never know what will make your best dim sum list.
author: Rebekah T.

description: All I wanted was good dumplings... And I got underwhelming Chinese broccoli with water down oyster sauce bad service a terrible table... And a check for $100...they got two stars because the pork buns were good
author: John S.

description: This place has some of the best dim sum in the Bay Area.  The food is authentic, tasty and well prepared.  However, as many others have indicated, it is expensive, almost double of what you would pay at other dim sum places.  For example, a piece of their tasty miso sea bass will cost  you $22 each and that's one slice of fish on a small plate that you will finish in a couple of bites.  As I was eating that, I was thinking, for $22 I could have order a full side entree on a really nice restaurant.  You get the idea, it adds up quickly as you order the small dishes that come around and bite them off.  My recommendation, come for the food and don't order any drinks, just water or tea.  Even at this rate, be ready to shell about $50-$60 per person.
author: Amanda K.

description: World class dim sum. A must do whenever I'm in n San Francisco. The peking duck was perfection. Big variety of dim sum.
author: Andy R.

description:
I went with a party of 3 one Saturday morning and we got seated right away. Since they are constantly coming around with carts you can have your food very quickly. The flavor of the food is good but not really special. Naturally, we ordered a lot of different things. Our favorite was this long fried shrimp puff. The Xiaolongbao is okay here while the Peking duck is only so-so.  

Since they ask so fast and give different names for the items, it is a bit difficult to figure out how they items they offer you correspond to the names on the list. This makes it difficult to keep track of how much the individual items cost and how much you have already accumulated. In the end we ended up with a bill of over $130 for three people even though we had not eaten that much food. 

The service is okay-not awful but nothing to brag about either. 

All in all, Yang Sing did not impress me and I will not recommend it or come back especially since it is quite pricy for what it is.
author: Emma E.

description: Service is exceptional. Everything came quickly and everyone was very friendly. Good was good, the Szechuan chicken was my favorite. Prices are pretty high but this place must cost a ton to operate since there is so much staff.
author: Rhonda J.

description:
Fancy dim sum restaurant. Expensive. 
Had to wait at least 45min for the table. 
We sat outside which had roof, windy and cold.

Not many cart came by, so when the cart came, you have to grab.
Shanghai dumpling with hot juice inside was real tasty. 
One of the best I had. Other stuffs were ok. 
You can get that level of dim sum almost anywhere in the world. 
Not only that you don't have to wait or pay like Yank Sing. 
Everything was so clean, even hot sauce bottle.
Tablecloth was spotless, glass teapot was inviting, real ceramic plates and spoons, only chopsticks were plastic.
Looks like one of finest dim sum place in San Fransisco.
Real Chinese would not eat here, I think. 
Something tells me that.
author: Jean Y.

description:
On my 4th visit to Yank Sing, I had my first experience with bad service. It appeared that no server was notified we'd taken a table in their section, so after like 10 minutes we flagged someone down and got some tea. After that, smooth sailing once again - but I can see people being upset if that happened on their first visit. I would urge those people to give them another try.

Anyway, my vegetarian favorites are the green beans (sooooo gooooood) and spinach dumplings. Seafood favorites are har gow and seafood dumplings, but this time we also tried the special of scallop balls. I don't know what was in those things, but they were freaking delicious. The only dessert I've tried is sesame balls, which have grown on me but my Midwestern mom totally hated.

Yank Sing is ALWAYS busy, so either make a reservation or try to go closer to closing time, when there will be fewer carts going around but you'll have a drastically shorter wait time.
author: Rachel M.

description:
This place is NorCal version's of the SGV's Sea Harbour, but a bit more...old-fashioned?  Yes, Y.S. may be a bit on the old-fashioned side of things with the rolling carts, but that is not what this review is about on this establishment; first, I'll get to the basics:

I was actually surprised that a dim-sum place like Yank Sing doesn't open for dinner.  When my parents and I were attempting to look for a place to go to for dinner after we first landed in SF, we went inside the Rincon Plaza, and saw that not one peep was heard; the lights were dimmed; no one was there to help us take us where we needed to go.  Then, as I went to check the business hours of Yank Sing, it said that they are only opened for lunch from 11:00am-3pm.  I thought, "Wait...that can't be right."  Then I remembered that night, I checked their website; I was right...they really don't open for dinner. #Dangit

The previous morning, I had met up with my cousin, and we had lunch; the place was pretty busy, and of course...the food?  Looked delicious.  We had ordered the pickled jicama salad, and I pretty much devoured the whole plate (yes, that's how great it tasted); my dad asked. "Anyone up for a second plate?"  Then my cousin just laughed, and replied "yes."  

I've read a lot of reviews of this place on the spinach mushroom dumplings and truth be told, I wasn't actually a big fan of them; guess my taste buds didn't quite agree.  The soup dumplings (Xiao Long Bao) were great (but, they couldn't compare to Ding Tai Fung in Shanghai or Arcadia, CA), and the honey-glazed sea bass...?  If I had to give this particular dish a rating on a scale of 1-10 (10 being delicious), I'd actually give it an 8.5.  The fish was not chewy nor hard for my teeth to sink into, but I was surprised that the fish wasn't that tender, either.  

So....will I come back (next time I visit SF)?  YES! :D  The food was great, service was great...the only reason why I took off one star for this establishment was that because they don't open for dinner.  Lunch only. :(
author: Jonathan S.

description:
At first I was worried that the dim sum here wouldn't be that good considering that it was in a fancier part of town, they have a respectable website, and they spell dim sum "deem sum". 

BUT, all my worries were put to rest when I started eating! 
I went here with only one other person, but we managed to put away a great deal of food. We talked to our waiter and got some recommendations on dishes we've never tried, ordered things straight from her, and picked up several dishes from the carts rolling by. 

One of the best things we had were the soup dumplings, which are near impossible to find where we traveled from. 

The char siu bao here is very good. The meat is not as sweet as some other places, but it has a bit more complexity in flavor with some different spices. The meat to dough ratio was also pretty good. 

We were brought a chicken dish and asked if we wanted it for $8. We passed the first time, but the second time they asked us, we gave in and got the spicy chicken. It was good, but after eating for a while, our lips got a tad numb from the peppercorns. 

We also got sticky rice wrapped in tea leaves (a dish we usually don't get), and it was good. The shrimp was a tad too fishy and overpowered the other proteins, but other than that, it was delicious. 

We ordered some pan-fried chive dumplings and they were also good. The outside wasn't as crispy as I would have liked, but the inside had great texture. The filling was so simple, but it really let the quality of the ingredients shine. 

The prices for dishes here are a little bit more expensive than in Chinatown, but I was happy to pay the extra dollar or two per dish. My only regret is that we went here after visiting the farmers market, so the space I had reserved in my stomach for the beckoning, jiggling orange gelatin dessert had been filled by fruit slices, nuts, and bread. 

At least now I have an excuse to go again next time! 

After going to dim sum in San Francisco, it is very hard to be satisfied with what is available locally.
author: Nicole O.

description: Went here for Sunday brunch right at 10am and it was fabulous.  The food was hot a fresh and very good.  This was my first time here and I will definitely be back next time I am in the city,
author: Patricia G.

description:
TOP quality
Good tea
Big selection of dim sum
Love the ambiance, the atrium.

It's pretty authentic. However, the presentation is too nice, its dressed up for the locals. If that makes sense. 
I love the peking duck!
author: Jen L.

description:
The best soup dumplings i've ever had. 

Great variety and great quality.
author: Petar B.

description:
Incredibly delicious, juicy and piping hot dim sum!
 My BFF and I had made reservations for 10:15 am and there was already a line waiting for Yank Sing to open. (More like DANK Sing)

We had the shrimp and chive (favorite), regular shrimp, savory veggie dumpling (soo much flavor), 
Foiled chicken (on the bone, flavorful but more bone than chicken), potstickers only because I love potstickers and they were PERFECT, Chinese broccoli which was served cold (weird), lotus leave rice, and the Peking duck (life changing) .

The pecking duck was my absolute favorite dish. Which is hard to decide because everything was perfect. Make sure to save room for that incredible dish.

The lotus leaf is a close second. It was savory and delicious. 

I won't be ordering the broccoli again because it was cold and that threw me off. 

Please note, my best friend and I did end up racking an $80 brunch bill which included hot tea, but it's WORTH IT! I have a sensitive stomach so I can't dine at many dim sum establishments, especially in Chinatown (sketchy). 

MAKE RESERVATIONS.
author: Ariadna C.

description: Went to Yank Sing while I was in San Francisco recently. We were walking the waterfront and cut into the financial district to meet some family members at Yank Sing. The location is a little strange since it's sort of inside a building, but it looked pretty packed so it seemed promising. The Dim Sum was actually pretty good; with some exceptions. The service was pretty poor, the ladies were quite rude and it took a while to get our drink order. We walked out with a pretty large bill which I didn't think was representative of what we ate. Overall it was OK, I know food in SF is expensive but I am sure there are other Dim Sum places that are better than this one, or at least with better service.
author: Didier C.

description:
5 stars for quality of food, 4.5 stars for service, 2 stars for price.

I have a love-hate relationship with Yank Sing. If you come during peak dim-sum times, you can expect to wait for about an hour. They have a really efficient way of keeping track of the waitlist though - they text you once your table is about ready so you don't have to sit around. Yang Sing has genuine tasting dim sum, probably the best I've ever had. But, of course, it comes with a high cost. With that, they do validate for parking - which is awesome since parking in the city is so pricey.
author: Katarina D.

description: I love their shanghai dumplings with fresh gingers on top~  the soup inside the dumpling is very thick and rich.. Sea bass plate was my 2nd favorite!  So good~~ Fish was cooked perfect.. tender and creamy~  best dim sum ever!!!
author: Isabelle H.

description:
Yank Sing slays at dim sum, and is hands-down the best dim sum experience you can get in San Francisco. The variety of the menu, the service, and the speed are prime. However, it is really pricey and dim sum brunch for 3 came out to over $100 for us. 

The must-gets are the xiao long bao (Shanghai soup dumplings) and the steamed BBQ pork buns -- I don't even like BBQ pork buns, but the ones here are SO light and fluffy with quality pork inside that is savory and sweet, that I ate two. I wouldn't get them anywhere else. The pea shoot dumplings are the best veggie option here, I think, very delicate and fresh.

If you're a first timer, make sure to learn how to eat xaio long bao (helpful link here: http://www.foodrepublic.com/2014/01/30/how-eat-soup-dumplings-step-step-guide-red-farms-e). My preferred way is to eat the first one plain, and then think about the chili vinegar. The soup is so rich, I usually put a spoonful of the ginger-chili vinegar on the bottom of my soup spoon, let the dumpling absorb it through the skin, bite the top knot, suck the soup, and then slurp up the rest of the dumpling with the runny soup that spilled out + meat + dumpling + vinegar. 

Other items are worth skipping though... the potstickers are just so-so, the jello desserts are all a waste of time (they look cool though), and sometimes the veggie dishes are cold from being pushed around for a while. 

And they do have vegetarian/vegan friendly options; the spinach dumplings and pea shoot dumplings, especially, as well as the cabbage and walnut salad.
author: Laura J.

description:
Been coming here since I was a kid. Still THE BEST xiaolongbao I've ever had. Nothing anyone has raved about in SF or NY has come close, IMO. (although, to be fair, I haven't been to DTF etc.). 

It's a little pricey for dimsum, but it's a bit of a classier affair than most places.
author: Sam R.

description:
Best dim sum in SF. 

Get there early because there is always a long line. 

Siu Mai is the best. Barbecued pork buns are good also. Egg tarts are not very good. They are too crumbly and the filling is slimy and slides down your throat like snot. 

It is very expensive so watch out as you order individual dishes.
author: Eric P.

description: This is one of the best Asian restaurants in the United States to be honest. The food is authentically Chinese. And unlike other Chinese restaurants, Yank Sing has actually great customer service.
author: William S.

description: Yank Sing makes the best dim sum I've ever had (especially the XLB and duck buns), and that's coming from someone who has tried nearly every XLB restaurant in the city. The XLB here are so so so juicy, bursting with broth. And the Peking duck is surprisingly not greasy; I believe it is steamed, which makes it especially aromatic. Unfortunately, the dim sum here is a bit pricey, at $15 for 6 tiny XLB, and $6 for a single duck bun.
author: J L.

description: Food was good, service was fast, parking was easy.  They really pack in the people (not much separation between tables) so you are quite close to your neighboring diners.  The quality is good but the prices are pretty high for what you get compared to other places.  If you don't mind paying $100+ for two people you will enjoy the eats and beverages.
author: James W.

description: I was quite fortunate to attend a wedding at Yank Sing last year. I heard the dim sum is overpriced and just alright, but that was definitely not the case for our dinner. We had shark fin soup (!!) and a sea bass almost the size of my thigh. Talk about some of the most unsustainable foods - and this was at each of the 30+ tables! No complaints here as it was all very delicious and reminded me of the extravagant holiday dinners we'd have at my favorite Chinese restaurants. :)
author: Jessalyn C.

description: Tasty dim sum, but way overpriced unfortunately. Pros: They serve dim sum til 4pm Sundays. They also have radish cake!
author: Aleyna S.

description: Overpriced and overrated. We wanted dim sum and many people told us to go here. It was good, but not exceptional. The congee was excellent however. All other dishes were pretty damn standard as any dim sum place.
author: Ali S.

description:
My review is based on being a guests on two separate occasions at Yank Sing wedding banquets. The first wedding I went to was held in the Rincon Center. It was set up beautifully and it was very spacious. This is probably the most expensive Chinese wedding venue in all of SF. I think you get what you pay for. They served excellent food and the wait staff/bartenders were professional. The water fountain in the middle added a nice touch. When it was time for dancing, they covered the fountain floor with a dance floor. Really neat. The second wedding I went to was held inside Yank Sing. It was nice and the seating arrangement wasn't too crowded like it can be in other Chinese seafood restaurants. Again, staff was professional and they were attentive. 

I saw Yank Sing on The Food Network's The Best Thing I Ever Ate. They featured the baked bbq pork buns. I have yet to try the dim sum there. I hear, it's quite expensive dining here in general. My parents said they had dinner at Yank Sing once and the waiter kept pressuring them to order all the expensive dishes. They said the service was very pushy. I think I'd only come here if I was invited for weddings. I've enjoyed those experience thus far but don't care for dining here on a regular basis.
author: Liv A.

description:
Livid livid livid.

I had a very busy day with a critical deadline this afternoon. But I have to eat and someone suggested Yank Sing. I went to the take out corner assuming it would be quick. It was about 11:30, before the lunch rush, and no one was in line. 

I walked up and ordered. I asked if there were onions in the rice, as I am horribly allergic. No. No onions in the rice. No green, yellow, or white ones? I am allergic so this is important. No, maam. No onions at all. Ok. 

I order three things, typical dim sum fare. Nothing fancy. I went to wait..... And wait.... 22 minutes passed from when I ordered to when they gave me my food. I was so angry. I asked for a refund while waiting and they said they couldn't do it. 22 minutes for three basic items before any lunch rush.

Ok. Whatever. I come back to my office to eat. I have the feeling you bright yelpers know what is coming. I open my rice. Bam. Onions. Everywhere.  As far as I am concerned, this place tried to poison me. I wasn't planning to write a review for the ridiculous amount of time it took, but this pushed me over. I can't stand this type of negligent restaurant behavior. 

Rule #1 in running a business. Don't try to kill the customer. Do they think lying to me to get me to order something will somehow benefit them???

I can't tell you if the food was any good. I gave all of it to a coworker and am skipping lunch today. The second worst part is how damn expensive it was. I get dim sum often on weekends. I eat like royalty for nothing. This place. Ten bucks for three tiny items. Maybe 1.50 worth at any where else.

But I know their murder attempt won't sway most of you, so let the exorbitant prices and slow pace be why you go elsewhere. So many great places here. Skip this one.
author: Harrier T.

description: Excellent food but I had a hard time finding food without shrimp in it for dim sum.  Pricy but good.
author: Pat M.

description:
This has to be the most overrated and overpriced dimsum place in the universe (how's THAT for hyperbole?!).

I'd really recommend taking a short walk to basically ANYWHERE else for dimsum, like City View or my favorite New Asia (which is, arguably, more authentic).

Our bill for two people, not huge eaters, was $80.  A "serving" of peking duck, the kind with the little puffy pancake, was a single piece... each one was over $6.  Since this was dimsum we didn't check the prices and had a serious surprise waiting for us!

I understand this is in the Financial District, but seriously... we could have gotten sushi omakase for this much money at a Japanese place.
author: Brian D.

description:
Yang Sink is one of the premier dim-sum eateries in the Bay Area. This review is specifically for the main restaurant, not the take out area to the right of the main location. 

I have been a frequent patron of Yang Sink for many years. I go to Yank Sink every time I vacation in San Francisco. Over time, I have noticed that while the quality and environment has been relatively consistent, the service of some employees has definitely been on the downhill slope.

The food is relatively tasty and delectable. However, as good as the dishes are, the particular dim sum dishes that I ordered were definitely not categorized as purely an authentic form of "Chinese" Dim-Sum . It is more catered to the PF Chang type of crowd. Overall, I have to say the experience with the food was sub-par at best, depending on your viewpoint. 

The service was borderline atrocious. We did have a friendly gentlemen, who was most likely the manager who was assisting us at times. However, there were many cart-pushers and servers that blatantly ignored us when we waved for their attention. It was not a pleasant experience. 

The price is reasonable, slightly on the high side at 120 dollars for a party of three. As for the decor, the restaurant was decently clean and bright as well. I would think twice before coming to Yang Sink again after my last experience.
author: JK C.

description: K - am updating as we made our annual pilgrimage to Yank Sing - now, living in Richmond and being next door to HK Lounge & Dragon Beaux (the best of the best btw), as well as having my significant other who is a dim sum fanatic as is her family; I think I can now (as a white dude)  testify that I know a thing or two about Dim Sum - :-) - that said, Yank SIng, albeit is excellent quality, in the end it really is a tourist trap!! - over priced is an understatement, the waits are ridiculous, and the food is just not worth it when there are literally dozens of options that are as good if not far better - but I can't knock the place entirely, the food is actually pretty good!!  We had all the staples, Har Gow, Siu Mai, Bao, etc., and as I said, it is all good quality - but nearly 2x more than other places!! - and, one thing you notice right off bat - no asian people are eating there!!! - that should be a dead give away!!
author: Richard D.

description: Great food best dim sum in the city... We go all through the bay but always come back here
author: Seth J.

description:
The place has two spots in downtown SF, this one is near the Fed Reserve bldg.  I made the reservation over the phone because they won't take online reservation for Mother's Day. At lunch hour this place was packed, people jammed the hallway because they ran out of waiting area. 

The place seems clean, but very noisy like all Dim Sum places; Typical dim sum items are all available at acceptable price, those more premium dim sum dishes are pricey, they tastes okay but not worth the money. Overall, I've had better Dim Sum food at so many lower priced places in the Bay area; unless you only want to get those premium Dim Sum dishes and don't care about price, this is the place for you. 

Quality/Price is not high, mostly due to the price. Food is okay.
author: Bobby W.

description:
Dim Sum here is pretty good. Everything we had matched up pretty well with other Chinese places that we like. But. And this is the 4-star but...

Soup dumplings. 

If you get nothing else here. Get the soup dumplings. Happiness ensues.
author: Joe A.

description:
Great!

I know people love to hate on it, but hey, it's great. Love the style and the food is fresh, even if you have no idea what you are eating. The dumplings are amazing and the place has great service and its super clean / enjoyable. 

Even with the steep price point, this place is go-back-able.
author: Stephanie M.

description: Overpriced! Perhaps it's location or whatever, but there are plenty of equal or better dim sum places that won't charge $14 for basic pork dumplings. They were good, but $14 bucks? Get out of here...
author: Ashley W.

description:
I've been to Yank Sing a few times now since the family loves to come here when they come visit. They have plenty of variety of dim sum and as others have said, you can order what you want and they'll bring it to you quickly if it's not on the floor already. The sea bass is excellent! Very moist and fresh and expensive too.

We ate in the courtyard each time but I kind of like it out there. The only reason I wouldn't give it more stars is because of the price. Even though it's great dim sum and certainly comes at a cost and I wouldn't call this place a great value. But if you pretty much want the best dim sum in the city, this is one of the spots.
author: Art O.

description:
We enjoyed ourselves a very pleasant dim sum experience at Yank Sing.  This will be very different in particular for native Chinese dim summers who are accustomed to loud conversations and needing to scream at someone across the table just to have a conversation, pushy carts, lack of care for decor, server 'tude and sometimes good/sometimes questionable food items. At Yank Sing, they offer total volume control, a combination of carts and servers presenting the food to you on-foot, a clean environment and hands-down the best customer service at a Chinese restaurant.

For food, don't go with the regular items (shrimp dumplings, shu mai, rice rolls, chicken feet, etc).  Those are very mediocre and not worth the extra money you pay.  Instead, Yank Sing has their own specialty versions of dumplings and other delicacies that will pleasantly surprise your taste buds.  They are very vegetarian-friendly and sensitive to allergies, always willing to check into an ingredient inquiry to confirm the ingredient list for the customer.  In Chinatown and most other dim sum restaurants, I usually receive a glare and then I'm told to "just pick out whatever you're allergic to."  Vegetarians, they have an uh-may-zing steamed curry dumpling that is really worth at least a try.

I'd take business associates here if they were interested in experiencing Chinese delicacies outside of the Americanized Chinese food, but Yank Sing can really put a damper in your wallet.  It cost us near $80 for only 3 people and we really did not eat that much (I think we had a total of 9-10 plates).  At a regular Chinese restaurant, that same bill would've probably been around $30, including tip.  My cousin did point out to me that we were in the Financial District though where business men and women frequent and that the actual Chinatown was still very much the same as everywhere else I've ever been to.  

If you don't give a hoot about decor, environment or customer service and only  want the simple, quick, down & dirty, go into actual Chinatown for dim sum.  Personally, I feel that Yank Sing is really paving the way for new Chinese restaurant standards and I will happily pay again for the quality food and service.
author: Crystine W.

description: The best Dim Sum I have had.  The service is quick.  They were able to accommodate our large group of 10, with no reservation during lunch rush hour.  The food is a little pricey, but definitely worth it.
author: Courtney D.

description: Yank Sing is different than other Chinese restaurant in the Bay Area with better service and atmosphere but of course higher prices on all the dishes.  If you are comparing apple to Apple, not the ones in Chinatown, it's worth it to get together with family and friends here once in a while not on the daily basis unless you have a Ton of money to spend and you love the food here without getting tired of it.  Not sure if they are still doing it but a wedding banquet held here is perfect if you like the western set up with Chinese food.  The hall is looking like the city hall with the water fountain in the middle.
author: Jason C.

description:
Yang Sing has no been a favorite of mine.  Ate there often when I worked in the area, so decided to meet a friend here for lunch the other day.  Came early (11:45) to beat the lunch crowd.  Was a nice day, so we decided to eat outside on the patio.  Pretty empty as we beat the crowd but it quickly filled up.

They still do dim sum by the cart.  Great, attentive service as always.   Had most of the staples: sui mai, ha gow, cha sui bow, shanghai dumplings, taro tarts, etc.  All the dim sum was very good, but didn't blow me away.  Some of it wasn't very hot - maybe we were too far from the kitchen.  For the price ($60 with tax + tip) for 2 I expected top notch dim sum.  This was B+ quality.

So 4 stars for the food, -1 for the price = 3 stars.  Sorry, really wanted it to be better.
author: Steve G.

description:
I am a huge dim sum fan but not exactly a fan of Yank Sing. I was blessed enough to have tried dim sum in many countries in the past. My conclusion? I always rave about many restaurants in Melbourne, Australia, offering top quality dim sum outside Hong Kong: super fresh ingredients, excellent flavour, and of course, very generous serving! Those are worth a rating more than 5-star. Now a resident in California, I never stop searching for something similar here if not better.
