So far, Yank Sing seems to serve the best dim sum I have ever tried in the Bay, yet it is only as good as any average large dim sum restaurant in Melbourne. It did not really "wow" me during my recent patronage, unlike my best dim sum experience in Melbourne. Not given this high price range for sure.    

I did love the egg tarts here though. They literally melted in my mouth without much biting. It is probably a good idea to order some of the dim sums at Yank Sing 2 Go. Same food quality with much lower price tags.  

At least the dim sum here is generally less greasy, and the servers here are quite polite (one was kind enough to point out to me that parking is always free on Sundays).
author: Sylvia C.

description: Had a great Dim Sum with our family yesterday. The food was great and so was the service. We sat in their courtyard which was lovely and not as noisy as inside. This is a pricey restaurant. That is why I gave it four stars.
author: Lark H.

description: Been coming here for years. Today was horrible. Dim sum tasted like it was frozen and size was a lot skimpier. Had reservations and waiting is to be expected but they give priority to bigger parties either walk in or reservations...so if you're a party of two reservation or not expect to wait at least half an hour past your reservation. Very disappointing food. Quality and portion has gone down. It was expensive before but not with lower quality and portions not worth it.
author: robbie l.

description:
It's hard to recommend any one dish since everything I tried tasted great! 

Here are a few key things to know when dining at Yank Sing...

Groups - Come with a big group and request to sit in the atrium. This place caters towards large parties. 

Ordering - Food can be ordered off the menu or off the cart as it comes to your table.



Price - this place isn't exorbitantly priced but because it's so easy to order a lot very fast, the bill can add up. 

Taste - If you're looking for a very authentic Chinese dining experience this is probably not the place. However, the food tastes amazing and because of that Yank Sing is never a bad idea!
author: Nicolas H.

description:
The review is regarding a wedding reception I had there last year. I just got around to writing it now.

My wife and I got married and wanted our reception to be there. They offer two choices: either one in the atrium or one inside the actual restaurant. We unfortunately got there too late, as the atrium was already booked, and decided to go forward with the restaurant. There was definitely a worry doing so that there wouldn't be enough staff, or the guests would get confused, etc. 

Upon arriving an hour early to check on things, I realized that they had barely started setting up. I asked around only to realize that they had just closed the dim sum portion of the day and didn't even allow my vendors in to set up until just then. I felt that to be a little unacceptable, as I was told beforehand that they close two hours before. Consequently, rather than relaxing and hanging out with my wedding party, I had to assign each and every person to do something so that we could be ready in time once the guests arrived. Again, they need to be very clear if we'll only be given an hour to set up, as I had A LOT of details I needed up and was under the impression that we'd have closer (or more than) two hours. 

So being unhappy about that, why the 4 stars? I think that everything else made up for it pretty well. The service was very good, the food was excellent, and once everything got set up, it was pretty smooth. They even had some staff members outside guiding the guests to each party so that there wouldn't be confusion. All in all, I'm happy with the experience. I was lucky though that I had such understanding friends who jumped at the opportunity to help me when I was in need.
author: John S.

description:
I don't write a lot of reviews on here but since it's my worst memory of my trip to SF, I feel like it's my duty to warn others about this place - at least those that appreciate at least semi-authentic and reasonably priced dim sum.

I've had dim sum in Toronto, NYC (Manhattan and Flushing), Hong Kong, Mainland China and probably everywhere else in between.  I'm not even joking when I say that 4 regular dim sum dishes and 3 peking duck buns on a weekday at 11:30 am cost over $70.  I'm not going to attempt to write out the names of the dishes we ordered because I can't write Cantonese but they include shrimp dumplings, friend turnip cake, lo mai gai (don't even know how to describe it in english) and some other small/medium dish.

The service was horrible, the food was not fresh and I still can't believe how expensive it is.  I just came back from Jing Fong today in Chinatown in NYC and the above order minus the extra dish I forgot came to $15.03.

Anyway, I didn't get a chance to try other dim sum places but I would suggest reading other restaurant reviews to see if there are other places that might be better than here.  I'm sure with such a large Chinese population in SF there should be much better options.  From the other reviews, I seriously doubt this place is the best dim sum SF has to offer, if anything it's a place where only business people go for meetings (hmm, maybe that's why it's located in the Financial district in an office building).
author: C C.

description: Best Dim Sum in SF!! Visiting from out of town and discovered this gem located in commercial building. Food is very very delicious!!! There is even a 2 go restaurant for those want to eat at home!
author: Scott M.

description:
When one side of your family is Portuguese-colonized Cantonese and the other side of your family is Shanghainese-Taiwanese (seriously, I'm a Chinese mutt), it's inevitable that you will become an expert on all things dim sum. Especially if you grow up in a city with a reputation for being one of the best dim sum cities in the world.

I had high hopes that Yank Sing would be that elusive, upscale dim sum restaurant. The type of restaurant with traditional dishes done right and lots of unique, creative dishes added to the mix (like Casa Victoria in Toronto). Dim sum restaurants have such a bad reputation in the US of being these dirty, grimy, dingy hellholes with cheap, greasy food. It's been hard for me to convince even open-minded people that there is such a thing as a beautiful, modern dim sum restaurant with high-quality food and fantastic service.

Let's just say, Yank Sing didn't exactly meet me halfway.....but maybe 10%. The service was definitely better than at other dim sum restaurants. However, take that with a grain of salt, since I do speak Mandarin and Cantonese, and it's always easier to converse with Chinese staff in their native language. The restaurant is pretty, but not in a sleek 'n' chic way--more antique-y, Old World beautiful (the kind of place you take your fiancee's strict, conservative parents).

And the food. Because that's what it really all comes down to. 

Kudos for the Walnut Shrimp. Score 1 for a creative non-traditional dish that quickly became my boyfriend's favorite. 

Kudos for the Coconut Rice Roll with Custard, one of my favorite dim sum sweets. For some reason, it's very difficult to find this dessert at dim sum restaurants. The roll wasn't as sticky and thick as mochi (which is a good thing) and the custard was creamy, sweet and delicious. Score 2 for offering what many other dim sum restaurants don't.

Kudos for the Har Gow and Egg Tarts, traditional dim sum favorites done well. The shrimp were plump and juicy, and the pastry on the egg tarts literally melted in your mouth.

Kudos for the Char Siu Bao. Fluffy, white, perfectly sweetened dough, with well-minced meat inside.

No kudos for the Shu Mai. Greasy, overcooked, and missing the beloved yellow wrappers that are my favorite part of Shu Mai. 

No kudos for the Vegetarian Dumplings. The skins were way too thick and the vegetable filling was missing any form of seasoning.

No kudos for the Bean Curd Rolls. Way too many water chestnuts, not enough other vegetables, and...is that sour I taste? No. Sour bad.

No kudos for the Soup Dumplings. OK, here's where I rant a bit: What is up with SF restaurants serving XLBs as part of Cantonese dim sum? First off, it's not a Cantonese dish. It's from Shanghai. Second, it's never done well. Like Yank Sing's had way too much ginger and barely any pork. And third, XLBs aren't even part of Shanghai dim sum! Nor should they be. Dim sum originated from the time of the Silk Road, when travelers would stop by tea houses to rest. Owners of said tea houses realized tea was good for digestion and began to serve small bites along with their tea. The food was created so that it would travel well, since travelers usually had to hit the road pretty soon Hence, dim sum favorites like well-cooked dumplings, thick-skinned buns and hardy pastries. Now, picture a soup dumpling with its thin skin and piping hot broth. Does that scream "travels well"? Didn't think so.

With a party of 10 ordering liberally, we each ended up paying $34 in total. Had it just been me doing all of the ordering, the total would probably have been in the $20s. Not bad either way, but certainly not the dirt cheap $10 or so of other dim sum restaurants. I don't think our experience was worth quite what we paid, but I don't feel ripped off either. All in all, glad I did it but probably won't seek to do it again.
author: Josephine L.

description: The food didn't seem as amazing as I remembered it but it was still good.  The one thing I really liked was the XLB, really soupy as it should be.  Service was excellent.  Price is really on the steep side for dim sum.  I would come back but probably not for a while.
author: Helen W.

description:
You can't ever complain if the food is free.

I came here with a group of people at night. Yes, night. Yank Sing apparently opened up their private dining space for us and catered to the research group I am affiliated with.

8 different dishes shared throughout the table. Some wine. It was all good.
author: Julia P.

description:
Yank Sing is one of the best dim sum places in San Francisco. It's authentic, fresh, and service is pretty good. If you're planning to come here on a weekend though, definitely make a reservation! It's usually packed for brunch. 

The only thing I don't like about this place is that it's wayy over priced. A small dish can go up to $13 - and by small I mean very small. However, it's worth the try. Just don't order too much if you're not planning to splurge.

My favorite small plates are the Taro Crunch and Soup Dumplings.
author: Vivian W.

description:
Food maybe good, but I will never go back.  I sat at the bar for lunch, ordered a diet coke.  None of the sodas were listed on the drink menu, but I asked if they had diet coke.  It was served in a very small glass for $2.50.  When I was finished I was asked if I wanted a refill.  I said yes, twice.  When the bill came I was charged $2.50 for each.

Disgusting.  Since almost no one charges for each soft drink these days the restaurant should have been clear as to whether they were refills or a new soda.

Ethically speaking, this is not a restaurant I want to patronize and moreover I would stay away.

Food is way overpriced and this just sealed the deal.  I will never go back and  advise everyone to stay away.
author: Ty L.

description:
Meh is right. 

I was not impressed by the food or the price of this place, they market themselves as high end but the food really wasn't that great. They had some cool ideas but nothing really special. Their xiao long bao was terrible, I went for a quick lunch by my hotel and the xlb was better at that small place than it was at Yank Sing. The food was all lukewarm too due to the large venue they have, during lunchtime we took over the courtyard of the building they were in.

The food is mediocre and overpriced, I won't be coming back.
author: Michael L.

description: Pretty good place to have dim sum! Great servers l, feel like getting back hometown. I am originally from Canton, Chang Fen (steam rice noodle? I not sure) is the best!! Yank Sing the best dim sum, I will recommend my friend come.
author: Claire H.

description:
Yank Sing is, and has long been, at the top of the list of SF dim sum restaurants.  I've been a customer since the 1980s, when I'd eat dim sum lunch at their 'alley' Financial District location.  

The Rincon location is fancier but, the dim sum is the same---top quality.  The only thing preventing a 5-start rating is the price.  We always go even though it's expensive ($135 w/tip for 3 light eaters), because it's one of our treats when we return to The City, now that we've moved away.

Some of our favorite dishes:  honey glazed sea bass, walnut shrimp, pork buns, steamed shrimp dumplings, pork dumplings, grean beans & mango pudding.

Service:  efficient and business-like

Atmosphere:  fantastic inside Rincon's central atrium with the suspended waterfall fountain.

Wait Time:  make a reso or be prepared to wait quite a while.
author: Mark S.

description:
Want Dim Sum in San Francisco?  This is the place to go.  Yes, it is a bit expensive, but it is worth the price (or just have a date pay).  While you can have the typical experience of the servers offering items off the cart, you can also order off the menu.  Everything I've had has been delicious.

I suggest coming with a larger party so you can try more items, at least three since most items come in 3's.  If you are going for a weekend brunch, get a reservation.  The wait here for a large party can be significant.
author: Michelle K.

description:
Food: 4.5S
Service: 4.5S
Ambiance: 4.5S

This is my favorite dim sum place just as good as their other location.  We came with my friend, wife and two kids.  Everything was delicious, espcially the Shanghai dumplings.  The dumplings were some of the best I've had. I've had them in Shanghai, China and at Joe's Shanghai Dumplings in New York as well.  

The one dish we had that was not up to snuff was the duck/skin sandwich.  It was cold and dry.  I told our server and he discounted a few of our other dishes. That's great service because sorry doesn't show my wallet you are sorry.

Overall, great food but you will pay for it via your wallet.
author: Duke H.

description:
Delicious delicious dim sum - especially for vegetarians who don't get to find a lot of options regularly - but you pay the price as well. This place is extremely expensive for dim sum which is supposed to a "cheap, street food" kind of cuisine. 

The ambiance of this place is really interesting! Waiters come around with carts filled with a wide variety of options and you get to tell them what you want off the cart. It's a little weird to me that they still give you a menu because you never have a chance to order for yourself because these ladies come around so fast. Sometimes they can be a little rude because they always seem to be in a rush, but you do end up getting all the food you want by the end.

I think I've tried every single one of their vegetarian options for dim sum and I LOVE all of them! Two of my favorites are the mushroom dumplings and the  steamed vegetable dumplings - both have great flavors and taste great, especially with their spicy mustard sauce. I've also tried the chicken lotus dumplings which were very tasty and had a flavor that was very unique - definitely recommend those as well! For dessert, I've gotten the mango pudding and the egg custard. I was a little skeptical about the egg custard because the name kind of put me off, but it was very yummy - tasted kind of like a caramel custard to me. The mango pudding was delicious and just melted in your mouth!

It was a very fun experience dining at this restaurant and if you're in the mood for dim sum and looking to splurge - yank sing is your place to go!
author: Malika R.

description:
Still probably the cleanest and nicest place for dim sum in the city.  I felt like the prices skyrocketed and thus here is a lower review.  Their Shanghai Dumplings reduced to 6 pieces at 12 bucks, where it was 9 pieces for $15 before.  I'm kinda over this place but haven't found my favorite Shanghai Dumpling anywhere in the city beside Yank Sing.  So I will continue coming here once in a while when I crave these soup bursting dumplings. 

For cheap and good dim sum, go to chinatown Jackson street Kay Cheung.
author: Kevin L.

description: The food was alright! I've had better dim sum, but it wasn't bad. However, I was pretty surprised to get an $85 bill for a lunch for two. We didn't eat much, since we'd just come from a brunch, and I would have had much higher expectations for a lunch that cost $40 apiece. Wouldn't go again with so many great options with better price points.
author: Jackie L.

description:
It's been a long time since I've been to HK for dim sum, but I do nyc dimsum semi-regularly... even so, this place is pretty dang tasty. It's got all the classics:  shrimp/beef/veg in rice noodle rolls, sticky rice, baby spare ribs, shrimp dumplings, chicken feet, turnip/taro cake, etc. and more--and best of all, it's fresh.

Super conveniently located nearly across the street from the Hotel Griffon, we seem to make a stop here every time we visit. 

Round out the usual dim sum / tapas-sized plates with regular-sized entrees of their crispy prawns with mayo sauce and a dish of sauteed snow pea shoots with garlic.

Good stuff, but yea on the pricey side for dim sum.

Thank you. Come again.
author: Melinda C.

description:
I really don't like the fact that their prices went up considerably and the service is not great because they are very busy and rushed.
Our last meal before tip was $150, for 3 people and what bothered me is that the table next to us complained for being overcharged, and same happened to us.
author: Daniel U.

description:
All of my Asian co-workers have given this place numerous praises so I figured it was worth a try.  They did, however, warn me that it was pricey.  I didn't realize it was THAT expensive.  This place would've gotten a solid 5 star rating until I got our bill.  My boyfriend was in town and we usually get dim sum together, so it was a great opportunity to try out this place especially after the Chinatown fiasco, we were still searching for a good dim sum place in the city.

+  BART accessible.  It's located right off the Embarcadero exit and near the Ferry Building.  My boyfriend and I are big on public transportation so it was a delight knowing it was a 2 minute walking distance from BART.

+  We were seated pretty fast.  When we first walked it, we were shocked to see how packed it was and thought it would take forever to get a table.  They said our wait time was 10-15 minutes and they didn't lie about that.  It didn't feel like we waited an entire day to get a seat.

+  Fast and friendly service.  One thing we normally get annoyed with dim sum places is how long we have to wait for a cart to come by even if we're the only few customers.  This place was different.  Even before we got sat down, 2 carts came by asking what we want.  WOW!  Never had that happen before.  Also, we never had to ask for water; it came without us asking.  The only thing we were asked was what kind of tea we want in which they have a variety (Jasmine, Oolong and Chrysanthemum for instance).

+  Food and tea.  We ordered the following typical dishes - Har Gaw, Soup Dumplings, Egg Rolls, Pot Stickers and 2 Shu Mai.  All of which were very delicious and absolutely fantastic.  It was certainly the best one we've gone to in the city.  The food was also very hot and fresh from the kitchen; I hate having lukewarm dishes that's been seating in the carts for a while.  We also got the Chrysanthemum tea and it was also just as great.  It was adequately rich in flavor and the aroma was wonderful.  The serving pot was pretty cute too.  It was a clear pot so you can see your tea steeping; no guessing on when it's okay for you to start drinking.

+/-  Price.  Now here is where I'm on the fence.  I'm an avid advocate of getting your money's worth for good food, but I'm also a devoted promoter of "cheap but good" food.  Living by yourself in the Bay Area is expensive so spending on a lot of money for dining experiences is a touchy area.  For 6 dishes, our bill came out to be about $60 (including tip, and the tea was $3.90/pot).  That's about 3 times more expensive than any dim sum places I've gone to.  I don't deny that it was good dim sum, but I wish I can say that I can be a regular at this place.  I will definitely come back, but it will be once in a while when I don't mind splurging.
author: Deana M.

description:
Mediocre, expensive Americanized Chinese food, especially for San Francisco. 

We were seated outside the restaurant next to the fountain and the take-out shop. It was crowded and I didn't feel like I had enough room. There were many food choices and the women with the carts were always around. The portions were not that generous. Only a few dishes were okay to me (like the sea bass and beef), but most of them (like the dumplings) were not very good.
author: Victoria L.

description: Went for dim sum. The food was good, but man, its pretty expensive. The majority of the clientele here was caucasion and the building is quite fancy.  The dim sum was pretty authentic and pretty good, but it comes with a premium. You can do better in San Francisco, and for much cheaper if you don't mind eating with chinese people and not in a nice building.
author: Jon Q.

description:
I'm impressed with the dim sum they serve here. SF has the best dim sum in the best Chinatown of California (yes, SF Chinatown sh*ts on LA Chinatown, and I say this as an LA native). I've never been to a dim sum spot that offers good dim sum and (wait for it...) GOOD SERVICE. Usually dim sum restaurants lack one of the two, but Yank Sing knocked it out of the park in both fields. The staff was very friendly and attentive. 

Never have I ever had a fried sea bass roll at a dim sum restaurant... Actually, I've never had such thing until I got to try it here! The flaky-ness of the fish, and moisture were absolutely fantastic along with the crunch of the breading. It was so good, my family had to order a second dish. Each sea bass roll dish costs a whooping $11 for 4 pieces.

From the sui mye, to the shrimp dumplings, to the Phoenix tail shrimp, EVERYTHING was good. My family and I enjoyed our brunch here.

My only complaint was that my family and I witnessed a customer at a table across from us who kept opening the containers and touching the food ON THE CART while the employee let her. That is a big NO-NO, lady! Anyway, we ended up not getting anything from the carts that she touched. Who knows? She probably scratched her butt with that finger. Let's prevent contamination, thanks.

So, Yang Sink deserves my four stars. Well done for a James Beard award winning restaurant.
author: Melissa T.

description:
Dim sum.  Two little words that conjure up so many memories and emotions.  I've had dim sum at countless places since childhood.  I would like to think that I have a good handle on what good dim sum should taste like, but honestly, I don't think I've visited enough of the world to cast an 'expert' judgment.  My experiences have only been all over California.  Should be good enough though.  Seriously.  I've eaten a lot of dim sum.  A lot.

I've had dim sum all over the SF Bay and the one thing I can be certain of is that I've never really had good dim sum in SF itself.  Not that I haven't tried to find a place--of the numerous places I've been in the city, I just haven't found one worth praising.  Well, it took me a while to get around to Yank Sing and I'm glad I was finally able to give it a go.

Yank Sing, looking past some of its peculiarities, delivers on some pretty tasty dim sum dishes.  The staples were all certainly there.  The flavor was mostly there.  Note that the restaurant definitely caters more toward a Western palate.  That shouldn't bother you unless you're a diehard traditionalist.  There are some subtle hints and also some not-so-subtle, brazen applications in their dish preparation.  One look across the dining room and adjoining atrium and I knew why--there's a great diversity of well-to-do patrons.  As such, the service was far better and friendlier than your average Chinese restaurant that only gets frequented by Chinese folks.

I won't get into all of the dishes that we had, but know that they were pretty decent and  properly cooked. Some oddities: The Peking duck buns were abominable.  Too much fatty duck meat on the cut, skin nowhere near crispy enough. Shanghai dumplings, while tasty, certainly not worth writing home about.  While every other bay area Shanghai Dumpling place is certainly a D- or F, Yank Sing hits a good enough dough thickness to juice to meaty flavor ratio to earn a C. 

Whoa, I had a few double takes: there was a lot of stuff that I really wouldn't normally associate with dimsum: honey walnut prawns during dimsum?  Not seen before in my lifetime!  Grilled sea bass steaks?  Cabbage salad? Hmm.  I guess if it sells, it sells.  Being that I'm not exactly an authentic Asian guy myself, I can't be too hypocritical.

At the end of the day after all of the tea was consumed and all of the mile-high piles of steamer baskets and empty plates were taken away, we were stuffed and left with the bill.  The price was definitely high for dim sum.  Probably the most expensive dim sum I've had anywhere.  Was it worth it?  Sure.  For now it reigns as the top spot in the city for 'deem sum'.  Plus you get those buzzing pagers while waiting, better than the typical loudspeaker going off next to your ear.
author: Al C.

description:
Yank Sing is probably one of the classier dim sum joints around. I prefer the atrium seating vs the regular indoor seating they have available. Service and food are a step above. It is a huge restaurant so getting a table is easy but they do take reservations in the event you have a large group.

This place has all the usual dim sum items but nothing unique that I could see. That being said, the items they do have are fresh, hot and tasty.
author: Schelly Y.

description: The food was excellent - dim sum and steamed rice rolls (beef especially!) melted into your mouth... The pork buns were yummy too. It was fun to have the food brought to you on trolleys, as and when it was cooked - thereby ensuring its freshness. And that meant you could just order according to your ongoing appetite. Make sure you don't accept every single dish they bring to you though, unless you really want to try it! As you will get full quite fast. Service was perfunctory and decor was a little old fashioned - but somehow it kind of tied in beautifully with the experience.
author: Helene D.

description:
High class dim sum food in San Francisco. When visiting this foggy city one of the places you must visit is Yank Sing. Famous for their dim sum and flavorful condiments which are sold nation wide. I personally love this place because of the delicate hand made dim sum dishes. They are served the traditional way on carts and they are steaming hot. So why Yank Sing versus any other dim sum joints? It may be slightly more expensive than your average dim sum joint, but the quality of the food is unmatched and the service is wonderful. You can easily have a business lunch here or just come here for a casual breakfast. 

The key is to arrive early, before the doors open. There is an indoor seating area to wait in. Parking is a bit tight, but there is a garage below the building.They will validate your ticket for up to three hours. If you're up for a little walk after your meal you should venture towards the pier, it's right across the street and visit the cupids bow and arrow sculpture. Cash or credit is accepted.

Here's a quick lesson / guide of dim sum etiquette, following with a list of items to look for. This can be applied to most Dim Sum establishments. Dim sum originates from Hong Kong. It's a whole breakfast affair that deals with a wide variety of food which is all shared, family style. Ideally go with two or more people so everyone can have a bite from each dish, but hey it doesn't hurt to dine alone, that just means you'll have left overs to take home if you decide to try a variety of food, which I highly recommend. Traditionally men and women would put on their Sunday best for dim sum dates. Almost everything is hand made, and steamed. There are vegetarian dishes, but it's not an ideal cuisine for those with gluten allergies or who are kosher. You may order drinks and other specific dishes from your waiter but the food is ordered directly from the ladies or men who come by with carts. The prices per dish ranges anywhere from $3.50 to $9 and you won't know until they stamp it on your check at the table upon ordering. You may ask to see what is in the cart if there is a language barrier or if you're curious. In a way, dim sum is Chinese soul food, the real deal what you can expect from a visit to Hong Kong.

The good stuff: aka what I always get
Hagow - shrimp dumpling in a clear noodle three pieces
Lo-mai-gai - fabulously wrapped little sticky rice balls filled with all sorts of pork, Shrimp, veggies. Comes in three pieces. 
Shumai- pork meatballs in a noodle with minced vegetables. I always dip it in Yank Sings chili sauce which is at every table. four pieces to an order
Char sew bow- red pork in a white bun. three pieces, for meat lovers, but I know people who will devour the bread part only, fascinating how they steam the buns.
lo-bak-go- turn up cakes made with dried shrimp and pieces of pork. they're square and come in three.
Chicken feet- I don't always get these, but they're popular among the older Chinese people. My grandparents enjoy them, so in some cases I have one or two, but people are usually scared of this. Comes in a pile. Sorry I don't know the Chinese name for this. 
Pork Spare Ribs- Don't know the Chinese name but these bad boys are some of my favorites! Depending on the time of year they can be cooked with squash or taro roots. They're cooked and served with bones in and this is the only dish I order one specifically for myself and a separate one for my friends or the table to share.They look pale with a light glaze sauce, so good. I eat them with my hands, don't worry, not rude. 
Dan tat- an egg custard brought to China from Portugal. This is a very popular treat that you can find at most Chinese bakeries. But I'd order them here, you know they'll be fresh and hot. Comes in three, enjoyed as a dessert.
Beng doi- sesamie covered balls filled with red bean or some sweet bean. comes in three, enjoyed as a dessert.

I hope the above helped out especially if this is your first time having dim sum. You don't need to know Chinese to dine here, but if you have a friend that speaks Chinese it will be a plus. I don't speak Chinese, I only speak dim sum. I'm always opened to try new dishes, but after ordering all those other dishes there's hardly any room to fit new foods into my dim sum list.
author: Trisha W.

description: Yank Sing serves dim sum. It is a little bit pricey, and it can be a challenge to get a table. The expensive sea bass was not worth it, but do get the shrimp dumplings, pork siumai, and the egg custard tart.
author: Paul M.

description: Honestly, the food is good.  However, the prices simply don't justify the experience.  $220 for four people, two of which didn't eat so much, and...well...you get the picture.  There are quite a  few places that are equally as good in the city for half the price.  This place survives by reputation alone.
author: Art B.

description: Everyone kept telling me the quality of this place went down but I didn't listen. I kept insisting that it would be good. Well the food wasn't that great, service was average and super pricey :( really sad I can't recommend this place
author: Tiff W.

description:
Big carts of dim sum being pushed around the restaurant, yes please. The food was delicious, especially the Peking duck and dumplings. 

The service was pretty bad, I asked 5 different people for help, it almost turned into a game for me, to find someone so I could order a bottle of wine..

All in all though I would go back. The food was pretty damn good
author: Leo T.

description: Great Dim Sum. Went on a Sunday morning and was impressed with shu mai, pork buns, soup dumplings etc. Nothing mind blowing, but still very good and all served in a nice, civilized setting.
author: Nigel T.

description:
Having heard of Yank Sing during my college days across the way, I've long avoided it for the simple reason that I've grown up with dim sum as something that was simple, enjoyable, and most importantly, affordable. Yank Sing fails miserably in the last of these, coming in at a mildly obscene and outrageous $60 after tax for a mere six dishes.

My lunch companion (who is a much greater fan of this place) and I ended up ordering soup dumplings, shrimp dumplings, vegetarian dumplings, snow pea dumplings (I swear it'll change up soon), sesame balls, and sticky rice. And while these dishes were all good, and the soup dumplings were made particularly well (as one would expect: very soupy, with delicately thin wrappers), they were not of a quality enough to justify double the price of any other dim sum restaurant I've ever been to.

For those that do still insist on coming, reservations are highly recommended, as many, many others seem to find that the food does justify the price tag here - that, or because any other decent dim sum restaurant is a bit out of the way.
author: Johnny W.

description: After having dim sum in Honk Kong and seeing the hustle and bustle of some amazing spots, this place brings me right back to that great feeling as well as great taste. The service here is amazing and the food is just as great! If your looking for authenticity this is the spot.
author: Keo Y.

description: super great! really delicious, plenty of foods to choose from, a little on the fancy and expensive side! It's in a business park so there's a lot of suits running around and catching lunch, had a great experience!
author: Nicole N.

description:
Had not been to the Rincon Center Yank Sing in awhile....remember going there and saying "$150 for six people...what is happening?  And we were not even seated inside the restaurant.  Just the atrium...???!"  Well, sad to say nothing has changed other than it is more expensive than 3 years ago.  And we ate more with more people the last time we went there.  Around $150 for five people this time.  Luckily we had gift certificates.  My two boys used to think highly of this place, but after becoming more experienced dim sum eaters...they kept griping about the cost!  Guess I have brought up my young grass-hoppers well!

Here's the breakdown, the Peking Duck at $5.70 per serving was not up to par.  Skin was not crispy.  The $19 Honey Basted Seabass was nothing compared to the first time we had it although it has jumped up in price tremendously.  The boys kept reminding me that it would have tasted better roasted with a miso glaze.... could have had a whole steamed fish for that price in Chinatown.  Fried Soft Shell Crab was tasty...reminded me of a mini-fried dungness crab from R&G Lounge.  Traditional Siu Mai and Har Guow were over $6 for four pieces....The steamed food did not come out piping hot but more luke warm.  Yechh...

Be careful with the fancy glass teapot as it pours extremely fast.  We spilled and saw two tables near us spill.  The tea does not retain heat in the glass pots either.  I believe they sell the teapots but suggest you pass on purchasing the good looking but inefficient and dangerous pots.  Very good service....

Thank goodness for gift certificates.

Note:  I remember going to the first Yank Sing on Broadway right below Stockton in the early 70s.  It had the best BBQ Pork Bun where slices of just bbq'd pork were served in an open faced steamed bun with scallions and more BBQ sauce.  Someone should revive that concept!   Oops...I guess someone has thought about this approach..the CHAIRMAN truck!!!!
author: Scott L.

description:
We had Yank Sing with friends the morning after watching Game 4 of the World Series!! We ended up ordering 14 different plates and each one was Amaze-balls!!

Next time I'll get some good recommendations as to what to order...I didn't write down what we ate but I plan to go back very soon!!
author: Roman R.

description:
One word: overrated.

More than one word: I grew up in Hong Kong and ate at many famous dim sum places there as a little kid so I developed a critical tongue when it comes to dim sum and Yank Sing doesn't make the cut. The place is nice, fancy schmancy, good for wedding banquets, I suppose, although the one time I came for a wedding banquet, I wasn't impressed by the food, it was not memorable. The atrium is pretty and the water fall from above creates an ambiance of sophistication but I'm here to eat.

The dim sum fare are standard and none of the regular fares (har gow, siu mai, etc.) was impressive. The prices seem on the steep side for what they give you in quality and quantitiy although I didn't pay, but I'm sure my in-laws felt it. In any case, I prefer a more authentic experience at a less pretentious place and will not return here if given a choice for dim sum next time I'm in SF.
author: Joyce W.

description:
Pros: order the Peking duck, the shrimp rice noodle, the cabbage salad, and the shanghai dumplings/ mushroom dumplings. Consistently delicious. Oh and the all time favorite Seabass mmmmm

Avoid: the Szechuan chicken, egg rolls, and any of desserts. 

Check your bill especially if you're a large party bc they tend to accidentally overcharge by a lot. 

Overall: the only dim sum place I go when in sf
author: Anita A.

description:
First off, I noticed that most of the clientele at this restaurant were white people, not Chinese. This means that they cater to a different target market from the various dim sum restaurants in Chinatown and elsewhere in the Bay Area. However, it doesn't mean the food here is bad; in fact the quality is very good and perhaps surprisingly, the dim sum are quite authentic as well. I do agree with many of the reviewers here that the biggest problem here is price. Or rather, what you (don't) get for the price you pay. It's easy to establish that a meal here costs at least twice as much as it would at any of the other decent dim sum restaurants in and around SF - just compare the menus. Unfortunately, there's not much that they offer to justify this price difference. The food here is good, but not significantly better than elsewhere. The service? If anything, it's WORSE here than your average dim sum place. There are some items that they don't carry on the carts, which you need to order yourself. But none of the staff will come to your table to take your order, so you'll have to hunt them down yourself. And they only send 2 or 3 carts around the very large restaurant, so getting something you want could take a long, long time.

I can think of two things that Yank Sing has going for it. The first is their location. If you work close by, then obviously this is going to be your go-to place. For those living outside of SF (or even just another part of SF), it's not worth traveling here for dim sum - go to Chinatown instead and save your money. The second is that their staff knows better English than at most Chinese restaurants, which is helpful for non-Chinese customers. I wouldn't be surprised if this fact alone is responsible for many of the awards that they win.
author: Bo D.

description: I love Yank Sing and have for years. Whenever I get back to the Bay Area I try to visit. Don't miss the Shanghai dumplings!!
author: Will C.

description:
This place caters to an american crowd, as we realized after sitting down. We were the only asians dining there, haha big red flag already. If people from the same ethnicity as the restaurant are not dining there, that really tells you something. When I looked around the other tables and there were wine glasses present, I really tried not to be bias towards the food.

We ordered the normal stuff for Dim Sum, egg tarts, chicken feet, BBQ Pork Buns, ground beef rice flour rolls, and of course the XLB (Xiao Long Bao, Shanghai Dumplings). We actually came here especially for the Xiao Long Bao, because we heard so much good things about it. Wow, were we sorely disappointed. The xiao long bao here are not uniformly made, the skin is too thick and filling is not consistent from one dumpling to another. I have never had such a bad experience eating xiao long bao. It is very tough to have proper XLB when you've had them from Din Tai Fung in Taiwan; hands down the best I have had. The locations in Arcadia are second, but still the best in the United States. Don't waste your appetite on the XLB here, they are very poorly executed.

The rest of the dim sum items were not special at all, and with the inflated price tag on every dish, I demand a wow factor.

All and all a very subpar dim sum place, not for me. But if you are intimidated by the normal dim sum restaurants where they only speak chinese, then this might be a good place for you, since all the servers speak english too. Or if you like having a glass of wine with your dim sum, though odd, this can cater to your needs.
author: Michael W.

description:
Yank Sing has some of the best chinese food I've tasted in San Francisco!  Even my wife approved.  Their Show Lump bow (beef soup dumplings ~ 16$ for 8 of them!!) were excellent: not many places in the US can make them this good.  Their Cha show fan (beef rolls) were delicious as well.  Both were quite flavorful.  The restaurant and it's bathroom was very clean.  On Saturday, there was a 10 minute wait for our table.

The only downside is, this restaurant is quite expensive, like most other restaurants in the area.
author: Pascal A.

description:
This is my favorite Dim Sum in northern California, simply because it's clean, their meats are of higher quality,  they either use very little or no MSG because I don't feel thirsty leaving this place, and overall, experience is nice.

Lots of ladies come out constantly with fresh food, rarely do you find it sitting there. They also offer roast duck but by the piece/bun at $5 a pop which is pricier. Dim sum overall at Yank Sing is pricier than other places, but well worth it for a celebration with family or friends. I also love their xiao long baos  - not as great as Din Tai Fung, but really quite nice and juicy already!

It gets busy here so get early on weekend peak hours! Parking can be validated in the Garage below at this location!
author: Veronica S.

description: Probably one of the better XLBs I've ever had. Better than Din Tai Fung. It is pricey here but if you don't mind forking over more $ to get fast service and good dim sum, this is the place for you. They have plenty of carts and if you ask for something, you will get it. Each server wears a headset and they communicate to one another to get whatever dish you requested in minutes. Dim sum and good service never go together but they do here and they speak English too!
author: Linda P.

description:
Talk about efficiency...within the first minute of taking your seat, carts start zipping by you and before you know it you could easily have 5 things on your table...my recommendation is to let them take a few laps, look around at what's on other people's tables and make a educated attempt at ordering. 

Steamed pork soup dumplings are some of the best I have had. (think its called Shanghai dumpling)

Pork buns are amazing.

Pork Siu Mye are always worth it.

I am forever a fan and will come back often!
author: Derek S.

description: This was a fun dim sum experience with the carts but I'm only giving 4 stars because it was a bit pricey for small portions of food that was good, not great. I usually pick up dim sum from a bakery in Chinatown and will leave with two bags full of delicious food and only spend $20 for all of it. The food was good but I feel like I get more bang for my buck from hole in the wall bakeries in Chinatown. I guess you pay for the experience of the carts going around from table to table but it just wasn't worth how much money we spent.
author: Jordan M.

description:
Go ahead and call me broke.. I'm just a college student.
Visitors please be aware of their pricing before you even step in... (If you are familiar of what eating dim sum should cost you)
I was wondering how good they are since they got good feedback from many blogs and rating sites, so decided to try it out this morning.
Place looked clean, but still noisy like other dim sum places, and was slow to give my change back (took 10 mins).
Let's cut to the main point, their pricing is just ridiculous. Very super unreasonable for dim-sum $$$$$$$.
First of all, their "House special" Shanghai Pork Dumpling. Looks delicious and indeed it was, but $14 for 6 pcs. What !? World famous Din Tai Fung only charge $9.5 for 10 pcs, and they are more professional too.
Second, Pork & Shrimp Siu Mye, it's nothing special than other dim-sum places, but you have that $7.15 for 4 pcs.
Next, fried "Sweet rice dumpling"... bro you over-fried it, and it was $10.70 for 4 pcs.
And peking duck rolled through, looks delicious, ordered 2 (funny it was priced by buns), $6.55 each bun. ($13.10 for 2 buns w/ little meats, and it wasn't really crispy). With same price, I could get a half duck with 6+ buns.
Most ridiculous one, Egg custard Tart 4 pcs for $11.70, FXXX these are only 3 for $1.60 at Chinatown.
I stopped ordering after I was aware of their pricing... total came up about $85 before tips for 2 people, and we were not full.
Other things to be mentioned, they have 4 Spring Rolls for $10.70, and Wonton soup for $14, lol.

They have the old fashion style food carts and the dim-sum card stamping, but each food have their individual ridiculous pricing.
COME ON PLEASE, YOU CAN GET ALL THESE FOODS IN MULTIPLE DIM-SUM RESTAURANTS OVER CHINATOWN THAT ARE FEW BLOCKS AWAY THAT ARE WAY CHEAPER WITH EQUAL QUALITY OR EVEN BETTER.

I'm a college student, their price didn't seem right to me. If you are not rich like me, you better avoid this place.
If you are rich, I still suggest you to go over Chinatown's Dim-Sum restaurants for a different experience with wayyyyyyyy reasonable price point.
I'm Chinese, and Dim-sum has never been that expensive before... Chill 

Btw there's no free parking.
author: Nick C.

description:
If there was Chinese version of High T, Yang Sing is IT. 

Into the maze of tables and rooms separated by partitions of Chinese motif etched glass, hostesses donning the return of the side slit cheongsams lithely escort you to your special table. 
Having evolved from it's legendary humble beginnings on Broadway, for its celestial taro croquettes, exquisite Jasmine and Gook Bo teas, and quick & efficient table service, Yang Sing is the pinnacle synonymous with San Francisco Dim Sum, with style and sophistication unparalleled outside of Hong Kong.  

Desserts . . . visually as well as tasty tasteful the little gems showcased like jewels on a cart.  -the most heavenly, lightest custard cups in the world are made here.  

- boldly treading outside the box, serving popularized Shanghainese delights, as well as unique inventions, and even some items traditionally served only at dinner and banquets!

Ultimately, we know how excellent it is when prices are secondary after the fact.

The Atrium adjacent is also available for the POSH posh weddings on a weekend day.
author: Clifford L.

description:
Sub par dim sum.
Nothing was amazing. 
It's overpriced for what it is.
Been here two times and I would not recommend coming here.

I have yet to find a great dim sum spot in the city.
author: Heejin L.

description:
Really?!?!

$7 for minute serving of chinese brocolli?

$9 for three shrimp and chive dumplings?

$9 for luke warm chicken egg rolls?

$22 for two pieces of cold peking duck?

Granted, the Tea was delicious, the Xiao Long Bao was very good, and the custard tarts were some of the freshest i've had.

I left there still hungry with my Dim Sum budget eaten up for the next 3 months.

This could be the worst food value in the bay area.

Don't buy the hype.

REALLY?!?!
author: Bradley H.

description:
My wife and I dined here recently as guests at a Chinese wedding banquet, about 300 people, held in the enormous atrium of One Rincon Center.  Eight or so courses (I lost count at some point in the proceedings); everything first-rate to my western palate.  Open bar all evening.   Glad I wasn't paying for it!  Attentive service.

The one downside was something beyond the restaurant's control, the parking.  We had validated parking in in the Rincon Center garage, which was all well and good; but this building has one of the worst laid out parking facilities I have ever tried to navigate, with narrow spaces, a forest of pillars surrounded by curbs high enough to interfere with door opening, and tight, awkward turns to get into the spaces.  When I come back here (I'm quite curious about their regular dim sum menu), it will be as a BART passenger.
author: Alan F.

description: Excellent deem sum. Don't overdo the dumplings - far more interesting items on the menu. Outstanding string beans as well as the glazed walnut salad - both containing seafood. Peking duck was superb!!
author: Kesh G.

description:
I usually don't write reviews of dim sum places, because up until 4-5 years ago, I had never had dim sum before!  However, since then, I'm frequented many dim sum places across the Bay area, and I have a better idea of what's good and what's not (at least to my palate).

I'd heard a lot about Yank Sing prior to coming.  Mainly that: 1. the food was really good, and 2. the prices were really high.  Based on how popular it is, I was expecting a long wait.  I preferred to sit inside (for fear of getting less attention outside), but even then, the wait was not bad (less than 15 minutes at 11am on a Saturday).

One thing that I noticed right away (and kept noticing throughout) was that the service here was AMAZING.  It far exceeds any dim sum place, and is amazing even if you were discounting that it's a dim sum place.  All the carts seemed to make sure to stop at each table and get us food right away.  Before we had finished sitting down, we had 3 plates in front of us.  On top of that, when we asked about one dish, they were prompt to call in another person to bring that cart over to us.  As if that weren't amazing already, when we asked about another dish that they had run out of, they made it fresh for us and it came out piping hot!!

Now onto the food.  The best things for me were the har gow (the outside of the dumpling was soooo soft and good), the egg custard buns (this was the dish that came out piping hot and they were definitely worth the wait -- best egg custard buns I've ever had), and the egg tarts.

Some of the other dishes were a bit lackluster for me, for instance, the shrimp crepe dish (don't know what it's called in Chinese), which had chives mixed in and had a sweet soy sauce rather than a regular soy sauce -- this is usually my favorite dim sum dish and these two differences made me like it less.  The siu mai and the shanghai soup dumplings (a.k.a. xiao long bao; served lukewarm) were also not as good as I've had elsewhere.

When the bill came out, it wasn't cheap by any means, but I've had just about that much at other places (about $33/person including tax and tip).  I think that for the service and quantity of food, the price was actually not bad!  Had we had a 4th person, the value might've been even better.  However, given that it's pricier than other dim sum places, this is probably a "splurge when I can" place.

Thank you Yank Sing for the amazing service!! Special shout-out to Luis, who was the best of them all!
author: Alice M.

description:
My apologies if this is politically incorrect, but as my coworker put it, Yank Sing is dim sum for white people. This restaurant caters to the fancy business FiDi people so don't visit anticipating authentic dim sum.

I'm the great, great, great granddaughter of the almighty dim sum creator--joking. However, I do know my dim sum, and Yank Sing offers decent food at best. Yes, this is an upscale Chinese restaurant with good service. Yes, the dim sum dishes are aesthetically pleasing. Yes, you pay close to an arm and a leg for your meal. Yet, at the end, the dim sum is just OK. I came here for a lunch meeting with a party of eight. Our bill was well over $200 before tips (but I'm unsure if they autograt). If you have to pay $20+ individually for dim sum, it better be the best damn dim sum outside of Hong Kong (note: which Yank Sing is not).

We ordered the typical items: shrimp dumplings, siu mai (shrimp and pork dumplings), shrimp rice noodle rolls, shrimp and chives dumplings, BBQ pork buns (baked AND steamed), potstickers, egg tarts, and spring rolls. We even had honey walnut prawns! All of these dishes were average, although I did not try everything. I know, we ate A LOT of shrimp. 

I opted for some of the less Americanized stuff and asked for the ham sui gok (deep-fried pork dumplings), deep-fried taro puffs, chicken feet, and sticky rice in lotus leaf. I didn't eat the chicken feet but they looked measly. The rest of the dishes were actually pretty tasty. The ham sui gok was crunchy and chewy with a sweet honey shell but the meat filling lacked seasoning. The taro puffs were good but not enough taro flavor. I really enjoyed the sticky rice; it was moist and packed with pork and saucy goodness. This was by far my favorite item. 

Overall, everything was mediocre and bland. The dim sum wasn't too greasy, which is a plus. Yank Sing's selection is relatively small compared to other restaurants. I wish they had more choices but they are serving a different crowd. The wraps for the dumplings were too thick and hard. Portions are on the smaller side. Yank Sing does have a few vegetarian items but it's really difficult to do vegetarian for dim sum (their mushrooms dumplings were alright). Parking is impossible during lunch hours, even with their parking lot. (The restaurant does validate.) I came with low expectations and left with low impressions. This isn't anywhere close to legit or delicious dim sum but if you're willing to pay the extra dollars, swing by Yank Sing.
author: Judy H.

description:
My husband and I decided on Yank Sing on a whim - I work near this location.

The food quality was good - but a lot of the food was cold.

I give this place 3 stars because it was extremely expensive for what it was $75 for a small meal for two people.  This would be half or less anywhere else with the same quality.  

I wouldn't go back.
author: Mariza W.

description: We went during lunch time so it was really busy but still received excellent service. The only downfall to this restaurant is that it's much more expensive compared to other dim sum places but food was really good.
author: Judy K.

description: Excellent food! Dumplings made right! Try the soup dumplings the best to offer! Reservations recommended!
author: Ekta S.

description:
Excellent dimsum. The food was decadent and tasty. However.. coming from Boston it isn't really saying much so I will just rate this based on the restaurant's ambiance and staff tentativeness. 

The decor of the restaurant was interesting. Not too many sculptures of dragons and phoenixes that you'd typically find in a regular chinese dimsum restaurant. I went on a Sunday morning and the first thing I've noticed was seating outside the restaurant in the middle of the plaza. Yes, the restaurant is located in a plaza. All of the other shops closed and Yank Sing was the only place open. I was seated inside the restaurant and it made me sad because I really wanted to dine outside where there was a waterfall from the roof. It was a great focal point. 

Staff tentativeness was on point. I could pretty much order anything I wanted without waiting for the cart to come over because all of the old asian women pushing the carts had walkie talkies. I pretty much ordered one thing from one cart and she called all the other carts to come straight to me. 

PRICE WISE: Yes it was expensive. but Yes it was worth it.
author: Andrew K.

description:
Came here on a spontaneous date today. I was recovering from a fever and refused to spend another day in bed wasting away. We were going to go for dinner but I found out they closed at 4pm so we came at 1pm instead because we were both craving dim sum at that point and refused to settle for anything else. I was kind of on the fence since I've always heard mixed reviews about this place and theres nothing worse than paying a high price for shitty food but that was not an issue. 

If you can find street parking, go for it. The parking lot is a never ending clusterfuck of a labyrinth. Theres seriously cars going in every and all directions and half the parking lot is parallel parking and the other half doesn't even look like a parking lot and forget about it if you have a big car. If it weren't for the super nice parking lot attendant, we would've given up entirely. Apparently you can park on the first floor reserved parking. Then you just take the elevator up to the restaurant. Oh and make sure you get your parking validated! 

The place was pretty packed, never an empty table. Make sure to make reservations if you don't want to wait. The restaurant was filled with mostly white people if that tells you anything. I didn't even notice until my date told me to be honest. 

I watched in horror as my date dumped out all the soup in his Shanghai Dumplings and I laughed at myself when I told him to bust out some Chinese and then realizing they speak Cantonese in dim sum places and not Mandarin. 

We also got the shiitake mushroom dumplings, shrimp dumplings, shrimp rice rolls, egg tarts, giant thing of baked cod, sticky rice, and some other stuff.  Everything was good except the cod was kind of overcooked and cold but it was still good. The egg tarts and shrimp dumplings were my favorite. 

Service was good, especially for a Chinese restaurant. It came out to be $70 for the food and around $8 for the tea and his Coke. I thought it was going to come out to be way more since I didn't know the prices of anything we were ordering and we kept getting plate after plate of food and all the other reviews freaked me out about the end price. I think it averages out to around $7/plate. I don't know how I feel about spending this much for dim sum (or as they like to call it, deem sum) but I would definitely take my parents here the next time they're in town. 

Oh and props to them for using compostable take out boxes!

*fun fact edit: I just found out my mother had her wedding banquet here way back when with my dad!
author: Tiffany V.

description:
I'm torn between giving this place between 2 and 3 stars, but because it does have redeeming qualities (i.e. good food), I will be generous and give Yank Sing 3 stars. Fiance said he would give this place 2 stars.

This review is based on three experiences.

1. Inquiry/meeting as potential wedding reception site:

I'm getting married and because I'm Chinese there was no way I was going to serve my family American food. God forbid I make my grandma eat a salad!
However, I also wanted to host my reception at a "nice" venue. I looked high and low for a Chinese restaurant in the Bay Area that did not have tacky decor (you know what I mean - flying dragons). The choices are limited and the other "high-end" Chinese restaurants in the Bay Area just didn't work out for with some of our priorities. 

Yank Sing seemed to meet all of our needs:
-Aesthetically-pleasing Chinese food 
- We could book the entire restaurant to accommodate our 100 guests and thus, did not have to share the space with other restaurant patrons (not possible with HK East Ocean unless we wanted to fork over $20,000).
-Beautiful decor and ambience
-Great reviews on service
-Validated parking for guests

We met with Daisy Hung who was very professional, prompt, and answered all of our questions in great detail. We were considering our menu combinations and Daisy worked with us to reprice out all of our menu substitutions.

Since we did not want to spent close to $1000 on a tasting, we decided to try their dim sum.

2. Dim sum experience: 

So my fiance and I made a reservation for dim sum on a weekend. I don't know about weekdays, but if you don't make reservations you will probably not eat. The place was completely packed.

Initially the cart pushers were very prompt and attentive. We ordered several traditional dim sum items as well as some food that's more likely served at banquets  and dinners such as the honey walnut shrimp, fried crab claws, and Chilean sea bass. Everything was very good. Not overly greasy.

Towards the end, the carts didn't seem to stop by as often. I wanted to try their mango pudding since that was to be served at the wedding. It took about 10 minutes for someone to get this to me.

When it was time to get the check it seemed like they were not concerned about all the people waiting for a table. We told them that we were ready to get the check. Waited for about 5 minutes and then my fiance goes to the restroom. When he is done, the check is still not ready. I went to the restroom, came back, and still no check. We had to flag several waitstaff for the check and after waiting about a total of 20 minutes we finally got it.

I knew this was not going to be a cheap meal especially because we got the sea bass. However, $90 on dim sum for 2 people is just insane. Seriously, you can get dim sum on par to this place for half the price. The food was really good, but not THAT good.

3. Booking Yank Sing for wedding venue: NOT POSSIBLE for 2014

Despite the slow service towards the end of our meal, we still wanted to book Yank Sing for our reception site. 

We were emailing Daisy back and forth and wanted to see about the pricing for a few menu substitutions. We didn't hear from her for a few days and she said that she's been busy with wedding banquets and will get back to us the following week. No word from her that week so we send a follow-up email. For another week, still no word from her. Finally after about 2 and a half weeks, we get this email from her: 

"Thank you for your email, my sincere apologies for the delay. 

Unfortunately, after much thought and consideration, our company has made a decision to restructure our business model and therefore will not be taking events from 2014 onwards. We sincerely thank you for considering Yank Sing for your special day, and apologize for any inconvenience.

Should you have any questions, please do not hesitate to contact me. 

With kind regards,
Daisy"

At this point, I was really upset. We had been communicating for about 2 months and was looking forward to checking this item off my list. Now back to square one.

In the end, I think things will all work out! We found a reception site and booked Ginger Cafe for our catering. So far, they've been so amazing. I'll write an official review after our wedding.

Final words: Try Yank Sing if you want to impress your date and have the funds to overspend on dim sum. I'm glad that I got to try this place, but I will not be returning.

Glad to get this off my chest!!!

tl;dr -  Good food, but too expensive for dim sum. Long wait time to receive check. Not taking 2014 wedding events.

Suggestions for Chinese off-site catering (the only 2 I could find in the whole damn Bay Area):
Ginger Cafe
Le's Kitchen Catering

Chinese restaurants with nice ambience (not tacky):
Hong Kong East Ocean
Koi Palace
ABC Seafood Restaurant
author: Stella M.

description:
Yank Sing was recommended to me by a long time SF resident. I was a little put off by the fact that it is a really nice restaurant in the middle of a business mall. Weird location. However, the food was amazing!! I don't even know what I had. They just kept bringing things around and I tried them all. I loved every bite. 

It was crazy busy, over an hour wait for two people at 3pm so we snagged two seats at the bar and the owner or manager came over to us and asked us to let her know if there was anything on the menu that we wanted to try but was not coming around. Great customer service! We asked for a crab dish that we had not seen yet and 5 minutes later, there is was. We will be back again and again. Drinks were great too!
author: Bridget B.

description:
Although I enjoyed the food at Yank Sing, I have mixed emotions about the whole dining experience.

Let me start off by saying the food is good. It isn't the best, but you can tell it is high quality and tasty. The standard har gao and siu mai were good and the xiao long bao was amazing! Must order if you do go.

What causes me to second guess is a few things. The queue is atrociously long. For a table of two, we literally had to wait an hour. I understand that it's popular, but the food does not warrant that long of a wait, in my opinion. Next, this place is expensive! This place will yank your wallet and make you sing Usher's "OMG" (see what I did there?). Don't even think about the cheap dim sum you could have had nearby in Chinatown because it'll ruin your experience. Third, this place caters to the dim sum newbie so I'm constantly having to shoo away carts that have these contemporary/fusiony dishes that probably look better on paper than in reality. This means I have to make an effort to scout out all the traditional dishes I want. I'm here to eat, not accomplish an assassination mission.

All jokes aside, Yank Sing is good, but all of those set backs are enough for me to not come back often.
author: David P.

description:
I was visiting San Fransisco a few months ago and I happened to come across Yank Sing. I didn't really know what to expect but when we sat down it was such a fun experience! I had never been to a restaurant where the waiters/waitresses run around with ready to eat food in carts so that was really different. 

All the food was really good but more importantly...the dim sum. I have always liked dumplings but this really did top my list of favorite meals. I live on the other side of the country in Miami and there is just no place like Yank Sing here - not even close. If I flew to San Fransisco for 24 hours and could only have one meal there, this would definitely be the place.
author: Desi K.

description:
I don't know how they make the skin of their dumpling so chewy.
well if i knew, i'd own a successful restaurant.

I'd say their SOUP DUMPLINGS are up there with Din Tai Fung in L.A and Joe's Shanghai in NY.

The broth is a lil fattier tasting compared to the other two.
And the dumpling skin's definitely chewier.....lol

stick to their soup dumplings and you won't regret it.
author: Ji K.

description:
alright folks, here's the deal, straight up.

yank sing is NOT cheap.
yank sing is EXPENSIVE.
yank sing is so WORTH EVERY PENNY!!!

in case you didn't know...
yank sing has been in san francisco for 53 years!
founded in 1958 by helen chan.
3 generations later, her granddaughter is in the kitchen every day.
james beard award winner.
michelin guide recommended.

***run-on sentence alert***
i'd say they've earned their right to charge a little bit more for their amazing food selections (and stellar service) than other places that just churn out mediocre eats for those that care more about their pocket book and less about their palate.
i am not one of those people.
give me something that i've had a million times over but do it in a way that i've never experienced before and i'll pay you whatever you charge.
i'd rather spend $100 on amazing food that i'll remember for a lifetime than $50 on good food that i'll likely forget about tomorrow.

i'm chinese so i have to have my dim sum fix.
BUT i don't eat meat.
WTF am i supposed to do???
the answer?
yank sing, bitches!!! (am i allowed to say that?)
=o)
they have the largest selection of vegetarian items i've ever seen at any dim sum place.

the ingredients are super fresh.
they make every single thing on their menu from scratch.
they have a huge menu with all kinds of different items that will surely please anybody.
like i said, i'm chinese, i've had me some dim sum in my 30+ years of life.
i've never had such good dim sum as i've had at yank sing.

some of my faves:

shanghai dumplings - Yank Sing signature dish of minced Kurobuta Pork, scallion and ginger wrapped and steamed in its own aromatic broth.
the absolute, hands down, best i've ever had (back when i used to eat meat).
the skin is so thin and yet, somehow, stays completely intact and remains ever so al dente even with the soup inside of it.
how do they do it?
i wish i knew.

mushroom dumplings - a mixture of wild mushrooms sauteed to perfection, stuffed in a wrapper and steamed to perfection.

seafood and basil dumplings - my all time fave! 

snow pea shoot dumplings - stuffed with a filling of chopped snow peas, roasted pine nuts and a hint of ginger, garlic and sesame oil.

mandarin dumplings w/ chives - fresh herb filling of hand-chopped chinese garlic, chives, cilantro and shrimp stuffed in translucent 'three-cornered-hat' dumplings.

stuffed lotus leaf - best i've ever had.
i'll sit there with my stix and pick out all the meat just so i can eat it.

savory vegetable dumpling - stuffed with a savory mild-curried vegetarian filling of rare sichuan bamboo fungus, cabbage, bamboo shoots, carrots, sun-dried bean curd sticks and gingko nuts.

goldfish dumpling - crunchy shrimp, winter bamboo shoot tips, and cilantro stuffed in a hand- wrapped translucent goldfish-shaped dumpling.

steamed pork buns - my hubby's fave!

egg custard tart - it really is "velvety smooth"
the pastry shell is super flaky.
best ever.

spinach dumpling - hand-chopped spinach, water chestnuts, carrots, shitake mushrooms, bamboo shoots in a natural chive juice colored dumpling.

taro root dumpling - again, i will sit there and pick out all the lil pieces o meat just so i can eat it.

sweet rice dumpling - you guessed it, picking out the meat in this one too.

egg custard buns - we call these 'boobs'.
best boobs i've ever had.

as for service.....you will never find better service at a dim sum restaurant anywhere.
you may try, but you will not succeed.
from the moment you sit down, you feel as though you're the only person dining there even though the entire restaurant is packed.
the servers are attentive and quick.
i require a lot of attention as many of my vegetarian dishes are not readily available on the carts so i'm usually ordering from the servers and they are more than happy to help.
i place my orders with them and out comes my food shortly afterward, piping hot.

so, if you're willing to spend a little bit more money than usual on much better dim sum than usual, yank sing is the place.
author: Christina W.

description:
The first couple times I came to Yank Sing, I thought it was a solid 4-5 star place but I soon learned that it's hit or miss after a couple 2 star experiences. The best way to do this review justice is to just list pros and cons... 

Pros -- good Dim Sum, nice atmosphere...esp the atrium (if you enjoy a lively, bustling vibe), and some solid main course dishes (sea bass,  general's chicken). 

Cons -- long waits to be seated, the staff can be a little pushy with the carts, the food can be cold / not fresh at times, if you forego the carts and order directly from the server they will likely completely screw it up aaaaaaaand everything is over-priced.
author: S T.

description: Horrible service every time I go so that's 0 stars. The food is average and way overpriced. 2 stars. ...and that's being generous!
author: Samantha S.

description: Incredible food and the service to match! I went for lunch today, the restaurant was packed, and I didn't have a reservation. I was ready to sit at the bar (for which there was no wait), but when the server saw I was pregnant, she insisted on seating us (immediately) at a table for my comfort.
author: Kelly M.

description:
The food here is 5 stars and consistently has been for at least the last 8 years I've been eating here... the decor and environment is a bit festive and the perfect place to grab some dim sum on the weekend...

The service is between a 2 and a 3... the waiters/waitresses are great, but the front desk staff (the ones that take your name down and call you once your table is ready) suck! They are just always rude, and idk go check it out yourself... it's not that bad but since it is a classy dim sum place you'd think they'd be classy as well!
author: Nolan M.

description:
People should just quit babbling about the slightly higher dim-sum price here. Americans should eventually learn that the real Chinese food is NOT your cheap sweet and sour chicken in a dark greasy hole in the wall. I am super relieved to see all the change that new immigrants have brought to Chinese restaurants here. 

Yank Sing may not be the exact real deal in China but it is so damn close. I just love having some decent dim sum in a clean and beautiful restaurant and go to a spotless restroom afterward! Waiters and host have smile on the face and actually pay attention to you? Hallelujah!

One thing they could do better is to try to keep their food hotter. Har Gow tastes like yesterday's leftover once

 it is just slightly cold. Actually most steamed and fried dim sum items should be enjoyed piping hot. Other than that, perfect.
author: Cathy S.

description:
$96 for three people where I could get dim sum just as good on the Peninsula for a fraction of the price. 

Thanks but no thanks, I won't be coming back.
author: Ilya V.

description:
Highlights: 
- Wait time was about 25mins or less around 1pm on Saturday.
- Shrimp and leek dumplings were my favorite. Thin skin and quality flavorful filling.
- If you haven't tried their pork buns (baked or steamed), they're the best!
- Egg tarts were really good. Flakey crust and not too sweet. I like that they allow you to do half orders (2 qty) or full orders (4 qty).
- Validated parking for 3 hours in the garage that is connected to their restaurant (121 Spear St).

Improvements:
- Skip chicken feet. Too salty.
- It seemed like everything that came out from the carts were the same things rotated. If you don't see something you want, ask the waitress and they will bring it out for you. 

Tip: 3 people for about $90, approx. 10 different items tried.
author: Tracy T.

description:
This is a review for their take-away option.

I have no idea why so the line here is long.  I was craving seafood dim sum so opted for the "Seafood Supreme" option.  Unfortunately, it consists of five tiny dim sum and the remaining 3/4 of the carton is filled with lumpy, cheap vegetable chow mein.  

Terrible quality and value for the cost, I'll not be eating here again.  I am seriously considering just throwing it out and buying another lunch from somewhere else.
author: O S.

description:
Yes, it's expensive.  No, it's not in Chinatown.  But so what.  The dim sum here is fantastic.  Soup dumplings, yes.  "A house specialty" according to our server, and I can see why.  These soup dumplings are smaller and more delicate than others I have tried, and are accompanied by an addictive vinegar/ginger sauce.  Other dumplings, yes.  All are well made and subtly flavored.  In fact, everything we tried was quite good.

We arrived with a reservation at 1030 on a Saturday morning, and the place was near empty.  Within an hour, it had turned into a madhouse.  Reservations are well advised.  

What are you waiting for?
author: Adam W.

description: Yikes! The bill was pretty steep. Dim-sum and it's cousin Sushi, are definitely a good way to separate people from their cash...fast! It's probably been 15 years since the last time I ate here...not so easy to post things back then...anyway...good dim-sum can be had within a wide price range and from different places... there's no mistaking the quality of the dim-sum at Yank Sing...you gotta try the Peking duck which unlike other places had flavor and was not greasy, the Purple Cabbage salad with it's refreshing citrus flavor, and the awesome Honey Glazed Sea Bass...I don't get the same quality anywhere else I must admit...unfortunately, I'm going to have to save this place for special occasions or impressing that out of town guest or at bonus season... and get my daily dim-sum fix somewhere not detrimental to my cash flow.
author: Orlando J.

description:
I remember when going out for Dim Sum was a cheap treat!

Everything about Yank Sing was good.  The atmosphere (a little corporate), the service and the food (skip the bbq pork buns.)  But, the bill was a total shock.  I'm accustomed with SF food prices, but $58.00 for 5 dim sum plates and 1 diet soda was outrageous. Even though I picked up the tab, I was embarrassed when my friend asked how much the bill was.  In good conscious I cannot recommend this place; simply based on price.

I'm sure there are other Dim Sum places in SF with much better value.
author: Steve S.

description:
Came here for lunch on a Monday and didn't have to wait for a table. Pretty pricey though, so prepare to drop $30/person for a handful of dumplings.

Food:
+Salad- Cabbage salad with walnuts; it was refreshing and tasty; good to share for 2
+Shrimp Steamed Dumplings- pretty tasty and hearty amounts of shrimp
+Chicken & Mushroom Dumplings- only 2 per order but still quite tasty; didn't taste the individual flavors bc its really mashed together
+Savory Vegetable Dumplings- hubs liked this
+Mushroom Dumlings- not bad, just a ton of shiitake mushrooms

*want to try the Shanghai and seafood basil dumplings next time and maybe the sea bass roll if there's another non-veg with me!

Ambience:
Large, roomy, upscale setting restaurant in the financial district. It's a very hustle-bustle feel because they are just carting around ready to go food. No need for a menu, just say yes or no to what they're offering (fogo de chao style).

Service
The whole process is geared towards getting you in and out asap, which I can appreciate. However, as soon as we sat down, we were overwhelmed with the servers asking us if we wanted 5 different types of dumplings right in front of our face.

-Hungry Hungry Pongy
author: Sangita A.

description:
Pros: compared to other dim sum places I've been to (Jing Fung in NYC, Hei La Moon in Boston, Emerald in San Diego, the one in the old Newseum building in Arlington, VA), the food quality was great in my opinion. Thought they did all the staples well, and also had better vegetable options than I've had before in dim sum.  Also feels classier than the usual dim sum places I've visited, which was nice. 

Cons: by far the most I've ever paid for dim sum; like twice as much more. Oof. Enough where I didn't have that usual happy dim sum feeling of getting lunch and a show for half price. 

In short, you get what you're paying for, but that means it ain't cheap. Definitely go if someone else is paying.
author: Aaron S.

description: Very fresh. Very tasty. Very clean. The service is attentive.   We always make it a point to come here whenever we visit SF.
author: Teri K.

description:
What a great place to eat! And eat and eat and eat!

On my travels in Southeast Asia my favorite food became dim sum, and this is the place to enjoy having your heart touched by this wonderful cuisine.
