Plate after plate of exquisite delights are brought round, sometimes on metal steam carts and sometimes on trays. The variety is wonderful and the preparation excellent.  The servers help you out by explaining what is what, and they're friendly and smiling. Did I mention the Shanghai soup buns? OMG! The best in the City, bar none. Better than I've enjoyed in Shanghai and I ate my way thru that town a couple of times.

Come enjoy! Now (Chinese New Year 2012) is a great time for special treats.

Enjoy!
author: William M.

description:
This is not based on cost.

Fresh, clean, timely, good quality. I'd probably just get everything in the top part of the menu minus the vegetarian stuff b/c I can't vouch for those items.

4 of us (we are big eaters) was about $100. We left pretty full. 

I definitely take out of towners here and wouldn't just wander over on my own.
author: Vicki T.

description:
As many pointed out, the biggest problem here is the price. For a group of 3~4, you're expecting a check that's way over $100. Now, in order to justify this tag, one or more has to meet from the follows:

1) Taste: it is good, but not the best in SF. Except for the Xiao Long Bao, many steamed Dim Sum are just around par. The wraps are slightly thick, ingredients are not superb, taste/spice was just around the norm.

2) Variety: most streamed/fried Dim Sums are the usual suspects. I was expecting more authentic variety; again at this price tag. 

3) Service: personally, the biggest thing that matter in Dim Sum is the speed, and that's not just because I want it first, but it's because the Dim Sum's taste quickly degrades after it leaves the kitchen. I think this is the reason why some of the modernized/westernized restaurants (e.g., Din Tai Fung) are not using the cart, but directly serving from the kitchen. There cart speed (or number of carts) are just around average.

4) Quality: At this price, you can't expect a single Dim Sum to go wrong. But one of our Xiao Long Bao had a hole and leaked its juice...

The only thing that was good was the parking (though they still charge $4). 

Not recommended, especially in this city.
author: Kunhyuk K.

description:
My coworker & I went here for lunch a few Fridays ago.  I knew it was going to be pricey but was so curious about Yank Sing after hearing about it so much.  

Got here right before 12 & didn't have to wait for a table.  We both don't drink tea, but even if we did we'd skip it because they charge up there for it.  

We got: xiao long bao, siu mai, cha siu cheong (bbq pork rice noodle roll), mango pudding, ha gaw, & crispy shrimp.  Everything tasted good & you can tell that the quality is better than your average dim sum place.  But when there's quality there's a price to pay!  We split the bill in half & she got a coke too so six dishes & a coke pre-tip was $23 a piece.  Everything tasted good & the xiao long bao was juicy which is very rare for a Cantonese restaurant as it's a Shanghai specialty.  

The restaurant is nice it's just damn pricey!  The service is friendly and speaks English so there should be no confusion for anyone.  So torn between a 3 & 4, just due to price.  But where else can you go in the area for dim sum besides City View?  Exactly!  So I'll round up to a 4.
author: Cat C.

description:
My favorite dim sum in the city, if not in the entire Bay Area. 

Went with my wife to this cozy dim sum restaurant. He's been here before several time with business colleges but this was my first time. Found it a little overwhelming at first with all these servers shoving little dishes from their food carts at you. 

After going to Yank Sing, it's very hard for any other dim sum restaurant to compare. My favorite dish is the soup dumpling - heavenly.

It is spotless and service is more than optimal. Staff was very accommodating and respectful of our needs.
author: Narayan N.

description: We came here for a dim sum Sunday brunch. I'm not a fan of dim sum, but my dining companions love it so I tried it. The food was flavorful, not too salty or greasy. We loved it and will definitely return. We were clever to arrive just after they opened to receive immediate seating. By about 11 am a long line formed outside their door.
author: krissy S.

description: Greasy,  americanized, limited selection. The only authentic item was the xiao long baos. We got there as the doors opened, no wait. Line out the door, confused as to why.
author: Shelby W.

description:
I hadn't had dimsum in a long time, but a date suggested it so I said okay since it had been on my list for a while. 

We had all the traditional dimsum items and we got some items that the date has never had before which I was so happy that I had introduced him to some other items - turnip cakes and other stuff. The carts are so much fun! That's probably the best way to order dimsum. Definitely fun going with someone who didn't know too much about dimsum and ordering. Expensive, but delicious!
author: Nina Y.

description:
The food here is great.  I love the steamed pork buns.  The food is pricey, but seems to be comparable to other places in the financial district.  It has a big selection and I haven't had something I didn't like here.  

The bill can add up quickly so make sure to keep track of what you have ordered.
author: Lisa G.

description: Food is really good, ambiance isn't anything special. Also there is a parking structure and they validate parking!
author: Kelli L.

description:
MEH is the correct word for this place. It's location is fantastic and the restaurant is  beautiful, but the food is MEH. I came here with a couple of friends from out of town. The food is nothing spectacular... I've had better. Also, the prices here are ridiculous. There were 4 of us and we paid roughly $30pp. WHO pays this much for dim sum?! Dim sum is supposed to be cheap and delicious.

Overall, if you have friends from out of town and want them to eat mediocre dim sum, then by all means bring them to Yank Sing!
author: Heather R.

description:
No clue why/how Yank Sing has 3.5 stars.  I've eaten here a number of times and have yet to be disappointed. 

Yank Sing has CLEAN, HIGH QUALITY FOOD.  Some of the cleanest chinese food I've ever had.

Some of my favorites
- Wonton Soup
- Shrimp Dumplings
- Steam Pork Bun
- Sezchuan Chicken
- Fried Egg Roll

Tip - the baked pork bun sells out in the afternoon. Very popular item. 

I'm a regular and plan to be for years to come.
author: Nick M.

description:
Still the best dim sum in the city - hands down.

The service is quick and attentive.  And you'll find interesting and unique offerings not seen in most places.  Even the dim sum mainstays, like sui mai and spare ribs,  are above what I usually encounter in dim sum restaurants

We tried some dishes we hadn't had before- the shanghai dumplings - so unique with tasty pork broth inside and the fried cod - greaseless and moist!
author: Ruth S.

description: Cousin comes here often and knows one of the workers! Good dimsum to go. Egg tart was yummy. Char Sui bao was ok. Dumplings were nothing special but customer service was very welcoming! Small restaurant when you go inside to order. Located at financial district but they have seating outside which was good for big groups. Just to save time and money order to go!
author: Majell D.

description:
Yank Sing is comparable to Koi Palace in Daly City.  Very pricy.

Good dim sum, however, you can get better dim sum at a hole in a wall in Chinatown at fraction of the cost.  That's why I only gave 3 stars.

You don't have to wait long for the next cart to come by.  The restaurant is clean.  Good for bring your visitors if you want to impress.
author: Chris R.

description:
This reaturant is my favorite out of whole world since 1999 even before they open 2nd branch.
All of their menu from cart is the best besides strong Chinese herbs in it. It is little pricy however every dollar you spend at here is worth it.
My favorite from here is Xialongpao(i dont know if i spelled correctly), very juicy dumpling. 
Just this dish, that makes my day already happy. 
And i love their grilled seabass as well. Overall, their ingrediant and way of cooking done in just right. Perfectly balanced. 

Anytime craving for dimsum?? This is the place i would go even i am living in Los Angeles now.
author: Suerim K.

description:
Boasting superior quality, Yank Sing is easily in the top tier of dim sum restaurants in San Francisco.  The great variety of dishes are fine and delicious.  The dumplings are very juicy, savory, and delicate.  Unfortunately, saltiness is a notorious characteristic of Chinese food- but not here.  You are able to taste so much more of the flavors instead of MSG.  I wasn't a big fan of the rice noodle rolls though- very strange, gummy texture, like it was undercooked, which was very disappointing.

However, with all that this restaurant has going for it, there are a few drawbacks.  First is the price- it's outrageous!  Despite the quality, I find it incomprehensible that it's so much more expensive than anywhere else.  It's not justified.  Also, they charge a lot for tea!  For something that is practically indiscernible from other restaurants, it is ridiculous that they would try to trick you into paying so much for something so simple.  They're also a little pushy with the food and are constantly hawking you.

I would say that eating here is a nice treat to have once in while.  But for the most part, I would much rather go to a neighborhood place in the Sunset or Richmond.  Yank Sing tends to cater more towards Westerners and non-Chinese patrons.  But hey, it's in the Rincon Center- it's all about "presentation."
author: Brandon C.

description:
Soup Dumplings! https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Xiaolongbao

Was in SF for my BFF's wedding on 7/27, and came here with college friends for dim sum that Sunday before flying back to the East Coast. We had our usual dilemma of the fact that my friend is Northern Chinese (and speaks Mandarin), so none of us spoke Cantonese, but since we weren't in Chinatown, and we were at very popular and accessible (for anyone wanting to try dim sum) Yank Sing, it was fine. Also, while I did wonder if this was as "authentic" as other dim sum spots, my friends convinced me that Yank Sing uses better quality ingredients. It was delicious, just as expected.

Also, I really, really, REALLY loved the soup dumplings (and did not break one!) #firsttime
author: Sally M.

description:
Xiao long bao is just right, but the price has a little height. 

If you are looking for neatly presented Dim Sum you found the right place.   

Everything looks just right as far as it goes for a restaurant of this price range.

Seems like a power lunch spot where business people come to talk shop. 

Nice outdoor patio with heaters for that unpredictable SF weather.

Main concern is getting your dim sum lunch cart lady to find your table... and the price.  A small plate of dim sum can run you $12 per dish.
author: Ken C.

description:
It has been WAY too long since I have had Dim Sum in my life. I recently moved to the Bay area and realizing that there is such an abundance of amazing asian food, I just knew there was some Dim Sum deliciousness available to enjoy!

My friend from NYC was visiting and we used to Dim Sum it up all the time together last weekend, since we used to all the time on the East Coast. This place had some great reviews so we decided to commandeer a larger group of friends and check this place out.

The venue was spacious, definitely packed on a Saturday, however, the perfect thing about dim sum is that it's instant, the food is on every cart just at arms reach. They have tons of food options! So many delicious options, however, we were very surprised with how expensive our bill turned out to be. It was delicious, don't get me wrong, but yowza, why so pricey?

Service was great, we may return again, but for the price it was, I was a bit shocked that it wasn't the best dim sum I've ever had.
author: Akvile D.

description: Wow, I've never been to a dim sum place that cost almost your 1st born!  How do 4 people and a baby end up w/ a $200 check????  And leave as if we just had a snack?  The food was good but not that good! Yikes!  I felt bad that my brother in law paid for lunch!  If I had known, I'd just have tea!
author: Judy S.

description:
I took a client here for lunch after it had been highly recommended by a number of people, including those on Yelp.

Ugh. What a mistake. The dim sum was mediocre at best. 
--I couldn't eat the dry fried string beans because they were too salty and boring, as if salt could make up for tasteless vegetables.
--The siu mai had lumps of tough meat in it, and again no real flavor; 
--the char gow tasted like they came from, at best, Trader Joe's.
--The cabbage salad tasted only of that herb that tastes like soap (I'm not talking about cilantro, either, which I love). 
--The shrimp-covered deep fried lobster claws were rubbery and tasteless, even tasted like old refrigerator once you got through the fried breading.
--The eggplant was the ONLY good dish we had, out of seven choices.

 I would NEVER go here again; City View is much better. Hong Kong Lounge in the Richmond is **way** better. And East Ocean in Alameda, much much better. Even a crappy little restaurant called Mayflower on University in Berkeley has better standard dim sum.

So disappointing! Anyone who says Yank Sing has good authentic dim sum has probably not had good authentic dim sum ever....
author: Gina P.

description:
Came here with a girlfriend and her boyfriend.  The wait for dim sum wasn't bad and it was certainly bustling with people.

The service was mediocre and is expected as it is a Chinese restaurant - not necessarily the friendliest of staff.  My girlfriend is fluent in Mandarin and spoke with the staff.  We tried several times to get other carts to come our way - but for some reason we would keep seeing the SAME carts over and over again.

The food was fine - average at best.  A bit on the salty side.

The price for the food was INSANE.  We barely had enough to eat and were still hungry and the bill came out to some ridiculous 3 figure number (not counting cents)!!!

If you want authentic dim sum, do not come here.  It is full of non-asians - something I'd not want to see if I wanted authentic chinese dim sum.
author: Emme F.

description:
We drove 2 hrs just to try this place out  while visiting friends in Sacramento.  They raved about this place so much that we had to see it for ourselves.  
Yank Sing is located in a commercial highrise, so it was a bit odd since you have to take an elevator, when you arrive at the lobby level you really don't feel like you are going into a restaurant, it feels like you are there to meet with your account or something. The restaurant faces the atrium which has lots of natural light and a water feature from high above, it is nice to stroll around while waiting or after stuffing your face with dimsum.  The restaurant itself is very nicely decorated, again it looks like an commercial office space and especially not your typical Chinese restaurant.  Personally, I love it!  Tired of the same-o dragon, phoenix, koi pond, etc. theme.  
We arrived pretty early and were able to grab a table right away.  The food was very good!  The Hargow (Shrimp balls) are my favorite item to order at dimsum so we got some of that right away.  I have to say, these are probably the best ones I've had.  The skin is ultra thin so you get lots of shrimp taste and not so much of the skin which is usually what I see in most places.  The "main attraction" was the Xiao Long Pao's, they are mini steamed buns with pork and when you bite into it it has pork juice that is usually pretty darn hot.  You dip them into vinegar and ginger.  They were REALLY good!  A very close second to my favorite ones from Din Tai Fung.  We also ordered some braised string beans, it had good flavor but it was cold.  I would love to go back and try more dishes in the future.  We were in a hurry since we had to catch a flight back to S. Cal. so we didn't get to really sit there and try all the different dishes they had, but
author: Tania S.

description:
The food is good but pricey, as a mainland Chinese decedent, i wouldn't pay $$$ for dim sum, but there are quite a few pluses:

1. Nice ambiance, high-ceiling, wide space in the Embarcadeo location (the other location is impossible to find cheap parking, if you do, pay lots of quarters, so you don't have your lunch ruined by a 45 dollar+ ticket)

2. 5 star for the chill oil sauce that you can purchase from the restaurant. Try it first on the table, then tell them that you want to buy it. They are on window display too. Spicy, good marination, appropriately salty, love it.  I bought two jars, used it for months and couldn't get tired of it. It fresh compared to supermarket pre-packaged chill oil

3. The downtown location serves Perking Duck with sweet BBQ sauce and white bun as a part of the dim sum selection! I LOVE the BITE-SIZE edition of this beloved dish
author: Dilys S.

description:
Yank Sink fills the void that Din Tai Fung left when I moved here from Seattle. While I can never love another place as much as Din Tai Fung, this is a good temporary replacement, kind of like a rebound while I still pine for a lost love. But hopefully, eventually, I'll get over DTF and find the courage to move on ;)

The first time I came here, I felt a little pressured by the service; I was not sure what to get and ordered whatever they brought to the table in their rolling carts - it ended up being a very expensive meal :P But I've gotten better at saying no and asking for the things I like! I really like their mushroom, curry, snow peas and vegetable dumplings. (And it's very hard for me to stop eating once I start - hence expensive meals!!). 

I generally call ahead to reserve a table and still wait for at least 15 - 30 mins depending on how crowded it is. Going a little later than lunch time, closer to 2 has always worked out well for our group.
author: Harini S.

description: Good dim sum for the area. It's overpriced compared to china town but hey it's tasty and good. Service was on point and all the usual famous Chinese dishes came out. I was pleasantly surprised as food was good and parking was validated. If your looking for reasonable dim sim this isn't the spot but it is tasty.
author: Darryl S.

description:
I've never been a big fan of dim sum (the wait for something good to come around) the indecipherable stamp system, the blandness of it all) so take this with as much salt as required. My boo and his cousins were in town and we heard this was THE place to get dim sum so I was hoping it would turn the tide of mediocrity I experienced in LA. 

We had reservations which was a good thing as this place was packed on a Sunday at noon. The restaurant actually expands into the building lobby on the weekends for just this reason and we were lucky enough to sit next to the waterfall right in the center.

Unfortunately, the food was like that of any other Dim Sum place but for twice the price (seriously, we spent nearly $50 a head on a just barely stomach filling meal). If it's not in some sort of bland dumpling dough or drowned in brown sauce, it was over cooked vegetables and indiscernible animal parts masquerading as meat.

The service is pretty standard with carts running all over the place, servers yelling across the room and a constant negotiation with clanging tins to see if you'll eat now or wait for the next trolley. Some people enjoy this hustle when they go out to eat. I can handle it if the food is worth the price but I can safely say this place tastes like any other. If it's your racket, there are certainly more affordable places in the city.
author: Brandon K.

description: Best dim sum! We come every Christmas season and are never disappointed. Reservations recommended, but you can come without and wait at the bar for a table. Parking validation available too at the Rincon Parking garage.  Google directions for the Hotel Griffin to get to the parking garage- Google map won't direct you to the Rincon garage otherwise.
author: Barbara R.

description: Quality dim sum.  Clean.  Great service.  A bit pricey.
author: Yoichi N.

description: Oh, my. So much good food! Left full, happy and ready to return! The hot and sour soup, the dumplings, the bao... Just come hungry and wear loose pants!
author: Jennifer J.

description:
I took my wife and three kid for lunch on vacation from LA. The bill was $182+ tip=over $200.
Food was not bad but way too expensive. $19.95 for small portion of seabass. Hot tea for $3.95 ×2 all the different dumpling tasted same... food was good but not great. I think they make you wait so u r more hungrier when you start to eat and order way too much. Ask how much it is before you say yes I'll take that...save your money and eat chowder at piers....
SAVE UR $$$$$!!!!!!!
author: Yang K.

description: Great service. ..very nice and attentive. Came in when they opened at 11am on a Friday and was seated immediately.  Their shanghai dumplings are really juicy and tastes great. Their other dim sum items were good. Pretty pricey place though. $14 for 6 shanghai dumplings and 5.50 for 2 of other dishes. Expect the bill to be at minimum $35 per person plus.
author: Quang V.

description:
This is a solid dim sum place. I've had it all over from HK, NYC, and LA. Portions were on the larger side and taste was definitely there. Only knocking off a star due to its high prices. 

Came here on a Sunday and the overflow seating was situated in the courtyard of the Rincon highrise professional building. Definitely more seating here than their 49 Stevenson St location.

Good service. Only waited 10 minutes at 12pm on a Sunday!  Maybe the crowds were out watching the America's Cup. Carts endlessly came around and if you didn't want anything from their cart the first 2 times, they didn't incessantly ask you each time they rolled around for the next 1.5 hrs which I appreciate. Waiters/waitresses were attentive, raised your hand and someone was there. Empty tea, and it was filled within the minute. 
 
2 dishes stood out to me. First the cheung fan was super packed with cha siu. Usually there might be just a thin row of filling in this dish but they didn't skimp on the ingredients here.  In fact, the har gao and siu mai, were ALL stuffed.  
The other dish was the sea bass. Its price is quite steep but the fish was cooked, seared, and marinated to perfection. Very tender, almost melted in my mouth and no bones! You can either ask to have this ordered or they constantly walk around with it in their hands asking if anyone wants one. 

Probably not an everyday dim sum place for me due to the price but a nice place to hit up if you are from out of town and wanting a little more upscale than the joints in chinatown.
author: Jonny I.

description: Yummy but the most expensive dim sum I've ever had.  There was a huge line 15 min before it even opened, so prepare for a wait.  The sea bass was AMAZING.  The rest were good but just too pricey.  You can find similar dim sum for better prices.
author: Sophie L.

description: For Dim Sum is somewhat pricey.  The fact that they let you do reservation is pretty awesome...  The little pork dumpling is very good and tasty.  Will be back
author: Ray L.

description: Not sure what some of these negative reviews are about but I would absolutely recommend coming here! While it may be a bit expensive for dim sum, the taste and quality is totally worth it! We got the pork buns, soup dumplings, chicken buns, snap peas, pork potstickers and more. Worth every penny! We didn't have reservations on a sunday and they were able to seat us which was even better although they were slammed as usual. GO HERE!
author: Megan W.

description: While visiting friends in SF, I was super excited to come try Yank Sing as I had heard it was the best dim sum in the city. Unfortunately, the food was mediocre at best. For a place that boasts the best dim sum in the city, I would expect more variation, hotter food and better flavors. After getting our dishes, which have been maybe $40 in previous experiences, the bill came and they had charged us $140. Appalled, we asked them to explain the charges. They had charged us for two things we didn't order, but overall the price was just completely outrageous for what the food is. I was prepared to spend more money as I knew this place was pricier than most but not over $50 for dim sum. Not to mention the restaurant is in a glorified food court. I will not be recommending this restaurant to anybody.
author: Nina S.

description:
So I've been here for two weddings and actually lunch/dinner. First time I was here was for a wedding and the restaurant  was inside but catered in their lobby area were water falls and beautiful flowers surrounded the place. I think it was great location for a wedding, and very spacious compared to inside the restaurant. 

The restaurant served us an 8 course meal, and by the time they got to the 5th meal I was so full! I thought the food was okay, but rather went to R&G's in SF if you do a comparison. The other times I've gone dim sum was decent but pricey. I did get to cross off the sesame balls from the 7x7 list, but they tasted ordinary to me! LOL
author: Kathy V.

description:
Super underwhelming, especially for the price and the hype. Steamed plates came out lukewarm and soggy. Food was OK but each dish is marked up by 25%-50% compared to your standard dim sum joint. You can definitely do much better in Chinatown or the Sunset/Richmond.

My guess is that this place just coasts by on its reputation and appeals to a clientele (aka corporate expense accounts) that is unaware or indifferent that better, cheaper dim sum options exist in the city.
author: Rob C.

description:
I've been here several times and normally they are okay, albeit a bit over-priced for what you get. The dim sum is pretty decent though. 

However, we went here on Christmas day and it wad super busy, but we had a reservation. 

They gave us a beeper and we still had to wait. Then, when it beeped and we went to the counter, they said they messed up and we still had to stand there and wait another 10 minutes or so. 

They seem very unorganized here and not with it. 

That said, it's probably the best dim sum in this area, if not the only one.
author: John D.

description:
Kung Hay Fat Choy  -  Year of the Horse 

this is definitely our favorite "up scale" Chinese restaurant.   A special place to plan a nice visit to the City.  

Fast easy seating for Dim Sum  -  for family CNY we chose to eat out in the fountain courtyard - less crowded, noise lever allows you to have table conversations with ease...   BEAUTIFUL.  

$$$$  -  expensive but worth the extra

Menu selection includes all the usual Dim sum choices,,, and adds many specialties eg.  Shanghai dumpling w/red vinegar&ginger., lettuce warp, garlic onion encrusted sea bass, chicken feet, long life noodles,   many we will like to try on our next visit.  

We have no yet experienced a dish with REGRETS.     Great Flavors on everything  even on the common dishes.  

Dim sum cart servers have ear/radio communications,,  tell any cart servers what you want and they will guide the other servers to your table.   BIG ADVANTAGE over other "CITY" traditional dim sum houses.  

Remembering that we have come here in the past (at least 15 yrs ago)  even celebrated MY BIRTHDAY here in the past,,    less frequently back then as we were starving students,,     

now as empty nesters -   we've  found ourselves here  4 times in the last 6 mos.   - that's a GOOD THING.    lol.    


Service is EXCELLENT - all staff are well versed in English and are able to respectfully handle the diverse clientele of this upscale Financial District.  

Parking is FREE
author: Uncle Ernie ..

description: Nice upscale dim sum place, where you can order specific items and also grab from the carts.  We ordered several items, and most were very good to great (the XLB were adequate only).  The main downside is, as mentioned, the price.  It is VERY expensive, especially compared to other dim sum places.  Most everything is about $6-$15 a plate (a slice of roast duck with bun is ~$6 and an order of Xiao Long Bao were $14 for 8 pieces).  Our total was about $97 for 2 for lunch, so it is easily double or more compared to other places.
author: A. L.

description:
This is the first place that I want to eat when I touch down in SF after a long trip.  The food is comforting, classic and cleanly presented dim sum.  My fav's are the soup dumplings, taro puffs, egg rolls and the cod roll (light and delicious)!   

Only downside is often my favorite items are not on the carts but you can just ask one of the servers to bring you items directly from the kitchen.
author: Kate R.

description:
I've had better dim sum in NY...but it did have certain dishes that was worth the visit. 
So here are list of items worth mentioning.
1. Xiao long bao: the skins were paper thin, but not enough soup inside.
2. Spinach dumplings with spinach and mushroom was juicy and yummy.
3. Turnip cake was too dry.
4. Fried crab claws barely had any crab meat

My friend's mom, who has been going to Yank Sing since it opened, said this place use to be a lot better, and the quality and details of the dishes has going downhill the past year or two. I think its time to venture elsewhere in SF for dim sum.
author: Nancy Z.

description:
Not sure what happen from 2008 til now but Yank Sing has gotten better.  Less greasy and fresh ingredients.  Definitely one of my favorite places to go to now.  Its the only dimsum place that I go to in SF that doesn't make me sick.  
Highly recommend: Shrimp rice noodle plate, Shrimp Dumplings, Sui mai and Tofu skin. 
You can't really go wrong here. This place is a bit on the pricey end but so is everything else in SOMA. 
I still think Koi Palace is the best Dimsum in the bay area.  But if you are stuck in SF than this is the place to be. 

Parking: free with validation

Wait time: Don't be intimidated by the line. The line moves really fast.   They also have a YankSing to go next door, if you need to return to work asap.
author: Ying F.

description:
Really small portions for dim sum, and kind of pricey. 
The food: MEH. I think it does the job if you're hungover and or really hungry, but if you can, go to a cheap/dirtyish place in chinatown. 
Things that i think can make or break dim sum: the skin. A lot of the skin on the dishes I had yesterday was over cooked

It's saving grace: they validate your parking, which can go a long way in SOMA.
author: Priscilla W.

description:
The dim sum is always great and never greasy.  All the dumpling we has were tasty. 

Weekday lunch was a little disappointing as the selection was limited.  

The prices are probably double Chinatown prices, and taste 25% better than the other places. Probably in my top three places, but Koi Palace is better.
author: Jon H.

description: The food was really good and the waitstaff was very attentive.  Previous reviews have made mention that you just point at what you want since the staff doesn't speak English.  That wasn't the case here. Everything was explained to us before we decided whether or not we wanted that dish. It wasn't a cheap meal but it was definitely worth the experience. I'd recommend this to a friend and even come again if I'm in town.
author: Dillon W.

description: Some of the stuff here was nicely executed but, given the hype, most was pretty disappointing.  Really crowded with tourists looking for a dim sum experience, which isn't really a great sign.  Duck buns were our favorite.  Lots of other stuff was just too greasy or going stale.
author: Mike L.

description:
If you are going to do do Dim Sum in San Francisco, Yank Sing should definitely be at the top of your list.  A local SF institution for over 60 years, and 3 generations of the Chan family, serves up cart fulls of delicious bites and flavors to mouth watering patrons.  A great weekend lunch spot, or really anytime of the day or week, get ready to satisfy all your Chinese food cravings.

A few go-to favorites are featured here but definitely mix and match to your hearts content.  A great way to sample a few selections is to visit Yank Sing To Go in Rincon Center.

Shanghai Dumplings - These are savory soup dumplings garnished with pickled carrots.  You lift the dumplings from their tops and place on a soup spoon to catch all the juices.  Best to put the whole thing in your mouth at once and then bit down. mmmmmm!

Peking Duck - the duck is carted around the restaurant and dished table side.  It's hard not to immediately think of the movie A Christmas Story and imagining the duck smiling at you :)  Its a signature dish here and the honey roasted crispy skin and delicate meat is to die for.  It's served with a soft bun, scallions, and hoison sauce to be assembled before eating.  One of my favorites!

Meat Bun - steamed, fluffy, soft, gushy, BBQ-y....  I literally can eat like 5 of these at once.

Walnut Shrimp - a favorite.  Caramelized walnuts, served next to fried shrimp, served on shredded lettuce.  I would have been fine just eating this.

Spicy Sezchuan chicken with chili - No we didn't eat the chilies but all the spice and flavor infused the fried chicken pieces.

Pot stickers - I can't eat dim sum or Chinese food without an order of these.

Shrimp dumplings and Siu Mye - these are must haves at Yank Sing.  Steamed and served in bamboo baskets, you'll probably need more than 1 order.

Sesame balls - although I usually don't have room for dessert, these sweet little balls definitely topped off the meal.  And no - we wont judge if you dip them into the chili sauce on your plate!

Of course, all while sipping on some tea.

If you are just visiting San Francisco, or lucky enough to call it home, I highly recommend adding Yank Sing to your must dine at restaurants!

Check out pics of what we ordered here: http://beatseats.com/yank-sing/
author: BeatsEats K.

description:
Expensive. Food is mediocre. Way overrated.

We came here with a family friend who has lived in the city for quite some time. They thought this place was great for dimsum, but little did they know that the bay area has a plethora of dimsum places that are way better than this place.

I'm Chinese and I've been to a number of authentic dimsum places, some from out of the states, so believe me when this place is tailoring to those non-Chinese people aka "foreigners".

The service is decent if you don't know your dimsum, because almost all their servers speak English.

The food is forgettable but the price is very memorable. Almost $10 for a small dish of egg tart ("dan tat").

I feel that the only positive thing I liked about this place was the fountain in the building (not in the restaurant). Perhaps that's what you're paying for, the location.

Stay away from this place and go into Chinatown or out of the city for better places.
author: S T.

description:
I rate tjis spot 10 stars. lolz..
I traveled to SF for my vacation with my husband and found out this place thru friend's recommendation. well, I have to say Yank Sing sells the best Dim Sum ever. It's a lil bit pricy for two people but its worth it. We will definitely be back. Love there pistachio pie..so yummy
author: Khanh Thy 9.

description: Definitely not the best dim sum but will do for fidi area.
author: Daniel N.

description:
My husband and I recently had our Chinese wedding banquet at Yank Sing One Rincon location, and I couldn't have picked a perfect place!  

Originally I had reserved a space at R&G Lounge for this, got a private room and even willing to book the entire evening, accepted their minimum of 2400$.  They were so unprofessional, inflexible, and so unaccommodating.  Person A does not talk to person B, so you end up calling them multiple times...then they refer you to speak with the manager who is always busy, telling you to call back later.  It was total chaos.  It was literally weeks of stress dealing with them.  They have absolutely no costumer service.  Just don't even waste your money there if you want to have a Chinese banquet done right!

In a panic, I decided to call Yank Sing, spoke to their event department and boy was I glad I did.  The folks at Yank Sing was very very professional, and this is a rare find in Chinese restaurant.  Daisy & Vera the coordinators had made the evening very stress free and memorable.  Don't let the midrange review you see for their dim sum fool you.  I suggest you read the reviews carefully and look at the ones for banquet, all good reviews.

I had been to many Chinese wedding banquets, and the 10 course meal I picked was the best I ever had!  Top notch on presentation and taste, even red napkin for family tables!  The service staffs were very professional, they keep my guests' wine and champagne glasses flowing.  They also helped coordinate toasting and making sure everyone has a glass ready.  Try asking that at other Chinese restaurant, they will probably blow you off.  Let just say my guests were all stuff by the end of the meal, all liquored up in a good way...just how a Chinese wedding banquet should be!  My husband and I couldn't be happier with how it turned out.

At the Rincon location, they can only have 4 tables of 10 people max.  Is a modern private room and you end up having that space all to yourself.  We were able to do some light decorating with double happiness signs, red lanterns with glow sticks...just that added touch of traditional elements.  The space was great for photos with friends and family. The setting was intimate and cozy. You can easily walk from table to table, chat with your guests, do traditional toasting and still be in the center of the room where everyone can participate!  Parking is validated for your guests as well.

From my personal experience, most Chinese restaurant has decent food but lousy costumer service and just want to rush you off, maybe that is fine for dim sum.  However if having a Chinese wedding banquet done right is important to you, impeccable service, great accommodation, give Yank Sing a call.  You won't be disappointed.  I'm glad I did, and it was money well spent!  

On a side note, as soon as I cancel with R&G lounge, and told them I booked else where, they call me back immediately after 5 minutes and say...oh, we just have this space opened up for you.  Meanwhile the night before I had called them and was told no, and rush me off the phone.  I hope their owners realize their staff's lack of costumer service had just loss the restaurant an easy 4-5K$ dinner.
author: Ray H.

description:
I was torn between a 2 and a 3, but maybe I'm just too used to the bustling greasy low quality dimsum that I love so truly.  The ambiance was really  nice, classy.  The food was ridiculously over-priced for Chinese food, but I will overlook that for the moment.  

The food was good, but it just wasnt' hot enough.  It's coming in a little cart, shouldnt' it be piping hot?

There was this honey glazed fish that was pretty delicious though.
author: Aly A.

description: way overrated. over priced. poor service by the people wheeling the carts. they are easily annoyed when you ask questions. save your money and go elsewhere .
author: HelpMe Y.

description:
I've had so many bad dim sum experiences -- where there was literally not a SINGLE vegetarian item offered except for vegetable side dishes -- that I actually had some breakfast ahead of a planned family brunch at Yank Sing. I ended up being very pleasantly surprised! There were so many vegetarian dumplings and potstickers offered that we actually had to turn some down, and I never ONCE experienced my biggest dim sum pet peeve: Asking if an item is vegetarian, being told yes, and then in the same breath being told it has shrimp or fish in it. 

Everything was delicious, and the service was impeccable. I would have given five stars except that (1) it's expensive and (2) we had to wait about 20 minutes even though we had a reservation. Otherwise, thumbs up!
author: Gaelen X.

description:
This is a twice a year journey - not because we can't get there more often... But more because it's a special place. We like to bring guests, family, and enjoy celebrations. It's the type of place you will remember - so I hate to squander it on some boring lunch that didn't have a celebration.

Imagine all the tiny carts, buzzing arounds you with amazing small plates of foods. The perfect amount to share!

I've decided that all the shrimp offerings are the best! The shrimp dumplings, the tempura shrimp rolls, the honey walnut prawns - you can't go wrong here! This is also one of the only places that offers a soup dumpling. Those are great fun, served in a big spoon. You put some ginger vinegar in the spoon, then add a dumpling. Bite the top, drink the soup & eat the noodle. WOOT!

If you're looking for a fabulous weekend thing to bring the whole family together - look no further. Kids will be delighted by all the carts, and the adults can pick and choose their favorites - off of carts and off the menu. Want some super family fun? Dare the kids to eat some chicken feet :-)
author: Maureen B.

description:
Came here Easter Sunday to see what the hype was all about!
The wait was about 40 minutes for 2 people, which wasn't too bad since you can wait in the building area and not outside in the cold). Once we got seated I was impressed by the nice clear teapots. Service was better than other dim sum places, but that was to be expected considering the $$$ you pay here. The clientele here is varied- which means you don't have to speak Chinese to get your food (yay!). The ha gow, sesame balls, turnip cake were delicious. I think we spent at least $60 on dim sum for 2 people, so don't be expecting cheap prices!
author: Emily C.

description: Not pleased. The food is okay, but highly overpriced. Almost 7 dollars for 2 pieces of roasted duck is insane! And it doesn't even taste good. Not planning to come back.
author: Shawn G.

description:
After reading all of the reviews about the Shanghai dumplings, I'm so disappointed that I couldn't give them a whirl! Since I don't eat meat, my spread was a bit more limited but still so, sooo good: 

- Shrimp dumplings: my favorite option on the menu, hands down!
- Snow pea dumplings: not worth the money; mediocre at best.
- Seafood basil dumplings: very good, though second to the shrimp on the dumpling scale.
- The crab 'pops': not sure what these are really called, but they're pretty delish! Kind of pricey, though... not sure I'd order them again ($12 for 2)
- Green beans: great for a dose of vegetables.
- Soft shell crab: good but pricey!  

On top of that, my boyfriend munched on the BBQ pork buns (mediocre per his review) and the Shanghai dumplings (on point). 

The service here was great and the seating was plentiful. While I knew it wasn't going to be cheap, I was actually pretty astounded by the bill we managed to rack up! My advice would be to peruse the menu before just picking stuff off the carts as they go by -- that method adds up and you unless you get to see EVERYTHING they have, you could miss out on some great options.
author: Shannon E.

description: As always the food is excellent. The atmosphere is nice. The only thing I wish they could improve on is the communications of some of the servers and their carts. It's a little hard to order sometimes.
author: SmOoOoteensie L.

description: $120 for 10 plates of dim sum? Well, I've never had sth so economically disadvantaged... esp. for a Chinese place
author: Jenna H.

description: Amazing food!!!! We were meant to go to Hakkasan but they couldn't seat us for our reservation time because they couldn't seem to cope with the crowds on Black Friday. Found Yank Sing by accident. Great atmosphere. Not pretentious at all. Definitely returning.
author: Monica R.

description:
Dim Sum Heaven

Actually, it's their  homemade chili sauce that sent me to heaven! My favorite was the soup dumplings (shanghai style) and the honey sea bass.  They also have  shu mai, potstickers,  hot and sour soup, green beans with shrimp, spicy chicken, and more. All of it tasted even better with a drop of their homemade chili sauce -- which is placed at each table.  

Seriously, this place has more dumpling and dim sum plates that you can imagine. They even give you a menu so you can tell your server in case you don't want to wait for a cart. 

Service was good and fast.  The food was awesome. The only bad part is that they are a little on the expensive side, my friend and I dropped $80 on dim sum, a first for me!

p.s. there are 2 locations. I'm told that they are both the same.
author: Shaman D.

description: Perfect spot for quick lunch downtown...There is a main restaurant but there is also a take out window around the corner with plenty of tables. The food is great and the order comes out fast.
author: Sylvia S.

description:
Apparently, Chinese people hate this place. Whatever, I'm not Chinese! I enjoy my Panda Express Orange chicken! Haters gonna hate lol.

Okay, so it's just a tad bit pricey for dim sum, but the quality is excellent. Some of the best soup dumplings (xiao long bao?? Did I get that right?) I've ever had, with a very thin skin and tasty soup. Their pork bun had some of the softest bread I've ever had on a pork bun, and the filling lived up to the quality of the bread, as well. I don't know the names of all the other dishes we had, and I have nothing else to say other than "delicious!!!", so let's just leave it as that and save ourselves a few minutes. 

If only it was cheaper, this place would definitely get all 5 stars!
author: Kazu O.

description:
3.5/5. Two of my roommates decided to treat me out to dim sum for my birthday last year. We were supposed to go to Hong Kong Lounge in Inner Richmond, but by the time we got there they were closing shop. So we decided to stop by Yank Sing instead, which closes at 4 p.m. on Saturday. Street parking was a breeze to find, but a bit frustrating, since the meter only accepted coins. And because it cost nearly $4 and hour, we had to round out quite a few. 

By the time we got there, the place was nearly empty, but they still had carts circling around. We tried most of the classic dim sum dishes and they were all solid, though not exceptional. I found the quality to to be on par with Bao Dim Sum House in Los Angeles or Koi Palace in Daily City. Xiao Long Bao were very juicy and had thin, delicate skins, but I wouldn't say they were the best I've had. I'm personally still more partial to those at Ding Tai Fung and Joe's Shanghai. The lady parading the Xiao Long Bao cart was a bit persistent, telling us we should have more since they were so good. Not knowing how pricey they were, we were like "Sure, why not" and she then proceeded to place two more orders for us. 

Although I didn't end up paying, I could not but help feeling that Yank Sing is overpriced. My roommate, who was paying, wouldn't let me see the bill, but it was clearly upwards of $120 before tip. And this was for three people, who hadn't ordered anything remotely exotic. The food was good and the ambiance superior to your typical dim sum place, but enough to be charging 3 times more than Koi Palace, which has just as good dim sum.
author: Pierre B.

description:
Yank Sing was one of my first meals in SF when I moved up to the bay for college. Back then I was impressed but after 4 years at Cal and 5 in the city I have learned that Yank Sing is easily beaten, especially given the price tag.  With the exception of the soup dumplings, I prefer the dim sum at Hong Kong Lounge and a few of the take-out spots.  At $2 a piece it's over 3x pricier than the dim sum take-out spots,but I'll admit that the table settings and service are 10x nicer.

If you have (dim sum novice) guests to impress or a business per diem to kill, I suppose it's worth trying just to cross it off your bucket list, but if you really love dim sum and care more about dumplings than dining service hit up Stockton or Clement Street for something better for your tummy and wallet!
author: Krystle S.

description: This place is busy! We made a reservation online but they didn't have a record of it (it was ok, they still accommodated us with a short wait). One of the things I like about dim sum is the moment you sit down you can start eating. They constantly come by with different carts filled with goodies. All of it was very good...it's pricey for dim sum...but very good. Must haves are the Mango pudding and egg custard tarts for dessert.
author: Tammy D.

description:
Pretty delicious dim sum with a pretty steep price.  I would've began by saying the quality is worth the price but not after my recent experience with their Sunday service. My family and I were so disappointed by the lack of variety on Sundays!  I've eaten dim sum here during the weekdays during lunch and they were awesome.  I don't understand why Sundays are their off-days when it should be the most important day of the week for any restaurant serving dim sum!

How can you not serve pan-fried chive dumplings, or shrimp stuffed mushroom, or shrimp stuffed eggplants?!  I also didn't see egg custard buns.

I honestly believe that they changed up their menu to better serve the taste of Westerners/Americans rather than the typical Asian who grew up going to "yum cha" every weekend with their family.  If I'm going to be paying that much for dim sum, I'd rather go to Koi Palace, where I know they have ALL the dim sum staples and MORE.
author: Ivy Z.

description:
I have been coming to Yank Sing for years. In my opinion it is the best Dim Sum place in the city. Yes..it is a bit pricey..but you get what you pay for--really fresh ingredients. The dim sum here doesn't leave me feeling greased up or in a sodium induced coma. 
I love coming here with a big group--trying more variety. 
My favs here are the Shrimp dumplings, rice noodle wrapped shrimp, efu noodles, scallop dumpling, and the fried crab balls that are made with fresh crab legs. 

The service is good..albeit a bit pushy.
author: Mimi T.

description:
Literally, the only one star missing is for the price...it's $9.60 for sesame balls!! It's more than ridiculous. They are 3 for $1 in Chinatown and most dim sum places charge $3-4!! I don't like it but my man loves that stuff. He also said it was not the best he's had. Too little filling and the dough a bit overfried and was brownish yellow....which brings me to the point, it's NOT WORTH $9.60!!!

The fat rice noodles, my favorite, was over $7!!! 



Everything else is delicious though. The service is beyond good, it's like SCARY good. They all have walkie talkie and if i get something from one person and mention i want something else, he/she immediate calls someone on the talkie telling them to bring it over. Within literally a minute, it's there!!! All smily happy...i mean it's like dim sum in 25th century.....efficient, modern and kinda....SCARY!!

The indoor waterfall is awesome and open space is a bit noisy but airy and fun!!

All in all, this place is for special occasion for most of us and everyday fare for rich people!!!
author: Xiu L.

description:
The first thought that comes to mind about eating here is the price.  This place is pretty expensive for dim sum.  Two people for lunch came out to $70+ with a pot of tea (including tip).

The food is pretty average, so what you're paying for is the location and that it's a nice restaurant-- not a casual dining experience, like if you went to Ton Kiang.  This is somewhere you would take someone for a special occasion.  I find myself hard pressed to spend that kind of money for two people for Chinese food again.  Plus, this place is super, super busy, so it's very noisy.  If you're not a fan of large crowds, lots of chatter, babies crying, etc...I would recommend avoiding this place.
author: Anna V.

description:
Depending on where you're from, this place might be worthy. Ok. I take that back. Never. Again. The pricing for dim sum here is just ridiculous. Eating here alone, I ordered four dishes and I spent 45+ after tips. Shumai, soup dumpling (xiao lung bao), eggplant, bbq pork dun).
Non of the dishes above were exceptionally good. They were not bad, except for the shumai.

Yes, I am a brat. Visiting from SoCal, I know that I can have better and tastier versions of what I ordered here for a much lesser price. 

Clearly, this place is established for rich and non Asian diners who don't know better about dim sum. The parking garage in the same building cost 12 bucks. That's already 57. Bleh.
author: Kevin C.

description: Come for the food, not the decor. It's in a nice building, so if you sit "outside" the waterfall is lovely. The food reminds me of dim sum restaurants in LA...
author: Crystal S.

description:
Yank Sing is located in a beautiful area - almost like a fancy mall area. There's outdoor-like sitting located inside the mall. The restaurant is HUGE! Yank Sing also has a togo place where you can order some dishes to take out. 

SERVICE: the best service you can get in a dim sum place ever! Servers greet you with BIG SMILES! Unlike other dim sum place where they force you to try their dish on the chart... say, "no" and they'll happily move on with a thank you. The server even reminded me, "don't forget to validate your parking ticket." Cheers with hot tea.. - 5 stars for service! 

FOOD: 
1. Shanghai Dumplings - 5 stars: Dumplings with hot juicy soup! 
2. Shrimp Dumplings - 2 stars: the skin is too thick.. so, all I could taste was skin and not shrimp. Still edible. But, if the skin was thinner - it'll be perfect.
3. Pork Dumplings - 2 stars: never been such a great fan for pork dumplings, so don't trust me on this rating
4. Shrimp Noddles: 5 stars: crunch shrimp! Noddles were perfectly cooked - not too sticky, and plus the sweet sauces ... to die for! 
5. Sticky Rice Wrapped in Banana Leaf: 3 stars: I had better... but this is a pass!

End of the meal: Server will usually ask you at the end of the meal if you want any take out.

THE DAMAGED: For two people - $70. I never paid so much for dim sum.

**OVERALL: I never paid so much for dim sum before, but it was all worth it!  a 4 Star!
author: Mindy Y.

description:
When did the prices of Yank Sing go through the roof?  I haven't had dim sum here in a while, but omg 4 pieces of har gow for $12?  And it didn't even taste that great.  The service was a bit slow as it was a crazy Thanksgiving Day.  They also charge you $2 a piece for tea, even if you aren't drinking any.  Why not ask first?  That's restaurant 101, c'mon my chinese peeps.

The 2 Go menu is more affordable during the week.  I don't think I'll ever return for dim sum and won't be recommending it anytime soon.
author: Brian L.

description: Came here on one weekend when I had friends visit from SD.  This place is expensive, but worth coming if u really want good dim sum on special occasion. If u are on ur budget, don't pick this place !  We were all happy after long traffic. AAA for food
author: Takae K.

description: Still undoubtedly my fave dim sum in the city and possibly one of the best restaurants in SF! I still love their potstickers and egg rolls, but their mushroom and pork dumplings are also super awesome.
author: Kiki H.

description: Yank Sing has an excellent dim sum menu and the quality of the food is outstanding. Too many choices to list but their Shanghai soup filled dumplings are not to be missed. As in most Chinese restaurants it's noisey so don't go if you want a quiet, intimate setting.
author: Hank S.

description: This was my first Dim Sum experience.  It's awesome to get a chance to try smaller versions of everything.   It's also nice to see what everyone else is ordering.  The food is great, I wouldn't say amazing.  It's also a bummer when you see something on a cart coming around, and they run out before it gets to you.  However there's always something tasty on the next cart.  Just go knowing you're going to spend some money.  There were 2 of us, and our total without tip as $135.
author: Amanda S.

description:
So the food is good.  Good meaning clean, upscale dim sum, and they have some creative dishes.  However, it is totally overrated.  I'm lucky we had a reservation because if I had to wait more than 10 minutes for this place, it would have been a complete waste of time.  The restaurant is too loud and the outdoor space is neat, but awkward all at once.  

I don't think I'll be back unless I have a reservation and someone else is paying because it's some type of occasion that requires fancy dim sum to celebrate.  Otherwise, I will be content going to a dirty hole in the wall dim sum joint for just as tasty, if not tastier, dim sum.
author: Jaclyn L.

description:
Long overdue review.

Dim sum (yum char) for me is like KFC of the east.  I would really crave it and then afterwards I'd be like... no more dim sum for a year.  It's usually greasy and pretty heavy.  

Not at Yank Sing. 

Service: 
First of all, their service is impeccable.  The servers will smile at you (Yes SMILE) and they are super attentive.  Usually when we go to a dim sum  place where they have all the goods on a cart, I'm usually strategically seated so I can make eye contact with the servers and waive them down our way.  (Otherwise I feel like the ones that you want never come to you).  At Yank Sing, it's almost like the servers know which the new tables are because every single cart came to us.  

Food: 
Everything we had was delicious. We had:
- cabbage salad (very refreshing - not your standard dim sum affair)
- Shanghai soup dumplings
- Fried shrimp meat
- Pork siu mai
- Steamed BBQ pork bun
- shrimp dumplings
- Seabass

I think we had a few others but I just can't remember any more.  

Had I known that Seabass was $18 I may have skipped it (It was good but I'm not sure if it's $18 good)

Nothing felt overly greasy.  

Price:
Expensive.  For the two of us, we ended up paying $85 with tip and tax.  Not your standard Sunday brunch pricing.  However it was definitely worth every penny.
author: Sujan H.

description:
Pretty good dim sum option in FiDi (not that there are too many). Gets fairly crowded during lunch time. Know that it's sit down service - the to go booth is next door (the sit down service is quite efficient and fast though).

Everything is pretty good quality. Nothing is SUPER fresh, but everything still tastes pretty good (but not excellent). I will say that the service is superior to most dim sum places (not that the bar is too high) - they are pretty non intrusive with the carts (and don't try to push plates on you) and are pretty friendly and responsive.

It is quite costly though, which I suppose can't be helped given the location. Not bad, not great. Hits the spot if you have a dim sum craving! Super conveniently located for all the business types nearby.
author: Jocelin L.

description:
Simple
Really good dim sum and excellent service; they really know how to handle large crowds. I'm always happy and satisfied. It is a little pricey, but worth it.
author: Rosana J.

description: Waaaay overpriced$$$$$$.than Clement St, Geary Blvd(HK Lounge& Ton Kiang), Chinatown and Las Vegas.Tried the Beef Churn Fun, Mushroom Dumpling, Crab Claw, Ha Gau  and the Sea Bass Each order only feeds two so for three people you have to double each order.($130.00 for three people,)Just had Dim Sum at Wing Lee Bakery at 6th &Clement to go for 8 people at half the price. Must be the atmosphere your paying for in the financial didstrict
author: Wyatt U.

description:
While its fair to say thank Yank Sing will never qualify as a "budget bite" its as good as it gets for dim sum in a city with more than enough to go around.

While I prefer the pricey, ambiance and foodie experience that is the dining room of any Yank Sing, the great "out the door" bites at their Spear Street location will allow you to "take away" some of great flavors in picnic fashion and at comparably bargain prices.  Take your to go Yank Sing to Rincon Plaza or at the nearby waterfront facing the Bay Bridge (Aim for the grass near the arrow sculpture along the Embarcadero for a perfect city picnic spot!)

Highlights from the take-away ordering include the Seafood Supreme plate, some shu mai ala carte, and sesame balls for dessert!  (If you do upgrade to the dining room, impress and scare your friends by ordering the chicken feet, and eating them!)
author: Rachel H.

description: Among the best Dim Sum in San Fran!  Brisk service and delicious fare. Our San Francisco visits are never complete without stopping by here.
author: Truth S.

description: I'll be honest, it's best to go if someone else is paying, or if you have the expendable income go for it. This place is not cheap but sooo worth it. On the weekends it's out of control so be prepared for a long wait for a table (again, worth it). We have loved everything we have here, and they typically have 30 dim sum items. If you don't see what you like, you can ask. Must orders for me are peking duck, shanghai dumplings, and bbq pork buns. If you do go, and you're hungry, the bill can add up very quickly.
author: Alyssa J.

description:
When I think of good dim sum/deem sum there are two categories that come to mind. There's the really good dim sum that is sold at a hole in the wall place and is not only delicious but it's authentic and then there's the nice fancy restaurants that despite the higher prices have managed to serve dim sum in a classy setting but still maintain their authenticity. Yank Sing would be placed into the latter. 
 
I had to write a review for Yank Sing because this is my favorite place to get deem sum. Hands down this is the best deem sum place I have ever been to and I've tried A LOT of different places. I will admit that this place is definitely pricey and it is easy to rack up your bill because the food is so good but it's definitely worth it. I think some of the scores that people gave Yank Sing were probably affected by the pricing but I don't mind spending the extra buck or so on great quality food! 

The xiao long bao here is my favorite out of everywhere I've tried it and trust me, I've tried it at any place I've been to that offers it. I love the cabbage and candied walnut salad as well. Its nice and light and compliments the other items nicely. The sea bass here is amazing!! It is always perfectly cooked and has a nice light but flavorful sauce. The Peking duck here is amazing as well. Honestly, I've probably tried almost everything on the menu and everything is always so delicious. So rather than me listing everything you may as well just look at the menu and see what fits your fancy. I'm sure it won't be anything other than delicious and satisfying!  

I've been here countless times so everything that I say I say with conviction. Come here for business or for pleasure. The atmosphere here is versatile and accommodates many different types of gatherings. The inside of the restaurant has large tables for people who come in a large group but there are smaller more intimate tables and there is also seating in front of the restaurant (but it is still inside the building Yank Sing itself is located in). There is also "Yang Sing to go" right next to the restaurant where you can order some of the menu items to go if you don't feel like sitting down and eating at the restaurant. 

"Deem sum" translated to English literally means "to touch the heart" and Yank Sing definitely embraces this idea with their wonderful cuisine!
author: Beca P.

description:
This is the opposite of hole-in-the-wall dim sum shops.  This is sophisticated dining with great choices, attentive service and attractive (though fading) surroundings.  Despite the  large numbers of patrons (250 inside and an additional 250 in the courtyard on weekends), food carts arrived swiftly with a profession of well-prepared, warm food with wonderful and piquant tastes ranging from mild to robust and spicy.  Most servers could explain the more exotic items and captains were nearby to refill tea, gather condiments, and track down special requests.  Asking for warm custard tarts at the end of the meal rather than accepting cool ones from the carts provided an ethereal pleasure.  Who knew that a humble egg custard tart could be so sublime?  

Be advised, lines can be long for seating.  However, we arrived a bit before noon on a Saturday and did not have a long wait.  Do note that this fine dining comes at a price; it is very easy to run up a large bill while enjoying the myriad of passing pleasures.
author: M S.

description: Quality has (sadly) gone down in the past few years.  I suppose that is to be expected.  The cost has stayed the same, the food was only fair, in comparison.  Perhaps it was because we were sitting outside in the indoor-outdoor rincon center location, so the food took longer to arrive?  I'll have to go back again sometime in the future to test this theory.
author: Shinny L.

description: Best Dim sum in the city.  We come here every time we go to San Francisco. 9 of us came this time.  Great food and speedy service.  Can't miss with this restaurant.
author: CJ F.

description:
I'm a dim sum snob. I hate to say it but 95% of the Chinese restaurants I go for dim sum don't meet my standards. To say I'm picky is probably an understatement. So when I went to Yank Sing, I set my expectations low. 

Reservations make it easy to get a table on the weekend and you don't have to wait. My favorite dishes were the Shanghai dumplings (xiao long bao), sesame balls, and marinated chicken feet. Everything else was pretty bland and I needed the chili sauce and mustard to make the food more flavorful. The service is pretty good but the prices were a bit high for my taste and doesn't quite match the quality of food. 

A decent dim sum place, but there's better out there.
author: Jess W.

description:
Sorry but I tend to walk out when xiao long bao is served with red vinegar with no shredded ginger. 

Overpriced Dimsum. Not worth my time and money. 

Yank Sing 2 go is awesome though. Less than $8 for the daily special. HUGE portions.
author: DANIEL T.

description:
Bomb. Super legit. It's on the pricey side, but it's definitely one of the best dim sum places in the city.

This last time I was pleasantly surprised with their dessert. They offered jello orange slices. They pureed the flesh and blended it into the gelatin, then set the gelatin back in the orange slices. Tedious and delicious.
author: James T.

description:
The most common comment I hear about Yank Sing is that's it's ridiculously priced for what you get, essentially no value for the dollar. I tend to look at it a bit differently. You need to go in with the mindset of having a special gourmet dim sum experience, not like the typical dim sum spots in Chinatown. There's nothing wrong with Chinatown dim sum (in fact, I highly recommend Great Eastern) but it's obviously a different mindset and almost an entirely different type of cuisine. 

It's like comparing In N Out's double double to NOPA's hamburger. Obviously they are both delicious but one calls for a different occasion than the other. That's the exact case with Yank Sing and its Chinatown competitors. 

Absolutely every dish is mouthwatering here. I love the turnip cakes, the sticky rice, the shrimp dumplings, the soup dumplings, the peking duck, the shrimp in rice noodles and the shumai. The wine selection is also incredible and complements the dim sum very well. 

Also, the ambiance is by far the best I've ever seen for a dim sum restaurant. It's spacious, classy and located right in the heart of Rincon Center. 

FYI - you can order from both the carts as well as the menu, although the carts have an immaculate selection so you won't really need to whip out the menu. 

Happy Eating, Yelpers!
author: Priya S.

description:
Came here after landing from Chicago on Christmas eve- and can I just say that this place has both real authentic Asian food and a very attentive staff. Like super attentive!  If you frequent dim sum/Chinese restaurants, you will know that attentive rarely belongs in the same sentence as dim sum.  My water was always filled, I received all the orders I asked for, and the employees were all really pleasant.  I guess the only reason NOT to come, would be the price.  It is definitely more expensive than other dim sum restaurants.  Think about spending $5.00 or so per dish.  Their special Shanghai soup dim sum is amazing- but it's $10 or so for 4 pieces.  

Bottom line: it's a very good restaurant... if you can afford it.

BTW- on the weekends, park in the garage!  It's free with validation!
author: Mel S.

description:
Okay, Yank Sing is $$$ for their price range. Fine, $90+ for two people and dim sum that is okay and not super authentic.

But then we see something on the bill that we cannot read, so we ask one of the wait staff or whatever he is. He says that he will take the bill to the cashier again. He comes back to the table with an huge ancient calculator that may as well been an abacus and asks us to calculate the bill ourselves. 

We asked to clarify what the charge was, not to insult us by bringing out a calculator. Yes, we can add. Thank you.
author: Regina W.

description:
40 bux per person for dim sum? Did I mention this was before tax+tip? Their dishes are mostly average and start at around 5 dollars.

I can appreciate that their steamed dishes are not too oily but boy, they make up for it with their fried dishes which are dripping with oil. Their xiaolongbao's are not that great and they're mad expensive. 

Sure, they have insanely good service for a dim sum place. And it feels like there's 2x the staff buzzing around the tables. But the price that you have to pay for that just seems unsettling.
author: Megan H.

description: We were recommended this restaurant from our hotel.  We thought it was odd that the restaurant was in an office type complex.  The place was extremely busy, but we got seated right away.  As soon as we sat down here came the food.  There was so much to choose from.  Of course we ordered too much food.  About the food...DELICIOUS!!  Besides Hong Kong, this is the best dim sum we have ever had.  We are sorry we don't live in SF to come here more often.  The service was also excellent. We are now thinking of an excuse to come back to SF just to go to this restaurant.
author: Doreen D.

description:
We were in town for wedding and wanted to get dim sum while we were here. This place was close to the hotel and recommended by a guide book. We thought this place was great. For $25 a person we left stuffed and wanting to try some many more dishes (we are thinking about going back before we leave!). The servers were friendly and were willing to explain what anything was. 

the soup dumplings and pork buns were great! Also, the seabass wrapped in sweet potato and fried was great.
author: Jen G.

description: Meh, totally overpriced and underwhelming. Shanghai dumpling king all the way if you don't mind the greasy floor but the food and prices are so much better. The quality of ingredients also seems the same. Oh well I tried it.
author: Myles A.

description:
Torn on what review to give. 
The dim-sum was one of the better ones I have tried but at the same time it was too pricey. Def worth a try if you are into dimsum 

FYI tea is $7.80, we thought it was going to be free like all other Chinese restaurants.
author: Abbot S.

description:
This review is for dim sum only.  Yank Sing is a solid 3 stars.

The Good:
-Good variety of dim sum
-Ambiance - one of the nicest Chinese restaurants, I've been too
-Good service
-A good solid Xiao Long Bao

The Bad:
-Pricey, $5.50 for a piece of Peking duck and bun, wowzers
-During dim sum hours, get the dim sum item, I would suggest straying away for the nontraditional dim sum items

Overall, Yank Sing is good for dim sum.  However, be prepare for a big bill.
author: Phat T.

description:
I wanted parcels of msg and meat so I waited about 30 minutes for a table at Yank Sing for 1 person during the busiest time of the day.

It was alright, the shu mai was a bit off, something tasted funny in it.  Everything else included the shrimp dumplings, the snow pea dumplings, the lotus leaf rice were standard and nothing extraordinary.

HOWEVER, the xiao long bao (although pricey) were AMAZING.  It's been forever I've had a soup dumpling where the soup to meat ratio was perfect and the skin was thin and delicate.  I wish I ordered 3 trays of the xiao long bao, they were that memorable to me.
author: Minnie M.

description: I've been going to this place for a while now. Yank sing is pretty freakin awesome. I like the fact that you don't have to wait to order. As soon as you get in, ready made food just comes to your table. I LOVE the dimsum which has soup in it. I don't know what it's called but explain that to the server and they'll bring it to you. I was in a out of that place in like an hour. Super nice. Also, I just realized that they validate your parking so please don't spend $10 on parking like me
author: Sanchit J.

description: We've been to some really wonderful Dim Sum restaurants this is now on the list! Great staff and amazing food. Some of the best duck we've ever had! Unlike some of the reviews we found it to be very reasonable in price!
author: Kristan D.

description:
It's good. It's extremely pricey.   (One order of itty bitty dim sum can be 13 bucks!). Elsewhere it's 2-3 bucks

 I'm kinda angry they would not validate parking because we parked at 10:30 and they don't open until 11 am

Even though we were there buying over 100 dollars worth of food (for 2 people) from 11 am to 1 pm, because we parked our car at 10:30 am, NO validation

I go to another dim sum place and spend 40 bucks for five people and we even have a lot of leftovers to take home, to give you an idea how pricey this place is.....here, I leave hungry even after forking over 50 bucks for my portion.
author: Foodlover B.

description:
Pretty lobby/entry area with 3 story water fall. Yank Sing has a festive atmosphere that reminds me of China Town. It's food is tasty. My favorite is their specialty: Shanghai soup dumplings. (I think you will like them too.) Also delicious was the lotus leaf wrapped rice, and the sesame dumpling dessert stuffed with red bean paste. Although many of the dumplings were pork or shrimp. 

Reservations got us right in, even on labor day. It was a little pricey, but not too bad. After eating, it was nice to walk over to the scenic waterfront, then back to the pretty outdoor patio area in front of the restaurant building. It was extra nice to have our parking validated at the Spear Street garage. Good restaurant to meet up with the family. Nice afternoon.
author: Cathy R.

description:
Paris Syndrome (http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Paris_syndrome):  Psychological disorder encountered by visitors to Paris characterized by anxiety, sweating, and dizziness.  Caused by disillusionment of visitor's perception of Paris compared to reality.

Yank Sing Syndrome: Symptoms very similar to Paris Syndrome; caused by sticker shock from absurd prices for what amounts to decent but unspectacular dim-sum fare.
author: Johnny W.

description:
Really good. I take my clients here because it's family style and keeps the interaction going! Then I visit about 4 times a month on my own because.. well, it's delicious.

Try the soup dumplings, phoenix tail, and shrimp dumplings if you know what's good for you!!
author: Erin V.

description:
Awesome! Yummy!

(And expensive!)

Well, unfortunately, great quality costs money. And the quality here is just superb. The mushroom dumplings are great, but it's hard to single out just one dish because then that implies all the rest is not at that ethereal greatness level. And here, it really is.

So I wait for special occasions and then I go.... and it's so worth it!

(And also great service!)
author: Peter M.

description: Absolute joy, best dim sum we're ever had. Delicious is an understatement! Fast and courteous service round out a very cool SF experience. Get the Shanghai dumplings, their signature dish. Not as pricey as I had expected, either (seven dishes for $50 and two very full stomachs).
author: Brandon J.

description: Good dim sum.  very pleased.  little on price is higher side than one I usually go to in Flushing.
author: Don T.

description:
You need no menu at this upscale but still family-friendly dim sum parlor (seriously the best dim sum I've had in SF!). Just point at what looks good as the servers roll the carts past your table, the array is staggering with a dizzying number of choices made with the utmost freshest ingredients. 

This place is great for groups.
author: Ty T.

description: The triple dollar sign probably came from the Shanghai dumplings, which were somewhere between $2 - $3 a pop. But boy were they worth the price. Pro tip: This is the place to go if somebody else is footing the bill ^.^ The rest of the dim sum items were pretty good as well, but the Shanghai dumplings takes the cake.
author: Angela G.

description:
Yank Sing is a great spot for traditional weekend dim sum for seasoned and rookie dim sum (or "deem sum") diners alike.  The emphasis on "weekend" is important because weekday dim sum here involves more or less the same high quality, well crafted dim sum dishes but it is served at a frenetic Financial District pace and service sometimes suffers.  To beat the perennial line here, it's best to arrive by 11 am, otherwise you may face an hour-long wait.  

Yank Sing provides excellent renditions of the dim sum classics and largely avoids sacrificing authenticity of these dishes for the unfamiliar palate, though it also serves a few spotty dim sum dishes (e.g., the gailan, Chinese broccoli is too chilled for my liking, and is cooked in such that it minimizes the vegetable's natural bitterness).  Of course, there are plenty of highlights.

For starters, we enjoy pairing a combination of Pu-erh/Chrysanthemum tea with the meal.  Yank Sing's version is authentically smooth and slightly sweet.  

The Shanghai soup dumplings are also generally good, though a little too dry (lacking in the eponymous soup) on a recent weekday visit.  

The Mandarin dumplings with chives -- fresh chives, cilantro, and shrimp stuffed in translucent rice flour wrappers -- are delicious and not commonly found in the triangle shape that Yank Sing has adopted.  

The shrimp dumpling ("ha gau"), a classic dim sum item, is quite good here.  These bite size dumplings have chopped shrimp embedded with crunchy bamboo shoot in a bite-size.

The pork siu mye, another classic dim sum dish, is also generally very good.  It features chopped shrimp with pork, shiitake mushrooms filling wrapped formed into a fluted "basket" with wonton wrappers.

The house-roasted Peking duck, served as an appetizer, is also good, but those who love Peking duck will be disappointed by the high cost to portion ratio.  This dish features crispy honey-coated duck skin and tender slices of duck stuffed in a steamed seashell bun, and served with slivered scallions and tangy hoisin sauce.

The steamed pork buns, another classic dim sum item, is also tasty, though not the best I've ever had.  These fluffy steamed buns are stuffed with honey-glazed BBQ pork.  These are often a hit with little ones.
