To finish off a dim sum lunch here, we like to get Yank Sing's bite size egg custard tarts, which combine flaky crust with a delicate egg custard interior.  Yank Sing's egg tarts are up there with Golden Gate Bakery's.    

Service is generally responsive and friendly, and the venue is spotless.
author: Chris T.

description:
Horrible. Why was I even bamboozled in to eating dim sum here?

Because the "Shanghai dumplings are the best ever"... NO. NOT AT ALL. I guess it's my own fault for believing such absolutism. These things were not the authentic, juicy, pork filled pillows I am used to elsewhere.

This place is beyond CRAMPED (tables on tables on tables), suuuper overpriced.

Never returning.
author: Tay R.

description: This place is a bit pricey for Dim Sum. I think they cash on the location. This place had good hygiene and the staff could decently communicate. I am a vegetarian and I tried their mushroom, savory vegetable and spinach dumplings and crispy onion cake. We really liked their savory vegetable and spinach dumpling. Crisp onion cake was insanely priced. Jasmine tea was great. We ended up having 6 servings of dumplings, 1 serving of onion cake and tea for 2 and paid $53. Way too pricey for the food. But overall a good experience.
author: Nidhi P.

description:
I like their Shao ron pao(soup dumpring).

There is famous Shao ron pao place called Joe's shang-hai in NYC but I like Yank sing shao ron pao better. And its kind of interesting the dim sum style. The ladies walk around with carts that carrying many kind of food and you can pick the food you wana eat as much as you can but me and my husband only eat about 3-4 shao ron pao and only 1 shrimp shu-mai.lol To be honest, i think these two are most tasty thing in here. Also you have to pick the cart that carrying fresh, hot dishes! Otherwise, ou have to eat cold hard skin dumplings..isn't it so sad?:..( You can check the cart and if she carries many dishes, it means she just came out from the kitchen. Get that cart!

I really like their shao ron pao and I'm going to this place everytime when I go to SF, buuuuut, I everytime get minor stomach upset after i had their shao ron pao. Yes, everytime. So I think they might not using "super" fresh pork....I guess....(Its just my opinion)
author: Oso S.

description: Horrible customer service and Luke-warm food. I took my parents to dim sum on Christmas Day and this place was packed inside so the restaurant created an eating area outside in the center of the plaza. Originally, I thought it was a great idea but as soon as we were seated I realized this was a horrible idea. No carts came by the far left side of the area. The ones that did were ha gao & Chinese broccoli. I had to request more carts to come to our area twice but that didn't help much. Instead, the waiter, Philip, just rolled his eyes at me and walked away. In the end, I ordered a radish cake to-go and high-tailed it out of there. For a group of 4, the bill was around $127! That's completely overpriced for disgusting dim sum and crappy customer service. In Monterey Park and Arcadia, I've paid $70 for a group of 7 and received way better service and more selection! I do not recommend this place.
author: Lynn T.

description:
food was not served hot and tasted as though it was cooked earlier
Service at table was good
food service was slow and the presentation of new food had to be requested
every restaurant has off days, I generally like the food and service and plan to return
author: Steven M.

description:
Went during the week, on a Thursday, and figured it might be a good idea to get there before 12:00, which was the right idea. After being seated at the bar, within minutes, I had the (much anticipated) shanghai dumplings in front of me and a request for pork shumai and shrimp haggau on the way. All were phenomenal and the dumplings with their soup-insides were excellent.

I also ordered scallion pancakes which were not that good; they seemed to be made of more filler than others that I have had in the past, but the shumai and haggau were the best I have ever had.

Do go early, even during the week, as when I left at 12:30, the line was out the door. They do accept AMEX, unlike a couple of other area dim sum places and they also have a to-go restaurant next door for those on the run.

The only downside to my visit was that the waitstaff pushed to either get you more food when it appeared you were done or pushed to get you your check, but that's understandable with the sheer amount of customers they have.
author: Jason S.

description:
Oh my goodness, I never NEVER get disappointed when I get dim sum here (even if the usual wait time is about 45 minutes to an hour on regular days)!

I'm very picky when it comes to dim sum. If one of the dumplings or steamed rice or whatever isn't cooked, steamed, fried right, then I would never come back again. But in my personal opinion, everything is cooked the right way!

I really wish I remembered all the names of the things that I always get but I can't seem to remember them that well.. But ALWAYS get their Shanghai dumplings or Xiao Long Bao because it's their signature dish there. 

Service can be a little crappy at times but I actually don't complain and I understand because this place gets super busy.. And because their food always makes me happy, I don't mind their crappy service.
author: K P.

description:
Fun atmosphere out in the aviary looking setting, with the sound of small plates, cups and bowls clinging around.   The pork was good, the king crab wrapped with protein stuff was odd but delicious.  My first try at chicken feet so I have no comparison but I did like it. 

Good place to take kids.  Fun.
author: Sean H.

description:
Went here on New Year's Day with friends! We didn't make reservations, but it wasn't a problem as we were seated once our entire party was present. Carts came around at a very good rate & the dumplings were simply amazing! We elected to sit inside versus out, which is probably why the carts came around at a good rate. It took awhile to get our check, as there wasn't a main server per table. They also have a take out service, which I'm looking forward to trying soon. 
5 stars for quick seating on a holiday.
author: Mikey B.

description:
How many reviews for Yank Sing?!  Cor!!  Four figures?!

It was the mid-1980's when this business center opened up in the historic Rincon Center post office. I remember this specific location housed a Chinese restaurant called Wu Kong.   There was a piano player located outside in the center of the complex entertaining those who were patronizing the various eateries.  My, how time flies.

I was surprised to come to Wu Kong to find out that Yank Sing had taken over the restaurant space from its longtime Battery Street location. It has been quite sometime since I have been here.  I met up with some friends for dim sum.  Pricey, yes, but well worth it. The standard dim sum staples are delicious.  What was new to me was the sea bass.  Tasty and good.

Must come back and have some dim sum next door at its to go, Yank Sing 2 Go which is excellent if one is pressed for time or for reasons otherwise.
author: Chiara A.

description:
The date of this review is Saturday, February 1, 2014.

After reading about Yank Sing Restaurant from a rival website, my wife and I decided to dash to San Francisco just to try and sample their Dim Sum menu. Several days before our trip, we emailed them and the manager responded by confirming our reservation. We left our home around 4:00 a.m. and we arrived at Yank Sing about 10:50 a.m.

We identified ourselves by showing the e-mail and we were immediately seated, table for two. Since we did not know what to order at this place, we asked the manager to help us in the selections. She suggested a few items that we ordered plus we picked up a few more from the carts passing by us. We don't know the names of the Dim Sum items, but three outstanding items that the manager recommended were BBQ Pork Buns, Shanghai Dumplings, and Egg Custard. On these three items we doubled up. Everything that we ate was tasty and delicious. Of course hot tea was served to us.

Our bill at Yank Sing Restaurant came to $127.00, tax and tip included. After we finished our lunch we decided to drive to the Fisherman's Wharf area. We stopped at the Boudin Sourdough Bakery to pick up a few loaves of their sour dough bread.

Overall we had a great one day experience in San Francisco and we truly enjoyed our lunch at the Yank Sing Restaurant. If the opportunity presents itself again, we will definitely repeat our adventure again.
author: Stephanino B.

description:
Probably the best dim sum place in SF and it's not even in Chinatown. They have xiao long boa (Shanghai pork dumplings), which are amazing and my Chinese father tells me only hardcore dim sum places serve. 

I'm not giving 5 stars for the extremely long wait-1.5 hours for a table for 2 and this restaurant is HUGE. Also, I know dim sum is generally considered for lunch, but this place is missing an opportunity by only staying open until 4. Plus, it is located in Rincon Center and nothing is open around it since its the edge of the financial district. We had to walk a few streets over to find a coffee shop to kill some time in.

Plan ahead for the wait and you won't be disappointed!
author: Jennifer C.

description:
I came here for a pre-Christmas dim sum lunch with friends -- on a Saturday.  You know a place is good when there is a line to be seated, as was he case with Yank Sing on the day I visited. Our group was not seated in the restaurant; we were seated out in the courtyard. As I understand it this is how it is done on the weekends.

Things move very quickly, but dim sum carts always come around and there are plenty of opportunities too get whatever you desire. For me that would be the chicken feet, which were very tasty.  In addition I found the tofu skin and fried tofu wrapped in seaweed to be excellent. I dream about the fried tofu now! That's how good it was!
author: Courtney S.

description: This is hands down the best Dim Sum I have ever had. Before I get to how delicious everything was let me say, this place is extremely clean and the quality of the ingredients were stupendous.  The staff was kind, helpful and proficient.  I called ahead to notify the Resturaunt that my sons have food allergies. Ella called me back and gave me a list of options.  Once we arrived Ella helped us again with which dishes were acceptable with the allergies. She brought me a printed list and double checked everything.  Ella brought out special treats just for my boys to make them feel special. The place was packed with a line forming before they even opened.  It's all delicious especially the Shanghai Dumplings. We are ate far too much!!!
author: Jennifer J.

description:
Yes, a FAN!  Very good and consistent!  Lots of choices and everything is good.  Service can be rushed but not bad.  You always have to wait but it is worth it--and, we often sit at the bar to eat--no wait and good service.  Don't be shy--order off the menu for some additional specialties e.g., beef noodles--very yummy!!!  Shanghai dumplings (not up to the quality of Din Tai Feng--but very, very , very good--hot, juicy and love the vinegar/ginger) are on my list every visit as are the triangle shaped shrimp and chive dumplings--DELICIOUS!!!  A little bit of a tourist trap but overlook it and enjoy the food/tea. 

Yank Sing--My fav dim sum in SF.  Four thumbs up from us!  I recently took my mom and she loved it too!!!
author: Jeff P.

description:
Second time here. Today's service was awful.  In one hour dim sum cart came by only once.  Manager and staff unapologetic. 
DON'T RECOMMEND ANYMORE. 
Would give zero if possible.
author: Paul G.

description: They were out of BBQ pork buns which was a disappointment, but will be back for them along with shanghai dumplings. Great variety of dishes.
author: Noel C.

description:
Very good. Honey walnut shrimp, potstickers, XLB, Peking duck, chow fun, and Don-taut- all excellent.  A little pricey, but worth the wait and cost. 

Also- one of the nicest looking dim sum restaurants.  Validated parking in the smallest garage spots ever. Would def go back.
author: Tim S.

description:
Dimsum is okay and pricey. You can have better dimsum in Chinatown or Oakland area. Good thing I came here for a free lunch with a friend because I wouldn't pay 30 per person for dimsum.

Just walk around Chinatown and check out the Dimsum bakeries where alot of Old cute Chinese ladies line up and carry out with them huge pink boxes.
author: Claudine V.

description: Wait was really short despite the line of people waiting to be seated. A lot of room when you're seated so you don't feel like you're sitting on top of each other. The cart was ready by the time we sat down. chow fun was really good. I wish the soup dumplings were a little hotter, they came out more warm. I'd definitely come back.
author: Michael K.

description: Great dim sum but very pricey. Easy $100 for lunch for two.
author: Gerald H.

description: Awesome buzz, great dim sum and friendly staff. Crowds of Chonese locals, so you know it's the real deal!
author: Hilaru W.

description: Very clean. Decent dim sum. Steamed pork buns not so great. Good tea, good xiao long bao
author: M M.

description: Beautiful setting, and lovely options but I'd say that the dim sum isn't as good as it used to be. AND its even more expensive than before.
author: Gwenn G.

description:
Let me preface this review by saying I'm a vegetarian. That is why I wanted to go to Yank Sing because it's hard to find vegetarian-friendly dimsum and they definitely offered more vegetarian items than your average dimsum place, though still not a lot. 

The spinach dumplings, mushroom dumplings, and snap peas were my favorite dishes. They also make some of the best fried sesame balls I've ever had. So yes, the food was good, but for the price, I would not return. The sesame balls were $11, that's just unreal. They're famous for their soup dumplings, which everyone at the table loved, but again, for dimsum this place is simply over priced. You can find the same quality of food for much cheaper. 

Also know that it's extremely crowded on Sunday mornings, so expect to wait at least 45 minutes.
author: Maleenee B.

description:
So for my first trick, I will pull a new yelp review out of my 2 year hiatus. 

Seriously, it's been way too long for me to not have informed fellow YELPers about all the food I've fallen in love with and hated. I should feel a little guilty about it but...ehh, what can I say, life happens. So to honor this comeback I'd like to take this time to write about one of my fav. foods: dim sum at Yank Sing in SF.

I came here just before lunch on Sat. I was initially thrown off by the huge banquet space of the Rincon Center but immediately found my way to toward the sights and sounds of the bustling restaurant. It was much bigger than I thought. This place was no hole-in-the-wall, which I'm typically accustomed to. Servers pushing their carts like NYC cab drivers, not caring who's in their way, and the smell of fresh dim sum in the air. This was no dim sum restaurant at all. No, no. This was heaven.

To tell you the truth, I don't remember half the names of the items. There was hella dim sum that before I knew it, I lost track of what it was I devoured. But thank God to online menus. Here's what I liked: the Shanghai dumpling with its contents of pork and savory broth. The Mandarin dumplings were alright, just needed some soy sauce to moisten it up. The soft shell crab, seasoned with salt and pepper then deep fried, was a nice touch. For my fellow San Franciscans, ever heard of bacon wrapped hot dogs? Well then try the bacon wrapped shrimp. The stuff's so good it would make Bubba cry. Other things worth trying were the Sea Bass and the walnut shrimp. But the one item worth savoring (and ordering to go) was the Steamed pork bun. Seriously, take a moment to truly enjoy this mouth-watering, honey-glazed, warm and fluffy bun, stuffed with sweet bits of pork. It's amazing! 

Drooling yet?

I bet you are. This place very much accommodates small-large parties. Great for families. It's clean. Though it is a big restaurant, it's still seems like tight quarters. So get to know your neighbors. You'll be there for a while if you're satisfied with the food.

Other things to note: the service is good but I can see how busy it can get. And what's cool is they also validate parking (You're welcome). And if you're in a rush, you can order-to-go just outside the restaurant. 

So if you're craving dim sum, hit this place up. You won't regret it...I hope. Overall, I was impressed. I'm definitely coming back, faster than you can say Abra-Cadabra.
author: Will S.

description:
I went to Yank Sing again today because I had such an awful experience at another restaurant for Dim Sum.  I figured at least this place is nice and clean and the service should be a lot better, albeit expensive.  I know it gets packed during the weekend so I arrived before 11AM.  

We ordered the following:

Shanghai XLB Xiao Long Bao -  each dumpling had soup inside.

Haa Gow - quite good with nice amount of shrimp.  

Peking duck - Good, skin could be crispier 

Jook - OK, quite tasty congee.  

BBQ Pork - Kind of sweet.  

Mango Pudding - Had some mango inside.  Very nice looking.  

Overall, I enjoyed my experience here.  The quality of the Dim Sum is good and the service level is bearable.  You could just tell that the woman who pushes the cart is trying to be patient and not blow up when you ask what's inside those steam holders.  This is especially true when you didn't find the ones you like.  I actually see some smiles at this Dim Sum place from the service personnel.  It's expensive, we spent $60 for 2 for Dim Sum which is worth it for me not to deal with sticky table and surly service from some of the other places that serves Dim Sum.
author: Jim J.

description:
Let me start out by saying that the food is pretty good.  I have been involved with a New York vs San Francisco dim sum debate...which one is better? I went to Yank Sing with low expectation because most locals say that it's over priced good food.

We ordered

Shrimp dumpling - my favorite dish
Chives dumpling
Braised spare ribs - not worth it
Chicken feet - just okay
Xiao Long Bao - pretty good - tasty brooth and the meat is nice.  Can't compare to NY though.
Egg Tart - yummy!!!  But boy are they expensive.

I can't remember what else we ordered.  Overall a decent meal but too expensive for dim sum; especially when you can go to Chinatown and order an entire menu for the same price as dim sum for 2...  

With that said, the shrimp dumpling and chive dumpling were really really good.  The dumpling skin had perfect consistency.  They had the best dumplings for the trip.

Be sure to check out my review of Koi Palace for the NYC vs SF Dim Sum summary.  

Verdict: NYC - Asian Jewels
author: Peter W.

description:
$10 for three "jeen-dui" (sesame balls with lotus paste) made our table of Chinese-Canadian diners exclaim "What the frak?!?" My father, who was a part owner at a dim-sum restaurant, would have had a coronary. Our waiter told us that their "Jeen-dui" were somehow more special, but they tasted pretty much the same to all of us there, except perhaps they were less crispy than one would like. 
And $12.80 for "sui-lung-bao" made me want to weep. We were there for over an hour, and no sign of "cheung-fun" either. It's just as well, cause I couldn't afford it. And I thought that Koi Garden in Dublin was expensive! Oh, how I have misjudged ye, Koi Garden.

In case you think we're a buncha country hicks going yum-cha for the first time, let me clarify - our table comprised of experienced dim-sum goers - we've ALL had dim sum in Hong Kong, Singapore, Beijing, Toronto, Vancouver. We begrudge Yank Sing the gall, (the hubris!) for these prices, because you can better and cheaper elsewhere. 

This country mouse just can't keep up with San Francisco prices.
author: Tina C.

description:
Can't come all the way to San Francisco and not have Dim Sum!  
Anyway, we found this place off of yelp.  There are actually 2 Yank Sing restaurants that are real close to each other.  But, we only came to this one because there's parking here.  You park in the Rincon garage, and they give validation.  

 We came here with a group of people.   (Around 12).  On a Sunday morning!  There was a wait, but it wasn't too long.  Around 30 minutes.   The way this restaurant is set up is it's in some kind of shopping complex.  Sort of like a mall.  They seated us outside.  (Not outdoors).  It was outside of the restaurant.  In the mall area.  It was nice and bright.  Although, some places were a little to sunny.

I like this place because everything we ate was delicious!  From the har gao to the shu mai.  There were even a few dishes they had which I've never seen before.  Those were good too. 

Not sure if it was because we all had a big appetite after running the marathon / half marathon or because this place is a little expensive. . . but the bill came out to around $30 per person.  

Regardless, I would definitely come back here! MmM mmM my tummy is growling just typing up this review.
author: Emily S.

description:
Four stars for Yay! I'm a fan, but really 3.5 stars because damn it I can't afford to really be a fan and come here all the time. 

The food is pretty good and the service is definitely superb, but for four people the bill ended up being $167 before tip. Uhh....
author: Rowena L.

description: Great food and tea. Each dish is well made. The dan tots are better than golden gate bakery...:)
author: j. l.

description:
The definitive review:  
The dim sum is quite good (there's certainly much better though).
There are not varieties of dim sum that would make a Midwesterner squeamish (forget about trying duck feet here).
The dim sum costs at least twice as much as almost any other high-quality dim sum restaurant (like, some other restaurants within a 15-minute walk).  
The ambiance is rather sanitized for westerners
If you go to Yank Sing, you'll be missing out on more than just half your paycheck. 
Secret:  If you get take-out, it costs half as much.
author: Rob B.

description:
Great dim sum, fresh ingredients, not at all oily, attentive service, atrium has great ambiance, much bigger than the Stevenson location. Our favorite dishes were shao mai, ha gao, sea bass, meat and 1000 yr old egg congee (hidden gem), stuffed lotus leaf, sesame balls, chicken feet and a rice flour ball dish with meat inside (don't know what this is called!). We were not as impressed with the xiao long bao, turnip cake, and the chicken and mushroom dumpling. Overall, everything was very fresh and we left happy. You will pay more for the better ingredients, financial district location, the James Beard and Michelin Star, and the restaurant's illustrious history. However, we all (7 of us) felt it was money well spent ($20-$25 before tax and tip). 

BTW, I am sick of people who are willing to pay $30, 50, 80, 100 per person for New American food, but find it insulting that great Chinese food costs more than $15 pp. If you are going to write a review stating that this was only so-so because dim sum should never cost this much and chinatown is cheaper, please take a moment to consider your values and whether your cultural biases influence your judgement. Thanks.
author: Hauwei L.

description:
we went to this place as dim sum fans.  the service is awful with cranky Chinese waitresses around you, pushing their carts next to you urging you to take more than one dish away.   if you didnt end up doing that, they would make their face look worse.   everything is overpriced. Especially Xiaolongbao.  We have been to many dim sum places here or in NY and China.  Yank Sing is below average to me, with its cold vegetables with generic soy sauce,  steamed pork ribs that do not taste fresh at all.  Most disappointing is Xiaolongbao.  Yes it still has broth in it which is a sign of successfully made Xiaolongbao.  But its flavor is stale and average.  And it costs 13.6 dollars.

And Sui Mai here is again very very average.   You could get something equal or better from any takeout dim sum place in Chinatown.   And every dish was served cold. It is only around 10:30 am when we ate there.  

Another advice is about their service.  People pay upscale price sometimes to just have upscale services.   None of the waitresses I saw there was friendly, helpful or smiley.   Yes in some Chinese places we have "rude" Chinese waiters, but the place is at the same time very cheap and good and maybe doesn't have the money to pay the overworking waiters to fake a nice smile/patience.  But Yank Sing is a so called upscale place.  Yet its waiters look mistreated or depressed somehow, for what we wonder.

With a more reasonable price, you can get much much better dim sum at Great Eastern Restaurant on Jackson St in Chinatown.   Dim Sum there are served hot, fresh, and made with heart.
author: Shuting Z.

description:
Food: 5/5
Service: 4/5
Cleanliness: 5/5
Decor & Style: 4/5

What else can I say, As good as it gets!
author: Nick N.

description: Came here for dim sum on a Sunday morning and waited for about 30 min for a table. The food was mediocre, as I have had better dum sum. The restaurant didn't have a large selection of food.
author: L Y.

description: I'm a fan of Dim Sum and I wasn't disappointed. There is a nice variety of items, but you have to be proactive about asking for vegetable dumplings because the staff really push the pork and shrimp, so it's easy to end up with far too much meat! Everything was delicious and reasonably priced, and we quickly went from starving to stuffed. The building is very corporate (it's in the Financial District after all) but the atmosphere inside is a typical Chinese restaurant.
author: Matthias H.

description:
Best chinese food I've ever had. The wait can be ridiculous on the weekends because every one comes here. Luckily, it is a HUGE restaurant but still can have a very long wait. The first time I came, i was just with one other person and we were able to snag seats at the bar and ordered our food there.

Honey Walnut Shrimp is amazing. It doesn't taste as fatty as most places because the sauce is minimal and the shrimp is crunchy. Even the walnuts are delicious. 

The Schezshuan (spelling is wrong, sorry) chicken is also extremely delicious. I am actually starting to crave it as we speak from just typing about it. 

And you have to come here and have their shanghai dumplings. These are the best I've had in the bay area so far.
author: Stephanie P.

description: Old school dim sum, fast service, yummy food..  what more do you want?  We went there twice during our 5 night stay in San Fran...
author: Soo M.

description:
*** REVIEW 1001 ***

My stars are strictly for the service I received in planning my wedding banquet and the service provided throughout the entire event!

The Hubsters and I decided on having our wedding reception at Yank Sing after scouring the Bay Area for venues and realizing that nearly everyone on our guestlist would probably enjoy Chinese food more than the obligatory seabass/steak/chicken/vegetarian options. We booked the date 6 months ahead, signed the contract and away we went!

I worked closely with Vera who was instrumental and amazing in pulling together our day so that it was perfect. I didn't get a chance to eat a lot of the food since we were mingling and greeting but what we did taste, it was awesome! The price lists that we were given was definitely the most expensive in the bay area in terms of wedding banquet food but it was classy food in a classy location without any tacky gaudy bits that you normally find in a Chinese banquet.

Vera was amazing to work with... extremely patient and calm. They took my wines a week ahead to hold in time and worked with my florists so that they could pick up the large arrangements afterward. Highly recommended!!!
author: Vicky L.

description: This place is bomb. I really enjoyed everything this place served me. We had the honey walnut shrimp, shrimp dumplings, soup dumplings, Schezuan chicken, Shrimp noodles, and the duck bun thingy. When the servers come by in their carts, I don't see how you turn down anything they offer. My one complaint is that there were periods of time where there weren't alot of carts out. But this place was very good and I will be back.
author: Nick R.

description: My favorite food and my favorite place. I have dined at Yank Sing for over 40 years. This location is the best of the current locations. (I loved the one on Broadway decades ago.) Dined early today and had all the carts I wanted. English was used to explain and answer questions and service on water and tea, just right. No one can make turnip cakes as well. And the basil seafood dumpling is a great addition.
author: Frank R.

description: Good food but we didn't eat extravagantly by any means and it was 100 bucks for 3 people.  Just sayin for rice and noodles that's a crime.
author: Jordan B.

description:
- pretty busy restaurant. 
- the items are delicious, especially the dumplings, and even more specifically, the shrimp one. 
- good dessert selection!
- adorable tea pots with pretty good tea to go around. 
- service refills water and tea consistently. 
- nice noise level; there's a lot of energy

negatives:
- not too many selections...or not as much as they say. 
- even when you refused an item more than once, the lady keeps coming...not one wants the red cabbage salad!

so:

- have a menu on the side to order from it to diversify the table. 
- go with a group. 
- make reservations, even on weekdays.
author: Taz H.

description:
The place wasn't too hard to find, but parking was.  I was not fond of the fact that when using their garage we had to use the valet parking, and was not given an option to park the car ourselves.  After taking the elevator up we walked into the building where Yank Sing was located and were immediately awed by the beautiful waterfall in the middle of huge eating area.  All around the building was a food court, and there were some pretty great choices.  Next door to Yang Sing is Yank Sing To-Go, so you can go there to get all the foods you love, but faster =).  We walked into Yank Sing and were immediately sat.

We got a smaller two top table and were quickly approached by one of the carts.  They have an EXTREMELY WIDE variety of dim sum,but it doesn't just stop there -- they have chicken lettuce wraps, chow fun, soups, and the list can go on and on and on ... which was a MAJOR plus for me. I never felt limited, and you will always find something that you like.

On top of the amazing food, the service was was just as great.  My water cup was never empty, AND when all the ice melted the server did not want my water to be warm when they kept filling it, so he got me a whole new glass with ice in it.  They are all VERY helpful, and gave such absolutely amazing service.  But there was this one woman that was pushing around a cart that always had a mean mug on her face, but whatever ... everyone else was fantastic.

Although the place is very very very expensive compared to other places for dim sum, the way I see it is that you get what you pay for -- and here, I felt like I get every penny's worth.  After one visit Yank Sing has stolen my heart and quickly became my favorite dim sum place.  It was love at first bite.  ;)
author: Pia V.

description: Never really was a fan of dim sum until I tried Yank Sing. Although it's a bit on the pricey side, their quality of food is good and they surprisingly had great service! They also validate your parking in the Spear street garage. My favorites were the shanghai soup dumplings and the crab claws. Will be back to try their peking duck and $18 sea bass!
author: Theresa P.

description:
I love love this place :-). My favorite dim sum place. Been here for lunch on a nice day and sat outside. I've tried most of the dim sum- all yummy. Love the duck and the sea bass here! Veggies are good too. Sesame seed buns are the best here :-)

Everyone is great, great service.

I can't wait to come back and do some damage. Lol
author: Azizi A.

description: Fantastic dim sum.  Not every item (spring rolls, shu mei) measures up, but the stuff that's good (pork buns, pot stickers) are outstanding.
author: Steve S.

description: This place came highly  recommended from the Mark Hopkins in Nob Hill. The food was good but service was horrendous. The carts mostly focused on the tables that were on the outer perimeter and big tables. We arrived when the restaurant opened. Eventually, had to order dim off the menu so we could eat  since it took the carts awhile to make it around to us. Even with that, it took repeated reminders to the servers about our orders.  I've been to bigger dim sum restaurant than Yank Sing and received better service. Would not go back or recommend this place. Highly overrated and overpriced.
author: Le P.

description:
#85 on the 2011 7x7 List: Sesame balls
#97 on the 2009 7x7 List: Sesame balls

This review is between both the catering and the week day dim sum.

they catered two friends' weddings and the food and atmosphere was excellent.  (i love jellyfish).  

the manager was very polite and attentive at dim sum when i was holding up the table inside the restaurant waiting for my bf to arrive.  the dim sum is pretty standard / yummy, but expensive (thanks for treating, J)

The sesame balls are good - pretty standard, good chewy mochi outside, nice red bean paste on the inside

http://www.yelp.com/biz_photos/SAFRM460dH7LHqYVAdoWgA?select=I2hEcob17vn9WLMON7eleA

This place is what the HK crowd would call "Gwai Lo" chinese place - catering for the Caucasian/business crowd.  Not a bad thing.
author: Winnie L.

description: Start your day with brunch at this dim sum place, would never go wrong with fresh and yummy selection specially scallop siu mye, wrapped chicken, radish cake, lists go on and on. Consider one of the good egg custard in Bay Area too!
author: CH T.

description:
I'll make this quick:
Food: Damn good & as authentic as you can get. I'm addicted to their chili sauce & went to Marina & bought 3 bottles.
Service: Ehhhh, however much better than other dim sum joints
Will go back for the food, however will expect a 3 star service.
author: Nadia N K.

description:
3.5 stars for good dim sum and excellent service. For the prices they charge, yes I do expect great service. You can request dishes directly without waiting for the cart and it will come out immediately. I wish all dim sum places had this type of quick and efficient service. 

Dishes to order: Shanghai dumplings(favorite), shumai, BBQ pork buns.

Disappointing dish: Pecking duck. The bread for the pecking duck was really dry. I was looking forward to this.
author: Jennifer S.

description:
This place is great for vegetarian dim sum. If you are vegetarian, you know that it is very dificult to find things you can eat at most dim sum places. This place is the complete opposite. As you as you sit down, the waiters start bringing food to your table. They quickly figured out that my friend and I were only eating vegetarian items, so from then on they brought us only vegetarian things. I love how the service is so fast. 

The best item by far is the curry vegetable dumplings. We kept ordering more of those. The mixed vegetable dumplings and the mango pudding were great too. I'm so happy I found this place! :)
author: Vrushali P.

description: When it comes to domestic dim sum, I don't want it from anywhere else.
author: James M.

description:
So years ago, I ate at Yank Sing for dim sum. I'm no expert in this culinary regard but thought back then, it was good; in spite of the price point at the time.
My last experience was for my cousin's wedding that was at Yank Sing & yeah howdy was this a lovely experience! Food was very good (my cousins are from Hawaii & are Chinese/Japanese). The food ran the traditional wedding choices and then some. I pretty much felt I hit cross cultural nirvana at this event. This has been several years ago, so I only hope they still deliver in this regard. This was one excellent wedding with dragon dancers & a thousand cranes to boot. Just lovely.
author: Kathi H.

description:
If I were a poor student again, living off student loans, I'd certainly feel raped and hungry after eating here.  Now, I'll rephrase that, because violence is wrong, and this is too much of an exaggeration to be considered a valid review.  So, I'd certainly feel violated.  But, I am no longer that said person.  Because now, I am so rich that I have cash oozing out of my leather lined Hermes boxer shorts.  You might say, "Lies!  I shop at Hermes all of the time- last purchase was a  $1200 hoe for my gardner because I didn't want my neighbors to be talking about me behind my back, and they DON'T have leather lined boxer shorts!"
Well, my dear, I have news for you, because I happen to know Hermes.

As this string of exaggerations continue, so does dim sum.  Dim sum is supposed to be a casual experience.  If people are justifying platinum prices, then be my guest.  It's just that if I were to go and have brunch somewhere and spend 40 bucks per person without a bloody mary in the mix, then there is a problem.  I mean, what makes one eggs benedict that much more superlative than another's?  

It's perception and deception.  Yank Sing is genius from a business standpoint.  Pure genius.  "you get what you pay for" and "attainable exclusivity" is used here, all by using commonly used household items!

Enough hub bub.  What I love about this place is that we don't have to wait for too long.  I mean, we usually have to wait an hour or more for Mayflower, that fishy palace near Serramonte, and other places in the Richmond.  
The dim sum is never "horrible".
The service is great.

So, my next business idea is to make a chinese restaurant, make consistently easily made but fresh meals, ramp up the prices, and...Oh, wait, I just described R&G.
author: John L.

description: I went to the newer one on Spear Street. Dim Sum was great.  Service was very good.  Nice atmosphere.  Just a little on the pricey side.
author: JJ M.

description:
If someone hates Yank Sing on the premise that it's too expensive or too loud/crowded, it is because:

a) They have a food double standard - i.e. willing to shell out $50+ for mediocre French/Italian food on any day but ethnic food somehow does not have the same value.

b) They don't value good ingredients, which cost money. Most other dimsum places don't serve expensive fish, they serve lots of fried stuff or stuff wrapped in rice based products, so is it that hard to figure out why they are cheaper?

c) They place no value on service or quality of dining experience - yes I can get food that is almost as good for half as much, but do I enjoy chasing carts, waiting 20 minutes for tea and water, and having to grovel to get the bill? This is more food double standard going on here, if you were treated like that at a French/Italian restaurant you'd be pissed to pay even $15 for it.

d) They have never been to a real Chinese dimsum place - waiting is normal - if there's no wait, it's usually bad. And Chinese people are loud (being one, I can say that for sure), and if it's loud, it's a good sign that there may be a lot of Chinese people eating at the Chinese restaurant - which is usually good.

e) all of the above


The first time we went, we had 18 different plates between 3 people. And only one of them was fried and only one was wrapped in rice noodle. I've gone several more times and have had 30+ different plates. Most were good but not amazing, but the standouts were the sea bass, sweet potato wrapped seabass with basil, steamed shrimp and pea shoot dumplings, peking duck (try to wait for a fresh cart to come out though, otherwise its just so-so), and soup dumplings (xiaolongbao), which were the best I've had in the US after DinTaiFung in LA. The 7x7 sesame balls are the greatest sesame balls anywhere and their egg tarts are hands down the best egg tarts I've ever had (Golden Gate Bakery has NOTHING on these!).

The restaurant is clean, spacious, gives you a buzzer when your table is ready, all the carts come around on a regular basis even when we were tucked in a remote corner, the carts were almost always fresh and well stocked, there are dozens of people with wireless headsets you can flag to get you whatever cart you want to come to you, water and tea were always full, the staff were courteous and friendly and the bill is brought at the right time, when you want it. After tax and tip, ~$40-$55/person 

Some of the best food I've had have been at hole in the wall dives that violate many health codes and would scare the hell out of most people. But that does not mean every dining experience has to be like that. For the first time in a long time, DimSum was tasty, relaxing and orgnanized, and how often can you say that?
author: Snuffles B.

description: Quick, friendly service.  Great variety of items.  Servers describe items to you.  Food is fresh.  Standard fare of dumplings done right.  Soup dumplings are pretty good.  Nice high-end place for special events/celebrations, but not necessarily a regular 'go-to' spot, due to the high prices.  Totally recommended!
author: Ryan U.

description:
When your boss suggests an impromptu dim sum lunch at Yank Sing, do you say no? If you do, don't talk to me because we're not friends. Our office party of seven was seated promptly. Side note: Yank Sing is one of the few places in the area that's so blase about seating larger parties. They don't even ram tables together, they just bring you over to one of their enormous round tables. It's heartening to see a place that's used to handling high volume crowds so efficiently.  

The range of available food is impressive, more so considering we had a vegetarian and a gluten free person in our midst and no one went away hungry. Everything was nicely steamed, the dumplings were nicely filled, and the service was wonderfully prompt. You could do much, much worse than Yank Sing, especially when it's comped as a tax write-off.
author: Aaron Y.

description: Food was delicious very authentic. Did feel a bit rushed out because of the line that was forming outside.
author: Luli M.

description:
Not sure why everyone calls it Americanized. Yank Sing is known to be expensive but all their dishes are well executed and very authentic. I'm Chinese. I know. I think people love saying it's Americanized because the place is clean, not located in Chinatown or Richmond, and has great service (not rude waitstaff which is the status quo in most Chinese establishments).

I like it better than Hong Kong Lounge because you can make reservations and there's plenty of seating. In the Spear St. location, the open air seating with water in the middle is as beautiful as the perfectly made dumplings and tasty Peking duck.
author: Calvin W.

description:
You definitely won't leave hungry!
Yank Sing is always busy, but it's because its so good.  My favorite is the sea bass, it's $20, but worth every penny.
Staff is very efficient and service has always been good.
They do come around a lot, so I suggest taking it slow and waiting to see what they have to offer.  Forget the spring rolls and fried shrimp, there are so many other options that are way better (duck, fish, pork buns, dumplings).
Don't go if you're on a budget.  Expect to spend between $45-65pp.
author: Lynn T.

description:
Food was good, but somewhat unremarkable.  Nothing particularly stands out in my mind as having been better or worse than any other place I've tried.   The one time I've sat down for lunch inside, services was a touch on the pushy side, constantly coming by with the same dishes being offered multiple time.

I appreciate them trying to get us fed, but it could be disruptive to conversation and bothersome at times.

Take out I've tried a few times, whether be their special plates or a la carte, and the food was of similar quality, though it can take a minute to get your food.

I wouldn't sing this places praises, but I wouldn't speak too ill of them either, its just....unremarkable.
author: Christopher G.

description:
I finally went to Yank Sing after visiting San Francisco several times because my brother insisted that he would "disown me" if I spent another day here without visiting Yank Sing. To put things in perspective, my brother came to San Francisco for a conference, during which time he ate at Yank Sing every day for lunch, for five days.

So what makes Yank Sing so good? Its difficult to say, because there are so many things. The restaurant itself is refreshingly clean, and ranks a full grade above any other dim sum place I've been in terms of cleanliness. If you're lucky enough to get an atrium seat (on a sunday?), you should take it, because its a beautiful way to enjoy your meal. The spacious atrium is brightly light with natural sunlight, and the water feature in the center makes for a lovely backdrop for your sunday-morning conversations. 
 
More importantly, the food and service are also excellent. There are enough people and enough turnover of food that the food you get is always hot and fresh. We got some of the honey walnut shrimp, which, though overpriced, was some of the best I've had, and I would gladly go back and pay that much again for the delicate and crispy shrimp. The dumplings, as expected, were delicious and full of flavor, with just the right texture in the dough. The bean-paste filled sesame balls were delicious and fresh, but were extremely overpriced (at least compared to what i'm used to paying for them...), and I would probably not order them again here. Overall, the meal was extremely satisfying and we didn't find a single bad dish. In fact, we both left wishing we had room to try more of the dishes....Next time, I suppose. 

The bottom line is: if you're here and you want dim sum, you won't be disappointed. I haven't had enough of San Francisco's dim sum offerings to really say what's the "best", but Yank Sing is a comfortable and clean place to eat, its easy to get to (they validate parking), and the food is excellent, so I recommend it highly
author: Zameer A.

description: We used them for a catering for my dad's birthday party in SF.  It was a great experience!  They arrived at a good time to set up and made the table look so fun.  They brought plenty of leftover sauces and a heat lamp.  They made the whole setup so easy.  The dim sum was a huge hit with our guests!  Shrimp and pork dumplings and buns.  The chicken egg rolls went SO fast - they were gone before even the guest of honor had arrived.  They arrived on time for pick up the next day and made the whole process so seamless.  I would definitely use them for a future event!
author: Amanda K.

description:
If money doesn't matter, 4/5.
If money matters, 2/5.

Came here for dim sum.  Be careful.

Ordered like I usually do at a dimsum.  The "What is that?  I don't know what it is, but sure bring that over" and got hurt for it.  They also placed things on our table when we clearly said no thanks, but that I can live with. Dim sums do that sometimes.

This place is expensive, easily 2-3x more than what things should normally cost.  Potstickers for $9?  $4 for each lettuce wrap.  $10 for tea?

Yes the taste is decent, service is fast, nice environment, and convenient location, but paying $35/person for a quick lunch barely being full was not cool.  That's like a meal at a decent seafood restaurant.
author: Kenji Y.

description: Went for Sunday brunch and it was great!! Exceptional prompt, polite service. Clean vibrant dining room and great atmosphere. Everything we had was great but I highly recommend the pork rice rolls, bbq pork steamed buns and the soup dumplings.
author: Dhroov M.

description:
I'm all about the service here! None of the servers leave with bitter faces when you don't want anything from their cart. The food is just fine, nothing too stand out. Had the pistachio ice cream pie dessert and that was great... but I wouldn't buy it again since it was $8.50

4 people getting full hit us with a $150 bill pre tax... so it's pretty expensive.
author: Michael A.

description:
So delicious Great service Nice atmosphere.. But way toooooo expensive for dimsum... 
It feels like I have in&out burger in France for $50..
I really liked their egg tart. I had egg tart in many other places but this is the best! Dimsums are ok.. they're delicious but you can find that level of dimsums in many other cheaper places.
author: JS P.

description: I have enjoyed number of fun business lunches at this place, feels like the Dim Sum version of a big American lunch buffet.  The folks are nice, the food is tasty,but the variety of selection, and diversity of options (lacks veggies etc) is a challenge.  Come prepared for a fun experience, with many choices of shrimp
author: mike j.

description: As a guy grew up on Dim Sum, this place is more for the ignorant rich who is in it for the novelty. The food is passable, though most of the food is more lukewarm than hot. The shrimp dumplings were quite firm and a little tough to chew, same for the sui mai. The prices are insane! For the amount and quality of the food you are getting is not worth it. Though I must concede the tea was phenomenal and for only 10$, the only thing that is worth the money you are paying for in the restaurant. The Staff are friendly and like many other dim sum restaurant will press you to accept what they offer. This place is great for those who have some cash to burn and into the novelty of eating in an 'good quality, authentic' dim sum restaurant. But to those who knows the difference between quality and novelty, Yank Sing is definitely not a place you would go for a good time and a good meal.
author: Hao L.

description:
My old college friend and I just had lunch and it was $60 out the door including tip. What a RIPPPPP OFF!

We only ordered the 6 typical dim sum items

1.) chicken feet
2.) spare ribs
3.) shanghai dumplings
4.) ham sur gok
5.) lo bat goh 
6.) siu mai!! 

Food was luke warm, besides the steamed items,. lucky we were short on time and had meetings to get back to and didn't fully indulge in ordering massive amounts of dim sum like we normally do.

No thank you! Will not be back! I rather walk a few blocks down for Canton Seafood & Dim Sum Restaurant!!! We can order way more for two and our tab at most will be $30 total!!!

http://www.yelp.com/biz/canton-seafood-and-dim-sum-restaurant-san-francisco
author: Chanel L.

description:
Our favorite Dim Sum in the city! We go every time we're in town -- just about once a month! Yes it's pricey, and worth every penny IMO. The food is clean, delicious and always fresh... the mustard and spice rack is always tidy (these are messy and sticky at other dim sum restaurants I've been to)... their service and food is consistent. 

If you have a bit of time to plan your visit in advance, call ahead to make a same-day reservation. We do this every time and we've never waited for a table. 

We LOVE:
Pan fried chicken bun 
Chicken and mushroom dumpling 
Soup dumpling (!!) 
Shrimp dumpling 
Dan tat (!!) 
Sesame balls 
Chrysanthemum tea

***With some dishes, you can ask for a half order, allowing you to save space to try other things!
author: Mark D.

description:
Food is very good. Traditional Cantonese style dim sum. Har gow pretty standard, Chinese broccoli with oyster sauce was good, various seafood steamed dumplings excellent and better than most places. Fried sweet rice dumplings (savory dish) excellent with crispy outer layer and creamy inside. The soup dumplings were a let-down: soup was fatty and bland, not rich with aspic as in other places. Variety of dim sum dishes large, with unusual additions such as chicken lettuce cups made to order, spicy stir fried green beans, chicken satay, and wonton soup.  
Service is mostly good though I became forgotten about halfway through my meal and dim sum carts stopped coming near me. All waitresses speak fluent English, a total plus! Luis (tall Chinese waiter) did a good job following up with the cart ladies after noticing my table was full of empty plates. He was like a ninja removing empty plates with a sneaky deft hand--one minute dirty plate, next minute mysteriously gone. Four stars because I did feel some of the dishes were overpriced (avg $6 each, soup dumplings $12), but I will definitely be back--especially if someone else is buying!
author: Anna M.

description: The shrimp dumpling here is the bomb diggity!!!! Their chicken and rice lotus leaf wrap is cooked to perfection. I can only do dim sum here because I cannot handle the pandemonium at all the other dim sum joints. They use walkie talkies so you can tell them exactly what you want and in a few moments, boom! There it is! It makes dim summing so much more orderly, efficient and civilized. ;)
author: Daisy B.

description: Went here for an impromptu lunch break. It was great! I think I ate about 10 Shang-hi Dumplings... Its kinda pricey, but a fun place to go for lunch if you have the time.
author: Natalie B.

description:
We come here once a year to eat Christmas lunch. I recommend to call for reservation so that you don't wait too long.
Great food but bring lots of money....it is expensive.
author: Andrew E.

description: Came here for lunch on a weekday prior to noon. It was very busy but we were able to get a table right away. Everything was very delicious overall but very overpriced. As for the hargow, I still prefer Koi Palace's large plump hargows since the ones here were tiny and less juicy. I would say that everything else (pan fried radish cake, suimai, pork spareribs, etc), was comparably delicious to that of Koi Palace, except their beef chow fun, shrimp long noodle roll, and xiao long bao were superior here at Yank Sing. The xlb and beef chow fun were the best, we even got thirds of the xlb bc it was that good, and the beef chow fun was probably the best I've ever had. I also liked how their food tasted fairly low in salt, and was just delicious based on pure flavor and freshness of the food itself. I did love it here but might only come back when I'm feeling extra spendy, as I could go to Koi Palace at least twice for every time I come here and Yank Sing isn't 2x better, but only about 15% better overall.
author: H I.

description: Wow.  Eating here reminded me of growing up in China and eating my grandmother's cooking.  Which is quite a compliment since I was born in Florida and have never been to China.  It's like their food awakened some DNA memory in my cells, of centuries ago of a may-be Chinese ancestor long forgotten.  I do have a father-in-law from Taiwan that drags me to various Dim Sums, and this was the best I've had.
author: Jim C.

description: The food here is excellent. The xiao long bao, their signature dish, may be the best in this country. You pay quite a bit here though. My wife and I ate here for lunch, and our bill turned out to be around $50 *per person*. Good thing a friend gave us a gift certificate! You also are paying for the fact that this place is an extremely rare find--A Cantonese restaurant with clean bathrooms and good service!
author: Amos Y.

description:
Shanghai Dumplings are a must.

The service is wonderful, the servers/cart runners/plate holders all speak English as well as Cantonese and Mandarin.  I'm not Chinese so them being able to speak to me in English was amazing.  Plus, the carts came in handy cause all I had to do was peer inside and pick out what I wanted to eat.

The taste was fabulous and everything was so fresh and was the perfect temperature.  I've had crappy ass dimsum and after having this, I don't think I can have dimsum anywhere else again.  Think about it... good food, great service, CLEANLINESS, smiles all around? I don't ever want to have dimsum at a ghetto place again.

It IS a bit more expensive, but after everything that I listed, I think that it was well worth it.
author: Jenn C.

description:
When both locals and past SF visitors keep bringing up the same spot to check out, then its a definite MUST!

Everyone keeps talking about how it is pricey, but you also haveto  outweigh the perks and convenience that comes with the price.

- there are 2 locations, but we made sure that we went to the one at rincon center, with its beautiful location and stunning water feature.
- it was best to sit outside near the water feature because it was a lot more spacious, less stuffy than inside the restaurant. ("outside" is actually still "inside" the bldg).
- food was delicious! you can tell that  yank sing uses quality products, clean but still stayed authentic for an awesome dimsum experience.
- servers speak english, which is such a bonus, especially when you are trying to explain or request something. you want to enjoy your dimsum experience not be stressed out about it.
- the place is clean, no loud crashing of plates unlike some dimsum spots, and did i say CLEAN and not sketchy!
- it is ideal to go with a group so you can try different plates, and the bill won't be so steep.
- this place was also a find, because its rare to find an asian restaurant, or dimsum spot that will take reservations. From Southern California to Northern California, it is rare to find a place where you can actually be seated right away on a busy Sunday and not have to wait 40mins to 1hr or more just to get great dimsum! yes, you have to use a credit card to hold a reservation, but who cares because you don't get charged if you show up, and you are guaranteed to be seated right away! win win situation!
- for parking.. they validate which is a perk in my book!
author: Abby C.

description:
Be prepared to pull out wallet/money for dim sum!

Excellent: honey baked sea bass ($$$)

Very Good: XLB (xiao lung bao, aka Shanghai dumpling), steamed rice noodles (shrimp, beef, or bbq pork), custard tart, fun gwo (meat dumpling), chicken rice wrapped in lotus leaf, sweet tofu.

So-so: har gao (much better at Koi Palace with thinner skin), siu mai, steamed pork bun, steamed pork ribs

Service was decent with so many tables, but given the astronomic prices they are charging, this area needs to step up to match the pricing. 

Tips:
The ladies pushing carts will intercom for an item you want that's not in their carts. Of course, it helps if you know exactly what item it is you want.
Make reservations...always crowded for dim sum. 
Will validate parking in Rincon Center garage.

Will I be back? ...only with friends who insist on coming here.
author: Lil D.

description:
This is as good as it gets in the San Francisco Bay Area. If a restaurant in San Francisco can survive solely on serving dim sum, then it's got to be pretty good. Yank Sing expensive but well worth it because of the service and authentic food. 

Growing up in Singapore my parents often took me to the Shangrila for dimsum making me a dimsum enthusiast today and I have to say that Yank Sing offers the most authentic experience. Firstly, the service is fantastic. If you want something just wave a waiter/(ess) down and they will get it for you. This is the way it should be at a good dim sum place. 

The Chilean Sea Bass is excellent. The layers of fish slide off and melt in your mouth just like it should. You'll have to try it! The Shrimp Dumplings, or as my parents call it "har gao" has the right thickness of dumpling noodle to shrimp. At most dim sum places I find the dumpling noodle too thick and pasty. I also like the Xiao Long Bao/ Soup Dumplings. The only place I believe to have beter Xiao Long Bao is Ding Tai Feng. The Sticky Rice is good here too. Don't forget brunch comes with dessert! The Sesame Balls, Egg Tarts and even Mango Pudding are delicious!
author: Kelly H.

description:
My favorite dim sum place. 

Today for the first time I saw this orange, orange flavored jello dessert. I want to try it next time. It looked really cool. They used real orange peels! 

Monday - Friday: reduced parking fees 
Saturday - Sunday: complementary parking
make sure you give them your parking ticket when you pay.
author: Jess W.

description:
Have had Dim Sum at other places, but theirs takes the cake. UNBELIEVABLE! 

It was a little pricey at $140 for 2 (plus tip), but felt it was worth it.
author: David Z.

description: Delicious dim sum. One of those places where you are literally swarmed with carts the moment you sit down. My only complaint is the price. It's easy to keep saying yes to everything and wind up with a bill that makes you cry.
author: Rachel W.

description:
3.5
came here for lunch w the coworker.. got there before noon to beat the lunch rush.. the place was packed when we left 

ordered:
-Chrysanthemum Tea

-peking duck w buns: skin could be crispier

-pai gwaat (steamed spare ribs): good i haven't had these in so long

-char sui bao (steamed bbq pork buns): good but once i got these i saw someone with the baked bbq pork buns! i wanted those instead but didnt get to try it

-xlb (shanghai soup dumpling)

-hau gow (shrimp dumpling)

-sui mai (shrimp pork dumpling)

-chee cheong fun (shrimp rice noodle roll): prefer the noodle rolls w chinese donut inside for texture

this place is good and i'd come here again but it's a lil pricier than your normal dim sum place.. i believe the bill was ~$80 for 2 ppl including tax tip
author: Raquel T.

description:
What a place! I have never seen so many selections of Dim Sum in my life. Everything was so fresh and hot. The place is enormous with people everywhere obviously enjoying the food. We went at 2:00 on a Sunday to the location in the financial district and waiting 30 minutes for a table. No big deal! It is fun to watch all of the serving carts moving around offering up the dim sum... 

My only complaint is the servers act like they are on commission. Once we were seated the Dim Sum cart selling frenzy started and we were quickly over whelmed with selections. No time to order a cocktail or even an ice tea. It was a Dim Sum fest. I think we waited longer for our table than for the four of us to eat $150 of DIm Sum.

Yes, I highly recommend it. But take it slow and don't feel rushed to try everything on their first run at your table. They will come back!
author: Teresa G.

description: Just about time for a mini road trip back to SF for some Dim Sum.  Drove by it last week going to Giants Game and it was closed.  It's always hard trying to decide, but whatever you choose it's always delicious.
author: Lynne M.

description: solid food. great atmosphere, especially sitting in the main lobby. little tough to hear but worth it. service is good.
author: Drew H.

description:
1. Overrated, Americanized dim sum.
2. Expensive because it's in the FiDi. 
3. I guess it's clean...
author: Michelle L.

description:
Ok, let me start with the bad news:

This place has the most terrifying parking garage I have ever had the misfortune of entering. The spots are teeny tiny, people drive in every direction, and there are frequently cars parked in non-spots blocking other cars in.

Now that that's out of the way, let's get to the food. The food here is absolutely delicious! It is much higher quality (and also much pricier) than the dim sum you get in Chinatown. I also really appreciate that they take reservations, so you don't have to wait forever to get in.
author: Diana G.

description:
Back again to Yank Sing and very happy to say it is absolutely first class despite some of the negative reviews.  I am a bit of a dim sum addict having lived in Asia for 20 years 
and I expect a lot and got it at Yank Sing.  Absolutely every dish we had was first class with the possible exception of the Peking Duck which doesn't belong at dim sum anyway.  (Probably the price had something to do with that).  The service was excellent, the food came fast and often and when we needed a special dish the girls with their head sets radioed for it immediately.  Believe all the good reviews of the Shanghai dumplings - super, but so was everything else.   Prices are higher than your average place but then so is the quality and well worth it.
author: Hank W.

description: Don't take the pile of red cabbage or mushrooms during dim sum.  Eleven buck each for underwhelming,
author: Michael E.

description:
Overpriced by a ton!

Yes, the dim sum is nicely served.   Yes, the dim sum is generally tasty.  Yes, some of the dishes are unique.  But they are so overpriced, you have to come here knowing that your pocket is being picked.   This makes Yank Sing a place to go when it's a very special occasion.  The soup dumpling is excellent, Peking duck was a soppy disappointment, and the sea bass interesting but quite expensive.  Not likely to come back here again ( unless I'm on an expense account with clients or my brother-in-law foots the bill).
author: Bad News S.

description: This is a fun place to try lots of different Asian small plates!  Some of our favorite items included the shrimp dumplings, shrimp rice noodle dumplings, the Peking duck, and the pork buns!  Yank Sing is always a must visit when we make it to San Francisco!!!
author: Michelle H.

description: Good food but WAY over priced.  13.60 for 6 XLB?? Good experience but will not return.  Try dim sum at Dim Sum Club or Hong Kong lounge to get your money's worth.
author: Ying H.

description: Great food, but save it for a special occasion due to the cost.  Recently I had a feast at Koi Palace and the cost was 1/2 as much for about the same quantity of food (and a comparable level of quality).
author: Patrick S.

description: Came for lunch with family I was visiting. What a fun place!  We ate outside the restaurant, its a fun, bustling atmosphere with nice upscale touches. It is well suited to groups so you can order lots of different yummy items  from the carts and share.The food was excellent. I especially loved the Shanghai Dumplings, oh they were just fantastic, tender little dumplings filled with a wonderful broth, they were so good, I would like some right now just thinking of them!!  All the food was great, very good quality. As for desserts the egg custard tart was also fantastic, we ordered some but I was so full that I didn't really want desert, but I  was told " you have to try these"  well yes I did have to, they were in the flakiest crust I ever had and the custard was so smooth and silky. They were wonderful really! I will want to go back when I visit next time.
author: Karen R.

description:
This was my first time at Yank Sing, but it was a little different since my visit was for a wedding reception.  We got to try a lot of dishes though, which was really great.  The menu was:

Double Happiness Cold Platter
Kweilum Shrimp Croquettes
Sauteed Sea Scallops
Supreme Sharksfin Soup
Braised Sea Cucumber
Crispy Spring Chicken
Crabmeat Ragout
Shanghai Style Crispy Sole
Braised Soft Noodles
Sweet Lotus Seed Delight

Everything was pretty good - my favorites were the sole and the crabmeat ragout, and my least favorites were the sea cucumber and the soft noodles.  Not so sure I would pay the big bucks for the food (my rating is based on what I would have given with the pricetag), but I definitely enjoyed it without the bill!
author: Jenna L.

description:
I have eaten here twice. The food is good, not all of it, but most of it. 

My biggest issue is that It is super busy, there are 1000 waiters trying to jam food at you, it's very rushed and loud. I only go here when it's  with a friend, in other words if they want to go for their bday or something, I wouldn't pick it myself. When I go out to eat I like to not feel rushed and relax.

I always feel stressed here plus the parking garage is made for minicoopers and smartcars only! OMG smallest parking spots ever and lowest cieling ever, as I was driving out I thought about a giant earthquake and being in the pit under this huge building and I couldn't wait to see sunlight.

BIG PLUS is that they validate parking under there...
author: Jennifer T.

description: We regularly make Yank Sing trips to the city. Well worth the over 60 minute drive each way. Have yet to find ANY Dim Sum anywhere that comes close to theirs. Yes we spend allot of money here but we leave hurting stuffed because it's hard to not try everything. Plus we always bring home a lot of take out that is lucky to make it to lunch time the following day. We actually took some friends there awhile back and keep getting asked when we where going back. SOON, VERY SOON without a doubt.
author: Ray L.

description:
This location is WAY BETTER than the Stevenson one. 

SCRUMPT-DILLY-UMPTIOUS.

Shanghai dumplings - solid A (which made my lunch). 
Service - A+ super fast. 
Chinese Broccoli - A made well and not chewy. 
Tzong tze (sticky rice wrapped in lotus leaves) - A+ extra credit
Green Beans - B a little burnt and too salty
Shu Mai - B not memorable but good

OVERALL - shanghai dumplings TRUMP the meal and I was a HAPPY DUMPLING, stuffed.
author: Erin C.

description:
Watch your wallet!
For a special occasion, I took my daughter to Yank Sing for a dim sum lunch. The food is scrumptious (we had chicken lettuce cups, cabbage and jicama salad, foil wrapped chicken, steamed pork buns and a gorgeous piece of bass.) About midway through the meal I began to wonder how much this was going to cost. There is no menu and no prices are posted. When I asked for a cup of tea, I was brought a huge pot. I suspected that there would be a charge so I said 'no thank you' but the waitress said 'no no worries.' When we got the bill it was $93 - including a pot of tea for $7.75. I will never go back. I've been to many dim sum houses in SF - and none operate in such a fishy fashion. I'm really surprised that they have a packed house. Not my scene.
author: joan g.

description: Food was incredible! Overall a little pricy, but so worth it! Loved the chicken curry turnovers and the Shanghai Beef. We will defiantly come back.
author: Jesi B.

description:
Delicious! I was here for a birthday party and it was also my first time trying the infamous Yank Sing. I was not disappointed.

We tried the soup dumpling, har gow, pea shoots dumpling, egg roll, pot sticker, chicken and mushroom dumpling and pan fried noodles with beef and bell peppers...all so tasty! Service was great and  I really liked the fountain that falls from the ceiling - adds to the ambiance.

Would come back again for dim sum and noodles! YUM.
author: Kristen S.

description:
I was expecting a lot from this establishment when I was recommended it by a friend who lives around the area. It's tucked away in a little street almost seeming like an ally way. It's small simple and clean. 
We came for the dimsum and sat down, the carts passed by and we chose the items that we thought looked best and wanted to compare to other dim sum. We also ordered a fried rice to come along. Honestly their dim sum was a very common dim sum that you can find at many places, and the fried rice was sub par. I love fried rice and have been to many places, and this was the poorest rendition of a yangchou style fried rice. 
The waitresses were nice and they always came by to see if anything else was needed. For the most part the service was extremely good. 
My gripes come when comparing the taste and quality of the food with other notable chinese restaurants and for the price they serve it at. For a mere 5 plates of dimsum, and a plate of fried rice, the bill came out to eighty bucks plus tip. Extremely overpriced, and very disappointing.
I recommend other cheaper restaurants around SF or LA because you can dine on foods of similar quality for better prices. However you wont get the service that yank sing has!
author: Shota P.

description:
My husband had never had dim sum before and I, being an expectant mom and lover of dim sum, decided it was high time he had the experience.  I debated on where to take him since it would shape his opinion of dim sum forever more.  So I decided on Yank Sing thinking it might be more expensive, but at least we wouldn't have to deal with rude or pushy servers or dirty surroundings and it would be a very pleasant experience for all of us.  I was wrong.

We arrived at 2:00pm on Sunday and were told by the hostess that there was a 25 minute wait.  Fast forward 45 minutes and we still had not been seated.  Meanwhile, our toddler is hungry and on the verge of a meltdown, as were my husband and I.  Finally, after almost 55 minutes, we are seated.  As we were sitting there, I was explaining to my husband all of the different dishes I like to order and that there were oh so many more for him to choose from, too.  So we waited, and waited.  Finally, a woman walked past with a (that's right, singular) small plate of walnut shrimp in her hand and my husband and I quickly said "we'll take it".  I tried to feed my son but he wasn't having any shrimp so I prayed a cart would come by soon with something he'd be able to eat.  Finally, after about 15 minutes, a cart came by.

I requested some sesame balls because I knew it was something my son could eat while we waited for more carts.  So the three of us sat waiting.  And waiting.  And waiting.  We had been seated for 30 minutes and only two, TWO, carts had gone by.  And the restaurant was full!  What the hell?????  We soon realized that what they were trying to do is to get people to order off the menu because A. the items are more expensive and B. so they wouldn't make a bunch of dim sum and then have food left over if no one purchased it off the cart.  

I was livid.  I could not believe this so-called "amazing" dim sum place was being so cheap and chintzy with food WE WERE WILLING TO PAY FOR.  It's not as if they were giving it away!  I complained to three different servers that we were still waiting for carts to go by and they kept bringing the same cart around, trying to get rid of the left over food.  Then they suggested we order something off the menu.  Excuse me, isn't this dim sum????  Aren't you supposed to go by with carts overflowing with tasty treats for us to choose from?  What the hell is going on?????

That was it, I asked for the check.  And can you believe, after all that, the three of us left hungry and still ended up with a $46 tab.  For what?????  Sesame balls and dumplings?  You have got to be kidding me.  AND, these cheap bastards charge you for tea!  Have you ever heard of such a thing?  Wow.  Needless to say, we will never eat here again.  

This place is all hype.  Save your time and money and eat at any other dim sum restaurant but this one.
author: Homaira W.

description: When I asked several locals where to go for Dim Sum, they both overwhelmingly responded "Yank Sing". This is where the locals go and has a large business crowd during the week. It is a very nice restaurant vs a quick to go place like many in Chinatown. As a result, expect to pay more but it is so worth it! The food quality is excellent and quick- most of what we wanted made the rounds and when it didn't our server got it for us right away.  The only complaint I would have is that the noise level is pretty high during peak times, but not much more than typical SF restaurants.  Overall I highly recommend!!
author: Laurie B.

description:
The dim sum here was really tasty. I really liked the mushroom dumplings, peking duck and green onion cakes. They seemed kind of pushy as far as giving you additional plates of stuff. Like getting it halfway on the table before even finishing telling you what it is; before you can say yes or no thank you. Granted it also part of the charm of the place...this place is very expensive though. Definitely something for a special occasion. 

Also, considering we were there on an idle, rainy Saturday afternoon and this place was still packed to the brim, if you have a party of more than two or three I would suggest getting a reservation beforehand.
author: Jennifer P.

description: OK dim sum, with tons of fried things and way way way way way over priced food. The xlb (xiao long bao, or dumplings with soup inside) were just OK, definitely not worth the high price. We got about 6 items, two large ones and the rest were smaller things like daikon cake, stuffed mushroom, tried shrimp sticks, etc. For 3 people we were almost full for a total of $80! I guess it's just the SOMA price, because outside of SOMA this stuff much list than that may $20pp at the most. If the service was great then I might be okay coming here, but it's loud, cramped, and the cart with the steamed items kept passing us by. I guess because I was with non-asian people, they assumed that we only wanted fried things and didn't want the sui mai type of stuff?? Meh.
author: Grace L.

description:
Delicious xiao long bao. Probably not spelling it right but the steamed dumplings with pork and soup in them.  Can't get enough of those!

The spinach and shrimp dumplings were great too.

I'd dish out five stars if it wasn't so expensive!
author: Mara S.

description:
This place reminds me of going to a Korean hostess bar. I go buy some drinks, some for the mama sans and some for the ladies. When the bill comes .... Damn those mini shots were ten bucks each?

So my Thai friend never had dim sum in sf, so I go looking it up and we end up here. This place is so classy! I applaud them for the customer service and atmosphere. They are breaking the stereotype all chinese restaurants have bad customer service. But food wise bleh. Food is all sweet. Same flavor profiles. And the food was not hot. Where's my tripe? Where's my tendons? Where's my jook? Diew. The bill was the shocker. 95 bucks. I just got bamboozled. Well at least I had a great time with my friend, just like the hostess bar. Now if only the waitress were as hot as the hostesses. Aye buddy next time we going to east ocean in alameda.
author: Q L.

description:
One of the best dim sum that I've ever had....and also one of the most expensive dim sum I've ever had.

When I am in SF, my family and I love to come here for dim sum. I've been to their other location, but this location is a lot bigger and has more food selection.  If you are in the mood for some fancy dim sum then this is the go to place. 

My favorite dishes here are:
-Peking duck (you can get indiv. portions!)
-Ha Gau: my favorite dim sum dish!
-Pork Siu Mye
-Steamed pork buns
-Stir fried Green beans
-Sautéed snow peas shot: served cold and the sauce on this dish is amazing!
-Red cabbage with orange zest and walnuts: so good!

They also offer soup dumplings here that are pretty good as well. The have traditional dim sum items and also unique items here. Only downside of this place is that it is quite pricey!
author: Phuong K.

description: SHRIMP RICE ROLLZZZ... not too salty not too bland. you'll get full real quick here without knowing it cause the food comes out on the trays so fast.
author: Susan H.

description:
When visiting SF ... if you love Dim Sum ... you have to go to Yang Sing! 
Absolutely Amazing!!!!  The best Dim Sum I have ever had.   The prices are high.. but,
really worth the quality of what you get.   We tried everything and loved it all.  Too many favorites to list them all.   The wait staff was equally amazing!  

LOVE LOVE LOVE this place!!!! Can't wait to eat here again.   Just know that it is pricey ... but well worth it!
author: Suzie Q.

description:
[Featured:  Best Thing I Ever Ate, Food Network]
