Yank Sing does not live up to the price you pay.  Don't get me wrong, it's not bad dim sum, but for the price, you'd expect something special, that extra ummph that this place seems to be lacking.  They've mastered the art of efficient service.  Once you get there, you're innundated by a parade of carts - and why not - they know you're hungry, will likely eat everything in sight, and likely not paying attention to the price.  They're also quick to remove your empty dishes, otherwise you'd notice how much you've eaten or spent.  I'm saying this as a piece of advice to stay aware when you're eating at Yank Sing.  Expect shelling about $75-$80 for a filling lunch for two.  Overall, a decent dim sum place, but does not provide good value.
author: Angel S.

description: All the dishes were on point in taste and quality. Had the stuffed lotus leaf (my fav), shrimp and chive dumpling, bbq pork bun, chicken stuffed mushrooms, and shanghai dumplings. Service was good even though they were busy. Definitely make a reservation here because the wait would have been 45 min without one. This would be 5 stars but I'm giving it 4 since it is pricey. Overall really good place to get dimsum if you want great taste and dont mind the price.
author: Tony W.

description: I am from Minneapolis but visit the bay area several time per year and always make it to Yank Sing.  My wife and I love it and have been coming here since the 1980's.  The quality is extremely high and there is lots of variety.  Some of our favorites are the Shanghai dumplings, sesame balls, steamed buns stuffed with barbecue pork, and the crab claws. It is spendy but worth it.  The down side is that it has absolutely spoiled me for the Dim Sum available here in Minnesota - just can't compare. Ambiance is great.
author: William G.

description:
Since it's Michelin-rated and all, I was expecting greatness.  But sadly, I was disappointed.  I'm not sure if it's because I grew up in SoCal where authentic, good, cheap dim sum was at every corner but Yank Sing just didn't live up to my expectations.  It's definitely good no doubt, but nothing to rave about and spend upwards of $100 on a couple people.  

Good thing the boss paid for this!
author: Jane N.

description: Best dim sum in town! Would give 5 stars but a lil pricy for the amount you get! But the dim sum melts in your mouth!
author: Jamaal B.

description: Love love love this place.  It's not cheap.  It's got high quality, tasty and unique dim sum.  If you love good quality dim sum, and you're up for paying for upscale Chinese food, this is the place.
author: PT B.

description: The best Dim Sum! The most expensive but, well worth it! This is my wife and I's favorite Dim Sum place in the city. Highly recommend it. Try their purple cabbage salad and the seafood basil dumpling, incredible!
author: Kris L.

description:
I had a very disappointing experience at lunch here.  The dim sum was lukewarm and extremely overpriced.  I even pointed out to the person bringing around dim sum that one dish in particular was not warm enough, and she just replaced it with another dish at the same temperature.  When I mentioned it to my server, he said that customers don't like their food that warm.  (It sounded like a lame excuse to me.)  And interestingly, the women at the next table were complaining about the same thing.   Maybe it had to do with the fact that it was almost closing.  We were probably eating food that had been on the floor for a while.

The service (overall) and dining room were nice, and the validated parking was a plus, but I will not be in a hurry to return here.
author: Jane D.

description:
Well now that I've had the best Dim Sum ever, how will I ever go back to Rhode Island and survive without it. HUH?? HOW WILL I DO THAT NOW YANK SING??

This place isn't small or intimate by any means. We went on a weekend, and it expanded out into tables in the mall. In other words it's huge, and the people with their food carts come flying at you the minute you sit down. You want to try this? You want to try that?

Sadly I missed the asparagus wrapped in bacon TWICE because they were so fast, but had the most amazing steamed dumplings and honey bbq pork on this planet and I don't know how I'm going to go back to chinese food here on the east coast.

Is there a support group for dim sum withdrawals?
author: Amuse B.

description:
Went to lunch here with a group. We were quickly seated. Soon after, the carts started rolling by and in short order our table was covered with a wide range of tasty food. Everything I tried was very good. Everything was hot and fresh and service was quick, polite,and informative.

I have been back and it still holds up.  Everything I have tried has been very good.  A typical dimsum room with many steam table moving throughout.

I enjoyed it very much and I will return.
author: Mark D.

description: So good we went twice during a three day visit to SF. Fresh, delicate and delicious dim sum.
author: Lori C.

description:
Beautiful restaurant....easy parking in Rincon Center. Food is outstanding. We had the pork buns with vinegar and ginger....wow and explosion of tastes. Shrimp dumplings filled with shrimp...not just a wimpy few pieces. Everything we had was great....

Expensive by dim sum standards but worth the experience.
author: Mack T.

description:
I've eaten at Yank Sing several times but this is the first time I've taken the time to write a review.  I took out of town guests from the mid west who'd never had dim sum before and they loved it.  I'm Chinese and I know dim sum well.  I give them 5 stars because their food is excellent, service is excellent, and provide a superior dining experience when it comes to dim sum.  Yes you can go to any tea house and have decent dim sum and pay a lot less, but if you want a fine dining experience and not to just get fed dim sum, then this is where you want to go.  

Those who complain about the prices are not comparing apples with apples.  My husband and I eat out a lot.  Often it is just to get fed in which case, we go for good tasting food at budget friendly prices.  Other times, we want to have a nice meal, or if it is a special occasion, we go to nicer restaurants and expect to pay more.  Yank Sing should be compared with other fine dining experiences price-wise, not the hole-in-the-walls.  It is expensive to run a restaurant right (I'm from a restaurant family and practically grew up in a restaurant) and I think Yank Sing knows how to run a business.  The restaurant is clean, their staff are friendly and attentive and don't seem rushed and frazzled, and the food is delicious.  Just because it is a Chinese restaurant doesn't mean that it should be cheap!

I almost forgot to mention that they have underground parking and they validate!  I came on a weekday and parking would have cost $18 but it was free because of the validation.
author: C. W.

description:
We held our wedding banquet here and absolutely loved it! We booked through Daisy in Sales, and she was helpful, fun, and professional. We e-mailed her a lot of questions since we don't live locally, and she was timely in her responses and also had some great suggestions!
On the day itself, everything went smoothly, and we and all of our guests were blown away by both the attentiveness and professionalism of the staff, and also the food quality. 
You will pay more than a traditional Chinese banquet in Chinatown, but the price increase is well worth it for the venue, food, service, and designated parking garage.
author: Angelique F.

description:
A true Parisian will tell you that in order for a French restaurant be truly French, it must serve both frog legs and horse meat. If in fact this BOLD statement is true, then we Americans have a bone to pick wtih Hubert Keller.

I admit I have never been to China, nor have I even really traveled anywhere in Asia (Does a 27 hour lay over in Seoul count?). But with Linsanity in full swing, I just had to have a "real" Chinese lunch. But for someone like me who is not wise when it comes to what to look for to find "real" Chinese I just hit what's closest to my office.

I've been to Yank Sing several times over the last five years, and each time I come away feeling like something is missing. It used to drive me batty, and could never quite put my finger on it until last week. 

What's missing is money from my wallet. This place is expensive! It seems to me what you pay for is ambiance (which is nice) and real estate (located in the heart of what the Occupiers hate most). The food is good, but is their dim dum really that much better than what I can find in San Bruno? San Mateo or even Santa Clara? I

Nice place for an office party, but if you are looking for something that will knock your socks off at a decent price you may want to keep walking.
author: V B.

description: This is by far my most favorite Dim Sum place. I've been here a couple times when the lines were long and the wait was for hours. But let me tell you, no matter how hungry I am and how long the wait is. I WILL WAIT- IT'S WELL WORTH IT. The place is clean, the staff is attentive & the Dim Sum is AMAZING! I never leave unhappy or hungry. Just writing this has my mouth watering.
author: Lainey L.

description:
First off I hate line ups, but it's always a good sign of good food.  Lots of locals lining up for the food, and overheard many of them saying good things about Yang Sing.  The wait was about 30 minutes or so, and the place was PACKED, but service was fast and "friendly rushed"  Food was very good and drinks were cold, what more can you ask for.

Wish I was spending more time in SFO, as I would have liked to have gone back and try other items on the menu.
author: Wade V.

description: Went there today for lunch. The good: the service and the ambiance is very good. The staff is trained well as they were very attentive and we didn't have to wait long for the food. The bad: the food is mediocre and the price is slightly outrageous. I wouldn't mind paying $125 per person if the food was good. We ordered 8 dishes and two stood out... The pecking duck and some sort of chicken dish. But the dumplings are a disappointment. If you want Americanized dim sum and good decor then you might enjoy Yank Sing. If you want to eat good dim sum then Hong Kong lounge is definitely better. Koi palace is tastier too.
author: Lians S.

description:
I've read many reviews on Yank Sing and when I knew I had to entertain a party of four I decided to take them here for a Sunday brunch. I saw Grace K's review and she gave it 5 stars so I knew I had to experience it.
Yank Sink is known for there dim sum and it's lavish, spacious, eating area and it is quite impressive. When you see the interior in the Rincon center you will find many waitors and waitresses being polite and offering trays of delicious dim sum.

Ordered the follow:
Potstickers: wrapped Pork dumplings-flavorful. Not greasy.

Pork soup dumplings: dumpling with a pork filling and filled with soup. You can add red wine vinegar sauce for additional flavor.

Sui mai: pork with a dumpling wrapper, full of flavor, not grissley and not greasy. I have had greasy sui mai before and my stomach did not appreciate it.

Honey walnut prawns: prawns in a white sauce very yummy with candied walnuts.

Gai-lon: green vegetables sauteed. Nothing special

Peking Duck. This was one piece of moist duck with the plum sauce and the soft flour bun. Flavorful, just one piece per person though.

After all of this I still had room for dessert. I ordered the mango sorbet that was light, colorful and very yummy. I was suprised with the bill, it was approximately $88.00 for four people. Not bad, I thought it was going to be over $100.00. I will definitely be back to try other specialties. Plus my parking $10.00 was validated. Very Nice.
author: Jim D.

description: They have prices themselves out of the market!  The labor costs of doing dim sum is substantial but when it costs over $40 for a few dim sum for lunch per person...it had better be Fook Lam Moon!  The price is like $2 per piece and that is too much for regular hargaw, sui mai, etc.  I hate to say it...but most all are frozen beforehand as I glimpsed into their commissary on Spear Street where the cooks were taking a break and saw them pulling out what look like pizza boxes, which got my attention but they were all flat boxes of dim sum lined up frozen in rows and rows....ready for the steamer.  How good can it be if it was frozen first and at those prices...never going back!
author: Gregory C.

description:
I must admit, I was kind of intrigued about yank sing since I saw it aired on the food network. Chris Consentino made a comment that the best pork he has ever had was from here. Apparently Yank Sing is home to some spectacular Char Siu Bau (baked bbq pork buns) Well, it just so happened that a friend was having a birthday the very next week at Yank Sing.  

To keep the story short (sorry, I have a short attention span) I made it a point to try the buns. The bbq pork buns were ok... don't think I would rank it anywhere near the best pork I have ever had that's for sure. I think us Filipinos are picky about your pork. As for the rest of the food, it was good. The dim sum was fresh to order and came out piping hot. Service was very attentive, and the restaurant itself was quite fancy. 

Like many have stated though, this place is EXPENSIVE. I mean seriously... for dim sum? how much?
author: Steven T.

description:
I ate here during a company lunch and it was just down the street.  Yank Sing definitely appeals to an older generation of businessmen.  I'm sure they made good food back in the day, but have since, been commercialized.  The one thing that is likely still the same?  Their chili sauce.  Its amazing.  But other than that, their dim sum really falls short of today's expectations in the Chinese community.  You're also overpaying for what you'll get at a lower end dim sum joint. 

Even funnier is that I understood what exactly the waiters were saying in Cantonese and lets say its a bit more than derogatory to their own customers.  I had a good time with good company, but their food and price cannot compare to the new wave of Chinese restaurants that is Asian Pearl, Saigon Seafood, Chef's Wok among many others.
author: David O.

description: Dim Sum can be an offensive experience but this place is completely non-offensive. The dumplings are fresh and always tasty. I highly recommend the sesame rolls. We also enjoyed mango pudding and orange jello (I mean, how many times is jello listed on any food menu? One just has to get it). Possibly the best sea bass I've ever enjoyed. Fresh and tasty bok choi. The major catastrophic downside - the price. Unless you have deep pockets or are up for splurging, don't come here. It was $100 for two people, with two modest appetites and we didn't get any booze. But, if you can deal with the cost - this is a great option and you won't be disappointed.
author: Natasha J.

description:
Yup, it's expensive, but IMO you do get what you pay for.  Yank Sing has probably the best service I've ever had for dim sum (and Chinese restaurants in general).  My water glass was never less than halfway full (and I drink a lot of water!), they've passed this benchmark test with flying colors that many fine dining places I've been to have failed.  Whenever there was a specific dish that we wanted, if we asked a nearby cart, they would radio the cart that had what we were looking for to come over.

All the dishes were great, but the highlights for me were the xiao long bao, peking duck, beef rice noodles, fried taro, and egg tarts.  For the three of us, the bill wound up being over $100, which is pricey for a Chinese restaurant, but similar to what we would probably spent if we ate at a nice French restaurant.  I think that for the quality of the food and the service, it's totally worth it.  Can't wait to come back!
author: Arlene M.

description: Extremely overpriced dim sum for what you get.  The food isn't bad, but it's also not spectacular.  We ended up paying $~50/person when I usually pay $15-20/person for the same amount of food!!  I saw the egg custards are listed at $12 for 3 or 4 on the menu.  Ridiculous.  At such prices this place should have food that tastes just like the quality in HK, but sadly, it does not.  The service was also horrendous and my friend had to yell at them repeatedly in Cantonese for us to get any food or tea.  Save your money and go elsewhere.
author: Christina C.

description:
DO NOT EAT HERE!  I've been to Yank Sing many times but now after learning that the owners were underpaying their employees and demanding unpaid hours of work from them, plus taking their tips, I will never eat here again.

Each meal is insanely expensive compared to other Dim Sum restaurants (even other fancy ones), so it is truly appalling that these added profits were not even somewhat shared with their employees.

Do not eat here and support this unjust business!!! You can read about the case here: 
http://m.sfgate.com/living/article/The-dim-sum-revolution-6177566.php
author: Teresa H.

description: Very good dim sum.  Very expensive dim sum.  4 star for food, 2 star for price, therefor 3 star overall.  Did I say its expensive?
author: Tim A.

description: Overpriced Amercanized dim sum. Don't get me wrong, it's good food, it's just not the same as good authentic dim sum. $75 for two people is a bit ridiculous, but the Xiao Long Baos are very good, the food isn't as greasy, and the quality is commendable. There's free parking with validation! Don't park on the street and pay meter every hour!
author: Judy L.

description:
These stars are for the xiao long bao (shanghai dumplings) and nothing else. These XLBs were goooood. But it goes downhill after this...

My number one pet-peeve about restaurants is an underestimation on the wait-time. We were quoted 25-35 minutes, and of course, we waited an hour plus.

The dim sum was cold, salty, and the flavors were not very good. 

Also, it's pretentious, overcrowded and wayyy overpriced for dimsum. Definitely go elsewhere.
author: Lynn C.

description:
UPDATE:
I came here today for Easter Sunday dim sum and it was jam packed.
I especially enjoyed the steamed mushroom dumplings and xiao long baos. Actually there is quite a selection of vegetarian dim sum served here such as pea sprouts dumpling and spinach dumpling. 
The service is good too -- if you don't see the dish you want, just ask one of the staff members to get it for you.
------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
While the dim sum is good here, the egg custard tarts are superb! Clean ambience with good service but definitely on the more expensive side.
author: Helen Y.

description:
Recently went to SF. Decided to give Yank Sing a try after much rav reviews. My impression, mediocre. There is a disconnect between the price they charged and the corresponding quality. For their signature dish, kurobuta pork dumpling, aka shao long bao priced at $12.95 for 6, it was ridiculous. It's even more expensive than the world renowned Din Tai Fung. This dish is known for the thin yet resilient dough to hold the broth within the dumpling. Yang Sing version was the Chinese version of piggy in a blanket, except the blanket is for the harsh Siberia winter! The poor piggy is most probably suffocating in the blankie. If I wanted to eat dough, I will just go buy some SF Sourdough bread and be happier eating that. A hallmark for this Shanghai delicacy is that the dumpling form a pear shape when pick up with the chopsticks, when is the laying flat in the steam basket, the centre of the dumpling is surrounded by a brothy perimeter within the dough, and as you pick it up, the broth moved to the bottom, if it breaks, it's bad craftsmanship, My late father would have tossed it away and send it back. Also you can count the folds, which should be about 18. I will have no problem if this is just one of Yank sing regular item for $8 pr $9, for this to be a signature item, it failed miserably! It is what it is, a terrible rendition of the traditional shao long bao. Dough too thick, not enough broth, # failed! For the other less famous items, Yank  Sing was actually half decent, the Har Gow, the Peking duck( a steam bao instead of the crepe but quite tasty I must say) and the shrimp rice noodle roll was all legit! The rice noodle roll reminded me the way HK dim sum chef pulled their's noodle  from the steam cloth, it was really good! But the misguided self proclaimed signature steam pork dumpling has left much to be desired. It was supermarket frozen food quality but for $12.95! At the very least put some crab roe and meat in it, that way Yank sing could at least commend that kind of price point. I know I am repeating myself, but that dough was thick enough to keep me warm on the golden gate ferry cruise. 

SF deserves better than that, to call Yank Sing a must go dim Sum place indicates how deprive people in SF are from good traditional dim sum, if you don't speak up, then mediocrity is all you are going to get! I understand they have been in business for 60 yr with three generations of the Chan family at the helm, but regardless of how many generations or how many decades you are in business, doing something bad for that long is not going to make it better. It just 60 yrs worth of crabbiness in this signature dish. My last name is also Chen, my family are from Shaghai and I am born and raised in Hong Kong, and now lived in Toronto. We have over at the minimum 100 years between 3 generations tasting shao long  bao, we are no experts just ordinary folks that take their old country food seriously. Yank Sing, please don't insult my palette and intelligence by calling these pretenders shao long bao! If your chefs don't have the chops to do this properly, take it off the menu and no one will blame you.
author: R's C.

description:
Very very very good dimsum!
Probably the best in the city, at least, a mon avis.
Defnitely better than anything you can get in Hawaii, trust me, I've already tried them all!
Service is very good--staff wears headphones to communicate to each other, not to mention how many staff members there are-- every sunday must be like preparing for war for them.

Paring is weird, its really cramped if you go up the ramp, so DONT go up the ramp!!! Once you've past the ramp its all downhill from there, you basically need a smartcar to fit in any parking stall.

Price: Def. on the most expensive side of any resto for dimsum.

Plus: they have a full-service bar.

Sundays they expand into the lobby taking over, theres a pretty cool suspended waterfall its from floor-ceiling.

Tip: Call and make a reservation, exactly when you decide you want dimsum, even 30 minutes before, and they will instantly bump you up & help you cut in line!!
author: Ash R.

description:
Simply awesome.

I am giving it four stars simply because it cost more than double to eat here as it does at comparable Dim Sum Establishments.

If you are used to everyone paying between $16-22 per person you are going to end up paying $40+ dollars per person here.
author: Keith A.

description:
I love the service here. It probably has the best service compared to all the other dim sum places. The ladies that push the carts know their english and are super polite. When you ask for something they immediately radio it over to the kitchen, then bring it to you immediately.

On the side of food, it's good food but not great. Weighing the cost and tastiness, cost is high. Super high. However the xiao long bao's are really good.
author: Vanessa K.

description: Yank sing is always delicious though if on the expensive side. Their pork buns are divine as are all of their dumplings.
author: Rachel E.

description:
Dim Sum is a hit and miss topic.  I didn't necessarily dislike this place, but I also didn't like it.  Hence, the 3 stars.  

Here are a few hits:

1) dim sum servers were very responsive to putting in your request in the "dim sum  realm" even if they're not carrying the particular item you're craving for.
2) my water was always filled.
3) dumplings were so meaty and tasty you couldn't have just one serving.
4) Jasmine tea was delicious and very fragrant.

Here are the misses:

1) a little bit pricey for dim sum.
2) do not order the Shanghai Dumpling.  I was a fool to point, nod, and smile at the server.  $12+ for 6 pieces of kurobuta pork dumplings that stick to the container.  That pretty much ruined the whole fun... NO THANKS!  
3) I noticed that they hide the menus with the price of the dim sum under the table sheets, and I took  that as being deceitful.  I almost pointed to a swordfish until I found out it was $16... yeah... I don't think so.

This place is great if you're looking for something quick around the Embarcardero area, but otherwise, better save your appetite for Chinatown or Koi Palace in Daly City!

Here's what we ordered:
- Shanghai Dumplings --- SKIP IT!
- Scallop and Shrimp Dumplings ---- DO IT!
- Pork and Shrimp Dumplings ----- DO IT!!!
- Chicken Feet ---- DO IT!!!
- Sauteed Green Beans ---- SKIP IT!!! (too salty and oily for my taste!)
- Pork Ribs in Beans ---- SKIP IT!!! (not great.  it's all pork fat with no taste)
author: Anne D.

description: Despite what some have written about this restaurant, it is an outstanding place for dim sum. The service was super friendly and no wait time for a Saturday morning! The Shanghai dumplings were a culinary delight and is what distinguishes this restaurant from the rest. It was pricey for dim sum but well worth the money spent. The sesame balls were the best I've ever had, made with sweet potato and lotus seed. And the custard cups were also the very best. If you want to dine in dim sum heaven, make your way to Yank Sing and I'm sure you will be satiated.
author: Alex C.

description:
Located inside the Rincon Center.  Dim sum lines can be a bit long on the weekends if you don't show up pretty early.  I say you have to be there by 11am otherwise there will be a crowd by noon.  On the weekends, they have more feature food items.  Shanghai dumplings are so tasty with that soup inside.  I like the typical dim sum dumplings as well.  Weekdays, the choices are limited.  Oh no one can say no to their egg tarts, it is like $2.50 each, but think of the cost of getting authentic French macaroons from Laduree or Pierre Herme.  BTW New York City has a Laduree so you don't need to go all the way to Paris for French Macaroons now.

I go there often on weekday and weekends.
They have another location at 49 Stevenson as well.

Our wedding banquet was here.  Our guest list was so big that our party there many years ago was outside of the restaurant premises and on Rincon Center grounds.  They served excellent 8 dish wedding banquet menus if you like shark fin soup and almond flavor bird's nest for dessert.  The dragon and phoenix cold platter was awesome in presentation and the selected cold cuts were the best of the best there is unless you are having this party in Hong Kong.  They did a good job, the lobster came whole in a pair for each banquet table, that's the point, it is about the newly weds.  Some restaurants will fail to do that over price and cost.

We had a chocolate fountain and traditional candies/sweets to accommodate Chinese and American taste.  The restaurant was really cool in giving us a dance floor after the banquet dinner.  We brought in our own MC and DJ.  We had a video of us from childhood to marriage explaining how our lives entwined with modern love songs playing in the background.

Very tiring with so much entertaining to do and all dress up, had to change outfits three times. The bridal room was a short walk and easy to get to, it was really a converted private dining room of the restaurant.  The wedding party entered the premises in our western wedding outfits upon introduction.  We changed into the traditional Chinese wedding attires with the restaurant being able to provide a stage set up for us to have our tea ceremony for both sides of the family with all of our guests as witness to our wedding.  Lots of walking to each table to show our appreciation to our guests for coming to our wedding and taking pictures.

The wedding party was too distant from the guests.  We had to use large screen tv/monitors for those who sat further way from the wedding party.
author: Esme W.

description: Came here on Christmas Eve for lunch and it was extremely busy but the food and service were outstanding. Best dim sum in San Francisco bar none!
author: Jonathan A.

description:
Solid, delicious tasting Dim Sum. Only problem here is, it's SO expensive! All dim sum items are at least $4 and most of them range from $4-$7... Although it is so expensive, food is good - at least they're not serving crappy & expensive food. 

The XLB (Xiao Long Bao) here is excellent - like many other Yelpers have mentioned, this is definitely one of the best that I have had in the Bay Area. So if you like XLB, come here for that. 

Between my boyfriend and I, we had the XLB, Siu Mai, Shrimp Dumpling (Ha Gow), Black Bean Spareribs, Turnip Cake, and Chinese Broccoli w/Oyster Sauce. We didn't even order that much and our bill w/tip came out to around $70. YIKES! 

With that said, I would probably come back to Yank Sing if there was an occasion or I wanted to stop by for a tea and snack (the proper way they eat dim sum in HK). Luckily the bf and I weren't too hungry on this visit, but if we were to order dim sum in the amount we usually do, we would've gone broke! (well, not exactly broke, but ya know what I mean) But if you haven't tried it out, don't be scared to - all of the dishes were very tasty and cooked properly. I also love their Yank Sing chili sauce!
author: Tiffany K.

description:
I've visited Yank Sing twice in my visits out to the Bay Area, mainly because I'm a huge fan of soup dumplings and I read that they were the best there in the area. They are delicious - and far better than any of the soup dumplings I've had back in the New York area - but they're also a bit pricey ($11 for a crate of 6!)...not really the best deal when you can get better-tasting soup dumplings at Kingdom of Dumpling for half the price.

Nevertheless, the quality of the dumplings, along with the rest of the dim sum, is better than most. If I had to put a word on the cuisine, I'd call it 'gourmet dim sum', particularly given the price. The bill has run about $60 for 2 people on both occasions that I've gone, and I can't really say that the quality of the food is appreciably better than the dim sum I could get in New York's or Philly's Chinatown and would cost half as much. It's certainly more upscale, is clean, and has carts with everything on the menu on the floor, but I have to dock it a star simply because I don't think the quality justifies the price.

The service is very organized, and I'm a fan of the large pot of tea they bring out for the table. It's a nice place for a laid-back weekend lunch, but if you're really hungry you might burn a larger hole in your wallet than you expect.
author: Asuka N.

description:
I really enjoy this place! It's been good for many many years and is always consistently tasty and fresh. It seems to have moved locations in the past, so if you haven't been in a while, make sure you check the directions.

I love the Dim Sum, the Peking Duck is also great, but the Not Too Miss Item is the Sea Bass (maybe Miso Glazed....not exactly sure what they call it, but it is Really Good).

I don't think you can go wrong with Yank Sing!

Yum Yum
author: Millard M.

description:
my fav dim sum restaurant in SF. I know the price is a bit high but you get what you pay for. The quality of food is undeniable and cannot be compared to Chinatown dim sum because they use crappy cheap ingredients. I do not like to chew on fat mixed with little meat in my pork dumpling and thick chewy skin while enjoying my shrimp dumpling. I love love love the xiao long bao here. I can probably eat a dozen to myself easily. 

I lived and been to China before so i know what good dim sum is. This is good dim sum!
author: Amy L.

description: We arrived around 11:45 am for lunch and were seated immediately.  The carts were passing by steadily but we did not feel rushed to make selections.  All of the dishes were hot from the steamer or fryer.  The only dish we had which was fried was a shrimp dish and it wasn't greasy.  They tiny sliver of meat you get on the Peking duck dish though does not justify the $9 price tag for that plate!!  We also ordered several items which were not on the carts and those came promptly.  We enjoyed our tea and they refreshed the pot nicely along with having a selection of several teas to chose from.
author: Willanne W.

description: I am a passionate of this place. Food 5stars but price is highly exaggerate . Love the service and easy to get a reservation .
author: Marta M.

description:
Passing through San Francisco twice over the past week, I returned to Yank Sing twice; once with new friends and once with my wife.  A third visit would have been better.  

On a Sunday afternoon, Yank Sing was hopping and there was a one-hour wait.  (Note to self: plan ahead!)  Just before noon on Friday, we were seated quickly but had we arrived 30 minutes later, we would have waited.

On each visit, the service was was steady with little opportunity for hunger or boredom.  Women pushing carts streamed by offering their steamed and fried offerings with explanations if required.  Between the two visits, I enjoyed broccoli, snow peas, shrimp siu mye, potstickers, the magnificent Phoenix tailed shrimp and their signature Shanghai dumpling.

Are there other places in San Francisco that offer food as excellent for less?  I don't know...this is the only dim sum I've enjoyed in SF for 30 years.  I'll be back as soon as I can.
author: Doctor B.

description:
YANK SING! OMG best Tasting DIM SUM I've EVER HAD!!!! 

but why the three star? here we go!

A little refresh that I dont just eat out for food :D Eating out for me is the whole experience with FOOD, AMBIANCE, SERVICE and PRICE.

FOOD: DELICIOUS! Everything taste super fresh! We had our dim sum usual, su mai, hagowr, sao long bao ( soup dumpling), Shrimp rice noodle, etc and man the flavor is perfect! Especially the sao long bao, OMG the soupiest sao long bao EVER! and the wrapper is strong enough that it doesn't  burst, you can see the soup just sitting in there waiting to be sip! OMG so good! 

AMBIANCE: typical fancy Chinese Restaurant kinda thing. I went to the one located in the big financial building, it feel kinda random. But overall average upscale setting good for lunch meeting or if you wanna impress your gf family. It's clean :D

SERVICE: Good service in compare to many Chinese restaurant, working as CSR for some time in my younger year, I'm quite the stickler for service. They didn't fail me, they are tentative, but then again it's hard to said when the restaurant is not busy, that's when everything change. They had tea in the fancy big glass kettle :D that was nice, but it might the part of the reason why they are so pricey!

PRICE: EXPENSIVE!!! Never Have I EVEr (this might be cause i'm from small city like San Diego) SEen a portion of su mai with four pieces that cus me $6:50 like OMG for Real??/!!? and everything else is price at that range $6.50 - $15 per portion. A person like me normally order 5 dishes that's like $30-$40 easy! for one person? OMG so yea good to try once, unless your pocket is loaded or if you wanna impress someone, this is too PRICEY for Dim SUM.
author: NIkki L.

description:
A San Francisco dynasty for more than 50 years, Yank Sing is still a dim sum favorite.

Tuned for the Western palette, dishes are not strictly authentic, but delicious nevertheless.  All items boast high quality ingredients and are fresh and light, rather than heavy and greasy as at some lesser establishments.

Pork buns ($4.50) are fluffy and tasty. Light and sweet, the shrimp dumplings ($5.50) are so good they disappear before your eyes. Perfectly executed, Peking duck ($5.25) is moist and tender with nicely crispy skin. Filled with shrimp, barbecued pork, or beef, the steamed rice noodle rolls ($7.30) are a treat.

Yank Sing even raises the bar on condiments. Eschewing the ubiquitous chili paste, Yank sing provides a slightly smoky chili pepper sauce that is delightfully hot with just the right amount of sweetness.

Service is polite and friendly. Most wait staff speak at least a little English and are happy to accommodate special requests. They even wear head sets and microphones to quickly convey orders directly to the kitchen.  Sunday brunch can be overwhelmingly busy, so for a more peaceful dining experience opt for a less popular time.

Americanized or not, for a taste of Hong Kong dim sum save your air fare and go to Yank Sing.
author: CJ G.

description:
It was good dim sum, but not anything fantastic.  Nor was it worth the price.  As the two-star description literally translates, "Meh.  I've experienced better."

Obviously, this caters to those who prefer a quieter, less hectic dim sum experience.  You can enjoy your meal peacefully with family and friends (in my case, friends I had studied abroad with and hadn't seen in over 6 months) as long as the bill doesn't bother you!  And I was pleasantly surprised that this place had chicken feet, my all-time dim sum favorite!  I was under the impression that this place was rather Americanized, but I was wrong!

Heads up; parking is a pain.  We went into the garage which was valet only for visitors, and then when I went to validate my ticket IN THE RESTAURANT, the lady loudly and rudely said, "Four dollars."  WHAT?  Why is a parking validation in the business I just spent a ton of money to eat in demanding MORE money?  In the end, not worth the money.  I'll take an energetic, noisy dim sum restaurant in the heart of Chinatown over this place anyday.
author: Addi M.

description:
well, i really liked the food.  came here after a long night out, and i didn't think i was craving dim sum, but... after getting seated, i was DEF ready to eat.

obviously the service was fast because people are coming around in carts.  there was a waiter going around asking us if he could get us something right away, though, which is cool.

we ate a decent amount between the four of us (three girls and one guy).  when i eat dim sum with my family at other places, we usually spend at MOST 40 dollars.  here, we somehow spent ~75 dollars.  i don't really know how it happened

don't think i'll be coming back again, but it was quick and convenient!
author: Jennifer L.

description:
Dim sum for snacksgiving? Why, yes!
Location kind of threw me off a little bit, it's in a food court, inside of an office building, that happens to have a waterfall-ish fountain that falls from the sky. Weird.

ANYWAY. Food was really good. Service was excellent. If you wanted something the lady didn't have, she called some other lady and BAM, it was at your table. Kind of pricier than what I'm used to... but I think it's well worth it!
author: So H.

description:
Yank Sing is a pretty solid choice when it comes to Dim Sum.....who would have thunk it? Financial district? Corporate water garden establishment? to host an amazing quality establishment like Yank Sing....why not. And man was it crowded when we had X-mas day lunch here! It was very convenient for us, since we were staying at the Hotel Vitale, literally 1/2 block a way. Try to sit inside...they have open seating in the Atrium on the weekends.

 The staff here are ALL very nice and helpful...(mainly because they want a FAST and SPEEDY turn around..especially when there are 40 families waiting outside to get seated - but at the same time, you don't fee RUSHED). They expedite everything out HOT, well prepared, without skipping a beat on quality. If there was anything  that I was looking for, our server Nancy was on top of it. She ran into the kitchen to retrieve anything that we couldn't see rolling around the restaurant..

Highlights:

- Having your own hot mustard and chili sauce dispenser at your own table. Fuckin Genius! 
- The tea is very good...they are always on top of it. 
- Shanghai Soup Dumplings (5 star)
- Taro Dumpling (5 star)
- Spinach Dumpling (2 star)
- Chicken, Shrimp, Pork, and Seafood Dumpling (4 star) - all staples but were good nevertheless
- Peking Duck (5 star)
- Shrimp Rice Noddle (5 star)
- Turnip Cake (4 star)
- Egg tart (5 star)

Hidden Secret - the Blood Mary was excellent (5 star)
One draw back...it's not priced like your typical Dim Sum establishment (either here or in Hong Kong)....plan on spending between $80-$100 per couple to have an enjoyable meal.
author: Master B.

description:
Overpriced dim sum. The place was certainly better than most dim sum restaurants. Communicating with the server isn't a problem as well (it happened to me several times that my servers in dim sum restaurants do not speak English). Having said that, the food was not the best. The peking duck was okay and so fried shrimp, pork bun and veggies. The xiao long bao was notably bad. It was really dry. The sesame ball, which made 7x7 Big Eat List, was alright but I had much better sesame balls in other places. The best thing out of all will be the xiu mai but that was about it.

When I pay $40+/person for dim sum, I expected the food to be amazing (considering most dim sum places are not expensive), the table to be slightly larger (so the food doesn't have to be stacked like Tiny Tower) and more space between table.
author: Cliff T.

description: Food was good. Their pork buns was amazing though. Everything else was alright. Their service could be better.
author: Miguel P.

description: I was utterly disappointed with the temperature of the dishes. I have been to a number of Dim Sum places here in US and around the world but found this place to be the most disappointing. We have the special Peking Duck along with the typical Siu Mai and Shanghai Dumplings and the other regulars. A good Shanghai dumpling is served hot on the inside and this one is barely warm. That goes for all the food - including the Peking Duck. You don't pay $6.50 for a piece of cold Peking Duck that is being shuttled around in that Dim Sum cart. Brought this up to the Manager of the restaurant and all he said was he will talk to his chefs. It has nothing to do with the Chefs but the way you operate those carts to make sure that the food is served hot. If you like cold or warm Dim Sum at best, Yank Sing is the place to go.
author: Turino F.

description: Overprice OK dim sum.  I thought it was a nice place to have dim sum, outside spacious and awesome.   However the food did not match the environment.   Every dim was a bit cold which is weird since we order it.  Must have been sitting out a bit before server actually served it.  Dim sum all small portion looking.  I'm not impress. I had better hot dim sum at hole in the wall places.
author: Tee K.

description:
A) you either need to get here at 11am when they open or make a reservation. 
B) Holy moly bring an empty stomach! 

If you love dim sum, this place will blow your mind. Do not leave without trying the pork bun dumpling, shrimp har gow, shu mai and even the steamed broccoli is to die for. I have yet to order something I did not finish and every person I have ever brought here becomes a loyal fan. 

It is pricey as far as dim sum goes, but Yank Sing has been a staple in SF dim sum for over 20 years and there is a reason they charge so much. You get what you pay for.
author: B D.

description:
Yank Sing has some truly great dim sum, and while the price is higher than you would pay at most dim sum restaurants, it's not at all unreasonable for the quality of the food. 

As others have mentioned, the soup dumplings are not to be missed. Other standouts for me were the perfectly crispy shrimp spring rolls and the Szechuan chicken.
author: Ben G.

description: I came here for lunch with relatives and three other families during San Francisco trip. I liked how there are two parts to the restaurant: the indoor and the outdoor seating which is centered inside an open aired building. When you're seated, carts come to your table with a selection of food which I thought was cool. Their food was delicious; the dumplings, the siumai, their Peking duck, their sesame seed balls, were all superb. One thing that really surprised me was how much our check was. There were about thirteen people in my party but the bill came out to more than $400 and I thought it was ridiculous. We didn't even order a lot of food. I guess people weren't kidding when they said this is place is pricey, but it was worth it in my opinion.
author: Kim O.

description: Quite a simple yet lovely experience: the plates are yummy, quite traditional. We came for Xmas dinner/lunch so they take over the atrium an it feels overwhelming, once we sat down the carts kept on coming. Word of advise: 1) be patient, don't fall for the first few carts and request what you want, they will send it your way, 2) it feels expensive but it's a nice experience, its located in the financial district ($), and they do it better than the average Chinese joint; its clean, cordial service. We had a blast, take your time eating and sip some tea (jasmine tea is delicious), chit chat a take a break between plates.
author: Carlos L.

description:
Busy for a friday lunchtime around 1. The wait time was about 30 mins and there was a line. We were starving by the time we got our table. Get there early! The restaurant extends to the outside in the middle of building it is in.

Food- a variety of dim sums. 
siew mai- ok
scallop kabobs- the scallop in the middle was good
lotus leaf wrapped glutinous rice- flavorful and delicious
crab cakes- has real crab, interesting flavor
fried crab balls- ok

jasmine tea- good

Service- waitress forgot my taro balls! bOo. But overall was ok service.

Price- definitely more expensive than many other dim sum restaurants.

I'm not sure if I want to come back for the wait. I expected better dim sum and it wasn't worth the drive if I were to come back.
author: Crystal H.

description: The Service is better, the selection is larger, more refined and sophisticated in their other location, but this location is fine if you don't have the time to make it to Spear Street.it is perfect if you want good dim sum without having to wonder further afield.
author: Steven C.

description:
as y'all know or probably figured out, there are two types of dim sum in san francisco (actually everywhere, but whatevs). one on hand you've got the cheap, hole in the wall place that's super asian but as authentic as they come. and on the other you've got the zagat/michelin rated, clean, classy dim sum that's authentic, but only to a certain degree because of the sky high prices. one guess as to which category yank sing falls into!

now don't get me wrong, the dim sum here is delish. everything is wheeled by the tables on a cart, and you can choose what you'd like based on what you see. i looooove the xiao loong baos (soup dumplings), daan tat (egg tart), and the pae don jook (preserved egg and pork porridge) they serve here. the waiters are super friendly and attentive. each time you take a dish, they stamp your order paper. keep track of what you order, because the stamps and price level are def not shown on the paper, and before you know it you've got an order sheet with colorful dots all over it that you can't decipher for the life of you.

the restaurant is located in the Rincon Center by Embarcadero, which offers a spectacular view of the city. the restaurant space itself is open at 10 am. at 11 am, the restaurant expands outside to the middle terrace. my family usually sits outside, because the ambience is so nice.

but back to the pricy. for a family of 5, we managed to rack up 250 dollars worth of dim sum. compared to this, we usually eat about $80 worth at a hole in the wall. nothing wrong against yank sing, but it's definitely classified in my book as a luxury dim sum excursion, and there are DEFINITELY places in san francisco you can find the same dim sum for a cheaper price (but a not so good ambience).
author: Caitlin C.

description:
Why is it so hard to find good dim sum?  
Anyhow, I love my dumplings and my egg custard tarts.  Heard this was one of the best dim sum places in SF.  It was pretty tasty.  I don't think it was THE BEST I've ever had in my life - but my dad used to make some good dim sum - so I guess I have my standards set too high.
author: Julia J.

description: Very decent dim sum in the Financial District.  Nothing stellar to write home about.  we enjoyed the har gow, chicken feet and steamed bbq pork buns.  Again, very standard dim sum items.  We thought the shrimp rice rolls were not that great as the wrapper was falling apart instead of having a slippery elasticity to them.  Yes, it is pretty pricey for a dim sum restaurant.  You are paying for location and western style service.  I can appreciate that.
author: Jenn N.

description: Just..... wow! My boyfriend and I visited the city this weekend and went to Yank Sing for brunch with friends. The steamed pork buns and pot-stickers were incredible. San Francisco is obviously known for having wonderful food, but what also makes Yank Sing unique is its location. The Rincon Center is a beautiful building and the fountain was gorgeous! We will be back on our next trip.
author: Karley J.

description: Not that I really need to review this, as it's a San Francisco institution. But had lunch here recently and it was wonderful. Soupiest XLB dumplings ever, yet nearly unbreakable. Outstanding walnut shrimp. Good selection of vegetable dishes. Fairly rapid and helpful service for a dim sum restaurant. Main drawback is the line during normal mealtimes, but we managed to get a table for two at 1 pm on a Thursday with no problem. There is also a takeout shop next door, which I have not tried.
author: Cage H.

description:
Yes it's overpriced, yes it's Americanized, and yes a couple of dishes were not very good. That being said, it was still the best dim sum I've ever had and I'm looking forward to going back soon.

I've had dim sum many times, and never really enjoyed it. The only reason I kept trying it was because so many of my friends love dim sum. It's very trendy, but I've never been a fan of the food, poor service, or questionable cleanliness. The food is typically too bland or too salty and too greasy for my taste, and the service has always been rushed and careless. This place is different. Every dish we tried was decent and many were fantastic. The hot tea and iced teas were excellent. Service was spot on. Cute space. They even had black napkins, which I always appreciate during business lunch (no lint roller required). Very enjoyable experience, and as long as you're not a hard core dim sum purist, I highly recommend checking this place out.
author: Mistie T.

description:
It's been awhile since I sat down to pen a review.  Kudos to all my yelp friends who are always ever vigilant about writing awesome reviews of places so others such as myself may peruse and make educated choices on how to spend our time and expenses.  thank you. 

As for Yank Sing, well this used to be a fav of mine every time I visited SF.  Like things of the past, sometime we need to keep it in the past to preserve the good memories we experienced.  

On my last trip here, I found myself, quite sadden by the services and qualities I received.  Perhaps I spoke too esteem too highly, that i stories became even grandiose in my eyes.  Perhaps the shanghai dumplings pictured in my mind grew to iron chef proportion.

Never the less, when i visited this mecca of high end dim sum, my expectations outgrew the reality.  To me, the yank sing of the past was a five stars establishment.  Perfect like in their promotional video plastered on their web page.  But here is where yank sing lost me this time.

-1 star for price.  A simple weekend dim sum dinning for two cost $65.  I must say, the shanghai dumplings are good, but not at $10/plate.  We were never full, just a couple of dishes and bam, the bill was ridiculous.  They have restaurant weeks here in SD, I must say, I get better food at swankier joint for $30/person.  I know SF is expensive and the spear building rent must be high, but gauging patrons dinner prices for breakfast, that's was below the belt.

-1 one more star for service.  we tracked down 4 people to get us our tea and ice water.  I was surprised by the hap hazard staff.  I was so steamed that I was about to stand up and walk out, if it not, for my company, who held me in check.  We were given a table on the side just because there was only two of us. we wanted a bigger table, and there were plenty, but they said it was reserved for larger party.  I understand, but one knows how dim sum goes, big table with big spread of food.  If you are going to decline the bigger table for me, at least have the staff clear off empty containers more often.  We ran out of real estate on our table, hence we did not order much, which comes to think of it, was a good thing, otherwise we would have had a larger bill.  And to top it off, two parties that followed us had better services, with their tea brewing and their water glasses filled.

-1 one more more stars for dim sum taste.  I swear I must accept that yank sing prepare their food, cause they said so.  After sampling again the basics here of har gow, shumai, char sui bao, etc., I have to say, I have had better at buffets at indian casinos.  If someone told me that yank sing ordered them from china and just reheat them, charge premium price, and pass it off as their own, as a juror in a jury box, I would be inclined to believe such a concocted story.  it was simply plain, I could have found better for cheaper in chinatown.  

Overall, I frown upon yank sing.  She lost her ways with me.  After my visit to hong kong, I placed her on a pedestal, shouting to the crowd, she is the only worthy dim sum place this side of the pacific.  Clearly my fallacy has been exposed to the world.  Hard press for me to return.  I think yank sing rest on her laurels too long.  Her staff both front and back needs refreshing.
author: Kevin B.

description:
This is upscale dining.  You pay for it and you get it.

Went here twice in one week while on business.
It's a really nice place with linen table cloths, glass teapots and professional service.

It gets busy and on the weekend they expand the dining room out into the indoor courtyard.  Busy is good for dim-sum.  The food comes out fast and furious.  

The breadth of selections is unparalleled.  I've never had had anything I didn't think was spot on.  I've been lucky to go with no fewer than 6 people and we tried a LOT of dishes.
author: Allen L.

description:
Light your money on fire and enjoy some perfectly good dim sum in a mall courtyard!  Awesome!

I mean, when these reviews all say pricey, I don't think you understand what they are trying to tell you.  $50/pp for dim sum...for brunch...with no drinks...like, not even juice?  That is unconscionable.  You should hate yourself for a good 3 hours after eating here unless a) you've never had dim sum and don't know how much it is supposed to cost, or b) you are in the top 2% of US HHI.
author: Victor C.

description:
Yank Sing is an awesome place for a fancy but quick meal for big groups. I'd recommend it for business lunches when you don't really have time to peruse the menu and wait around for food because the servers will just walk around with carts and throw delicious looking things at you. You don't even realize how much you've eaten until the bill arrives.. and BAM! You'll be like, holy crap, that was expensive! Great business model, Yank Sing!

I had about 20 dishes and have no idea what they were. All I know is that they were delicious and expen$ive. I likely would not go back.. unless it's on the corporate card ;) I'd say skip Yank Sing and opt for cheaper, equally yummy authentic dim sum restaurants in Chinatown.
author: Joyce C.

description:
If you're not a fan of crowds, avoid Yang Sink on weekends at all costs.

Yang Sink website states: "On weekends Yank Sing's tables spill out into the elegant surrounds of the Rincon Atrium and the 49 Stevenson Arcade; filled with friends and family, laughter and conversation."

My version of the statement above would be: One weekend we booked a table for two, showed up early and still had to wait way beyond our reservation time (great, the food must be delicious right?) I have to say-despite the "spilled out tables", guests were packed like sardines. It gets better. The rooms "are filled with loud conversation and laugher" simply means you won't be able to have a dialogue at the table. Even if you come by yourself I'm positive you won't be able to have an inner dialogue either. Oh well, you can enjoy your meal instead but you'll have to convince servers that "no" means "no" first. They push steaming hot carts around the room with various dim sum dishes and they try to place them on your plate before you even know what they offer. Our mission  that day at Yang Sink basically  got boiled down to- eat quickly and get out of there. This is NOT exactly what people want from a restaurant though, right? Right.

 Good news? They offer food to go.
author: Elma C.

description: Delicious food! Only bad thing was I ordered the Sea Bass and they forgot about it. Therefore it took an hr to get it. It was delicious when it finally came.
author: Natalie G.

description: Good dim sum but not worth the money. We didn't order that many dishes (maybe 7 dishes total) and the bill came out to 65 dollars. Pricey! Food was good but they didn't have that many options. It was the same carts/trays circulating - where was the chicken feet?! Nothing really stood out for me besides the Shanghai dumplings (extra soupy). I would save your money for Koi Palace instead.
author: Donna W.

description: We love this place! It's the only Dim Sum I know of with great vegetarian, seafood and meat options. The mushroom dumplings are heavenly! They also have 4 or 5 other veggie dumplings. Snow peas with chili are delish as are the green beans. The service is much friendlier then the upscale place in Oakland where we have been many times. This is the most expensive as well as the best we have had, so we feel it's worth it.
author: solell s.

description:
My review title says it all.... Yank Sing has the best dim sum around.  We have the pleasure of going to Yank Sing when we stay overnight in SF.

Yank Sing is very popular.  We usually go on a Sunday morning and there is always a little wait, but it's ok because we go to the small bar and have a bloody mary while we wait.

Every dish we had was delicious!
Shrimp dumplings (soooo sweet, $6.10/per order of 4 pcs)
Fried crab claws (amazing!  $12.25/per order of 2 pcs)
Rice noodle w/pork (delish! $8/per order of 3 pcs)

Pricing is a bit higher than other dim sum places but sooo worth it!!  Can't wait to go back!
author: Buba M.

description:
Useful notes:
Xaio long bao are good. So is other stuff here too. I like the carts, location, and it has consistently been good for years. Har Gao are my fav. It is expensive and there are better places.

If you want better Kingdom of Dumpling out on Taraval is better. 

Shanghai Dumpling King is horrible now. Used to be good.

Koi Palace out in Daly City is fun but there is usually a wait.
author: Matt D.

description: The food here is really amazing. Some of the best dim sum I've ever had. Soup dumplings were great. Yes, it is expensive, but I think it was worth it. The only weird part was how crazy fast everything went...they were offering us dumplings before we even sat down. They came by every minute or so. And they're not the most polite people ever - it's more of a DECIDE NOW kind of attitude. Not a bad thing, they have a job to do, but it was a little too in-your-face for my taste. I'll be back for sure!
author: Courtney Y.

description:
My parents ranted and raved about this place so naturally, when I finally made it back to The City it was on my list! 

I took my boyfriend who was a dim sum virgin but I am proud to say, he is a total convert. He STILL has not stopped talking about how good it was. We will definitely be returning the next time we are in SF. There is a really good dim sum joint in my hometown so I am no stranger to the cuisine. They had all the yummy staples I am used to finding at my local spot but they do offer a few delicacies unique to Yank Sing. You MUST try the soup dumplings. They are to DIE for; if you don't burn the crap out of your mouth trying to eat them. 

A few tips:

*The price tag was a little shocking when the bill came but I guess that is SF for you. I am used to paying roughly $40 for my family of 3 to eat at our local dim sum restaurant but this was closer to $70 for just my boyfriend and I. (And no sake was to be had) 
* GET HERE EARLY! We decided to take a cab instead of walk, which cut our travel time to half and we ended up arriving about 15 mins. before the restaurant opened. And it is a good thing we did! The place filled to capacity within minutes of the doors opening. As we were leaving (around 11 am) there was a line out the building. 

If you are a dim sum fan or are trying it for the first time, you definitely need to stop here!
author: Maura H.

description:
At 800+ reviews, there's not a lot more that I can say.

But if you're looking for Dim Sum while in San Francisco, this is a great place. Been here many times over the years and always come away happy.

Dumplings are melt in your mouth. Crispy duck, terrific. Buns are sweet and filling and don't seem like they've been frozen and de-frosted. Nice and fresh.

Efficient service. Nice atmosphere. But come with a large group so you can sample everything.
author: Dan S.

description:
I have been there a several times.  Usually for a business lunch.  The ambiance is very nice.  The location is very convenient for parking.  It's a  perfect place for a business lunch or when guest comes to town.  The place is more expensive than most dim sum places, but the difference can be justified by the ambiance.   

The dim sum is only okay.  I doubt many knowledgeable locals would choose this place as their first choice.  I can think of at least three places better.   I have a rule of thumb for Chinese food, which I apply to restaurants in Asia and SF.  If there aren't many Chinese customer's I doubt the food is very good.  This rule was validated at Yang Sing.  The food is only so-so.  I wouldn't go out of my way to eat there, but if you're in the neighborhood and want ambiance, it's a good choice.
author: H S.

description: This is my go to place for a decent yumcha or dimsum as Americans call it. Their shaolongbao (shanghai soup dumplings) is a must order item. The hargao (prawn dumplings) meets the standards. Tofufa (silken tofu with ginger syrup) is only available on the weekends. Another good thing about this place is you can select the tea of your choice. I usually order the Tiguanyin (Iron Buddha) but Puer can also go quite well with the fried dumplings. A little bit on the pricey side but clean and good service with 2 hour valet parking downstairs.
author: Bomin K.

description: Okay place but pricy. I ordered one order of the shrimp roll (ha cheung), one sticky rice (comes with literally just one not one order which in most restaurants comes with at least 2 pieces), and two pieces of porkbuns. Total came up to 18.06. Pretty pricy to me compared to most places. The ha cheung itself was $8 (posted pictures) which to me is super expensive. Flavor was just ok.
author: J C.

description:
Pricey but delicious.  

The last time I had soup dumplings I was in Taiwan.  These held their own.  The peking duck came with a steamed bun roll which isn't bad but wasn't as good as the normal pita type skin they mostly come in and the actual duck skin wasn't crispy.  The fried foods are all really fresh and the sevice was excellent.  The steamed pork buns were too bready though.  All and all this was a pretty good place.  Only problem is the price.  $165 for 3 of us, but we werre pretty full.
author: Thugnificent M.

description:
If you like to O/D on MSG and love to quench your thirst for hours afterwards, then don't eat at Yank Sing. Go cheap and stock up on H2O.

I like YS because the dim sum isn't greasy so you can taste the ingredients. Shrimp har gow is large, generous, meaty and fresh. The peking duck comes with fresh buns and is not fatty so you can taste the meat. Shanghai XLB is soupy (good for dim sum), but not the best I've had (best still is in Taiwan). 

My favorite dim sum dish is shrimp cheong fun and YS is able to deliver it in a way where I secretly consume half the dish without my friends realizing the dish is there. Yes, that's how good it is!

In addition to the good service where they call in the dishes you want, we are hilariously obsessed with an over the top customer who is always decked out in fur and bling in the most gaudy manner. Tasty dim sum with a show, life is good.
author: Sophie C.

description:
Definitely prefer this location to the one on Stevenson St.  They've got everything I want (cheung fun, daan tat, dau miu, ALL kinds of tasty little dumplings, and more) and it's a non-threatening (read: white person friendly) place to go for dim sum.

Only drawback to this place is the price: we spent $90 for 2 people this weekend.  But whatever, that's the price I pay for finding a place that doesn't freak out the gwai lo boyfriend.
author: Priscilla T.

description: Good variety. Extremely high prices for Dim Sum, at least double SF Chinatown prices.  Busy, efficient service.  Ordered WonTon soup, finally cart came around after we were finished eating. Their one-of-the-best-Chinese-restaurants outside of China rating may be a little much. Pretty efficient cart service. Good service, good obvious mgmt. presence. Nice to try once but, be prepared to pay through the nose for their reputation.  Meh
author: J C.

description:
We arrived this morning at 9:45am for our first visit, and to our surprise, there were already 25-30 people waiting in line already, most of which were Chinese.  Everything was run like clockwork, with the army of employees each well versed in their responsibilities.  Unlike a vast majority of Chinese restaurants, the staff were all very attentive and friendly.  Everything about the place was also impeccably clean.

Now onto the best part - the FOOD!!!!!!!  Everything we ate was incredibly fresh and amazingly delicious.  Our favorites were the Har Gow, and the Mandarin Dumplings.  The Shanghai Dumplings were good, but not our favorite.  Portion sizes were big, and we ate a LOT :)  Our bill was just over $100.00 including tip, which was very fair considering both the quality and quantity of the food.

By the time we left, the entire (very large) restaurant was packed full, as we're the numerous outside tables they had setup.  This place is a MUST try if you enjoy dim sum!!!
author: Rick J.

description:
I'm not going to lie...I like me some gwailo dim sum now and then. I also appreciate that this place is great to bring peeps who are not adventurous enough to try dim sum from a real dim sum joint. They get to try a gentrified dim sum experience, and hopefully, get exposed to a bit of culture that's different from their own.

I'm probably being way too esoteric...

I love this place. Yes, it's expensive and not quite as authentic as if you go to say Ton Kiang or Gold Mountain. BUT, there's something to be said for the customer service, and the fact that, if you don't happen to speak Cantonese, you can still ask questions and order without worrying you picked a dish you'll regret.

There hasn't been a dish I've had here that I didn't like. Some of my stand-out favorites: chicken fun gwor, pork siu mai, egg rolls (I know, how boring, but they're sooo good!), and egg custard tart.

Great place to bring your gwailo out of town guests ;)
author: Christy L.

description: For good dim sum in the FiDi south of Market, it's worth not hiking to Chinatown. even if the price difference almost justifies a cab.
author: Mike V.

description:
This is one of my favorite Dim Sum places in the country. The perfect number of people to go with (in my opinion) is 3-6 so that you can have the most variety of dishes. Servers come around in carts to offer an enormous variety of traditional Dim Sum. Be sure to get the Shanghai Dumplings and eat them the proper way (ask a server if in doubt)

I'm giving it 5 stars because it is absolutely delicious and never disappoints. The only complaints someone could have is price and how busy it gets at peak hours. As long as you plan ahead and get a reservation then service is never an issue. I always feel I get my moneys worth and refuse to visit San Francisco without a Yank Sing stop.
author: Keith W.

description:
VERY busy place. Make a reservation ahead of time. There is a "to go" next to restaurant where food comes out quite fast but they don't have full menu. 
Parking is validated but spaces are very tight!
Check menu prices ahead of time because there are few items that cost a lot for what you get like the fish.

Make sure if you have a reservation like we did, but go early, they know you got there in advance to get in earlier. We got there an hour & a half before our reservation time because they said we could get in sooner if we did that.
Hostess was confused & kept us waiting a long time & had us on the list on our set time but we had to get a bit ugly to make her listen to what we were saying. Girls here are all very nice & have great customer service. I know she was busy & had a lot going on.
author: Peedee M.

description: Best Dim Sum I've ever had and great service.  They'll bend over backwards to make sure you get all the different types of dim sum you want! :) Great for family gatherings.
author: Amanda V.

description:
3 x ($) signs ain't no lie. I'm a huge dim sum fan and I can usually be found on the weekends munching on giant shumai at one the take-out dim sum places in the Richmond. So I figured I'd switch it up a bit and try a legitimate sit down place hence my first visit to Yank Sing.

First thought...total sticker shock, however the food is almost, almost worth the price.

1) Shanghai Dumplings - Yum-O (get out of my head Rachel Ray!). These put the version at the Michelin-rate Din Tai Fung to shame; yes them be fighting words.

2) Peking Duck - hand assembled right at your table; crisp skin, perfectly steam bun, good stuff...

3) Shumai - seriously bursting at the seams with shrimp; the prettiest shumai I've ever seen...hey you eat with your eyes first no?

4) Shrimp Wrapped in Rice Sheets - ugh...worst dish...wtf is with the addition of cilantro?

5) BBQ Pork Baked Bun -  these are definitely well hyped and well deserved. The pork itself is delicious and the crust is flaky if not completely unique in texture. The honey wash brushed over the top was a bit much for me though as I'm more of a traditionalist.

6) Sesame Balls - man these are tiny comparatively to what you can get in the Richmond, none-the-less, these are pretty darn good. Best when fresh out the fryer with a crisp sesame seed exterior and steaming hot red bean...mmm...leaves you wanting more.

Had a bunch more stuff, chicken feet, etc etc but this is already getting a bit long winded.
author: David H.

description:
i love dim sum.  almost as much as i love sushi.  and i would eat it as much as i eat sushi, but i can never find a great place that serves it!

i was in san fran visiting friends, and when they said do you want italian or chinese i said "uhmm... HOW ABOUT CHINESE?!!!  PLEASE?!!!"  they said they love this place so we zipped on over as i tried not to drool at the thought.  it was crazy bustling busy at lunch but we were seated quickly.  and even more quickly the table filled up with dozens of trays of delicious dumplings!  har how, su men, pork buns, these famous soup-in-dumplings they make here, peking duck and more.

i remember as a kid always trying to eat as much dim sum as possible because dayam, it's good!  i also remember as a kid never managing to eat as much dim sum i liked.  i was always left wanting more... but there was no more!  (yes... my life is a dramatic oliver twist novel...)

well thank god we ordered so much that i almost passed out in a food coma.  everything was very very good.  everything extremely tasty, and given quite the kick from the hot chili sauce and mustard i was slathering on things.  and i could have kept going all day but i ate so much i started falling asleep!

service was prompt and efficient in somewhat broken english.  when i asked for sauce "on the side" they poured it "on the side" of the dish instead of in a separate bowl.  haha.  oh well!

but it was definitely a lovely and delicious lunch.  and when i'm back in san fran i will hunt this place down again.

xia xia, yank sing!
author: Ryan H.

description:
I want to preface this and tell you all that I do not like dim sum that much, I maybe crave it once or twice a yr. 

I get to rincon, excited because people were telling me yank sing has really good dim sum. So I walk in and grab a menu and was trying to make a decision on what I wanted. 

lady-"are you ready"
me-"no, not yet thanks"
*30 seconds pass*
lady-"are you ready?"
me-"no i'm still looking thanks"
*20 seconds later*
lady-"are you ready to order?"
me-"i'm sorry i'm still looking"
*10 seconds later*
lady-" are you ready to order?"

Rinse+wash+repeat.

O-o ??

There are two customers in there, and they are already being helped. Am I missing something here? It's only 1pm and I don't think they close until 3pm.

I ordered 2 shumais, turnip cake, and shrimp noodle roll.

$16 bucks.

You have got to be kidding me. I'm trying to contain myself, because I seriously just got ass raped by this place. I've never paid $16 bucks for lunch. I'm thinking this had better be good.

I opened up the box and died a little inside, I paid 16 bucks for some scrap food? The portion was tiny, I must have paid 6 bucks for 2 dinky shumais.

Then I tasted it, the turnip cake was burnt, and there was some kind of mystery ingredient that I couldn't even chew. 

The shrimp noodle roll sucked equally, the noodle was hard and the sauce that came with it was WAY too salty. 

I had non-consensual ass rape sex with Yank Sing, I will not return thanks. And I want my damn money back, but the chances are slim. I lose.
author: Thao L.

description: I've tried 2 different combo's so far to go. Always have a big portion of rice or chow mien. The dumplings are not bad.
author: Nathan B.

description:
I agreed with other reviewers about the price. Be prepared to spend about 100 for a party of two.

Although my waiting time for having a table ready was 20 minutes, I'd recommend that you make a reservation beforehand. This place's always been packed for a brunch time. 

Overall: I'm satisfied with decent food quality and service.

Pros:
- Great location, located in Rincon center (Financial district), short walking distance from nearby Muni station and Ferry building.
- Nice ambient. 
- Decent food and service. Staff/Waitresses speak English well.
- Great host/hostess and their waiting/queue system. I got text when my table was ready instead of having to wait and wondering if I miss host/hostess calling out my number. Thumb up on this.

Cons:
- A bit expensive. (see above and other reviewers warning about price)
- Although the service was decent, waiting time for dim-sum cart may vary.
- Food was decent (above than average). I'd say I had better dim-sum.

I'd recommend this place. Great for spending quality time with your family, friends or non-first dates.
author: Nate K.

description:
Best for quality of ingredients and consistency.  Best XLB I've found in the Bay; but still mediocre compared to what you get in Asia.

Expensive as hell for dim sum; but I go in knowing that, so it doesn't effect my rating.
author: Josh K.

description: It's overpriced and average for SF, but prepared to be disappointed if you've ever had dim sum in Vancouver or LA. This place would be laughed out of business. But for some reason SF people don't seem to mind bad dim sum. And they keep pushing expensive dinner items on us like a cheap Chinatown joint. Not classy.
author: Edward L.

description:
Let's talk about my love-hate relationship with Yank Sing. Every time I leave there in a tizzy, I vow to never go back. This time was no different. After a long night of schmoozing and boozing, I often wake up in the morn with a hankering for some dim sum. Who doesn't?  

Their dim sum is divine. Hits the spot EVERY time. What leaves me with a nasty taste in my mouth is the horrible service. To start off with, the manager/owner/whoever he is moves like molasses. We gave him our credit cards to split the bill and he came back about 20 minutes later. Then I gave him my parking ticket to get validated and after 10 minutes I was forced to chase him through the restaurant to get it back so I could get the hell out of there. No wonder the place is always packed!! I can't figure out the servers either. I asked one of them for a diet coke and she laughed and walked away. Huh?? One of my friends asked another lady walking by with a big cart of pot stickers if we could have some and she BARKED back at her that she would come back. She walked back 5 minutes later with an empty cart and a smile on her face. Exsqueeze me??

I just don't get it. Maybe I never will. I'm sure I'll wind up coming back again in a weakened hungover state. They're lucky their food is so damn good!!!!!!
author: Nora C.

description:
Went here with a group..
SHANGHAI DUMPLINGS: this was the best thing here... was good (little pricey)
THAI SALAD (red cabbage)- this was good.. very limey and fish saucey
HONEY WALNUT SHRIMP: the candies walnuts were good.. other than that.. it was ok
POTSTICKERS: this is ok.. nothing special
STICKY RICE: this was ok... nothing special
SESAME BALLS: this was good
PORK BUNS: the bread was soft... but this was ok
EGG ROLLS: this was ok.. nothing special 

the food here is okay.. nothing special... I gave them 2 stars bc it was way too much for OK food
author: Helen C.

description:
C'mon. Really. It's like $1.50 per dumpling! No matter how good, I cannot see any justification for the prices they charge. ROBBERY! I'll take my dingy $1.99 for 3pc dim sum in Monterey Park any day over this.

Why is it so crowded?! Is it just pure fame? Cause there was a 40 min wait on a weekday at 11:30am.

Then you have to pay for parking. They validate for 2 hrs but it takes that long to wait for a table. Then it's still like $4 to park with validation.
author: Karen Y.

description:
It was an amazing venue for my wedding. Quality service, support, pre-wedding meetings and the whole sha-bang! Daisy (wedding coordinator at Yank Sing) was one of a kind. I fell in love with this place when I first attended a wedding there years ago. The beautiful central waterfall seals the deal. It is a very vast open space so you can do a lot with the area, with a big wedding or a small wedding. 

As anything in San Francisco, the cost is of course the biggest deal. I would suggest this place if it fits your budget or can just splurge for a one in a lifetime occasion.
