The ambiance, as I mentioned, is just right. You are pretty much paying for the environment. The food is delicious as well and you get what you pay (in terms of service).

Yank Sing a long time in my heart...my wedding memories here will live on...literally....I think I left a bunch of my crafts there.
author: Jennifer C.

description:
3.5 stars.

Great dim sum place for a special occasion. Food is good, just a little overpriced, you're basically paying for the ambiance so make sure you get a table near the waterfall like we did. Very Americanized with good service. They validate parking and they take reservations (the wait can be long during the holidays) so those are bonuses!
author: Karen L.

description:
It's my favorite dim-sum restaurant in San Francisco. The service is quick and friendly. The restaurant is very clean. Although 
it's a bit pricey, you pay for what you get.
author: Rk S.

description:
Bustle bustle bustle at this busy stand by dim sum. I seem to recall liking the food quite well in the past but today's lunch was passable at best.  Cold hot dishes. So cold we even sent one back. Greasy fried items (not the delicious kind of greasy) and generally neutral but edible items. We had made a reservation but two in our party were greeted with utter dismissal -  "nothing in the book" by that name. The other person in our party didn't have the same trouble. But the hostesses could not have cared less and left some in our party of 4 to wait indefinitely outside. You don't come here for gracious service though, so we shrugged our shoulders and rolled with it. 

There are better choices for dim sum in SF.
author: S T.

description:
Okay, so here's the thing. If money were no object, this place would probably pretty easily be a 4 or maybe even 5 star for me. But I just can't get past price on this one. Maybe it's my own fault - I just don't think dim sum should be this expensive.... It's like tacos, there's no reason for that.

Food - it is pretty delicious. I mean, it's dim sum. Of course it's delicious. And they do a really good job... (soooouupp duumpplllinnggss....). They have a ton of options, they're all prepared pretty well, it makes me super happy. Until I get the bill. Then I'm a little angry. Stuffed, but angry. 

Atmosphere/Service - so I'm fairly certain this is why it costs so much. This is the nicest dim sum joint I've ever visited. It's pretty clean... you get actual service... it's weird. ;) Nice, but weird for dim sum. 

In conclusion - If you have some bucks to spend and want to enjoy some delicious dim sum without the added flavor of standard-Chinese-hole-in-wall-mom-and-pop-let's-just-not-think-too-much-about-it atmosphere... go. You won't be disappointed. Full and broke, maybe. But not disappointed.
author: Permahungry C.

description: After a bit of a hassle getting seated due to a disorganized checking system, we sat down to a very tasty meal. The cole slaw was so nicely dressed. The dim sum was light and flavorful, including the shrimp shu mai. I think the only thing that might have made our meal nicer was more interaction on the part of the waitstaff, although I do have to admit that it was nice that all of the staff did speak English, and were able to honor our request to not have any pork.
author: Wayne S.

description:
Yank Sing is a great spot for dim sum located in Rincon Center on Spear.

I like the outdoor ambiance and the waterfall.  Try and come here with more than 2 people so you can eat more dishes:

Favorites to Order:

Xiao Long bao (comes in order of 6)
Egg Tarts (really good!)
Sesame Balls
Shrimp Dumplings
Shrimp Crepe
Sea Bass
Preserved Egg and Pork Porridge
Tofu-Fa (dessert tofu)
Duck with Buns

Come on the earlier side to beat the rush!
author: Carli F.

description:
........ and no Jennifer c "Smiling is sexy" P.'s I am not cheap and I have a very good paying job but thank you for your concerns with my finances.

I always thought different from people from the city. But this is not the case Jennifer c "Smiling is sexy" P is very rude to an insulting extent.... wow. She obliterated me with nosy, insulting and rude compliments and then she blocks me. Wow the maturity!
author: R C.

description: Dim sum was really good but the prices do not justify. You can do better elsewhere. $70 total for 2? Cmon
author: Ben K.

description: Absolutely spot on Dim Sum. Having lived in Hong Kong, my craving for good Dim Sum is insatiable. But this place does as good a job as you can expect in the U.S.  The Shanghai dumplings, filled with pork, ginger, and hot soup, are a specialty. Other favorites are the shrimp and chive dumplings, Shao Mai, etc
author: B F.

description: Came here for a reception so only got to try the pre-ordered dim sum.  I had the normal ha-gao, shumai which were ordinary.  The fried shrimp was pretty good but a little bit too oily.  I think I will have to try some of their specialties in order to tell how it compares with other dim sum places.
author: Jennifer S.

description: The fried rice was barely luke warm and the shrimp dumplings were downright cold. Both were lacking any flavor. The dumplings might have been edible if they would have been hot and included sauce, which they most likely forgot because they were trying to rush me out the door. Spend your lunch hour elsewhere.
author: David G.

description: BEST dim sum ever. The walnut shrimp was to die for. Service is excellent. Lots of vegetarian offerings! Upscale dim sum, can't wait to go back.
author: Jane R.

description: Way too over rated and absolutely way over priced!! I took my brother and sister here for a Saturday lunch; only 3 of us in total the bill came out to well over $120!! And we were totally not even full at ALL!! That is absolutely INSANE! Since we weren't even full, we walked over to Thai OSHA on Embarcadero just to eat again! That just shows you how expensive and small their portions are...absolutely ridiculous!! Come on! Lower your prices and give a little bit more to the consumer for god's sake!!
author: Bobby C.

description:
I came here for 2 weddings in the past 2 months ... If it weren't for the weddings I wouldn't come here.  The place itself is in a office like building with a food court in the middle .. there is a big waterfall that comes raining down from the glass ceiling above. 

I've had better dim sum .. and it sure gets really quiet during the weekends because its situated in the financial district.  Be prepared to fork out some cash for mediocre dim sum.  Perhaps the price of the dim sum covers the bill for using the damn waterfall outside.
author: Jeremy L.

description: Haven't tried all their dishes. Not sure what is the hype, I have tasted better dim sum elsewhere. Ate 5 dishes ~ 40 bucks
author: John C.

description:
If you love traditional Chinese dim sum, don't expect to like this place because 1) lack of variety and 2) your wallet will almost be empty before you're done eating!

I grew up eating traditional Chinese dim sum but I like eating at Yank Sing because the quality of their ingredients is excellent (i.e. I will not get stomachaches or diarrhea). You do pay extra for higher quality ingredients, but you also pay for the nice interior view. I loved how they turn on the waterfall so that water falls from the ceiling and hits the ground, which looks really pretty on a nice sunny day. Their Shanghai style soup dumplings is excellent for a restaurant that serves dim sum, but you still get better tasting Shanghai soup dumplings at a Shanghai style restaurant. Their Peking Duck is also very very delicious, but you pay an arm and a leg ($8) for a bread and a slice of peking duck meat. The only dish I would not recommend getting from here is the steamed rice rolls. It tastes funny.

Service is excellent/prompt, and waiters/waitresses can speak English decently. I do feel that Yank Sing caters more to westerners and the upper middle class since the food and restaurant in general is very clean.

My family has had Yank Sing cater at my house, but I don't remember much about it since it was over 5 years ago! My sister also had her wedding reception there. Food is decent, but is definitely not a cheap venue!

To sum up 5 stars for food and service minus 1 star for lack of variety.
author: Selina T.

description:
Since moving to the city I have discovered that people here love dim sum, and that they have specific places that they like to go for their dim sum.

I judge the quality of a dim sum place based solely on their steamed pork buns.

The buns here were good, but they were by far not the best in the city I have had. 

The rest of the food was good, but it was pretty pricy. Another thing I liked about this place was the quantity of food they had out on the floor at any given time. You could pretty much pick out a menu item and they would have it to your table with in minutes.
author: Stephanie T.

description: It's a clean, beautiful restaurant, but the food is way overpriced.  It is definitely not worth the money. There are so many dim sum places in sf that you would enjoy more and get more bang for your buck. Service wasn't good for an up-scale restaurant either. Would not come back or recommend it.
author: Heather M.

description:
Once upon a time, long, long ago - I was a Dim Sum noob. After a couple of flashes of what could be in spots in LA and New York I hit Yank Sing - fell in love with Dim Sum - and thus began the longest, most stable relationship in my life.   But this review is not about my obviously sad and pathetic shell of an existence, not about my 25+ year history with the place, it's about whether or not you should pay them a visit today.

You should.

Here's why:

Xiao Long Bao - The soup dumplings here are not to be missed.  They are everything a soup dumpling should be

Ha Gao - Perfectly balanced - you taste the meat of the prawn in every bite - not "paste" the skin is crystalline and precisely the proper thickness

Try any of the special dumplings - lamb and peanut, green onion and shredded beef - everything on the specials is amazing

Tea - Some people complain that they charge for tea.  They charge because they serve truly premium teas - not Costco bulk.  I am partial to the chrysanthemum tea here - it is spectacular and truly complements the food.  

Let's get those pesky negatives out of the way;

They're expensive. Yup. This is one of the highest price Dim Sum places in North America.  Even so, by rest of the city/state/universe standards it's not all that bad for the quality you get.

Some of the non Dim Sum items could be better. Yup. Come here for Dum Sum; there are plenty of other places that do other things much better.

It's crowded.  The best places tend to have that problem - go somewhere awful and you'll have the place to yourself,

It's a beautiful restaurant, the service is usually quite good, and you'll really enjoy the food - IF - you don't allow a couple of pesky negatives to ruin your meal...
author: Howard H.

description: Yes, this place is expensive and YES, there are probably better dim sum places out there (although most of them seem to be take-out bakeries). With all that said, the dim sum here was excellent. If there's something you want that's not on a cart, they are really quick about getting that dish (either from another cart or straight from the kitchen). The tea was especially good. I think there's some kind of prejudice about Chinese food -- that it should be cheap, that it's not sophisticated. People will pay a lot of money for Japanese or French food but there's just this assumption that Chinese food (and Mexican food) should always be just a notch above fast food. THere are certainly cheap dim sum alternatives but, as the saying goes, you get what you pay for. Part of the extra cost here is that the overall quality is just better.
author: Tommy K.

description:
I took BART into the city on Black Friday with my girlfriend (no WAY am I going to drive in!!) and she had reserved lunch here.

First, let me say the service was absolutely outstanding.  We had the first reservation of the day at 11am, but they actually opened a little early and seated us at 10:45.  We weren't seated but a few seconds when the waitress came up to us with their special of the day, which happened to be Chilean sea bass in a slightly sweet sauce.  The fish was SO tender that I could have eaten a whole plate of it! But of course I wanted to try other things.  I'd never tried the pork balls with the soup inside, but the waitress was kind enough to show me how to put it on the spoon and eat it with a little sauce and ginger.  That was pretty good.  Other items I tried were the Chinese broccoli (nice and fresh, though could have used a bit more lemon and pepper seasoning), Phoenix tail prawns (nice size and meaty!), foil-wrapped chicken (tasty but hard to get the wrapping off and still had some bones in it), regular pot stickers (about the same as every other Chinese food place I've tried, hard to mess them up), and shrimp/mushroom rolls (excellent with a bit of soy sauce!), and finally, a palate-cleansing dish of strawberry and melon balls.

The sea bass was the best, but as the special was not listed on the menu.  Depending on the day you go, they may have different items such as soft-shell crab.  Make sure you ask the price beforehand though, because their specials tend to be the most expensive items.

Overall the meal was really good save for the minor flaws mentioned above, and service could not have been better.  One thing I wish they would offer is some kind of sherbet which would have made a better palate cleanser for the spicier things than the fruit did.  I understand the difficulty of showcasing such a dessert, but I honestly think there would be enough demand for it that they would lose very little to melting, and they can always bring some out to order.

Be careful what you get here, though, because those prices add up!!  The total for just me and my girlfriend was $160, and that without tip!  Not a place you can go to every day.
author: Paul W.

description:
Despite living in SF for about 16 months now, and going to college at Cal for four years I was a dim sum virgin prior to coming here for a Sunday brunch (not sure if dim sum is considered "brunch" but that's what I'm calling it). Therefore, I really don't have anything to compare this place to. 

I thought this place was fantastic though! I came here with two other people who eat here about once every month or two and I let them do most of the ordering (I'll eat just about anything). One of our dining companions only eats gluten-free foods, so there were a few items that she ordered that I didn't get a chance to taste. 

The two of us non-gluten free people started with an order of pork pot-stickers and chicken egg rolls. They weren't bad, but they were probably my two least favorite things that we had. These were the only two non-steamed items that we had, and I'm thinking it's because of this they didn't taste as fresh as some of the other items we ordered (they were a little greasy). 

The first two steamed items that we tried were the shrimp dumplings, which were awesome (they were basically all shrimp) and the Sui Mai? (I think that's what those pork dumplings are called?), and they were delicious! We also had two orders of the the steamed pork buns, which were highly recommended by one of our dining companions, and they did not disappoint. We also has the Shanghai dumplings (those soup dumpling things), which were great (these seem to be a popular item here). 

Our gluten free companion had some sort of leaf-wrapped rice patty thing that actually looked really good as well as the mushroom/chicken dumplings (I guess whatever they use as the "dumpling" with this item is gluten free). 

For dessert we had mango pudding as well these sesame apricot ball things, which were both delicious! I'm not sure what kind of tea we had (it wasn't the jasmine), but it was good as well. 

Since I was a dim sum virgin, it's kind of hard for me rate the service since dim sum service works a little differently than a restaurant where you would order off a menu. However, the carts came around often and all the servers seemed to know the dishes pretty well. At times they can be a little pushy (they'll start to put plates down on your table before you say whether or not you want it) and it did take us a few tries to get the mushroom/chicken dumplings (this was the only item we specifically requested). 

I see where a lot of people say this place is expensive, and it definitely is a little pricey, but I thought it was worth the price for everything we ate. With tax and tip each of us in our group paid about $30 and we ate a LOT of food!!! 

I would definitely come back here for dim sum, especially with a large group for brunch or birthday.
author: George A.

description: Clean and good service.  Dim sum was good.   Not too many varieties but had all the essentials.  Price is above average compared  to other dim sum restaurants.  Waite staffs were polite and attentive.
author: Allen N.

description: If you like dim sum or never tried it before, this is one of the best places in San Francisco. It's usually crowded but worth the wait.  The food is the best because unlike other dim sum establishments, the food is fresh and non-greasy.  The price is a bit higher than most but your stomach will be happier once you complete your meal.  Be careful not to order too much, often my eyes are bigger than my stomach at Yank Sing.  Be careful of the specials, they can be more expensive than the regular items you can choose.
author: Mikael B.

description:
The food is really hit or miss, and I might give Yank Sing between 3-4 stars for the quality of the food... but the prices are what really drives this review down. 

The only thing I would maybe say was worth purchasing for my meal was the xio long bao (SO GOOD!) ... but an $80 bill for 2 small women is overly ridiculous for dim sum. I can only imagine myself going back if I stumble upon some exorbitant amount of money.
author: Lucinda W.

description:
Location, location, location. When you have it you can pretty much serve anything and people will chow down. 

Price is not too bad for high-end dim sum, but you can easily pay 1/3 the price and get 2X the flavor anywhere in nearby China Town dim sum places. Here you get the honor to pay for high-end price while having the pleasure of tasting food like shipped from a so-so dim sum joint that doesn't know better. Oh they also offer the usual Chinese restaurant services. Yes, exactly. 

The dim sum ingredients here are not fresh, not to mention they don't even make them the proper way (hard BBQ pork bun that doesn't taste like it, Xiao Long Bao that doesn't taste as good as those from the market refrigerator, anyone?). You get better value in Koi Palace for high-end dim sum. The silver linings here are the entrees. They barely get a passing grade. When it comes to Asian food, never trust the white rubber tire dude. 

This is a unique experience that I want to keep it that way by not going back.
author: M C.

description: Best dim sum in the city , go with a reservation or expect to wait at least an hour . Nice staff and service the food comes out hot n fresh , wouldn't go anywhere else for dim sum keep up the good work
author: Ali S.

description: Super & crazy expensive !!! Not worth it !!! I travel worldwide & i have to take a moment to say this !!! I Will not ever come back here again
author: B N.

description:
I'm torn with this place and I'm not sure how to feel about it.  It's definitely bigger, cleaner, and much more friendly than your other dim sum spots in the city.  However, the high cost and mediocrity in the quality and authenticity of the dim sum is evident.  If I was hosting dim sum to non-Asian, non-experienced, out of town guests, this place would be perfect.   However, for my Chinese friends who are dim sum connoisseurs....  they refuse to eat here.   According to them, this is where only the "YANKees SING praise..."

Does that make me a yankee?  I personally like the place... but then again.  I'm not a connoisseur when it comes to dim sum.  In fact, I still order based on how the dim sum looks.....  You know, like the crab ball with the claw sticking out...  the white flat noodle thing with beef and soy sauce....  the sesame seed balls... You know you do the same!
author: Danny L.

description:
Great Dim Sum at prices that almost de-qualify it from being called Dim Sum..almost but not quite.  

If you go, get the Shanghai dumplings: they're filled with soup, with a bit of meat in the middle.  Actually, everything I've had on the menu is very good.  There's always a line for the cheaper option of take-away lunch, as well.

But neither option is as cheap as Dim Sum should be.  If you want real Dim Sum, there are places in Chinatown and on Clement street.  If you want very clean, approachable Chinese food for a holiday or with more picky family members or if work is paying, go to Yank Sing, definitely.

On my scale*, Yank Sing gets a 3, but I'd probably only drop the dough if it was a special occasion/guests in town/etc.

*Scale:
1: Would not go back alone and would protest if a friend suggested we go.
2: Would not go back alone, but would not protest if a friend suggested we go.
3: Would go back happily and willingly without being prompted by someone else.
author: Lauren J.

description:
Another one of those restaurants where you get the feeling that all the employees are secretly cackling and rubbing their hands together as you pay EXTRAORDINARILY high prices for mediocre, white-washed Dim Sum.

I think the two biggest offenders are their 'house specialty' soup dumplings ($12 for 6 golf ball sized dumplings). But it comes with secret sauce! Red vinegar and small Dim Sum do not a $12 dish make. Also, paper thin slices of duck (mostly just skin) are $8 a slice. The slices are the size of my pinky.

Go on a business lunch when you company is paying. If you spend your own money here, you're an idiot.
author: Zach S.

description: This place is highly over rated.   The quality of food is OK, but it does not justify for the outrageous price.  We were a party of 4: 2 adults, 2 children.  We had exactly 10 small dishes, 3 of them were deserts.  The price?  $150.  Holy shxx! In a Chinese Dimsum place, $150?  I am from San Jose area, and I probably pay less than 1/2 of that at the the best DimSum place in the area.  Why do they charge this outrageous price?  This must be a rip off places for tourists.  I highly do not recommend this place.  I would give 0 star if I can.
author: S S.

description: Tasty dim sum with a westernized flair. Fresh ingredients and presentation are top notch, nice and clean interior and the quality is there.
author: Maritha S.

description:
Yank Sing is definitely not like any of the typical dim sum places I've been.    The Shanghai dumplings were delicious and were my favorite. You have to be very mindful while eating this. A soup spoon is definitely needed because it's filled with delicious warm broth. I would've been happy just eating this, but since we are not locals, we tried many other dishes.  This was definitely the stand out because I can't remember the other ones. I will definitely come back just for the dumplings.  

They were pretty busy when we went there on a weekend so be prepared to wait.  Also, if you're seated inside, the tables are pretty close so if you easily get annoyed with the general public, I would suggest grabbing a seat "outside."
author: Vy N.

description: Dim sums are great here, BUT they do not know how to stamp. I've been here twice already (always go to the other one) and they made the same mistake TWICE. They over-stamp their papers, so CHECK THE RECEIPT BEFORE YOU PAY. Twice is no coincidence, so I have a strong feeling that they do this on purpose.
author: Stacy H.

description:
How many of these reviews will be about the fact that they basically just rape your wallet? 

Look.. i get it.  The location itself is enough of a tip off as to how ridiculously overpriced this place will be, but what i don't get it why anyone would continue to subject themselves to it.  Sure, the food is pretty good (why it gets two stars instead of one).  But with soooo many options in the city and in the bay  that are as good or better than Yank Sing, why come here?

Smaller portions at twice the price... no thanks.  You may choose to call me miserly, but i call it learning how to stretch your eating dollar.  And believe you me.. with as much as i eat, that dollar better be as pliable as it can get.
author: Felix W.

description: EVERYTHING is great here. Just make sure you price your menu ahead of time, if you just grab and eat like we did, you can run a bill up to $100 per person if you're not careful!
author: Larry B.

description: Best Dim Sum in Peninsula + San Francisco
author: Jonathan D.

description:
When did Chinese food start costing $35 per person for lunch (w/ no alcohol)?  I knew Yank Sing was expensive but I had no idea a lunch could cost that much.  Sure, the food is fine.  But it is not amazing - I've been to plenty of dim sum places in the South Bay and the SGV (in LA) that have food just as good if not better than Yank Sing.  The XiaoLongBao are not that great - just go to Shanghai Dumpling in Saratoga or Hu Chiang in Cupertino if you want really good XiaoLongBao for less.

Isn't a Yelp rating supposed to represent the overall restaurant experience?  Based on the price alone, I just cannot recommend Yank Sing.  They have duck for $5.  You may think $5 seems reasonable and it is if you're getting a small plate of sliced duck (like you'd get at other dim sum places) but it's $5 per person per slice.  Yes, ONE slice of duck costs $5.  Lu Din Gee in San Gabriel sells a whole duck for $32.95.  

If you're not Asian, you may think it's ok to splurge on dim sum just because this place is clean and the servers speak English.  But for the price I paid for one meal, I could've gone to dim sum twice at another equally good restaurant.
author: Yi Z.

description:
The dim sum here is some of the best I've had.  LA just can't compete with SF.  The buns are all well made and fluffy, never soggy (lol).

I came here with 5 friends and we ate like we normally do.  Stuffed, we ask for the bill and it came out to about $160.  WTF.  I've never had to pay so much money for dim sum.  It's like walking into a deli for turkey sandwich and walking out $50 poorer.   

This place is clean and the food is good but the price is just ridiculous.
author: Lawrence B.

description: A great dim sum experience from beginning to end.  I had some out-of-town friends visiting and they requested dim sum.  I called up Yank Sing and got reservations for 8 very easily.  When we got there, we were seated right away and carts came by our table frequently with fresh, hot food.  Even thought it was a bit on the pricey side for dim sum, it was well worth it for CLEAN, QUALITY food.  This will be my go-to place for dim sum in San Fran.
author: Jenny K.

description:
In a city full of good dim sum Yan Sing holds its own.  It's food is good but not amazing when compared to other excellent dim sum restaurant in SF (particularly in the Inner Richmond).  

What Yang Sing can boast that no other dim sum restaurant has in the city is its amazing ambiance.  The space Yang Sing has in the Rincon Tower is pretty impressive . . . especially the ceiling to floor water fountain.  

I would absolutely go back to Yang Sing again and definitely encourage fellow Yelpers to check it out.
author: Oski B.

description:
No wait at 11:00am, but table filled up quickly. Two visits in 5 day trip in Bay area, would wanted to try other cuisions but it was too good to by pass for just one time. Being one of the few tables. 1st impression, good greeting with smile, dim sum cart lady came right after tea being served ( no early no late, well trained- good timing. )

Must try -
Baked Black cod - $19.00 / a really thick hand size of cod, so tender and juicy. Well worth the $$
Sesame Ball - $10.00 / the most delicious n pricy one I ever had. I even ordered extra to go. 
SH steam dumpling - $12.50 / The best!!! Better than Taipei. Good silky skin texture, full of juicy soup but not oily.
Lotus Steam bun - the lotus filling is so moisture, the dough is a plus.

I tried almost everything on the menu, about $180 for two of us. Yes, I ordered a lot, but Trust Me - being a Cantonese with my grow up tradision cuision, it worth every dollar when you want both quality and atmosphere. 

Special - 
The customer service is a true highlight. From the server, cart lady, to Manager - Bill, who are extremely enthusiastic. Busy but caring. Worth 5 stars
author: Jenny W.

description: Yes, I occasionally eat here, but that certainly doesn't make me an expert on the place. Being that I cannot order in the original language, I tend to be the odd one out in the group of friends. Food is still decent, but I'd like more input than just inserting food into my mouth and nodding my head in approval.
author: Garett T.

description: I have been coming here for every new years day sense I was a kid. I love this places the food is amazing. But this year i went with my family and the seating for out side is yes beautiful but the service sucks. Your food is cold you have to constantly ask people to help you and they give you a nasty look. I wish i did get the name of one of your servers because he was just a sweetheart!! He was very helpful and really helped me out. I really hope that next year things will be different. 5 stars the the waiter who helped me out that day. 5 stars on the food (when its hot)
author: W L.

description: Was a tourist here in sf and decided to try a good dim sum place. Unfortunately, we went to the wrong one.. the service was alright but the waitress didn't even tell us how much their dim sum was. We received our bill and it was the most expensive dim sum ever!!   Wth! One of the small course costs $24 and they taste super generic if anything worst than other dim sum places that I've been to. Definitely never again...
author: Christine T.

description:
Definitely worth going to dim sum here if you're in the area.  Other reviewers are certainly right, this is more expensive than your normal dim sum place, but not outrageously so. 

After looking for street parking and circling the block a couple times, I'll save you the trouble and tell you that they validate parking, though I can't give you the details.
author: Michael L.

description: Expensive for a Dim Sum location but well worth paying the extra bucks for great service.  Also, all the dishes are really good too...The shao rong bao is yuuummmyy!!!  And they have the traditional haw kao, siu mai, chicken feet, and pork spare ribs that's really really good.  They have validated parking in the basement of Rincon Center.
author: Jorge C.

description: I've only eaten here once, but it was enough for me to want to finally sign up for a Yelp account. I have no idea why this place gets rave reviews. The dimsum was even hardened at the tips--a sign that it was put in the fridge overnight and steamed again in the morning. This might be because I went there at 11:30 a.m., before the lunch crowd. It seemed they wanted to get rid of last night's leftovers. The sea bass was also hardened on the outside and the inside was not the soft, moist, flaky meat you'd expect. We had about eight dishes total, and I would say six of them were from the day before.
author: M A.

description: Place is legit.  Great vegetarian dim sum items, and usually quick to be seated.
author: Max K.

description:
Way overpriced for what you get.  For my husband and I the total bill was $80 and we didn't order very much.  Nothing was really memorable either. The xiao long bao wasn't really fresh, it seemed like it was sitting there for awhile.  The dim sum staples (sui mai, ha gow, shrimp rice noodle rolls) were good, shrimps were a good size etc but just didn't see the value in it all.  I would prefer going somewhere in Chinatown. 
It definitely has a more upscale atmosphere, service is great and that's really what you're paying for.
author: Tanya N.

description:
I'm not sure what's going on here; I can't tell if their standards have changed or if my expectations have.  We've probably been going to Legendary Palace in Oakland and Grand Fortune in San Jose for a while now over Yank Sing, and it started out purely for budget reasons, but I think my tastes must have genuinely changed.  The hot sauce here doesn't seem hot, the Shanghai dumplings tasted as if they had been circulating on the floor for a while, the pai good didn't have any real good pieces in it.  I gave up on the BBQ pork buns a while ago, I think maybe two and a half to three years ago they changed their supplier on them and I'm not a fan.

Service was good as always, we always make reservations so there's never a problem with a wait.  I think we're going to just strike this place off the list for now though.  I still think it's a great place to bring tourists and when out of towners come that want to go here I'll always take them, but Legendary Palace is Oakland my fave.
author: Kym P.

description: It's been years since I've been to Yank Sing, but they offer by far the classiest dim sum I've ever gone to! Lots of options for vegetarians. It's a San Francisco Must.
author: Kate M.

description: Great dim sum place for large groups because you can make a reservation on Opentable.com. Parking is validated but the spaces are uber tight. Dim sum selection great. Lots of options to choose from when you first sit down. The service though is iffy once you get closer towards the end. Had to flag several servers down for more tea and water.
author: DJ S.

description:
Been here many times because it's close by.  Short wait time too.  But if I had a little extra time I would go elsewhere. The food itself is okay but the selections are limited compared to other dim sum places in the city.  Add on top the $$$, it's just not worth it.

You don't see as many Chinese customers there any more... What does that tell you?
author: Jennifer L.

description: Very clean place; good dim sum.  Friendly staff and very helpful and little on pricey side..
author: Ricky K.

description:
Not sure that this place lives up to the hype, but it's still good. Not sure it's worth the price either, but again, it's still good and it's a nice place to take guests. The carts with different food come by pretty regularly. There's a lot of selection and variety. With all the delicious looking food coming by, things can add up pretty quickly, which is bad news for me since I am really good at spending money and not caring about it until I look at my bank statement later.

Even though on weekends they move some tables out into the "lobby" area of the Rincon Center, it still feels crowded. Also, I called to make a reservation here a couple of days in advance but when I showed up they didn't have my reservation, so if you do make a reservation here you might want to call back at some point and confirm that they have it.
author: Alison B.

description: Considering I've reviewed the other place on Stevenson, I'll add on to this.  First of all, this place is HUGE.  It spills out of the restaurant and into the main atrium.  And even after doing that, you STILL have to wait in line.  So in terms of the food, I stand by my initial review where I love their Peking Duck taco.  Absolutely delish.  The Shanghai dumplings are also delicious, so at least that's consistent.  Everything else was sort of mediocre.  The service, in my opinion, is actually worse here than at their other place.  We were sitting in an area where the carts came by once every 15 minutes with all the same things.  No one came by and asked if we'd like other things on the menu, and no one came by to refill our cold teapot.  It took about 20 minutes for us to get our check, and another 10 minutes to get our cards back after paying.  The total for four people was $120 before tip...WHY? Given that there are only a few things I like at Yank Sing, I probably will start trying to find other places to go for quality dim sum.  At the minimum, I won't be coming back to the Spear restaurant and will opt for the Stevenson location.
author: Lisa I.

description: One of my favourite restaurants in SF. Outstanding. I'm amazed that their overall rating isn't at least 4 stars.
author: Paul W.

description:
I feel a tiny bit embarrassed kind of enjoying my visit.  Liking Yang Sing makes me feel like I'm betraying something.  That something could be my background, my culture, or even my inner being (maybe not my inner being).  Dim sum was (and is) one of my connections I had with my family when I was younger.  Many times we were at a table having dim sum together.  The dim sum here didn't seem like the dim sum of my youth, more a polar opposite. 

After my fifteen minute wait  the buzzer went off, and we were lead to our table.  I got the oolong tea as usual.  The buzzer seemed absurd for dim sum, but was effective.  Absurd because I'm just used to the host or hostess yelling out a number amongst layers of overlapping conversation in a crowd of people.   

I had the day off, and my parents were available.  Bringing them here was only appropriate.  We sampled the typical dim sum fair such as the har gao (shrimp dumplings), shiu mai (pork dumplings), and BBQ pork buns.  They had the normal stuff you'd expect from your usual dim sum parlor.  

I never liked checking off a list and ordering dim sum on the spot.  Watching carts roll around is my preference and this place has carts. 

As their xiao long bao (XBL) was surprisingly good, the general variety served followed that surprising feeling.  The ratio of quality to price still doesn't equate its prices unfortunately.  What I'm saying is it's simply not worth the money you're paying.  The audience they are obviously aiming for is a "non Chinese" (I don't even know why I put this in quotes) crowd, and thus assuming the better service.  Bottom line, personally coined by me the "banana" (white on the inside and yellow on the outside) of dim sum restaurants, offers unchallenged superior level of service for dim sum and the food isn't half bad.  It's just overpriced and doesn't have anything unique enough to back those prices.
author: Arnold T.

description:
The food is pretty good here and the prices are high for dim sum.  Whatever.

But the most notable downside to this place are the pushy dim sum ladies who serve you the food.  They are like sleazy sales people...they put food on your table even though you didn't ask for it.  They literally, set it in front of me.  I had to tell two different ladies that we didn't want the food that they tried to leave there.  

On the good side...the guys pouring water were awesome.  I never had an empty glass.  And they were quick to take away finished dim sum boxes/plates.
author: Christina B.

description: As a Hong Kong resident, I was marginally disappointed with the offering at Yank Sing. I believe that the variety and service is quite westernised, so it is still a good option, but definitely not the place for a traditional Dim Sum experience.
author: William J.

description: The quintessential dim sum experience in San Francisco.  My only complaint is that I prefer a real orderly lunch, you know, starting with salad, then an app, then a entree, etc. and ending up with dessert.   In the chaos of Yank Sing, the ladies come at you with a hodgepodge of dishes.  You choose this, you choose that.  Admittedly, all dishes are really good.  But, who wants to eat dessert before the entree?  But, if you can control your impulses it would be a really great experience.  Of course, I will go again and again, but just be forewarned!
author: Marshall W.

description: Best dimsum in town.. Food is delicious. Food is not oily. Sea bass is excellent. Service is superb.. If you are looking for real dimsum this is the place. Pricy but all I can say it's worth it..
author: Christine m.

description: The very best in food service and presentation of Asian American foods.
author: Kevin R.

description: They have the best dim sum in town but of course it comes with a steep price tag. Their Shanghai dumplings/xiao long baos are the best I've had in the bay. It was as good as the ones we had at Din Tai Fung in Australia. All of their other dishes are delicious, too! Service is good, they're quick and attentive.
author: Phuong H.

description: The very first time I had dim sum I was already in my 30s--yea, how'd that happen?  Was taken to a place in Chinatown I no longer remember the name of--huge place though.  The next time I had dim sum, it was at Yank Sing.  The trick is: take a bunch of people with you so you can taste a lot of dishes.  4 people cannot go through enough food.  I seemed to remember Yank Sing also doing this crab claw dish that was outstanding but the last time I was there (with 20 of my nearest and dearest), they didn't have those claws and I so wanted my dad to have some--he is now dead without having tasted them, so sad.  It's noisy.  We had reservations so I don't know how lucky you can get without them.  We ate a LOT.  I'm not a huge dim sum fan, have to be careful with all the wheat things (all those wrappers, my gut doesn't like wheat) and all that fried stuff.  Still, it is an experience.  I'd like more vegetables though.  But this is not a place for regular dining (cause you have to rustle up 20 of your best friends which isn't that easy to do, everyone is so busy).  Many years ago there was a really good dim sum place in Embarcadero One (maybe some of the same space Crystal Jade now occupied)--they did have crab claws daily, and a take out area too, but they closed.
author: Kai T.

description:
Super overrated, and it doesn't help that this place is on *both* the Michelin Guide and the 7x7 100 things to eat in Sf list. I'm even tempted to give it a 2 star (it's really a 2.5).

I met up with a fellow Hong Kong girl who is just visiting this area. She was craving home food, as was I, as usual. I chose this place because of its fame and convenient location from BART. The location is amazing -- there's "outside" seating in the food court atrium with a gigantic sunroof and a nice water fountain in the middle. The restaurant is clean with nice tableware which is a rare sight in Chinese dim sum restaurants.

However, the food didn't really satisfy our wants (or, ahem, needs) for good dim sum. Our first impression of the har gow (shrimp dumpling) is "ew, it's a bit hard". Indeed, the little dumpling was so stuffed with shrimp they might as well just sell the shrimp filling. The delicate balance of the filling and the skin was destroyed, and that immediately got me disappointed. The siu mai didn't even come close to tasting good, the chicken feet were not marinated enough (you can see the non-colour-stained meat in the inside! Although the sauce is pretty good), and the bbq pork buns just had the wrong dough texture. Other things that were just meh: Rice wrapped in lotus leaves, fried pork dumpling, spring rolls (they serve it with plum sauce, which is wrong! We eat it with worcestershire sauce in Hong Kong).

They redeemed themselves a bit with the XLBs (soup dumplings), since they were quite soupy and the skin was nice and thin. The fillings are still just average but overall it's much better than the usual XLBs you get in the area.

However, when I tried their oh-so-famous sesame balls, my reaction was "ugh, this is tough".  There was too much filling and they were just not fluffy enough. This is their supposedly famous dish? I can find a lot of places in the area with much better sesame balls! Double disappointment at this point.

All-in-all, I did find a dish that I really liked -- the jello "orange slices". The taste was amazingly orangy, the texture a bit more like custard, and I was so ready to have more of it just to offset the other not-so-good dim sum I had.

Ah, the service. At the price of this place, I was expecting to have more than just 3 carts come by my table. We sat on the edge of the outside dining area. While they attempted to fill our table within the first 5 minutes of us sitting down (slow down, geez!), at the end of the meal it seemed like the carts just gave up coming over even when we were ready to order 1 or 2 items more. Also, it was incredibly difficult to get the attention of our server -- they somehow do it U.S. style here, so another server cannot process our bill or anything, and have to help us get our server. Why bother with that at a busy Chinese place?

Summing up, the dim sum here is only average. Not too bad, but I'm not willing to pay so much for just mediocre dim sum, when other mediocre dim sum cost much less. This place is way too overrated and you'll do yourself a favour for not trusting Americans on their idea of what "good" dim sum is.
author: Alice C.

description: Tried this place out a while back and had a fun experience.  The food was good, but as a vegetarian I couldn't partake in much of the dim sum and ordered from the menu, but what I did have was good.
author: A K.

description:
Sesame Balls Sesame Balls Sesame Balls!!!! 
I want them here, I want them there I want Sesame Balls any and everywhere!! 

...but I am getting ahead of myself. 

Brat I, Brat II, Brat IV and Mother Supreme were in for a treat. The weather was oh so nice. The destination was even more so. Yank Sing. My very first Dim Sum, and oooh there is NO better. Let's get right down to it, as here is sincerely is ALL about the food, glorious food. 

Broccoli. Plain, fresh and perfectly palette cleansing between more savory dishes. This is a great choice for a plain little bite. 

Fried String Beans. A little heat, a smattering of salty minuscule dried shrimp and tada! Tasty side dish at which to whittle. 

Pot-stickers. Golden brown outside, yummy meaty inside. A standard. 

Baked Pork Buns & Steamed Pork Buns. Pork Buns as we all know them, are the steamed with the lovely chewy outer, the succulent, pork and sweet/sour inner. These, of course are the best you will ever have of a pork bun. Not at ALL skimpy on the filling and, like everything here, a clean, good flavor. Baked Buns are something I have never seen anywhere else, and having seen them on The Food Network's Best Pork Thing I Ever Ate, I had to try this Brother to the Steamed Bun. A little honey outside, and the same great inside. The baking dries the dough a little more and you miss that chewy perfect texture, so I am going to say - if you only get ONE bun, make it the steamed. 

Roast Duck with Pancake. This is SUCH an unassuming dish, but truly wonderful. The same pork bun dough in a tiny little pancake form that you stuff with your slice of duck, top with shaved onion and gorgeous hoisin. This was simple as could be, but excellent all around. 

Honey Walnut Prawns. Delectable, sweet and fresh fresh prawns in the slightest lobster sauce with toasty, crunchy, beautiful walnuts. So, so very good. 

Red Cabbage Salad. This is the first thing they will ask you if you would like. It doesn't at all look like much, but this was one unassuming dish I could NOT get enough of. So crunchy, a bit citrusy, a bit sweet and a LOT great with cilantro and fennel and more of those lovely walnuts. Yum. 

Now, don't think we forgot about those famous Soup Dumplings. Us newcomers were instant fans and Brat I, Miss Knower of All Things Wonderful, sat and nodded knowingly. These are not to be missed, and 2 orders right away are not frowned upon. 

BUT, the BEST thing - of all these honestly perfect dishes is the Sesame Balls. Coated in toasted sesames, delightfully crunchy outside and so so wickedly chewy inside and then a little dollop of sweet paste, these are definitely one of the best things I have ever had the joy of eating. Forget the damn Lucky Charms- THESE are Magically Delicious.

Yes, Yank Sing is pricey. But paying for great food that you know is clean, fresh, nothing funny going on with the ingredients and leaves you feeling uplifted and not greasy gross - done. 

Yes, I dare say, Yank Sing will inspire you to...Sing!!
author: Katie W.

description:
Best Dim Sum I have had . It was super busy had to wait 30 mins but the staff is very efficient and a show of their own!
Definitely a place to come back to.
author: Jean-Paul D.

description:
Good food but small portions for the price.  But where else you gonna go when your down that far on Market so far away from China Town.  And God help ya if you need to park a car in that area.  

Where oh where...cha ching!  Watch yer wallet...
author: Jacque P.

description: Quality is not bad but the place is way overpriced. You are paying for the location, not the quality of dim sum.
author: R K.

description:
Come here if you are not coming here for the food. :)
Come here if it's a special lunch and you want to impress the guy/girl. But don't come here if you want good food. This place is completely over-priced and you can tell you are really paying for the decor and the nice plates/ teapots. The food is not that good but sure is costly. Will not come back again.... 
The 2 star is for the service and atmosphere.
author: MissJ J.

description:
I love dim sum and Yank Sing is one of my favorite stops for lunch when in SF. 

Pretty much everything here is delicious and service is fast and friendly. It's usually really busy during lunch, but you don't need to wait long to get food in your belly with all the ladies pushing around dim sum trolleys for you to choose from. They also have some really tasty specials on the menu so I always make sure I leave enough room to get a couple orders from the menu in as well.

Go hungry and leave very full and 'dim sum drunk' :)

(oh, and they have a take away counter if are on the go)
author: Jennifer F.

description:
AMAZING.. Hands down the best Dim Sum in USA.  Just control yourself.  Your eyes will be bigger then your stomach.  There is no hurry, so do not grab everything in site.  

Well worth the price, and the fast service makes this a great lunch stop.
author: Meredith A.

description:
We went for a late lunch last Saturday and I have to say, I was very disappointed. We went at 2, which is 2 hours prior to the time they closed, and it seemed like they had very little food left. The carts hardly passed by our table which was unfortunate because we were in the mood to eat. We had to keep flagging someone down to order food. 

They ran out of the baked pork buns which are my favorite so that was a bummer. We ordered the BBQ noodle rolI and never got it.  I also tried the congie for the first time and it was gross. I will never have that again.

I used to love Yank Sing but don't know if I will be back after that last visit.
author: C O.

description:
This review is just for Yank Sing 2go, and only for their lotus-wrapped sticky rice.

Overpriced FiDi food.  Cheap filling of mostly brown sauce.  You're better off going to Clement.
author: XinYi X.

description:
Pricey but very decent food.  

Koi Palace was better but it's also not in San Francisco and your food isn't served in the middle of an atrium with a hanging waterfall (your call as to whether that's a good thing or not.)  

My favorite items were the Shanghai dumplings - same skin as in Din Tai Fong with Joe Shanghai's meat inside and the Roast Pork rice noodles.  Everything else was decent but not amazing.  

Given that we were seated outside the main restaurant, the cart ladies did a pretty good job of making sure we always had food.  

One thing they did stand out for was their tea - it comes in big clear pots and the leaves they use are above average.  I forget what the name of ours was but I really enjoyed it.  

You pay the price, though.  In our case - $34 per person.  About $20 more than I would normally expect.  Could just be SF, though...
author: Simon L.

description:
Best dim sum ever! Everything was so tasty and well presented. I came on a Saturday morning and the place was full. All I could see were many little carts passing each table with a variety of dim sum and I wanted to just run up to one and start munching. 

We got seated fairly quickly and as we sat there was a waitress waiting for us already. Talk about fast service. She offered us the Shanghai dumplings, which were my favorite and highly recommend, and explained what they had and how to eat them. We also tried the steamed pork buns, my second favorite item, and baked bbq pork buns. I was hoping the Peking duck was going to blow my mind but it was just good :/. The little piece of duck meat was pretty dry even after I added the hoisin sauce. The stuffed crab claws, scallion prawns, and shrimp dumpling were really good.
author: Pablo A.

description:
Best Shao lin Bao in the city! Actually, probably the best dim sum in the city. Reserve a table outside, you will get to sit by the coolest rain fountain (a fountain that literally rains down in the middle of the building from 4 stories high) and it's a much nicer dining experience. Inside the restaurant it gets super loud and crowded. Come prepared to spend some dough, because Yank Sing is not cheap. 

Park in the garage at Rincon Center, they will validate for up to 3 hours.
author: Renee T.

description:
The rule of thumb when judging a Chinese restaurant is look at the clientele. The more Asians (specifically Chinese) that patronize the establishment, the better (and more authentic) it is. 

I walked into the Rincon Center and saw lots of white people seated at the tables in the atrium. When I approached the hostess, she greeted me in English. I know I don't look fobby, but I still look Chinese. 

Yank Sing, please prove me wrong.

Did they?  Kinda.

I was really impressed with the Xiao Long Bao, or as they call it the "Shanghai Soup Dumplings."  They are seriously some of the best I have ever had.  Everything else... it wasn't bad.  The authentic stuff was pretty good, but not very outstanding.  Some of the less than authentic dishes (like a candied walnut coleslaw) were also creative and good.

The thing that creeps me out the most was the insistence of the cart pushers of using English.  I don't know what half of Dim Sum is in English:

Me: Yat long Ha Gow (One order of Shrimp Dumplings)
Server: You want Shrimp Dumplings?
Me:  Uhh... Um.... Yeah.

I have never felt so non-Chinese in a place that serves Dim Sum.

This place does have its advantages, Dim Sum is a Chinese family's Sunday brunch so any legit place would be packed on a Sunday afternoon with hour plus waits.  Here, the food is decent and the wait is less this 30 minutes.  My wallet was a lot lighter when I left though.
author: Kenny L.

description:
Probably one of the few clean Chinese restaurants you'll come across that serves good dim sum. This is a popular place upon non-Asians because the real ones know not to pay this much money for food that can easily be found elsewhere. I haven't had anything that I didn't like from here, but I also don't come here very often due to their price tags. This is your typical push-the-cart-around dim sum eatery placed inside a business center. I think the most memorable thing may be the water fountain? Haha.

P.S. Although it carries a hefty tag, the Peking Duck is superrrr yummy! Throw that baby in a bun and slather some sauce on and it's a done deal.
author: Alysia W.

description: Excellent . Been here a zillion times. Very hectic crowded atmosphere , that's Dim Sum. Tourists !!! Make reservations! I saw a few tourist oriented websites that said " just walk in"... Nonsense!! Tourists visitors to my town a reservation will save you HOURS !
author: Armando Z.

description:
Wow! This was a great time! The dishes were in general very good and the atmosphere is clean. 
For a fun meal or date this is a great choice. 
The house tea was soothing and the service is very attentive. 
There is a standout bass dish and the dim sum style gives you a quick chance to sample a number of flavors.
I was even given a chance to speak some Mandarin which was greeted with a smile. :)
author: Josh W.

description:
I came here for lunch one day because it was nearby, convenient and has extremely fast service. The first time I ate lunch here I ordered the chow mein with eggplant special which gave me a bad stomachache. I should have taken that as cue to stop going but eventually I decided to give this place another try.

On try #2 I ordered their dim sum off their special menu. I was given 6 pieces for $12. No dim sum should cost $2/ dumpling. I'm sorry even fine chocolate doesn't even go for that much!

On try #3, I decided to save money and just get the lunch special with chow mein and dumplings. The portion was enormous, and as I bit into my dumpling I actually bit into a pebble. No joke, a small ROCK. I was shocked. Initially I thought maybe it was a clump of spices that didn't dissolve, but no, it was actually a ROCK! I consulted my friend who was sitting with me and she urged me to take it back. I took it back, they apologized profusely and offered to give me free lunch. Sorry, no thank you after all those experiences. 

So even if you manage to avoid stomachaches, rocks, and their expensive dim sum, their food is still very bland. The chow mein seem like they were boiling for hours, there is TONS of greasy oil in their meat dishes, and their dim sum is very subpar.

Do not recommend even if you're trying to have a 5 min lunch!!!
author: Marina S.

description: I dream of their Shanghai Dumplings ! MmmmmMMMmmmmm
author: Brandy R.

description:
Do it like this. Whatever it is, REFUSE the first three dishes that come your way because what happens is you tend to fill up on stuff and then other things come that you want after you're already full. So pace yourself. The pork bun was excellent! As was the sea bass!

Now having said that, the problem with this restaurant is that for the quality of food, it is quite expensive. A lot of the dishes are hit or miss, especially during non-peak hours where every second dish they brought was some type of watery oily dumpling. 

Id suggest, if you go there, get a maximum of 3-4 dishes, and make it stuff you know you really want to get.

Recommendations:
Pork Bun
Sea Bass

Getting one or two items from their to go place is a better idea all together though.
author: Ash S.

description:
OMG this place was good! 
OMG this place was expensive!

This was possibly the best dimsum I've ever had. We just got back from Japan and became dim sum connoisseurs after eating it every other weekend. Every single thing I tried here was cooked to perfection. The sea bass was divine. The shrimp dumpings, pork dumplings, and shrimp egg rolls were mouthwatering. And every thing else was just as good! We went with a large group so it was great to be able to try a bite of everything.

One word of warning. They come by very quickly with the carts so I wanted to grab one of everything at the beginning while I was starving, but then you have way too much food and it's not as fun when the bill comes!
author: Kimberly M.

description:
Another holiday season means another holiday party to plan for my company.  We had Mexican in 2010 so we decided on dim sum this past year.  Their reservation coordinator, Daisy was a huge help and she was always there to answer any questions I had.  We were a party of 20 and they set us up in a private room away from the hustle and bustle of their main restaurant.  Our dining room also had its own private powder room which was a nice touch.  Service was excellent and the dim sum matched their service.  Each dish came out promptly and none of them were greasy as many traditional Chinese dishes can be.  

I've also been to two other wedding banquets here and they were both very good.  This is definitely a place to consider for another group meal.  The dishes cost a tad more than your local hole in the wall dim sum eatery but you're also paying for the service, and presentation which add to the whole enjoyment of the meal.

One of my only gripes about the location is the parking situation.  Although they do validate parking the garage is a sh*t show.  Give yourself time to get out of there because you may be waiting for a while.
author: Rosalind S.

description:
Not bad but pricey.

They have all the standards and the carts seem to be plentiful (dont have to wait long as long as its not somethign specific you want).  We enjoyed everything we had but would have liked more variety.  

I had to specifically ask for steamed pork buns (we saw someone with them but they never came by us) and chicken feet (had not seen anyone with them but when I asked for them I had them in seconds... perhaps they were on a cart but no offered to us non-asians?).

Everyone was friendly and they refilled waters and took empty items away quickly. 

I think next time i will adventure to a chinatown spot and save some $$.
author: J. B.

description: I have been a regular to this restaurant for the last several years.  The food and service used to very good.  I was there today and was very disappointed in both the quality of food and services.  There are four of us; we usually liked to sit in the courtyard without problems.  Today the courtyard was not full; so we asked to be seated outside.  The manager said the tables are for six people.  As a result we can only sit inside; the tables are very close to each other and it was very noisy.  The food was cold; they were not even warm.  We asked for the dark tea, and they gave us green tea instead.  The tea did not have any flavor.  The four of us had a total bill of $192.  When we left the restaurant, we noticed the Caucasians - the party of two and four were eating at the courtyar.  I would never return to this place again.  For the money we spent, we can get very good service and food elsewhere.
author: Jane B.

description: Some of the best dim sum in SF.  Ingredients are fresh and cooked well.  For dim sum, the food is not greasy and the flavors are clean, which can be said for a lot of the cheaper dim sum places in the city.  The only drawback is the cost, probably the most expensive dim sum in the city, but well worth it.  And they take reservations, but only for large parties (8 or more, i think)
author: Jason M.

description: Dim Sum! Shanghai Kurobuta Pork Dumpling are one of the restaurant's signature items, made here with the upscale ingredient of minced Kurobuta pork, along with scallion and ginger. They were actually quite nice, with a lovely pork relish, a delicate wrapper, and a savory soup released upon mastication. Worth every penny.
author: Joy T.

description:
This review is for their take-out express section in Rincon

Limited selections with a couple of daily specials  but everything is favorful and very reasonably priced.

Love the chiken salad and potstickers. Cant go wrong with the dim sum items
author: San P.

description: Good experience, good food.  Not outstanding, but I'm not a huge dim sum fan.  All aspects well-executed but make no mistake, this is a factory.  It was on our bucket list, and if it's on yours then go for it.
author: harold k.

description: PRICEY! But...  The food was really good, service was great, busy but I was seated immediately.   I have a feeling you could get just about the same elsewhere in SF for probably half the price.   Sometimes you just have to treat yourself.
author: Wes H.

description:
Yay! I'm a fan, if I'm rich~
I'm here for the xiao long bao which is amazingly delicious!!! After years in SF, I haven't have any good xiao long bao like this. Thin skin with full of filling and juicy soup inside is so wonderful. However, they are super expensive. An order of xiao long bao comes with 6 for almost $12 dollors.  The veggie spinach dumpling is very tasty too. 
I really like this place but I'm afraid I won't visit it again in the near future. The whole experience for two people costs us more than $90 in total. The most expensive dim sum I ever had.
author: JustinE Y.

description: Way over priced! The dim sun quality was poor. Most dim sum came our room temperature. It feels like they have been sitting there for while, not fresh made. We were so disappointed.
author: Na L.

description:
Expensive dim sum. Very expensive imo. Just because it is located in the financial district? Well, it taste pretty good though, had to admit that. I dont know which is better, here or Koi palace. But I know for sure Yang Sing's chili paste is awesome. I cant describe it, but it is great. 
valet parking voucher available when you eat here. 2 hour free.
PS, dont dress too casual here, you WILL feel out of place. This is not one of those typical chinese restaurant.  Think financial district
author: Albert W.

description:
Went here on a Saturday during the lunch hour...

Pros: Fast service with great food. I 143 the Mango Pudding...

Cons: Although you may turn over your order invoice which indicates that your done ordering...the dishes keep coming!!!
author: Carrie G.

description:
Man, I hate giving 5 stars to businesses, because I'll feel bad if they let me down on a subsequent visit.  But I'm going to take a chance on Yank Sing.  

Dim Sum used to be one of my least favorite dining experiences.  I found the experience at all restaurants to be similar.  Long and haphazard waits (people being seated randomly it seems), non-existent service, loud, crowded, and sometimes not a very "clean" facility.  Now, some people like this type of thing, I personally hated it, so avoided Dim Sum like the plague.

Then my wife and I decided to try this place.  My wife is an established Dim Sum "veteran", so she immediately noticed the prices.  She says it's basically double what you'd pay for a comparable item at a regular Dim Sum place.  But then she also says food-wise it's the best quality Dim Sum she's had as well.  

I personally think the food is excellent, and most importantly, consistent.  We've been going about once a month over the last year, and each time the food quality has been high.  Yes the XLB lives up to the hype.  And a bunch of other stuff my wife orders us that I still don't quite know how to spell.  

But more importantly, I really like the overall experience, in stark contrast to all other Dim Sum restaurants I have tried.  Yes there is a wait, but it's quite orderly and efficient.  Longest we've had to wait without a reservation is 30 minutes.  The restaurant does get packed, but at the same time not as claustrophobic as other places.  And the servers are actually fairly polite and friendly, and they'll bring specific items out for you if you don't see it on a cart and they have it available.  Very prompt in cleaning off plates and getting your check as well.  Clean facilities.

Overall, I am giving this place 5 stars because Yank Sing has made Dim Sum one of my least favorite dining options to one of my most favorite.  I always look forward to making it out to YS when I am in the City.
author: Leo C.

description:
Yay! It was my first Dim Sum Food experience!  Excellent food!  There is so much going on when they come to offer food you get to see what it looks like before you say yes which is fun.  It was really good, I liked the little soup pouches- I forgot what they are called!! 
Really great service too!
author: Rachel N.

description:
I'd say 4 stars for the food, 2 stars for the price and service.

Came here for lunch just before noon with the bf.  I really liked their signature dish, the Shanghai dumpling, it reminded me of won ton soup.  A few of their dishes are assembled in front of you, which probably adds to their expensive prices.  For the two of us, it cost about 70 bucks without tip and I know we weren't full.  Service sucked too, it took forever for the carts to circle around and it seemed like they rarely made it to certain areas.  However, you can get free parking if you get your parking ticket validated by the restaurant.  They also have a cool looking glass teapot.
author: Joycelyn L.

description:
Wow, just about the best dim sum I've ever had.  The only reason it doesn't get 5 stars is that the prices our outrageous.  And I didn't like the fact that you can't see the prices.

On busy weekend days this place is packed (or even during peak hours) and it's pretty much expected you'll queue up for a table.  But if you're willing to spend the dough it's worth the taste.  Just for comparison, I can have dim sum with a group for about $10-15pp in Chinatown or Inner Richmond, but here I'd budget maybe $35-40pp.

Other than prices, the food is outstanding.  You name it, they have it.  Carts come by with great frequency and anything you don't see just ask a passing waiter.  Service staff cleans the table quick as well.

Probably the best items to get are the standard shrimp dumplings, Shanghai dumplings (xiao long bao), and the absolute best was the sea bass (it literally melts in your mouth as it's so soft, and the flavor just screams deliciousness in your mouth).

Overall a fantastic place, just very pricey.
author: Andrew Y.

description: One of the best foods I had ever tasted. It was overpriced, but I still give them 5 stars. Service was good, too. My mom said that when I went to San Francisco 6 years ago, there were many very good tasting foods that were taken away. I can't imagine the restaurant better.
author: Vikram A.

description: This is the most over priced dim sum in my life. The dim sum and the service was ok. After ordering the first several dishes then looking at the prices, I was shocked. Left feeling hungry and wallet was a lot lighter.
author: Alice M.

description:
Disclaimer- We went a few years ago and it is possible it could have changed since then.
For those from NYC if you have not had Dimsum in San Fransisco or Hong Kong you haven't had Dimsum! 
To you reviewers who try to say this is or isn't Hong Kong Style, have you ever even been to Hong Kong? Or have you been lately?  This is the best Dimsum we have had in the US. Yes I have had Dimsum in Kong Kong. My issue with those comparing it to Kong Kong is that there is not just one style of restaurant or even just one style of Dimsum in Hong Kong. Hong Kong has every type of restaurant ad every type of Dimsum the states has and more. Having said all of that Yank Sing was far better on every level in every way than any Dimsum I have had in NYC. I actually do not review them (NYC Dimsum restaurants)  they are so bad. Their menus are limited and they are all pretty filthy and with a life threatening shell fish allergy I have found that NYC Dimsum puts me in danger every time! I ask if there is shell fish and they always say no in NYC. My husband even asks in Chinese so it is not a language barrier. And no I am not allergic to all sea food. I got nasty message from some weirdo here at Yelp saying if you are allergic to seafood blah blah blah... I am not allergic to sea food and eat Seafood more than any other cuisine. I am just allergic to shrimp. And I wasn't always. It is a relatively new allergy. But I digress...
Yank Sing was clean, the service was good, and the food was good. But what I liked about it the most is the menu was very extensive. I have been to all of the top Dimsum in NYC and we have NOTHING like Yank Sing in the 5 boroughs. The closest I have had to Yank Sing was in Hong Kong which is why I am mentioning Hong Kong. I do not think most of those who are mentioning Hong Kong have actually been there. Hong Kong has some cutting edge restaurants. Some are dirty like here in NYC and some are very stylish and clean which we do not have here in NY not for Dimsum. Some are like Yank Sing in Hong Kong   and some are very Americanized for tourists and some are old school. There isn't one style of Dimsum in Hong Kong. So having said all of that it is the closest to what I have had in Hong Kong. We had Dimsum at several restaurants in Hong Kong.
Yank Sing got the James Beard award and is also in the Michelin guide. It was also voted one of the top Chinese restaurants in the US. http://top100.chinesemenu.com/event/2010/en/winner.asp
My Chinese husband liked it a lot! He is hard to please as far as Chinese food goes because he cooks it better than any restaurant we have been to in the US. He said the thing he liked about it the most was that it seemed more like an authentic Dimsum "experience" than any Dimsum restaurant in NYC,  he explained that in NYC they rush you and most restaurants here are rude and dirty. He said the presentation at Yank Sing  is more professional and more like what we had in Hong Kong.
At Yank Sing the experience itself seemed to be more like what we have experienced in Hong Kong. If and when we go to San Fransisco again we would love to go back and try it again. Some say it has changed. It is worth a visit to find out.
The thing about having Dimsum in San Fransisco that is different than NYC is it seems everyone has Dimsum. It seems to be a part of the culture there. 
Also all of the servers spoke Cantonese unlike  Ton Kiang where they did not speak Cantonese. http://www.yelp.com/biz/ton-kiang-san-francisco#hrid:-ZcurFux6rQdaxisRB_Pug/src:self
My favorite part of the meal was the Peking Duck. 
The only real down side was the price. But you do get what you pay for!
 And if you don't believe me at least believe San Fransisco resident and foodie extraordinaire Jeff W.
author: Pinky And The B.

description:
During my initial encounters with Yank Sing, my brain was singularly fixated on the xiao log bao and pea shoot dumplings. In my recent visits with my eyes no longer drowning in earthy greens and gelatinous pork broth, I have found a new champion among the gaggle of choices:

Har gao. The best of its kind that I have ever eaten; subtly pink shrimp meat packs the translucent, angelic skin. The bite is silky yet still has that velvety, toothsome snap that all crustaceans should aspire to. The flavor is sweet, buttery shrimp punctuated by a kiss of sesame. The little pouches are sublimely synaesthetic wonders; the subtlety belies their intense complexity.

Yank Sing certainly will never be one of my regular hangouts, but every once in a while (usually twice within a week-long period because after the first time you compulsively run back for more) it's worth the splurge. Making reservations is just icing on top of frighteningly efficient high-volume service.
author: Nuri K.

description: I give them a star for good food. But the downfall is that the chefs use the bathroom and not soap their hands afterwards. Not only that, they go into the toilet with the same apron they go into the kitchen. Talk about bad hygiene.  Now that I think about it the food was a little salty. And I never Yelp, so you should consider this serious.
author: Zeeni N.

description:
Went in with high expectations and left with my wallet feeling lighter.  

This place is huge!  Not just one area to eat but two!  There is a main restaurant and it expands outside to the mall area.  We got a table for two during their peak hours within 5 minutes (Noon)  :)  

There was a wide variety of dim sum to choose from but nothing out of the ordinary.  The food was tasty but came with a 30% mark up compared to other places in town.  

I don't see the reason for the mark up on the dim sum since its nothing to brag about.  I know I didnt pay anything extra besides the food because the service and ambiance was average at best.

Besides this place being gigantic it's nothing special.

"Average dim sum and service for above average prices.  Asi Asi"
author: Junho S.

description: This is really one of my favorite restaurants ever. Don't miss the BBQ pork buns and soup dumplings. And take the advice I ignored: order slowly.
author: Eric B.

description:
We originally were going to Fook Yuen in Millbrae, but they were closed. My parents haven't been to this place so we thought we'd bring them here at least once. It was an overall great experience, but I still think the food is not that great and it's way overpriced.

Teas are of high quality and good. Service is impeccable! If you don't see something you want, just tell anybody and they will bring it to you ASAP Decor is upscale and clean. We were bombarded with food the moment we sat down, which was both good & bad since we got what we wanted, but the food got cold.

GET:
- Shanghai Dumplings: tasty soup, thin skin, good meat = excellent (we got 4 orders of this =X)
- Sea Bass: delicious and cooked to a nice tenderness served with teriyaki sauce
- Chicken Lotus Leaf Rice Wrap: delicious mix of rice and meats
- Steamed Egg Custard Buns: not bad, good bread, filling is okay
- Fried Sesame Balls: not overly sweet filling, nice chewy outer layer with crispy sesames
author: Linda C.

description:
I think this place is a little pretentious and have never returned having found more affordable, and better tasting dim sum else where.

We came here after glowing reviews on yelp and were very disappointed. We left after a few dishes and went elsewhere.
author: Y B.

description:
Dim sum in a food court setting (if you sit in the outside tables). 

Food is decent with all the usual suspects and I really like how they take reservations. That's a BIG plus 

Parking:  3 hrs free with validation! BUT garage spots are *really* cramped and need help getting into and out of spots
author: Annie c.

description:
Tasty, fresh, perfectly steamed BBQ pork buns on demand?  YES PLEASE!  These buns are - chewy, sweet, savory, fluffy and filling rolled into one tiny little fist sized package.  Albeit expensive, this is by far the best dim sum place in the city.  It is practically impossible for one to leave this place unsatisfied -even the pickiest eaters can find something that they will enjoy!

Give this place a shot (but keep an eye on your tab, it gets pricey --fast!)
author: Lindsay P.

description:
I've been going to Yank Sing for over a decade now. Either my taste buds have become more picky or this place has gotten worse over the years.  Maybe it is a combo of the two.  Regardless, the food here has sadly become ordinary for me.  Nothing mind-blowing.  You can get just as good dim sum for cheaper elsewhere.  

BTW, the parking lot in Rincon Center is ghettttoooo. Worst ever. Free on Saturdays and Sundays, but its layout makes parking headache inducing.  Get street parking if you can.
author: Sean B.

description:
We are not locals, so when we are in the area, we really enjoy stopping  here for some nice dim sum. 

Our usual order are shrimp dumplings (har-gow), juicy pork dumplings, baked sea bass, sticky rice with pork filling wrapped in a banana leaf.  Almost always, the food has been great. Also, they make their own chili XO sauce ( which can also be bought) and it goes really well with the dumplings. 


Service is always on point. It is more on the pricey side compared to most dim sum restaurant. But if you are looking for quality ingredients, this is where you will find it.  
Note: Hot tea will be charged per person at the table (not free)
author: Jennifer T.

description: Yes, indeed...The dim sum is expensive here; but judging from the zip-code of its location, it certainly is no surprise. Some of the food was not bad (XLB's, lo bak gou, ha gou). If you happen to be in the neighborhood, and somehow have busted legs and cannot get over to the central part of SF (hint-hint: HKL - OUTER RICHMOND, HKL2 - LAUREL HEIGHTS), then I guess 3-star YS will do.
author: Derek N.

description:
