This place whips up some delicious dim sum and is staffed with some outstanding employees.  I just had the pleasure of dining here again for lunch last week.  I had a lunch date with a family friend on the day of Chinese New Year.  This place was PACKED.  At most Chinese restaurants busy means chaos, which translates to terrible service.  I mean I totally forgot what to expect, given that it's been about five years since I've  been back here.  My expectations were surpassed.  Our server named Ed took great care of our table.  

Everything I ingested during the meal was of top-notch quality.  Come here for the dim sum staples like har gow, siu mai, etc, but make sure you try their Shanghai dumplings and other specialties.  I find it nice that they still utilize the carts and trays to showcase their selection.  The traditional way ROCKS, because I don't like it when other places put in your orders after you mark them down on a menu.  It really dampens my dim sum mood.  I like to pick what my stomach desires by looking at the dishes as they roll by the table.
author: Sharon L.

description:
My mom almost died at Yank Sing. 

No, not because she was poisoned or anything. Granted, everything here tasted like it'd been watered down and tamed to "American" taste buds that there really would be no chance of poisoning anybody. 

No, my dad ordered the Peking Duck, which was $6, and when the plate was set down, she choked in shock when she saw that ONE ORDER of Peking Duck meant ONE SLICE OF PEKING DUCK. My dad had to pound her back, probably re-igniting her scoliosis, but at least she didn't die of laughter. But really? One slice? One. Slice.

Other Lowlights:

A saucer-plated salad made of shredded cabbage, sugar and mayonnaise was $9.60. Really? For oversweet coleslaw!??!!?

$6 for ONE LETTUCE CUP. One tiny dome of lettuce, with about 3 spoonfulls of minced chicken. For Six Dollars.

Then there was the Special Shanghai Kurobuta Pork Dumplings. My dad asked the waitress what this was for $11, and she was all "Blah blah, scripted answer, blah blah, Xiao Long Bao" and my dad was all, "WTF Srzly??? Then why is you callin' it this Kurobuta nonsense????" And to that, the lady had no answer.

Yank Sing was astonishing to say the least. It makes me sad that they can get away with these prices because there are many people who are ignorant of better and cheaper options in Chinatown or the Richmond or East Bay.

The only highlight? The ice-filled urinals. It was like peeing in the snow at Tahoe, taking me away from this place and the horrifying thought that I just spent $60 on dim sum for THREE people.
author: Joshua L.

description:
Is it me...or does Yank Sing sound like the name of a castration clinic? A painful one for that matter. I don't think I'd sing "Ah, Sweet Mystery of Life" if someone yanked my willie. Maybe that's why I don't come here much. Actually, it's because the place is a zoo at lunch time, and besides, their next-door fast-food kiosk, Yank Sing 2 Go, usually fits my needs on a workday.

Anyhow, my longtime friend Debbie and I came here for lunch yesterday, and yes, it was a zoo. You would think the Rincon Center would be the sole bastion of the white collar drone, but somehow the anti-contraceptive-using families of tourists find it and take control of the bigger tables. We were stuck at a little table for two where the dim sum carts recklessly careen. They should have those glue-on plastic shields on the chairs to prevent scratches, or better yet, they should just apply them on me so I don't get scratched.

I needed to go the restroom when we got there, a point I usually would omit in a Yelp review except for what I saw once I was in the men's room - a mountain of ice cubes in the urinal. It was the oddest thing I ever saw though it did make my cheb sack tingle. When I got back to the table, I noticed a see-through pot of tea on the table. I passed. I know what teabagging means, but for Pete's sake, not at the table!

Anyway, we chose things off the carts speeding by like dragsters. Usually, the woman would say something indecipherable, and then Debbie and I would look at each other for mutual agreement or dissension. However, if this process took more than two seconds, that cart was gone...history...already at the table three aisles down. Yes, this is no place for any of the current Presidential candidates to eat since it requires decisive measures implemented quickly.

Shanghai dumpling. Shrimp dumpling. Chicken fun gwor. Green beans in pork. Broccoli spears. Tasty enough...though still no Ton Kiang from my limited perspective. We were done in a relative flash, and believe me, you want to come in and out quickly to avoid fifth-degree burns from the speeding carts. Be mindful that at $4 to $7 a plate, this place ain't cheap, and even though Debbie was treating, I was feeling a twinge of guilt after the fifth plate. I got over it.

FOOD - 3.5 stars...reliable dim sum for the city...hits the necessary spot
AMBIANCE - 3 stars...Grand Central Chaos...and they have ice cubes in their urinal..Scotch rocks, anyone?
SERVICE - 3 stars...the waitresses have been known to be ticketed for their steering
TOTAL - 3 stars...a dim sum option in the FiDi is essential...not sure it has to be this one
author: Ed U.

description:
I'm not used to "nice" dimsum. You know, the kind where they don't have a health inspectors report with ONE STAR displayed proudly in the middle of everything? 

So I came here on a date. However, said-date didn't show up for 45 minutes.  When you have to wait for that long, it doesn't matter if they show up with a pair of roundtrip first-class tickets to Paris--you're going to be a little peeved. 

So I sat there denying goodies. Also denying things that didn't look so goody. They didn't have quite the range of dim sum that I'm used to--maybe because its better here, who knows. I was quasi-disappointed in selection, regardless. 

And the waiting.

I'll hold off on coming here again. If I want good dim sum, I'm going to go into the middle of Chinatown like my friend from high school does all the time. 

Meh.
author: Jaime L.

description:
For their steamed bbq pork bun: I generally don't usually eat pork buns but the ones here actually are good! The red sauce they use in their bun is very particular and you won't confuse it to elsewhere. It has much more flavor compared to just the general sweet, vinegar sauce like other places.

+ to-go and take out available

Haven't tried the rest of their dim sum but I really need to get myself
author: Tiffany N.

description:
Met Friend One here for lunch.

Took Friend Two here to meet Friend One.

Thought they should meet each other.

They talked through the entire lunch.

I sat back quietly, listened and just ate.

One of my friends paid for lunch.

See my plan?  

FANTASTIC AND FREE LUNCH!
THIS PLACE ROCKS!
author: Rachel C.

description: Normally,  nearly no Asians patrons at a  dim sum place  is a bad sign.   This is the exception.   Xia long bao (sp?)   are the best.   Surprisingly less greasy than the usual dim sum.   Service is a bit pushy...  But it would not be dim sum otherwise..  Eg,  the golden unicorn in  NY...
author: Bruno L.

description: Had a short lunch with friends here on Saturday and she was surprised that there was no wait at all! The restaurant was fully seated and it looked much less like the other Chinese dim sum places... Anyway, the food in general is decent but since I'm a huge fan of Xiao Long Bao, I was very satisfied. The closest to Ding Tai Fung that you can get in SF I think?
author: Goby Y.

description:
I'm not a fan of Yank Sing's. Why? Well, because with the number of restaurants in the Bay Area alone which serves up authentic dim sum, why even bother going somewhere where the dim sum is catered towards Western palates?

Most of the offerings aren't even Chinese: crab rangoon? I mean seriously! Where does one find cream cheese in a bit of fried wonton skin in Hong Kong?

Although the food isn't all that here, I do like some of the more 'healthy' versions of their chef's creations. I've tried some chicken dumplings before and others which just sound too fusiony to remember. However, having said that, the restaurant itself is rather nice and they serve their tea in really 'fancy' looking teapots, not like those you get in Chinatown where there are chips here and there and the place is dirty and the staff don't speak Chinese.

Ask yourself what you want. An authentic dim sum experience like that in the old country? Or do you want something that you see out of a James Clavell mini series?
author: Anita L.

description: Really awesome dim sum, not really my thing - but if you're gonna go, go for the best in SF!
author: Brendon K.

description:
I'm thinking... 3.5 stars...

I've been to plenty of Dim Sum restaurants...  I've managed banquets and catering for an Asian Fusion restaurant that served Dim Sum... and I have to say, this place is seriously expensive!

I'm the last person to whine about pricey food, if it tastes good.  I'm not saying the Dim Sum at Yank Sing didn't taste good, but it didn't taste any better than the other restaurants I've dined at that charged $3-$5 per dish.  I'm not even sure how much each dish cost, as we were starving and just saying yes to most of the items coming around on the cart, but I know that my friend and I spent almost $40 each.

The one dish that stood out most, was the fried crab claw.  Mmmm. So perfectly cooked and juicy yet crispy on the outside... love.

We were very disappointed to learn that they didn't serve hot and sour soup (maybe just during lunch?).  That was the #1 thing we were looking for.  Our server told us that they didn't have any soup at all, but then came back halfway through our meal to tell us that she had asked the chef if he could prepare something quick and simple.  We said yes, and she came back out with a big bowl of chicken and vegetable soup.  It was simple, but I was craving some hot broth.  I thought that was nice that she had asked, but maybe that's what had made our bill so high!  Ha, oh well.

Yank Sing was very busy!  The place is very clean, yet the entrance was located on a small alleyway side-street.  I would've never noticed it if my friend had not suggested it.

This probably won't be my first choice if I'm looking for Dim Sum next time in the city, and definitely not for my hot and sour soup craving, :( but if I'm invited out by someone, I wouldn't mind returning.
author: Gina L.

description:
By far the best dim sum place that I have tried, but you really pay for it. The Shanghai Little Dragon Dumplings are the best I have had in the U.S. 

They have a very large selection of dum sum and it usually get to your table pretty fast. You can always order directly for the waiter if you don't want to wait.

The only down side to this place is the wait; so, I recommend get there early or have a late brunch.
author: Mike K.

description:
You wouldn't normally find me at Yank Sing because first off, it's just damn expensive for dim sum.  But it's oh so good though!

When you're dining with table cloth napkins, that should be a sure bet that your lunch won't be a cheap one.  And when your tea arrives in a fancy teapot like the ones here, that's another sign that you better have brought the good plastic to pay for your meal!

I love love love their Shanghai dumplings ("A Yank Sing signature dish of minced Kurobuta Pork, scallion and ginger, wrapped and steamed in its own aromatic broth.").  Yes, it's their signature dish and I have no complaints about that.  They even provide a soup spoon for everyone just so you don't lose any of that yummy soup goodness when you bite into this heavenly morsel.  And don't forget the red vinegar because that's what makes that little dumpling steam!  

I love their deep fried tofu wrapped in seaweed.  Yeah, not something you would normally find in dim sum, but still damn good!  Their individual servings of Peking Duck ("A Yank Sing Signature dish, house-roasted Peking Duck served as a deem sum appetizer, Crispy paper thin honey-coated skin and tender slices of succulent meat stuffed in a steamed seashell bun, accompanied with finely slivered scallions and smears of tangy hoisin sauce.") and Lettuce Cups are a nice way to sample what is normally reserved for banquets or large dinner parties.  

Their Egg Custard Tarts ("Warm oven-baked velvety smooth and sweet egg custard in flaky pastry tart shell.") have been a hit or miss over the years.  They used to be miniature ones and tasted so good.  And then they became the regular size ones, and it wasn't so nice anymore. But on my last visit, the little ones were back and they were good! 

Overall, their dim sum is pretty fresh and they have a pretty huge variety.  Everything looks visually appealing, so you can't help but want to try it all. And plus, most of the staff speaks English, so they are more than helpful when explaining what all the little plates are.  And service here is considered fabulous compared to other dim sum restaurants around.  You never have to ask for your teapot to be refilled because they can see for themselves when it needs to be and it gets whisked away before it's half way empty.  

They offer indoor seating and outdoor seating in the atrium, which leads to a minimal wait on a weekend.  And with free parking available in the garage downstairs, it beats circling the block a few hundred times in Chinatown looking for a space.  When I want to spoil myself, I'll come here.  But like I said, this is a special occasion kind of place!
author: Teri C.

description: Good service as for every waiter and waitress can speak English, but the place does not have authentic dim sum necessarily. It is expensive and not worth for the try.
author: Shuyin Christal W.

description:
Might be the best dim sum place in all of S.F. Inside famous Rincon Center, the atrium features a waterfall in the center courtyard and diners can eat around it (outside of the main dining hall.) 

There is always a large wait, but it is so worth it. Service is no less than on point, friendly, and attentive without being pushy. They have perfected the art of serving tea, loose leaf of course. And the dan-tat, baos, shu-mai, ha-gao, and xiao long baos are my favorite. I grew up eating these and hold every other dim sum restaurant from then on to Yank Sing's standard :)

Next time I'm home, of course my first stop in the city is Yank Sing, naturally!
author: Lauren N.

description: Food is delicious.  Does it worth the money? maybe not.  I prefer Crystal Jade or Koi palace for the money :)
author: Lyn L.

description: Food was good, service was alright- but for the 'so-called' best dim sum in SF, they did not live up to any sort of expectation. Especially with the cold food and slow rotations after the 45 minute wait for a table.
author: Harry J.

description: Delicious Dim Sum and their signature Shanghai Dumplings are scrumptious beyond words. Prices and the line add up quickly but it's a great experience.
author: Victoria K.

description:
This is the best place for dim sum in San Francisco for the quality of the dishes, decor and service.  The variety may not compare to that of Koi Palace in Daly City, but it's dim sum at its finest if you don't mind spending a bit more for this level of sophistication.  A perfect example of this refinement is evident from a taste of the steamed pork bun with the soup encased in a thin skin.  This is comparable to that of the most famous places in Taiwan.  Moreover, they have chilean sea bass and other higher end dishes for you to try.  

Parking is tough on the street with metered parking, but they validate for garage parking.
author: Jenny L.

description:
This place is very overrated. I came with my family and we were incredibly disappointed. It's not only overpriced but also the food was not even close to good. 

If you're like me and grew up with lots of traditional Asian food and plenty of trips to dim sum restaurants, this place is NOT for you. I grew up in Pittsburgh and we would drive 2hours to dim sum in CLEVELAND, OHIO and it was great. This place is a joke compared to it. Needless to say my family and I were incredibly disappointed to find that this was the kind of top rated dim sum place in the Bay Area.
author: Jessica C.

description:
Best service ever...they remember us and greet us with excellent service, without fail!
I mean everyone....the ladies pushing the carts and the lady who maintains the restrooms....

The best dim sum in the Bay Area....my Italian mother-in-law is a big fan like us : )
author: Barb L.

description:
Yummy, yummy, YUMMY, YUMMY!!!

This place is yummy.
author: Teabags L.

description:
I was born and raised in Oakland Chinatown. 

BBQ pork buns are 50 cents each.

BBQ pork buns are $2.25 each here, and not even as good.

This is just one example out of a hundred.

Pro: tea here is good, egg custard tarts are good and very buttery.
author: Adrienne C.

description: Da bomb!!! What else is there to say. Oh yeah, soup dumplings. Yelp said my opinion is on the short side so I need to bloviate a little more. Better now?
author: Mark L.

description: I hate the parking situation at this place.  Terribly small, surprise I even found one underneath that garage, but at least it is FREE.  The place is always packed.  The food is your typical dim-sum.  Overpriced for sure.
author: Trynh K.

description: I like Dim Sum, I've had Dim Sum at the best places in the Bay Area and in Las Vegas, NV... This place is my Favorite!
author: Tage H.

description:
Get the egg custard and the shanghai dumplings. Simply amazing. Expensive... but amazing. Also good are the Siu Mai and most of the traditional dim sum stuff. Stay away from their high margin upsell items like the seabass, 

5 stars for the food, 4 because of the price, 3 because of the high margin upsell items they push quite hard.
author: Brandon O.

description:
Price/Portions:
Any small plate you pick up is either $10-25,  2 small pork buns $10.  For real?  We tried to order a small portion of chicken fried rice for my kid sister and they said the dish only comes family size so we said yea ok.  The family size portion turned out to be any regular sized fried rice plate for the price of...can you guess? $24. Fried rice homies, with barely any chicken.  For real? Lol.

Quality:
Maybe because Im so used to LA and OC dim sum being so bomb, this is just average.  Ok maybe its a tad bit above average, but it can't even touch OC dim sum.  When food is expensive I expect a lot, what I got was far less than what I paid for.

Helpful tip:
If you want to make sure your bill is correct, you best keep track of everything you order bc you wont understand most of it unless you can read the language.  I honestly didn't know the cost of each item till the bill came and was quite surprised.

Bill: Breakfast for 7 and a kiddo, $245 not included tip.

Overall, ok service, average dim sum quality, overpriced, will not be a returning customer.
author: Tommy M.

description:
The food is good, the servers are a little too pushy for comfort, the wait for a table is long, and the prices are obscene. My co-worker and I decided to treat ourselves to a nice lunch, but we didn't count on spending $60 (including tip) for 4 dishes.

Next time we want dim sum, we'll walk over to Chinatown.
author: Michele N.

description:
They don't even have congee with thousand year-old egg!! Gentrified dim sum at its finest.  Not in a good way.  Dim sum isn't supposed to be fancy shmancy.

That said, the dim sum is still very well made.  Their XLB was pretty good, but it didn't melt my heart like XLB I've tried in LA.  It's just hard to call it Chinese, especially after the spinach tortellini.  It's almost fusion.
author: Trinity G.

description: It gets busy so prepare for a little wait. The atrium seating area is nice. There's water sprinkling down from the center of the ceiling and it brings in a lot of natural light. Dim sum was delish! Only thing I did not like was the sticky rice. Ordered the chrysanthemum tea which went perfect with the meal.
author: Nikki P.

description:
It's pricey, but you're paying for a large selection of dim sum, clean silverware, location in the financial district, and friendly service. 

I recommend the xiao long bao (theirs has a good soup to meat ratio), spinach dumplings, honey walnut prawns, house salad, pecking duck, and sea bass.
author: Jen G.

description: Best dim sum I've ever had in the U.S. Even better than the one I used to go to in my hometown (Wuhan, China). It is a little pricey though.
author: Yushan Z.

description:
The perfect dim sum place for the tourist from Nebraska. If you like orange chicken, you'll love Yank Sing. If everything looks like a "dumpling" to you, then definitely hit this place up.

Possibly the most overpriced, lowest quality dim sum joint in the Bay Area. Next time you visit, just order some ha gow and keep this in mind: there is more cornstarch in it than shrimp. And that half a gram of shrimp was frozen for a couple years. If you pay attention, you'll see. 

The secret to their success: The decor is awesome--right out of Balls of Fire or The Last Emperor. The service is Caucasian-friendly. And location, location, location!

Funny fact: their delivery van says "Yank-ing" when the door is open.
author: Jeff K.

description:
Good dim sum.  Really creative items.  
Good food anyway.
Great service.
Great decor.
Place lives up to its reputation.

My only problem: it's too expensive for everyday goers!  It's just expensive!  

I would recommend this place for first time goers...because it is safe for those who have tender stomachs!
author: Fannie S.

description:
consistently serving quality dim sum and some unique AZN fusion offerings. somewhat California-ized (is that a word?) Honk Kong style food, but still very good. perfect business lunch spot because the food arrives quickly, service is efficient and friendly and the company is paying for a great lunch. Koi Palace is more HK authentic but the service and atmosphere is much better here at Yank Sing. the XO condiment sauce is incredible. what is in it? it is a combination of dried shrimp, dried scallops, garlic, and other seasonings. slight fire but mucho flavor. 
YS also sells it by the jar.

this location in the Rincon Center is larger and can accommodate larger groups a little easier. plus you get to walk by the incredible Rincon Center four storied water fountain with live music during lunch time!
author: Jeff W.

description:
delectable small plate dim sum...carefully presented....greater than norm price tag to match...dim sum for the higher socioeconomic class in society..particularly sf....from the crystal clear teapots...to immaculate presentation...high power chinese food for the buisness luncheon with an expense account....

often seated in the overflow area of the rincon center lobby...west meets east feel....while dining inside the interior is mostly preferred for faster service.....from steamed dumplings to sticky rice...experience has been "fresh" and "hot"....consistent...but..for an afternoon weekend meal....bit "touristy" for my liking....for options for dim sum in sf seems endless for similar with reduced prices...
author: Hen A.

description:
I had the privilege of sitting at the same table with the owner of Yank Sing. (This may or may not have biased this review, but in all fairness, I did not know he was the owner until after having tasted the food). 

Hands down, some of the BEST xiao long bao I've ever had in my entire life! The wrapping is delicate yet doesn't rip, well stocked with hot savory soup, and the filling is very loose and tender. It literally melts in your mouth. 

Har gow, sew mai, fun gwoh are all perfectly flavored and  thinly and delicately wrapped, then steamed to perfection. 

I see that a lot of people are complaining about the prices being high. Well here's a take on food pricing. You can order a steak from Denny's that is $8.99 and you can order a better steak at Outback for $25, and an even better steak at Ruth Chris' for $40+. The difference in quality of the steaks warrants the price hike.

Well same goes for dim sum. You can eat that dollar-cheap stuff from a run down "hole in the wall" in Chinatown, but I assure you that you won't be getting the same high level of satisfaction as if you were to enjoy the clean and spacious dining room, the on-point and polite service, and good dim sum at Yank Sing.

The same goes for French, Japanese, or even pizza, or any kind of food for that matter. So why can't Chinese food also be pricey if the ingredients are excellent, the service is accomodating, and the quality of the food is up to snuff? It is time we recognize that Chinese cuisine can also be high class.

Many details and a lot of thoughtfulness have been put into this fine establishment. From the community chopsticks for serving to the dark colored napkins to prevent lint getting stuck on your dark slacks, they have really thought of it all. The tea is so fragrant and even the chairs are so comfortable and made of the softest calf leather. They even bottle their own signature hot sauce.

This restaurant will celebrate it's 50th anniversary this year, and its longevity and success is well deserved.
author: Charmaine L.

description:
3.5 stars..

The dim sum is good here, don't get me wrong, better than anything I can get in the south bay but for the SF area I think it's only a tiny bit above average. The dim sum here is PRICEY.. we had about 6-7 dishes which came out to be 80 bucks!!! For that kind of price we were hoping for something a little more special. On top of that we kept getting the same carts over and over so there was no variety. This clearly is a dim sum place for non-Asians. My dad who likes traditional dim sum would be pissed if I brought him here. For dim sum I would stick with Koi Palace instead.
author: Stanley C.

description: The Dim Sum here is just delicious.  There is a great variety of dishes. Everything is fresh.  I love to eat my dim sum with vinegar.  Sometimes that seems like a problem to convey at some dim sum restaurants but it was not a problem at Yank Sing. The service also is outstanding.  Servers are friendly and very accommodating.  This is a must go to place for locals and out of towners.  It is not cheap but it is worth every penny!
author: H. D.

description:
ugh, what can i say about yank sing's over priced dim sum? I just have to say that i am not into pricey and mediocre at best dim sum. i came here with a friend during lunch. bill came out to $80 for the two of us and I cant say we ordered a lot. 

i love dim sum and this place doesn't do it justice.
author: Katelyn M.

description:
If you've ever had a late late late night and then next day enjoyed Dim Sum at Yank Sing you will understand why this place is famous.

We sat in the VIP section and the owner (manager?) Vera came and greeted us. Very classy. We ordered tons of food and when we wanted something special we hadn't seen it was brought to our table special. The pork buns were great and the sticky rice was the best I have had. 5 stars for the coconut dessert and gin doy. Nothing was greasy.

Our lunch was about $175 for 5 people. Not too bad for the crazy amount we ate! :)
author: Nikki M.

description:
I read the reviews before going here and despite the "overpriced" comments I tried it anyway. 

Good location but thats about it. The food was OK but I'm sure for half the price I paid for I could have gotten the same or much better in Chinatown (which was a couple of blocks away).

II'll repeat, OVER PRICED and OVER RATED.
author: salvador p.

description:
really really bad.

I was thinking of a lot of things to write about this place, but to be honest I would just rather not relive the abuse my taste buds were exposed to.
author: Scott J.

description: The food was decent but it was pretty good. I have def been to better dim sum places. It was way too expensive. We only ordered a few dishes and it totaled to be 130. The party of two next to us had a bill of 107! Wouldnt really come back for the price. Three star for food but two becAuse of the price.
author: Ian L.

description:
maybe next time, I'll request fresh cha sui baos. The pork buns were suppose to be fluffy and airy but this was not like it had been sitting for a bit longer than it should. 

The experience alone is worth 5 stars. Chinese dim sum with top notch service. Water constantly filled. tea freshly made and the carts always stocked.  The shanghai dumplings is pretty good here along with the pork spare ribs. They didn't have beef egg rolls (strange). 

parking garage right next to the restaurant that validates. WIN!

4 stars for the cha sui bao

5 stars for the service
author: Eli T.

description: Definitely one of my favorite places to get some yummy Shanghai dumplings. It is a little pricey but the quality of the food is really good. The pork buns are also very delicious.
author: Cassandra W.

description:
Okay, don't put me in the stocks and pelt me with rotten tomatoes, yelpers, but I hadn't had dim sum before this day.

Agh! *Ducks* Look, it's one of those things I'd never gotten round to. Sure I've munched my fair share of Chinese food, and I know I've no excuse because we have a Chinatown in Manchester (sandwiched between Studenttown and Gaytown didn't you know), plus I know it taps into my favourite way to eat - little nibbles. But come on, what better way to sample these delights than in the popular Yank Sing in my new spiritual home of San Francisco?

(Dang, it's like I'm cheating on Manchester. I still love you, of course, Manchester... it's just that San Francisco satisfies needs I can't... I'll shut up now.)

Onto the dim sum. I came here with a lovely bunch of coworkers and instantly items were thrust upon the table. One of our party warned us that they will just leave these here and charge you for them if you don't reject them. It's quite an experience - like eating in a market stall with pushy salespeople almost. But they're on it, they really are. My water glass never got down even halfway and the food is marvellous. I'd thoroughly recommend the spring onion pancakes, they're so rustic, and any kind of dumpling, but please... if you do one thing, try the marinated sweet roasted seabass, it comes in a huge chunk and is to die for. Of course the pork buns are the favourite, but although I can't eat those they did look delicious.

With beautiful outdoor and indoor seating and a menu of light bites to tempt and tantalise, Yank Sing is a wonderful choice for a simple lunch or an easy dinner. I'd thoroughly recommend it.
author: Emma Louise M.

description: Really solid Dim Sum.  Consistent from visit to visit.  Not a value play, expensive for Dim Sum.  Always enjoy the food though.
author: Russ F.

description: Yank Sing has a great mix of traditional and unique new dishes to try! The cabbage slaw is a must try and they offer a lot of great vegetarian options! We went on a Sunday when the restaurant opens into the rincon center lobby and with the water feature, the setting is gorgeous and provides a lot more space than most dim sum restaurants. Both the food and ambiance were fantastic and it is highly recommended for anyone looking for a great dim sum spot in the city!
author: Jennifer L.

description:
Don't think you could find a Dim Sum location better than this.
Excellent quality, great service, nice variety.

If you're in San Fran then make your way to Yank Sing.
author: Rawhide W.

description:
We came here during a rare visit to SFO. Chinese is by far my DH's favorite food, provided it's authentic and not American-Chinese, and I try to treat him to something special whenever we're on the West Coast or BC. We've had outstanding dim sum in Vancouver/Richmond and I was really hoping Yank Sing would measure up, but it was not to be... The 5-6 dishes we ordered were good, but not great. We left hungry despite a $80 bill (with tea), and we're not big eaters to begin with. Can't imagine going there if you are trying to feed a ravenous appetite. 

Yank Sing's décor and service did not make up for the "meh" food. Then again, I must admit that we tend to focus on food in our enjoyment of a meal and are willing to forgive almost anything for tasty food.
author: Isabelle M.

description:
These folks have it DOWN. We were in and out in about 45 mins which was great because we had things to do.

All the food was great and tasted very fresh. The pork buns were definitely the hit of the meal, as well as the fall of the bone spare ribs... yum! The only complaint I'd have is you have NO idea how much you are spending!!

Sitting outside has a cool ambiance, but can be a little loud. I also feel like you get better service if you sit inside. I will recommend this place to friends.
author: Alison M.

description: Yank Sing is probably the best dim sum I've eaten at but boy, it is EXPENSIVE! 2 people and a toddler today with the bill rang up at $65. We had 7 dishes and 2 were just desserts.
author: Amy L.

description: Have heard so much about this place, I was thrilled to finally go there. Gathered there with some friends yesterday afternoon. Making reservations was helpful. We got there a little early and didn't have to wait long, although the place was packed inside and out in the courtyard. I now know why. The dim sum is fresh and delicious. The restaurant is clean and the service is efficient and excellent. This place gets a 10 from me on quality and taste; in fact, from our whole party.  The only reason I didn't give it 5 stars was due to the price. It's a little pricey, but this is San Francisco. We really enjoyed the food and the experience. If you love dim sum, I highly recommend Yank Sing.
author: Lorraine P.

description:
High end dim sum - yes please! 

It was my first experience eating at a fancy dim sum place over the weekend. My parents' place is walking distance to the Spear St location of Yank Sing in the Rincon Building. 

We got there pretty much when it opened because of my dad's fear of crowds. It wasn't that busy yet so we got seated right away and then got down to some dim sum eating business.

There are still carts pushed around but its like an enhanced experience there...Don't see what you want on the cart? Ask the woman if they have the dish you want and she gets on her radio to request it for you. Within a couple minutes...the steamer of ha gao is delivered to your table.

Service with a smile?! Chinese restaurant?! Pretty amazing...yes

Tea pots were the clear glass ones and were constantly refilled by the staff. Everyone was really pleasant and very accomodating and helpful.

Yank Sing is definitely not for the faint of heart with the impression that dim sum is a cheap dining experience. Normally it is pretty low cost, but not at this Rincon Center location. Prepare to pay...$4 for ha gao and $9 for 4 egg custard tarts. Its like sushi prices on Chinese dim sum lunch...

Its ok I didn't mind the prices because its not a weekly thing. We live in LA so probably it'll just be a visit every few months.

Delicious!
author: Betty Y.

description:
By far the most expensive dim sum I have ever had, 2 of us 100 bucks, its like eating sushi - but man o man, I can't stop eating their soup dumplings! I think between 2 people we ordered 6 dozens.  I didn't need anything else and had I known that 4 egg tarts were 13 dollars, I probably wouldn't have ordered the other things on the menu.  I fell in the trap of thinking dim sum - how expensive can it get, so when people push the cart by and offer, I accept.  Bad idea.  Look at the menu first, its at least 2 or 3 times the price of other dim sum places.  Yikes!  

But let's get back to the star of the show, the siu long bao's....  The skin was PERFECT - thin and tender and not too soft that the juice comes out, the soup bursts in your mouth with flavors of meaty green onion and ginger goodness.  However their soup after about 2 dozens becomes a little overwhelming, a little too fatty, but the first dozen is just out of the world.  So even though the price is a little high, I can't resist coming here every time I'm in SF.
author: Tina K.

description: My friend a co-worker took me here a couple weeks ago for dim sum. Having never tried it before found it to be tops. Amazing little hidden jewel in SFO. The seabass was awesome and the service was excellent.
author: Paul N.

description:
Yum! This is consistently the best dim sum I've ever had. The only problem is that we always seem to wind up in and out of the restaurant way too quickly. 

Favorite menu items: the soup-filled wontons, Peking duck, steamed pork buns, and pork and shrimp shumai. But basically, everything is good, and consistently so. 

I wouldn't recommend just walking in because they're always slammed busy, but if you make a reservation, you should be fine.
author: Stephanie W.

description:
Came here for dimsum this week during lunch with a colleague. The place was packed around 12:30PM but the 2 of us only had to wait for less than 10 minutes. The service here is really really efficient, but the food was OK and VERY overpriced. I guess you cant really expect the prices to be decent or low considering the area and being the only dimsum restaurant around (though the prices are really ridiculous). Their XLB were really good and they also served walnut prawns during lunch hour (my favorite!). They had a LOT of food going around, which is a plus for hungry folks!

Koi Palace in Daly City is pricey but worth it. Yank Sing is pricey and totally not worth it.
author: M W.

description: Amazing dim sum. Most of the time I go for the hole-in-the-wall chinatown stuff, but I'd come here every day if I could afford it. Tender meat, strong-but-balanced flavors, great variety, and incredible consistency (I haven't tried everything, but I've never tried something I didn't like, and my favorites are perfect every single time).
author: Chris M.

description:
I was so disappointed by this place. So many accolades, a James Beard Award Winner, Michelin Guide Acclaimed, the list goes on and on....

But the food and the service didn't quite match up.

When we got there, the hostess stand was a mess. We went into the restaurant and politely gave our name for the reservation we had called in beforehand. Fifteen minutes go by and we realize that we were the only ones that were still waiting inside the restaurant. Apparently they had moved the entire hostess stand outside into the cortyard of the Rincon Center and failed to mention this to us. They had even forgotten about us! When we went back to tell them, we had to wait another 15 minutes before finally getting seated.

The food wasn't much better than the service. Overpriced and cold xiao long baos, sticky rice, egg custard tarts and Chinese broccoli made its way over. It was probably the worst dim sum I've ever had, and even the most expensive dim sum I've ever had. Pick anywhere else in SF and you should have a better experience. Much better.
author: Stephanie Y.

description:
Food is so so, service is horrible. 
I read many reviews from books n internet saying this place is must when I'm in SF. However Yelp review wasn't that impressive n which is true. 
On Sat, 10a when they opened, still some tables are occupied. 
No cart ever came by for 15 min after we sat. When I asked waiter, he called someone. Finally food came. They don't have many choices. I only liked shrimp one. Outside was so thin n chewy- I liked it. However rest of food sucks. 
There are one woman who looks like waitress having a major attitude w/ me. She doesn't want to listen to me n doesn't want to look at me, but keep eye contacting w/ two of my friends when she talks even though I'm the one talking to her. I don't like they kept pushing us to have the food plate even though we said no already. 
Anyway it came out $139 for three of us.  
Definitely not worth it. 
Try Chinatown.
author: Sunnie P.

description:
I agree with pretty much all reviewers that the Dim Sum served here is absolutely delicious! But damn is it expensive...I am on the fence if the quality and the service are worth paying double / triple the regular price?
Yes, it is really good but is it that good? 
Sigh - might need to come back (I am prepared for the bill now!) and give it another try...
author: Sonja S.

description:
Some think YS is overrated, but I'd have to disagree.  Yes, the dim sum is expensive, but really, you get what you pay for.  The atrium is beautiful and the food is well-seasoned and well-presented.  

I confess, I have a special place for YS in my heart because I got married there.  If you are even considering a beautiful but elegant banquet, do not rule out YS.  Our wedding was even featured in a magazine.  See here:  http://66.34.224.169/index.php?page=pay

Anyway, back to the food.  Yes, it is expensive, but it's worth it.    Each dumpling is carefully made to perfection, and it's also clean.  And - gasp! - the service is quite decent.  People complain that it's not as cheap as other Chinese holes in the wall.  HELLO - YS is not a hole in the wall.  Also, to those posters down there who recommend Ton Kiang, I'd ask that you not go there (they have had many labor issues and have been sued numerous times by the Asian Law Caucus).  

One small caveat is that parking may be an issue.  I'd recommend parking on the street.  The YS parking lot is available, but the spots are tiny (we got in a small accident in that lot once and have never parked there since)!  

Finally, beyond the dim sum, if you are planning to go to dinner there, I'd also recommend one of their banquet menus.  Yes you will be paying $400+, but the food is exquisite.  And, my parents who will only eat authentic Chinese food, have noted that this food really is very *different.*  They love it!  If my Mama loves it, so will you!
author: Quyen T.

description:
Perhaps it is because every corporate luncheon was held here when I worked for Citi that I cringe when I think of Yank Sing.  

Being born to a family of dim sum chefs and living in HK, I have been spoiled by fantastic dim sum.  While some dishes here are well-executed, I feel that YS caters to their corporate clientele a little too much and charges an exorbitant premium.  They've dumb downed some of the dishes in order to please a certain audience.  That is my biggest pet peeve for Asian restaurants - then again, it make visiting HK ever so much better.
author: Monica L.

description:
Ingredients are very fresh and not greasy.  I think that's what makes Yak Sing a "go-to" place for dim sum.  Plus location is good if you work downtown.  But you sure pay for it.  

A friend and I met for lunch.  I emailed meeting place to be Yak Sing 2, but she must have overlooked the '2" and had already waited 20 minutes to get a table at the main restaurant.  Fine, let's not order a bunch of overpriced dim sum.  Just a few plates.  Well, 1 1/2 hours later the bill comes.  With tip and tax it was $93 (!?!?).  

Don't get the peking duck with steam bun.  Didn't check the menu price before... 1 small slice/piece of duck (i mean like really small bite size) with bun was $5 EACH.   What???   Yea, I've had better duck elsewhere.  

I do like the sticky rice and shrimp dumplings.  Mango pudding also good.  Should have stuck with just those items 1 order each.  

Service is very good here.  You pay for that too.

Way, way overpriced.
author: Angelique B.

description: I thought most of everything I had was pretty good. Pork buns were really good, as well as the pot stickers. The tea there is the best I've had.
author: Jeffrey R.

description:
So I'm a dimsum snob. Actually I'm a pretty big snob when it comes to Chinese food in general...after all, coming from Flushing, NY, I feel like I've definitely been spoiled. There is a certain level of quality that I expect and anything that doesn't match that standard is "meh" or just "ok." So with that said, Yank Sing would have probably earned 3 stars because that's how I felt about the food - good but not great; executed well but doesn't really have an impact. However, $10.90 for 6 pieces of xiao long bao??? (Shanghai steamed dumplings) $8.70 for an order of cong you bing??? (scallion pancakes) My mom and I ordered 10 items and the bill was over $100!!! For dim sum...that was pretty crazy...and we didn't even order a lot of the "high end" food except for Peking duck. Honestly...unless the food is extremely amazing, there should be no way that dim sum should end up to be this expensive. And even then, most dim sum items are fried or street-food/ish...so this is the reasoning for the 2 star rating.

My goal is to find a place with good Shanghai steamed dumplings. I've given up on finding amazing xiaolongbao...I've long come to the (jaded) conclusion that only Joe's Shanghai could make amazing xiaolongbao. While these dumplings were soupy and tasty, the soup doesn't lack the thickness or viscosity that makes really great xiaolongbao great. These were merely good...but honestly...for the price...I was very disappointed. Especially when I knew Joe's Shanghai's xiaolongbao would be twice as good and half the price with 8 pieces instead of 6. Peking duck was dry unfortunately and at ~$5 for 1 piece, kind of expensive. There were two standouts, however. The curry pork bun was really good, but again, I could get just as good for less elsewhere. The cong you bing, despite the ridiculous price, was my favorite...flaky, light, and full of flavor, it was the best dimsum item we had.

Yank Sing also excels at desserts (which at normal dim sum places I never get to try since I'm usually too stuffed for dessert). The mango pudding was really yummy and refreshing. And the real stand out is the mango ice cream pie...cold ice cream (that somehow sticks together and doesn't melt!), delicious crust, a cheesecake bottom...this is probably the wierdest item I've enjoyed at a dimsum place, but it was definitely the best thing on the menu!

While I've heard good things about Yank Sing, I felt like it didn't live up to the expectations that I had and the felt was simply just ok. Most of the diners were white and a lot of the menu items definitely seemed catered to non-Asian audiences (probably that mango ice cream pie!) and the menu doesn't have any Chinese on it (besides the name of the restaurant). These factors plus the prices definitely automatically made me skeptical and honestly, I probably would not come back or recommend this place, although I'm glad I was able to try it. Some places are not worth the buzz!
author: Kristen S.

description:
Definite skip.

I'll start with the positives.

The tea pot is pretty.  Clear glass with an infuser.  It's big too so no need for constant refills.

Service is good.  Very friendly staff (unlike typical Chinese restaurants) and yes, most staff speak English very well.

Parking is validated for 3 hours.

Decor is restrained but nice and tasteful.  Not gaudy like most expensive Chinese places.

Now for the negatives.  Yes, that really is all the positives.

It is EXPENSIVE!  Now, I'm ok with expensive.  I love Koi Palace, which is what I'm comparing Yank Sing to the most.  That said, while you get sticker shock at Koi Palace, once you bite into their food, you get an accompanying, "Wow!  Yum!"  You can see why they charge more.  Not here.  The food is mostly bad.

Things like the har gow, siu mai and fried turnip cake are dry and/or bland.  Small too.  Worth $1 max, not the $5.25 they charge.  There was a coconut cream roll that was tasty, but it was small and seemed like it could have been made a while ago.  

Their famous Shanghai dumplings were alright.  Good I guess.  Koi Palace is still much better.  Throw in the price difference and it tastes worse here.   Plus they're small like at Din Tai Fung (SoCal locations).  For the record, I don't like Din Tai Fung.  I'm from down there.  While I have to say the DTF dumplings have skin that is made and cooked to perfection (consistent, perfect thickness and cooked just right), the meat and juice is super bland.  That lack of flavor ruins the flavor of the skin.  At least here, there's flavor.

Overall, I'd give the food 2 stars.  However, considering how so much more expensive the food is, that drops things down to 1 star.  One last thing.  We went on a weekend.  The only Chinese people there came with white people except for us and one other table.  That tells you everything you need to know.  This place would last a month in SoCal.  Maybe.
author: Richard N.

description: Don't mind driving 350 miles from LA to enjoy Yank Sing.  The best!  Can't find such level of dim sum near LA China Town or even in Monterey Park.  Such perfect balance with almost everything...  This is a must visit for our family when visiting San Francisco.
author: Calvin L.

description: Five stars as usual, never a bad experience. The deep rich flavors found in the Shanghai dumpling, the crispy flake of the green bean cake, the perfect heat on the szechuan chicken, or the cool rich flavor of the Mango ice cream pie.......love.
author: Elizabeth C.

description:
I am a dim sum n00b. Apparently so is my friend, because when we got there, she did not say 'No' to a single item and soon we realized we had more than enough food and hadn't even gotten around to trying most of what we wanted. Also we were not that hungry. So I do not recommend going there if you are as dim sum incapable as us. 

That said, most of the items we got were pretty good with the exception of some lobster meat drumstick concoction. Oh also the patio seating is not open during the week :( 

3 stars for now, but I will go back!
author: Richa A.

description: Absolutely loved it! The Shanghai dumplings are amazing! Couldn't find anything like it at any other Dim Sum restaurants I've been to.
author: Julia P.

description:
This place is in a great location, and it's huge there's always a ton of food moving around on the floor.

I enjoyed everything I tried, and the service was fast and friendly.

A little on the expensive side, but the food is fresh and great.
author: Kevin M.

description: Wedding 8-10 course dinner. Thumbs up.
author: Thomas C.

description: I have no negatives. Totally impressed. Some SF natives suggested and it was delicious.
author: KJ C.

description: I think the food there are authentic and tasty! Comparing to most of Chinese reataurants, Ricon Center location is pretty decent. They have good vegetarian selection, too.
author: Shell J.

description:
The food is good, but by god is this place expensive.
Three people, about $120 (tax/tip incl).

It's in a pretty expensive area and a lot of people are tourists or not asian. The atmosphere is quiet and there's no need to competitively flag down the carts (which is a sport. trust me.) since they come around to every single table which is nice.

But wow. there goes the money I could use to buy another pair of shoes. EHEHEHEH.
author: Hilary S.

description:
THE place to go for Dim Sum in San Francisco.  Dim Sum is different from hoighty-toighty gourmet-- it actually works better when the restaurant is huge and bustling.  The scale means everything is made in real time.  Yank Sing has bigger variety than any other place, and it's always fresh.  

As for atmosphere, the noise and bustle is a kind of atmosphere unto itself.  A great place for a big group or celebration.
author: charles h.

description:
I'm sad that we didn't have enough time in our trip to SF to try more dim sum places so I could have a better comparison, since Chicago dim sum is a shame.  Living in the midwest all my life, this probably was the best dim sum I've ever had.  Every dumpling was cooked to perfection, perfectly moist and oh so delicious.  The soup dumplings were also fantastic!  We did order the peking duck and that did not turn up well.  Prices were a bit high, but that was expected since it is near downtown and the place is very clean and decorated nicely.

So 4 stars seems like a fair rating with room for margin of error.
author: Hubert L.

description: So far the best Dimsum in town.  I feel like it could be little less pricey but still give them 5 stars since their steamed shrimp dumpling are soooo good!
author: Miho Y.

description:
Pros:  Very attentive wait staffs.  Food is fresh.  I think that it was prepared that day.

Cons:  limited selections, over priced, long wait, and DON'T order the Peking duck.  Let me explained:
We saw this lady pushing the cart around with Peking duck.  She asked us if we wanted any and we said "yes".  She asked us "one serving or two".  We said "one", thinking that she would put 2 or 3 pieces of Peking duck and two or three pieces of bread for both of us to enjoy.  Nope.  She placed 1 tiny square piece of Peking duck and 1 piece of bread on the plate.  We turned it down.  I later learned from the menu that 1 tiny piece of Peking duck costs $5.95.  I am glad we turned it down.   We have gone to other dim sum restaurants in the City and have seen much more selection and better price.  Dim sum for the to of us costs more than $50.  YIKES!!!!!

Would I go back?  NO
author: Tai N.

description: Dim sum was great. Service not so much. It's been 5 years since I tasted the glorious dumplings and delicious treats and I expect the best of everything when I come to yank sing. If I am going to pay premium prices, I expect premium service. Sadly, today I was disappointed. We ordered items that never came out, only to find them on carts after we were tired of waiting for items to come out and paid our check. We were there for over two hours and left hungry. I mean how many times do I have to tell someone I want lettuce wraps. Please get your act together yank sing!
author: Easy L.

description:
Wow. Fanciest place I have eaten at. Thank god for amazingly nice managers taking interns out...or I'd be out an easy $70-80 on this meal! 

Ambiance: Classy, upscale, fancy, and all that jazz. It's funny seeing the types of crowds in this area. You'll see people dressed really nicely, or the college kids in jeans. But regardless, the restaurant is a really nice place to have lunch and I highly recommend it for a corporate lunch or really for any nice occasion! 

Food: So unfortunately I'm vegetarian...but this didn't stop the party I went with from ordering almost every single vegetarian dish on the menu (overkill, but what a nice gesture). I sampled the vegetarian mushroom dumpling, some orange tofu dumpling, green beans, steamed broccoli, this empanada-type dish stuffed with tofu, and of course, the mango pudding so many yelpers raved about. Overall, I'd give this place a 3 for the food, but that's definitely because I'm a vegetarian. The options were limited, but from what I sampled, the mushroom dumpling was really tasty, full of flavor and cooked perfectly. The empanada dish had way too much oil for my taste, but interesting nonetheless. The other thing that stuck out was obviously the mango pudding. Not a smooth texture of pudding, but rather it was as if it had been in the fridge for a couple hours and served. So amazing--as good as the reviewers claim! 

Where did the extra star come from? Impeccable service. The waitresses knew my manager since he comes so often, so she literally brought out all his favorites, without any questions, and kept coming back with vegetarian options every now and then so I didn't feel like there was no food at the table for me (there was enough food for me and my three other vegetarian family members). They were kind, quick, and knew their stuff. I have never been to a dim-sum place, so this was a new experience. But I liked watching how she stamped our bill with numbers each time we ordered something (so sneaky btw, you can end up spending SO MUCH because you feel like you're at a buffet) and since I wasn't paying, it was just more interesting than frightening! Our bill for a party of 5 came out to be $380 with tip...pretty damn steep but it's worth the experience! Plus I wasn't paying so...

Also, only open for lunch!! So make sure you plan your trip here. And definitely make a reservation because it gets crowded.

Verdict: Steep prices, nice restaurant, so try to go with someone who will cover the tab ;) or save up. But it's worth to go atleast once in my opinion!
author: Anu P.

description:
WOW ... there are a lot of people lining up at 11am already. I was pretty excited to try out this place since it's just a short walk. I was really impressed that all staff could speak Chinese and English fluently. Their hot tea came in a clear teapot, which was genius. They knew when to refill the pot. For our table of 5, they gave us 2 teapots, which meant the tea was not just tainted water after 4 refills. Plus this place is CLEAN!!!!

The savory dishes were pretty delicious. I enjoy all the ladies pushing the carts and pointing out what I want from it. We got a table full of dim sum within 5 minutes of sitting down. I got the egg tart and wasn't too happy. the crust was thick and the custard wasn't warm. It was also super oily. I like my egg tart to end a yummy dim sum meal. Then wash the grease down with hot tea. Too bad they do not have many choices either.
author: Stephanie Y.

description: Very good dim sum in a pretty, albeit a bit crowded (do the tables need to be that close to each other?) dining room. Huge dining room, several dining rooms, even serving guests in the atrium outside the restaurant. So they can serve a lot of people, and that they do - serve many many patrons. The thing is, they do it well. Service was excellent. Just excellent, which is not the norm in Chinese Restaurants. The dim sum was good, but not out of this world, as it once was. Maybe other dim sum restaurants have caught up with Yank Sing's quality, so that it isn't as exceptional as I once remembered it to be. Or maybe others have simply surpassed it, as the competition for the best dim sum from Hong Kong has heated up in the big cities. I don't know. The price is much higher than the norm, but I attribute that to the great service rather than to great dim sum. Still, I'm a fan!
author: arlene j.

description:
So damn good (and expensive) I could cry.

Every year for the past 11 years, I have run in the Susan G. Komen Race for the Cure to benefit breast cancer research.  While my times have steadily declined over the years, one thing that has not declined has been my enthusiasm for the post-race reward I have allowed myself: the ever-more popular Dim Sum for the Cure.  This year (2010), one of our group suggested that we go to Yank Sing instead of the usual Yet Wah.  Although I resisted this mucking about with tradition, it proved to be a most fortuitous and simultaneously wallet-lightening suggestion.

There were 7 of us dining this past Sunday (although only 3 actually ran), and we picked every quivering, steaming morsel that caught our eye.  The ladies pushing the carts around were pleasant and laughed with us as they marked our ticket, plying their delicious wares like the most seductive of sirens.

"Shanghai dumplings?  We make them soooo goooood here.  The skin is soft and delicate, while holding the flavorful juices within."  Oh God yes!  Yes!  We'll take two orders!

"BBQ Pork buns?  Why choose?  You could have them...both ways."  Yes, wonderful- we'll take one steamed AND one baked, please.

"Giant chunk of roast sea bass the size of my not inconsiderable fist? So delicate and exotic...so forbidden.  You can't get this anywhere else." (Ok, I may have exaggerated this part a little, but not the size.)  Ummm...unusual for dim sum...but yeah, ok, we'll take that too.  

For two glorious hours, it was simply wonderful, like a decadent, gluttonous dream.  Then, like the recent financial crisis, the check arrived, the party ended, and the hangover began.  Holy mackerel, did the party end.  The bill worked out to about $45/person, which was about 3x higher than our usual dim sum outing.  I ran the numbers twice, then thrice, before I looked glumly around and told everyone the bad news.

One person considered declaring bankruptcy.  Another started talking about strategic default.  Yet another started berating her unlucky boyfriend for eating beyond his means.  But ultimately, stern-faced, we all reached into wallets and paid the piper.

So, is $45 a small price to pay for possibly the best dim sum in the area?  Well, let's just say I'm glad I don't live in SF.  Otherwise, I could easily see myself seduced, again and again, by those cart-pushing, food-laden divas of dumplings.
author: Alan L.

description:
Dim Sum at its finest ! I think I might actually love the service more than the food, but it's a close one. Everyone is so attentive & courteous. Loved it!

The day we went was super windy, but our food was never cold. Everything was delish & we were extremely satisfied by the end of our meal. There wasn't that gross feeling of too much MSG, or too much grease, or the nearing of a stomach ache that normal dim sums tend to give off when you're finished.

It was by far the best dim sum we've ever had... as well as the most expensive. We weren't FULL, but content... at $90 for two. I suppose we could have done major damage if we were being little piggies. Good thing I wanted so many other things in the area that I decided to save my stomach a little!

Definitely worth a visit. We'll be back again next time we're in town !
author: Paulina N.

description: Just had a solid lunch here.  The sea bass was fantastic.  So were the mushrooms with sausage.  If you are super hungry this is a great place to go stuff yourself.  The food just keeps coming and coming, but watch it, it's not all you can eat.  Our bill for two people was $80.  Keep in mind, If you really want to talk with the person you are with, the constant food delivery is a bit of an interruption.
author: Albert S.

description:
Pretty darn pricey, but so damn good! Get the shanghai dumplings!

Also, you'll be convinced to buy with your eyes. So, I hope you know what you want before you get there.
author: Grace N.

description: This is the advice I would give Chinese speaking folks.  If you would like to have better service, please don't speak any Chinese to the waitstaff.  Otherwise, they will give you bad service.  That's the way they operate.  They look down on their own people, as management probably trained their staff to operate like that.
author: Fong K.

description:
My sister had never been to eat dim sum so I wanted to make sure she went to a traditional place where you pick from carts as they push through the restaurant.  Yank Sing did NOT disappoint.  She loves dumplings so was having a great time looking through the offerings and choosings various items.  The foods were delicious, especially the Shanghai dumplings!!!!  

My only knock on it...it was a little too pricey.  We paid over $116 for the 3 of us.  Spring rolls were $11 an  for an order of 6 small ones and most items appeared to be about $9.
author: Janel Marie M.

description: This restraint was way too overpriced. We literally at like 10 dumplings and got a $100 bill.
author: Kai L.

description:
This restaurant is way overrated. The service is no different than what you would receive at a cheap Chinese restaurant. I had to ask several different wait persons to refill my ice tea -- which was served in a small glass. My buddy had to keep asking for the soft drink he ordered. We could have dehydrated severely had the weather been warmer. 

The dim sum is OK. I don't mind paying for good food but the food here is as plain as vanilla ice cream. 

I was impressed by the spicy chicken satay. The best I've had in the Bay Area. In fact, I ordered a second plate, which took forever to arrive. After repeated request, a manager came by and advised that they ran out and the kitchen was still cooking some. 

I think the best place for dim sum in San Francisco is Tong King in the Richmonds. 

I get the take out occasionally for lunch. Why must they use so much grease to cook everything. I have to wash down the grease with two cokes or sometimes a beer.  The take out lunches are inexpensive and you get good portions.
author: Peace L.

description:
Very good, high quality, creative dim sum.  The service is quick and all the servers have headphones and mics so you can ask anyone for anything and they'll bark the order into the system.  They'll come around in carts and ask you all the time if you want to eat what they have.  If you have a crowd ask for the magic scissors, have them cut all non-dumpling items in half so you have more to go around and can try other dishes instead ordering more of the same thing (unless you really like it of course).

They're really known for their shanghai dumplings which I think are just okay.  I especially like the different variety of vegetable dishes, not just vegetarian dumplings, that they bring around.  They also have a lot of deep fried/breaded dishes which I don't favour but cannot avoid when going with non-Chinese friends.  If you are like me, try to situate yourself closest to the aisle so you can commandeer the carts and pretend not to hear other requests.

The prices are quite high, easily over $30/person if not more.  I think for that price I would prefer Ton Kiang.

Caveats:  Very crowded.  On the weekends the crowd fills the lobby area and outside seating in the atrium.  Get reservations.

Bike Parking: designated bike racks across the street from the Rincon center on Mission St.
author: Jean K.

description:
Normally, when I enter a Chinese restaurant where the number of patrons match the tablecloths (read: WHITE) is above 50%, I cut and run.
  On any given lunch day, the white patronage ratio is some 90%. At least. 

But of course... when it's on the company bill, my Asian sensibility takes over and realizes that it's a free meal. And I, for one, am never the type to turn down a free meal. 
Actually, thank God for the company credit card. 
Because while I don't mind plunking down good money for stellar food, I just can't justify eating here on my own dime. 
  Example: once, for lunch, it came out to over $100 for 2 of us! Yeah, unless you just killed a lobster and a baby cow and served them to me for the meal, would I be okay with that price for lunch. 

But I digress. 
Despite the sticker shock, the food's actually pretty well made. Definitely gears towards appeasing the American palates that roam their way here daily for lunch. But tasty, nonetheless. The seafood's fresh and the place is definitely clean and provides good service. My American colleagues love this place for those matters. 

But wait! 
I don't expect good service at a dim sum place. I want the rude HK women yelling at me. I want my cow stomach (tripe) and heaping bowls of congee. And I want a bill that won't make my parents cringe in horror. 

For nicer, upscale dim sum I think I'll stick to Dynasty in Cupertino. Otherwise, there are plenty of other cheap dim sum joints that let me get my dim sum on without taking out my life savings.
author: Vic C.

description:
Setting: admit it. we've all had the midweek dim sum craving. on this particular day, my partners in crime (5 of us) decided to tackle our hunger at yank sing.

Reservation: nada. we got there around 11:30am to avoid the long lines. we parked in the garage directly underneath which offers 2 hours of free parking with yank sing validation. there was no wait, although we were seated in the corner so that our poor chopstick skills didn't confuse the other patrons. 

Order: juicy pork xiao long bao, pork and veggie dumplings, shu mai, BBQ pork buns, fried shrimp, chicken claw, pork spare ribs, turnip cake, chinese broccoli, sticky rice in banana leaf, jasmine tea. we devoured everything that didn't slip between our chopsticks and land on the table for more than 5 seconds. the change of plate mid-meal is always appreciated. alas, no room for dessert, but i'll come back for those egg custard tartlets another day...

Cost: $28 per person. a bit pricey so not your everyday dim sum.
author: Janet Z.

description:
If the SF Chinatown messiness and stench of dried fish is too much for you and wellll if you're looking for a higher end dim sum shop, this is the place. Yank Sing from your first impression gives no subtlety as it's located inside the lobby level of a business tower near the embarcadero area. The restaurant itself is very nice, reminds me a lot of expensive restaurants ice visited while in Hong Kong with the decor and the table arrangements. I came here on a Saturday and they also has tables setup outside the restaurant in the lobby which was very nice.

If you're a Xiao Long Bao lover like myself, be ready to rate this place 5 stars. The place I usually get my Xiao Long Bao on is Din Tai Fook in Pasadena, by the way I've also visited their branch in Shanghai last August. Call it recent taste bud recollection of what have you but this place's "soupy dumplings" are fantastic and above average. Coming from eating the like in the swankiest of Hong Kong establishments, this place does a great job.

I did mention this place deserves 5 stars however given the pricey bill, i had to lower it to 4. Still very good if you got the extra cash to spend. A party of 4 was about $115 not inc tax. We did have leftovers we brought home however
author: Juan F.

description:
We came here around 1pm for a party of 2. 

I loved their shu mai. It had good chunks of shrimp (not ground up shrimp) you can really taste.

Everything else was average. 

I kept seeing carts I was waiting for that never came. A few rows down I was eye-balling the peking duck but it never came. I was also wondering where their spare ribs were...it never came around but after I asked, they paged one of the carts to serve us an order.

I'd give this place a higher rating if more carts came around. That's one of the best things about going out for dim sum. Sometimes you don't really know what you're in the mood for until you see it up close.

Note: They don't have tripe. They do have chicken feet though.
author: Angelica P.

description:
One of my favorite and best dim sum spots. The dumpling variety and dim sum selections are unique and creative. Instead of the predominantly shrimp and pork based selections served at most other middle-of-the-road dim sum restaurants, you'll find a diverse range at Yank Sing. From vegetable dumplings, to chicken w/shitake and cilantro ones, fat, juicy Xiao Long Bao's (meat dumplings), or chicken feet, mango pudding, and other standard dim sum dishes, expect all to be made with quality ingredients and delicious. 

I like to go and sip a cup of chrysanthemum poured from the beautiful clear teapot and snack on pan-fried yellow-chive dumplings, pork buns, and plenty of dumplings. The only dish I've disliked here is the peking duck. It's a dry sliver of duck, served on a white bun with hoisin and scallions. A typical dish, but I was surprised to see that they charged $12 per serving. Meaning, one sliver of duck + one bun = $12. If it had been particularly good, I may not have minded, but $12 is a bit much to pay for a bit of duck in my book. But besides the duck, you'll find plenty of other items that will surely please your palate. 

The ambiance is comfortable, clean, and peaceful.  Service is attentive, despite sometimes being crowded, the staff will always accommodate your requests, and you will never feel lost within the hustle and bustle of a busy Saturday afternoon. Alternatively, if you prefer a peaceful meal, go when the restaurant opens at 9 a.m. for breakfast. Either way, don't forget to grab some egg tarts (dan tat) for later on your way out at Yank Sing to-go.
author: helen l.

description:
Overpriced and not that great.  Much better dim sum in Chinatown.  Good thing we went for a work event and it was comped!  I don't think I would come here on my own dime.  The food was just nothing special and the location and decor is kind of lame.

Not a fan.
author: Chad H.

description:
Sunday dim sum in San Francisco! It doesn't get better than this. I wanted to go to Chinatown to get an "authentic" dim sum experience but I am glad I chose this place. They had me at Michelin star rated, free parking on weekends and large atrium seating with no wait- unheard of in my native Los Angeles!

Yank Sing offers soupy Shanghai style dumplings- please eat right away, not so good when it cools. The shu mai and dumplings were extraordinary. Seafood ball on stick, snow pea dumpling, shitake mushroom dumpling, jicama and red cabbage salad and the crowning glory- green beans sauteed with dried shrimp and black bean sauce- to die for!!!

This was a great place to have very high quality food and catch up with an old friend. Beyond recommended.
author: N Justine K.

description:
*sigh* Another overpriced, westernized dim sum place who lures unsuspecting patrons with their fancy decor. My sister recommended that my mom and I come here because we were in the area that day...mistake. Service was fine, excpet they stuck the two of us next to this pillar that everyone seemed to walk by.  Seriously, i felt like waiters/waitresses were bumping my chair ever 5 mins. We also couldn't get a lot of food or our teapot filled because we were tucked away next to this pillar. 

 The only thing thats amazing is their xiao long baos. I recommend that you come here and order a few baskets of these tihngs and peace out. Other foods were not particularly amazing nor unique...especially for the price. 

Left here feeling very unsatisfied. Best believe I left a long and detailed msg in their comment section. 

I did attend a wedding that was hosted here and they do turn on this fountain thing where it simulates rain in the center of the room. A little too much if you ask me. Id rather they pay attn to the quality of their food to match their price.
author: Mindy H.

description: I came here once back in 2008  (back when I don't really know yelp yet) and it was very good. The texture was very refined, and the taste was exquisite compared to your typical dim sum. 6 years down the road, I was just back again on Friday after Thanksgiving and it has definitely changed. It is no where near the standard it used to be yet it is still as expensive. In comparison to other dim sum place, i would say it is now average in terms of taste. I am quite disappointed.
author: Sean C.

description:
Yank Sing is my test case for Yelp's new smart phone App.

Someone else made the reservation on a conventional telephone, and I have been there several hundred times over many years.  So, yes, I know the place even though I had not read all 973 Yelper reviews.  
And I still haven't.

Anyway, I knew the answers before I asked the questions -- it seemed like a fair test of the Yelp App.  I found the place on the map, opened the Yank Sing pin and brought up the Yelp.com page, where I enlarged the menu to an easy readability.

So, decision time -- whether to walk-in or walk-on by.  Three and a half stars.  OK.  
Then there's a check-in item in the App.  So I hit that and also hit the Add button.  This was new stuff, what-what?  
Things happen.  
First, it broadcasts a notice to Yelp Friends that I checked-in at this 3.5 star Chinese restaurant. (I need to understand this part better).
Also, first, it posted "Your Next Review Awaits" on my Yelp.com welcome page along with a favicon of the menu.

That prompted me to rember Yelpers bad-mouthing the App for this:  some dedicated reviewers want to write their reviews on the phone's App in real time in the restaurant.  
Alas, the current App allows you only to draft your review on the phone and you may only post it later from your computer. 

Well, I tried to prove the concept.  
First problem I encountered was competition for right hand priority.  Both Yank Sing's plastic chop sticks and Apple's gleaming iPhone need the same hand (in my case the right) -- or you will have to alternate setting down the chopsticks and the iPhone.
  
This is do-able, but there are consequences.  Second problem, the more you eat and the more often you set down the chopsticks, the messier you make the table -- so where to set down your expensive iPhone?  In your own greasy mess?
I think not.

Even worse, for thousands of years the Chinese have been pouring from pots that slop a lot of tea onto the table cloth. 
If they haven't fixed that by now, they're not going to.  So Deal with it.
Do NOT set your iPhone down on the tea-soaked table cloth.

So what does this have to do with Yank Sing's food, service and 3.5 star rating?
Forget about it.
You're going to be so busy punching buttons and trying to keep food off your iPhone/hand, you're not going to notice that stuff.

And there you have it.
author: Peter N.

description:
When I want Dim Sum, Yank Sing is what I think of first.  I usually go to Yank Sing on the weekend when their entire restaurant and courtyard are full.  People are buzzing everywhere sometimes waiting as long as 1 hour to get a table.  If the wait is that long when you go, I suggest staying and enjoying this wonderful food.  Many chinese restaurants try to do Dim Sum but no one comes even close to comparing to the freshness, flavor, and quality of Yank Sing.  

My favorite dish here is the dumpling soup (forgot what Yank Sing calls it) which is their signature dish.  I also love the pork belly buns and the shu-mai.  You really can't go wrong with anything you order here.  Everything is delicious.  Occasionally the ladies who bring the food around are a little slow, but its probably because when I go I am usually starving and ready to eat!

Be prepared to spend some serious cash though.  This place adds up fast.  Most of the time when my wife and I go for a Sunday lunch, the bill for the two of us is anywhere between $60 and $80.  Don't forget that they validate parking for the garage below the restaurant.
author: Ash S.

description: Dim sum was okay, nothing special, ridiculously expensive! $25 for 2 xiao long baos? I'll never go there again.
author: Yifan S.

description:
Yep, this is pretty much the best, most reliable dimsum you can get.

And it's probably also the most expensive.  Thus, 4 stars.  But oh, it's the little touches that make it great!

The xiao long bao (shanghai soup dumplings) are big and full of juice, just barely keeping it all together for the trip to your mouth.

The wu gok (fried taro dumplings) have a pleasant five-spice flavor in the pork filling.  Why can't other places do that?

Pork ribs!  They were amazing -- I ate the last one without compunction.

The fried mochi-like things actually had char siu (red pork) in them, as well as little shrimp and mushrooms!  What a good combo!

The sesame seed balls (which I normally eschew) were soft and molten on the inside, crispy on the outside -- so different from the usual oily skin and thick paste nugget.

The siumai and hagao had flawless skins... no oversteaming here.  I also sampled and enjoyed the tofu skin rolls, numerous vegetable dumplings, and fried thingies. 

There were only a few surprising little disappointments: the pork spare ribs and turnip cakes weren't that interesting.  (No black bean in the spare ribs, for example.)

Anyway, it's a great place to go -- especially if someone else pays.
author: Daniel S.

description:
One side of a little placard on each table at Yank Sing reads:

"Dim Sum, those small, delectable dumplings served with Chinese tea, used to be for imperial stomachs only.
