A thousand years ago Sung Dynasty emperors nibbled on such delicacies as minced pheasant, lark tongues, and sweets made from steamed milk and bean paste.  With the invasion of the Mongols in the 13th Century, the emperor and his court moved slowly south, introducing the palace cuisine to every province on the way to Canton."

The quote comes oddly enough from the Asian Wall Street Journal - not exactly what I had in a mind as a dim sum expert. 

While you will not find pheasant or lark tongues at Yank Sing, I highly recommend the Shanghai Pork Dumplings. Its easy to eat way too much at Yank Sing and its true that there are far cheaper alternatives. But here the service is friendly, and almost everything is very good.
author: Abhi S.

description:
I really enjoyed dining here and plan on going again as soon as I can. I really enjoy the experience that goes along with eating dim sum and I was pleased on all levels with that. The service was expedient always well-timed (no unnecessary interruptions, came quickly to refill tea). The carts were well-stocked and the waiters were helpful when I didn't recognize an item. 

The food was absolutely delicious and the tea is superb as well. I was a bit blindsided by the bill because, though the menu has quite a few moderately priced items, they place the most expensive dishes on top. We ended up spending much more than I anticipated, but I was very pleased with the food so I thought it was worth it. On my next trip, I will choose my favorite items off the menu and order them exclusively so that I am not surprised by the bill.
author: Kara P.

description:
The dim sum here is nonpareil compared to other places I've tried in SF. The service is super fast and kind of amazing to watch. It's totally busy but once you're seated, they don't rush you, and they make sure you've got everything you need all the time. Water glasses always full. Tea hot and steaming. Empty dishes and plates gone before you can even think about it. 

For dim sum of this caliber, I would brave a lot. And I do. It's pretty far from my normal stomping grounds. The parking is the WORST in the entire city. It's always astoundingly busy. If you sit outside it can echoey and loud. But all of that pales in comparison to the true enjoyment you will experience when you eat the food.

Maybe they put some kind of magical ingredient in there to brainwash you against the considerable obstacles to enjoyment that may otherwise convince you to go elsewhere. The food is just so GREAT. We go there time and time again and love it for better or worse. I'm pretty sure this place sets the bar for what logistical things I will endure for exceptional food and scarily competent staff.

Another reviewer described the parking situation as "a never ending clusterfuck of a labyrinth" which is absolutely true- I have seen many a couple near tears as one tried to direct the other one into or out of a space while a long line of impatient angry people watch helplessly. I suspect relationships end over the parking in that place. On the upside, it's free. I am only giving four stars because the parking really is that bad.

GO here. BE BRAVE. And put on your patience pants cos it might seem like a bit of effort to get to enjoyment but you WILL enjoy it.
author: crystala t.

description:
I came here only because they validate at a special price and I needn't some help after spending 2+ hours at my dentist in the same building...they have a take out express shop that sells combination of dimsum / noodles...it was expensive and atrocious...i mean, it felt like Panda Express, but instead of getting a good sized portion of two entree selections, I got a couple of eggrolls, 1 shu mai, and 2-3 potstickers w/ rice / noodles.  The food was below average (I think Panda tastes better). The worst thing was that they wouldn't validate me bc I came into the building too early in the morning!  The experience totally blew.

My home town is Monterey Park, a east LA suburb w/ Chinese food galore.  If I ever want dimsum, I will steer clear and go somewhere else in the City.  I mean, there seems to be a booming Chinese population, why settle for mediocre and expensive in FiDi?
author: Yvette H.

description:
Pro: Excellent Dim Sum. Great ambience. Short wait time, Parking validation. Parking provided in same building parking lot. 

Con: Very pricey for dim sum. Parking lot in build has very tiny parking spaces.
author: William H.

description:
Yank Sing has always been my favorite place for Dim Sum. As far as quality and taste, they are above any other dim sum place I've been to. I've always felt this way and on my last visit earlier this week, I was very impressed with their service. 

I couldn't believe I was in a Chinese restaurant. Our water glasses were always filled. Chopsticks were replaced right after I dropped it on the floor. Didn't even have to ask. And all the servers and whoever were super nice. 

The sea bass which is my favorite was delicious! Everything else really was too. 

Maybe the food tasted even gooder cause my friend paid. =)
author: Rocky S.

description: The best dim sum I have every had in the US! A bit pricey, but I that's to be expected as the restaurant is in the San Francisco downtown business district. I ordered a pot of Jasmin tea, the awesome Shanghai soup dumplings, steamed shrimp dumplings, chicken feet, steamed pork dumplings and softshell crab. All sumptuous, delightful, and exquisitely tasty! I went during a weekday and although it was busy, I immediately got a table.
author: Nat V.

description:
OKAY my fav's are the Chicken feet and anything with shrimp in it.
You've got to order the chrysanthemum tea (can't believe I spelled that right w/o spell chk.) if you're going order the chicken feet.  This is one of the few restaurants in SF that has consistency in great taste and freshness. The food taste as good at 11AM  as it does at 1:30 on any chosen day.  If you have kids the fountain is a great place to keep them occupied while you eat a crab dumpling with your glass of Chardonay.
author: Kingmond Y.

description:
I eat Dim Sum pretty often, and this place is pretty amazing!

It's a nicely decorated place with huge mirrors on the back wall (makes the room appear much larger than it really is, haha). 

When we called at 12:15pm to make a reservation, the hostess we talked to put us down for a Party of 7 and told us they'd have a table waiting for us at 1pm. Well, we got there at 12:50pm, and apparently they didn't have a table for us--as promised, so that wasn't the greatest first impression.

However, they quickly made room for us and the food definitely made up it! It's definitely pretty pricey, but for the food quality, it's seemingly understandable. However, for the price of Dim Sum, I'd probably come here once or twice a year. There's a great variety of food items (mainly most of the usual Dim Sum items you would expect). We ordered about three orders of Xiao Long Bao (steamed buns; or literally: "little dragon buns" Haha.), because of how good it was. The sauce inside the skin with the meat was great. A lot of Xiao Long Baos are too salty, or the skin is too thick and chewy or the meat inside is tasteless. However, these baos were spectacular.

The Har Gaw was tasty as well! You know how the skin of a lot of Har Gaw are either way too thick and sticky or way too thin? WELL, these Har Gaw were well-wrapped and the skin thickness to shrimp inside ratio were really good. 

Definitely try their chili sauce! They have black beans in it that pair nicely with the chili! I bought a jar home afterward. :)

I wouldn't recommend the fried crab ball dish...for the price, it's really not all that worth it. It doesn't taste as great as it's advertised to be on their menu, but of course, it could just be me. I felt that there was much more batter around the crab leg than crab meat itself.

Overall, the food service was fast, and the overall food quality was very nice!
author: Jason T.

description:
TLDR:
- LIkely the most overhyped and overrated dim sum in the Bay.
- Dishes are lukewarm.
- Take the extra drive to Koi Palace or check out the sleeper dim sum joint: Mama Ji's.
author: Christopher L.

description:
The MOST overrated dimsun place!... WAY TOO OVERPRICED!!

pretty pathetic and unreasonable!.
author: Hand T.

description:
An amazing experience.  Lovely staff, super clean, and food that is epic.

My partner and I sampled about 5-6 various vegetarian items--each one delicious.  The stars were the spinach dumplings and the seaweed tofu.  And the tea--dear lord.  so.good.    

I am still not over how yummy of a time I had here.
author: Jessica G.

description: Best Dim Sum restaurant in the city!! One of few traditional and authentic hong kong cuisine in the bay
author: H T.

description:
Me no likey...$300 for deem sum for 6 people?  I don't think so.  Definitely a great location--walk to the waterfront, clean surroundings.  But mediocre food and shiny floors do not warrant the enormous bill that comes at the end of this mildly satisfying gastronomic fare.

Skip it and walk over to the equally pricey Ferry Building location of the renowned Slanted Door.
author: Joc V.

description:
One of the better Dim Sum places in the city.  Wide variety of dishes in a nice fairly-relaxed setting.  Good place to introduce someone to Dim Sum if they've never had it before...I say this particularly because most of the dishes are really well-prepared and not too greasy like some of the other places in the city.

Quality unfortunately comes at a cost.  Yank Sing is probably the most expensive Dim Sum place I've ever been to.  Every time I've gone, cost has consistently run in the $30-$40 range per person...For Dim Sum, that is a lot of $$$.  Because I believe in the principal that Dim Sum should be relatively affordable, that really kind of limits my frequency of visits to Yank Sing...Since Dim Sum isn't exactly healthy, that however may be a good thing in the long run.
author: Justin L.

description:
It wasn't anything exceptional. I did enjoy the food and the location and restaurant itself is beautiful. 

The parking was a bit of a problem. They say they validate parking but THE PARKING LOT WAS FULL!!! I went at 1:30PM on a Saturday for Deem Sum. Try to go early to avoid the full parking or go somewhere that has a more reliable parking system.

Also, its VERY EXPENSIVE. For 3 people it was $90 and we didn't get that much food.
author: Kathy S.

description:
Fantastic dim sum in a pretty art-deco post office: everything about Yank Sing is classy and delicious.  Definitely go for the soup dumplings; Yank Sing describes them as their "specialty," and they are amazing.  

Take out is very cheap and fast if you don't want to wait; but believe me, it's worth the wait.  Try getting there about 1pm on a Saturday when the crowd starts winding down.  Any earlier and you'll have a 45 minute wait minimum.
author: Tasha D.

description:
I've always been a big fan of dim sum so when my mom offered to take me to Yank Sing, I was super excited because I've heard wonderful things.  I'm afraid I don't believe the dim sum lived up to all the hype.  The shrimp dumpling filling was yummy but the outside was rather dry and it stuck to the roof of my mouth so I was more focused on unsticking it than the flavor.  The turnip cake was a little mushy and wasn't as crispy as I like it.  Their baked BBQ buns were almost covered in honey and was way too sweet for my taste.  

Good things were the shui mai and the xiao lon bao Shanghai dumplings.  Their steamed BBQ pork dumplings are also yummy bit they cost $4.50.  In fact, the cheapest thing on the menu was $4.50 and the most expensive thing was $17.50(?) and that was for a small piece of steamed sea bass.  

They do offer validated discounted parking during the weekdays and free 2 hour parking on the weekends.  But the garage is a pain in the a to get into and navigate.
author: Christina C.

description:
I am not a tourist, I grew up in the bay area surrounded by wonderful Asian food. I particularly love dim sum and have been to many of the best in the bay area and even Hong Kong.
I had out of town visitors downtown last week and I wanted them to experience dim sum.
yank sing would not have been my 1st choice but it was convenient so we went. 
what a mistake!
we were greeted with "do you have a reservation?" no. " give us your mobile phone and we will call you when there is a table". we were starving and I said maybe we would find someplace else. suddenly, they had a table for us in the corner.
the food was average at best, quite small servings and plain preparation. they have a bad habit of bringing some of their slightly more interesting items around by hand and then charging double for them!
we are 3 petite women and we ate relatively sparingly and the bill was $85!!
absolutely outrageous!
many other places in the bay area are tastier, more welcoming and 1/2 or even 1/3 as expensive.
i'm sorry I wasted my time and my money.
author: lianne v.

description:
First of all, the dim sum are very delicious but it is extremely expensive.

The place itself it really cramped. It is really noisy and sometimes listening to your partner talk ca be a problem.

All of the regular dimsum items like hakau, siumai, chengfan, chicken feet, tripes, etc are all delicious. They also have carts walking around that offer peking duck, sauteed fish, etc. I tried the sauteed fish and it was really good. I would come here again. I think all of their food are incredibly delicious. The only thing is.. i didn't expect a dimsum place to be this expensive. I had breakfast, and this is just a small brunch for me and i spent over 40 dollars.
author: Jurgen J.

description:
Excellent food, but extremely overpriced.  My family can eat, but we spent a little more than double the amount at yank sing versus your average dim sum spot.  

Before we even sat down, there was a waitress at our table offering us the dishes on her cart.  The waitresses here are EXTREMELY aggressive and will even put food down on your table before you say that you want it.  However, everything looks so good that you will be hard pressed to actually say no.  haha.  

A few of the standout items were the shu mai (is this actually bad anywhere?), stuffed mushrooms, seaweed tofu (a must try) and the kurobuta pork dumplings (supposedly the house specialty).  The one thing that really disappointed me was the baked bbq pork buns.  This is my favorite dim sum item and usually my standard for judging a dim sum place.  Yank sing failed miserably.  The bread was extremely dry and hard to eat.  They put too much of the glaze on top and the filling was just average.  A bit disappointing. 

Was this place worth double the amount that we usually pay for dim sum?  I am going to have to go with a no.  I forgot to mention that some of their dishes are per piece, so be careful with that (i.e.  lettuce wraps, peking duck).  They might use better quality ingredients than your average spot in chinatown, but once you add all the spices and sauces can you really tell a difference?  I like to compare it someone making a burrito using filet mignon vs your typical carne asada meat.  Aren't you just wasting filet mignon at that point?  

Anyway, I'd only come back here if someone specifically requested it and I was not watching my budget.  The food is really good, but I just cant imagine paying this much for dim sum on a regular basis.  Parking is horrible, but what else is new in downtown SF?

Quick tip...be careful when pouring the tea.  They serve tea in these fancy pots and my first pour resulted in a soaked table cloth and napkins.  Yes, I was that guy.
author: JP T.

description:
I was there for the Sunday Dim Sum last week or so. Free validated parking at the Rincon Center. Good food.  This dim sum place is good. Service is probably the best in a Chinese restaurant that you'll ever find anywhere in the US, because it caters to more higher paying customers. Very Americanized.

Lots of attention as soon as you sit down. Everything appears to come after you, anything that they are serving. The tea pot was very interesting. I wonder where they bought it...Macy's? Not sure. 

Actually, it is probably the most expensive dim sum place I have been to in the bay area.
3 people for around $120. Purely dim sum, nothing else. No chow mein, or noodles, or anything. I like it though, and I would pay for service and quality.

If you have had Yank Sing 2 go (usually lunch in the Financial District on weekdays)  you would realize that all of their dim sum also has it as well. 

Notable stuff to order:
Peking duck. Off the hook. Very good.
The steam pork buns: Xiao lung bao. Good!
Spring rolls. Good!

I would go back.
author: Jason W.

description:
Always top on my list of best restaurants to take any visitors or newcomers to San Francisco. Plus, I don't mind the check for breakfast being what I'd usually pay for dinner when the food is that inventive and delicious. AND- you know they actually take reservations (415 957 9300) so you don't have to wait an hour! Love them! 
Plus, the location is wonderful start for a tour to walk off your meal- WPA murals in the historic lobby, two blocks from the Ferry Bldg.
author: Christopher E.

description:
The Dim Sum here is slightly "westernized" and is a little bit on the pricey side.  However, it is super clean, decor is nice, parking is easy and is just a short walk to the Ferry Building.  Most importantly, the Dim Sum is great.

I've been fortunate to have been to Din Tai Fung in Taipei, Taiwan - that's the place that's been credited and highly praised for their Shanghai Dumplings and I like Yank Sing's version better.

If you go - try the Onion Cakes, Mushroom Dim Sum, Red Cabbage Salad and of coure, the Shanghai dumplings.  Also, ask for the Baked Pork Buns - they have 3 small ones on a plate with honey (don't get that) - ask them to get you the big ones.

Also, they have a menu on the table that you can look at (with prices) and if you see something you like than you can ask the server to order that for you.
author: Randy H.

description: came here on christmas day and it was absolutely packed. we were vacationing in sf and didn't get a chance to make concrete plans/reservations for christmas, so we expected to have to wait. well the wait was 3 hours long... so we opted for take out from their to-go place. the options were a lot more limited, but it was better than nothing. i was surprised that xiao long bao wasn't on their menu, so when we saw the line at the bottom of the order sheet that said "special orders," we asked if we could get an order of the xlb's. the lady said sure and we paid for the order. while waiting, it occurred to me that the order seemed way more expensive than it should have been. we looked at the receipt and everything was slightly overpriced compared to what we're used to in houston's chinatown, but still around $4-7 for each thing. however, the order of xlb's was $14! whatttt. dim sum orders are never more than $10. they should really be less than $5. we asked if it was a mistake and the lady said no. we figured maybe it was because we placed a special order, but no one had said anything about an additional fee. well, about 20 min later, we got our order. although there were no open tables in the actual restaurant or the few tables immediately outside the door, there was a giant food court-like area right in front of the restaurant that was completely empty. so we grabbed our food and ate it there. everything was average. especially the xlb's. all SIX of them. no idea what the people on yelp are raving about. and apparently, $14 was actually the normal price, even for dining in at the restaurant. absurd. other i've been to charge $2-7 for an even larger order of way better xlb's. half of the ones from yank sing didn't even have soup in them because they had leaked out. soo disappointing. :( skip this place and opt for one of the hundreds of other amazing food options in sf!
author: Ann H.

description:
Woot! Short wait, fast service, everything cooked to perfection. Yes, it is at least twice as expensive as dim sum anywhere else (we got away with $30/person), but it may be at least twice as good. Maybe better. 

Thankful for other yelpers suggesting the shanghai dumplings! Full of win!
author: Sam Z.

description: Decent, overpriced, fancy dim sum in downtown San Francisco. Their decor is super nice, they're very clean and everyone speaks English here. They cater mainly to non Chinese people - us Chinese folks know better than to pay $5.30 for two egg rolls!
author: Rosie W.

description:
Okay, I am just gonna come right out and say it - - if money is an issue, don't come here. 

However, if you're looking for an excellent meal and are relatively new to the dim sum experience, then Yank Sing is perfect. 

I'm an extremely picky eater and I unfortunately do not speak Chinese. Therefore when I decided to delve into dim sum for the first time I knew that wherever I went I would need to know exactly what was in every dumpling before I could eat it. This isn't possible when dining at other dim sum establishments that come with grumpy women who just want to get you in and get you out as soon as possible. I'm looking at you Good Luck Dim Sum... 

the first time I ate at Yank Sing they brought the carts around and offered me some shrimpy thing, to which I said no to and casually mentioned to the person I was dining with that I didn't like shrimp. From then on out the ladies with the carts didn't offer me anything with shrimp. Afterwards I found out that they have headpieces that they clue the other cart ladies in on details as such. Which really impressed me. 

As for the food, it is DELICIOUS. The beef noodle rolls, the shanghai dumplings, and the pork buns are my favorites. But the potstickers, shu mai, and sesame buns are really good as well. Also, the jasmine tea is a MUST with the meal.

I wish I could fully convey how much I love this place. 

To all the people that talk about how wonderful the food is, then knock two stars off for it being pricey: Isn't the saying, "you get what you pay for"?

p.s. I come here with my friend and we eat like lunatics and end up spending about $50 per person including tax and tip.
author: Colin A.

description:
I'm kind of sad returning from here. Don't get me wrong the food is good, the service is even better. What? yeah you heard me, the service here is phenomenal! When you ask for something, whoever it was, they take ownership of that request and follow through. they are observant, empty plates are cleared of immediately, and even water gets refilled.
  So why am i sad? I came here because Chris had raved about the cha siu bao, but the ones we got weren't that great. The honey on top had hardened and the bun wasn't fluffy as expected. 
  Overall a great dinning experience. A tad on the pricier side but with their service it makes it a worth the experience.
author: John T.

description:
We averaged about $11/person which isn't bad for a dim sum restaurant. We ordered a variety of dishes that were all really good, however my friend and I noticed they lacked in the variety of steamed dumplings available. One other disappointment was that they don't serve "tofu hua" on weekdays, only on weekends - BUMMER.

But anyway, going in to the Rincon Center to the entrance of the restaurant, I was amazed at how beautiful the setting was. There's a water fall in the middle of the center and the restaurant is just to the right. Obviously I've never been there even though I've lived around the area my whole life, so this was a nice discovery. The restaurant is in the middle of the SOMA so of course there were a lot of businessmen on this fine Friday afternoon.

The usual dishes I like to order are the shanghai soup dumplings, custard buns (have to ask specially for those), sticky rice, shrimp balls and shrimp wrapped in long rice noodle. Oh yeah, the pork ribs and chicken feet, too! MMMMMM.

It's busy. Garage parking at the Rincon Center. Validated. No brainer. GO.
author: Julia K.

description:
The best dim sum I've had so far. The 25 min wait was totally worth the experience!

Thumbs up for: 
fresh quality on food, esp. the sea bass and peking duck
refreshing atrium w/ waterfall environment 
cleaniless on food & table
soothing hot tea that is constantly refilled 

are the servers' names for real? there's no way their names are kitty, freddy, or carol. haha.. i couldn't help but notice.
author: Jane S.

description:
VERY EXPENSIVE. For 6 people, it cost around 118$. If you ask me, that's too much for dim sum. I could find a place that had around the same quality of food for a much cheaper price. Don't bother with the 'dan tat' or also known as egg tart. They give you 4/5 small ones for 10 dollars. I think that's just too much!

The best part of it was the service. Very good service. If you ask them for something they'll use their headset to get it for you. It's really cool.

The only reason why we came here was to try the pork bun because on the food network, the pork was seen as delicious. Personally, I thought the pork was good. Texture wise, it was juicy and smooth but taste wise, it tasted like any pork bun. I'm very strict on buns because I only go to dim sum for the buns

So, I thought this place was just okay. It wouldn't be my first choice of dim sum. I don't think it's even worth the price, but that's just my opinion.
author: Justina L.

description:
Review 1 in process

$90 for 2 people, for 9 dim sum platters made up of:
good enough, but my chinese-ness says to pay less in Oakland for more ghetto!
author: Jim L.

description:
Oh, how I love you dim sum.

I went here on a weekday on the later side of lunch.  The carts were still rolling, and within about 30 seconds of sitting down, the table was full of steamed yummyness.

The staff was friendly and although they try to get you to take as much as possible, they are really not overly pushy if you give a "no thank you" response to their sales tactics of "this is really good".

Yes, it's quite over-priced when you consider the cost of making the items (and I've made most of 'em myself).  The overall experience was great, and I'd go back. 

Don't forget to get your parking validated!
author: Alex H.

description:
Non greasy and good sized portions. Food comes out piping hot.

Ordered: 
Hainan chicken- gingery and flavorful 
Sticky rice and Chinese sausage wrapped in banana leaves- flavorful, moist and not dry
Pea shoots- nice saute with garlic
Har gao- huge dumplings
Tofu skin dish- very delicious
Milk Buns-warm, comforting and not too sweet
Savory Vegetable Dumpling
Peking Duck
Pork Siu Mye
Mango Pudding

Noodle dishes also looked good. 

Beautiful ambiance. Felt like I was inside a pagoda. Beautiful wood detailing and lighting was soft. Your date could possibly look a little more attractive... It is trendy but you also can't complain when the food is equally good. Because it is relatively trendy and in the midst of SF prices are about twice as much as you would otherwise pay at a traditional dim sum joint. However, I tend to go to restaurants for the experience and not the dollar sign factor. To each his own.
author: Mvt L.

description: While it may be a bit pricey, it is a must try for dim sum in San Francisco.
author: Alex G.

description:
There is legitimately good Dim Sum in the city.  Hong Kong Lounge in the Richmond comes to mind for example.  Yang Sing is mediocre dim sum at high prices.  The location is nice, and they've got all the dim sum basics, but basically you're paying 2x the price for 1/2 the quality.  

All that being said, if you have some friends coming to the city who don't know Chinese food, and you want to take them to the sort of place they imagine would serve Dim Sum, take them here.  They'll thank you, and maybe pay for the meal too. 

P.S.  Their Shanghai Soup dumplings actually had soup in them!  Shock!
author: Leon K.

description: this place is way over priced dim sum. I think koi place is by far the best in the area.
author: Chih S.

description:
It was a nice day out on Sunday, so me and my hun bun decided to go for a stroll to Yank Sing to enjoy some early afternoon Dim Sum.  The restaurant was crowded when we got there with patrons filling up the tables located within the restaurant and throughout the adjacent common area.  However, we did not have to wait too long as we were promptly seated within 10 minutes.

The service was surprisingly pleasant being that Chinese dim sum restaurants usually have the stigma of not having the most polite service.  The wait staff was attentive and always provided us with bottomless cups of water.  Although our table was located in a corner adjacent to a wall, the dim sum carts would still regularly stop at our table. 

We ordered about 8 typical dim sum dishes:  shu mai, fried pot stickers, shanghai steamed buns, scallop dumplings, spinach vegetarian dumplings; curry vegetarian dumplings, fried radish cake and flat rice noodles with roasted pork.  The cuisine was appetizing and well-prepared so together with the quality service that we received, we were going to rate the restaurant  4 stars and were thinking about coming back in the future..that is UNTIL we received our bill.  

Ever just want to say WHAT to a situation? To say the least, the bill caused us to regurgitate our food. For 8 typical dim sum dishes the total bill was around $60 (more than double of what normal dim sum places charge!). We had to ask the manager for a breakdown of the food prices (which most dim sum places provide a menu with the prices at the table, Yank Sing did not)  Notably, 2 extremely overpriced items were the fried pot stickers at $8.70 and the shanghai steam buns were $10.90 (it's not like they had shark fin in these buns)

If it weren't for the crazy prices, we might recommend Yank Sing. For those who are adventurous enough, take a look at that price list one yelper was kind enough to upload. You don't want a heart attack when you get the bill.
author: Betty C.

description:
Came here as recommended by a fellow guest at R&G.

Decor is gorgeous and the clever use of mirrors makes the place look larger. 

The food was hit or miss. The xiao long bao is to die for, the soup inside the bao is tasty and the hao gao is also well made. The dan tat feels heavy when lifting it, and it was perfect. The shell was well made--flaky and the custard was delicious. 

On the other hand, the fried food was not hot nor did it taste good. The luo ba guo was cold; although, with hot sauce, everything tastes better. Their other other food looked interesting since apparently this place is about inventive dim sum, but no go for my family. 

I did notice that the place became remarkably packed after 12pm, so I would recommend coming before. I recommend the steamed dishes versus the fried items. The steamed dishes are fresh whereas the fried items seem to have been left to sit.
author: Priscilla C.

description: This place is good if you are entertaining non-Chinese guests or on company expense, because their prices are high.  Nice atmosphere, quality dimsum, good service, but you pay for it.  If you want to just enjoy dimsum, you get far better value at other dimsum places in SF.   Our party of three adults and two kids didn't eat much but ended up with a $150 tab.  The same thing at New Asia Garden would've been less than $50.
author: Mike Y.

description:
The dim sum was mediocre, but the price was exorbitant!!!
4 people paid $150 for dim sum, and we werent even full!!!
they just stamp these things on your bill, and dont know whats what.
or how many plates you actually had. 
Bad experience...
go a few blocks down to chinatown spend a third of the $$$ and enjoy..
author: Ali M.

description:
The food here is so freakin good! There wasn't one thing I didn't like! The Sea Bass & yam dish was unbelievable. Then there was the soft-shell crab plate that was just out of this world. Service here was real nice.

Only left off a star because paying $60 for brunch when there was only 2 girls is a bit too pricey for my palette.
author: Lisa R.

description:
The best in The City
I like the one in the Rincon center. Literally IN the center. ha
Sit next to the door as the food comes out - bam your right there!

Try the Jasmine Tea so mellow and smooth. No bitter after taste.

It does get SUPER busy!
author: Erika G.

description:
This restaurant hosted the wedding that was the entire purpose of my SF weekend visit. They cleared out the entire atrium of the building and had about 35 rounds that went clear around the room. The food came out quickly and was fast. All of it was good, although I would not really consider this real Chinese food. There aren't rude servers, the food is almost too neat and it's on the expensive side. 

They did a great job with the wedding, but for authentic dim sum, I'd head to Chinatown.
author: Ming-Jou C.

description:
After attending both of my sisters wedding banquets inside the Yank Sing restaurant, I decided to follow in their footsteps and hold mine there as well.  I chose Yank Sing for their fantastic 10-course banquet dinner, especially the Chilean Sea Bass.  It's been 6 years since I last ate their dinner...and their menu prices have definitely gone up.  The starting menu is about $500.  

As for wedding planning, we initially worked with Vera, but as our wedding approached closely, we worked with Daisy as the banquet coordinator.  Communication was difficult at first when we tried to work the logistics of our banquet such as table settings and reorganizing our dinner menus.   But in the end, we were satisfied with Yank Sing's service.  One of their server named May, was phenomenal.  She tended to us throughout the service, from the tea ceremony to 'til the end of the night.   May kept us on schedule on what we wanted/needed to do for the  banquet.  Overall, I would recommend Yank Sing as a vendor to cater your wedding.
author: Lisa W.

description: Xiao lohngg bao!  It's really expensive, so no 5 stars.  After eating here, no more dim sum in SoCal.  None of the places here can compare.  Only Koi Palace is even at this level.
author: Ty C.

description:
If you work in the SOMA district of SF...this is the ultimate lunch date spot. Their Dim Sum is made fresh daily by Hong Kong trained Dim Sum chefs. This means there is a full crew, making this stuff from scratch...at 4:30am every day! 

Everything here ROCKS; spring roll, har gow, char sui bao, shrimp stick, fried taro cake, meatballs, pot stickers, egg custard, beef chow fun....ok, I'll STOP here!!!
author: Zachariah A.

description:
I normally go to less expensive dim sum places, and I don't find the food that much more impressive here, but if you can get a table out in the atrium near the fountain, it is soooo worth it! The focus of the atrium is a 5-story-, 80-foot-high waterfall-type fountain, which drops from the overhead skylights directly into a very shallow, round pool that lies on a level with the floor in the center of the atrium. Very dramatic and beautiful, and yet not at all noisy or splashy.

Inside the restaurant proper, the ambiance is less striking, more of your standard nice Chinese restaurant kind of thing. The carts come around steadily, and the wait staff is remarkably attentive, filling water glasses frequently and such.

My dim-sum-going buddy is very fond of Yank Sing's Shanghai dumplings (though I'm not so fond of the broth bursting into my mouth) and their Peking duck, but I think my favorite dish was actually the jook (rice porridge/congee). Okay, jook is simple and not the flashiest dish in the world, but at Yank Sing it was very flavorful, with a perfect consistency. Also, the slightly spicy Szechuan green beans are AMAZING, cooked just enough to be tender, but still very crisp. Just remembering them, I'm tempted to go back, because they may have been the best green beans I ever had!
author: Kimberly A.

description:
I love dim sum.  It's really hard to get wrong as well.  Yank Sing didn't blow my mind but was pretty decent.  I live close to so many lovely dim sum places, I wondered if the trek to the other side of the city would be worth it.  It was because I was meeting up with a girlfriend of mine who wanted to meet my new fiance.

The Shanghai dumplings were my favorite.  Nice and soy-sauce-y and hot.  I think that was it.  The other stuff was just average.  I think I could have gotten better less pricey dim sum in my hood.  But the conversation was fun and overall it was a fun time.
author: Susan C.

description: I crave the soup dumplings, but my hubby won't let me return because of the prices :(
author: J. G.

description:
I think this was the best dim sum experience I've ever had. Totally didn't expect the whole shopping center to be closed off, so they could have tables set up next to the water fountain! Now if only they could seat us closer to the fountain everything would have been perfect...

Dim sum was delicious. The thing that usually makes it or breaks for me at dim sum restaurants is how fresh the chinese broccoli is. If it's bitter and nasty, I tend to be turned off from the place, but that was not the case at Yank Sing. There was a lot of dim sum carts going around with a huge selection of things to choose from, so if you're sick of going to a dim sum places that don't have everything, this is the place to go to. 

The workers are friendly too. They're really good about getting you what you want even if they don't have it on that particular cart because they have headsets to communicate with other workers--SUPER LIKE!

This place is pretty pricey for dim sum though. We spent about $30 each person, so I definitely wouldn't make this my usual place to eat.
author: Angelic L.

description: The setting is beautiful, but the food is not good and very expensive.  I came here because this place had a very good rating, but I think the people who go here don't know what dim sum is supposed to taste like.  The food here was bland.  Small portions.  Did I mention expensive?  They didn't have liver or tripe.  I shouldn't have been surprised.  If you want good dim sum, you should probably go to China Town.
author: Cindy T.

description: High end dimsum place. It's has a good menu for its dimsum but expensive as compared to traditional ones. I ate at this place several times and it's a hit or miss for my MSG allergy. Overall not bad at all.
author: Michelle L.

description:
So I grew up in LA, and pretty much lived off dim sum. I went three-times a week- and it got to the point were the dim sum ladies would know my family by name and exchange fruit& pictures of their kids with them. I even made a pound of the pan-fried radish cake at home once... ugh, but that's another story.

After moving to the Bay Area, I have not yet found a dim sum restaurant that can rival those of LA in taste, price, and atmosphere. And so, even after reading so many good reviews, I was super critical of this restaurant walking in. 

My cousin rent out the atrium in front of the restaurant for "red egg& ginger party", so all the table received a good sampling of all the dim sum they served at Yank Sing. 

I think that I was impressed with only half the dishes they served. The presentation for the "Peking duck with flat bread, spring onions" was flawless (the fat was completely gone& only the top layers were displayed)- the duck was sliced so perfectly, that my friend commented this is only place that's done it correctly besides Beijing. I personally like their Shanghai dumplings- it's rare for me to find a place (& a dim sum place to boot!) that can keep all the soup in the dumpling. 

The other dishes were meh- I've had better shumai, shrimp dumplings, & Asian buns in L.A. 

Atmosphere-wise, this place is definitely fancier (&prolly pricier) than your average dim sum restaurant- but I think it's good to have a change in atmosphere every once in while.
author: Lucia C.

description: One customer commented on the professionalism of the hostess.  I totally disagree.   I found the hostess to be extremely rude.  We originally had a lunch reservation for 3 people today and needed to add one more person.  My colleague called in the morning and requested for the change.  The hostess was so rude and said a flat "no".  She said the restaurant is very busy and cannot accommodate this change.  I am very surprised. Since we have a reservation for 3 people already, this means we only need to add one more setting vs. changing table as I am sure we will be seated at a 4 people table.  The hostess needs some training on customer service and needs to understand that loyal customers will leave if this kind of treatment continues.
author: Rocky B.

description:
The best dim sum place and food I've had or comparable to Hong Kong.

It is a bit pricy for dim sum but everything was very well done.

I came here twice during my visit to SF and both times, this place was busy.

It's also the cleanest chinese restaurant I've ever been to, the most courteous and efficient.  hahaha..i got a kick at how all the waitstaff had like a CIA like earpiece.  Overall the best service I've ever experience in a chinese restaurant (not counting Mr. Chow b/c I don't consider that real chinese....you know what i mean).

Overall...this place is awesome.
Food: Best Dim Sum outside of HK
Decor: Typical chinese set up but definitely much cleaner
Service: Efficient and surprisingly courteous.  I'm use to the Flushing/ Chinatown DimSum services...you know what i mean.
Vibe: crowded and energetic.  You're always on lookout for your next dish.
author: N S.

description: this bathroom uses high quality materials in a tiny space. like a tiny vegas bathroom.
author: Fzarond K.

description:
YAY for Dim Sum! Or, shall I say "Yum Cha". This is my favorite type of Chinese food. Dim sum is a Cantonese style of eating. Their dishes involves small individual portions of food. The cart ladies stroll by with their carts filled with small steamer baskets or small plates of food. All of which are delicious in their own ways!

Yank Sing's dim sum is very good, and perhaps the best I've eaten in SF. They are on top with their service. (something you usually don't get with Chinese Restaurants). If there's something you'd like, and you don't see it being pushed around in carts, simply ask one of the waitresses. Each worker wears ear pieces and microphones that helps one another communicate which helps us get our food in a snap.

This place is always jammed pack, and the prices are high compared to other Dim Sum places in SF. But, if you love Dim Sum, you'll love it here at Yank Sing. It's a place where friends and families gather, great atmosphere that is filled with energy. :)
author: Sweet P.

description: Lettuce wraps good, mushroom and mandarin dumplings ok but no dipping sauce, sea bass roll greasy but fish was good, kept asking for the Peking ribs and after 10 minutes, just left. Reviewed the check total and $2 mysteriously added on.  They fixed it but not sure what the hype is. Wouldn't really recommend.
author: Leslie S.

description:
I heard so many things about this dim sum place. We finally tried it today with my brother and his friend. We called for a reservation, arrived early and were seated pretty promptly. A lot of people were waiting for tables. 
We order: shanghai dumplings - ok, shrimp dumplings - i thought was the best one out of all, $19.95 seared sea bass - sauce was too sweet, scallop dumplings were blend, sticky rice - do not taste like what we usually have at other dim sum place...no salty egg yolk and only tastes the bbq pork, shrimp rice crepe and beef rice crepe were served luke warm...yuck...we each tried a piece and didn't touch the rest, chicken feet - ok, black bean spareribs  - ok...BBQ pork - not good. 
This place is catered to American and 3rd or 4th generation Chinese. Quality and taste of dim sum is not good worth the price at all. Dim sum at HK Flower Lounge on Geary or any dim sum place at Millbrae we tried are all better. We can't understand why this restaurant is so busy!!! Definitely will not go back!!!
author: Cony K.

description: This is what I consider "westernized" dim sum. Located in the heart of downtown SF so of course, catered  to your fru-fru corporate heads.  Servers speak in "engrish" and tell you what each thing is.  I'm not gonna front, food here is delicious.  BUT MAN, it's expensive for small dishes??  It's like I gotta order 5 of 'em to fill me up!
author: Diana M.

description:
I am in no way an authority on good deem sum, but I've enjoyed many meals here with my wonderful chinese friends and they give the place two thumbs up.

I stick to any of the steamed dumplings (nothing fried for me), steamed pork buns (my fav!), the sticky rice in lotus leaf which is very comforting the morning after a late night and the tasty sesame balls if I have a hankering for something sweet.

They are open until 4pm on the weekends and the garage below provides free parking with validation. Works for me!
author: Coco M.

description: A friend took us here for lunch on a Sunday.  Im not much of a dim sum eater, only because most of the random things I tend to pick have failed my taste buds and wallet.  You need to spend a lot of money and waste stomach space to know dim sum.  Luckily, my friend was a reg here and knew what to order.  Sorry I don't know the names of the dishes, so you'll just have to check out my pics.  I do remember the jin doy (spl?) Everyone on our table thought it was crack.  We came back the next day to get a box to take home.  It was that serious.  Anyways I thought it was a pretty expensive lunch - $160 for 5 but worth the experience.
author: J L.

description:
I haven't had legitimate dim sum in a long time and Yank Sing did not disappoint. With a wide selection of options, each dish was as tasty as the one before it. The location itself is pretty amazing. You walk in and you have a quick host area before entering into a high-ceiling, windowed dome full of tables. And all around, like spokes on a bicycle, are smaller rooms with a number of additional tables.

It's also fairly convenient. Although the day I went, there was a Father's Day event going on that made parking a nightmare, I've been told by a regular that parking is usually quick and painless.

Having said all that, Yank Sing is incredibly expensive for what it is. I've found dim sum to be fairly expensive in general, but these prices are pretty ridiculous. But I'd still go again!
author: Alvin L.

description: Everything was delicious and the dishes were all fresh and high-quality. Service was attentive. Was it pricey? Yes, but nothing ridiculous, especially for the quality. Not a bargain joint, but great for parents or groups of friends.
author: Jordan H.

description: I'm very conflicted about Yank Sing.  It was featured in multiple TV shows and highly regarded by the food critics.  I do admit that their dim sum is the best I've ever had.  I usually do not like BBQ pork buns, but I LOVED theirs.  Their shanghai dumplings are awesome... but I've had something similar at Capital Seafood and other dimsum establishments.  Our lunch for a family of 4 came out to $150 (for 12 small plates), which I think is outrageous.  Yes, it is really good dim sum.  But is it worth triple/quadruple the price?  No, definitely not.
author: Sofie D.

description: Best pork dumpling I've probably ever had. Great food all around, fast options coming at you as it should be. Didn't pick a bad item and missed out on a few I wanted. However, I did get a second order of those pork dumplings!  Will be back.
author: Reid W.

description:
Whenever I go to dimsum in SF, it's at Yank Sing. 

Pros:
-Consistently good; never surprised by the quality of the food. Plus all the dishes are served piping hot (temperature-wise)
-Good service. The cart pushers and waiters are equipped w/ headsets so they can talk to each other. E.g. if I want a particular dish, they will call over the person who has the cart containing that dish. Quickly.
-Dim sum is plentiful -- many places I go to, you're left waiting and waiting until the carts appear. 
-Free parking on weekends b/c they validate
-The Yank Sing special sauce that is available at each table's condiment tray. A cross between chili + black bean sauce. Delicious when mixed w/ soy sauce too.

Cons:
-Expensive. Be prepared to pay over $25 per person for dimsum. That's significantly more than most places
-Restrooms are CRAMPED.
author: Christine T.

description:
Definitly not worth the price! Nor the experience.

I don't have much to say, other than EXTREMELY americanized dim-sum. I'm so used to the original classic chinese dimsum that when I tried this place out w. a few coworkers for lunch, we were ALL dissapointed.

- The portions, alright. 

- Prices - RIDICULOUS!  For each little basket was about 5 bucks, when there was only 4 small pieces in there. The sui mai was 5 bucks, same w. the har gow, & 2 peices of bao's was 6 bucks! & one measly "sticky" rice leaf was 5 bucks! Absolutely ridiculously expensive. NOT worth it. Everything is so american and to be honest, kindof gross. The sticky rice wasn't even properly made, it was just regular white rice w. some bbq pork in the center? I don't even know.

- Service: It was pretty quick, a lot of variety. BUT, dissapointed in quality of food. 

One thing i didn;t like is, we didn't order tea, but a lady persisted to come by and drop off a pot. We told them we didnt order but they refused to listen, so we ended up just drinking it. You have to PAY for the tea too! 6 bucks!

Only a 1 time thing, I will never come here again. I'd rather take an extra 10 minutes and go to china town where the REAL dim sum is at.
author: Jessica L.

description:
There's one thing that is at a premium in San Francisco... parking!... and Yank Sing actually has it. Depending on what day of the week you go, you either get discounted parking (which is still great for SF) or you get up to 3 hours of free parking (weekends or holidays only). Either way, you win. 

We showed up on a Sunday at 2:30 and we were seated right away. The oolong tea was good. We had shrimp shu mai, the pork and ginger steamed buns, pot stickers, chicken egg rolls, the barbecue spareribs, and last but not least the sesame seed balls for dessert. Everything was pretty decent. 

The only thing I wasn't too keen on was the price of the food. It really is pricey for dim (average price was $5 and went upwards to $15 for one plate). The food servers were helpful and the selection was ok but there was a dry spell dry where no one was attending to us much less offering us food. Food was authentically good but it seemed too commercialized in some ways.
author: Melanie A.

description: OK so this place is supposed to be the king daddy of all the dim sum in San Francisco. I am no expert on this whole Chinese dumpling thing but I know what I like when I have it. This was outstandingly good. Superlicious in fact. Yes its very expensive. The house special Shanghai pork dumpling was $12.95 for six pieces. And they go down quick. But they are crazy good little steaming hot dumplings full of a hot soup broth with tasty ground up pork inside. Sort of like a fat wonton. You sit at your table and they keep coming around with carts stacked with these bamboo bowl things with lids on them and they tell you what they have if you want to try it. Every time you get one, they mark it on your receipt and then count it up when you are done. Brilliant. I had a few other dumplings, pork buns, pot sticker things etc. and most of the time I had little idea what was in them. Could have been hound dog but I could have cared less, it was all very good. But it adds up quickly when many of these bowls are $7 to $12. I also got the Peking duck which was very good but sadly was a very small piece. To me this is a top of the line high end example of a San Fran dim sum restaurant. There are lots of others in Chinatown for far less the price but this is a special occasion one. I would certainly go again if possible.
author: Brian B.

description:
3.5 stars

Aside from the obvious---WAY TOO expensive for dim sum, the food did not live up to the price.  The food was good but you can find other comparable dim sum places for much cheaper.  I believe our bill for 6-7 dishes was $45.  That's over $6 a dish?!

The only dish that stood out for me (and you probably can't get anywhere else) is the stuffed crab claws.  Its actual whole crab claws filled with pieces of seafood that you can actually see.

I wouldn't rave this is the best dim sum place I've been to or visit again.
author: Sunny W.

description:
I'm by no means a dim sum expert, but this was, by far, some of the best dim sum that I've had.  It probably didn't hurt that I went with a coworker who had been there before, and had a keen eye (and taste) for what to get off each quickly rolling cart. 

The soup dumplings were divine, the wrappers so delicate that you really needed to be gentle.  ...but when they reached your mouth? Perfect little morsels. I had always shied away from turnip cake, but it was quite good with a little sauce.  

I was in a pleasantly full state as we sipped our last tea and wound down. Yes, when the bill came, it was certainly expensive.  I wouldn't rule out that there might be less "fancy" dim sum places with food that's just as tasty.  But... Yank Sing still gets my fan-dom on its own merits. 

Was it worth it? Indeed. I'd particularly recommend Yank Sing if you have a larger group so that you can try plenty of things and defray the higher price a bit.
author: mariah c.

description: Best Dim Sum Ever!!  Hands down!!  Talk about fresh and perfectly sumptuous.  Unfortunately, the wait is ridiculous, but since I love their foods so much, I will review the food only.  They need to get a larger venue.
author: G B.

description: Over price, the food is A- not excellent be A+. 4 people eat very basic lunch dim sum about 7 small plates cost $120 including tips and we still hungry.
author: Ecks E.

description: Great brunch. Servers a bit aggressive and u have to know ur way around dimsum. But a good place to go with friends anf spend a nice sunday morning
author: Riad A.

description: What. a. rip. off! We heard the XLBs were good here, so we paid a visit to Yank Sing on a Sunday for dim sum. What should have first tipped us off as to what we were in for was how many non-Chinese people were eating here and there was a printed menu in English. We ordered only a few things, as the prices were exorbitant- XLBs (2 orders), shrimp dumplings, pork and shrimp shu mai, and gai lan. Each item was just ok-- could have been at any other dim sum place. The XLBs were only pork- no delicious crab meat inside, like Joe's Shanghai. Even without the crab, the XLBs were good. But at $11.55 for 6 XLBs is crazy!! And tea at $4?? Come on! Our lunch cost us $55, which is loco for dim sum for only 6 dishes that weren't stellar in any way. I can't recommend Yank Sing unless you like overpriced Chinese food.
author: Merrill H.

description:
Why do people keep saying this place is "westernized"??? Are you comparing this restaurant to Chinatown? or dim sum in Hong Kong (where this deliciousness truly came from)? I grew up in Hong Kong & Shanghai, lived in both LA & SF, so I have so say that aside from the high price, this is as authentic as it gets here. 

Their Shanghai dumplings: the key to this dish is that the skin must be thin yet DO NOT BREAK as you pick it up to eat. There should be juice or broth on the inside that has not leaked out. And filling should be pork meat, without loads of MSG or onions! The times I've come here, they have all met these criteria, so I'm willing to pay the price just to be transported back to my childhood, when I used to visit my grandma in shanghai every summer. 

Har Gau & other steamed dumplings: if you like your dumplings full of onions & leek, please do not come here. Their dumplings have really good quality ingredients and their skins DO NOT BREAK! I can't stress that enough because so many places, (even in HK), make dumplings that either fall apart or have skins super thick and chewy. Yuck! 

Snow pea shoot (dow miu?) is pretty good. Also fried spring rolls are pretty good here. The filling has pork, shitake, and cabbage, not stuffed with raw carrots & cabbage like some places in SoCal. I also love the fact that dishes are not very salty or full of MSG. Some people really like "flavor" but I prefer the milder taste of the ingredients alone. 

The price is definitely $$$. But please don't say things like you could just go to chinatown for a third of that price and get the same thing. Because you really CAN'T get the same thing. Due to work & college, I haven't visited Asia in about 5 years, so when I really crave good dim sum I come here despite the price. I figure since I never go to those crappy dim sum places in SF or Oakland chinatown, I've already saved up enough for this place.
author: Anna C.

description:
I first heard about Yank Sing from the food network channel while I was watching The Best Thing I Ever Ate. 
The baked pork buns they were talking about looked sooo good that I actually called up some friends right away to tell them about it & I was able to convince them to come with me to the restaurant that day! ;Dlol 

We rushed over there since we live 45mins away.
WOW..the baked pork buns are definately 1 of the best things I ever ate! They are now 1 of my favorite foods. :-9  
It's perfect...hot savory bbq pork inside a soft bun with a honey glazed top that's baked golden brown. 
My sister also tends to watch The Best Thing I Ever ate so when I told her about Yank Sing, she wanted to go asap too so we went that weekend. haha
From the dim sum carts my sister & I got:
~Xiao Long Bao
~Potstickers
~Shrimp dumplings
~Pork Siu Mye
~Stuffed mushrooms w/ oyster sauce
~ 1 order of Baked pork buns & 1 order of steamed pork buns (2-3 per order) 
~Sesame Balls & egg tarts for dessert.

We also ordered the Chicken Chow Fun and that was really really good! We ordered quite a bit just for us two but we wanted to try as much as we could. haha My favorites were the Baked & steamed Pork Buns, Chicken Chow Fun & sesame balls. So if you go there, I highly recommend that you try those. 

While we were eating, we see a cart with peking duck! It looked sooo yummy but we already had a 4 person table filled w/ food  (a 2 person table was too small so we had to move! hahah)  we still had yet to finish. We were sad we didnt see it earlier or else we would have ordered that because the other stuff was just OK... but we decided that the peking duck is a must try next time we go. 

I give it 4 stars & the minus 1 star is because you can tell 2-3 of the women pushing around the carts are rushy/impatient & do not look very happy to inform you about what some of the foods on the carts are...I hate the negative vibe you get from those kinds of waiters.. totally brings down the dining experience. :/  (atleast 1 waiter was pretty nice though!) & it is pretty pricey. :/  Our bill for 2 was over $100! Some of the stuff was over priced...I think the 5 small stuffed mushrooms were over $11. Which means each little mushroom was over $2.  When I went w/ my friends we tried to order less but the bill was still about $30 per person. 
They also charge $3 or $4 for tea that is usually free at all chinese restaurants... & you don't find out until you see the bill because they offer everyone tea w/o saying its an extra charge. :/
IF you even notice it because I definately didnt notice that the first time I went with my friends but my sister did when I went the 2nd time...

Still this place has the baked & steamed pork buns that are to die for. :)
author: Eunjoo P.

description: Best dim sum I have had. Outstanding quality and very prompt coordinated service. Only negative is that it is somewhat spendy. Still given the quality the cost was barely noticeable.
author: John M.

description:
Used to be a shit ton better a while ago...I mean some of it's good, but for the price you pay...semi-rip off. 

Wanted dim sum with the family and that's typically hard to come by without a line on a Saturday! So parents decided Yank Sing because we went here before in the past and it was yummy. Well this time around...

- Big, plenty of tables, the wait staff is nice, and the bonai tea is crackin'. 
A little sad that there weren't as many crazy cart people going around and that they didn't have more of a selection...

-Shrimp dumplings: good, but weren't as moist and juicey as they usually should be on the inside...

- Shumai: really not that awesome...were kinda dry...or just not as moist as I had in the past.

- The floppy white noodle things with shrimp on the inside and shoyu-based sauce (really need to step it up with my Chinese side hahah...I wanna say it's called Shern Fun?): had a weird taste...

- Steam buns with Pekking duck: was really whatever. Had better ones at Gourmet on Franklin street for hella cheaper.

- Steamed char siu baos: They are very very soft and delicious here! 'Cept I wish there was more filling 'cause I like more filling but it's quite good!

- String beans: flavor wasn't that on point.

- Turnip cake: I liked how it wasn't too greasy and it really did taste fresh.

- Shitake mushroom pot sticker thing: very good flavor from the shroomsies!

- Vegetarian egg rolls: nothing special.

- Shanghai dumplings: were good, but I've had better. My sister said the dumpling place on Balboa shits on them.

- Sesame balls: very good.

- Dan tats or the custard tarts: the custard wasn't that good. 

It got the job done...but it's not like how it was a long time ago when I was younger! It's just AVERAGE dimsum for a LOT of cash money.
author: Eryn K.

description: I'd consider Yank Sing to be the gourmet dim sum, hence, the price is a bit up there. The food in general is on the sweeter and milder side. While I don't feel it's truly authentic, it is a very good blend of traditional and modern cooking -- perhaps aimed for both regulars to dim sum and people who are not very adventurous with food.  Regardless, the food is very yummy. The ingredients tend to incorporated more seafood items and they taste fresh. I'd recommend making reservations.
author: Andy C.

description:
Positives:
Good dim sum. Dumplings are great. Clean and moderately upscale.

Negatives:
Someone tell the servers that when we have 6 full plates on the table they don't have to bumrush us with another series of offerings. the vibe being very hectic is true. That with a bit overpriced takes this down a star. 

If you just want good grub and don't care if everyone rushes you, then this is solid. But, there are a number of places in the Richmond who offer food that is at least as good who don't have these shortcomings.

For lunch hour, make reservations.
author: Marcus J.

description:
Yank Sing always seems to be my place for business meetings.  The  service is good, food quality is clean, they have the authenticity of dim sum with the understanding of western lunch meetings.   Did that make sense??   When in SF, I insist on having my business lunches here because of the cleanliness, service, price and location.  I find the large Chinese ones are way too loud to carry any discussion and they try as quick as they can scoot you out.  

I wish LA could conjure up a Yank Sing for business lunches and brunches.
author: Thad C.

description: For a Dim Sum lover, this place rocked. Everything you could order is delicious. I tried almost everything that came around, but my favorites are the Peking Duck and Pork Buns. The Szechsuan Chicken was also super good! I came straight here after getting off my plane. Best Dim Sum in the city.
author: Hannah S.

description:
I used to work across the street from the Rincon center so I've had Yank Sing to go several times. I'd be hard pressed to give the to go portion even 3 stars and I've actually been to a weeding catered by Yank Sing in the Rincon center so when my girlfriend suggested we go to Yank Sing for dim sum, I have to admit I was a bit skeptical since I knew it was going to bit a more expensive than a regular Dim Sum place. 

I was totally surprised. The dim sum was tasty and not greasy. They have these soup dumplings that are to die for. FYI if you don't know they're little dumplings that have a tiny bit of soup so you pick one up and put it on your spoon. Break it open and pour a little bit of the red vinegar you get and then you can sip on the soup from your spoon or try and soldier through and envelope the whole thing in your mouth. Depending on the temperature of the soup, the latter could cause you to scald the inside of your mouth. lol

Most everything is else really flavorful and in comparison to most other dim sum places I've been to, much less greasy. The shumai was tasty with the pork and shrimp. The potstickers were delicious.

The one thing I'm torn on is the duck sandwiches. You know the little buns you get with a little bit sprig of green onion, piece of duck and some plum sauce to put on it. So I love duck sandwiches where you get a nice crispy piece of skin. Other places are usually good about it and the duck sandwiches even though are a bit more expensive still usually come three to an order. At Yank Sing they charge about 5 bucks for one and the pieces of duck are definitely much meatier but the skin wasn't that crispy. I have to say that was the one thing I felt I liked the cheaper grungier dim sum places.

We went a couple times before I decided to write this review to make sure it wasn't my extreme hunger that was skewing how I felt about this place. Both times the food was the same consistency. Service isn't fantastic but it's a great place to bring out of towners or if you just want some quality dim sum and you're not so much on a budget.

Oh also FYI they validate for parking in the Rincon garage which is awesome.
author: Hyung L.

description: It is expensive, but the food never stops, is never cold, and occasionally surprises with items like deep fried Sea Bass, that I have never seen before. A great place to go if you feel like splurging on something outside of the Richmond.
author: Michael J.

description:
After about 5 visits, I can say with confidence that my love affair with Yank Sing is almost over...

The 'WOW' factor just doesn't happen anymore like it did the first time with the shanghai dumplings.  My husband & I spent countless months in Socal looking for these delicious dumplings with no success.  We ended up in SF for an event llast year and stumpled upon YS dumplings.  We were seriously "wow'ed"..  They were perfectly cooked and they ginger/soy dipping sauce was the perfect complement, the meat filling was tasty, and when consumed all together with the savory soup, it was heavenly.. 

We made our way to YS numerous times throughout the year and honestly, I believe the quality has decreased while the price seems to increase.  Last week the dumplings seemed off..  The restaurant was packed and the dumpling cart started off with the highest stacks of these dishes..  It seemed like they were 3-4 feet high.  Anyways, we eyed them around the restaurant and when they finally made it to us we were dissapointed.  The skin was hard, the meat was 'barely' a bite, and the lukewarm soup was just so-so..

For $1 a piece, it's hardly a bargain and the bill can add up really quickly.  We had about 7 different dishes and our bill was $50+.

YS is definitely a great place to try dimsum for the first time, but once you start knowing your favorites, there are SO MANY other better places in & around SF.
author: Seung Eun C.

description:
So.....for me Yank Sing was the mythical hot sauce that I have kept in the house for years to "doctor up" the barely passable Asian food we get here in Firenze when I need my fix.  
The name Yank Sing was even more magical since it was introduced to me with it's fairytale story of how it was this sauce that was the gateway to the Chan family's American Dream - from a tiny 40 seat restaurant "under a bridge" near Broadway and Powell Street to a 230 seat bustling mainstream restaurant and soon after a second location nearby......The story I heard was that the Chans noticed that people were swiping their home made hot sauce sitting on the tables in their original location; and thought hmmmmmmm.....people really like our sauce - so they decided to package and sell it and it went "viral".  The chili pepper sauce business made enough profits for them to move out of Chinatown and over to the Embarcadero area.
So when I was in San Francisco recently I was dying to go......but sadly it was over touristed and not the mystical place I built it up to be in my mind.  
Honestly it is easy to please my Asian food palate after living in Italy for the past couple of decades where "ethnic food" was just accepted over the past 10 years but not evolved into anything super yummy yet. But even with my current low bar, Yank Sing was less than memorable.  The really friendly wait staff does stick in my mind as does my putting their Chili XO sauce on just about everything.....I really thought doctoring up would not be necessary here at the home of yummy dim sum but quality is often compromised  with quantity and at least the condiment compensates worldwide!

So although the restaurant gets an mmm.....ok
YS Chili Pepper Sauce 5 stars!!!!
YS Chili XO Sauce 5 stars!!!!
author: Jennifer S.

description:
This place didn't piss me off so I'm contradicting my motto but whatever.

Came here for lunch today so it's still fresh in my head.  I give this place two stars and the two stars are really for the decor and the service.  For Chinese restaurants, this is probably the cleanest place and offers you the most professional service.  Not trying to be racist but YS caters to Caucasians and not Chinese so everyone that works there speaks to you in English instead of Chinese which tells me one thing 1) the food isn't going to be that great.  Onto the food.

We only had a few different dim sums and then realized 1) the food wasn't good and 2) it was not worth it.  The bbq pork bun to start off with, there were only two, most restaurants have three which is fine.  The bun's shape wasn't well made, there weren't a lot of bbq pork in the bun, and it wasn't hot.  The shrimp dumpling was luke warm at best, so were the egg rolls, and so were rice noodles.  The rice noodles were $7, egg custards which we did not get were $9.  Egg custards at $9?  I'm definitely not one of those people who isn't willing to spend more on food and I'm not going to tell you that you'll get better quality in Chinatown but simply put the food is over priced and the quality is not there.  They also lack variety; many carts that came around were the same food over and over again.

Unless I was invited to YS, I will not go back.
author: Pierre L.

description:
After enduring five job interviews in the last two days, I was in serious need of a treat...a special splurge...some comfort food. What better way to treat myself than to stuff my face with dim sum. Actually, the truth is...what better way for a generous, employed friend to treat their poor, laid-off friend to lunch. 

The Shanghai dumplings were delicious, while the Peking duck was forgettable. The pork siu mai, potstickers, and the handful of other items we ordered were all good. I have to admit that I have no idea what half of the things we ate were because it was a whirlwind of a lunch, with dim sum carts coming at us every two seconds like we were in some freakin' dim sum eating race with a five minute time limit. I'm no dim sum expert, but all I know is that Yank Sing is much better than the Old Place Seafood House in Oakland. Of course, $56 for lunch is outrageous, but thank goodness for generous, thoughtful friends.
author: Anastasia B.

description:
Nice restaurant for dim sum. Fancy and pricey for what we call just regular asian fast food =) 

the steamed bao's which is their famous dish is just mediocre. Its good, yes. but nothing special. Just like the din tai fung in san gabriel. 

The sea bass that is baked was great! $17 for the dish. fyi its not the one they push around the carts or carry around. we ordered it from the waiter and took aboug 15 -20mins. so order it first.

The service is impeccable though! If you want fast and efficient service that is also kind and friendly you should go here.
author: Mary M.

description:
Look at the PRICE before you order!!! The menu is at the table! If you don't mind paying lots of money for regular dim sum...go right ahead =]

I went here with 2 other guest a few months ago on a saturday afternoon. We came here for dim sum around 11:30 am. It was packed. Parking is free on the weekends at the Rincon Center. Give the ticket to the waiter and they will validate for you.

Tea is served right away when we get our seats. We waited probably less than 5 minutes. We sat down and next thing we know is people bombarding us with food choices. We order the standard har gao, yui chi gao and some specialties like the siu leung bao. Food was very fresh, hot, and steamy just the way I like it.  I had to use their special yank sing chili oil to compliment the dishes. The dumplings didn't stick to each other and didn't fall apart. However, the food itself was very plain and ordinary compared to other dim sum places.

The most important part of my meal I would like to discuss is the PRICE. For the group of three eating moderately with dessert (btw the mango pudding is terrible...) before tip was just over 100 bucks. I don't mind paying for food that is good and expensive but when food is regular and expensive, its just a rip off. The har gao was about 7 bucks, the siu leung bao was like 12 bucks for 7 pieces...For that price I could have bought 3 bags from 99 Ranch and steamed them and fed a family of 12.

My overall rating of this place is a 3 for good service, easy parking, and standard food. The price destroys the actual value of the dim sum which is definitely not worth what we paid.
author: Jason W.

description:
dont get me wrong, the dim sum here was great, but it wasn't great enough to justify the extremely high prices.

sure, the servers were nicer and spoke better english than at most dim sum places and it was clean inside, but the actual product isnt really that much better than what you would find at City View or Koi Palace.

the red flag is the fact that 60% of the clientele are white.

all of the dumplings and the sesame balls were above average to great with the exception of the shanghai dumplings which were forgettable.  i also felt the lettuce wraps were bland and subpar.

i doubt i will be returning anytime soon.  Koi Palace is just as good and half the price.
author: Christian C.

description:
Great Xiao Long Bao, Great Service!

Weird to be eating such good yum cha in the middle of what feels like a shopping mall atrium. I had to dock a star for the shopping mall feel and the fact that it's the most expensive dim sum I've ever had.

I have never had someone say "Enjoy", or notice we were looking for something and come over and ask, "Is there something you're looking for that I can help with?".  My goodness they were so friendly I didn't know what to do with myself!  All the explanations were in English as well, but they understand Chinese if you want to try to have a more authentic experience. 

The char siu bao and char siu cheong fun were really good.

Other than feeling like I'm in some super mall, it is pricey.  But I do think I got pretty good food for what I paid. They charge for tea per person - so if you don't drink it, let them know.  The tea pots are pretty cool, though!

They take reservations - so to avoid waiting, make a reservation and you shouldn't have any trouble getting a seat!

Parking on Sat/Sun is fully validated in the under ground garage - so bring in your ticket.  Parking around there on a Sunday morning isn't too bad either.  On weekdays I think there is still a parking charge, even if it's validated.
author: Traci H.

description:
The most expensive breakfast ever.  I was going to give 3 stars till I saw the bill.  $72 for 2 people, just dim sum and tea, no booze.   The dimsum was just OK, perhaps the least tasty I've ever had.  Portions were too large for 2 people, and each plate was between $5-10.

Service was fast as you would expect in a dimsum place.  The flavors were different from every other dimsum I've had, and I didn't like them as much.  I'm sure there are many places with better food and better value - I'll definitely be looking elsewhere next time.
author: David G.

description: A little pricey, but the food was fresh and they used good ingredients.  Some of the servers are a little pushy when they come around with the dishes.  I dunno, maybe because my friends and I went on a Monday afternoon at around 3pm.  We got a whole range of dumplings, shumai, pork buns, crab rangoons, etc.  We ordered some food that wasn't on their carts and those came out fast and hot.
author: Byron K.

description: I'm only giving it two star because my friend likes this place. Terrible service, the servers wear ear pieces but who the hell knows who they're talking to because they sure didn't bring what we requested. This is expensive over priced dim sum. The food quality does not meet the price. Dim sum....Dim NOT!
author: Vero H.

description:
ah piss off......
this restaurant offended me.
food was very mediocre 
and didn't stand out.

only good and unique dish here was the soup dumplings
but i'm talking about DIM SUM standard GOOD
not shanghai style dumpling GREAT, cuz then you can't compare.

for the chokingly expensive prices for each individual dish, the hype and the wait, ahhhhhhh PISS OFF. 

dont' bother finding parking, take a long drive over to Milbrae,CA (conveniently close to SFO) to asian pearl seafood restaurant.( http://www.yelp.com/biz/asian-pearl-seafood-restaurant-millbrae ) i had the best DIM SUM in my life there and knowing NY'ers, that's hard to admit. Suckered punch delicious.
author: Davina L.

description:
We come here for dim sum whenever in SF.  Best dim sum in California.  They are efficient, polite, and offer a wide variety of choices.  Love their homemade chili sauce too!!

Update to 2014 from 2011.  Def feels like prices went up, and tea is expensive!  Refills are not free so FYI!  Still some of the best dim sum I've had in California.
author: Modern L.

description: I have eaten here before at this very fancy restaurant before during the lunch hours at Yank Sing. This place reminds me of a Five Star Chinese Restaurant. I like the way how they decorated the inside of Yank Sing.
author: William B.

description:
I just ate here for brunch today, then drove 5.5 hours back to Los Angeles.  The food was fantastic and I'm glad I went back.

As usual, everything was great, from very pedestrian items like Shrimp Har Gow to more exotic things like Chicken Feet.  I was sad to find that they didn't have tendon or tripe, but I'll have to snag those on my next trip up to San Francisco.
author: Ian M.

description:
I really hate this place.  Although their XLB here is probably one of the best in the city, I just can't overlook their pretentious and prissy attitude on a classic such as dim sum.   To pay for these prices and some of their other God awful selections that they have is ridiculous.
