They served us really cold vegetables with oyster sauce today and I told them we would like it warm.  They say............this is how we serve them.  I said can you warm them up?  They said...... we don't have  a microwave and this is how it is suppose to be eaten.  That's why there are a dozen orders of the same dishes on your tray that aren't sold right? 

Their other dim sum like har gow, siu mai, lo mai gai, tarot.............are all very forgetteable.  You can get any of these items anywhere for half the price.  Remember, you only come here if you don't know better or if you are here to impress your friends, families, or clients.  Have you ever thought that if you were here to impress a client.........wouldn't they question the way you spend?  hahahhah.  there is a food for thought.

When did a piece of peking duck and bread cost over 5 dollars an order? The next time there is an event here, may it be a wedding or a red egg party, I am not coming.  

5 ppl for 150.00.
author: jason g.

description: Nice restaurant in convenient south of Market location.  Excellent dim sum, some of the best I've had in the US.  The variety was also incredible.  However, the price was VERY high, and the restaurant was quite noisy, it was hard to have a conversation with only one other person at the table!  Furthermore, the servers were constantly interrupting, even when our table was full of food.  Next time, I'll forgo the restaurant service and visit their "to go" restaurant (prices about half), and sit in the indoor courtyard (that has tables) to enjoy the food without the hassles.
author: M K.

description: Hands down, the finest dim sum within the SF city limits, but it comes with a high price tag, and a long waiting line!
author: Mandy C.

description:
Dim sum: NOT GOOD. It's unjustifiably overpriced and it seems like everything is deep fried. I would say go to Koi Palace in Daly City if you want overpriced dim sum that's worth it. I'll lay that to rest now.

Dinner: SO GOOD! I attended two wedding banquets here and the food is absolutely fresh and delicious! My favorite is the fried crab claw and sweet chili seabass. Their shark fin is really good too. Perfectly flavored and not just 3.8 shreds of shark fin in it. The service is attentive and efficient. I was the MOH in one of the weddings and they were right there to assist the bride and to help her with moving things in a timely manner. They were very accommodating and never rude or pushy. Yank Sing is definitely the place for brides who want the Chinese banquet food without the gaudy, depressing, or just plain dirty Chinese restaurants that are all over the city. The other option would be the one in the East Bay on the water. That place is kinda "Chinese-y" too, though. Yank Sing is definitely modern and American.

Downside is the acoustics. The atrium goes about 5+ stories up so the sound is horrible. Guests in the rear can barely hear anything. The sound reaches about 1/4 of the way then starts bouncing around. This place is also super expensive and they will nickel and dime you for little changes you want. My friend wanted red napkins, but they would've charged her $1.50 per! C'mon, she's dropping over $40K on one night and they couldn't waive that fee?! They also wouldn't let her bring in vodka whereas she could bring in cognac. I don't get it.

There are definite pros and cons to this place, but if you're looking for a modern decor with traditional Chinese banquet food, this is the best place in the city. Also, the food will definitely not disappoint! Just be prepared to pay for it...
author: Freckles H.

description:
Living in Sacramento has it's advantages. Chinese food and quality dim sum is not one of them. Sure, there are places in Sacramento that offer dim sum. And at least one of them is acceptable.

And while there are numerous places in the Bay Area that offer dim sum, many of them good, I'm still partial to places like Yank Sing that have been there for as long as I can remember.

A recent return visit shows why they are able to persistent over time. And by the odd expansion (at least on weekends?) into the vast atrium area for their Rincon location, it seems that they not only persistent, but are actually growing their clientele base.

It's a rare opportunity for me to enjoy dim sum now so I pick my location with care. Yank Sing didn't disappoint. I won't itemize all of the various items we ordered -- suffice it to say that all the usual suspects were covered.

The quality and freshness of the ingredients -- perfect. Taste - perfect. The size and proportions of the items - perfect. Condiments -- perfect. The service - perfect. The tea - perfect. As a theme, across all vectors of a dining experience (quality, taste, service, cleanliness, ambiance), everything exceeded expectations as usual.

One note: apparently, because so many other people seem to agree, it is very crowded and one may be forced to wait for a table during busy times. It would be advised to get there early - mental note to self for future visits.
author: Gerry K.

description:
Best dim sum I've ever had.

Jokingly, I tell people this is dim sum for rich people.  It's no joke, this is high-class dim sum, double the bill of your go-to dim sum restaurant.  it's about $80 for two.  But i think it's worth it to spend the extra money.  You'll get quality dim sum here with fresh shrimp, real crab, perfectly shaped dumplings minus all the grease.    Every waiting staff has headphones, so their service is fast, polite and efficient.  We actually timed them, and it takes about 2 minutes for you to get your food.

I love this place.  Best siu long bao ever!
author: Uyen C.

description: When I worked as a hotel staffer (a while ago), I used to send anybody who asked me where they could get great Dim Sum to Yang Sing.  We finally tried it for ourselves over the summer and again this past weekend.  Heck, when I was a hotel staffer there was no way I could have afforded to eat at Yank Sing.  It is in a word "Pricey".  Don't let the little stamps the servers leave on your ticket fool, you.  You will drop over $100-150 here for lunch without even thinking about it.  But, that is money well spent.  The Shanghai "soup" dumplings are some of the best things I have ever tried in my life.  Every other item on the Dim Sum menu is also very good.  Yang Sing has spoiled us forever in that we can never go for cheap low end Dim Sum again without remembering how great their food is.
author: Erin M.

description: The dim sum is excellent. But price is very expensive. It's good for a business lunch.
author: Kevin C.

description: This place is great!  I went with a group of 6 and everyone enjoyed it.  They serve a wide variety of dumplings (vegetarian options for the vegetarian in our group), temperature is perfect, and the service is great.  Plus, it's in a nice setting - definitely groumet dim sum.  The soup dumplings, shredded cabbage, shrimp rice noodles, and ha gow were my favorites.  Also, tea is always constantly refilled due to their great teapots (my pet peeve at dim sum places is when you sit without tea for long periods of time). I was visiting SF and very pleased!
author: Jillian K.

description:
I've been here twice during the holidays and it was great.  I couldn't believe how busy it was and was happy we had reservations.

One of my friends is vegetarian and he had a ton of options, which is usually not the case with dim sum.  We all love the shitake mushroom dumplings.  Everything is so fresh and delicious.  They will bring you whatever you want if you don't see it on a cart.

I stay away from the purple cabbage salad.   They don't do refills in case you love diet coke.
author: Ayelet B.

description:
Man, this place is crazy busy. Although we did make a reservation, and they told us the wait was 15 minutes, we had to wait about half an hour anyway. Do you know why? It's because we were the only Asian family waiting to eat at this restaurant that caters to rich white people/business people. There was a steady stream of customers leaving and at least three large tables opened up, but we had to wait until the table closest to window opened up so that we could take the place of the token Asian family who had been shooed out a minute earlier. Geez, could they have been any more obvious about making us sit in front so it looked like their overpriced dim sum is endorsed by authentic Chinese people? We even noticed that they gave us food on standard blue-and-white round plates instead of the fancy schmancy white rectangular platters that white people got. Racist much? Other than that, service was very speedy and efficient.

$5.50 for a piece of Peking duck?! Yes, everything was way too expensive, and most of the food was only standard. The only real standouts were the green onion "pancakes" which are actually flaky, cylindrical-looking pastries with a nice peanut sauce. Then there was the excellent mango pudding which was light, creamy, addictive, and not gelatinous like the standard from-a-box variety. Soup dumplings were good, but Kingdom of Dumpling does them better.
author: Skye L.

description:
This place is just great. The food, the location, the ambiance....and the waitresses are just fun to communicate with ;-)... we had an excellent time.

Parking is under the garage and is validated..so thats another plus cuz after lunch just have a stroll on embarcadero.

Most of the dishes we tried were delicious..so bring your appetite and larger the group, better it is.
author: Mayank R.

description:
Service was better than expected.  Unlike other Chinese Dim Sum places, all employees did speak proper English.

Food Quality was really decent.  Nothing salty or sweet.  Only thing shocked me was the price.

I should have watched how many dishes I am taking...

My bill came out over $100 for 2 adults and 2 kids.

Well, I will come back next time and eat carefully and slowly. Haha.
author: James A.

description:
Decided to try this "Yank Sing", since everyone always says it's the best Dim Sum in the City. My younger daughter hadn't tried Dim Sum and her BF was finishing a job interview down by the ferry building, while we shopped so it all seem to fit. I always eat Dim Sum in Chinatown, but I'm always down to try something new.....

We made reservations, which seemed like a good idea. Even though it's a big restaurant, many business types are lunching there and it was fairly full on a Friday afternoon.

We were seated right away and offered drinks, which we ordered a pot of green tea. Then the trolleys start coming and coming and coming.....Whoa Nellie! 
My daughter was totally overwhelmed, and after she had about 6 plates already on the table, I told her maybe that was enough to start.
( I mean her BF hadn't even showed up yet) 
I see you'd never starve at YS but it's almost too much, they are at your table every couple of minutes offering dishes. After we had consumed the food on the plates (BF showed up in the middle of the Dim Sum eating frenzy) we carefully picked a couple more of the favorites. And I ordered one dish of duck in a bun (very delish). 
All our Dim Sum was very good, even the shrimp toast that someone had complained about on another post.
And to top off our meal, a mango pudding with a little condensed sweetened milk....mmmmmmmmm
So my final view of the meal: Great service, Great Food, Classy high end ambiance, but double what I'd pay if eating in Chinatown. 
Glad I got to experience it, but I'm happy spending less and getting the same elsewhere...just my preference. But totally enjoyable lunch experience.
author: Susan D.

description: Ok, here is the skinny.  Expensive but good offerings, nothing that blew me away.  Packed to the gills inside with people waiting patiently outside.  I miss Harbor Village in the nearby Embarcadero so this will have to do for dim sum in this area.  Good variety with the potstickers and the cha siu sow as the winners.  Refreshing shredded cabbage salad was $10!  We got Peking Duck, make it yourself baos that were kind of disappointing.  I'd say 3 on the food and 4 on the service, that was attentive and polite.  I'd go 3.5 overall.
author: Dimitri S.

description:
3.5 stars

I think my ancestors were rolling in their graves as I signed the $56 bill for dim sum for two. 

Was it worth it?

Depends on the items ordered. 

I found the Shanghai soup dumplings to be utterly delectable, and this is from a Shanghai soup dumpling expert. I spent a significant portion of my life consuming soup dumplings, I can assure you. These were so excellent -- so much soup, and wonderfully tender meat filling inside. I only wish they served black vinegar instead of that red stuff. 

The Peking duck was very disappointing, unfortunately. I was excited to have the opportunity to order an individual portion of Peking duck, as I rarely have reason to order an entire duck. But god....the duck was awful! The meat was gray, and there was none of the crispy skin that is really the absolute essence of Peking duck. I did, however, appreciate the very fluffy steamed buns. 

The steamed pork buns were good, but oversized. I'd rather have four smaller ones than two enormous ones; it really changes the bun/meat ratio. I was not a big fan of the baked pork buns, and I remain convinced that the bun is whole wheat. It just tasted of like that! 

I also impulsively ordered shrimp toast, an item that I recall eating at family gatherings as a child. Given that it was $7.60, I did sort of regret it. The toast was pleasantly crunchy and greasy, but the huge balled up shrimp was a bit overwhelming after awhile. 

The next time I'm here (and I will be, for the soup dumplings if nothing else), I want to try the snow pea shoot dumplings, the curry chicken turnovers, and fish (forget what kind it is, but looked beautiful). I really do like the variety of dim sum offered at Yank Sing. 

Ultimately, I truly could not get over the prices. I suppose it is unfair to think it's ridiculous to pay so much for dim sum...not all ethnic food should automatically be considered as cheap food and I think higher prices for high quality food could really do a lot to improve the reputation of Chinese food. Another rant for another time...but I suppose what ultimately got me was that at the end of the day, you can get something just as good for quite a lot less. At $25-30/person for what is usually brunch, it needs to be perfection.
author: Ada T.

description:
I've frequented this restaurant for many years as I love to eat dim sum.  My thoughts on it are that the dim sum is in my opinion one of the best in San Francisco BUT the most expensive.  Its rival is Koi Palace, though in Daly City, is better BUT the wait is just ridiculous over there.  

There have been a couple instances where I have been less than impressed but a majority of the time it is consistent and good.  The restaurant is also very clean, comfortable and nice.  My co-worker and her husband are VIPs at the restaurant so we always get a table immediately and a free platter of dessert so I love going with them!
author: Jessica T.

description:
This dim sum joint is definitely a bit more pricey than most other places but the quality of food clearly justifies the price difference. 

The food here is exquisite and you will rarely find a day where this place isn't packed to the gills with hungry patrons. Reservations are clearly warranted and recommended. 

An absolute staple every time I'm in the Bay Area.
author: Ehsan K.

description: The best dim sum in the world, literally even the shanghai dumpling is so much better than the original in Shanghai. Sea bass, walnut salad, pistachio ice cream, are must try.  Not big fans of the price though, totally overpriced.  Service is very attentive for Chinese restaurant, their service is the best.
author: Jen Z.

description:
Dim Sum: I absolutely LOVE the shanghai dumplings here, they are little dumplings filled with soup. I've never found these dumplings at other places as good at this, even at authentic Shanghai Dumpling places. Everything else is pretty good too.

I like that this place is clean and classy, although quite busy and hustle bustle. 

Dinner: I've attended a few weddings here and the rain in the middle of the restaurant is very pretty, not to mention sends a nice refreshing cool air throughout the room. The food isn't memorable but nothing to complain about.
author: Van C.

description: Wow, they were pushy. I know it is dim sum and the only way they make money is to push more food onto you. Nonetheless they don't need to give you those looks when you turn down a plate. The food itself was fantastic. I can not complain at all about the choices especially since I was not paying but the service is questionable at best.
author: Andrew M.

description: Yes. It is expensive. Yes. It is bustling. Yes. You can't turn around in San Francisco without running into a dim sum restaurant. All this is true, but it is delicious dim sum with great service, at least in our experience. I am a sucker for the soup dumplings. I love them and have never had an "issue" with them. I give Yank Sing four stars based on the price, $155 for three, for brunch, not including tip. Yes, I know you just dropped your chopsticks, but, we only go for special occasions such as every time we visit San Francisco. We definitely recommend it.
author: H. M.

description:
Yank Sing's Dim Sum never fails to fill my TUMMY!  Whenever I go here I know that I will be oooh so satisfied.  The Rincon locations can get pretty crowded so I always go early and stay for a very long time (you can easily kill 2 hours).  The best table in the house is right close to the kitchen (my preference) so when all the Dim Sum ladies come rolling out their hot carts, you have first dibbs of all the hot dishes.  The place can get loud, but hey, good food... people.... loud... is what the Dim Sum experience is all about.  The dishes are hot and plenty and if there is something that you don't see, you can special order other dishes.  The service is always good.  It can be a little pricey, but I don't mind paying more if I know that the food is going to be delish.

The restaurant is also open on Sunday's for brunch.  They open up the courtyard for extra seating.  It can get pretty crowded with people waiting to be seated so best to make reservations ahead of time.

If you've never had Dim Sum and want to try for the first time, have your first experience at Yank Sing... you can't go wrong.  If you do and find out it's not for your taste buds, at least you've experience it.

Highly recommend!

Enjoy!
author: Miriam O.

description: I had to hurry and write a good review after the bad ones I just wrote. Food is just wonderful!  Fresh! Just great! ALL NEWBIES TO DIM SUM PLEASE BE ADVISED. This stuff is expensive as hell, and they know you are new. They bring innocent looking small plates of a couple things, and then... BAM! They drop it like it's hot and mark the pad! We spent over $100 on lunch. We were not upset. It was delicious. But we felt like we would be more prepared the next time we go, and we will go again. But we will be more careful. I will order the Shanghai dumplings for sure. I can not recommend them enough. We will go back!
author: Nancy P.

description: We stop in SF sometimes JUST to get dim sum from Yank Sing.  I'm trying to think of something that I haven't loved but can't think of anything.  Order the house special delicate little soup-filled wontons with shredded vinegar cabbage.  You will dream of these...trust me!!  You won't be disappointed.  Get there early.
author: Katie C.

description:
ok if you have $$$ to throw away or you if you don't mind spending $80 on 2 people for dim sum.. THEN THIS IS THE PLACE to be! 
But honestly? you can take a drive to China Town and find even BETTER DIM SUM place  for a REASONABLE PRICE. 
 My thoughts: Not the best dim sum in town, prices are Jacked up and its in a "hoitteee toitee" environment (buisness upper class yuppies) again WAY TOO MUCH TO SPEND ON DIM SUM-and FOR WHAT... TO only be hungry again in an hour...  YAN CAN COOK BETTER BE MAKIN THIS DIM SUM IN FRONT OF ME BENNY HANNA STYLE if I ever wanted to pay this much again... 
if you ask me.... pass and find something better with Entertainment for the price of this place!
author: Analynn L.

description:
All the people complaining about prices are just clueless and tacky.  Of COURSE you can get good, cheap dim sum somewhere else.  But if you want a nice, clean, sit-down, special occasion place...you can't beat Yank Sing.  

This is not your spur-of-the-moment, let's-go-grab-cheap-dim-sum place, and to compare it with those is simply unfair to what Yank Sing DOES offer.  It's like saying dim sum isn't good enough for a special occasion.  Get over your oh-so-familiar-with-authentic-dim-sum-selves.  It doesn't have to be just what you're used to, why not try broadening your minds?

You're paying for more than the food.  Get over it or don't go.
author: T H.

description:
My friend who used to live in SF recommened this place...and yup she did a good thing.  I can now say Yank Sing is the best dim sum place I have ever eaten at.  I agree with the others being it was pricey, but to me worth it.  They offerered different types of dim sum not avail in many places especially So. Cal - such as the pork ginger broth dumpling...( I hope that's what you call it) ...so tasty.  
Between me and my husband, we ate $85 worth of mini plates. Yea, a bit of an ouch- but again... "oh soo good!"

Service was great too!  Very polite staff.  So if you're looking for some good dim sum and don't mind shelling out some money...I totally recommend trying Yank Sing.
author: Marian D.

description:
Once in a while, instead of a typical brunch, I have a desire for Dim Sum. And Yank Sing is undoubtedly one of the better places for it in the City. For sure, it is fairly Westernized, catering in large part to tourists and the well-heeled, and *not cheap* but it's an enjoyable weekend destination, particularly on wet weekend Sundays (like today!)

I hadnt been here in a while -- and in my excitement, I had almost completely forgotten the basic rule -- PACE YOURSELF. Every time, in Yank Sing, after getting there and getting seated, you are immediately assaulted by a dozen Dim Sum options in very quick succession. If you waver, they'll deliver the dish to your table anyway. Soon, before I realized it, I had ordered Pot Stickers, Port Dumplings, some kind of Shrimp delight as well as Chinese Broccoli and some tea to wash it all down. (I followed it up with a Tsing Tao beer to steady my nerves...) A quick injection of excellent food... After that, I regained composure, and started to take stock of what else was on offer. The Pork Siu Mye was a must, as was the Shrimp Dumplings -- and of course, some Egg Custard Tarts to finish. Outstanding!

However, there is a price to pay. It's very difficult to keep track of the dishes, and at up to $9.00 a pop, the cost of the meal mounts very quickly. So, definitely a fun, satisfying, once-in-a-while treat, but certainly not an everyday destination.
author: donal c.

description: Ok the quality of the food deserves 4 stars but the lack of Dim sum options dropped my rating to a 3.5. They had the basic dim sum choices, but none of the good stuff at most authentic Chinese places. What I'm saying is this place is obviously catered to the white folks. But it is good quality food. Also OVERPRICED! I could get double the amount of good dim sum for the price we paid.
author: Karen T.

description: Best Dim Sum in the Bay Area. Expensive, but you get what you pay for.
author: Steve L.

description:
I love this place for Dim Sum! 

The food is so good, and they have a great selection. Sometimes you have to wait a few minutes for the right cart to get what you want to eat, but it never takes too long. 

Another plus, they have a vegetarian selection... which is rare for Dim Sum places. 

The only reason they don't get 5 stars from me is that they are expensive! This is the type of place that I bring my white tourist visitors who are too scared to try a less attractive place in Chinatown. It's safe, and clean, and less of a risk for the tourist wanting to try some Dim Sum. Delicious food + nice place = Expensive. 

Ah yes, and if you go at the wrong time you will likely have a wait (though it's never that long because the seating space is huge).
author: Sandy M.

description:
Happy to find xiao long bao (soup dumplings) here, but compared to my hometown's Din Tai Fung (http://www.yelp.com/biz/din-tai-fung-bellevue) they were poorly made and fell apart before they hit my mouth about 1/4 of the time. The rest of the dim sum options were good, nothing too special. The staff bypassed our peripheral table too often and it often left me changing my mind at the very last second about something that caught my eye, but not interested in enough to call them back.

Then I got the bill, most expensive dim sum I've ever had in my entire life. Would not return despite the good food, because it's just a terrible value.
author: Varn S.

description: This would be a 4 or 5 star review - and the dim sum remains fabulous - but they CHANGED THE SINGAPORE NOODLES and I am not going to buy them anymore.  Undercooked rice vermicelli is not good.
author: J K.

description: Ok, it's ridiculously delicious; 5 stars of YUM but over $70 for 2 people makes it a super-special treat unless you are part of the Nuevo SF 1%ers.  The dumplings are truly extraordinary; thin-skinned and plumply filled with delight.   Chao Su Boa is scrumtiously tangriffic.   It's totally delicious but questionably worth the wait or price.  I grew up going to the hole-in-the-wall Yank Sing when it was in Chinatown in the 80's and the new, sleek Yank Sing is like the scruffy kid from college who became Obama; not surprising, but now somewhat inaccessible to the kids who knew him when....   If you are going to splurge, stick with the dim sum.  No reason to buy overpriced chinese food dishes, when there are amazing cheap places on Clement.
author: T L.

description:
I ate dim sum at Yank Sing twice in one week. It was the best week ever (ok, perhaps the best week this summer). I can't believe how many dumplings I devoured--definitely more than I can count on my fingers and toes.

The xiao long bao (soup dumpling) was phenomenal: Thin doughy skin, savory juicy filling... Completely worth the first-degree burn it gave my tongue. The measure of a dim sum restaurant--ha gau, pork siu mye, and char siu bao--were all fresh and all fantastic. I am still kicking myself for not making it a point to have the lobster dumpling and peking duck. 

This just means I need to return. Who has a company card and wants a hot (albeit hungry) date? I'm yours for dim sum... and only dim sum.
author: Liz T.

description:
Oh my god, my friend and I got a pick up order of their dim sum platter and the only thing that was good was the pork bun and the potstickers, the egg roll was greasy, the sui mai was tepid and tasted microwaved. I think it's better if you go to clement and get fresh hot dim sum from their piping hot steamers. 
This was overpriced and not tasty.
author: Charlene C.

description:
Ode to Yank Sing (with no regard to meter or rhyme):

Oh, you granddaddy of dim sums,
How to sum up the dining experience that is you?

As classy as the Four Seasons, sans the pretension
you sure don't come cheap, but are so worth the price.

Heaven is...your deep blue carpet, half-orb chandeliers,
a thousand carts expertly milling about.

Soup dumplings? Shrimp Shu Mai?  Chinese Broccoli?
Don't mind if I do. 

You even smile when I say "No, thank you."

You live on the West Coast, to my dismay,
but I will be back, faster than you can say Xiao Long Bao.
author: Hayley Sara B.

description: I have been to this place a few times and generally I thought the food was decent but way overpriced.  I've not reviewed before because I was generally just underwhelmed.  The last time I attempted to eat there, the restaurant was half empty and my husband, myself and my son (1 year) were made to wait for a table.  As we were standing there, 3 other parties of 3 came in after us and were seated before us.  I'm not sure whether it was because we had a baby with us or whether they were targeting us some other way but we just walked out and will never return again.
author: Julie J.

description: Loved the dumplings filled with soup, shrimp, the chinese hot mustard and in general the quick service and good prices.
author: Guillermo M.

description:
This was my first dim sum experience ever.  I'm new to SF, but the bf has lived here for 15 yrs.  So he recommended this place for my first dim sum, as a San Francisco classic.  He did mention that there's some debate as to whether this is the bar-none best dim sum in the city & that it is more pricey than many other places.  But it is legendary (as the Facebook comments from several friends who've lived & studied in the Bay area attest), & as such, I'm happy the bf was nice enough to take me here.

Having spent most of my adulthood in the southeast, I'm a huge fan of brunch.  Honestly, Chinese-type food for brunch doesn't appeal to me as much as, say, shrimp 'n grits, eggs benedict, or a luscious French toast.  It's just a mood/craving thing.  But I was happily able to find several things that quite satisfied the peculiar savory/sweet/salty ideal that haunts my thoughts on a late weekend morning.

My favorite items were the char shu bao (steamed bbq-pork rolls) & the small custard tarts for dessert.  The jasmine tea was also nice, but I had to stop for coffee on the way home; need a lil caffeine in my day!
author: Rebecca M.

description:
Better make reservations, this place will spew tables outside its own restaurant just to seat you, unfortunately there is not enough space outside either to meet the demands of the people. Note to reader, Make reservations. (also note, even if you have reservations, does not mean you will not wait.) 

Food: Off the hook. My family will wait up to an hour and a half just for the dim sum. Many varieties, made very well. 

Service: Almost impossible to get what you want, but you just gotta keep trying. the place is so busy so its understandable. 

Atmosphere: to tell you the truth....i dont think i have ever sat inside of the actual restaurant. so i cant really say. sorry. 

Sanitation: Good enough. 

Location: Inside a building with a parking structure, its really hard to get to, but many people try, therefore you should as well. 

Overall: Besides the mission to get there, and the wait, This place is great for dim sum.
author: Nye T.

description: They bombard you with carts full of items the moment your butt hit the seat!  Sit down try to order a drink and women with carts try to shove food on your table, it's hard to think, I was screaming no no give us a moment to think!  They do not stop! Now the dim sum, just ok not hot enough, just warm, just ok, very EXPENSIVE  not a nice relaxing time or time to enjoy what you have because these people do not stop shoving food at you.  Will never go back nor recommend to others.
author: tami g.

description:
Given that a majority of my job involves taking clients out to lunch, I typically select places where I can look good doing it.

Meaning, places where I am familiar with the food and can show off my exemplary good table manners.

Enter Yank Sing.  Important client doesn't feel like Boulevard so instead we head to Yank Sing.

Having never been here, nor experienced Dim Sum- I was literally thrown back in my chair by the onslaught of carts and little ladies flinging crazy plastic-looking creations in my face.

Quickly realizing I'd have to throw my Westernized etiquette out the window here, I disclaimed myself to client as a "first- timer",  put her in charge of ordering, and 10 minutes later was up to my elbows in juices from exploding soup dumplings, cabbage salad, some crab thing, stuffed mushrooms... and realized WOW had I been  missing out on this experience.

Now I just have to justify the expense to payroll :-/
author: Gabrielle J.

description:
I really like this place, I can't say its the best Dim Sum, but its good and very convenient. Its not too far from me and I like the fountain in the middle. It makes me feel like I'm not in the middle of a busy workday but somewhere far away..  It has good DimSum, though sometimes I wish I didn't have someone shoving food in my face every thirty seconds as I eat and try to chat. They could stand to have some sort of rotation that gives people about 5 minutes between each cart.  But I do really like their BBQ pork bun and xiu mai (Did I butcher that spelling). They have really good sea bass and some shrimp dumpling you put in red vinegar and slurp in a soup spoon. I think I enjoy the novelty of that more than anything. 

Dim Sum is never super cheap to go to, so don't expect a $10 lunch. It's the same price as most Dim Sum places in the bay. If you're strapped for cash and can't resist, go next door to their express café, you can get a meal for under $10 which has a nice sampling of what they offer.
author: Analisa S.

description: Ate here as part of a birthday party and was very unimpressed. The food is SO expensive relative to other dim sum places! Paying $7 for an order of dim sum is ridiculous, in my opinion. And the food wasn't particularly spectacular. The Xiao Long Baos were very tasty, and there was a chicken/mushroom dumpling that was very delish. But other than that, it was standard dim sum quality. The service, however, was atrocious. We had 2 tables in our group, and we each ordered a rice and a noodle dish. One table received both orders after about 30 minutes, and had time to eat it all, while the other table's order hadn't arrived yet! After waiting another 15 minutes, I had to go complain to the hostess before the food was brought out. During this time, barely any food was brought out in the carts. We had also ordered a beef rice noodle roll early in the process, along with two shrimp rolls. The waiter brought our shrimp rolls and said the beef rolls were still cooking, so we would have to wait a couple minutes. We all forgot about it until we were starting on dessert, and the waiter comes and asks if we still wanted to get the beef rolls. So the 'couple minutes' meant 45 minutes! Of course we didn't want the damn things anymore, we all just wanted to leave. So overpriced, mediocre food and terrible customer service. Definitely not worth trying!
author: Tina L.

description: Shanghai dumplings delicious!  Everything was good, even the jasmine tea. I've never seen so many waitstaff at a restaurant.
author: Kathryn K.

description: Good luck getting food if you are vegetarian. We were ignored by the staff and they didn't let us place special orders for vegetarian items. We barely ate anything except for cold snap peas and broccoli (the broccoli was gross btw). Never coming here again.
author: Rekha S.

description: The first time I went to Yank Sing was delicious and it hasn't let up since! Albeit it is more pricey than some dim sum, the price you pay is not only for delicious and fresh ingredients but also the amazing restaurant atmosphere. This is the cleanest, most well organized dim sum restaurant I have ever been to and I've eaten a lot of dim sum. My favorite delectable dishes are the snow pea tip dumplings, shrimp and chive dumplings, sea bass entree, chicken stuffed mushrooms, mango pudding, sesame balls, and baked pork buns. The food dishes would never be complete without their signature spicy black bean sauce. It adds the perfect amount of flavor and spice to the dim sum without over powering it. Overall, no matter if you go once or twenty times your experience here will be a memorable one for you and your taste buds. I love this place!!
author: Jaime R.

description:
Over priced fancy smacy dim sum, but at a very clean and nice restaurant.  I must say the sui lung bao are very good.  ( Juicy )  The soup stays inside!  Today we experience something new...they serve Gai Lan COLD!!!!  Not very good if you ask me.  Nothing special...ha gow, sew mai, pai gwut...taste ok..not bad but just ok. There is a selection of teas...so thats cool.  Im a huge fan of tea variety.

A piece of peking duck for one is $5.75!  THATS BANK!

There was 5 of us for lunch and the bill came out to be about $150.00.

My favorite dim sum place is still Koi Palace in Daly City.  YUMMY!
author: Sandy L.

description:
Ambiance - I've never been to a dim sum place that sat you in the atrium with soothing waterfalls, natural light, and high ceilings.  Sigh.

Service - Everyone, including the cart ladies spoke English pretty well. 

Food - Some hits and some misses.  However, expect to pay a premium.  Our bill for four came out to about $43/pp.  Expect a short wait around 1130 to noon.  Do ask for chrysanthemum tea and do have some chili black bean sauce.  I loved that all the dishes came out in real bamboo steamers instead of the commercialized metal ones.

1.  Shanghai Dumplings - A pleasant surprise.  I've never had SD at a dim sum place until I came here!  Really good, hot and flavorful!
2.  Shrimp Tubes - Awful!  The rice noodles were dry. 
3.  Shu Mai - Some fillers.
4. Ha Gao - Good
5.  Peking duck and Xiao Long Bao - Another favorite!  Crispy skin, hearty cut of duck, soft bao and a hoisin sauce that wasn't too sweet. 
6.  Sweet Tofu - Not enough ginger and flavor.
7.  Chicken Feet - Well carmelized.
8.  Spareribs - Not enough color and too much flour.

We had several other dim sum plates but nothing that stood out.
author: San N.

description:
One of my favourite dimsum places in the Bay Area! Growing up in HK, I've been hard-pressed to find a place that makes dimsum just right - just the right texture and flavours! 

Lots of great dimsum favourites like hagao (shrimp dumplings), chasiubao (BBQ pork buns), and siumai. Everything I've tried there is delicious. Go for the seabass if you want something new at dimsum.

Unlike most good Chinese restaurants, the place itself is quite nice. Only down side is that it's a bit pricey for dimsum. Great treat once in a while! Try to make reservations if you can to shorten your wait!
author: Natasha C.

description: I love this place.  Sure it's expensive but it's worth it.
author: Victoria P.

description:
I've eaten here many times over the years.  Many of those visits were expense account lunches.  But a good number were family visits that I paid for.  For the three of us it would come in at $70-90 before tip.  For the first time in about two years I visited with my family and was surprised to see the check come in at $120 (btw, no alcohol).  I was looking over the check when a hostess came over and just outright asked me if I would like her to help me "figure out the charges on my bill" - like it was a routine task that customers were surprised by the bill and needed a translation from their obscure system of markings and line items on the check.  The hostess ignored me when I told her that "No, I'm fine, I'm sure the check must be correct" and just launched into a rather loud and I must say embarrassing accounting of each dish with the charges on the check.  It was as if I'd challenged their integrity and they were going to publicly prove me wrong. 

My opinion is that they have managed to price themselves to perfection.  The businessman who needs to keep an eye on his expense account budget is going to think twice.  At $12.50 the small plate of walnut shrimp either needs to be impressive and if not, the customer must not know any better.

I'm not in the Dim Sum business so maybe this pricing strategy is working for the owners.  But for me it doesn't and I will only be visiting again when it is being paid for by someone other than me or my employer.

Btw, the food was above average , but not the best i've had by far.  Service was good except for incident at end of meal with hostess and the bill.
author: tony f.

description:
I have heard about this place so many times and quite excited that we have enough people so more varieties can be tried...well, well, my expectation was disappointed a big one.

It is expensive - we spent more than $30 per person with the quality we can get here in south bay without spending so much.

The best one is XLB - we turned it down when was recommended since we don't believe Cantonese can prepare Shanghai style dish - we were wrong, it tiurned out the best one among all the dishes we ordered - almost 5 star, very expensive also - $12.20 for 6 of them.

All the others - chueng fen, chicken feet, turnip cake, spring roll, steamed dishes all are only average.
author: Chi Y.

description:
The place is nice...not too big, but they set up outdoor seating in the center of the Rincon Center which is nice (as long as it's not freezing outdoors). 

We sat indoors on a sunday around 11a and the place was packed. It was very loud as well.

Pros:
*Lots of different dishes. They even have mandarin duck circulating on a cart. 
* Different sauces on the table. Hot pepper sauce, mustard and soy sauce :9
* Defn try their red cabbage salad. VERY very good. I never had that before.

Cons:
*Although they have a plethora of dishes, some of them were cold or luke warm....its takes away from the yummy dish :(
* It was a little overwhelming bc waiters were coming at you from every direction. We would be looking at one cart on my right and another 2 waiters would come to my left and shove dishes in my face....back off!!!!
*It's in the embarcadero area, so street parking can be VERY limited. 

Overall, the food was good. But it's not the best dim sum I've had. I think the experience is nicer becuase of the location and the crowd it draws. But I've had better for cheaper.
author: Radha X.

description:
Darling Yank Sing, we've had some good times together.  However you are now geographically undesirable for me and parking is atrocious so you have been downgraded to occasional hookups when I feel a need for something that others can offer me but I have a special fondness for you.

It would be nice if I didn't run into everyone and their mother when I visit you though.
author: Poppy C.

description: OVERPRICED!! I'm a foodie and am willing to pay for great food. This place is overrated and EXTREMELY OVERPRICED! A table of 2 for 6 average tasting dim sum small plates with just tea cost us... Get ready... Are you sitting down? ... Over $60! Eating here is the only vacation regret and I even got a sprained ankle from snowboarding!
author: Phoebe C.

description:
If you like shrimp, shrimp and more shrimp... then you'll love this place!
My sister-in-law and I ate here from a suggestion given to us by a friend.  We had a few things that were great:
     *BBQ pork bun
     *Shrimp dumpling
     *Fried shrimp
We ordered some chicken mushroom won tons...  They tasted more like curry than anything else.  We ended up sending them back and the restaurant comped the item.  
We had the crab claw, which was covered in shrimp batter, hardly any crab!  We had another dumpling that tasted just like the shrimp batter.  A little overkill with the shrimp!
The hot tea was good and the service was alright.
It took 10-15 minutes for us and our neighboring table to get and pay-for the check.
I don't have a lot to compare to, but I thought Yank Sing was alright.  I'll probably visit again.
My overall favorite??  The BBQ pork bun, which we bought at the to-go counter while waiting for our table!!!
author: Dana B.

description: Wow, what is so special about yank sing.  The food was okay, not bad. $40 bucks for dim sum per person, that is ridiculous and we did not order anything fancy. I HATE THE WAITRESSES HERE, SO RUDE and always try to put the dishes into our faces to make a sale.  We came here only  for the convenience for business meeting since it is right in financial district , nah never again.
author: T B.

description: Tourist trap, way over priced, and not nearly the best dim sum you can find in the city.   Go somewhere else and save your hundreds of dollars!
author: Manoj L.

description: Make a reservation, this place fills up fast. Excellent food - the soup wonton and pork dumplings are just a few of my favorites. Tea is amazing and desserts are so delicious.
author: Genevieve W.

description:
This place is pricey for Dim Sum, and not just a little. I could probably get as good or better for less money down around Clement Street.

Attentive staff, but to the point of being pushy. I often make the mistake of ordering (or being coerced into ordering) several items to the point of being full, then see something that I really wanted. Damn. 

I was reminded how much I like Jasmine Tea. I was not a fan of the Mango Pudding. Probably won't be back due to price.
author: Ken L.

description: I haven' t had dim sum in ages, so when my friend suggested we meet here for brunch, I readily agreed. We were pretty early, so the place was nice and uncrowded. The outdoor space looked like a nice area to sit, but we were there before they were seating that area. I can't say I had anything that was super outstanding, but I do love dumplings and well, you're gonna get dumplings, by the cart. If I go back, I'd like to venture beyond the dumpling space. Super filling, not totally cheap, but a fun experience nonetheless.
author: Renee E.

description: Love Yank Sing.  This one is better than the one on Stevenson.  The Shanghai dumplings are amazing and not available at a lot of other dim sum places.  I have enjoyed all my meals here immensely.  One caveat: overpriced.  Be careful when you order.  There's a sea bass they bring around that's great but it's 20$ all by itself and we didn't realize which item was so expensive it until we saw the menu on a different visit a month later because the bill's written in Chinese.  The peking duck is also really good but 5$ per person. They have priced menus available so just make sure to get one and know what's what.
author: Vanessa S.

description:
Yank Sing catered one of our holiday parties a few years ago and everyone loved it. Hadn't had an opportunity to go sit down for the full experience and it was EPIC!!!!

The food trolleys come by so quick we didn't at first realize we could pick and choose - we just kept saying yes, yes, yes. Everything was hot, flavorful and served by wonderful attentive staff. It was one of our best meals out in a long time!

Love the Jasmine tea and my parents bought a ton of it to take home.
author: Mariangela S.

description:
I'm shocked by all the high reviews for this place. Yank Sing is highly overated, their dim is average, but you pay three times the price. 

My bf and I usually spend about 30-40 bucks on average whenever we grub on dim sum. We came to yank sing and ended up spending at least 70, between the two of us, for DIM SUM!!!! Dim sum should never cost this high.

People, save your money and go to the Richmond district for good dim sum at MUCH cheaper prices.
author: Pauline T.

description: Always a favorite for dim sum whenever we're in the neighborhood. One of the best we've had, and we've had dim sum the world over, and this ranks up with some of the faves in Hong Kong.  It's refreshing to see this commitment to the product in the SF area.
author: Matthew S.

description:
So far my favorite place for dim sum (even if it is more expensive)!!!!

I've been a few times before and recently took my gf here for a belated bday lunch.  She absolutely enjoyed herself and of course it was yet another enjoyable experience for me.  

The folks at Yank Sing do dim sum right!  The attention to detail on all aspects of their business is top notch.  They queue up a wait list and effectively manage seating/turning over tables, they have a good sized space in the restaurant (for patrons, carts, wait staff, etc.) as well as the overflow area out by the Rincon Center's waterfall.  There is a plethora of GREAT FOOD available at all times and if there is something you have not seen, you can stop anyone and ask...they'll order it right up for you.  Lastly, I appreciate the service.  They cater to Chinese and non-Chinese alike.  Tea is served (in cool glass teapots) and refilled regularly (since it's easier to eyeball when a  clear teapot needs refilling) , water is promptly delivered when asked and the employees are very very polite (thank you's & your welcome's go a long way).
author: Aurelie N.

description: SOUP DUMPLINGS .. Always crazy busy. Worth the wait!
author: Candi M.

description:
I gave it 5 stars because:

1. the food is excellent - you know when you see a lot of Chinese people at the restaurant, its Chinese food is pretty good. 
2. fast service - once we were seated, 3 carts rush to our table :)
3. everyone speaks English 
4. very very clean

They don't tell you how much each food plate is until you receive the receipt at the end. It's pricey for dim sum, but I am so happy with this place, I am coming again...very very soon!
author: Frannie C.

description: Good dim sum in a nice restaurant, for a price. Always go here with the parents, or others that need to be eased into the dim sum experience.
author: Michael B.

description:
Wonderful service
Lovely setting
Attentive ladies with dim sum carts
Good food

But why the 2 stars?  MSG.  Loads of it.  I'm dehydrated, I'm sleepy, I'm not happy.
author: Cinnamon Z.

description:
The Cantonese mom's rule-of-thumb is: If there are more white people eating at a Chinese restaurant than Chinese people, you better run the other way.

I should have run away from Yank Sing, screaming bloody murder. But, of course, I never listen to my mom.

- The service was excruciatingly slow. They rarely filled our tea pot.
- The food was appallingly mediocre, AND they had NO variety. It was clearly gringo-fied dim sum because they only served the deep-fried stuff that normal Cantonese people don't eat, i.e. potstickers or jin dui (fried glutinous rice balls) or ja liang (fried Chinese "doughnut") or fried egg rolls. Each tray that passed by my mom got a slow shake of disapproval and contempt.
- It was embarrassing bringing my Hong Kong-native parents here. They just sat politely and quietly the whole time - HUNGRY - because they knew I felt bad for bringing them here on behalf of the 1000+ positive Yelp reviews. 
- The tea wasn't even that great. We ordered jasmine tea, and the tea didn't smell floral or taste crisp and sweet. It was generic tea. Come on!!! Dim sum is about "yum cha"; it's about taking your time, philosophizing about life, over a pot of excellent tea. And Yank Sing couldn't even guarantee that? 

Now, here's the worst part. After paying the enormously expensive bill ($50 for 5 dim sum dishes.. uh. yeah), my mom leaned over to a server and wondered aloud in Cantonese, "Everything is expensive beyond belief. And there's nothing to eat. What's going on?"

The server looked around sheepishly, and then replied back in hushed Cantonese: "Well, you know. We gotta pay our rent."

AH! Now, it makes sense.
author: Dr. L.

description: Good quality dim sum in a nicer-than-average atmosphere...but over-priced. Four smallish shu mais for over $6? Hard to justify when there are so many other great hole-in-the-walls both in SF and Oakland. A nice experience, and I'd take guests here, but the quality of the food and nicer atmosphere doesn't justify the prices. We saved the $10.50 they charged for four sesame balls and got them from our usual spot 3/$2.
author: Gigi C.

description:
Designer Dim Sum. 

You pay a premium and you may have to wait a bit

BUT

HANDS DOWN this is some of the best Dim Sum in the City 

People like to complain about the price and might front like somewhere else is better  but honestly, if paying a little bit extra ensures that the meat quality is A+ (especially in my Baos) then I will gladly pick this place over anywhere on Clement or in Chinatown. 

YELP HATERS SIT DOWN.

5 Stars. FAST.
author: Cam K.

description:
Fantastic tasting Dim Sum in an amazing variety but way over priced.  I know of Yank SIng's reputation and it's well deserved but I guess I haven't been here for a while.
My wife and I went to lunch and ate maybe 6 or 7 plates (some with only two items) and the total bill came to $65.  Whoa! I wasn't ready for that.  Much as I enjoy the food. Love it... I won't be back.  Not at these prices. For lunch, no less.
author: Kenneth S.

description: Best Dim Sum in the city by far. We always get the Egg Rolls and Pork Shumai. Their Sesame Balls are on the BIG EAT SF 2009. They were unique for sure, but I'm not sure they really qualify as anything special. Be careful how much order as the tab can easily reach several hundred dollars.
author: Hayley H.

description:
A good place for Dim Sum, but this is one pricey place.  I never really realized just how expensive this place is until I actually had to pay for lunch for the first time a few months back.

The first time I came here was for a wedding (farewell brunch).  The dim sum was good as was the service.  I've been to Yank Sing several times since, but they were always for company gatherings as my former boss loved this place.  They were always expensed and I never saw the tab.

A few months ago, my friend and I decided to go for Dim Sum during our lunch hour.  We weren't that hungry so we ordered just a few items, so we thought.  When the bill came, I almost fell off my chair!  I expected it to be pricey, but more in the neighborhood of $50 or so, but  the bill was almost $80.  That was one expensive lunch! 

The dim sum is authentic here and the quality is generally high.  It's also one of few Chinese restaurants that offer good service and a reasonably nice decor. It's probably the closest experience to a nice Dim Sum restaurant in Hong Kong, but be prepared to shell out $40 ot $50 per person for your lunch!
author: Paul K.

description:
Hands down my Numero Uno Favorite Dim Sum spot EVER. 

The fam and I had brunch here last weekend for the first time in years and man it was just as delicious as I remember. Shrimp dumplings, chicken and mushroom dumplings, fried taro dumplings, roast duck....oh my! So yummy, so delicious! I wish I could eat like I used to because I wanted to eat more but my stomach would not allow it.

The dim sum is delicious and it's pricey, but it's so worth it. 

P.S. We made reservations, ended up running late and I called to let them know. Despite our delay, we were seated immediately upon arrival. Very friendly service and staff.
author: Christine R.

description:
Super expensive BUT
1. dumplings are bite-size (only way they should be in my humble opinion)
2. Noodles are thin
3. duck is fatty but you actually get meat too
4. everything is super fresh
5. service is polite and efficient 

I have had pretty much everything on the menu and nothing stands out as disappointing.
author: Megan F.

description: Maybe there are better places, but who cares.  This is great.  You want better Chinese food--go to China.  I have, and yeah, it's good.  But so is Yank.  It's too easy to walk from your hotel or office to Yank, and why not?  Great dim sum.  There aren't a lot of better Dim Sum places in the US, so save your passport and come here.
author: Anon M.

description:
OVERALL: 2.6

FOOD: 3
SERVICE: 3
AMBIANCE: 3.5
VALUE: 1

If you don't know any better, Yank Sing is decent and maybe even good for dim sum.

However, if you know your "Phoenix Talons" (fong zhao) & "Roasted Sales" (siu mai), you'll also know Yank Sing means "Sheep City".  (PS, that's not a joke)  More importantly, you'll also know that it's overpriced and mediocre.

GOOD:
*Nice setting in the glassy Rincon Center atrium near the waterfall, and since the rest of the food court is closed on Sunday, feels more spacious and classy, especially compared to other claustrophobic dim sum houses.
*Large selection of items, frequent and well-stocked carts.
*Attentive service--if nothing else, you definitely won't go thirsty!
*Xiao Long Bao were hot and deliciously brothy!
*Split the bill between 5 credit cards.

BAAAAAAD:
*Most flavors were flat and tepid--yuck, absolutely HATE it when those bamboo steamers are anything but piping hot.
*Texture of some of the steamed dumplings was overcooked and pasty.
*Pricey--Didn't gorge myself as I am typically driven to do at dim sum (good for the waistline, not so good for Sheep City), but the bill was still a  whopping $26/person (tax + tip inc)...!!  For dim sum, I'm more used to half that amount.

Won't be back....unless they bring in actual sheep.
author: Amy K.

description:
Good food but Overpriced.  
As with other dim sum places, you can't order a la carte items and get it before you fill up w dim sum (sometimes you can't help it when some people in your group prefer a la carte and they end up just watching others eat for at least 30 min!).
author: emily e.

description:
This is some of THE best dim sum I've ever had. 

My favorite is the Shanghai dumplings...mmm, juicy and done just right. It is also an excellent stop for lunch but during the week at the noon hour its a real squeeze to get in and out. Try the Yank Sing to Go as an alternative. 

The staff are very pleasant, and make you feel accommodated and are ever present. I would say though, it feels a tad bit like a mill at times, and all things aren't explained for a newbie to dim sum. I think I'd be lost with most things if I was not already familiar with some of the items. The noise level is a bit toward the higher end, but it gives a feel of enjoyment and merriment.
author: Poyna L.

description: If you're looking for a truly authentic dim sum fare, Yank Sing is not the right place for you. I'm all for Yank Sing though because they use better quality ingredients than most "authentic" dim sum restaurants. Yank Sing is the only dim sum I've had that doesn't leave my stomache hurting from too much grease. It's very light and tasty here. It's also highly recommended for those who are pretty new to dim sum. Worth paying extra $ if your stomache can't handle too much grease The uber cheap dim places tend to use mysterious fillers and usually have rushed service.
author: Foodaholic G.

description: The greatest trap of eating dim sum is that you order relentlessly without considering how much you're gonna end up paying. I should've read the other reviews before coming here, cus the stuff is EXPENSIVE.... and having eaten dim sum from all over Hong Kong... I'd say the food is just decent. Very filling though.
author: Dan T.

description:
Maybe it was the dumplings, maybe it was the company, or maybe it was just the mood I was in, but my experience at Yank Sing was incredible. If I were just reporting on the service alone, I'd report four stars just on the timely and friendly service. 
The sea bass with a plum sauce was incredible. We parceled out the dish and before we knew it, found ourselves wanting more! Some of the more classic dim sum items (including the egg tarts that I love!) were delicious and fresh as expected. I love that you can smell the delights coming your way before you can see them, and it's so fun to test your palette with new surprises delicately placed on the table by the waitstaff. 
The atmosphere was pleasant and I recommend getting there at opening, or make a reservation if you don't want to wait. I love dim sum for the experience, and although Yank Sing isn't an everyday kind of place (for my wallet) it really is a treat and I can't wait to go back.
author: Kelly B.

description:
I've had better is all I could think when I went here for dim sum. 

I'm all for fancy Chinese restaurants with good service but if the food isn't up to par then I'd rather go to my usual dim sum place with pushy and slightly rude waitresses. 

The thing that really bugs me about this place is that it caters to a (well I'm just going to be politically incorrect and say it) white crowd. 

The food is really 3 stars because it's not bad it's just nothing special. It is the price that brings it down. I'm not going to pay $20+ per person for dim sum that isn't amazing 

Bottom Line: If you want good dim sum go elsewhere.
author: Jessica F.

description: Very good Dim Sum, you can taste the quality of the ingredients and the care with which the Dim Sum is made, and well executed, i.e. crunchy when it should be cruchy, moist and tender when it should be, etc.  The non-Dim Sum items were good but not great, so I think 3 1/2 stars is about right.
author: Thommee H.

description:
Finally made my way up to the city for dim sum over the weekend.
Was very impressed with the outdoor seating and decor of the water!! How nice!! Because we were early, we had to sit inside, and I have no complains because then I really got to concentrate on the food carts that come around instead of getting distracted outside!! LOL

First order was the soup dumpling (siu loong pau) that everyone raves about. Yummmm....warm, tender, soupy, delicious!!! They were good, so good that we ordered more after a round of the other stuff (har gao, siu mai, etc).  The best thing to get at Yank Sing is the soup dumpling I have to say. The other steamed items are alright, but not something to write home about.

The service there was also great, teapot was refilled timely, food came quickly, if you need something that you don't see on the carts,they will order it for you, pretty good!!  

I will definitely go back for the delicious soup dumpling here, and perhaps sit out to enjoy the view. :)
author: Florence W.

description: I kept wanting to order more dishes so I could try more flavors! The house noodles were the best. The hot and cold teas were also delicious. Advise going with a big group so that you can try many things on the menu.
author: Karin Z.

description:
Fancy - yes, Quality -maybe, Best dim sum - Nope.

So what can I say, dim sum in SF proper is not done all that well. This place is fancy and has the proper feel of a high-end dim sum place with full service, tea and tables. 

But the prices are high and the dishes- well- just ok.

They have a long list of dim sum choices but few and far between were really great. I nee
author: Jonathan W.

description: The 'IT' place for dim sum lovers in the States. They have an extensive array of authentic dim sum items, made perfectly. The Shanghai Dumplings tasted just like the ones I had on my visits to Shanghai.
author: Rashmi P.

description:
WOW - I cannot believe I have never had dim sum before!! I went with a group of co-workers and had a great time learning about the whole concept as well as sampling all sorts of "surprise" dishes. The stuffed mushroom caps were great, the Shanghai dumplings were phenomenal exploding delightful flavor once its delicate skin was pierced, the egg rolls, pork buns, Phoenix shrimp and all the other fabulous (non-pork) items we tried were great. Not to mention that I felt cured of my hangover about 5 min after we walked out of here!!
One of the desserts was so cool looking: appeared to be orange slices but upon closer inspection it was actually orange jello that was set into a real orange peel. It tasted like Tang but who cares! I thought it was a cute concept. Bought some jasmine tea (as we didn't have any there) on my way out but haven't tried it yet. Can't wait to seek out dim sum here in Chicago!
author: Ivanka B.

description: Went to Rincon location.  Best Dim Sum I've had!  Wish it was open for dinner.
author: M F.

description:
4 stars for the food and atmosphere 
1 star for the service

My family and I are from HK and have a critical tongue for all Chinese food, especially Cantonese cuisine. Yang Sing is one of the few places we will go for dim sum. Although it IS overpriced and they offer a lot of westernized dishes aside from the traditional dim sum items, the taste is stable and of good quality (for America). The ingredients are fresh and the taste is better than most dim sum places in the Bay Area. The environment is also very comfortable, clean and classy, another reason why I would choose to go here. 

BUTTTTTT!!!!!!!! The service is no bueno.....unless you speak English and English only. Or at least that was what was carried across during my last visit. While the manager and servers were courteous and friendly, the majority of the dim sum cart ladies were rather rude when they talked to us in Cantonese (our mistake for letting them know that we knew the dialect; I cannot understand dim sum items when they're "translated" to English, so I had to ask what it was in Cantonese). No smiles, no thank you's...just a bunch of glaring, shouting and frowning. It would be more understandable if we had been difficult customers with ridiculous demands or rude attitude - no, we were perfectly civilized people wanting to enjoy dim sum with our out-of-town guests. Oh I'm sorry, I wasn't aware that only non-Cantonese speaking individuals (indeed the majority of their customers) deserved your respect and attention.

Normally we are chill customers and rarely complain to the managers. But one lady in particular was so bad that we felt it was necessary to report her (if that does anything?). I closely observed her - she gave every table a bright smile and almost bowed when she thanked them. As soon as she came into proximity with our table, the cheesy smile disappears and turns into a frown - before anything was said. In one instance, she was carrying pan-fried buns, which are traditionally made with pork. The ones she carried were chicken, and my dad, who doesn't eat beef, did not hear her and politely asked if there was any beef in the buns. To all of our surprise (dismay), she shot my dad a scornful glare and shouted (in English) "CHICKEN!" before proceeding with a look of annoyance. It sure did not sound like she was reiterating but instead it sounded like she was scolding him for mistaking (or so she thought) "beef" in Chinese for "chicken" in English. Needless to say, it pissed her off even more that we did not order the buns (evident by the rolling of her eyes.) Later on, she skipped our table a couple of times and made a face every time she inched close. SERIOUSLY? We did NOTHING wrong. 

LASTLY - the manager's initial reaction to our complaint was "Really? But she has been working here for a really long time!" .....umm are you trying to imply that we are making up the story and that there is no chance for a long-time employee to act so rudely to its customers? 

Of course, there were some ladies who were polite and treated us the same as everyone else. But overall, I was disgusted by how certain employees favored and sucked up to a particular crowd of customers. Though we thought the food was good, we did not feel welcomed by the restaurant at all. 

I don't know. My pride says this place does not deserve any more of our business....but my stomach still prefers their dim sum over any other place in SF/East Bay. Rawr. Damnit.
author: Grace C.

description: Xiao long bao here are GREAT. My bf, a cha shao bao connoisseur, said they also had the best cha shao bao he's ever had. Shaomai were good (real piece of shrimp inside every one!) and egg tarts were delicious. It is extremely pricey for dim sum, but it's not greasy like you often expect dim sum to be - a pleasant surprise. I also loved their tea selection (we got chrysanthemum/ju hua cha) and they had very cordial and prompt service.
author: Susan Z.

description:
I would say the best dim sum in town. I grew up in Southern China, where dim sum originates. Though the dim sum options and quality in Yang Sink don't come near to the ones in China, it's still pretty decent, especially other dim sum places in the bay area are fairly mediocre. 

I like their shrimp dumpling the most, thin wrap with fresh shrimp filling, which is the best you can get so far in the bay area. The dim sum at Yang Sink is on the pricey end. It can get very busy during lunch on the weekends. Parking is validated. 

I would recommend it if you want authentic Cantonese dim sum. It's the best remedy for my nostalgia for hometown delicacies.
author: Kai Y.

description:
My first issue with Yank Sing....

Going back to a saying I have used in the past.

"If it's all white, it ain't right."

Guess what I saw walking into Yank Sing?

LOTS of white people.  

My second issue with Yank Sing.

You know those all you can eat buffets that only charge you like $9 yet totally jam you up on a $4 drink?

Yank Sing employs some of this logic with well pushed items that cost around $18 each (like the duck).

What's GREAT about Yank Sing?

- The spicy bean sauce and mustard they serve.  Wow, a great combo.
- The shanghai dumplings are also pretty damned good.

What's OK about Yank Sing?

- The dumplings (I still stand by Cupertino on this one).

What's TOTAL CRAP about Yank Sing?

- The price (luckily Miss Grace K bought me lunch this time).  

It's tourist trap expensive.  

3.5 stars and since I am in a good mood today, I am rounding up to 4.

Steam.
author: Archie R.

description:
We have driven almost 50 miles each way to have Dimsum at Yank Sing for at least ten years,  Until now we have always felt the dining experience was well worth the extra effort.   We arrived today and found it to be as busy at lunch time as usual.  While my husband parked the car, I signed in for the one half hour wait  to be seated.   During that time I noticed there were fewer carts offering tasty morsels than in the past.  Although the dining room and atrium were full and lots of diners waiting, it seemed as though the food was either not being prepared quickly enough or was on rationing.  We did get seated within the promised 30 minutes, but no food was wheeled by our table for quite some time and we had to ask for tea, twice.  Also, the same carts kept circling and there was not the variety of offerings we have come to expect.  We asked for several dishes, as is customary to do, and they did not arrive for quite some time.   
To be fair, the food was pretty good, but each piece seemed to less dainty and fewer servings were given on each plate.   For a lunch that was almost $100, with tip,  I hope Yank Sing will return to its former, award winning glory so all those miles down the freeway still seem worthwhile.
author: Donalyn D.

description: I'm not super enthusiastic, even though I attended an event here and therefore didn't actually pay for it (I have a feeling I would like it less if I had had to pay). The food seemed consistent, pretty normal, and a little boring. However, if it's helpful/necessary for English to be spoken and understood with dim sum, I guess this is a good option.
author: Lisa K.

description:
i eat dim sum in LA all the time but Yank Sing now holds the #1 spot in my heart.
the food is delicious...the scallop dumplings! the shrimp & crab claw thingy! all of it. amazing!
it was easy to get tea & water. we weren't rushed. the servers spoke enough english so that i didn't end up eating things i didn't want. 
the prices were heftier than i was used to, but totally worth it!!
can't wait to go back up north and indulge.
author: dana b.

description:
I took my mom here for mother's day dim sum yesterday. I have to say I was thoroughly impressed with the service.  Upon stepping foot into the restaurant, the hostess wished my mom a "Happy Mother's Day". Also, all throughout the brunch, all the servers had genuine smiles on and treated my mom like royalty. Definitely a major difference than this Mother's Day experience. http://www.yelp.com/user_details_review_search?userid=GtAvwG3oTH4RxlpiDbO0tw&q=koi+palace
 
Thank you Yank Sing for making Mother's Day extra special for my mommy!
author: Sue L.

description: It's a very expensive place but they have good stuff !!
author: Anita J.

description: Very good, but very expensive.   I am used to dim sum being cheap and tasty.  I like their food better than Hakkasan, so I guess it is worth it.
author: Shannon S.

description: Let's see how my review compares to Mary M's since we were there together! lol! Ya, the Shanghai dumplings I believed they're called were fine but wasn't anymore wow than other places. The baked Chilean sea bass is def. a must! And the shrimp with rice noodle sheet tasted way better than any other dim sum place I've had it at!  And the egg custard dessert too, super moist and soft!  Other basic dishes were good too and did taste better than the usual dim sum places. Is it worth paying $120 for a 3 person lunch? Maybe not but it was worth a try!
author: Gigi M.

description: This place would get 5 stars if it wasn't so expensive. We ate in the "outdoor area" near a fountain, which is just the tables place outside the actual restaurant.  I didn't like it because it made me feel like I was eating in a mall food court that had waiters. The food is pretty good. The service is better than most dim sum restaurants I've been to but I don't think it's worth the price tag. Free Parking is awesome and rare in the city. Overall if they lower the price, they would get five starts
author: Pamela I.

description:
The best (and most expensive) dim sum. The food and service are so worth the slightly inflated prices. I love their steamed and baked pork buns here. ::drools:: And their chicken feet are pretty meaty. They have a signature shrimp dumpling dish. It was pretty good, but a little too wet for my taste. You'll never have to wait long for a cart or server to walk by, so your table will never be empty. Also, what I love about this place is that if you request a certain dish that they don't have on the cart, they will place your order through their radio system and someone will bring your dish straight to your table (no waiting for them to cycle through with their cart!). There are plenty of indoor and outdoor seating so the wait for a table to never long. And I love how the servers here can actually communicate in multiple dialects, not just Cantonese. And, here's a big plus for those non-Chinese dim sum lovers, the servers here actually speak English pretty well so there won't be anything lost in translation. Hahaha! If you're willing to pay just a little more for a great dim sum experience, I would definitely recommend eating here.

Also, if you eat here on the weekends, you can park in the garage and they'll validate your parking ticket. Yeah, sure you're thinking, "so what? other places do that too." Well, here's the thing, they'll validate your parking for FREE on the weekends. Yeah, I thought you'd like that. =)
author: Patricia N.

description:
I had dim sum here recently and with the high prices, I expected high quality. However, only the xiao long bao impressed me. Those were defintely good here. Everything else I found only decent, especially for the price. They did have a peking duck cart that we didn't try, I thought that was interesting.

I also tried a wedding banquet dinner here a while back which was really good, and highlighted their delicate, refined cooking. I guess if you're not paying, it can be a 4.
author: Derrick V.

description:
this is a great place for two things:  1) a fancy dim sum experience or 2) a wedding banquet.  

1) ok, let's start with dim sum first:

if you have out of town guests that you wanna impress, or have friends who get anxious about semi-dirty utensils and surly waitstaff - splurge a little and come here, where the service is actually good and decor is actually nice.  you will pay for it though - it aint cheap dim sum.

yank sing is very civilized compared to other chinese restaurants. no pushy foodcart ladies, large ass chinese families clogging up the doorway waiting for a table, grandmas boxing you out as you wait for your number to be called.  you can make a reservation and avoid all that mess.

must try's:  the xiao long baos and shrimp dumplings (har gows). my uncle from taiwan thinks their xlb's are the best, even better than din tai fung's (gasp!).  i like their shrimp dumplings...so fresh and non-greasy.

2) now for a wedding banquet:

i did my wedding reception here and loved it! sure, it's not 100% perfect but nothing in life is.  basically, what a successful wedding boils down to is good food and drinks.  YS definitely took care of the food part.

they have a few different banquet menus you can choose from. they also let you substitute certain items and charge the price difference (if needed).  compared to the dim sum, i found the banquet prices to be more palatable.  sure, you can get cheaper menus elsewhere, but if you really want chinese food at your wedding with ambiance and good service, it's well worth the price.

i loved being able to serve dim sum items as the cocktail hour hors d'oeuvres.  servers passed around bbq pork buns, shrimp dumplings, siu mai, etc.  

they also have a room that's set aside for the wedding party. you can change clothes in there, touch up hair/makeup, hide out from relatives, etc.  

basically they are pros at the wedding thing.  their servers even take the bride/groom around and facilitate the table toasting ritual. they make sure you don't get stuck at a table for too long and keep the show moving.  that was key for my 300 guest wedding.

to top it all off, you can have the reception out in the atrium and it's beautiful. only downside is it's kinda echo-y for speeches, announcements, etc. but who really cares about that stuff anyway? the food is delicious!
author: Jill L.

description:
Most delicious dim sum ever. Minus one star cuz they spell it "deem sum"... no, kidding, it's just because of the crazy prices. The shrimp rice noodle rolls cost $7 something for one order! Boo... but scallop shu mai, that's the first time I ever had that. Love scallop.

The typical dim-sum entrees have my pure-Chinese heritage approval =P ... that's your shrimp dumplings, turnip cake, sticky rice w/ chicken, egg+pork porridge, shrimp+chive dumplings, shu mai, anything else I'm leaving out... all very scrumptious and well-made, didn't cheap out on the materials at all.

I love sitting outside with the indoors waterfall! And I didn't feel like the service was skimpier just cuz we were outside... they refilled our tea like 3+ times. =P

It's just the price. Hurts my soul........... but so good... on Sundays (or is it every day?) they validate 3 hours of parking! So yay for free parking. The parking lot's a pain though, so if you can, park on the street hehe.
author: Daphne L.

description: As a tourist in search of good dim sum, I absolutely had to try this legendary spot.  Tucked down an alley, the building itself is upscale and far nicer than most other dim sum places.  I was seated at a table and the carts started swooping around me immediately.  I grabbed a few things that looked good, along with a few more traditional dishes.  The bill came to about $40, and I was definitely full, but for all the hype I was actually pretty disappointed.  The dishes were ok, but not stellar.  The glazed seabass was overcooked and dry, and the har gau dumplings and shu mai were very pretty, but not particularly tender or flavorful.  For dessert I tried a mango custard, and found it to be incredibly bland and unremarkable.  The staff are efficient and attentive and the ambiance is gorgeous, but the food was just subpar.  Overall seems like kind of a tourist trap, but if you've never had dim sum before you might enjoy the full cart experience.
author: Stephanie L.

description:
Just like all the other reviewers here...the best xiao long bao in the city. Authentic, quality ingredients, and exactly like how they make it in Asia. 

Very pricey for dim sum, but you get what you pay for! Classy atmosphere and superb service.
