author: Vivian D.

description: OK so those pot-stickers were CrAzY GooD yesterday, especially with the hot mustard and special chili sauce!!!  I've been here a few times but yesterday was off the hook.  My bestie Susan says Dim Sum is more of a team effort and I said it was more like a competition.  And it was!  As soon as we were seated a wall of food showed up at our table.  Dumplings, pork buns, stuffed mushrooms, beef in rice noodles (yum), pot-stickers, broccolini, Schezuan chicken, roast pork, and it just kept coming and coming!  I'm rather severely allergic to shrimp so I was highly impressed when they went out of their way to point out what had shrimp in it and what didn't and they put a special note (in Chinese) on the table so that the servers wouldn't serve me shrimp.  I think the note said "No shrimpy eatie!" or "No shrimp for you!" or something like that.  Anyways I felt special.  My only issue with this place is the duck cart.  You get these little square pieces of duck with buns and sauce.  They taste great but I want more like a dump truck full of duck, not just a couple buns worth.  Oh yeah, get the Shanghai dumplings.  They're insane!!!
author: Poochie M.

description: Hmmm. My mother-in-law took us here last weekend because she knows we LOVE juicy pork dumplings. She said they had the best in SF. So, we went. I was a bit disappointed. I mean, I get the same taste for a fraction of the money at Din Tai Fung. The rest of the dim sum was good, but not any better than I've had elsewhere. I'm glad I checked it out so I know I'm not missing anything.
author: Marcie C.

description:
Came here for lunch for dim sum. We were seated immediately and the food came quick. Dim sum was only okay, nothing special. The sui mai is the same as the frozen defrosted look and taste. 

This place should have 4 $$$$ signs. The bill came out to $65 with just 2 people. Value-wise, I would not go back.
author: Payne T.

description:
Quite pricey, although we didn't pay; my sister and her beau took us while they were in town. The experience was fantastic, the food beyond yummy! I suggest this for a large group so you can try all the tasty morsels and get help with the check. :) 

Love the DIM SUM!!! YUM
author: Christina K.

description:
I loved it. Worth the price because it is great dim sum. It was my first time yesterday and this place has completely changed how I view dim sum. We liked almost everything we ordered...sesame balls, shaghai pork dumplings, snow pea shoot dumplings, spinach dumplings, tea, pork bun, and chicken mushroom dumpling. The only thing I can say is that the pork buns seamed kind of average. Not really extraordinary. We also ordered curry chicken turovers which I would not order again because they weren't very good. Overall, it was a great lunch. The tea is fantastic and I love the chicken mushroom dumpling. I also highly reccomend the shanghai dumplings. Service is good, the waitress taught us how to eat the shanghai dumplings the Chinese way. 

Great experience, I will be back.
author: Elizabeth L.

description:
As for the 661st or so reviewer, I'll keep this short. 

Food = very good and safe but not really authentic, take your middle America friends and aunt Millie there 

Sevice/Atmosphere = great for a busy place like that. Very nice to watch the kids observe the waterfall from the courtyard ceiling. Get there before 11am on weekends or you'll be waiting for a bit...

Parking = essential for easy free valet (try parking in the richmond or sunset or chinatown) 

Price = expensive (at least $40 a head)
author: Moses G.

description:
Pricey but delicious.

That pretty much sums it up! It's the best dim sum I've had and they have tons of selection but be prepared for the final bill. It'll be a shocker!

On the weekends, this place is massive as they have tables in the atrium. I prefer the natural light anyway. I'd love this place more if I made 6 figures.

I do recommend this place to everyone at least once!
author: Rylan C.

description:
This place is pricier than most average dim sum places that you can go to. For a party of 3, I paid $70 when the tab is usually $30. But there are a few things that this place does better that the average dim sum place. The food is hotter than most average dim sum places, and they have a decent vegetarian selection that is much better than other dim sum places that I have seen.

The service is not anymore pushy then everywhere else. Its a restaurant; they're going to try to get you in and out as quick as possible: "Learn to say no."

They make great Shanghai Dumplings, and they do small things to improve traditional dishes. An example is there steamed rice rolls. By just adding a little green onion to the shrimp, they made that dish stand above the same dish found at other dim sum restaurants. They also have good contemporary dishes. I had a shrimp dish wrapped with bacon around a piece of green onion. I wouldn't go to this place every week, but once every few months is good if you are tired of the usual dim sum places.
author: Shih Fa K.

description: I've read a lot of hype about Yank Sing for years and finally went on my last trip out there. I've had a lot of dim sum in my life and this was decent. I was a party of one and I waited for 15 minutes. Cart service is a plus. I love the anticipation that comes when the women raise the top from each bamboo steamer. The food was good but you need to go for the baked pork bbq buns and the mango pudding. They are simply the most amazing dim sum dish I've ever had. Light, airy, sweet and unctuous. Better than advertised. Everything else I had, I've had better in SF and the pricing at Yank Sing is high. Next time, I'll just go get the pork buns to go and head to another spot for my dim sum fix.  They do validate parking at the Rincon Centre location.
author: Ethan R.

description: I haven't been here in a pretty long time, and the food was quite good, but the wait was really, really long, even though we had a reservation, 30 minute wait, but then there were the exorbitant prices!!! Are you f'ing kidding me?  4 adults, one very picky child, the total was over $200, not including a tip, and that is WITHOUT BOOZE.  That's just wrong, and I'm sorry but I'm not a tourist, and I am ashamed that a well respected and super busy restaurant overcharges so much for so little food.  Maybe they should consider including an itemized receipt with your bill, or possibly leave a dim sum menu on the table showing what the prices are for the various items?  I am not a cheapskate, but seriously this was a real eye opener for me, the prices have totally doubled since last time I dined here, and I certainly will not be back again, because no dumplings are worth that much, in my opinion.
author: Barbra K.

description:
Enjoyed a fine holiday splurgefest here with family. It took 30 minutes to be seated ... and then about 30 seconds before the food started a-coming!

Definitely pricey, but a good part of a fun "Day Out in the City" for friends and family.
author: Ron A.

description: Beautiful location. Aesthetically pleasing dim sum. Tasted light and fresh. Love the hot oil sauce. Take this home with you. Make a reservation.
author: Elle C.

description:
Wah. Wah. Wah.  
Maybe dim sum just isn't my cup o tea, but I just did not enjoy this place... and as the last meal of my foodie SF vacation, I was extra disappointed.  We were seated and before we even had a chance to glace over the menu card, we were swarmed by 4 staff strongly suggesting their dim sum as if they were competing with each other.  It was a bit overwhelming and our natural reaction was to accept the food... but I wish we would have just asked them to give us a moment.  Anyway, $80 or so later (thanks to the sea bass), we left underwhelmed.  Oh, and I can't forget to mention the sesame buns... I love these little gooey balls, but when I found out that four of them were $9 that's when I was done.  Time to go.  I'll get sesame buns from the next freakin' buffet I go to and be completely content.
author: Cindy M.

description: I don't think the Peking Duck is that mesmzerizing, but the dim sum dishes are fantastic.  i came here with my cousin's on their honeymoon, and the food is very good, I guess the location justifies the price tag.  I do think that part of the DimSum experience includes sort of a DCR(Dirtay Chinese Restaurant) vibe.  In China, the places that blow my mind are usually the ones with no writing on them in a grungy building  This one is so clean..it seems a little too corporate for my taste.  It's very good as far as presentation, but the atmosphere is just a little too stiff for Dim Sum.
author: Christopher L.

description: This place is excellent. I put it up there with Sam Woo's in S. Cal. Pace yourself and go with at least 4 people so you can try more food.
author: BRYAN M.

description:
Dim sum "a volontè" kindly offered by my gf's parents, but, ehi!!,  what-a -price (... I know, it was offered, why bother? answer: curiosity and a little sense of guilt) compared to other great  Chinese places I've been before! 
Despite the price-induced shivers, the food scored from good to great:

- Shangai dumplings: 5 star, I truly love them, especially the strongly ginger- flavoured  broth inside!
- mushroom dumplings: 4 star
- shrimp dumplings: 3 star (but, honestly, they never strike me, anyway) 
- spinach dumplings: 4 star
- shrimp and crab: 4  1/2 star 
- tofu skin dumplings: 4 1/2  star
- scallop dumplings: 3 1/2 star
- egg custard buns: 3 1/2 star
- sesame balls: 4 star 

Some other things worth to be mentioned: 
1- the clear glass tea pot  was a delight to watch
2- the noise level was comparable to that at the AT&T stadium the night before (I wasn't there, well not inside at least,  but I can easily imagine it ...)
3-  the waitresses are hardly understandable but more polite than the staff in other similar restaurants I've tried
4 - next time I'll have two full portions of Shangai dumplings, all for me :-)
author: Andrea L.

description:
I went there for a Saturday lunch recently; I admit my motivation was the 7x7 BigEat SF list, which included Yank Sing's sesame balls.  

You know you're eating great food when their famous item was among your least favorite.  This place was excellent; the dumplings were fresh and delicious, and the servers came by often enough to keep our table filled.  I was mildly disappointed that nothing too exotic like chicken feet came our way, but I'm too much of a baby to have tried it anyway.  

They validate parking at a nearby garage, but finding a spot there is like looking for uneaten carbs at a Jenny Craig welcome party.
author: Anthony D.

description:
I went to Yank Sing for brunch last Sunday to celebrate someone's birthday. I love going there with a group of 4. That way you can try a lot of their delicious dumplings and other delicacies. Yank Sing has a great atmosphere. I've sat inside the restaurant and also in the lobby/atrium area. Yank Sing is located in the Rincon Center in SF. It's kind of different location for a dim sum restaurant.

We had potstickers, su mai, roast duck sandwiches, gailan, and so much more. It was difficult to remember all of the names of what we ate. Sorry about that! The waiters and waitresses roll carts around to your table and you select what you want.

They even have dessert! Yummm.... We had the mango pudding and it was delicious. 

The price for a dim sum brunch for 4 people was reasonable. For four of us (2 guys and 2 gals), the bill was under $100, with tip.

This is definitely a place to go if you like dim sum. The food is nicely prepared, it's not greasy and everything was very tasty. They have a parking garage and they validate parking. 

I recommend you make reservations if you're going on the weekend.
author: Mari I.

description:
I know that many think Yank Sing isn't very authentic. But I always loved their various non-pork dim sum variety. It costs 5x ++ more than most dim sum joints. But especially after turning vegetarian 5 years ago, it's either here or nowhere. 

Just the other day for lunch, I stopped by the Rincon Center location (which I like far less than their Stevenson location) and ordered the VEGETARIAN DELIGHT $5.95 at their to-go counter. The meal comes with Vegetable Dumplings (2), Eggplant w / Hunan Sauce, and Vegetable Chow Mein. It's not as good as an dim-sum-only platter but certainly a good buy for a lunch at FiDi.
author: Tiffany L.

description:
Craving dim sum on the first day of the new year, we came here on the afternoon of New Years day to satisfy our taste buds and nurse our hangovers.

I have never been to a dim sum place quite like this - big and full of light and located at the center of an office building/food court. Looking at the surroundings, I wasn't sure quite what to expect...

Despite the size of the restaurant, we had a long-ish wait of about half an hour (to be expected as it was a holiday) but started scoffing as soon as we were seated and the carts visited our tables in quick succession.

Food was fab - tasty, hot and satisfying. Staff were busy (we had to wait a while for the bill), a bit aggressive, but otherwise ok on the whole. The highlight was the seabass, perfectly cooked and with a delicious glazing and, for dessert, the custard tarts and mango pudding.  We left the restaurant full and slight less hungover. Will come again - maybe on a day when its less busy, if that's possible..
author: Shruthi B.

description: This was good dim sum, but I'm not sure that it lived up to the price tag. There are so many great Chinese places in the city, I'm not sure I want to pay the big bucks for dims sum. That being said, the crab corn dogs (as I'm sure they're formally called) were pretty tasty.
author: Rachel M.

description:
I went on Sunday made reservation for 12pm ahead. We waited pro 15~20min. not bad...
The place was packed also it was Farther's Day...

Three of us ate...
Chicken shumai
Shrimp dumpling
Scallop dumpling (so good!)
vegi triangle dumpling
bean curd
crab fingers
shrimp fry
Steamed Flour Rolls with shrimp
Peking duck
onion cake (excellent!!)

for desert
mango pudding
sesami ball

with Jasmin tea

mmm... now when I see the list, I guess we ate alot...
All that $132! My God! including tip we each paid $50!

All the dishes were not oily, well flavored and delicious!
It just too expensive... for dim sum.
I wish it end up around $30~$35. $40 the highest.
Anyway, it was great visit. 

I do recommend to people to try once, it is the greatest dim sum I ever had so far.
author: Green Mango Y.

description:
First off... No one should ever have to spend $$$ on dimsum unless it's some REALLY gourmet stuff.

The dimsum was good, I loved the soup dumplings (aka. Xiao long Bao) but not worth the price. It was pretty standard dimsum, the type you can get by running over to China Town and spending half the price.

We went with the basic stuff, hakaw, siomai, xiao long bao, steamed pork buns, steamed scallop dimsum, chicken feet, deep fried prawns wtih scallions and cilantro (this I LOVED)...

I have yet to encounter an order of chicken feet from a dimsum restaurant that I did not enjoy. Most people are hesitant to try this dish, but I gotta admit... it's the part of the chicken that holds the most flavor.

The dough the soup dumplings were served in was soft and tender. Although the dumplings werent too hot by the time I got to them. Which was a little disappointing. And it was served with a red vinegar sauce as opposed to the black that I'm used to. Still did it's job... But wasn't as great of a fit as the black vinegar sauce.


So, that's really all I've got to say. Good dimsum. Nothing amazing that I can really rave about. And way too expensive. I suppose it's just the location. But if I were you, I'd drive down to Chinatown for the real deal for half the price.
author: Jenny D.

description: Atmosphere welcoming and inviting staff extremely friendly. Best to make reservations, not good for people who are claustrophobic since aisles are small and seating is a little cramped. Overall food is delicious not greasy or oily like cheap Chinese food when it came to house fried rice and chow mien. Loved all the food on the carts that we tried, cant pronounce any of the names but it was great. Good for families or small get togethers.
author: Mimi W.

description: Yang Sing is OK and has decent dim sum. The major thig here is the shao long Bao.. This review is low because (1) it is good but not as good as koi or other more mid peninsula or peninsula dim sum places (2) how damn expensive they are. Literally it is like eating at a Michelin star restaurant but less class an less yummy food for the price. (3) bullshit reservation system. How is it that theybcangive people serv afoot time at twelve and still make the derivation people wait for over 1/2 hour? The reason why I make a reservation is so Incan get in and out. It's ok if you don't want to do reservations but don't freaking waste my time.
author: Chia-Lin S.

description: Confusion at the hostess stand (to say the least), food was good.  Shanghai dumplings were ok, but a bit of a let-down after hearing so much praise about them. Parking in the adjoining garage is a nightmare, even if you drive a practically microscopic-sized vehicle.  Long wait to pay the bill.  So, all in all...just ok.
author: J.K. S.

description:
Let's get right to it.   Non-greasy dim sum choices at ridiculously high prices!  $220 for 8 people, and unfortunately I can't even say we were stuffed. 

At the end of the day, it's all about the value for you money, and unfortunately, this place just doesn't cut it. There no argument that the dim sum is good quality.  We were all very happy with our meal until we saw our bill.  Here's a highlight so you get my point:

- $15 for tea (charged per person)
- egg custard tarts for 4 (my favorites!) for $10 
- sesame balls for 4... also $10
- 2 BBQ pork buns for $6

With all the other options out there, I'm sorry to say that you are crazy to pay these kinds of prices for dim sum, unless it was all made with truffle oil or caviar.  But then again, that wouldn't be dim sum, would it?  

Just CRAZINESS!
author: Helen C.

description:
Yank Sing wanted to charge me $5.10 for a SLICE of Peking Duck

Now, high prices don't usually bother me...I just don't buy whatever they're selling. But wanting five bucks for a slice of duck is just insulting. You can get a whole duck for $15 in Chinatown.

My first and last time eating there.
author: Eugene F.

description:
Came here for a 3-hour lunch on a Saturday while on vacation in San Francisco with my wife. It is in a located in a beautiful modern building. Even though they have an incredibly large number of seats, with  tables spilling out of their main area into the atrium, they were pretty much full. The place was bustling--for good reason, too, as was evidenced later by the food. However, we were lucky and were able to be seated right away. 

I live in Boston currently, and while people do rave about dim sum here, I have never truly liked dim sum...until now. Yank Sing has converted me to a dim sum lover, for I now know what is possible. The quality and taste of the food is just amazing. We sampled items from nearly a third of the menu, and absolutely none were subpar. The shanghai dumplings and Sichuan chicken were some of the best I ever had. They do provide a menu with the prices of each item, so no surprises were had on the bill--which was, of course, hefty. Then again, we ate until we could eat no more, as we both knew it would be a long, long time before we would have anything so delicious.
author: Leon C.

description: I keep trying and always seem to get sick to my stomach. I have one of those rancid grease detectors in my stomach. no matter how much savory sauce is poured over rancid food, my gut will not lie to me. All of the Yank Sings are the same, a big tourist trap, expensive and spoiled food. It all tastes the same anyway.
author: joan b.

description:
I had a very surreal experience here. We arrived at 11:30 on a Sunday, our party of 6 was seated right away and the service was unbelievably friendly and helpful I felt like something was wrong. It just did not feel like dim sum.

I can't disagree, the prices are quite shocking when we first looked at the menu but the combination of the service and the quality of food made up for it and in the end what we paid wasn't terribly ridiculous.

I was really looking forward to the xiao long bao since many gave it great reviews and I am such a huge fan. We carefully tried taking the dumplings out of the container onto the provided spoon but sadly the wrapper tore spilling out some of the precious broth on about 5 out of the 6 dumplings making it really disappointing especially at $11 an order.

Everything else however was absolutely delicious. You could taste a difference in the quality of the ingredients of even in the most basic of dim sum dishes. For example, I usually can take or leave har gow, but the shrimp in the ones at Yank Sing were so sweet that we had to order more.

I go to dim sum so rarely that I'm okay with paying a little more for excellent service and delicious food so I will definitely come back here again.
author: Cindy N.

description:
First off, my review is based on my wedding reception at Yank Sing & the Atrium.  I've only been to the actual restaurant twice (once for a food tasting and once for dim sum), so I'm not going to comment on that.

Our wedding was the best wedding ever (yes, yes, I know I'm biased because it was our wedding).  

Yes, this place is pricey, but was it worth it, definitely!  Our venue was gorgeous!  Having our banquet catered into the Atrium was probably the best decision we made wedding wise (aside from marrying each other, of course...I know, I know...gag). 

My husband and I both wanted to have Chinese food at our wedding but I was 100% against having it at a Chinese restaurant.  I didn't want tacky decorations, loud servers, dishes clanging...no thank you..not on my wedding day!  So this place was the PERFECT compromise.

Joy, who was their events coordinator, was sooo helpful.  She really did take care of everything!  We told her what we wanted from the menus, switched things around, and she made it happen.  

The customer service was superb.  All of our friends kept on commenting about how helpful the staff were.  On our wedding day, they even brought in an extra coordinator to help with our event.  The restaurant converts a room into a bridal room to put gifts, to change and such, with mirrors and everything!  

When we made our entrance to the reception, there were staff and servers that popped out of no where to help show us where to go as we made our way up to the head table.  There was also a lady (who was super nice) that patiently led us around the Atrium (to all 40 something tables) for us to toast.  

You can tell that the staff definitely know what they're doing when it comes to weddings because everything went so smoothly and if anything ever went wrong, I had no clue.  They really made sure that they talked to my coordinator, bridal party, or parents, as opposed to me so that I could enjoy my day with my new hubs.

If we could redo our wedding, this one thing we would never change..hands down!
author: Tracy M.

description: This place is exorbitantly expensive but it is so darn good. The xiaolongbao are on par with the best I've had in the world such as at DinTaiFeng.
author: Amy M.

description:
My only other exposure to Dim Sum restaurants (excluding take out from Chinatown which cannot be beat!) is Jasmine in San Diego which makes you feel like you are being served in a warehouse with a faux stage waiting for the wedding singer to entertain.

Easy to find on Spear Street a block or two from the Embarcadero Station. Yes! It is in the Post Office building! Just follow the noise on weekends....There is a lovely atrium inside and it was very crowded when we arrived around 1:30.

We were seated immediately and then the carts started to roll through. I loved that there was a menu that provides pricing and interpretation. Believe me for us white folks it helps!

We started with the tofu appetizer wrapped in seaweed...delicious! I recommend mixing the chili pepper sauce and hot mustard and taking that tofu for a dip...YUM!

Almost took the Sea Bass then checked the pricing at it was $17, so I am happy we declined.

Next up....steamed shrimp dumplings and BBQ pork rolls, we love these things!

Had the satay but am not a huge fan of chicken skin and this satay came with skin.....maybe that's typical in authentic places but I am still not a fan.

I love the idea of Dim Sum with carts rolling through and waiting for the unexpected but fear the take out joints in Chinatown are much more interesting and adventurous. Of course, it's always the cheaper bet for take out unless you want the experience and someone else to clean up after you. Since we were visiting the city again and in a hotel we decided the restaurant was the better option.....this time!
author: Travelinggals S.

description: There is a reason Yank Sing comes up first in the search results. Dim sum is served up at its absolute finest in this elegant, open and honest restaurant. The soup dumpings are about the best, and all dishes are extraordinary. Peking duck carved to order for dim-sum, perfect dumplings and rolls and pastries so varied that you should wait and watch for a while to make sure you see some of the more unusual plates. Its worth the drive and the wait, although the parking is very inconvenient and easily accessible. Cheers!
author: Matt S.

description:
This is the only dim sum place we would go to when we are in the Bay. Dim sum can get pretty expensive here. Among my husband and I, we can eat about 85 dollars worth of mini dim sum plates. It is a nice treat every so often when we are in the area. 

What I really love most is their special Shanghai Dumplings. The broth is super juicy and the outside skin is super thin. It compliments the  the red vinegar ginger sauce really well. The service is always good here. Do expect a wait during lunch hours.
author: Jenn T.

description: Having dim sum here can be on the expensive side. I guess the rent here must be crazy. Anyway, the only reason why I gave 4 stars is because of the Shanghai dumplings. I love that dish. Its steamed pork dumplings but they are filled with a liquid soup so that when you bite into it, you have a nice squirt of broth and meat. Its a bit pricey but we had to get 2 orders of it. Its so good.
author: Kenson K.

description: decent dimsum , good location especially for tourist, and great service but i feel like price is too much.  i guess you are pretty much paying for the location and ambience.  for me it would be good to bring visiting guests here but not just to satisfy my usual dimsum craving
author: Elc C.

description:
Come here if you want over priced dim sum! Half the stuff isn't even dim sum food. eg.. almond ice cream cake?? I think this is also the ONLY dim sum restaurant that I've ever been to in my life where you have to PAY FOR THE TEA!! that is so unheard of. 

The food is not lacking in quality (hence the 3 stars), but I just don't think it's worth it for what it is. Go elsewhere if you want authentic dim sum..
author: S H.

description:
"When you're in love with a married man, you shouldn't wear mascara," said Shirley MacLaine in one of my favorite movies, The Apartment.

Yank Sing Restaurant is that man!

Unless you are willing to spend your whole paycheck on quality dim sum, go elsewhere that charges half the price.  I will save you the heartache upfront.

Otherwise, Yank Sing is very charming because he keeps you coming back for more, even though you know he is not good for you.

Part of his charm is that he has the best Xiao Long Bao (XLB) in San Francisco.  It is so juicy and delicious.  If you can only afford one dish, this is it.  He can also prepare other signature dishes, like succulent Peking duck with buns and lettuce cups, served individually. 

Another skill is that he is bi-lingual, which caters to his discerned lovers, who are comfortable in speaking English or Chinese.

Still another attractor is that he is conveniently located in the Financial District instead of Chinatown.  Not everyone has the luxury of time to look for their lover outside their circle during lunch.  He even validates your parking downstairs in the garage during the weekends, while he wines and dines you.

Best of all, he knows your weaknesses:  available EVERY day, spotless bathrooms, and attentive wait staff to impress your friends when they visit him.

Just be prepared to wear your waterproof mascara if you are picking up the tab.

Chorus: DON'T CRY FOR ME, YANK SING!
author: CT L.

description: I love the food here, but my wallet doesn't love yank sing.  I used to eat here when it was about 8 bucks for 8 xiao long bao dumplings...now it's 6 dumplings for 11.20.  Come on now, the dumplings are good... but it better be orgasmic for those prices.  And don't get me started on portions of the other dishes.  Terrible value!
author: Ray T.

description:
Best Dim Sum I've ever eaten! I thought they were proficient and friendly (despite being busy). We always had tea and water. We both were super full afterward.

My one complaint is the same as everyone elses- it was very expensive (to me, totally worth it). If you're just looking for crappy cheap dim sum, don't go here. If you're looking for authentic, great tasting, great service dim sum and willing to pay a little more- then this is your place!
author: Amanda D.

description:
My lunch buddy and I decided to be spontaneous last week and get some dim sum at Yank Sing. What a splurge! I had only been to Yank Sing for dim sum 2 other times, and never really got exactly what I wanted since I went with my Caucasian co-workers. I didn't want to scare them with the traditional Chinese dishes. 

The scene:

Yank Sing is very fancy so be prepared to shell out $20-$30 per person on dim sum.

The food:

What sets Yank Sing apart from other dim sum restaurants are their original dishes such as the succulent sea bass and the red cabbage salad. The sea bass is definitely my favorite, but it's $18 a plate! Their house made chili sauce is bomb too. It's similar to XO sauce minus the seafood. I believe they also sell it at 99 Ranch Market.

Shu-mai (meat balls) - I'm not a big shu-mai fan, even though it is a traditional dim sum item. I always found it too meaty, nothing special. However, Yank Sing's version of the shu-mai is so flavorful and juicy! It's almost like the meat in a xiao long bao (Shanghainese soup dumpling).

Har-gow (shrimp dumpling) - This har-gow really wasn't any different than any other har-gow.

Beef cherng-fun (noodle roll filled with ground beef) - By far, my favorite dish at any dim sum restaurant. They put way too much cilantro in their cherng fun though. I am not a fan.

Fried tofu - Again, nothing mind blowing. This was just cold, lightly fried tofu with soy sauce. I love tofu, so I usually get this at any Chinese restaurant that serves it.

Jin Dui (sesame ball filled with lotus paste) - This is THE BEST jin dui ever. I could just get an order of this and be satisfied. The doughy skin was thin, chewy and crispy. The inside dough is orange in color, which makes me assume the dough is made from yams. I could be wrong. The inside filling is a sweet lotus paste rather than the red bean.

We ended up spending $25 a person for only 6 dishes. It's a little outrageous, so I don't think I'll be coming back any time soon. I may come back to get an order of jin duis to go though.
author: Sam L.

description: Yum! I came for a banquet and finally had a chance to experience their dinner menu. All I have to say is order the SEABASS. It's soooo delicious!
author: Natalie S.

description:
Not a citizen of this fair city, but come up here often on business. And when I do, I love coming to this restaurant for lunch. It's waaaaay expensive. Good heavens, I feel like I should donate something at Grace Cathedral after luxuriating in that place. Splurge is an understatement, given the amazingly good and reasonably priced fair within a mile or two from here.

But I love the soup INSIDE the dumplings. Dunno what it's called because I can't understand a word anyone is saying. (No, not all of us asians understand each other, thank you). I cannot get enough of this highly expensive but delightful dish. Delight is inadequate. I feel like a kid at Christmas time every time I bite into one of these explosions of flavor.

I typically order the shrimp and crab plates that go by and avoid the hearty stuff. With a glass of plum wine, lunch is around $25 with tip. That's my treat to myself when I'm in this city. Have a nice lunch at the bar (or table, if I'm trying to dine with a customer) and have a big smile on my face for a few hours.

Are there less expensive places out there? Of course. But hit the streets of NYC, Chicago, Honolulu, or DC and see if you get an upscale Chinese restaurant without these prices. It's not a place to eat on a daily basis, but definitely worth it for a nice visit. And if you don't want to pay that much, just hit the To Go portion of the restaurant next door.

Not sure about parking, since it's only two blocks from the Embarcadero Muni/Bart station.
author: mel s.

description:
Take heed, cheap dim sum lovers, this place is NOT for the financially challenged. Many reviewers paying $200+ for a meal of dim sum that doesn't cause a food coma are average events.My experience was no exception.  

On a more positive note, the restaurant is elegant, the staff are the nicest among all the dim sum places I've ever been and the food, the most important factor of all, is delicious. 

The dim sum here is very good, its excellently crafted. Its not greasy like how a lot of dim sum places make theirs. The shrimp har gow is the best example of this. They weren't covered in a giant, gummy skin. They were hot when they got to me and the shrimp was proportional to the dumpling skin. 

I also had the xiao long bao (the soup dumplings) and although they are NOT the best I've ever had, they were crafted well and had no real faults. The sesame balls were similiar, no flaws but not the greatest flavor.

Also had 
-bbq pork buns (very good, the bun itself is glazed in honey)
-pork shumai (NOT greasy! Yay!)
-broccoli (cooked correctly, had nice bright green color and were tender without losing the snap)
-tea (loose leaf was a huge plus and was fragrant)
-seabass (expensive! But totally worth it. Flaky, delicate white fish with a sweet glaze..treated with respect, it was a nice chinese variant to seabass)

Now here's where I'm bound to piss some people off. I hate authenticity whores myself, but can somebody tell me what part of China chicken lettuce cups and chicken satay come from? Now I know they have to cater to their clientele, tourists and business people, but really?  Just doesn't seem right. I'm not hating, I'm just saying...I don't want that family visiting from the midwest that sat near my table to think that the satay they're eating is chinese(which they did-the parents proclaimed it was to their inquisitive children).

ANYWAY, moving away from minor hostility...
We went early, like at 10am, so there was no wait and still plenty of room in the main restaurant. When we left an hour and a half later, the restaurant was starting to swell and the patio was being utilized. I'd venture to guess that if you came at noon there'd be a wait, so come earlier not to chance it.  

So the sum up this review, if you're a tourist, big on cart dim sum or new to dim sum itself Yank Sing is perfect for you. If you like an impressive ambiance and super nice people, you should come here. 
Otherwise, there are other choices...
author: Lauren V.

description:
I know it's hard to write a fair review on food when it is paid for by someone else...  So let me break it to you the price tag on dim sun for two on a Sunday morning--- $63.00 (plus a $10 tip) before proceeding with the rest of it.

First of all, the atrium is quite nice.  Very few places in the city, let along a Chinese restaurant, can provide such a cool atmosphere in the middle of an office building.  The food was really good as well.  Every item we ordered was delicious--- from the buns that sandwiched my Peking duck to the soft tofu dessert, you can taste the delicate preparation that went into it, with no trace of MSG (which City View never failed to remind me of 30 to 45 min after my meal there).  

Lastly, the service was excellent.  Always polite, always attentive to our needs.  The clumsy me dropped a chopstick which was replaced seamlessly by the waiter who happened to pass by me.  My request for turnip cake was transmitted from the cart lady's mic to the kitchen instantly, and showed up on our table within minutes.  I was thoroughly impressed.

So $73 for the whole experience...?  Part of me feels like it was way too much.  But part of me wants to justify it...  Why should Chinese food be so cheap?  Why should the expectation of a Chinese restaurant in general be so low...?  With that said, I think it was worth it as I am very grateful that I was treated to a wonderful meal at Yank Sing.
author: Jiajia C.

description: there are spicy dim sums and then there is yank sing. I managed to spend $130 for 2 people at lunch ... for dimsums!
author: spacemonkey m.

description:
Came here on X-mas morning for dim sum.
Place was packed but we were seated as soon as the atrium area was ready (10min).

We started with the Shanghai Dumplings.   Hmmm 4 star

The rest of the dim sum items were just okay, I've had better. 
Some items came to the table lukewarm...  2 star

I agree with others that prices are high, but look at where they are.  
Rent must be really expensive...
author: David L.

description:
Yank Sing, I miss you so much! I've been in New England ever since we met back in 2007. Not a dim-sum day goes by that I don't crave your fine variety of offerings. 
Some day we will meet again and I will smile with a full tummy and an empty wallet.
author: Sarah C.

description:
Okay, the dim sum ain't horrible here, but it's not great either.

My main issue is with the service and the ridiculously long wait.

One time we waited hours for some friggen dim sum, and when we were finally seated, they only had a very limited and very gwei-lo selection of fried and over-sweetened items.

If Fook Yuen (Millbrae) ever closes, try all 25 other dim sum places on my list before wasting your money at Yank Sing.
author: Justin C.

description: $40 for one person at dim sum is crazy.  I got ripped off here, there was no warning that they would have plates costing $10 mixed in with the cheap dishes....  I could eat at Aqua at Yank Sing's prices... The prices made this Yank sing for mercy.  I am NOTgoing back.
author: David B.

description:
I give up.
I love this place, and even if it's a $100 lunch with $4 additional for parking to eat here, I still eat here.  

Yes, it's still ridiculous.
But there are, perhaps, only 5 or 6 places on the planet that make me happy at the mere THOUGHT of eating there.

Yank Sing is one of them, and this place, pricey as it may be, is the KING of DIM SUM.  To find better, I'd have to fly to Vancouver, and when you price it out like that, Yank Sing is cheap.

My first review of Yank Sing was me ranting about $70 dim sum for two.  These days, our bill for two ranges from $75-$100, depending on how hungry we are, but at least we are no longer surprised.  We also have a good time playing a guessing game, "HOW MUCH IS THE BILL TODAY?" before the check arrives.  

Shanghai Dumplings..... 
Woman can live on that alone, I'm not kidding.
author: Grace K.

description: One of the yummiest dim sum restaurants I ever been to. They have many different choices not available at typical dim sum places. It's quite expensive though --- 13 peeps and our total was $440 for a lunch...I have to say I won't be coming here unless my the meal is expensable.
author: sonya h.

description: Well the atmosphere left a bit to be desired, but the food was, for the most part, quite good.   We came toward the end of lunch service (2pm), so some of the items seemed like they might have gone around a few times.   The dishes we tried that were fresh were all amazing.      The egg rolls, signature pot stickers, and peking duck were all delicious.   My crab claw dish was not a favorite- good flavor, but cold.   Toward the end, we realized that it was better to just order off the menu, rather than off the cart, as the food tended to be hotter/ fresher.   Again, this could be because we came toward the end and were the last people in the restaurant.  All around good experience though and great food!
author: Ashley N.

description:
xlb was kinda mushy but I traveled great distance to have them, so they weren't that bad. 

Let them cool down for a minute or two, then grab. They are pretty hot! 

Kinda expensive too. I've had some in NY and weren't half as much.
author: Nicole S.

description: My favorite place when visiting SF.  Food is fresh and delicious. My family loves the soup dumplings...but consumes the other dim sum in a rapturous bliss as well...
author: S T.

description:
Disclaimer first, 
I am not a fan of dim sum. My husband drags me to go in LA all the time. HOWEVER,  I would go more often if Dim Sum restaurants were as nice as Yank Sing.  You do pay more for your dim sum but I find that the quality is good, the food is fresh and the service is fast and polite.

I also found dishes here that are  lacking in LA dim sum places like the dumplings my husband likes with the nuts and pork rice noodle rolls. I would go again, and we usually do visit Yank Sing while in San Francisco. 

This is actually a very glowing review, considering how much I'm not a fan of dim sum:)

R
author: Renee L.

description:
Yank Sing developed the genius strategy of layering Four Seasons-style service on top of fairly authentic and yummy Dim Sum, and the result is a Westerner-friendly and delicious dim sum dining experience (and serious bank for the owners, no doubt).   To wit: host-type people in suits materialize as soon as you sit down, offering to bring tea, diet coke or what have you.  Halfway through your meal, someone is likely to show up and ask if you'd like to order any take out from next door (smart move - if you had hired McKinsey & Co. they surely would have suggested that as a way to drive incremental revenue, probably on the order of an additional 5 - 10% per table).   If there's something you desire that isn't on one of the carts, ask anyone, and they'll whisper into that handy-dandy headset thingy (reminiscent of Banana Republic) and within minutes your chow fun or other special order will be at your table.  

Atmosphere is not as authentic-feeling as (and much more expensive than) Ton Kiang, Koi Palace or the other Dim Sum stalwarts, but the food is great, there's a broad array of both traditional dim sum offerings and a bit of innovation here and there, the dishes are fresh, and tend to be lighter and less greasy, and it's a great place to take less adventurous folks who might recoil when having chicken feet waved under their noses at a more traditional dim sum venue.   The only down side is I always leave with my wallet a lot lighter, and my corpse a lot heavier.
author: Katy M.

description:
Yikes!  Tab for two for a moderate amount of dim sum was $90 before tip.  Little things add up quickly - shanghai dumplings are nearly $11 a plate.  We ordered four dishes which were well over $10.00 - one was nearly $20 - and there was absolutely NO indication as to how much they cost.  A pot of tea was nearly $4.00 - most chinese restaurants will throw this in for free.  Until this business realizes that blindsiding its customers is not good practice, I won't be back.  Too many other good dim sum places with reasonable prices.
Another thing - the same items were appearing over and over again on the carts.  There was almost no selection.
author: She-Ra ..

description: Don't like negative reviews based primarily on price. Everyone has different ideas of what "over-priced" is. I don't think Yang Sing is over-priced. The ribs are to die for, custard is only ok in my book, house special dim sum is excellent. The takeout side is a great value. Would definitely recommend.
author: Sam P.

description:
This is high class dining dim sum in the financial district.  Be prepared to drop $60-$70 for two people for tea service and a few dim sum dishes if you're going to be dining inside.  My favorite items are the shanghai dumplings, mango pudding, and shrimp cheung fun.  

However, if you wallet is a little on the lighter side, the Yank Sing 2 Go around the corner is pretty reasonable lunch menu for $6-$10.  You can get a dim sum plate with sui mai, hai gow, pot sticker, and egg custard tart or just order one of their daily specials over rice.
author: Cathy L.

description:
Unauthentic and pricey.  It's not that the food wasn't fresh or tasted bad....but it's very americanized and did not taste like real dim sum to me.  The place is way fancier than your typical dim sum restaurant, so I can see why it would appeal to the business-y clientele.  

As expected, it gets very hectic during lunch.   So hectic that they completely forgot about a dish we had ordered.  After reminding them about it and some apologies, it was finally brought out to us at the same time they handed us our check, and guess what?  It sucked.  And we were left regretting reminding them about it.
author: Michelle N.

description:
This dim sum restaurant is one of the better ones in the South San Francisco to San Francisco area. I've grown up going to all the good ones (really amazing dim sum does NOT exist in the bay area. I've come to that conclusion. you need to go to Hong Kong or at the very least vancouver) such as Koi Palace, Flower Lounge, Fook Yuen, Tai Wu, and Yank Sing is definitely up there with them. I felt that the food was not overly greasy/ salty or sweet. For example the charsui bao had the perfect amount of sweetness and meat. It wasn't a crazy dark red color from food coloring like most other places. and the bread was soft and not overly sweet either. Even the egg custard (dahn tat) was cooked perfectly. Many times even at the better dim sum places they over bake it and the egg turns out too rubbery and eggy tasting. I was impressed by that. And the mango pudding here is much better than the other places too. 

Definitely come here for good quality dim sum. But don't expect it to be dirt cheap compared to the take out places on clement. 

Also why would you eat out in the Fi-Ni, embarcadero area and expect it to be cheap? Every restaurant in the area is expensive.

Parking is great since they have a garage right under the restaurant.
author: Em F.

description:
Food - 5 stars- great quality, delicious 
Value - 2 stars - way too expensive 
Service 3 stars - room for improvement 

I think the prices are a little crazy.  The food is good, but it just is pricey for lunch.  It's nice once a year.
author: MJ W.

description:
Overall: B+
Take your time and read the menu so you don't waste precious belly space on fillers. Definitely some of the best dim sum I've ever had.  Definitely recommend bringing an out of town-er. 

Food: A 
Yummy chicken feet. Tasty but not overly sweet lotus seed buns. Vegetarians definitely try the snow pea leaves dumplings. For great texture and taste choose the chicken lotus shoot steamed dumplings.  

Service: A 
Patience is rewarded with food still steaming when presented. If you're western looking like me the staff will try to bombard you with the "American " options. Kinda wished I spoke Cantonese as my questions received vague answers. Guess I will just have to come back. 

Value: C 
I spent $59 on lunch for 2. It was worth it but c'mon $59 and I didn't even have a drink. 

Decor: B 
Classic business lunch spot. 'Nuff said.
author: Roger H.

description: Everything was hot and delicious.  Our favorites were the traditional dumplings and the pepper chicken.  Definitely start with a pot of tea.  This is exactly what we were looking for as our first dim sum experience.  A bit pricey but worth the money.
author: Jason K.

description:
I thought the dim sum at Yang Sing in the Rincon Center was okay.   The shrimp dumpling and the shang hai dumpling were good but otherwise; all the other dim sum were mediocre.   Service was friendly and prompt.   

I was amused how they kept pushing the more expensive plates to us like the seafood plates ($11-$17) or their specialty plates.  

I don't know spending over $25 per person for lunch on dim sum is just not my cup of tea.

I wish I could find some good dim sum in SF but I found myself thinking of Hung To in San Bruno.  *sigh*
author: pengrin ..

description: Its americanized dim-sum without many selections. I prefer city view at this point which is a bit more authentic with a larger menu.
author: andrew f.

description: Xiao long bao (4 Shanghai dumplings) is yummy!  I've never had one so juicy before-it was like there was a liquidy soup filling inside the little baos/bread.  Next we ordered walnut shrimp (8 fried shrimps covered with special mayo and a side of honey walnuts), deep fried crab puffs (2 fairly stiff crab meatballs with crab claws acting as sticks to these crab lollipops), the sesame balls with red bean filling (4), ha gao (shrimp dumplings), shu mai (pork dumpling), pot stickers, and pistachio ice cream pie (1 slice=bottom layer is likened to a soggier version of a graham cracker crust, ice cream that tasted like vanilla, second to last layer was a very thin layer of pistachio ice cream, and the whole pie slice was topped off with intensely salty pistachio).  Total of the meal came out to $126 for approximately 8 items.  Disclaimer: your tummy may be happy on account of having ingested tasty noms but your wallet will definitely be sad:/
author: P C.

description:
Thanks Charlton L., for reminding me to Yelp about this place! 

I've been to this location a few times, and to the location before they moved (or do they have two locations?). The atrium is beautiful, and the place is nice and clean. 

I love their dim sum because it's fresh and not overly greasy. This was my number one spot when my husband and I dated. The staff here is excellent as well, very professional and friendly.

Everything was great until we got our credit card number stolen a few times, and the one place that we would use it BEFORE it got stolen was here. It also happened to a friend of ours, who also frequented this place.

Needless to say, we haven't gone back since. One, because we live so far away and have kids. Two, because we're not sure if there was a shady employee but just to be safe we never went back.

As a precaution, if you dine here just don't use any flashy cards/Platinum cards/debit card/credit cards with high limits. Hope that helps.
author: Cami N.

description:
I'm going to review this place as a wedding reception area, not for the dim sum itself. Word has it that during the weekdays, it's a lunch cafeteria for businesses from the floors above and during the weekends, it's converted into a reception (courtesy of Yank Sing). 

The food itself was okay... it's your typical 9 course wedding venue meal. The service was just a-okay. (Why?) During refills of water and pouring of champagne into glasses, our waiter always seemed to forget about my (invisible) fiance. It wasn't till I said "hey Yen (I think that's his name?), can you fill his glass up too?". That's when he finally remembered we had 10 people at our table and not 9.

1) Chinese cold cuts - everything was decent. What stood out to me was the drunken cold chicken with it's slither down your throat meat in your mouth taste with a hint of wine. mmm....

2) Lobster - sorry about the poor name, I'm obviously not good with name. But for all those Chinese food loving people, it's the lobster all cut up and they have that gooey suck it sauce on it. I've always been a fan of this and Yank Sing did not disappoint.

3) Shark's Fin Soup - this is typical of all Chinese banquets. The soup was tasty, although honestly, I sometimes can't tell the difference between shark's fin and vermicilli.

4) Duck with bun - I've always loved duck... add hoisin sauce and those buns with some scallions and it's heaven in my mouth! The duck skin was nice and crispy and you couldn't taste on the fat going down your throat.

5) Fook Yin Rice - I'm honestly not a fan of this, the sauce is just a bit much for me. They had mushrooms, bamboo, celery... just a bunch of random stuff with rice and egg on the bottom.

6) Mango pudding - I love mango... I love pudding... they had little pieces of mango here and there so it was like tasting hidden treasures when eating by the spoonful.

There were probably 3 other dishes, but I forgot what it was. I really liked the "waterfall" from the ceiling, I thought that was unique. Overall, the place is cool... but it's most likely out of my range for a wedding reception area.
author: Ede S.

description:
WOW!  This place is HUGE.  I LOVE dim sum.  LOVE.  like... love love.  They took over the entire lobby of the Rincon Center including their own restaurant and people were STILL waiting.  There's also another location over a few blocks but this place was still packed an people were constantly lining up.  They have quite the selection of dim sum but what we ordered and my thoughts are below:

Shrimp har gow - yay
Pork shu mai - I don't eat pork but they're good according to others
Chinese broccoli with oyester sauce - yay
Shrimp in rice paper - ALWAYS a fan of this one
Grilled sea bass with plum sauce - Pass. Heavy but no flavor.
Egg custard - Greasy
Congi - yay

Try it out if you're in the area.  Definitely worth going to just to people watch.  Quite a scene.
author: Gina K.

description:
I'm from San Diego and my sister and I always make an effort to visit Yank Sing when we are in the City! We love their Dim Sum! 

Their service is excellent....something you are not accustomed to in a Chinese restaurant. 

Their variety of Dim Sum is amazing and the food is very good! 

I agree with some of the other reviewers that they are a little pricey but I'm willing to pay as long as the experience is good. You need to visit this place if you are a Dim Sum fan!
author: D F.

description:
Decided to finally check this place out. Nice setting! But..for the record, the Shanghai Dumplings are not all that! Not as great as everyone says they are. It's pretty pricey. The chicken feet is pretty good. The orange jello is pretty cool.

Service kinda sucks. Hard to get the attention of the people pushing the carts. There's other dim sum places that I'd rather go to before this one.

Total was a little over a hundred dollars which included tip and tax..for two of us.
author: Heather H.

description:
Every time I go to Yank Sing I get less and less aroused.  I remember the first experience I had here... Orgasmic.  Food is still delicious but I'm just not getting that high anymore.

I took a friend a couple weeks ago and we had a Tsing Tao and I picked 3 dishes and my friend picked 2.  I ordered the Signature Shanghai Dumplings (who wouldn't), Spicy String Beans (special order, they don't make them that often) and the shrimp dumplings.  My friend being her first time ordered the Spring Rolls and little bus stuffed with meat (they weren't the pork buns which are probably my fave).  Long story short with tip the bill was almost $80.  Not lovely.

I went yesterday and felt like I ordered a lot more for the same price.  I recommend the Chinese Brocolli (served cold and par-boiled with a light sauce), Fat Rice noodles with your choice of shrimp or BBQ pork ( I opted for shrimp), ordered 2 rounds of the shrimp dumplings and pork buns (buns a must with the hot yellow mustard), some tea and some Tsing Tao to flush it all down.  Solid food but I wasn't blown away.
author: Shiho F.

description:
Best Dim Sum in SF.
Hands down.

Only question is... $17 for the sea-bass??
author: M E.

description:
TOTALLY OVERPRICED but SOOO GOOD!!! Seriously, this is the best dim sum i've ever had. We paid $30 per person for lunch (they charge you ~$2 per person for tea). Typical dimsum will cost you half that and mostly with free tea. 

This is the place to go if you've never had dim sum before. It'll give you authentic delicious dimsum with non-traditional experience - clean, fast/friendly service in perfect english, and complimentary parking on weekends. Once you've developed your love for dimsum, you may develop enough courage to give REAL dimsum place a try.  You'll encounter dirty bathrooms, and unfriendly cantonese speaking only waitresses, but will still get excellent dimsum at half the price!
author: Jen K.

description:
Take 2 on Dim Sum for me, and Take 1 for the bf. We met up with another couple from grad school here for Sunday brunch, after slight confusion on where this was actually located (oh! it's in that...office building?)

Really funny (kind of) but after calling my friend to let her know we arrived, it was so massive and crowded that it took her a full 5 minutes to find us! All I could think was how much this place was raking in, profit-wise. 

We had a seat in the table set up area out there in that mall thing. It was fine, it still felt like we were part of the scene and not outcasts. The sunlight was great in there actually, I didn't mind being there at all. As far as food goes, this place had tons of veggie options - my faaaave being the green dumping - definitely get that whether or not you're a vegetarian. 

The service (if you can call it that - meaning, "service" is a bit of a misnomer at a dim sum place) was quick, efficient, and non-invasive. I had a great time here and would definitely come back...the only downside being that it was somewhat pricey.
author: Purvi R.

description: I'm Chinese and I've been going to eat Dim Sum for as long as I can remember.. The quality of the food here is good - as good as you would get at a non-Americanized dim sum place in an Asian area. However, in comparison, the prices are exorbitant. You pay for the atmosphere. I think our Shanghai Dumplings were close to $12. For two people our bill was $73 - hot tea for drink, and no desserts. In comparison, I ate at a super non-americanized dim sum place (one that does include Chinese on their menu) with my mom, dad, sister, sister's friend, and sister's dad last week for about $65 for the whole table. It isn't HORRIBLE, it's just not cheap, but the food is marvelous, and parking is validated at Rincon center garage :) They close at 3 on weekdays and 4 PM on F/Sat/Sun.
author: Sonya Z.

description:
Yank Sing was my favorite part of my visit to SF. In fact, I would gladly drive the 8 hours up the coast again this weekend or anytime! 

My husband and I went there for lunch on Valentine's Day. After about a 30 minute wait we sat down and ordered a big pot of oolong: first hurrah of the meal! The first car that passed by us seemed to be the "Fried stuff with seafood cart" - I'm jewish so I couldn't eat anything, so the wonderful girl pushing the cart made a call with her headset and had chicken egg rolls sent to our table :o) yay! They were delicious rolls of friend goodness. After that, the carts coming our way tended to be either vegetarian or chicken themed. We also really liked the mushroom dumplings, spinach, chicken and mushroom (in fact, we took two!), dried, sauteed string beans and the edamame. Not exactly chinese, but a nice way to make up for the fried goodness.  

All in all, an enjoyable afternoon!
author: Aryn F.

description:
Watch out! The dim sum is great, but make sure you ask for prices up front! Had lunch here with my brother and we ordered away. The same amount of food we usually get in San Diego place called Jasmine's costs about $40. We got the bill at Yang Sink and I'm not sure if it was because we're a bunch of white guys, but the bill was over $100!!! FOR DIM SUM!!! Must be a high rent district. 

However, the dim sum was pretty good. Nothing you couldn't find at any regular dim sum places. 

You've been warned.
author: Tony B.

description: WAY OVERPRICED and the waiters are pushy.  This place is a good place to go if you want tasty dim sum and you have 50-70 bucks to spend per person.
author: Vio H.

description:
Holy crack-a-moly Batman!  Xiao Long Bao (Shanghai style soup dumplings) are the Xiao Long BOMB at Yank Sing.  Have you ever had anything explode in your mouth that you've actually enjoyed?  Wait - never mind.  That discussion should take place in a different forum.  Let me rephrase - Have you ever had a taste explosion that was so amazing that it brought you to your knees?  

Hmmm, That wasn't much better, was it?   

Well anyway, Yank Sing's Shanghai soup dumplings are perfectly steamed pillows of delicious goodness that are filled with mouth watering pork and savory broth, accompanied with a traditional tangy, ginger infused vinegar dipping sauce.  These tender bite sized morsels are not your average run of the mill dumpling.  They are dim-sum, and then sum.  Of all the different varieties of hot and cold offerings, these are definitely the highlight.  Our party of 11 devoured steamer after steamer after steamer to the point when we began to resemble the shape of the dumplings themselves.  The cute cart pushing ladies are adept at pushing their wares much like a crack dealer - they give you one taste and BAM, you're hooked.  The only difference is that the first one ain't free.

A few other plates worth mentioning are the sio-pao (pork buns), the soft-shelled crabs, and the deep fried sea bass.  There is no trace of MSG in anything we tried and the overall quality of food is top notch.  Minus one star for high prices.  Our bill was $620 (15% gratuity was included in our bill) but hey, addictions can be expensive!  I'm writing this review a day later and my mouth is watering just thinking about their dumplings.  

They validate parking in the Rincon Center garage and they take reservations.  Go get some!
author: Ray K.

description:
The food was pretty good, but DANG, it's expensive for dim sum!  In NYC, you can get dim sum for like $2/$2.50 a plate, at Yank Sing, it's like $4/$5 for a plate.  The shao long baos are tiny and it's like $12 for 6.  Craziness.

I believe it's what would be called an up-scale dim sum experience catered to tourists :)  It's probably the nicest dim sum place I've been to in a while.  But the food was good, service is fast (traditional dim sum carts come around, AND waiters stop by with different dishes), and the place overall is pretty clean.  It's not an every weekend place to go - but for a every once in a while dim sum experience, I think it's pretty good.  And the fact that my dad - the world's pickiest eater - actually complimented the food.  That means it's REALLY good.  Haha.

Logistics - they validate parking.  This place is great for big groups.  We came around 1:30pm on a Sunday afternoon and we only waited about 15 minutes for a table.
author: Diana N.

description: Aiyah!! This place is sooooo.... expensive. I don't even want to remember what my bill came out to be just for dim sum. Although the dim sum was good. And I loved the fact that they have some items that just regular dim sum places at half the price do not have such as "deep fried sea bass wrapped with sweet potato". That dish was so different but wonderful.  They also had a crab and shrimp dumpling as well, instead of only shrimp dumplings. Unfortunately other than the specialty items, I would NEVER spent as much as I did for dim sum again. And the food was not so spectacular that it was worth the extra money. This place is so full though, full of mostly Caucasians and ABC's. But it is clean and service okay. What they need to do is get off their high horse and lower their prices. Please $10 for 2 measly pieces of cold Peking duck  with the bun. I should have shot myself for ordering it and wanting to see how it tasted for the price. :'(
author: Ms. T.

description: Food was fine, but three times the price I'd pay in chinatown. I'll take a place packed with locals where I have to share a table over this any day of the week.
author: Dan F.

description:
This was one of the best dim sum experiences we had so far in point of taste, freshness, service and ambiance. But THE worst in point of price. We never mind to pay extra for the quality of the experience, BUT to charge $12.95 for 2 small pieces of duck, or $10.95 for 4 small sesame balls or the plate of noodle rolls is REALLY outrageous.  Having said that I would still go there when in SF, but be more careful  about what I order. The duck wasn't worth even the standard  $6.95 they charge in other places for a quarter of it, as well as Snow pea and Spinach dumplings.
That's why I give 4 ** instead of 5.
author: Tatyana M.

description:
Best Dim Sum I have ever had. 
Food- very fresh and attention to detail.
Service- spectacular.
Restaurant- Nice.
Can't wait for September when I can eat this delicious food once again!!!!
author: nadia w.

description: $86 for dim sum?!  For two?!  Seriously?  I was shocked that we only had 8 items off the cart... 2 buns, 2 shrimp dumplings, 1 potsticker, 1 pork dumpling, 1 crab claw and 1 mango pudding.  On average one order of dim sum was $10.50.  It should be a third of that!  It's not like the food was any better than any other dim sum we've had at other establishments.  Feels like they have the "gotcha" factor with all the hotel guests and tourists in the area.  Avoid the wallet shock and find the same cuisine at a better price point.
author: Jackie O.

description:
Would be 3 stars if the prices were more reasonable.  I've been here a couple times before but never really noticed how high the prices were.  Maybe I happened to have ordered a bunch of less expensive items before.  But I recently came here with my parents and my wife, and the bill knocked us all out.  There were only four of us, but the bill was more like for a party of twelve.  The food was mediocre at best although the service was top notch for a dim sum restaurant.

I guess the fact that we were here on a weekday might have made a difference in terms of the quality of the food and the speed of the service.  They know they have to get diners fed in under an hour so people can go back to work.  The moment we sat down all the food carts came screaming towards us and loaded our table with food.  The cart pushers will say thank you even if you don't want anything from their cart, unlike most dim sum places where they will give you the evil eye.  However, the cost of having all the food items available right away means they're not all fresh from the steamer.  Some items were cold and others had the dry, sticky rice noodle skin from being out of the steam for too long.

I can't justify ever coming back again.  There are way too many other options that are much easier on the wallet.
author: Paul M.

description:
This used to be one of my absolute favs but the last two times I ate there - its outstanding quality and service slipped big time. Frustrating and disappointing when you rely on consistency and find it absent. I do still get whitecaps on my drool thinking about those Duck wraps....mmm but they were cold and chewy my last visit and when you are paying $$$$ you want the best. 
Oh well, people change so maybe Yank Sing can.
author: Lostin Thought A.

description: I don't care how expensive this place is, it's delicious and consistent.
author: Mark G.

description:
#97. Big Eat SF list: Sesame balls

(not sure if I cheated by going to the "express" version at work, but it's the same food...)

pro's = 
quick
i don't like sesame stuff, but I liked this!

cons = 
crazy heavy/oily (probably where the extra flavor comes from...)
unexpected a la carte prices... order of (2) sesame balls + (3) potstickers & (3) dumpling =$10+
author: S V.

description: Great dim sum but watch out -- your bill can add up VERY quickly!!!
author: Dave K.

description:
So there's this yelper named Nish N.  I guess he's sort of a big deal in yelpland, since he's like, yelpJesus, but resurrected for the umpteenth time, which makes him even cooler.

When I awoke this morning (looking pretty, but reeking of cheap champagne and even cheaper beer) I was a dim sum virgin.  Me, a virgin? *snort*  Hard to believe, right?!  Well, it's a little less far-fetched when you consider that my hometown only had one Chinese person, and he was adopted.

Anyway, Nish said, "Eat at Yank Sing," and so I did.  Not just because I'm a follower, but because he's yelpJesus. 

As followers in yelpJesus, my friend and I headed to Yank Sing, and, after a minimal wait, were escorted to a small table.  All of a sudden, carts were flying past us.  It was the coolest!  I felt like a kid who'd just been kicked out of fat camp and was ready to rebel.  Chicken buns, dumplings, and spicy chicken - oh my!

I was lucky to be there with a dim sum expert, or else I would have grabbed way too much food.  Fortunately, he helped me pace myself and explained what each dish was.

The bill was a little pricey.  Even split between 2, we each paid $45 for lunch.  But, since I haven't eaten a big meal in awhile, it was worth it.

Amen.  And dim sum.
author: Janney B.

description:
Arguably the best dim sum in San Francisco, so that would make it the best in North America.  

When their old location on Battery Street was condemned for new building construction, they set up in Rincon Annex and provided a shuttle service, so the bankers could continue to enjoy their top-quality Hong Kong cuisine.  Let me say that again:  a shuttle service!  

That's a bit of history for you.  What about today?  My friend was smarter than I, and remembered to phone in a reservation, so we were seated instantly.  The endless parade of dim sum carts still marches on, and for Chinese food it's remarkably clean.  We were just there for lunch, and had to restrain ourselves from picking everything that came by.  Fortunately, my smart friend also had her lunch already imagined, and was also unafraid to tell them what she wanted.  Some of it wasn't on the carts, so one of the cart waitresses called the kitchen on her intercom and ordered it for us.  On the first try the order was wrong -- no problem.  They just sold it to another table in the cart parade, and made what my friend was asking for.  

About a dozen dim sum for two, and tea, came to about $55.  If you want something besides dim sum, they also have a menu.  

It doesn't get any better than that!
author: David D.

description:
Fresh, abundant, delicious. 

It was a little expensive, but we're not going every Sunday.  

Pace yourself, and the cost might be less of a blow.  Say "no" and don't worry, more food will keep being offered.  

This was easily as good as dim sum I've had in Asia.
author: D J.

description:
Dim sum is very creative and delicious......Yank Sing offers outstanding food and ambience.

Excellent Dim Sum with a very Americanized taste....
author: Raider J.

description: I've eaten here twice now and both times were great experiences.  The first time we eat lunch in the dining area with a large group of coworkers.  Today I tried the take out part and was thoroughly impressed.  They have box options all of which are very reasonable.  I ordered a bbq pork bun, chow mien, a potsticker and an egg roll.  Basically every favorite Chinese dish I like!  All that cost $6.50.  What a deal for that part of SF.  All of the food was really good and they are super quick.  There's probably 10 small incredibly fast working people back there because the food was out in probably 30 seconds.  There's a bunch of tables out front for you to eat your take out and they even have heat lamps.  Looking forward to my next trip back to Yank Sing already and I'm still full from this trip!
author: Brian G.

description:
if people ask me where to go for dim sum, the first place that comes to mind is Yank Sing.  Yank Sing is the "King of Dim Sum".  

you can sit inside or outside; i prefer outside because it's got a huge ceiling and a waterfall - it's relaxing.  it's a great place to have dim sum on the weekends although they are open on the weekdays for the financial district crowd.  i don't know about the parking situation on the weekdays, but on the weekends, you can get validated for parking underground.  i always have to have their signature dish - "siu long bao", and the "mushroom gao" whenever i go there.  so yummy!  actually, I can say without shame that i can scarf down at least  'three orders of each'  of those all by my lovely self, that's how good they are!  it's seriously making me HONGRY now!!!  

the atmosphere is inviting; the service is top-notch (friendly & personable), and the food is superb!  and as fergie would say, "check it out".
author: Paulina C.

description:
Pretty good dim sum, but for the price???  I have had just as good in a few hole in the wall places in SF.
Upside:  the area is nice...good locale
author: K S.

description:
I, like Grace K, do not care how much this place costs, it is worth it every time.

They know that they're famous for their Xiao Long Bao (Shanghai Dumplings or soup dumplings) and they always seem to find a way to roll their infamous cart up to you first. Just say, "Two please." Trust me. One just isn't enough since it truly is the best dish, but I haven't had anything bad. 

The duck, the Chinese broccoli, shrimp and leek dumplings... the chrysanthemum tea. It's all wonderful. The quality is like no place else. I always find "parts" in dumplings from anywhere but here. If you don't like parts, appreciate cleanliness and friendly staff, it is worth the price.

But it's the Xiao Long Bao that I will keep returning for again and again and again no matter what the price. I love you, Yank Sing.
author: Amy D.

description: Shanghai Soup dumplings are my favorite items here by far.  Everything else is good, but these little bites of heaven are the reason to come.  Yes, it is expensive, but it is worth the money because it is delicious.
author: Katharine A.

description:
Yank Sing was my introduction to deem sum cuisine some ten years ago, when I was introduced to FiDi as a young ingenue in a law firm.  Then, it was still on Battery, with the little valet table out front, and long lines.  I remember going down to the basement and this wonderful little cart came around with all sorts o' goodies, and I was hooked.  I've had bad, mediocre, and pretty good sum dim since, but Yank Sing has always remained the feather in the hat.

Today it did not disappoint.  My favorite dish had to be this make-your-own-spoomful-of-soup deelio that was just awesome.  She instructed us to poke our chopsticks into the flesh of the little deemy sum, extracting the juice, which then filled the soup spoon.  Then we added a little red vinegar with sliced ginger in it before the bite made its way to the mouth.  It was heaven.  I could go and order JUST that.  Also great today were the seabass and what I like to call the Peking Duck taco, filled with a little hoisin and shredded onion.  Fab-u.

Service was quick, and we were able to order stuff that we saw on other carts that passed us by telling the nearest caddy, who in turn radioed her position on her Secret Service-like ear piece.  I mean, shit, that kind of technology just for summy dimmy needs a star all itw own.

Price for three, including one Diet Coke: $120 including tip.
author: Tamar D.

description: overpriced white people touristy dim sum.
author: Lin Lin S.

description:
Away from Chinatown and in the Financial District.

Expensive, yes. Great quality, fresh, dim sum, yes. Impressive service, yes.

If I had lots of money, this would be my first choice when going out for dim sum. Its worth it, but I will save spending the cash there only for special occasions.

They have a special dim sum that is filled with broth and is quite tastey. Full of Umami!
author: Roseabelle M.

description:
You can get the exact same dim sum at a China Town for way cheaper. 

I'm not one of those quantity over quality types. But damn, $10-20 for just a plate of dim sum is a little ridiculous especially if you know you can get it somewhere else for way cheaper and it tastes the same, if not better.

The restaurant is real nice, nothing like your ordinary tryin to be fancy Chinese restuarant. I would recommend this place if you're trying to impress your in-laws or you want to be fancy for a day and have a nice somewhat expensive lunch

I wouldn't mind going back again.... just as long as im not paying
author: Karen T.

description: Our family had Dim Sum lunch at Yang Sing today. I was extremely disappointed! I felt I was in at playground instead of a high-end restaurant. There were kids yelling and screaming from the top of their lungs. The manager didn't seem to care. When I made reservations in advance, I specifically asked for a table inside the actual restaurant. The receptionist noted it. The management did not honor my request upon our arrival. The dim sum was cold. Our plates were not replaced. Very noisy atmosphere. One would definitely expect more paying over $100.00 for a family of four.
author: Susie L.

description:
I went to yank sing this weekend with a group of nine friends... would highly recommend it with a large group of people because you get to try a bit of everything. i thought the food was really really delicious. everything was hot and served fresh, and didn't seem like it had been travelling around on the carts for hours. 

my main reason i felt compelled to write this review is for the service. the staff here is was totally attentive and very kind. having worked in the restaurant industry for years, I can appreciate good service and this was it. i will definitely return here again...
author: Ellen S.

description: This place has a hella good dim sum. I ate a lot of chinese foods back at home and this restaurant tastes just like back at home. The service is fast as there are Chinese ladies bringing you trays constantly and offering you new foods. Word of advice from me is that don't come at lunch hours, either come earlier or later cause it gets hella crowded here. The place is clean and i am always full in this place. Overall, really satisfied in this place. My only concern is that the price may be a little too expensive. But other than that......hen hao!
author: Cavin T.

description: We went to Rincon at brunch time on Sunday.  It was outstanding.  Do not miss the soup dumplings, whatever you do.  The shrimp in every incarnation was perfectly prepared.  We special ordered the minced chicken in lettuce cups, and it was worth the wait.  The only thing that was not perfection itself was the Peking Duck, which we were really looking forward to.  (If you want that, go to Peking Duck Restaurant in Palo Alto.  Amazing.)  No complaints at all, and total respect that they can do such a great job serving *all those people* (they have the whole inner court of Rincon Center, as well as the restaurant itself) at the same time.  I can't imagine what the kitchen must be like.
author: Elise Ann W.

description:
