I've only been here once, but I thought my visit here was memorable.  The place was relatively clean for a dim sum restaurant.  Their service was good compared to other dim sum restaurants, but you can't and shouldn't compare it to other regular dining restaurants.

Although I don't eat Asian cuisine often, I thought their food was good.  Every bite left a nice aroma in my mouth.  I especially enjoyed the dumplings.  There were other items that I enjoyed, but I'm not even sure what they are called.  Their food wasn't cold like what other reviews stated. 

There is "outdoor" seating outside the restaurant in the atrium of the building .  However, I don't think it is that scenic because of the surrounding buildings.

I enjoyed my visit to this restaurant.  However, the wait was a little too long.  In addition, I can understand why some people are griping about the prices...It can get expensive.
author: John N.

description: Maybe I am being a bit harsh with the 2 stars vs 3 stars, but I was extremely disappointed with Yank Sing. I heard rave reviews from magazines and Yank Sing consistently gets recognition from food critics, so when a friend was visiting from out of town, I decided to take her there. In fact, my friend's father who lives in Philadelphia told her about Yank Sing as well. After arriving and looking at the clientele, I realized the patrons of Yank Sing are generally not the kind of people who would appreciate authentic, cheap, delicious dim sum. It's fancy interior is further augmented by the high prices on the menu and I felt there is sort of a see-and-be-seen social scene in the restaurant. After getting over my initial impressions of the place, after the food arrived, my friend who is not Chinese, specially pointed out how mediocre the dim sum was. I felt bad since she was visiting and did not get a better dim sum experience. I will not likely come back again. There are better places for dim sum in the city that are also more reasonable in price.
author: Kai C.

description: Ok dim sum in a convenient SOMA location. Restaurant critics and Zagat have been heaping praise on Yank Sing. My feeling is that the food is overhyped, being mostly standard dim sum fare. The service however, was perfection itself, and the restaurant is nicer than your typical chinese place. So as the other Yelpers said (you can read more reviews under the other location), it's a solid choice when your looking for a comfortable place for a meal with the 'rents or other out-of-towners. This place does draw big crowds, so call ahead to make a reservation and you won't run into trouble.
author: Jeremy S.

description: With the other great dim sum restaurants in the city, I'm surprised this one is so popular. The food is just-ok, and the prices are way too much for the quality of the food. I have better luck trying anywhere along Geary St.
author: Steve L.

description:
Oh damn, them lil' Siu Loung Baos (Shanghai Dumpling?) are great. Let's get another. Cool, everything is bite sized, let's get more. This dim sum is pretty good. Not as greasy as other places. Let's get some more! 

(Check comes) Hot damn! $130 for three people at dim sum. I've never heard of that. I'm not sure, but I think Koi Palace and HK Flower Lounge aren't as expensive for dim sum. They sure do trick you with those lil' things. 

Oh how worlds change when money comes into play. I'm no cheap bastard, I'll pay for good food, and yes the food is great. But people, dim sum isn't meant to be this expensive! Take it from this chinese dude! But I have a feeling I'll be back one day. I feel so conflicted...
author: Al L.

description:
Um, can we be more innovative at upwards of $10/plate for dim sum?  The food tasted fresh, but I was expecting much more.  The dumplings and other selections were routine.  I realize that we are paying for a sterile environment here (for those afraid of hole-in-the-wall Chinatown establishments), but that doesn't have to mean boring.  The hot sauce is the only thing that saves it from being only 2 stars.  

If I'm ever going to drop this amount of money on dim sum again (I'm talking $70 for two people), it will be at Kirin Restaurant in Vancouver, Canada.  They know innovative, tasty bites.
author: kat s.

description:
I'm sure there are some great items here but c'mon let's face it...

* Insanely high prices for the quality. Maybe for the same price you could eat happily at even Koi Palace with a little more leftover for extra items. This is downtown SF, but also they know tourists and dim summers (aka the foodies) come here in droves no matter what. High end sushi bar prices for dim sum? They better be serving high end seafood themed items, like abalone and scallop siu mai, but uhhh nope! Standard fare...

* Most shillers of this place are non Chinese and Americanized Chinese people. Heck even the restaurant makes fun of them. Yank Sing, as in all yanks sing praises (or shills). The correct pronounciation of the Cantonese name is Yeung Sing (downward tone).

* Very cramped spaces. Maybe this would fly in Hong Kong but even then the experience in HK is way better.

* I think I found canned corn in my siu mai / shumai. WTF. I can appreciate creativity but they did it all wrong. Finding corn in siu mai is almost as bad as finding one in the toilet bowl. I don't need or want corn in my siu mai, please, and no thanks.

3 stars, mostly because this place is overhyped. -1 star for the attitude of the shillers (not yelpers, the shillers on the other foodie sites).

Perhaps the only place that was better than YS was Harbor Village that was true to its spirit, an official branch of the HK Tsui Hang Village, but sadly they're gone.
author: Ken K.

description:
The dim sum menu and pictures looked very tempting on their website and I decided to give this place a try as I was planning a visit to the Ferry Building. I love the fountain/water feature in the Rincon Center where Yank Sing is based.

One general observation is that in the USA, people seem to eat lunch very early and restaurants seem to open early as a result. Or maybe it's the fashion for brunch over in the USA?

The restaurant was already 1/4 full when I arrived at 11am and it filled up briskly. They are clearly catering to the upper end of the market with some nice decor, waitresses pushing the carts who all spoke good English and nice lace settings. The Chinese tea also arrived in a futuristic looking teapot, a first for me in all my travels.

There is good trolley service here and waitresses also wander around with trays of special dishes to try and tempt you. The old favourites are all available but Yank Sing does try to push out the dim sum boundaries by daring to innovate new dishes.

Overall, the dim sum was very tasty and the sizing of portions are generous. In fact, I had to persuade them that I only wanted 4 siu long bao as I was dining on my own, not the 8 on the tray.

I'm taking a star off as I think that the prices are quite steep for dim sum even if the restaurant is nicely done up.
author: Yee Gan O.

description:
Well... I had dim sum up on Sac & Kearny a few weeks back and I can't tell the difference between that place and this one.  Today's meal was identical to Sac & Kearny, which cost us $68 after tip for four adults.  Today's cost was $93 after tip for TWO adults.

Fuzzy math? Is dim sum not for me?

My take on this kind of food is that it tastes like it was cooked a week ago and held in steam warmers until I arrived.

Love the husband and all ... but when he caught the amount of the bill he casually slid it aross the table to me.  Chump.
author: Michael O.

description: At Yank Sing 2 Go, combination lunch specials start at $4.85 for some of the Bay Area's most acclaimed dim sum. There are two locations nearby, but I much prefer the Rincon Center location where you can sit inside the nicest food court in San Francisco. Be sure to check out the WPA murals in the lobby of the former post office.
author: Kathleen M.

description:
+ really good dim sum

- overpriced
- overhyped
- stuffy
- nothing you couldn't find in san francisco or even (gasp) oakland china town for a fraction of the price
author: Ahu S.

description:
One of my favorite dim sum places.  Great selection, good service.  A bit pricey, to be sure, but that comes with the territory.  It is sometimes hard to summon the Pekin duck lady, but if you keep asking, she will eventually appear, bearing delicious duck and plum sauce, ready for dip&fold enjoyment.

Desserts are a bit more hit and miss.  Frankly, no need to worry, because if you're working at it at all, you'll be stuffed to the gills before you have time to think about dessert.
author: Ben P.

description:
I've been to Yank Sing twice - both for special occasions:

1) Jim C.'s (see: ) Post Bachelor Party Dim Sum
2) My mom-in-law's US Naturalization Celebration.  

With 385 other reviews, I'm not sure I can add much nor do I plan to read them all.  My highlights?  

1)  Outstanding Friendly Service
2)  Clean Banquet/Dining Facilities
3)  Excellent Fresh Quality

Yank Sing's food is very good and the ambiance surpasses many of the Dim Sum places I've patronized. 

I'm tempted to only give Yank Sing 3 Stars, simliar to Ed U's funny review.  +1 STAR for representing the Best of Dim Sum in the Bay Area for us who are non-native Chinese.
author: James G.

description:
D*elicious.

I*nsistent waitstaff- I felt like I was breaking up with them every time we turned their choices down. But they were always present and quickly cleaned up the glass that dropped behind my friend's head. 

M*eh about the seating; cool to be in the open lobby with waterfall and sun shining down, but if it was a weekday and tons of people were walking around, I wouldn't want them judging me on how I miss my mouth every time I bring food to it. That judging should be reserved for friends only.


S*omewhat overpriced. Yes it was good, but I don't think it was THAT good. There are places in the Outer Richmond that are 85-90% this quality and way cheaper. 

U*pset that this is Yo Yo Ma's favorite place in SF, yet he wasn't here to play for us (well, according to the posters across town that list favorite spots in SF. Who knows if this is really his favorite spot. Maybe it's Trader Sam's). 

M*aking us wait until our whole party showed up, even when we had 6 out of 7 people? Not cool, Yank Sing. Not cool.
author: Jared S.

description:
Wah?
Huh?
White tablecloth dimsum?

No aggressive little chinese ladies throwing garlic spareribs, tripe, & chicken feet on your table despite your protests as they pretend that  they don't understand that  you're saying no?

Damn it. I'm too oldschool, I guess. I like my dimsum kinda ghetto.  Yanksing is definitely not ghetto.
And I suppose if Ghetto is not your style, then you can go ahead and take your friends/family scared of *real* chinese dimsum eats & eating experiences there.

Ghetto dimsum is where there are loads of families stacked around a table, carts running amok, a cacaphony of conversations & plates clattering on tables, having to share a table with strangers because the place is packed, and when you're done, they fricking just FOLD up the table cloth of paper placemats and stains instead of being all civilized and crap.

*That* is how I prefer *my* dimsum.
author: Min Jung K.

description:
REALLY good Dim Sum, also REALLY expensive. We were so surprised to get a check for over 100 dollars for two people to have brunch, but it was great.
For all you who claim this isn't authentic or it's geared towards a western palate, I have to disagree, I go to Hong Kong, Guangdong and Shenzhen twice a year for several years and find the food comparable on the whole.
It's more Hong Kong style than American for sure. I love the shrimp with mayonnaise and walnuts.
author: doug c.

description:
This was my first trip to Yank Sing (just moved to the Bay area a couple of months ago) and I came here for yum cha/dim sum. I give this restaurant 3 stars. Break down is below:

Food, 4 stars: Their siu long bao (or xiao long bao) were excellent and it was cool that you could get Peking Duck during yum cha. The rest of the dim sum were also pretty decent.

Service, 4 stars: Friendly and clean.

Price, 1 star: It's day light robbery! I've had yum cha every single weekend since I was a little girl. Usually for 2 people, we spend anywhere between $25 - $35 depending on city, restaurant, how much food we order. Our bill at Yank Sing came to $79!! Just because of the price, I don't think I'll be coming back here. I would consider this place for a Chinese wedding banquet (bai jou.)
author: Hannah W.

description:
First of all, let me say I hope all you people giving this place rave reviews aren't San Francisco natives.  If you are, shame on you; you should know better.  I'm a white girl from the Bay Area suburbs and even I know that the cheapest and best (did I mention cheap?) Dim Sum comes from little hole-in-the-wall places in the heart of Chinatown.  

The food at Yank Sing is great.  It's wonderful.  I have no complaints about the food.  But is ABSOLUTELY NO BETTER than the food you can find in Chinatown.  Lunch for two at Yank Sing: over $90.  That, in my opinion, is not acceptable.  Maybe Dim Sum used to be the food of nobles, but in this day in age when you can get a piece of killer Dim Sum for .75 cents, charging that much is nothing short of sin.  If you're a tourist with a big budget, knock yourself out; the food is good, the service is good, the atmosphere is decent, the bill is astronomical.  Let your wallet be ass raped.  If you want to take my advice, however, go on an adventure to Chinatown.  Just find the place with the most people in it and I guarantee you'll have more amazing Dim Sum than you can eat for about 20 bucks.  Walk to Union Square and make a picnic out of it.  Trust me, that will beat Yank Sing any day.  

P.S.  They did, however, have some kick ass green tea.  Yum.
author: X S.

description:
Actually my 2nd time here and food is still first rate.  The first time was OUT of THIS WORLD GOOD (2003).  This time, a bit different.  Atmosphere still nice.  Clientele professional, and a lotta hakujeans.  But gone are the massive lines and crowds.  Zero waiting.  I think its the recession and the higher prices.  Had all the standard dim sum fare.  Portions are smaller than SO CAL Dim Sum Houses, but still very very good.  MSG is masked better.  Dim Sum isnt slopped on a messy dish like So Cal.  Everything is petite, clean, and plated very clean.  Xiao Long Baos were very good.  Not sure what the best one is, but these were particularly tasty.  Again, nice acryllic tea pots.  

In the end, I wanted to treat the family to sunday brunch.....YOWZA... $215 plus tax and tip.  My anus is still quite red from that one.   Can you YANK MY SING anymore you sneaky carnivorous suckers!?!?!?!!!!  You got me good...you shit!!.. Scorecard:  Yank Sing:  1     Me:  1
author: Shon T.

description:
The service at this Stevenson St. dim sum restaurant is above par for the others in the Financial District. The dim sum is great, and the place is as spotless as your bathroom. Speaking of bathrooms, even that was a good experience here.

Why the three stars? Besides the outrageous price, the dim sum servers are very pushy, and if you attempt to order a salad from the menu, the odds are so against you, that you feel like an amputee swimmer stuck in rapids swimming upstream.  :O
author: Daniel C.

description: I think one of the best dim sum places I've eaten and I've eaten in many dim sum restaurants throughout the United States as well as abroad.  The xiao long bao was perfect with it's juiciness and taste.  The other dim sum items like har gao, shu mai, shrimp crepes, pork ribs, tofu rolls, etc. were delicious!  The service is good too.  The servers kept stopping by and offered their dishes.  The waiter kept the water refilled as well as the 7-Up.  A must if you are in SF.
author: Jim W.

description: Really nice place and ambiance. Its kinda bait and switch. They start off strong then kind of fizzle out. It's like a high class assembly line, the way the food comes around. It was a different experience. I believe this was a dim sum style restaurant. Not sure if this is how all of them operate, or if this was exclusive to here.  They roll around with carts, like at fine restaurants with the dessert carts, but instead of dessert, it's dim sum, which was cool, but be careful because you will rack up a nice size bill. You get excited because you just wanna try it all. There was quite a bit of waste because there were quite a few items that looked amazing but did not taste amazing. So I would suggest being very strategic in your ordering. Also ask for only a half order of what you want because they may have 4 pieces of something on the plate, and you may only want 2 pieces. If you don't tell them they will give you the whole order and you pay for the whole order, but be quick about it, cuz before you know it, they have dropped, marked, and ran. Marked means as you order they mark this"tab" that stays on your table as you get sucked up in the vortex of all these choices floating around the room. Ultimately, it was worth the experience. Would I visit them again while in SF??? Probably not. Check it out though.
author: ANGELA J.

description: Very expensive dim sum. About 3x the normal price. However, the wide variety they had was pretty impressive. Spinach and soup dumplings were awesome and new to me. Not something we have in Houston. 4 stars for being cleaner than the venues in Chinatown and because the staff speaks English-definitely convenient. Good experience,  good dimsum. Price though, I must say, made me cry a little.
author: Choi C.

description:
Their food was delicious. The sticky buns were sticky and had a crispy dough (can't stand when it is under cooked). We had the house specialty- the Shanghai dumplings, super yum. If you haven't had these before, let the waiter show you how to eat them, it's helpful and fun to know. I was impressed when the "fried" cart went by and the waiter said she wanted to get us "fresher" pot stickers as they weren't "hot" enough. I don't know if they were or not, she wouldn't let us have them, so I was thankful for her judgment. 
The reason I'm not giving it all 5 stars is because the service was overwhelming. As soon as we sat down, menus were slapped down in front of us at the same time as someone offering us drinks and two cart - servers wanted to give us dim sum. I was still catching my breath before I got to look around, put down my purse, smile at my husband, etc. They were fast- yeah ok, I know I'm in the lunch-in-an-hour section of the city- but man, I'd like to think about my drink selection before getting bombarded with food. Look out! :-)
author: Monica A.

description:
I refrained from eating at this place for years because people kept saying it was "too americanized chinese food" meaning - if you were asian, you wouldn't like it.

OMG - why did I hold out for so long! maybe I am too "americanized" cause I love this place. I'm used to dimsum places being semi clean but this place was clean! in addition, the wait staff did not try to force plates on my table. - which is a huge plus!

the SHANHAI DUMPLINGS are SO good.  I can order 3 orders of those ( only cause i won't pay over 35 bucks on dumplings) . ottherwise I can eat them all day.

If you think ur dish is a too cold, they will heat it up for you. I think overall, the place was good and the service is good. I've been there about 10 times now and each time was consistent. 

Unfortunately, the other thing that is consistent is the price. It is pretty pricey. $80-100 dollars on brunch is pretty steep. If you are cheap, go elsewhere.,
author: Anna T.

description: noisy and crowded at lunch time. but it has the best dim sum in S.F.  used to eat there in the late 1970's when I worked in the city.  took my wife for lunch Aug 15, 2014 and the food was as good as I remember  from35 years ago.  really enjoyed it,
author: Bernard G.

description: Who doesn't like dim sum? Well...i LOVE dimsum. You will not know the difference between good quality and bad quality dimsum unless you've experienced and have eaten at many many restaurants. Let me start off by saying this place is expensive but would you rather eat old stale dimsum, or fresh high quality dimsum? Your pick. I personally rather go all out and make my stomach and mouth happy. I've had some experience with bad food so I dont like to put a price on what I eat. I do not want to end up with a tummy ache later...haha. This place is very busy for lunch, lots of business people come here especially those who work around the downtown area and I'm not sure about dinner. But there is only street parking, and some valet parking around the corner. Their xiao long bao were sooooooooooooooooooo gooood. Hehe time to come back soon.
author: Colette P.

description:
Yank Sing, aka Yank Your Money, is the most overrated dim sum house on the planet.  It would be one thing if their dim sum were good, but it isn't.  I don't know of any Chinese person with half their dignity who would claim this place as having any decent dim sum.  They keep making it on the Chronicle's top 100 list and it just floors me!!  Come on!!  And you white folks who vote for it should really know better by now!  I could understand if you were from the Midwest and didn't know any better.  But anybody who's lived in the Bay Area or lived in San Francisco for a good amount of time should know better.

And the prices??  OUTRAGEOUS!!!  Save your money and make a trip up to C-Town or out to Clement Street for dim sum that is not only delicious, but it won't cost you an arm and a leg.  

Do not, I repeat, DO NOT, waste your time eating here.
author: Gordon A.

description: As good as any Hong Kong eatery. Pork kurabuto dumpling is delicious!
author: Bill K.

description: Spendy, but awesome.  The baked pork rolls are now one of my favorite foods of all time.
author: David H.

description:
review is for dim sum only. ..

+ :  nice ambiance with comfy Asian~y bistro chairs. .. nice tea pots and blooms and leaves. .. best Shanghai dumplings yet both in taste, construction and sauce. .. shrimp dumpling and pork ribs were also good. .. service is real good. .. appears to be a well-run establishment. ..

- :  poor price performance. .. some inconsistency in the yummy~ness of dim sum items: some real good, some iffy. ..
author: Y I L I W.

description:
If you want to pay a lot of money for mediocre dim sum, this is the place to go.  Indeed, as some Yelpers have said, the place is nice and more on the swanky side when it comes to dim sum restaurants, but what this place has in decor lacks in flavor when it comes to food.  

If you're not after ambiance and seek great flavored dim sum, walk a few blocks and try Great Eastern in Chinatown.  You'll get at least twice as much food and I hear their chicken feet taste better (but I can't vouch for that).
author: Annalynn C.

description:
Yank Sing is pretty damn good. 

If you are looking for CHEAP dim sum, why are you HERE?? You should be in Chinatown, sitting on a waddly three legged chair, listening to crying babies and slurping grandmothers. You'll get cheap there. You'll also get a large filthy aquarium in the front and a bird cemetery in the back. 

To avoid all this nonsense, suck it up and go to Yank Sing. Great lunch place all around:  "Rovery radies" come around with "dericious crab craws" with dipping sauce. If you happen to catch their eye, you'll get in front of you whatever it is they're peddling, whether you want it or not. Your card will be stamped and she'll be gone like a gust of August wind. So remember, NO EYE CONTACT. Also, don't feel rushed when ordering: they really make you feel like you have 1 second to make a decision or else.....or else what? They leave? Another cart is right around the corner.

Recommendations:
"Oh, crab craws"
"Oh, shitake chicken dumplin"
"Oh, warnut prawn"
"Oh, bake seabass"

Oh, fuck I'm full and in need of a nap!
author: Carrie R.

description:
Some people believe this is a "honky"-biased experience (Yank/ee Sing hehe)... well I think a bit different. I was introduced to this restaurant by some Asian imports from China, Taiwan and Hong Kong- they all suggested it's pretty authentic, taste-wise. My sweet girlfriend, who happens to be a beautiful Asian woman, also seemed to like it here. We weren't raving about it, but definitely see Yank Sing as a higher level Dim-Sum experience than most places in LA / Monterey Park / Rosemead, Walnut, etc. areas... :) Bummer, I wish there was a more upscale Dim-Sum restaurant that is a bit closer to where I live!!!

We agree it's on the expensive side, though. The places in Monterey Park and Rosemead are so much cheaper- here you must have a considerable budget to afford the otherwise super good Shanghai pork dumplings with vinegar and ginger, and all other goodies.

One thing we appreciate about this restaurant (especially this location): unlike many other Dim-Sum restaurants, this one has a bit more attractive visual presentation... While I wouldn't call it a marvel of interior design decoration, it is very clean, bright and even cosy. Very few Kantonese restaurants that I know can be designated as cosy- so this is a real achievement...
author: Miki M.

description:
Love the Shanghai dumplings (Xiao Long Bao), love the sea bass.  But $20 for each steamer basket of  Shanghai dumplings?!  Ridiculous!!!

We have been going to Yank Sing for years, and I could never figure out how our bill was either $80-90 for two or $120-130 for three, until our last visit (1/16/09), when I let my son indulge his fondness for the Shanghai dumplings and figured out how much they were costing me. Yikes!

I think Yank Sing is a great introduction to dim sum for those who might be a little squeamish about ... Chinatown, let's say.  The ambiance is nice, the food trolleys usually arrive promptly, and the staff is polite and helpful.  I do think the service has been lagging a bit. The last couple of times we've been there, it's taken forever to get our check.
author: Marjorie P.

description:
i'm use to the dirty hole in the wall dim sum places in little saigon. so when i saw that it was a white linen dim sum joint i was thinking in my head "it must cost a pretty penny" ...and it sure did. luckily i went here with three of my peoples and we got to try a good amount of things without going broke. 

i remember ordering at least 6 different dishes but the only ones i remember are the fried wontons (good), chicken feet (from what my amigas said it was decent) and the soup dumplings. The dumplings are delicious! the wrapper is thin but not too fragile so you can easily pick up the dumpling without breaking it. 

service was better than most chinese places. we went on a friday at 11 (right when they opened) and 30 minutes later the place was packed! so i totally recommend leaving ample time on the weekends cause i can only imagine how horrendous the wait would be.
author: Hang N.

description: great crab pork soup dumpling, but very pricey in general for what it offers.
author: Rebecca C.

description: Went to this place for lunch one of the few days we spent in SF on the recommendation of Raider J.  It was easy enough to find, located off the food court.  Love the tea, it was perfect a rainy, cold afternoon.  We ordered a bunch of things, the highlights for me were the steamed pork buns, and steamed pork dumplings.  Everything also was fresh and hot as well.
author: Sascha M.

description:
Somebody get me a needle and thread...I am bursting at the seams after dim sum at Yank Sing.  

So, what did we end up getting:
pork shumai
mushroom dumplings
green spinach dumplings
pork buns (we saw a toddler waving one in a chubby hand while waiting for the table and couldn't resist)
fried chicken
shrimp toast (yum, more fried food!)
dumplings with soup in it
mango pudding
egg custard (their crust is great...flaky, more like pastry crust than tart crust).

Two noteworthy points: the other Yank Sing near New Montgomery has more options.  Also, dim sum at Yank Sing is almost always more expensive than dim sum in Richmond or Sunset.

That said, it makes me happy to eat a big and long lunch while stuck working on President's Day while so many other people are taking a holiday...sort of a mini holiday.   But their egg custards are so delicious that they alone constitute a break from the banal.
author: Sooj O.

description:
Oh my!
Not knowing how much the cost of dim sum was, this place is pretty $$$$$!  It's delicious but not worth spending $5 - $10 for small dim sum entrees!

Great service and nice decor if it's your first time and want a nice upscale dim sum.  If anything, I rather go chinatown for dim sum... :)
author: A M.

description:
I ONLY...ONLY come to Yank Sing if I'm craving dim sum like crazyyyyyyyyy at work. Chinatown is a bit too far to go there and come back in 1 hour and get tasty dim sum, so I'll settle for Yank Sing's awesomely expensive dim sum. You can order from their to-go counter or sit down and eat with a few coworkers.

All the dishes are probably double of what you'll normally pay at a true traditional dim sum restaurant either in the Sunset, Richmond, or Chinatown. I think plates vary from $4-$10. 

I came here the first time with 5 coworkers once and our bill was $35 a head after tip/tax. 

I came here a second time with a party of 3 total and our bill was $30 a head after tip/tax.

Their food is good, service is decent, but their prices are absolutely outrageous. I would give 5 stars if each dish was $2 cheaper. Who in the right mind would spend $30 on dim sum? (I'm guilty of it but I was desperate on two different occasions). Normally, dim sum would be at most $10 a head after tip/tax.
author: Heidi C.

description:
I love the atmosphere! The food's delicious but definitely on the pricey side. If you can afford to throw down like $80-90 for dimsum for 2-3 people, then go for it.  

For me...I think I prefer Jasmine Seafood Restaurant's dimsum back home in SD.
author: Daphne L.

description:
OK so this is supposedly the 'best' Dim Sum in San Francisco so I figured I'd give it a try...now this is about a year ago my friends took me for a birthday lunch...and as time passes I forgot how awful and expensive the food was. 

Well yesterday I made the mistake of taking my mother there. Now I will be far and say I  am somewhat of a dim sum specialist  and truly love my dim sum...so  whats wrong with this place? Well first off - who are they kidding with those prices! Way WAY overpriced. Now the most annoying thing about dim sum can often by that the food isn't warm...well at Yang Sing they took it a step further - their food is down right COLD. 

You know I could go on for quite a while about this place but its' not worth my time let alone yours to go. You want some dim sum go the china town and get it there! Far better and the price won't even compare. Now if you need a 'sit down place' still try somewhere else i guarantee they won't be as bad as this place.

Bottom line:
Overpriced, cold, no unique foods (all the 'usual' dim sum's)
STAY AWAY!
author: Morty N.

description:
My dad told me that it met his expectation of Hong Kong quality dim sum. He was correct.  All of the dishes I experienced met my expectations.

Now you are repeatedly pestered throughout your meal to buy more dishes, even with a full table. Otherwise service was great.
author: Phil T.

description:
Yank Sing is delicious...so far everything that I've tried I enjoyed.  The service could be a little better and the prices are fairly high.  But overall, worth another visit.  

If you decide to go during a weekend, make sure to go after 1pm, the waits are insane at times.
author: ERICA G.

description:
I've been here twice and I just don't think it is that great.  Yeah I've read a lot of reviews that this is the best dim sum in the city, but if that is true San Francisco is in trouble.

Weekend dim sum is an event here.  It is so popular that they have the restaurant and tables in the atrium of the office building where the restaurant is located.  They must be able to seat 200+ people.  Get there early or wait in line.  They do take reservations, although we didn't have any the last time and still got sat right away.

The purpose of dim sum is affordable good food.  This place is far from that.  The basics are mostly good, but some of my favorites are disappointing here.  Since I was a wee lad, my favorite Chinese food item has been the steamed Char Siu Bao (yeah that is spelled a hundred different ways).  The filling is the key.  Put lean meat and a tasty sauce in there.  For dim sum, you usually get the small sized baos so that they can get 3 of them in one of those steamer trays.  At a good spot, I usually approach double digits eating these delicious morsels.  The Char Siu Bao here were mostly a not-so-flavorful sauce and fat.  I struggled to eat 2.  

We had another dumpling dish that came in a large bamboo tray with about 8 dumplings filled with chicken and broth.  It was supposed to be special.  Unfortunately, the dumplings had absolutely no flavor.  

The wife and I racked up a bill of $85 - food, a beer, and a diet coke.  Wow.  The cost alone forces me to pull down a star.  A similar meal at my local dim sum joint would be about $25...and it would taste tons better.
author: Eric W.

description: Yes to dim sum! I just love the instant gratuity of this style of eating. Yank Sing has hot, steaming, delicious pork buns, sesame balls, basically everything. We went with my very picky 7-year-old sister, and she asked specifically for grilled chicken.. 2 mins later it was at our table! Next, my mom tries to charade 'rice porridge' to one of the workers who had no idea what she was talking about. My mom gave up, but they didn't give up on her. Other people came to our table to see what she exactly wanted, they realize it was the conji, and they sent one our way, and it was perfect! Great service! :)
author: Sabrina T.

description:
One of the better dim sum restaurant, with quality food and service. Staffs are very attentive and friendly, something unnatural come to dim sum places around the town. Delicate and clean tastes on many items, but I personally prefer that loud and crummy regular good old dim sum joint at the corner. 

- I can say they have the best xialongbao in the region. 
- Noodle w/ shrimp: too clean, should be drenched in that sauce. 
- Crazy parking.
author: Ryan C.

description: Yank Sing is by far the best dim sum in San Francisco.  The quality and flavor the food is fantastic, the service is impeccable and they make sure that your experience is top rate from the moment you arrive to the moment you leave.  They pay attention to detail and the Chan family, who has run this San Francisco iconic restaurant for three generations is dedicated to the uplifting of the Chinese community.  Strongly recommend Yank Sing -- whether you live in town or are visiting San Francisco, it is  a must visit.
author: M C.

description: I crave their dim sum on the regular and unfortunately I live in South Florida without a 1/2 decent dim sum place nearby. Yank Sing is one of the better places I've tried and enjoyed everything we had (group of 4 with tons of items). The soup dumplings were amazing and I left very full and plotting my return.
author: Lynn M.

description: Good XLB (and dim sum in general), but SO OVER-PRICED. A plate of 5 piece XLB costs ~$10. I'd rather walk a couple extra blocks and go to City View (on Commercial street). Much more reasonably priced, and DELICIOUS dim sum (and decent XLB).
author: Sarah C.

description:
My co-workers have had several Elvis Costello sightings at Yank Sing.

Not enough of a draw?  Their dim sum options are also plentiful, fresh and authentic.  I would give it 5 stars, but it's a little pricey for my taste.  I came here with four people and we each ended up paying over $30 for lunch...  It also doesn't match up to Koi Palace's standards.  All in all though, it's good dim sum and very conveniently located in the FiDi.
author: Sid D.

description: Presentation and taste were the cornerstones of their dim sum dishes.  Priciness ultimately will prevent it from being more favorably reviewed.
author: Kevin L.

description:
It has to be the most expensive.

I also think the quality and taste is great, probably upper middle level.
 - There are better, and for sure many are not near as good.

It is also for sure super clean and bright and the service has always been spectacular each of the 4 times I have been.

If you want something very very authentic, go to Cinatown and roll the dice.
If you want great quality in an upscale atmosphere, Yank Sing is it.
author: Thomas J.

description:
Delicious Dim Sum, with good service - but a bit pricey. 

Food: 
Great selection of dim sum, all prepared well, and all very tasty. 
The soup dumplings are excellent.  

Service: 
The dim sum carts come around consistently, and you can also order things separately. 

You pay "dinner price" for a dim sum brunch - so pricey. Worth it if you can afford it, and a safe bet if you are entertaining people from out of town.
author: Koku Y.

description:
I think the best thing about this place is the awesome waterfall thing that looks like something from Gattaca. 

I've eaten dim sum my whole life, and know the person who invented it, and I gotta say, I've had better. And cheaper. Me and my Korean roommate spent $40+ here for breakfast, when we could've gone to Irving st. and spent under $4 each for some greasy deep friend siu mai balls of goodness.

Although, this is a good place to take your visiting parents, so they think you're living well, and not eating spam, canned corn, and rice IN THE SAME MEAL.
author: Steven H.

description: From my experience today, I would normally have given this place a four star rating, but the food.  Wow!  Best. Dim Sum. Ever.  I do have to say that this place is a bit on the expensive side, but it's hard to get good dim sum that strays from the rest of the pack.  The service was mediocre and for the prices they were charging, I would have expected much better service.   But based on the food, I'll have to give them another shot on the service because I loved the food that much.  I'll have to update once I've tried them again, but for now...the review is solely based on food which to me is worth 5 stars.
author: Christine C.

description:
Dim sum yum yum!

On the pricey side but they have great service and the best xio long bao I've ever had. Besides the xlb our must orders are the lettuce wraps and peking duck sammies,
author: a l.

description:
Bah, Humbug! 

People only rate down because they think Yank Sing is overpriced. If you ask me, it's worth paying a little extra to have a cleaner, better serviced, more pleasant dining experience. Don't pass on Yank Sing to go to some take-out-only dive in Chinatown or the Richmond. Even if your wallet will be sad, your stomach will thank you.
author: Amanda C.

description: Mediocre at best, bland in general. My party of 6 tried many things that came our way, and there wasn't a single thing that stood out as especially well-prepared, or even high quality. The peking duck was dry and the skin was firm but not crispy.  The orange gelatin slices were probably the best thing to come along -- refreshing for the end of a meal. The service was good, though. So, yay.
author: Nina W.

description:
OMG! This place is RIDICULOUS! Oksana T. and I showed up here around 1pm on a Sunday, and the whole place inside and the ENTIRE LOBBY of the Rincon Center were filled with tables and people waiting to be seated! It was a total madhouse, and after about 20-30 minutes of waiting we finally got our little table.

The dim sum here is really very good! I find a lot of it pretty heavy... but it is worth it! Oks introduced me to something I for some odd reason never tried before - the Shanghai Dumplings. Yuuuummmm! We ate two whole basket-plates of these! 

Also, this is a MUST, get the pistachio ice cream cake at the end! It's the perfect happy ending! :)

I walked out with a total food euphoria! I wouldn't recommend doing this every week though... I think I would literally die if I ever had dim dum more often than once a month!
author: Liza P.

description:
Shanghai dumplings.   

And, the people in the kitchen wear hair nets! How sanitary!
author: Wakako U.

description:
Yank Sing is everything you want in a Dim Sum restaurant, until the check comes. The food was delicious, though we were barraged by women with carts when we walked in as if they were in a hurry to make us full. Nonetheless, I ate many delectable things.

Our benchmark is the Empress Pavillion in Los Angeles' Chinatown, with equally great food. There, our group of 8 MIGHT run up a tab of $100, (And believe me, we make pigs of ourselves. Here, it was $275 or $45 bucks a person. That's a lot of friggin money when you are not working, which I am not.

So though the food is a 4 star affair, I have no problem downgrading a star for high price and rushed service. 

I think I may just have to wait for my next trip to LA for Dim Sum I can afford.
author: Bruce K.

description:
Came here for dim sum on a Sunday morning.  Arrived here around 11:30am and the wait was around 30 minutes so we elected to go for take-out...

Everything was good but nothing spectacular.  However, I was very disappointed with the portion.  Many items, instead of 3 pieces per order, each order only had 1 or 2 pieces.

We got:
- lotus leaf sticky rice (instead of 3 pieces, only came with 1)
- salt water potstickers (instead of 3, only came with 2)
- sesame ball (instead of 3, came with 2)
- baked pork buns (instead of 3, came with 2 but each was HUGE)
- tarot dumpling (instead of 3, came with 2, but tasty)
- turnip cake (very good)
- har gow
- har gow with basil (excellent)
- rice noodle wrapped with shrimp (WE NEVER GOT THIS BUT PAID FOR IT!)

The total was $45 which was a bit on the high side considering the amount of food we got.

It was good that there was a garage underneath and they provide validation.  However, the parking lot seemed to have been constructed by a 2-year old.  It was one of the worst parking garage lay-out I've ever seen.

Next time, we will have to try another place.
author: Yuan W.

description:
It seems to me that Cali dim sum puts Texas' to shame. It's really sad quite frankly...This was the first time I had Xiao Long Bao done right, and by that I mean, there's S'POSED to be a little broth or soup down in the bottom of the steamed wrapper [read: treasure chest], and it explodes in your mouth when you bite into it and slides down your throat like Liquid Awesome. When their attentive dim sum pushers come by, as they surely will, try out their Sea Bass, Shu Mai, and Gyoza too!

Their tea was also cool. Nifty clear pots! Haven't seen those too much in the Big Tex. Me and the sister kept making Mulan references whenever we could...You know? Yea you know. "Pourrr the teeea..."

I wish I'd gotten to see more of Cali dim sum. In fact I could probably make a whole trip outta just that. Except that I'd have to choose between my dinner tab and paying for the hotel...
author: Christopher L.

description:
This place is superb it's no ordinary dim sum this is strait out of Hong Kong quality yam tza . 

I came up to the City this weekend from Palo Alto to visit my sister for the weekend. I have been to Yank Sing a lot since it is a family favorite. Not until recently did I have a chance to peek at the bill. wow, dim sum for 3 for $80.00!!

Here is why its worth it:

First of all, its in SOMA. I mean the Fairy Building serves fish and chips for $17.50.  So you got to expect the price to be high. You are in a nice neighborhood, it doesn't smell like china town with that odd mixture of rotting garbage and good food. It smells fresh, its in a  part of San Francisco where the some comes out a lot. Prices are going to be higher for that reason. I mean, there are million dollar apartments around you.

And you have to talk about the quality of dim sum. Yes, I admit I have had better dim sum before, in Hong Kong. Each piece of dim sum is smaller then the dim sum peaces at places around the bay area. And you might be confused and start thinking that they are trying to rip you off  by using less filling in the dim sum. I can see that happening in this super sized culture we have created in the US. They aren't trying to cut the portions, its how dim sum should be. Tightly packed with pork or shrimp not filled with fillers like corn starch. The quality of dim sum is really high. 

Service, last week I went to dim sum with a non-asian friend of mine. She asked why the waitresses were so rude. My simple reply was, "it's dim sum you aren't paying for service, you are paying for dim sum." Well, thats not the case here! Excellent service, I mean really superb. They speak multiple dialects of Chinese and you don't have to worry about them not being able to make out your English like you do in China Town. There was an old Jewish couple at the table next to us and they got served just fine. Speaking of being served. The carts come fast, there is no waiting for the cart with the dim sum to come around to your table, it's there. And! if it's not? Every cart serves has a headset and you can ask them for whatever you want and the order goes through the headset and comes in less then a minute. Ridiculously awesome.

The place is clean, super clean. This is authentic Chinese fine dining-- no fusion involved. This is something you see straight out of Hong Kong, a restaurant equivalent to a nice steak place here, culturally different of course. This is why things are a little pricier, the dim sum places you find in China Town are equivalent to going to Denny's for steak or maybe at best Outback Steak House, you get my point.


Anyways, enough with defending the price, here is my latest experience:

It was a nice Sunny Saturday morning here in SOMA, we were headed out for brunch then, we were going to head over the the fairy building for farmers market, we stuck to the basics:

Sui Mai - Har Gau - Lo Bak Goh - Wu Gock - Pai Gaut - Nua mi fun
http://chinesefood.about.com/library/blmenutransdimsum.htm

They also had these really good Taiwanese dumplings called - xiao long bao. Goodness I haven't had xiao long bao since I was in Taiwan.

And to top it off we had some Pan Friend crispy noodle- which came with a generous portion of seafood, I mean, really good stuff.

Satisfied we paid and bought two jars of their house made hot sauce and we were on our way, full and satisfied.

So there you go, $80 bucks, great service, superb food; 5 stars for sure.

note: Don't get me wrong, I love going to china-town too. I really am not all posh and stuck-up as this review makes me out to be, there just needs to be a clarification of what this place is all about.
author: Steve L.

description:
My friend was craving Dou Jiang and You Tiao for our Sunday morning eats.  Couldn't find it in Chinatown, and thus we ended up at Yank Sing.

But when given a wait time of 30-40 min, we made the best of our situation and went next door to Yank Sing 2 Go. Ordered 3 boxes of dumplings and steered ourselves to the Ferry Market Building.  As a note of caution, none of the desserts at Yank Sing will be able to trump the sweet treats at the market.  So shun any notion of ordering the sesame balls, egg or mango custard.  Lest you will be taunted by all the scrumptious sweet treats at the market.

Of all the 9-variety dumplings we ordered, the exceptional ones were the deep fried taro root (not a dumpling), snow pea shoots and the crab sui mai.  

Unfortunately, the 3 boxes we ordered were above average but definitely not worth the $80 pricetag.
author: A W.

description:
I am really torn to give this place 3 stars or 4 but considering the service, I had to up it to 4 stars...here is why.

6 potstickers = $9+
Xiao Long Bao= $11+
Ha Gao (shrimp dumpling)= $5
Ha Cherng (shrimp rice roll) =$7+
etc. we also had the peking duck (1pc/order =$5) pork spare ribs, scallop dumplings and tea for 4= total meal $65 with tip.

Don't get me wrong, the food is good but I really think that the prices are steep for what you get.  Yes, I get that food quality is much higher here than some other restaurants but I really do not think 6 potstickers ought to cost $10.  I can only see myself coming here more often if I win the lottery or if I suddenly stumble upon an extra $100 that I really do not know what to do with.  

Service was excellent though!!!  Glass of water was never half empty; the waiters all spoke English and chinese (either Cantonese or Mandarin) and refilled our tea pot promptly.  The food servers all asked if we wanted anything from their cart and if we denied, they said "thank you" and moved on.  Here is the good part...we came specifically to try the peking duck.  Once we sat down, we sat the cart roll by 2 tables away from us but we were distracted by the waiter asking us what tea we wanted.  Throughout the meal, we kept looking for it but it never showed up again.  After we were all done eating what we had on our table, the waiter noticed we were looking around and asked if we wanted to order something, we mentioned to him we wanted to try the peking duck and ordered 2.  A few minutes later, I noticed a woman bring to the table behind us 2 peking duck pieces but nothing for us.  Another server asked us what we were waiting for and asked our waiter about our order.  He went to the back and checked but came back and told us they were cutting the pieces and would come out shortly and apologized.  When the item did come out, he apologized again and said, "this is on the house, sorry you had to wait so long."  WHAT?!  I've never heard anyone apologize this many times and then offer the item for free at ANY chinese dim sum restaurant!!!! I was really shocked that this kind of service is still to be found and that they really want their customers to be happy when they leave.  That was a really good way to end the meal.

If only Yank Sing were not so expensive, I would come back in a heartbeat but unfortunately, I have not yet won the lottery.
author: judy l.

description:
My favorite dim sum

I visited the building on other business in which this restaurant is located a few times, and had been intrigued by the thought of dim sum.  As a child, my family would eat dim sum about 4 times a year, we always enjoy the fresh Asian flavors.  It's similar to the Chinese version of tapas.  I always enjoy being able to "taste" a bit of everything at the table.  When a colleague invited us to a lunch there, I was all over it.

We dined on a Thursday lunch among a mostly business/workday crowd.  The restaurant is located in a great food court in a low-rise office building.  The food court has a beautiful water feature in the middle.  The clientele seems to be a sophisticated lot.

Dim sum is best consumed with at least 4 people, 5 or 6 is ideal (imo).  This gives the diner the ability to sample a variety of plates, and not have to finish every one.  With only 2 diners, you may only be able to sample two or three plates.

My group of 5 ordered about 15 dishes, including 2 xiao long bao, pork sui mye, lettuce wraps, steam pork bun, potstickers, spring rolls, egg custard tarts, sea bass, lettuce wraps.  I tasted all but two of the dishes and (thoroughly) enjoyed each one.  The servers pushing hot steam carts to our table were relentless from the time we sat down; they came so often, that we had a log jam of food on our table after the fourth cart.

My two favorite dishes were the xiao long bai and the sea bass.
The xiao long bao is magnificent, my dining mate from New Jersey asked for another order, this being her first time trying dim sum.  The dumpling skin had a firm steamed texture and the broth inside was perfectly savory.  The sea bass had a beautifully broiled outside, with a subtly sweet crust and a flaky tender flesh.

The wait staff was very attentive, and quick to answer any requests.  The dining room is very clean, with a nice heavy feel.  We arrived at 11:45 and didn't have to wait.

I wanted to try everything in this restaurant.  Every other dish looked terrific.  The bill for five us was $250 w/tip.
author: Parris B.

description:
One of the best dim sum in San Francisco. Covenient for me working on the second floor.  Excellent dim sum for Sundays were you get to sit in the atrium area...a little pricier though.  Also great for "to go" and eat in my office.

This is a much better place than their old place at Battery.
author: Jc C.

description: pricey dim sum but excellent and frequent selection of a wide variety of dishes and excellent service. Large atrium seating area in post office building- no wait if willing to sit outside on a Sunday at about 10:45a .
author: Kenneth T.

description: Favorite Dim Sum in the City.  In the Bay Area too.  on weekends, it is fantastic for kids, as they open up the atrium for seating.  With the waterfall from the ceiling, it is fantastic.  The Hargow, Shumai and the pork bunds are great.  As are their Signature dishes.  Must go!
author: Flip F.

description:
I have never eaten so much dim sum ever in my life! 

We wanted to have dim sum one day and Euge decides to go to Yank Sing because it's less intimidating than those more, shall I say, Chinese places. And you'd think, "Yeah, but Nance is Chinese, so no problem at those Cantonese places, right?" Sorry, but I can only understand half of what they say and sik gong se siu gong dong wa [speak a little]. I get shy. 

Good thing at Yank Sing, everybody and their mama speaks English. 

It was really weird to see so many non-Asians eating here. Doesn't seem right. I'm used to seeing a whole bunch of Chinese folks, everybody being loud and obnoxious, including the wait staff. 

And I just can't believe between us two little ass people; we had at least 12 orders of stuff. It's either:
1.) We were really, really hungry, or 
2.) The food was really good. 

I think it's a mix of both. The food was good, but it is not that great because: 

- Shrimp cheung fun (shrimp wrapped in rice noodles) is my ultimate favorite dish when I eat dim sum. So I'm pretty damn picky about this particular item. Yank Sing's is a little different. The rice noodle wrapping is clearer than it's supposed to be, giving it a more chewy texture. I don't really like that. 

- Daan tat (egg custard) was ugh... Edible, but was not brown, crispy and flaky enough. Undercooked. 

- The roasted duck didn't have enough flavors. 

- Mango pudding... It tasted like it was made with those instant-pudding mixes. I expected chunks of mango in creamy pudding but it tasted like artificially flavored mango mousse. 

It was a pretty interesting experience here. First time hearing waiters speaking English to you instead of yelling,"nay yiu mh yiu ha gow ma??!! Ni di siu mai hou sik ah!!"

I'd rather go to those HK dim sum places with pink table cloth covers and bear with those Cantonese speaking waiters and have my shrimp cheung fun and daan tat done right. 

No worries, at least I know SOME Cantonese right? I'll survive! 

I still love my hole in the wall dim sum place on Noriega.
author: Nance W.

description: wow... imagine you were walking down the street and got kidnapped, put in a van, and violated repeatedly in the rear end. that's how your going to feel when the check comes at this place.
author: Edward S.

description:
Yank Sing is good...so far the best dim sum I've had in SF.  I still don't think it tops my place in Seattle, but for SF, I have yet to see better. 

Very pricey.  For 2 people = $54, plus tip (not incl. any booze).  VERY pricey.  For this, only 3 stars.   Taste not exceptional enough to warrant the 4th...

Location is great, in an old Post Office.  Very pretty, but gets really loud when it's busy, which from the reviews seems to be all the time.

Easy walk from Union Square.  Just walk down Mission towards the water; Spear is a small street, so pay attention or you may miss. Literally at the corner of Spear and Mission, in the Rincon Building.
author: Kate P.

description:
Fantastic service, hands down best service I've had for a Dim Sum restaurant anywhere in the world, and I've been to quite a few in Hong Kong, Vancouver, and US. We were able to put in an order with any server, and they would immediately call in to their microphone for us. Everyone were very friendly and helpful.

The food quality is top notch as well, every dish we had were warm, beautifully presented and well made. The restaurant decor is simple and elegant.
author: John P.

description:
This is probably the only place to get decent dim-sum for lunch in the SOMA side of the FiDi. I know....Chinatown is so close, but sometimes you just don't have enough time at lunch. 

I can't believe this place is Zagat rated. The food is decent. The service is pretty good. It's definitely got SOMA prices - which go against what dim sum really is all about. If you order 4 dim sum dishes, the bill shouldn't come out to $40. Oh...that's right...they charge something like $5 for the TEA. I'm sorry, but that's not acceptable in my book.

That being said, you don't have many options in this area. Again, the food is decent, and they DO have the coveted Shanghai Dumplings (Xiao Long Bao), which taste good. So if you're willing to spend, then go for it!
author: Samir P.

description:
This place is insanely cool. 

DJ'ed a wedding here a while back where the entire dinner seating was out in the lobby weaving tables AROUND the ceiling waterfall & pond. Incredibly beautiful. 

Food was superb. What can I say? When Chinese food is good, it's good!

For people planning big events/weddings/parties and what not.. FYI... the ceremony was also inside the Rincon center and the restaurant has their own set of small JBL speakers and what not, but it looks HORRIFIC. Spits up speaker stands and speakers everywhere... just littering the entire venue. Ugh. 

Hella unnecessary. Please coordinate with your DJ to NOT use the house provided system. Please lol. Your DJ can cover it (speaking for myself, no clue about other guys not in my company).

Regardless, the food is great, and if possible, eat outside in the lobby of the Rincon center. It's insanely beautiful.

FYI, the waterfall from hundred feet me in the middle of the lobby serves as natural air conditioning for air circulation. It was hella cool. I noticed it did really warm up immediately the moment it was turned off as I was breaking down my gear.

Wicked.
author: Warren W.

description:
This place has great dimsum. I took my Chinese parents here and they claimed that it was the best dimsum they had had outside of Singapore. The quality of the ingredients is high, there is high turnover so the dumplings are always fresh, and they skew towards a more western palate (although it isn't fusion - it just goes easy on the chicken feet and tripe). 

It is, however, expensive for dim sum. Budget $15-20 per person. My Chinese parents got sticker shock...

The best day to come here is Saturdays - the crowd is always a lot smaller than Sundays when you can end up waiting 45 minutes, even if you do have a reservation.
author: jeremy l.

description:
Growing up in a traditional Chinese household, Dim Sum was a customary Sunday experience similar to going to Church for some. Having said that, I've had my share of Dim Sum in my lifetime and I have high expectations. 

When I moved to SF a year ago, I asked my boss for a really great Dim Sum place and he gushed "Yank Sing!" 

So off I went to Yank Sing with 3 others for brunch. On first impression, the place was clean and modern, service was attentive and the food was above average with the XLBs being the relative highlight and this is coming from an XLB whore. We actually weren't super hungry so we didn't order our usual bounty like we typically do.

Everything was fine UNTIL the bill came. Okay, for those who may not know, Dim Sum, by custom, is a weekend breakfast family tradition. Family as in your grandparents, parents, siblings, et al. If I ever took my family to Yank Sing and they saw the bill, which was over $45 per person, they would each line up and beat my ass. After that point, my parents would argue the merits of disowning me vs. an honor killing for having raised a humongous dumb ass.  

To Karena M's posting. $45 per person on average for nothing fancy Dim Sum is the equivalent to paying $45 for eggs, ham and pancakes. When was the last time you paid anything remotely close to $45 for breakfast that did not include alcohol or a prostitute? The XLBs were good enough to stave off a 1 star rating.
author: Tai K.

description: Yank Sing's sesame balls are listed on 7x7's 200 things to eat in SF list. We ordered them to go (along with some egg tarts). Would love to go back for a real dim sum experience here. Although its tucked away in a sterile office building, the food was very good. They've got a to go counter where you can order dim sum individually. The sesame balls were hot and plump, filled with red bean paste and made of a rice flour dough. Just before frying they're rolled in sesame seeds, which give it a lovely texture. Wasn't as impressed with the egg tarts but I'm looking forward to tasting their savory offerings in the future!
author: Mairead R.

description:
A very pricey Dim Sum experience but well worth every penny. The food was sooooo good I wanted to stay for a few hours to prolong the happiness my stomach was encountering! The Shanghai dumplings, crisp duck, egg custard were really incredible. 

Three Mimosa each and yummy Dim Sum = happiness. Be prepared to drop some serious cash here though!
author: Leanne S.

description:
How could I forget about this place? I've only been to 5 weddings held here. The thing I remember most is that they charge an extra $1,000 to use red tablecloths rather than white ones for your wedding. Talk about gouging someone for their special day. 

Another memorable moment? There's always someone at every wedding who forgets that there is a waterfall-like contraption in the middle of the room and walks through the pond in their nice dress/suit.

Food is mediocre. I'd rather go to Koi Palace any day.
author: Vanessa T.

description: Same here with some friends to get some breakfast. There was alot of people in line but that moved quickly, we got our food and ate. the food was ok, nothing really out of the ordinary for dim sum but the prices were ridiculous. our bill for 4 people came out for 120, when normally any other spot we go to it would be around 60ish.
author: Tony D.

description: Simply the best Dim Sum in the US.  You can go to Hong Kong, and they'll know Yank SIng the moment you mention their name.  No, it's not cheap, and it's an easy target for Yelp whiners and would be foodie hipsters from the sticks, but there is a reason the line is impossible after 11:50AM.  I'm a bay area native, and there isn't a better option in california, and i haven't had anything close in LA, NYC, or anywhere else.  I have clients that fly in from all over the country-they all want lunch at Yank Sing whenever they are in town, because they can't get this in MA, NY, TX, WA, IL, or anywhere in CA.  Sure, there are lots of 'New' Dim Sum places out there, but they're "New" because the last place they worked out folded after 12 months, ad infinitum.
author: kevin f.

description: One of the nicest and most expensive dim sum restaurants I have ever been to. For a party of 3, 3 short Asian guys, the bill was nearly 120 bucks! Normally when I eat dim sum with a party of 4, it is about 50 bucks but this was 70 bucks more! The restaurant is located near the embarcadero and finding it is kind of hard because it is inside of a building with no signs. Parking is hectic here and trying to find a space can take awhile. However, you can park in the garage and get validation for Yank Sing. The restaurant itself can probably fit hundreds of people inside and outside of the place with a nice waterfall in the middle to watch.
author: Danster L.

description:
Yank Sing's Shanghai Dumpling is the Bomb!!! Just make sure you eat it with just one bite so the soup doesn't spill.  Nothing really special about the Cabbage Salad besides the purple color vegetable. Pass on the Curry Dumpling.  

I was prepared for a big bill prior to being seated because a friend told me that their price were 3x higher comparing to any other dim sum restaurant.  The cheapest order we had was $4.35 and it was only stamped once.  The wait wasn't too long; taking pictures with the Christmas tree killed some time.  Service's decent.  Recommended? Yes.  Shanghai Dumpling!
author: Rebecca C.

description: First time at a dim (sp?) sum restaurant so I will warn other first timers - be prepared! As soon as we sat down we were surrounded by four servers with carts of food asking what we wanted and pushing little plates and steamers at us. Almost too many choices! Once we got our bearings and had a few dishes things settled down. I went specifically for the steamed pork buns I saw reviewed on Food Network and I was not disappointed! The soft dough contains a lovely pocket of sweet and tangy barbecue pork. Other highlights of our meal were the fried soft shell crabs and sesame balls for dessert. I will be back next time I am in SF!
author: Reuben P.

description:
A few reviews down, someone claimed to be a "dim sum snob", stating that his favorite dishes were "sui mai, shrimp dumplings, steamed pork buns, shanghai dumplings".

...wait...what???! Aren't those the most generic items you can order???

Oh well. To each's own.. :)

We went here partly as a joke but mostly because it was close to his work. This place isn't totally bad but it's definitely not the best dim sum place in all of SF. Like my better half would say, I've been spoiled. :) There are other better, authentic dim sum places elsewhere in SF - you just have to be willing to go there which I think 95% of the patronage at Yank Sing won't do (wussies).

The food was good, decor was modern, service was great, especially since everyone spoke great English. I think that's what draws most of its customers. The crowd was mostly business folk and a few "I'm too good for you" type people. PUH-lease, I noticed your dinky ass diamond ring as you struggled to control your chopsticks. AND you had on crocs!!!!!

And the price? Expensive.
author: T L.

description:
I came here on one sunny Sunday afternoon, the kind that reminds you how kick ass the bay area really is and how incredibly lucky we are to be living here.  There was 6 of us and we got seated in about 15 mins (sweeeet)  at one of the table right next to the waterfall thingie (soo prettty!)

Why I loved it:  no ordering needed, just point, smile and say thank you!  We tried everything from the peking duck, to thier famous Shanghai Dumplings to luttuce cups.

Atmosphere:  bussssyyyyyyyy but oh so much fun!! we were there for about 2-3 hours or so and never got rushed out, just drank our teas, talked and ate

Price:  We ate doubles and triples of everything, so our tab came out to be about 70$ per person.  Pretty high BUT the food was yum and i dont think i complained about anything we had.  One dumpling was slightly greasy but one out of the (what seemed like)15 we had.. not bad at all


Parking:  doood.. do i really need to say anything about the parking in SF?  Theres a parking lot downstairs but that gets filled up pretty quickly, i had to show some major clevage to the attendee to grab a parking spot that isnt typically used for customers

Would I Come Back:  helllllllz to the yea!


did i miss anything?:  All in all, i dug it pretty hardcore, im trying to arrange a time to bring new people here, the fact that its only a short stroll from the embarcadero adds to its charm, because we SERIOUSLY had to go for a walk after that 3 hour meal.
author: Brendalynn K.

description:
A Yank Sing haiku...

  Randomly priced treats
  Why are you so expensive?
  Ton Kiang? Better.

There are much better places for Dim Sum, such as Ton Kiang, but 40 minutes on the 38 Geary is just too darn long of a trip when you just want a quick couple of dumplings and some buns. So, the premium price equates to a penalty for lazyness. No consistency on the pricing or itemized receipt (take a hint from Tian Sing) makes me suspect that a $40 lunch for two one week costs $70 the next.

Overall, the food quality is good - but not nearly as good as when they operated the Battery Street location. The Rincon facility on the weekend is just too large and impersonal. A good place to introduce visitors to Dim Sum and when someone else is paying.

PS: if Ton Kiang is only two syllables instead of the three I think it is, make the last line of the haiku "Ton Kiang? Much Better"
author: Avery G.

description:
This is my favourite high end Dim Sum restaurant in SOMA. 

Go early (yes, 11:30AM) if you want to avoid the crowds as it gets BUSY and LOUD after 12PM. 

Kinda pricey but for the quality and selection I think it's worth it.
author: Nenette Y.

description:
I'm not Asian, but over the last 5 years since I started dating someone who is, I've been to dim sum about once a week on average. SO, I'm confident in saying that I'm pretty experienced. With that said, I really don't understand what the hoopla is all about when people talk about this place. There are a couple dishes that they do well, but overall, they are pretty darn average. The only level on which I'd rate them super high is customer service - very polite and attentive and everyone speaks great English. You don't get that in most dim sum places and I appreciate it. However, the food itself is pretty ok and it IS horrendously expensive...really really expensive for what you're getting. 

I go back cause my boyfriend (now fiance) likes their crab claw and a couple other dishes. Personally, I'd be quite content if I never ate there again - I can't say there's one dish I"d miss. I'm not saying I've had a bad experience, just not good enough to justify the cost. And just for the record, I've been there about 7 times now so it's not like I'm dinging them based on one trip - I really wanted it to be great since everyone seems to be enamored by this place!!!
author: Kat J.

description:
BEST (shanghai) siu loong boa's EVER!!  Seriously!

Never in the Bay Area have I had these dumplings made so perfectly.  The wrap was super thin, but enough to hold the piping hot soup inside.   Added with the traditional red vinegar and ginger dip, these dumplings were reminiscent of the ones I once had in Hong Kong.  

The rest of the dim sum is also pretty good (though I won't boast for them as much as I did with the dumplings above).  The jellyfish was one to note, not overly-oiled or any hints of a fishy taste.  The dim sum options, however, were a bit strange in my opinion.  Some dishes cater to a more American taste - I mean, when you offer salad plates and orange jello as part of your menu, you can't expect to be called completely traditional.   However, Yank Sink still provided the traditional plates and offered more than just fried foods (which some places distastefully do).

The service is extremely organized, though sometimes you may have to wait a little (**I say this admitting I went on Father's Day - does that change anything?  I don't know)  If you ask any server for a certain dish, they speak into their walkie-talkie/microphones and call up THE server  who is pushing the cart with said dish and they magically appear.  I've never seen that type of system anywhere else and was quite impressed.  The manager even came by and spoke to us at the end of meal.  Not bad =P

The scrumptious food was complemented by a huge glass roof ceiling with a water pump.  Essentially, if you look upward towards the ceiling, you see the sky and a waterfall going towards the ground, with water returning into the system through a circular canal in the floor.  That was probably not the best description ever, but that's the best I could do.  In any case, I liked it.

The one warning I have to future patrons is parking.  If you hit a busy day, the parking lot (which Yank Sing validates for) will be full and you will have to circle around the blocks for a street space.  Not the great nuisance, but when you're pushed for time, you still get stressed and yell at cars that speed up from a block away and steal the space you eyed at the traffic light (...stupid bmw...)
author: Bernadette C.

description: Sorry for being harsh, but $70 (b4 tip) dim sum for two doesn't make it in my book... Most expensive dim sum I've ever had and we didn't eat much. Food is average (3 star) but it's not worth paying $35 pp. Will NOT go back.
author: Mango G.

description: It was delicious! The pork soup dumplings were the best I've had. Pricey, yes, but for the ambiance of sitting in the courtyard with good company, it was worth the experience.
author: Elle D.

description:
We had reservations for 10 but were running behind due to traffic on the bridge. We called to move it up half an hour and there was no problem.  This location is located inside Rincon center, with the neat waterfall that descends from the ceiling (they charge extra just to turn it on for weddings; tables start at the upper $500s).  It doesn't actually get busy until 11:30 or so and service is really good (and they speak English!).  However, you get what you pay for.  It is definitely more expensive ($210 for 8 people), but again, they have good service and clean restrooms.  They even overheard us singing Happy Birthday and brought out a mango pudding for the birthday boy. How sweet - literally!

The other plus is that they are philanthropic and donate in-kind to local organizations. An extra star for that.
author: Nicole D.

description: Came here on Christmas Day because it was open, and they took reservations. Overall, service is a fustercluck, food is mediocre, prices are WHOA! Probably will not return, unless there's another holiday and we're desperate for a restaurant that's open
author: Tiffany K.

description:
Yank Sing may get most of the attention in the crowded San Francisco dim sum market, however, the most telling observation - Financial District neck knots and tourists, says quite a bit about the food and perhaps, more interest in paying a premium for average dim sum and decor, that's where the "yank" in Yank Sing comes in, and the "sing" comes from what the owners of this small two outlet chain do all the way to the bank.

Though they are a little more work due to language barriers, there are far better dim sum restaurants in The City.
author: Rafael R.

description: I love Yank Sing for many reasons: ingredient quality, ambience, family memories, dish variety, all spring to mind.  It's the closest I've seen in the Bay Area to Hong Kong restaurants in terms of ambience and hygiene; however, I have yet to find a dim sum place here that parallels the richness and sophistication of good dim sum in Hong Kong.  Food is always fresh and in abundance, but be prepared to wait a long time for a table on the weekend.
author: Risha L.

description: I love this place.  I take all my visiting friends and family to this place because you cannot go wrong wtih this place.  Their shanghai dumpling is to-die-for.  Some people might think that this place is not authentic enough....and perhaps I don't have such refined taste...but I love it and all my friends and family love it.
author: Sunny K.

description:
My husband and I go to Yank Sing for dim sum about once a year on a Sunday for dim sum.  We really love dim sum and Yank Sing was always a treat.

We made our annual pilgrimage last month and although I enjoyed the food I don't think I'll go back for sit down again.  Maybe get take out and go down to the Embarcadero on a sunny afternoon.  My complaint, the prices are just too high as the quality of the food has really slipped.  The food used to be so exceptional that you didn't mind the price.

Everything was good.  My husband and I ate $150.(not including tip) of dim sum so we had a variety.  The Shanghi dumplings are a favorite and good, but, again not exceptional as they used to be.

There is so much good dim sum in the City at much more reasonable prices.  I really enjoyed everything but the bill.  I don't mind paying for exceptional food but Yank Sing is just not exceptional any more.
author: Kathy A.

description:
I only been here two times since it is not affordable but mmmmm this place has some gooood dim sum!
Pretty much anything I order was yummy!!!  They have some non traditional items as well.
Yan Sing to go is available for take out or fast-food version but it is not the same.
author: Mika H.

description:
After an evening of cocktails, taxi-rides, and holiday cheer I woke up on the couch at my friend Rachel's house with one thing on my mind: dim sum at Yank Sing - dim sum is the perfect breakfast food.

So, after a cup of coffee and couple of Christmas cookies from Rachel's students, Gret, Rachel and I made our way to the Yank Sing at One Rincon Center.

The restaurant validates parking, but you may want to leave the SUV at home - even after several attempts Gret's bug was still closer to the neighboring car than the wall opposite.  Maybe it was lingering effects of last-night's punch.

We made our way to the entrance, were greeted by two friendly women dressed in traditional (I'm assuming) gowns, and were seated promptly.  There is plenty of seating, but from prior experience, there can sometimes be a brief wait.

Once seated, several servers, pushing carts towering with steaming baskets of dim sum, converged on our table.  Within minutes we were dining on an array of dumplings such as Shanghi Pork Dumplings, and my favorite, Shu Mai: meat and broth encased in a wonton skin. You have to eat it whole; when you bight into it your mouth is filled with savory-sweet goodness.  We also indulged on steamed BBQ-pork buns, pork short ribs, and crunchy spring roles.

Our head waiter, Ed, was professional, charming, and witty.  He took our drink order, three Tsingtaos and a Bloody Mary, as we selected our dishes and had returned with them by the time the first dumplings hit our lips.  We joked with him about joining us for a beer; he laughed with us and replied, "Oh, how I wish I could" - or something to that effect.

The restaurant is very open, clean, and busy.  The high-level of activity makes it a perfect place for large groups, families with kids, or three friends reminiscing about the events of the prior evening.  I hope that you enjoy your experience at Yank Sing as much as we did.

Context is everything.

Cheers,

Malcolm
author: Malcolm M.

description:
Alright, here is the deal:
If you want to impress someone special~
Business Executives, VIP Clients, or Shift-Leader from the Hooters.... 
!~THIS IS THE PLACE~!
and of course, this place is also a very good outlet to IMPRESS your wallet. 

Food has its class..... 
Good plating, Good elegance, Good quality.. 
but, not so much of blue ribbon type of world rank

Service IS very occupied~!
Because this place is ALWAYS PACKED! 
Very popular place, consider it is hiding in a postal services building?!

Dim Sum~ is a great time to bond with friends~
but, just pay a little attention on the numbers of items you are order~

Because, you might not get the chance to bond with
Tons of "Washington"
