Plenty of "Lincoln"
Couple "Hamilton"
author: Andrew W.

description:
In short: Decent dim sum but a bit pricey.

This place was located in the financial district in the heart of San Fransisco.  Since we were tourist here, we asked the concierge for recommendations on good dim sum and he directed us here.  

The place was easy to find, it's in a big commercial building full of other restaurants and what not.  The location was really busy and packed for lunch so we assumed it should have great food.  The atmosphere inside was quite nice and the service was great.  The carts came by frequently and our waiter was very attentive.

The food was good, well flavored and had a diverse menu.  I was a little disappointed that they didn't have more authentic dishes such as beef tendon but this place was more geared to mainstream American perspective.  The shanghai soup dumplings were amazing and so was the sea bass and the custard cups.  The price to food ration was quite awful, even considering this is SF.  Lunch for four cost us 140$ and we were still hungry, the above mentioned sea bass was 17$ and four custard cups was 11$, a bit too pricey in my opinion.  

In conclusion: The food wasn't amazing and the price was too high in my opinion, I've been to many dim sums and this ranks around the middle of the spectrum.
author: Bakaroo B.

description: The dimsum isn't horrible, and the place is pretty spacious, but for the prices that they charge, I expect soo much more. It is so frickin' expensive! AND a lot of the stuff isn't even authentic. This is definitely one of those places that use their locations as excuses to up their undeserved prestige.
author: Christine A.

description:
At a friend's suggestion went to Dim Sum today.  It had been a few years since I had last visited.  The selection was very good.  The Wu-gok, Hagow, Cheunfan, Spring Rolls, and everything else we ordered tasted very good.

The service was attentive and friendly.

When the bill came I remembered why it had been years since my last visit.  The bill is also the reason I only rated it 3 stars...the prices are excessive.  I don't mean slightly excessive, I mean "will not return unless someone else pays" excessive.
author: Saul M.

description: You like Dim Sum? Seek no further you have found some of the best anywhere. A bit pricey and only open day hours but this place is not just Julia's favorite it is actualy amazing.
author: Karl L.

description: I grew up coming into the city for dim sum at Yank Sing.  Now a days this isn't my #1 choice for dim sum , as for being convenient on work days it does the job.  Fancy Schmancier to draw in the crowd, not that great of food, smaller than usual portions with double sometimes triple the price for well made dim sum.  I used to frequent their old location on Battery and it might sound strange but the food seems different since they moved years ago.  If you don't feel like dining in they have the same separate counter take out right next door.  If you're in a dim sum mood, work in the FiDi, want to try somewhere different......try City View.
author: Stephanie D.

description:
Usually just get food to go.  Quick service!

The combo meals to go are pretty good.  Starts to become pricey once you start adding on dim sum.
author: C G.

description:
Oh, how I love thee Shao Lung Bao.

One bite into this dumpling & a magical delicious soup filling oozes out.  Soooo tasty.  The  dim sum sampler is definitely a must.

The decor is really upscale New Yorky/ very modern Shanghai style.  This place would look like gangsters play mah jong in the back.  I wonder if it's true.  

If only this place was a bit cheaper.....
author: Sheryl S.

description: Amazing dim sum, great service, good selection, and fresh. Their mango ice cream is truly genius.
author: Bryan H.

description:
I'm not getting it.  Other Yelpers, my co-workers and some friends rave about the dim sum here.  To me, it's over-cooked, over-fried, diarrhea inducing fast food.  I've eaten there twice and both times I've had an unfortunate case of buyer's remorse afterwards.

I think Lee's across the street has better food.  I seem to be the odd man out here, so don't take my word for it.  Try it, you might like it.
author: Tony M.

description:
One star since no star is not possible
Stay away, stay far away. 
Traditional dim sum is supposed to be inexpensive.
When the check arrived, I had to ask about the item for $8.50.
The server and I tried to recall what it could be and she said it was the sesame balls. Up the hill on Stockton, you would pay $3.00 on the high end for them.
She also mentioned, rolling her eyes, that the average per person price at Yank Sing is about $30.00.
This place is good, but not worth the price.
author: Geordie E.

description:
This place is too expensive if you're going for Dim Sum, but it sure is good. 

I typically get the craving for their spicy chicken salad. It comes with this fabulous mustard sauce that can clear anyones sinuses! We're all big fans here at the office.. 

Try it!
author: Monica S.

description:
Update:
On a recent visit to Yank Sing, we had pretty good Xiao Loong Baos and most of the dumplings were delicious too! Perhaps they up'ed their standard from previously. But then again, it's still pricey dim sum but nonetheless, they still draw their crowds.
Yup, they still serve Peking Duck and other fusion dishes during dim sum, that is still not authentic dim sum dishes.

Older review:
Overrated and very pricey for average dim sum....seabass is so not dim sum!
author: Yan M.

description:
Japanese people like dim sum.  My associate took our Japanese clients here for lunch without giving me the heads up.  I am Chinese and I dont do dim sum in the bay area unless my level-5 fob friends pre-qualify it on the Toronto-HK scale with risk of loosing their esteemed level-5 rating.

The shao-lung-bao/siu-loong-bow was edible.  The staff that kept on trying to make my clients over-order was not cool.  I am not going back.  I will save my dim sum cravings for when I travel.
author: H C.

description:
I love me some dim sum but I gotta say that for the amount of $ this place charges, the food better be AMAZING and quite honestly, I've been to fast food places in Oakland and Inner Richmond that serve just as good dim sum as Yank Sing if not better.  
It's the Financial District and that's why they can get away with charging as much as they do.   For my $, I'll be indulging elsewhere.
author: Lena W.

description: Yummy Dim Sum that is different than your regular fare.  So if you want a special treat and don't mind spending a bit of money, this is a nice place to go.
author: Gina C.

description: There might be better dim sum in San Francisco's China Town, but for the western palate, this is the best there is, period.
author: Gasper S.

description:
Update: I've been back and honestly, I think I'm done aside from business lunches where the company pays. I love dim sum but $80 on dim sum for 2 is just plain ridiculous. The quality may be good but not THAT good. 
========
Yank Sing is good and I seem to end up here often for business lunches. On those days, I have to give it a 5 star rating because well... it's on my expense account and so it's not my money. 

I can't say anyhting negative about the food because it is very good. The quality is excellent and the restaurant itself is clearly much nicer than those you'll find in Chinatown. I deducted a star however for the price. The cost is unbelieveably high for dim sum. If you're from out of town and you come here expecting to find the "cheap dim sum" that you may have read about in a magazine, you'll want to skip Yank Sing. For two of us, we've easily spent nearly $100.  

It's good and I recommend it, but don't go here if you don't want to drop a good amount of cash.
author: Anita B.

description:
2.5

Fried rice: No taste at all

Chow mein: Okay, but very greasy

Spring roll: Beyond greasy

Potstickers: Flavorful with a nice consistency

Dim sum: Small, but good. Perhaps that's what to stick with at Yank Sing...
author: Whit P.

description:
We took my parents here when they were in town. Basically all we were looking for were steamed pork buns, but figured for the special occasion why not try a nice sit-down place with a good reputation.

For $48 less, we could have gone out to one of my usual haunts on Irving Street. Fortunately, we ended up with a lot more on our table than just the pork buns, and all of it was excellent. I was initially outraged at the price ($50 for four of us), but after skimming other reviews, it seems that we got away with a little bit better of a deal. 

I haven't been back to the dining room--and probably won't again, seeing as comparable dim sum for less than half the price is easy to find--but I hit up the take-out counter time and again for the Imperial Salad. Let's say it again: IMPERIAL SALAD. Cabbage and candied walnuts in a citrus dressing: possibly the most delicious lunch you can get around the Embarcadero, for the price anyway. It's something like $4.00 for a single take-away serving, which is plenty for a light lunch. Grab a custard bun (about $1.50) to chase it with if you don't believe me, but I say a small salad is plenty.
author: anne s.

description:
the GOOD:
-- DELICIOUS! I'm not from San Fran, so I'm not sure how the rest of the dim-sum in california is.  However, as far as comparing this to the dim-sum in HI... this is definitely some of the best dim-sum i've ever had.
-- GOOD AMBIANCE: Again, not sure how the rest of the dim-sum in SF is, but I definitely thought the atmosphere here was good.  It's busy but really clean.  However, the noise level does get kinda loud.
-- VARIETY:  Overall they had a really good variety of dim-sum.  However, I think their desserts needed some work.  In fact, I wouldn't really recommend even dabbling with the dessert menu, it's not really worth it.

the BAD:
-- (some) PRICES:  Not everything here is a rip-off, but there were definitely a few that were highly over priced!
-- CUSTOMER SERVICE:  For dessert, I specifically had wanted to have a COCONUT chin-doi (it's like a fried mochi with coconut inside -- what I had always thought was a very basic dessert?)  Anyway, I ask the waiter for one, and they do bring a chin-doi looking dim-sum.  However, after biting into it, I see that it's dark brown, not light brown like it should be -- it also didn't really taste like coconut.  The waiter comes back to refill the water and asks how we like it, I ask "this is coconut?" and he says "no... it's lotus root."   ..........

Anyway,  aside from this slight inability to listen to what I wanted and just telling me "no we DON'T have it" -- instead of wasting my $5 on a lotus root thing....... this place was good.
author: Jennifer F.

description:
I like this place, even if it's a bit "un-authentic".  There's load of choice and everything is really fresh (!).  If something doesn't pass by your table, simply waive one of the many waiters and after some secret code spoken into their walkie-talkies, your fav plate will arrive momentarily.

My wife loves their sweet tofu as dessert in particular (mine would be the salad).  It's a bit expensive.  Also, I recommend asking to be seated inside instead of the cold atrium.
author: Philip I.

description:
i have never seen such an expensive dim sum bill in all my life. and while at any other establishment a $75 bill for two people would have ignited my inner desire to karate chop someone in the throat, somehow i was too busy rubbing my belly full of delicious manna from dim sum heaven and dropped the credit card without hesitation. 

my roommates are picky eaters (which is like saying my roommates are the antichrist, since i'm a foodie), so i was singing the hallelujah chorus when R.R. came to town for a long weekend. since she was born under a rock and didn't hear that dim sum is the new pho, i wanted to be sure to take her to try yank sing. thank goodness several trustworthy yelpers mentioned the super high price of satiety at YS, so i had a heads up before the bill came. but i have to say... pretty justifiable. YS's food is out of control good. the honey ginger sea bass was a highlight for sure; not too sweet and perfectly cooked. naturally we tried the oh-so popular bbq pork buns (sticky sweet pillows of dough with rich meaty treasure buried inside) and the juicy and delicious shanghai dumplings. the sliced bbq pork was tender and unctuous, and no i'm not ashamed that we ordered two forms of barbequed pork. 

i really want to give them five stars, because the food was that good. but i can't on principle; i just don't think dim sum is meant to be that expensive (i'll put in the ubiquitous request for half stars here, because YS should really be a 4.5). everyone should try this place at least once - just make sure you go after pay day.
author: Kris G.

description:
Believe it or not, I came back to Yank Sing for a second time because of the price. I was stunned at the bill and I thought it was miscalculated; so stunned I just paid and left scratching my head as I left the door. I had to go back a second time because I refused to believe that dim sum was that expensive. After that visit, Yank Sing made a believer out of me that it was the most overpriced restuarant I have ever been to.

Not only is this place expensive, it is almost unreasonably expensive. It is at least twice as expensive as the next most expensive dim sum restaurant I've been to. Unfortuantely for Yank Sing, the quality of the food does not scale with the cost of its dishes. Not even close. 

The food is good, but I'm still not quite sure where my money is going. The service is decent as well. Even for a late lunch around 1:30 PM , the trays keep coming with more food. 

Being the one of the few, if not only, Dim Sum restaurants in SOMA, you will end up paying a high premium for the food. Its a real shame Harbor Village in the Embarcadero Center is closed.
author: Arnold L.

description: MOST EXPENSIVE DIM SUM EVER!  $60 for two people is completely unheard of for dim sum.  $12 for 1 order of Shanghai Dumplings which comes with 6 pieces?!?!?!  Even though the food was good, I've had better and at half the cost.  Service was also spectacular by Chinese restaurant standards (expected since it's very "Americanized" here).  Validated parking is also a plus, but still not worth the ree-donk-u-lous prices.
author: Tina F.

description:
When I moved to SF, I read that Yank Sing was "one of the best Dim Sum" in the city.

I've eaten there now six times to make sure I haven't overlooked something, and I just don't get it.

Don't get me wrong, the quality of the food ranges from fair to good.  As a Dim Sum, service is virtually instant.   But I've never had anything here that was any better than just "good".

The down side is that it can be crazy expensive if you're not careful what you order.   Many of the items are tiny but still cost $10.   I had a few random things for lunch the other day and ended up paying like $45 for a slightly-better-than-strip-mall chinese restaurant quality lunch.  That was just nuts.   What a racket.
author: erin b.

description: Great dim sum but a little pricey.  Service was great, as soon as we sat down the first cart of delicious dumplings arrived.
author: Quentin F.

description:
Yank Sing will make you sing 'till you get the bill, then they will make you cry!  The Charming Boyfriend picked me up for lunch, and when we passed by Yank Sing on our way to another lunch spot, we decided to give it a try.  He'd never been there before; I had but on someone else's bill.  ;)  So I didn't know how excessively expensive it was!

We enjoyed steamed shrimp dumplings, pot stickers, the sea bass special, and he seemed to really like the pork buns.  Since dim sum is comprised of little treats, you have to eat a lot to fill up.  Consequently, the Charming Boyfriend requested an order of chicken chow mein, which was adequately tasteful, reminiscent of Chinese buffet chow mein.  They definitely are a dim sum restaurant, so stick to that!

When the bill came (a whopping $70, and written all in Chinese so we didn't know how much we'd been charged for what) we realized how naive we'd been, not ever asking how much an item cost.  And the sales routine is heavy-handed, with servers practically deciding for you that you want whatever mystery lies in that steam basket before you can even ask what it is.  

The food is okay; but it's very overpriced for what it is.  So if you go, go for dinner (who pays $70 for a lunch of dumplings and chow mein?), ask how much things are upfront, don't let them put things on your table unless you really want it, and either expect to leave with an empty stomach or an empty wallet.
author: akimbo j.

description:
I think Yank Sing vs. Ton Kiang for dim sum is a very tough call, but fortunately it's not one where you'll really make a bad choice.  With all the reviews here, a lot's already been said, but here's my two cents:

(1) Yank Sing 2 Go is as good as eat-in.

(2) They validate parking and you can park under the building (Zang!).  So you could, for example, eat dim sum, get validated (notice my clever use of layered meaning here), then walk on over to the Ferry Building for the farmer's market, come back to your car, and drive home with free parking.

(3) I prefer eating by the cool rain fountain in the atrium to eating in the restaurant - it's less crowded and more relaxed as a result

(4) The only thing I'm not crazy about is the peking duck.  Not because it's not good (it is), but because the portions are small - they sell by the slice, for goodness' sake - and so your value proposition is pretty grim.

Other than that, I've got nothing but praise.  Good shumai, spring rolls, dumplings, the cabbage salad is terrific, etc., etc.  Great way to spend a weekend morning.
author: John H.

description:
The dim sum here is very traditional stuff, but it's done right. Everything tastes great.

I go here pretty often (mostly because it's 1 block away from my work). This place is a bit pricy, i have never been able to get out of here without at least paying 25 a person, but once again, you get what you pay for. 

The food is very high quality, everything tastes freshly made, I never get the "been here since 9am" feeling that I get from some other dim sum places. 

The staff is also very good with helping you order exactly what you want, they have walkie talkies and all, it's like the black ops of dim sum serving here. It's great. 

The one food item i would highly recommend is this duck skin bun they have, it's like 8 dollars per order, but well worth it especially if it is your first time here, it is as it sounds, roasted duck skin in a bun, sounds stupid, tastes mind numbingly great, your mouth wouldn't know what hit it.
author: Bennie H.

description:
The food here isn't good. It's not even about the price because with good food, it makes up for the price. But honestly the dim sum here isn't good. I've had better at other popular dim sum joints like the koi palace. 

I have to admit their service is pretty good. What stinks the most at chinese restaurants would be the service but not at this one. They make sure your glass of water is always full and their manger comes by to make sure things are going well. 

Food carts come around pretty frequently and when you don't want an item they won't give you mean stares like at most dim sum restaurants. But really, the food doesn't taste good. Their dumplings fall right out from the skin which is not a good thing. It means they need work. The peking duck doesn't have enough flavor. The sticky rice in lotus leaf is made all wrong. That's not even the real thing. They made it their way which some people may like but I like to eat the real thing. All they have in there is meat! I see no chinese mushrooms, chinese sausage, or the egg yolk thingy. 

The one thing I do like would be there coconut creme roll. That is something that is hard to find elsewhere and it's pretty good here. Their egg custards are also worth mentioning because they are not as mini as other dim sum restaurants. They taste pretty good too. Overall, I don't think I would be coming back here for dim sum. Koi palace tastes better, more authentic with more dishes to choose from and cheaper.
author: Flora W.

description: I think this was the best dim sum I've ever had. The shrimp is so fresh and they have so much variety here! They serve items they usually serve during dinner time! The wait was not too bad for a party of 2 on a Sunday as well, so that's a plus. The only downside is the price. This place is on the pricey side, especially for dim sum. My bf and I wound up spending a whopping 100 bucks here and we ordered the same amount we would've ordered in LA.
author: Tiffany T.

description:
I would NEVER EVER come here again!!!!!!

Don't get me wrong the dim sum was good but the prices were out of control.

For 2 people our bill was a bit over $80.  Sure we got some of the specials, like a miso glazed sea bass, that was out of this world good, but it cost like $15 dollars for 6 bites. Just not worth it if I had known the price. 

The thing that made us furious and why I will never go back is that they charged us $10 dollars for tea.  I mean who has EVER been to a Chinese restaurant and been offered tea and not had it been complimentary.  We didn't order.  They asked us if we would like any, like any normal Chinese restaurant and we said sure.  I have never dined and ditched, but the outrageous prices made me want to.
author: M. S.

description:
dim sum is the quintessential cantonese brunch and yank sing has it dialed!

my dad is cantonese, an avid dim sum fan and a complete chinese-food snob. He and my mom have had Chinese food on every contient, and i've been to all the best in SF, NYC, LA and a few in beijing, shanghai, and canton. 

While i can attest that the food here is excellent, it is even more telling that my dad loved it too. both my parents thought that everything we ordered was prepared very well and the variety is amazing. perhaps the best dim sum place they have been to! They're glad to have come here once, but won't return because they can find very close-to-amazing for half the price in LA.

i found the flavor to be delicate for every dish, and 'you get what you pay for'. to have world-class dim sum in my back yard, it is definitely worth the trip.
author: Susan W.

description:
Dim Sum tends to be one of those things that vary little from place to place.  Sure, each restaurant may have some items that they specialize in but the rest of the dishes tend to be very mediocre.  Yank Sing has the best dim sum that I have tasted anywhere including the San Gabriel Valley and Hong Kong.  Though a little bit pricier, the quality of the food is high.  The baked pork buns were featured on Food Network Show, Best Thing I Ever Ate - soft doughy balls filled with sweet juicy BBQ pork.  The dumplings are perfect. The snow pea shoot dumpling as well as the spinach dumpling reaches a height of flavor that is amazingly accomplished with a lack of meat.  The Shanghai dumpling which has a pork mixture does not have that strong pork flavor.  There are others such as the lobster dumpling, goldfish dumpling (has shrimp, not what the name implies -  it is shaped like a goldfish.  But the chicken feet are literally chicken feet).  The stuffed crab claws are tasty and not greasy. My biggest problem is that that I get too greedy and want to order something from every cart that passes by and then get too full by the time some of the other carts pass by.  It is no wonder that they are the recipient of a James Beard Award. Seriously, I have booked a flight just to eat here and then come back the same day.

Best Thing - BBQ pork bun
author: Hion L.

description: Now don't get me wrong. I did not have to pay for this myself. If I did I would be broke. The best dim sum I have ever had. Period. 80$ for 2 people for lunch, well. Do the math. But holy dim sum. I still and will always remember the carts that kept coming and coming. yum yum.
author: Joseph P.

description: Despite the fame, the food here isn't as good as the Richmond area Chinese restaurants.  This place is expensive for the quality - you'll be shocked by the bill if you order a decent sized meal.  The food often comes out cold.   The hours are annoying not opening for dinner.   On the plus side the decor is nice and the service is good.  It's a bit of a tourist trap and over hyped by guide books.
author: Phd T.

description: Yes it is expensive, but it is so worth it.  They have the best shanghai soup dumpling, steamed pork buns, sticky rice...
author: Jessica P.

description:
When i took my favorite politician out for lunch for his birthday, I had no idea he'd choose the most pricey dim sung this side of the fog.
Yet really,it was worth every cent.
The staff was so electrically happy but then again I was with a regular.
Still, the food met the hubbab the birthday boy touted and I was glad to be there.  Since he was a vegetarian, they came up with all these chocies or said "o no,not for youuuu" and then laughed.
I thought, wow, everyone should have a place like this.
author: Sean S.

description: Pricey for dimsum, but as good as any dim sum I've had.   The place was packed on a Sunday afternoon, but we got a table for two immediately.   Service was pleasant and unending.  Recommend the sticky rice and the peking duck with the hoisin sauce; really it was all good, everything.   My only regret:  I ate too much.     Like I said, more than you might like to pay, but they delivered on the goods.
author: Christopher L.

description:
Delicious, but overpriced. Lunch for 4 today was delicious, but cost $120.

There is no better dim sum in SF, though.
author: Shanan D.

description: Was this place bad?  No.  Was it amazing?  Not really.  The best thing I had there was surprisingly the xiao long bao.  I don't know how I feel about a dim sum place having really good xiao long bao.  It's kind of like eating delicious sushi in a Thai restaurant.  It's great that they have it but at the same time it just seems really out of place.  Other than that, the other dishes were good but just not mind blowing.  Couple that with the high price of this place and I think I'd rather go to my favorite dim sum places in Socal like Sea Harbour in Rosemead.
author: Steven P.

description:
There was a reservation for about a dozen and like all of my personal life, I was running a little late (unlike my business life where I'm always way early),  so when I showed up there were already awesome dim sum waiting at the table. Everything looked fresh and healthy and hot.
There was a lot of asians which is a good sign at a dim sum place, as well as non asians so I guess the word was out that this was a nice dim sum place.

Someone mentioned that this one item is the best and it just melted in my mouth. Great dim sum, great location. It was a Saturday and it was packed. I don't know about the pricing because I wasn't allowed to look at the check but seeing the location and the free falling water in an office building near the Embarcadero, I'm sure it wasn't cheap.

There is parking in the garage and many people had a hard time getting in the spaces provided because it is tight with SUVs. You get it validated so it's free parking. I would certainly go back for dim sum for a date or large gatherings of friends when I'm in this area because it is a clean and well run place with friendly workers.
author: Brandon M.

description:
parking, where?  seriously, if you don't want to park in a lot around here, you might want to find another place to eat.  if you work nearby then cool, take a walk over.

this place is like its other yank sing.  i love it.  Its just a little higher priced than most dim sum places.

the quality is good, wait, great.  its smaller portions, for small portions.  the original yank sing was GREAT, it was family setting in the middle of china town on broadway street.  its not there anymore.

they opened this location and another one.  BUT they decided to go high end.  they charge an arm and a leg compared to just a finger....lol.  BUT i still love this place.  They do Dim Sum for anyone who has eaten dim sum to someone who has NEVER tried it.  BUT its pricey...so i guess if you don't mind paying a bit more COME HERE.  

I'll always find a reason to buy some food from here.  Or the To GO section they have connected to the place.
author: Bing D.

description:
One of my two favorite dim sum places in San Francisco. Shu mai to rival any other, hum bow with some of the best BBQ pork filling you'll find anywhere, BBQ pork slices in a super sweet goo unlike anything I've ever had before, carts of won ton soup, huge mounds of foil wrapped chicken, plates of savory veggies, and on and on. It's not my number one favorite and doesn't quite score that fifth star because they are missing some variety in the steamed dumplings and the rice noodle wrapped shrimp is gummy instead of slippery. 

Oh, and they take reservations. There are enough tables the wait time is usually less than an hour (not bad for Sunday dim sum), but why not call ahead the day before and only wait for 5-10 minutes?
author: Veronica L.

description:
Friends of mine took me here after a long night of drinking and I would have to say I wasn't blown away.  The variety was good, the food ok, service mediocre, and price through the roof.  We even had reservations and still waited 20 minutes...

...I will go back to see if maybe it wasn't just the previous nights vodka and gin influencing my opinion.  I don't think it will be any time soon.
author: Don I.

description:
Ok, so I was told this was THE dim sum place to go to in the City, so you can imagine how excited I was when my team went there for a team meal. It was pretty good, but it certainly wasn't the best I had ever had, which is what I was expecting given the prices they were charging. That said, I wasn't too impressed, particularly with the service. They were quite slow and inattentive to our needs, which if I were at an authentic Chinese dim sum place, I would have expected, but since this was anything but authentic and quite Westernized, I had higher hopes. In a word, I was disappointed.

If you're looking for good dim sum, just go to Chinatown. The quality of service and food are comparable, but it won't cost you an arm and a leg.
author: Ty L.

description:
The food is great. It's consistently good. The shanghai soup dumplings, the cabbage slaw with the walnuts, the peking duck, the shrimp dumplings, the mushroom dumplings, the scallop dumplings, and on and on. On the weekends they have the homemade warm tofu dessert with the sugary syrup. I don't know what it's called but I love it. 

Yes, it's expensive dim sum. Go there knowing you will be throwing down the cash then let it go. Why do you think they use those little stamps on your order card? It's so you don't know how much what you just ordered cost.  Personally, ignorance is bliss. Just keep coming around with the little cart so I can order some more okay?
author: Romeo And Lola K.

description:
Improving!

I had a bad Yank Sing experience here about a year ago, but Saturday's experience really impressed me.

How great is this?: You sit down, and within 60 seconds, you can be eating great food.

We got there right at 10:00 when they opened, and we were seated promptly. The jasmine tea was nice, and the food was improved since my last visit. The peking duck with steamed rolls and the barbecued pork buns were perfection. Shrimp shu mai did not disappoint. The deep fried crab claw was delicious, too.

Also, am I imagining it, or did they make improvements to the dining room? The teapots are new (nice simple glass ones). But I could swear they did something good to bring the dining room up to date.

Anyway, we're going back. Thanks Yank Sing, for a great, incredibly fast, delicious morning.
author: Karen Z.

description: Fairly good dim sum and good service. Their shrimp dumplings and their red cabbage salad with candied walnuts were probably my faves. Overall, I thought this place was overpriced though for dim sum.
author: Sophia B.

description:
Amazing.

(for the record: half the missing star is for being too pricey to ever want to eat there and the other half is because it's lacking more than a few of my fave tradish dishes that are probably too ghetto to take up precious real estate in their made-of-gold steamers.)
author: Mandy Z.

description:
My family of 4 went here today for lunch.  We arrived around 11:15 or so, and were sat immediately.  Service was prompt, and the food was quite good.  The soup-filled dumplings were notably very good, and I've never had them at dim sum before, so this was an excellent find.

So why 4 stars?  -1 star for the price.  I read that it was expensive, but I assumed that this must be because of the $15/plate specials, so we did not take any of those (they walk around with prawns, jellyfish, crab cakes, etc.).  Even without taking any of them, we paid $106.  In Boston, I've gone to dim sum at an excellent place with 7 people, and we pay about $56.  This was obscenely expensive.

Good food, good service, nice decor (very nice bathrooms), but holy mother-of-pearl expensive.
author: Alex B.

description:
Not a huge fan.  It's clean top of the line quality.  Great service, clean place, nice atmosphere. 

Brought my parents here, and they weren't very impressed, they said this place is the P.F. Changs of Dim Sum.  

Overall, it's good clean food, but super expensive. Family of 4 and spent around $200 here.  

Food- Clean, good, about 1/4 the size of normal dim sum food.  
They come around with dishes that cost up to $18 bucks.  

Parking- Sucks

Crowd- White, middle to upper class.  Financial working crowd.
author: Chase F.

description:
J says: Would give it 5 stars if it weren't so expensive! Top notch food and service. Love all the steamed dumplings. Definitely try the fried seaweed-wrapped tofu. Free parking in the garage on weekends. 

K says: A dim sum must. I like Koi Palace in Daly City, but I like Yank Sing more. The service is at a different level, and the quality of food is close. I'm especially fond of the xiao long bao, and could easily consume a dozen. The Boss (J) and I frequent here on the weekends, and my advice is to go early (1030am).
author: Jen Ken H.

description:
Friend A "It says $28"

Me "No, that's too little . . .maybe a messy $48?"

Friend B "Ask the waitress"

Waitress "That's $78"

Me "Oh, but of course when we are eating shrimp dishes at $10 a plate!"

What a freakin' rip-OFF. Puh-lease!!

Was it cleaner than most every dim sum place in Chinatown, the Sunset or the Richmond? Yep. A little fancier selection in ingredients? Yep.

Is that worth spending 4 times what it would cost anywhere else? Nope and nope.

Only go here if a) you have an expense account or b) are with guests who will absolutely freak out at the site of fung zao. 

Forget it, don't take the second category and let them learn the pleasure of dim sum. If you can't hang with the fung zao stick to your bran muffin folks.

Try any positively reviewed dim sum place and you'll be better off than eating here.
author: Michael H.

description:
Let me set the scene: My family and I were getting ready to head to the airport and thought it would be a good place to have lunch.  We'd been cleaning/packing all day.  I was in a stained up shirt and pants with baby food wiped on them.  

I guess it should have tipped me off when I saw the parking attendant helping people to lot.  I don't know.  But when we got there, we were asked if we minded sitting in the outer part.  Fine, fine, no big deal--it's DIM SUM, right?  Casual Saturday morning/afternoon meal with two small children. right?  No need to wait to sit inside where it looks all cozy and charming.

The food comes around--very, very good.  Mind you,  I'm a midwestern girl, so I may not be the best judge of authenticity.  But, it was tasty.  Our 4 year old loved everything.  We took one of everything practically.  We sent some things away because we didn't really care for them (and, really, what's dim sum cost?  $2-4 a plate?).  The sea bass was super fishy--and I imagine it was one of the most pricey menu items.   We dropped some chop sticks and a waiter flew in ever-so-quickly, ever so silently to replace them.  

I joked with my husband that our brunch was going to be $70-80.  He countered with, "Nah, it might be $40-50." 

When our tab came to the table--me in my stained up grunge wear, the floor covered with various things our children threw on the floor--and said $128... we were a little stunned.   I really enjoyed the food, the service was good.  But, for that kind of money, I want to sit inside, have on nice clothes, and not have my children in tow!  

Note:  If you're going to put out the big bucks to eat here--WAIT to sit inside, because other people who want the nice quiet experience wait outside and make a ruckus with their children.  This can ruin your $150 meal!

So three stars because the food and service are good--but there really should be some indication of price--even if you go into the take out part (a take out lady came to our table and asked us if we wanted anything to go) doesn't even indicate price!
author: Meri H.

description:
I took some out of towners here because:
I could make reservations
It was close to the Embarcadero
they validate parking in a garage
their specials are really special
The outside is really a patio inside the Center but it has a nice fountain
Little on the spendy side
My friends had a good time and thats what its about.
author: Gwyneth T.

description:
Had lunch here again last Sunday. Have dined here several times in the past, both for dim sum and private banquets. This review is based solely on my dine-in dim sum experiences here. 

WAY over-rated. 

Unless you prefer to pay for presentation rather than taste. 

Presentation is nice, and let's face it...dim sum houses generally are not the cleanest places in the world, and this is one of the cleaner ones. Yeah, this one actually has restrooms. LOL!

Service: "Look lady, PLEASE STOP randomly putting stuff on my table that I don't specifically ask for". Simple as that. Totally intrusive and over-bearing for the duration of the visit. 

Ambience: Gosh, I've never eaten anywhere else and been seated in the middle of a business/office-space/mall (that's closed on the weekend) that is outside of the actual restaurant . Does it get much more intimate than this?

Price: I don't think you can buy more expensive dim sum anywhere on the planet. Well, if you can, I haven't been there yet...

Saving Grace: the soup dumplings are the best anywhere in town.

Do the research, people. You can find dim sum that generally tastes just as good at a fraction of what you'd spend here all over town...Chinatown, the Richmond, the Sunset, etc.

Three stars (for having cornered and monopolized the tourist market).
author: J C.

description:
We dropped by before WICKED and we were seated right away with our reservations. Instantly food arrived and we scarfed... inhaled... I think we were almost full and checked the time... we'd only sat for 7 minutes. 

The dumplings are DELISH! The tofu dim sum were perfect, the sea bass was flaky... oh my goodness I would've just liked to stay there all day and eat. It's pricey...but worth it.

Next time I'm bringing a cooler in the car to take home dim sum after romping around in SF.
author: Queen S.

description:
No question this place has the best Shanghai dumpling in the city, No question this is also the most expensive, average dim sum in the city. Sorry I don't care how snobby/bitchy the hostesses are at Koi Palace, or the two hour wait for a table, they still have the best food. 

We sat at a table outside next to the waterfall. And for 25 minutes the only dim sum cart that rolled by our table was the Shanghai dumplings. We ended up with 3 orders. We had a total of 13 different plates (the usual stuff) the bill came to $115.00 before tip). 

Luckily, the parking was free...
author: L K.

description:
Came here in a small group for dim sum on a Sunday.  Got there late for dim sum (around 12-12:30), so it was a little bit tricky finding parking (the lot was full).  We sat in the "hotel lobby seating area" which was nice.  Probably the best service I have had for a dim sum place, also one of the cleanest.  Selection was good, the shanghai dumplings were above average, the shu mai was only ok, the rest of the dishes were pretty standard nothing to get too excited about.  

You're really paying for the service and the atmosphere, the food is average (not bad, just nothing special) and the price is pretty steep.  It was about $130 for the four of us, but then again we ordered a lot, I think :P
author: J T.

description:
The dim sum at Yank Sing is as good as anywhere in the world...maybe better.  Fantastic food, wide variety of choices and top-notch service.  We make the trip once or twice a month with our kids and we feast on ha gow, sui mai, lettuce cup with squab, PK duck, sesame ball, and on and on....   

Without question a consistent winner! and worth every nickelof the high-end $$$  Try the yogurt nearby or head over to the Bay Bridge or Farmer's Market for amazing views and/or indulgent treats!
author: Mike A.

description:
Abso-darn-lutely fantastic dim sum! The basics are very good -- shu mai, shrimp dumplings, and the like. The quality of the special dishes is great. The deep fried crab claws are large and full of meat. The Peking duck is very nicely done with a morsel of duck meat and a slab of very crisp skin along with a freshly steamed mantoh. The egg tarts are to die for, with a barely there but oh-so-flaky crust and oodles of smooth filling. 

The service is excellent as well. The table next to me had just missed a cart with plates of string beans, and asked a waitress if they could just order some. She told them no, the ones on the cart were old and cold; she would bring them fresh plates just out of the kitchen -- and she did a minute later! 

Not cheap, but definitely worth the price.
author: Paul S.

description:
I hate to be a hater (at only 3 stars) but $40/person for dim sum just seems excessive.  Yes, the location (with the cool rain fountain thing) is attractive, and the food was all quite good (though I've had better pork buns - the bun:pork ratio was too high, and the pork filling wasn't as flavorful as some I've had in the past).  The pea shoots were especially stunningly good.  Damn.
But for that price:quality, I can't go higher than 3 stars.
author: Don H.

description:
I love taking out of towners to Yank Sing for a special treat- although I do warn them up front that the average price is about $7 a plate...one time I had friends from Mississippi come to visit, they had been doing the tourist thing all afternoon and were starving...we met up at Yank Sing and ended up with a $200 lunch tab for the three of us (no alcohol!).

But I digress... back to Yank Sing, the ambience is nice, though a bit formal.  The selection is awesome, everyone always finds SOMETHING to eat that is delightful.  They will bring you special requests if you are vegetarian, and will communicate your needs to the other carts...the carts...The carts are plentiful...sometimes a bit too plentiful (it can be slightly annoying to be in the middle of telling a story, only to be interrupted by a cart...3 times...so you are constantly having to say "no thanks" in the midst of story telling).  

Bottom line, this is a nice place, good service, yummy food, nice atmosphere...I would give it 5 stars, but it's a bit pricey for the portions.
author: t j.

description: I'm definitely a regular here - weekends Yang Sing is among the best breakfasts you can have. Focus on the steamed dumplings and you'll be golden.
author: Rob G.

description: I only like the xiao lung bao (shanghai dumplings) and the nai huang bao  (egg yolk bun) there. Thats it
author: Cindy L.

description: Cream cheese crab wontons? Cream cheese in dim sum? Get real. Some of the food here has little resemblance to real dim sum. The food is expensive but the flavors and quantity needs adjusting. For example, their beef chow fun that costed me over 10 dollars but came in a child size portion and was as oily and bland as a dish you might get at Panda Express. The positives? Nice atmosphere, clean bathrooms, and generally good service but I don't consider this as a good representation of Chinese dim sum. If you come, be prepared to spend about 50 dollars on lunch for two people and leave hungry.
author: Lorissa W.

description: Probably one of the best dim sum experiences Ive had to date. Fresh clean flavors and presentation.. very nice surroundings. However very pricey though one of my dear friends bought otherwise this place would have been knocked for sure.  The duck sandwiches were out of this world!
author: Alexander C.

description:
I can confidently say that this is the best dim sum in the world.  Their soup dumplings rival all dim sum I've had in Singapore and Korea.  Basically, its amazing.  Yeah, its a little expensive, but its worth it.  If you're a starving college student, just take a bunch of friends with you and split the bill.  All you need is:
Tea
Shanghai dumplings.  A.k.a the soup dumplings.  There are six in one order.
Steamed bbq pork buns.  I believe there are two in an order.  

The service is really good, even though its normally ridiculously busy.  The only wait you'll have is the wait for a table.  And if you can't wait without a bite to eat, head over to Yank Sing To Go for a quick bite.  I recommend getting an order of baked bbq pork buns as a pre-lunch snack.  But get there early!! They sell out of the baked buns fairly quickly. 

Basically, if you have a chance to go to Yank Sing, go.  Its not often a dim sum restaurant will be better than a place in Singapore.  Trust me, I would know.
author: Hanah C.

description: I've come here with a group of co-workers. They are busy but never neglect their customers. The dim sum are not very authentic, some of the items you will not find in China, but they are tasty nontheless.
author: Kate J.

description:
This is a review by a vegetarian!
20 bucks plus tip for a filling midweek lunch, dessert included!
the vegetarian options were great. as soon as we told them we were veggie, they contacted the kitchen and got us spinach, mushroom, curry and another dimsum. They also got us hot crispy onion cakes...yummy...
They also had a nice pot of tea and tons of other veggie stuff like string beans, broccoli, snow peas etc.
the outside area is nice and open, partly covered. during a busy weekday lunch hour, we got a seat in 5-7 mins!
author: Soniya R.

description:
OK, I love dim sum.  I grew up on dim sum.  But I have a real problem paying $58 for four dishes and one chicken chow mein.  I mean, REALLY?!  The food is good.  The service is good.  There is no doubt about that.  It's fresh and they have some unique dishes that other dim sum houses don't carry (like Peking Duck, sea bass, or even crab cakes).  But the price?  Until I make CEO someday and can expense all my meals, this is a 'very special occasion' place for me.

One thing you do have to watch out for - getting charged  for double portions.  Certain items when you order (e.g. spring rolls) come with  two rolls on a plate.  If you see four rolls on your dish, then that means you're going to be charged for two orders.  I was just there today and they tried to give us four rolls - and I had to tell them "only one order please."  Dumplings usually come in fours, so those are OK.
author: Denise M.

description: This restaurant is the best.  Get the Pork Buns and Egg Rolls./
author: Skeff T.

description:
Very pricey but excellent dim sum.

You know the carts that come around and you can tell the items on them have been circulating for a while -- you don't pick those, right? Well, at Yank Sing, you almost never see those items because everything is delicious and is snapped up right away.

Now, I know it's not cheap...I mean, it's REALLY NOT CHEAP. But I can say that after more than 10 visits here with family, friends, and just the two of us, I have never been disappointed.
author: Karen C.

description:
Awesome dim sum!  Vegetarian and vegan friendly, although some of the servers need to be reminded.  The floor supervisor/manager was paying so much attention that he caught us about to eat something non-vegetarian and actually intervened.

Place gets super busy though, so beware.  Not a cheap meal, but well worth it!  Not getting a 5-star because they could try harder on the vegetarian/vegan selection.
author: Nelson A.

description:
This is the #1 places to go if you haven't #2ed in a while!

Its hard for me to say its the "Best Dim Sum" place ever, but for the location and I would say fairly reasonable prices, this is THE Place to go for chinese food around the Embarcadero area, especially

Granted, this was my second time at the place. My virgin meal was a Chinese Chicken Salad and it was above average because the salad was fresh, the sauce was a bit too salty for my tastebuds. Todays meal was the "Phoenix" which basically is a side of fried rice, chow mein, 2 pot stickers, 1 egg roll and 1 sui mai for $5.75 + Tax. 

As I was waiting for my food, the clown bus came in and the line was out of the store almost to the Thai to go express place. Strange, people must be following me or something.

Usually I hate eatting at food courts, so I brought back the feast and when I opened it, the noodles were still hot. It was really good the first 4 bites, then ... I noticed how much freaking OIL there was in the noodles! Both the top and bottom of the tray were well lubercated (not in a good way, might I add). The potstickers and eggroll was good, and actually had less oil than the noodles.  The fried rice, was well, fried rice.. not overly salty, but enough to make me go drink 32ounze of water for lunch...

3 hours after lunch, I am still feeling the affects of the noodles. Yes, they do give you a LOT of noodles, for a decent price, like Lee's Deli, but like Lee's Deli, this is an oil drenched meal.  

Time to work out. Good, but I wouldn't recommend eatting it EVERYDAY.... I'll go back, but I wont order the same thing again for sure..
author: Wilson L.

description:
Great dim sum. The place was cleaner/a little fancier than most of the dim sum restaurants in Chinatown, but with this higher quality comes a higher price. The location of Yank Sing is a dead giveaway though--it's located in SOMA, right near a ton of companies and the Financial District. I don't blame them for having high prices here.

Service was fast and efficient though. They also have a Yank Sing 2 Go next door for those on the run. Nice location, but I will probably only go here on special occasions. I'll go to Chinatown for cheap dim sum in the meantime.
author: Helene K.

description:
My sugar momma Hel offered to take me out for lunch on my last day working in the city. So being that she spotted this in Zagat before we decided to try it.

We got seated in this desolate corner behind a pillar, which usually means urban wasteland ie. lack there of food when it comes to dimsum, but it actually wasn't so bad. Since it was near the tea refill station we constantly had waiters walking by so we would just ask them to get whatever we wanted. 

The Chinese broccoli was cold. Not sure if that was intentional. But the Siau Loong Bao was really good. Thin wrapper with the yummy soup. Then the har kau and siu mai was good as well. The pork buns were meh, as I normally don't waste space in stomach for pork buns during dim sum and prefer to fill it with seafood or beef. The atmosphere was great however and the tea pots were so swank, I wanted to put one in my purse and take it home with me :)

All in all not bad.
author: Jessica C.

description:
How is it possible that I haven't reviewed this place yet?  My dad and I have been having lunch at this restaurant for YEARS!  When I was a kid we'd go to the old location on Battery Street.  They've been at this location for a while now, but the food is just as delicious as ever.  One of the best things is that they're constantly putting new things on the menu, but the old favorites never seem to disappear either.  I've tried other dim sum places, and I always compare them to Yank Sing.  The best part of the meal is the black bean chili pepper sauce you can mix into the soy sauce as a dipping sauce for the dim sum.  I miss it when I go to other restaurants and highly recommend you try it!

Parking is easy, as they have a valet in the garage.  Just don't bring any big cars, cause the spaces are tiny!  The restaurant will validate your parking stub, so it's even free!  Can't get much better than that in the city.

The restaurant is off of a beautiful atrium in an office building, and on the weekends the tables in the atrium are used by Yank Sing.  Weekdays it's all inside, but doesn't feel cramped or anything.  No cell service, but it's rude to talk on your phone at a restaurant anyway.  One word of advice: make reservations!  As big as this place is, it is always crazy packed.

My favorite things to order: jasmine tea, shrimp dumplings, chicken and mushroom dumplings, the signature pork dumplings that come with a red vinegar sauce, chicken in lettuce cups, red cabbage salad, and either egg custard or sesame balls for dessert.
author: Lindsay B.

description:
food: best dim sum in sf. i said sf. koi palace isnt in sf
decor: inside is nice. but if you come on the weekend, you might have to sit in the atrium.
service: above average.
price: one of the few times chinese food is hella money
verdict: if your willing to pay for it. its worth it.. trust me.

sidenote: one star off cause i noticed if you sit out side you dont get as good service or selection
author: Ricky Y.

description:
On a trip to San Francisco, I just had to stop at the famous Yank Sing for some dim sum.  Yank Sing is by far the nicest dim sum restaurant I've been to.  

My husband enjoyed the many plates of Dim Sum but the one memorable dish is their soup dumplings.  Probably the most expensive soup dumplings I've ever eaten, they were worth every bite.  
I would have given this place 5 stars but the food is way pricey.  I know this is SF but I was sort of sticker shocked when we paid up front.  Despite the price, I would definitely visit Yank Sing again and those memorable soup dumplings.
author: Hazel G.

description:
We had our wedding here - and it was more than what my inner-bridezilla expected. The busy atrium is transformed in the evening. The banquet food was top notch. All the guests were stuffed with the 10 course meal. It's not cheap - so if you go in knowing your are spending top dollar for Chinese food - you'll be fine.

I enjoy their dim sum too. I feel that too many Chinese restaurants load up the MSG and grease. I think Yank Sing does a nice job and is completely authentic.
author: Wendy L. V.

description:
I remember learning "brigand" and "exorbitant" as vocab words in 7th grade. Little did I know these words would come in handy more than a decade later in a sentence to review Yank Sing. Here goes:

The urban brigands at Yank Sing extort exorbitant fees for the privilege of their dimsum. Sure, the food is delicate, tasty and fresh, but it's DEFINITELY overpriced. What's worse is that the prices are unknown to you until the bill comes. $90 for 2 people for a small lunch? You have GOT to be kidding me. There are many other places I'd rather blow that kind of money on.
author: Lillian L.

description:
This is the Dim Sum version of a Brazilian steakhouse. Nice place, decent dim sum... great mimosas. I loved the chicken steamed buns... mmm. The dessert was ok. Some of the dim sums were pretty oily, which I think is half the fun... we also got a yummy red cabbage salad. 
Then the bill came... OMG $30 a head! ( Note to self ALWAYS check on yelp before going to a place) Totally overpriced but good dim sum. The price took the wind out of my sails.
author: Pooja S.

description:
Don't get me wrong, if taste/service are the only considerations, Yank Sing would get a 5 star from me. But when you take value into the equation, I have to knock a couple of stars off.

As soon as you walk in,  you know this is not a typical Chinese restaurant. The decor is really nice, the waitstaff are dressed in spiffy uniforms, the tea comes in a nice glass pot that's not chipped or stained. The clientele is at least half Caucasian for one thing, which is usually a bad sign, but oddly enough, the dim sum here is wonderful. The cheung fan is one of the best that I've had in North America, even Hong Kong ... although at USD$18-$20 a plate, it'd better be! This dim sum would normally only be $3-5 at other Chinese restaurants. We ordered a range of dim sum and not a dud in the lot, we loved everything. We were also impressed with their own brand of black-bean-chili condiment which tasted wonderful with many of the dim sum.

Anyway, we walked in here without knowing the prices and it was a really rude shock to walk out with a $100 bill for a dim sum lunch for 2 people. The cheung fan was especially outrageously priced. We didn't order that many things either.
author: Alice Y.

description:
Plenty of other Yelpers have had their say about Yank Sing, so I'll keep it quick & simple.  

The Food - exceptional variety and good flavors

The Ambience - clean, white-table cloth, fancy schmancy compared to Chinatown dives

The Crowd - mostly FiDi business crowd

The Service - fast & efficient and sometimes too obtrusive.  So many carts, so many Chinese ladies interrupting to tell you what they have.  It's hard to carry on a coherent conversation - but you won't go hungry.

The Price - EXPENSIVE
author: Lxs S.

description:
Loud and expensive, but I love the soup dumplings so much, it makes me want to cry.  I think I could eat 2 full orders on my own.  All of the dumplings are good, but the soup dumplings are out of this world, and for some reason, of all the times I'd been there, they never offered them to me until today -- such a travesty!  If you're going to Yank Sing, pace yourself -- I always make the mistake of getting 5 things immediately, and not waiting to see what else is coming, and this isn't the best thing to do.  I recommend calling the day you are going for reservations, because you'll still have to wait, but not nearly as long as if you go without calling.

Hey, why were the women across from us wearing sunglasses and a racoon cap in the restaurant?
author: robyn s.

description:
I did not have high expectations for this place at all - thinking its going to be your regular average dim sum choices for rediculous outragous financial district prices. 

Well, i had 1 part wrong -This is definately one of the best dim sums I've had anywhere in the bay area. It really stands out. There are dim sim delights here that I've never seen or heard at any other place before. and items were not just created half assed to be creative or to have quanitity to chose from. Everything we had here was better than any other dim sum places had to offer.

The other part, i was not mistaken was the prices. They are shockingly high. The thing is, you dont realize how much any of these items are as you point out what you like, and the waiter makes markings on your card. 

By the end of our meal, for the 2 of us, WITHOUT drinks, came out to be about $90. NO JOKE. The amount of food we had was no different then if i were to eat at any other chinatown joint, which would've costed about $30 , or $40 at the most. This was pretty shocking, and so I will probably not go here again, but keep the memories of a good lunch.
author: Mai T.

description:
Went on a weekend which means parking is free.

Really quick and yummy meal. Everything we ate was vegetarian and was prepared really well.

The place is loud.

I would go back many times when I am in the area.
author: Bret O.

description:
Wow.  It IS expensive.  Over the top, turn your pockets inside out, feel like you need a shower afterwards expensive.  

But those damn Shanghai soup dumplings keep calling us back.  The food in general is really good, not greasy, not too salty. 

It's a great place for out of town guests, or for people who might be afraid of dim sum, you know who you are.
author: John L.

description:
in my opinion, the classiest, most delicious, though-pricey dim sum in the bay area.


you can't go wrong, do lunch one time and thank me later.
author: Braden K.

description:
Let me first warn you that eating dim sum at Yank Sing is not easy on the wallet. It's pricey but WORTH IT! Yank Sing can do no wrong on dim sum and we keep coming back for more, and more, and more... 

Their Xiao Long Bao (Shanghai dumplings) are to die for. You can't be satisfied with just 1 order. Trust me. 

It's always crowded so before you go be sure to make a reservation. BTW, parking is validated at the Rincon Center.
author: Yen G.

description: This place has AMAZING xiao lung bao.  The dim sum is also really good and its got to be THE prettiest place to get dim sum.  It is basically in a really pretty office building and you sit in the middle of the lobby.  They also offer free parking int he garage.  If you're in SF, definitely come check it out!
author: Stephanie C.

description: Before i took my kids to yank sing this weekend, i had not been there since i held my son's red egg ginger party there 8 years ago. food is still very good  but i had no idea pricing had gone up that high.  i almost fell over when i saw the bill...   yes, the dim sum is very fresh..but the 'experience' wasn't original enough to feel good about the cost.  however, i do see that it opens up the dim sum experience to people who might not feel comfortable walking into a traditional tea house.   i can't eat here every weekend, but will probably come again if i have guests in town.
author: n y.

description:
We had a wonderful experience at this favorite dim sum sf spot, but i have to say the service is a bit pushy,at least wait for people to sit down before laying food on the table. the dumpling were by far the star, sea bass was great along with a couple of chicken dishes, the sticky rice was good, but some of the veggie were lacking in flavor or freshness.
must make reservation, it gets busy and loud early at lunch time
author: Giu G.

description:
Skimming through some of the reviews I truly wonder how many are really Chinese even though they claim to be.  The yellowness in you is really pale if you give this place 5 stars.  Or you are just easily impressed by average Chinese food.

This place is horribly overrated.  The wine flights are on the only reasonably priced items in the entire menu where yuppie wine bars will charge you twice the price.

The food is ok, not terrible but not what I would call good.  Koi Palace blows this place out of the water and even places like ABC in Foster City, or Dynasty in Cupertino serve better dim sum.  I haven't tasted shrimp dumplings as dry as the Saharas since I bought frozen ones for the microwave.  And some of the dumplings are only served in two.  Are you kidding me?  Is this supposed to the Chinese version of "It's a Small World"?  Do I look anoxeric or on a diet to you?  Hell, I'm not an NFL linebacker but I sure as hell need a decent amount of food to be full.

The ambiance and prompt service make up for the food to notch it 3 stars, but I will not come back to this place again for dim sum.
author: John D.

description:
Two words: soup dumplings. Regardless of what you call them, they are morsels of heaven. No longer does man have to slum it with dumplings in soup...we can all enjoy soup in a dumpling. 

I've only had them at 3-4 other places, but have gone out of my way to return to Yank Sing for theirs.
author: Matt P.

description:
No kool aid for me. 

The best thing about my visit was that the service was quite wonderful and attentive from the greeters, carts and wait staff. However, I found the dim sum sadly, nothing horrible but nothing exciting either and it's pretty much the only disappointment I've had in a long time.  

The menu (mid morning on a Sunday) had the usual (and I thought, a little boring), was an ok. I definitely expected more quality and variety for the price and will not be returning or recommending. There are better places in the Bay Area that's just as clean, fresh and attentive for the price points!
author: T C.

description:
Superb dim sum-- maybe the best I've ever had (and I eat a lot of dim sum). 

First off, you know this is going to be an expensive place when they trot out the super cool transparent teapots with self infusers-- these are beautiful, and the tea they contain is fragrant, hot and delicious (I was served jasmine). 

Service: Wonderful. Easy, relaxed and professional. What I really like about Yank Sing that other dim sum cart places seem to falter on is their approach. The cart ladies here don't try to hard sell you their wares. They simply explain what is available and then let you make up your mind. If you don't want something, they are very polite and thank you for considering their cart.  It makes the meal that much nicer when you don't have employees trying to push stuff off on you  because its getting cold or its a high ticket item or whatever. 

What I had: 

Shanghai Dumpling
shrimp dumpling (ha gao)
sweet rice dumpling

Everything was just delicious. The ha gao were perfect. Their famous Shanghai dumpling didn't disappoint, but at 11 dollars for six dumplings they'd better not have. I especially enjoyed the sweet rice dumpling, which was a fried item but wasn't greasy at all. 

Ambience: This is a popular place, so the dining room was busy. The room itself is elegant and pleasant, airy and large. The majority of the customers were Caucasian,  although I saw some Chinese as well, but I get the feeling this place doesn't exactly cater to the locals. I could see out of town tourists really getting into this place...the waiters speak clear English and the menu is catered to a western palate-- lots of fried items, and peking duck at dim sum. Whatever. 

I spent $30 for myself including tip for three dishes. Mucho dinero por the dim sum, mi amigos. You've been warned.
author: Tamara G.

description: Crazy busy on weekends. Always happy With my meals here...
author: Sean W.

description:
Having eaten dim sum more than 100 times in the Bay Area, Yank Sing is NOT worth the hype. There are many other great places in San Francisco where you can find great dim sum at an affordable price. Unfortunately, Yank Sing is not one of them.

While Yang Sing has a great variety of dim sum options, the price for what you get is a little mind blowing. When you go to a place where an average dim sum dish costs more than $5 and goes up as high as $11, it's disappointing when the dim sum is not the best you've ever had. At most dim sum restaurants in San Francisco or throughout the Bay Area, you can expect most dishes within the price range of $2-5. At that price range, you can expect very high quality dim sum with reasonable service and hot dishes. Yang Sing costs at least twice as much and it's not worth it, even if the service is great. 

Pros:
- Great setting and ambience
- Wide variety of dim sum options

Cons:
- Price (Way overpriced!)
- Small portions
- Poor value

If you have never had dim sum and have the money to spend, go ahead and try Yank Sing. 
If you want great dim sum but want to watch your wallet, try dim sum restaurants in the Richmond District in SF, Oakland Chinatown, Millbrae, or San Mateo . You'll be more than satisfied with your dim sum meal and service.
author: Chris M.

description: This place is great! While it seemed hopeless to find parking on the street, they actually have their own parking. You walk into the venue which houses the restaurant, and there is an artificial waterfall in the middle of a large, open center. We walked into the restaurant and were seated right immediately.  Within seconds, the servers (there were probably 15) were pushing carts full of delicious dumplings and other items and stopping to satisfy our desires! The service was excellent. The food is delicious--all of it! And we almost left without trying the lotus seed rice ball with sesame seeds on top (a dessert)... wow! it was really something special. i don't like to go to the same place twice, but I will DEFINITELY be heading back there.
author: Djamila D.

description: OH MY GOD....SO INCREDIBLY YUMMY!   Went there for the first time a few weeks ago. Now granted it was the first time I had ever eaten Dim Sum but does that really matter when the food is super delicious? It was a Sunday and it was packed so we had to wait about 30 minutes. I swear once we sat down the lady came by with a cart and we got to choose our first plate. I really have no idea exactly what we ate but it was all good. Tons of choices even for desserts. The only thing I didn't like is that refills on drinks were not free and they didn't tell us and they were really slow when it came to getting more drinks. The food was fresh and you don't feel all greasy after you eat which is great. I can't wait to go back! But make sure if you go to bring some money it isn't cheap but not super super expensive...it's just you can't stop eating which adds up.
author: Nizza S.

description: I love this place. I mean I could bathe in dim sum from here and probably live to be 300 years old. The environment is great. The wait staff is attentive and something with shrimp and yummy juice is out of this world.
author: T S.

description:
Best dim sum in SF. Great Shanghai soup dumplings and all the usual suspects, excellent service, free parking on weekends, and did I mention the smokin' hot hostess? The custard buns are orgasmically good, but you generally have to order them specially (they take about 20 minutes to steam) and they often run out.

Not cheap --- in Boston's Chinatown there used to be an amazingly reliable rule that no matter how much you ate it would turn out to be $10/person, but here it's more like $30 each. Then again, this place is way nicer.
author: Milhouse V.

description:
This place has tasty dim sum.  The rice wrappings on the dumplings and rice rolls were tight and thin.  Yet, strong enough not to break when you picked them up.  The egg custards were creamy and flaky and the sweet tofu was slightly sweetened and very light.  The chicken feet was soft with a hint of chili and it wasn't drowning in sauce.

I especially liked the way they served the rice wrapped in lotus leaves.  They cut the tops off the dish and give you a spoon to serve yourself with.  Most places only cut the dish in half and it's up to you to figure out a way to get the rice out.

However, eating here is PRICEY.  We were charged $8.80 for one slice of duck and one bun.  And, I'm talking about a small slice of duck.  Our jaws dropped after seeing that and we thanked god that we only ordered one.
author: Bernard F.

description:
I like going early on a Saturday morning.  It doesn't seem as busy as their Sunday mornings.  

The favorite item on the menu that I can't really fine done well anywhere else is the shanghai dumplings, which are dumplings with soup inside. The  broth is delicious and the dumpling is not overcook or hard where it is sealed closed at the top.

If you want baked pork buns, you have to order it.  They are nice and large and covered with sweet honey.

It can get expensive here, which is why I won't give it a full 5 stars.
author: Cathy A.

description:
Something's missing that was there before....

So I used to go here frequently to get my Dim Sum cravings taken care of- and I went there last week and it was just ok.... I dont know if the kitchen staff had changed or maybe they were having a bad day?

Yank Sing has the dumpling with the soup inside (shanghai dumpling i think its called) which is their specialty- and its good.

But this place is pricy for a Dim Sum place- if ur really hungry this might not be for you!
author: Nini D.

description: As a big dim sum fan sad and sorry to say this experience was Disappointing.     Have been here in the past and remembered it to be better,  and brought an out of town guest for what I thought may best represent SF's best dim sum.  Some of the dumplings were stale and everything was overpriced for what was offered.    Either Yank Sing has lost their touch or it was an off day.   Fortunately they validated the parking stub in Rincon Center.    Shrimp/scallion dumplings and sesame balls were good but did not make up for overall mediocre experience this time.  Will look for another place for dim sum before coming back here.
author: Elen S.

description:
Get your wallet out$$$$$ 

 I went with a friend and we typically have dim sum at Canton House.  This time we decided to try something different.  I soon learned it was good to try something different because the food was amazing and I would highly recommend this place to anyone.  If you have never had dim sum before this would be a great place to start.  Staff is warm and caring, restaurant is VERY clean, easy to get a table...  etc

We were shocked to find out our bill was $80.00 for two people.  We did try a lot of items since this was our first time there...  but....  wow - $80.00.  That is a hella lot when it comes to dim sum in San Francisco.  

Make this your special occasion dim sum spot.
author: Richard J.

description: One of the best dim sum places I've been to EVER... so glad yelp led me here.  Everything we had was amazing, very fresh.  The service was excellent, I'm so impressed with how well run the business is especially with how busy it is.  Great Soup Dumplings yum, sticky rice, sui mai all good,  peking duck was just ok for us...  etc.  $80 for 2 people, Definitely not cheap but worth every penny.
author: Tonya S.

description: this location has a cool waterfall and is a nice place to visit on a weekend before you take a walk around downtown sf or the wharf. Its v. good dim sum. Not oily and it doesn't leave you with that heavy feeling that one usually gets when you eat dim sum.The last time I went I was craving steamed BBQ pork bun and theirs was so good that I wanted to take some home with me, but I decided not to and regretted it. the bread was soft and creamy and when you break into the bun and take a breath of the steamy goodness you mouth waters a little bit just before you bite into a the tender sweet pork within. Man, now I want one! grrrr!
author: Theresa D.

description:
Leaving college and Seattle behind was hard for me to do. I especially miss my friends who I get to see once in a blue moon, so when I hear two of them (brothers) are in town, I jump at the chance to see them.

And, if seeing them involves having Dim Sum at Yank Sing with their entire extended family, I'm ok with that. 

Nothing says "I'm a good friend" like having to combine a reunion with an introduction to the family and the standard quizzing of your future goals, etc.

The food is really great and the service is impeccable. The location, however, is not so good. I would recommend the Yank Sing on Stevenson. 
The only saving grace is the free-falling water fountain in the middle. It provides a nice white-noise background and you can be entertained for hours watching the little kids play around in it - scaring the shit out of their parents. Awesome.
author: Ali L.

description:
This is definitely the best dim sum around, but way too expensive.

Clean, attentive service, well crafted dishes.

I do find the waitress that goes around the dining room area asking if you want to order anything to-go to be slightly annoying.
author: shaun l.

description:
wedding banquet here tonight.  Great friendly services.  Foods was excellent tonight and I have no complain.  

One best damn wedding party I ever had.  I love it.
author: food lover t.

description: Definitely worth trying. I went here last time I was up in San Fran and the food was delicious. We even had 2 dim sum virgins with us and they loved it. My only complaint is that they seemed to take forever bringing the different carts around, and not all of the servers were able to tell us what the food was... Granted 3 of us didnt need to be told, but 2 did. The parking situation isnt any worse than the rest of the city, but if you dont like walking then you may want to try somewhere else.
author: Jeanne P.

description: Delicious dumplings, buns, and pudding on wheels cost approximately $100+ (without tip) for 3.
author: Tiff T.

description: You have got to be kidding me.  Yes, I do understand that the location and the atmosphere is worth something, but this place is ridiculous.  The dim sum was average and the prices are 2-3x that of other places with similar quality.  I have been to some expensive dim sum places in New York and in Hong Kong and the better ones delivered innovative and very fresh tasting food, so you feel like you at least get something for your money.  For Yank Sing, you pretty much get better atmosphere if you are lucky enough to sit outside of the restaurant in the Rincon atrium.  If you are in the restaurant, then you have basically been ripped off because the food is a bit better than average.  If you have to be in this part of the city, then you don't have too many options, but if you can venture into Chinatown or even better, go out to the Richmond or even as far as Cupertino, you will have a much better and much more authentic overall experience.
author: Scott C.

description: While I am not the biggest fan of dim sum, Yank Sing does it right, and I firmly believe I could live off of Shanghai Dumplings for at least a week. The only obstacle preventing Yank Sing from receiving a 5th star was price,  $100+ for two people at lunch time is a little extreme, especially when the ingredients being used aren't that high-end (i.e. no truffles etc...). My favorites are the Shanghai Dumplings and the Crispy Duck, but there are multiple other things which I cannot pronounce that are very, very good. Yank Sing is a fun place to go every once in a while and if you have any doubts about dim sum make sure to give this place a chance before you make any final judgments.
author: Nick C.

description: Overpriced, yes. Way overpriced. But some of the best dim sum I have ever had. Definitely the best service at a dim sum restaurant that I have ever experienced - friendly, knowledgeable, accommodating. Beautiful setting too, at the Rincon Center, and they validate parking in the building, which almost makes the cost of dinner worthwhile. Don't miss the (way too expensive but so good!) sea bass or the (soupy, tasty, amazing) shanghai dumplings. The peking duck is a tease; I'd rather have a platter of just  the perfectly crisped, flavorful duck and skip the doughy buns.  I would go back to Yank Sing sure...if someone else paid, that is. Make it a special occasion destination and try not to blow the wad in the first fifteen minutes, and it's worth it.
author: Chava Libbe S.

description:
I don't like when dim sum places are flooded with gringos, but this place is definitely really good, albeit very pricey.

I only go here when someone else invites me, and would never go on my own. Nevertheless, each time i've gone, I've had a good time (as long as I don't go overboard and spend like 30 bucks on myself).
