The Shanghai dumplings are a must here. Some of the dim sum options are pretty nifty and look very pretty, and I suppose the main reason to come here versus a more standard place.
author: Bernie L.

description:
Waitresses who can speak English are great when you're out with non-Asian friends. But even when I go there with my parents (who are clearly older Chinese), they still speak English to us, every time a cart comes around! This is actually quite annoying, because none of us know the English names to dim sum dishes, and we always have to ask them to "translate" back into Cantonese.

(Admittedly, my own Cantonese is terrible, but names of dim sum dishes is one of the things I *can* understand.)

Anyway, here's a tip for Yank Sing, or any other dim sum restaurant. Your staff seem to all be capable of speaking in English, Cantonese, and Mandarin. That's great. So once you've established a table's language preference, why not mark the check with some symbol so that all the severs know to use the right language when hawking the goods? Wouldn't this make life easier for your staff *and* your customers?

It seems so simple, yet no one does it. Maybe I should patent this idea...

Oh yeah, the food. Well, I'll just echo everyone else's opinions - great quality, though not the best, and definitely overpriced. Good choice for dim sum virgins and out-of-towners.
author: Walter L.

description:
Who doesn't love a good Yak?

The food is 5 star, but in an effort to be fancy pants, they've priced their food above what dim sum SHOULD cost.  To me, part of the joy of dim sum is that it's not too expensive......Yak Sing did not get the memo.  

That being said, I have eaten here more times than i can count.  The to go area is fast and yummy.  Life without pork buns just isn't worth living.
author: Nikki c.

description:
Dim Sum does not get better than this. Absolutely delicious, wide variety, top quality ingredients make this my favorite Dim Sum spot in the US. Expect Yank Sing to set the bar far above what you are used to for dim sum standards and they also have some creative new items (e.g. sliced Peking duck with steamed seashell buns or cilantro/shrimp/water chestnut dumplings).

Upscale and polished, Yank Sing is an ideal place to take dim sum newbies or seasoned pros. Prices are about four times what you would pay anywhere else but the food is truly memorable.
author: Andrew B.

description: 4 starts just for the chili sauce I am already missing.
author: Nicolas C.

description:
The dim sum at Yank Sing is the best!

My absolute favorites are the stuffed lotus leaf (no mai gai), shanghai dumplings (siu loong bao), pork spare ribs (pai gwut), and baked pork buns (gook char siu bao - steamed is good too).  My husband loves the egg custard (dan tat).

I've also had dinner banquet at Yank Sing for my cousin's wedding, the service was impeccable and the food delicious.

Hard core Chinese people hate to love this place, it's super expensive and the dim sum waitresses serve in English!  However, the quality and the taste of the food is undeniable.  My parents ask to eat here every time they come up regardless.

Only showstopper negative item is that they serve shark's fin.  For my cousin's wedding, she specifically asked for no shark's fin, and they accomodated a version of the same soup w/o.  That's pretty much the only reason I didn't deduct a star.
author: Burrito M.

description:
I don't do many SF restaurant reviews since I don't eat out here much anymore. I worked in the City for over 13 years, but now traffic and the Bay Bridge mess usually keeps me away from any fun stuff. 

This is my co-worker/friend's favorite dim sum place. I say "place" because I've never really eaten in the restaurant part. I think fancy dim sum is an oxymoron and paying too much for ho-hum appetizers is silly. I would go back with Kendall, but never run here for the food. The atmosphere is more interesting than the usual dining room dim sum, but is it really worth it?
author: Janet P.

description:
the dim sum here is pretty good.  it is a bit pricy, but most likely because they cater to caucasians and have to have a certain environmental standard else their customer base be appalled by the service and dirty chairs/tables.  

it is obvious though that the chefs use some creative juices in making their dim sum a bit different than your standard dim sum places for the asian crowd that is tired of the har gow, shui mai and chai sui bao.  

i even liked the tea.
author: Wayne L.

description: Best vegetarian dim sum I ever had! Hard to find any dim sum with vegetarian options BUT San Francisco has soooo many options! I love how well it caters to our crowd! LOVED this place!
author: Priya M.

description: Amazing dim sum! The best in San Francisco. Visitors shouldn't miss it.
author: Karla C.

description: Overpriced. Not as authentic as Chinatown although very tasty. Basically for white people who are afraid of realdim sum. Went to great eastern the next day and got twice as much food for $6 less and it tasted just as good if not better.
author: Howie J.

description: I used to love this place. Then I became a foodie and got pickier on taste. Now I don't think I'll ever choose to come back. I'm a pescatarian, am allergic to cilantro and almost ever vegetarian or shrimp dish had cilantro! The shrimp rice roll had it (but thankfully I could specially order one without), the vegetable curry dumpling, some shrimp and cilantro dumpling that was sort of triangular, the mushroom dumpling, and it came on the side of the walnut and shrimp dish (although the last one was easily avoidable). The Ha Gow was one of the worst I've had. Its like  an imitation shrimp ball inside a rice skin. Not yummy. TC Pastry on Irving tastes much fresher and much more natural (natural pieces of shrimp and some waterchestnut in a thin, moist rice skin? delish!) The green beans with dried shrimp and ginger was my favorite here. Very flavorful! My second favorite was the spinach dumpling (I hope it didn't have cilantro and that my reaction was only to the curry dumpling). The rice roll w/shrimp was good after i ordered it without cilantro and the walnut shrimp was pretty good, but just like any other dim sum place. The sesame ball was good. My friend had ordered chicken buns close to the beginning of the meal but didn't come until after everyone had finished eating dessert...
author: Alice R.

description:
Pork and ginger dumplings.

Just get a dozen orders of those. You won't be disappointed.
author: Pamela B.

description:
YANK it and SING....

BLOODY hell...is that my dumpling ya YANK-ing on!!!!!!!!
author: miriam b.

description:
Yank Sing is pretty good for dim sum in the city and we have been here repeatedly. I'm looking forward to my next visit this weekend!

Food/quality: I enjoy the little dragon dumplings here as the broth inside is always hot, tastes great, and is never too salty. The dumpling with the mushrooms is great too, especially since I am not a huge fan of mushrooms. Most of the other items I have tried are great. There's this one item that isn't available unless you order it, so I bet they would make other items if you make a request.

Service: The service at this establishment is decent and attentive. For example, one time while I was here with a group of 6 or 7, one of my friends accidentally dropped her glass of water on the floor. The glass shattered both on the table and the floor. The staff quickly came by to pick up the broken pieces and put towels on the areas of the table splattered by the water/glass. In no time, my friend had new tableware for her meal. 

Atmosphere: One interesting moment was when my boyfriend asked one of the staff members in cantonese about an item as he was checking on tables. The staff member told us he didn't speak chinese!  Most of the rest of the staff seems to speak/understand cantonese, and it is usually what you expect if you go to a more authentic place. Although I'm not sure this place is the most authentic. It has a somewhat corporate feel, especially in the space in the rincon center. 

Any time I have gone here, (usually on a Saturday) it is always crowded and all the tables are filled. There is usually a mix of asian/non-asian people dining here. Even being as busy as it is with a continuous flow of people, I have never had to wait more than a few minutes for a table. 

Value: The bill does seem to be high at times after eating here, but I usually enjoy my meal and keep returning for more.
author: Cynthia D.

description: I'm a little put off by the bill, but what can I say? I like my $3.80 pot of Jasmine tea. I've been here on several occasions and I love those little ginger dumplings and I like how you're bombarded with different kinds of dishes every 2.76 seconds. Have you ever been to a dim sum place where the carts never seemed to make it to your table? So frustrating! Yum = Peking duck, egg tarts, cabbage salad, cha siu baos. A great way to not wait twenty-five minutes for a table is to sit at the bar. But careful, kids, you got to be 21 to sit there. The bartender was suspicious of me (I look young for 25, okay? It's those great Asian genes) for a second, but all was well.
author: Natasha P.

description:
In an area of the US where there is an abundance of Chinese from Hong Kong and Guangzhou, one would think that there are a lot of great choices for dim sum.  This unfortunately is not the case.  In a lengthy discussion with one of the best Chinese chefs in the US, Joe Ng (Chinatown Brasserie, Red Farm), most of the dim sum tea houses have people working for them that are too tired to prepare the dough the way it needs to be done.  It takes strength and vigor to make dim sum skin paper thin and the stuffing either nice and tight or juicy and flavorful.

Yank Sing is among the best in Northern California but still falls a little short of what the ideal should be.  This is one reason for just four starts.  While time tested for many years (10+), refreshing the menu would be helpful.  It is by far better than the Chinatown tea houses and better than the over rated Koi Palace.  Once the name James Beard rolls around or Michelin, then things must be absolutely divine, which this is not.  It's good dim sum, maybe arguably very good dim sum.  But it is not great dim sum.  Have it once, and perhaps to the less traveled dim sum hobbyist, it is great.  But have it the 4th or 5th time, and things get a little tiring.  Don't get me wrong...we went their at 10am and bought some extra to take home.  Sometimes, we even travel across the bridge just to get a bite to-go or even catch some to-go before having to catch a cross country flight.  But 5 stars this is not.  It's a solid four stars.

Almost everything steamed is very good.  For health reasons, we seldom eat anything fried unless it is a must have (like Hana's tempura or age dashi tofu); however, in the past, the deep fried crab and prawn dish has been very nice to have.  The XLB is probably the best that one can get in Northern California (look out for the upcoming review on the best XLB in the country).  What's an honorable mention for Yank Sing are the other, non-traditional dim sum items available (sea bass, Peking duck, lettuce wrap chicken).  Some of these items are nice to have.  Another very nice offering is the selection of teas.

One thought for some of the other posts:  quit complaining about the cost.  You pay for what you get for.  If you're looking for high quality dim sum, it isn't going to come at a cheap price.  If you're looking for cheap and large in quantity, go to Chinatown and eat that garbage.  Remember, high quality dim sum will have translucent skin with a) lots of juice inside (like xlb), b) firm texture (like shrimp dumplings...aka ha gow), or c) lots of flavor without an msg aftertaste (like Yank Sing's pea sprout dumplings).  

My suggestion to the readers, go early and grab a table.  One of my favorite times has been to take an early morning hike and then heading over for a 10am brunch.  Good times.  Good restaurant.  Good eats.

H
author: Heathcliff D.

description:
Highway robbery
Overrated and deep fried
Better in Richmond
author: Patrick T.

description: Repeating what has been said many times. Hands down best dim sum in the Bay Area. Shanghai Dumplings and Sweet Custard Buns (special order) are must haves. Shumai and everything else is also good.
author: Brad V.

description: Yank Sing was tasty enough and by my reckoning had all the dim sum standards.  And it's kind of cool to go on the weekend when they take over the building atrium.  However, I ended up paying well more than I'm accustomed for dim sum.  Really, I'm not sure if the food is distinguishable from the much cheaper alternatives.
author: Dano W.

description:
This place serves DELICIOUS xiao long bao (steamed dumplings with soup inside), however the price they ask is ridiculous. I realize that this is in the heart of downtown San Francisco, realestate is expensive, however, it's still way overpriced. My friend and I ordered maybe 5 or 6 little dishes from the cart, and our bill was nearly $70. Then, I ordered for some other little dishes to go, and was an additional $40.

I've only been there for dimsum, and I must say everything they serve is very high quality, and very fresh. I don't think I'll be going back unless I have some extra change in my pocket to spare. After all, $110 is 15% the price of a direct plane ticket to Shanghai. Where I can get all the xiao long bao to my hearts content for under $10.
author: LL L.

description: Everytime I come here, it is more delicious than I remember!!  Yank Sing had the best dim sum around.  Everything I have ever eaten there has been incredible but there are definitely a few that I have to order when I am there.  Their house special - the shanghai dumplings - are my favorite.  They melt in your mouth and are a great way to start off your dim sum adventure.  I like the cab puff and the stuffed mushrooms - both are a treat.  They also have a Chilean Sea Bass plate that is like nothing I have ever tasted - it is AMAZING and melts in your mouth!  Today I had the walnut shrimp (I don't like walnuts) but the shrimp was delcious - we ordered two of them because we couldn't get enough.  Everything is fresh and good - top it off with their mango pudding and you will have an incredible lunch.
author: Arica V.

description:
We went to Sunday brunch 10:15 before the ball game. We made a reservation and they were quite busy although there were still open tables
 Great service good clean tasting dim sum.  We really liked the spinach dumplings, the pork soup dumplings. Had fried soft shell crab for the first time. Very good. I tried the duck. I wasn't that impressed for $5 for one litlle piece with bun and sauce. 

Had an asparagus with chicken. Very tasty. Also the chicken and mushroom dumplings. 

Try the pistachio ice cream if you have any room left. 

We truly ate like sumus.!
author: Catherine S.

description:
one word... OVERPRICED

Maybe everyone in the dim sum business should strive to have the same level of service, cleaniness, and ambience. But, this is way overboard. Not that it should offend anyone, but when the waitresses would speak Cantones to eachother but switch to English when at ear-shot of the customers kind of sums up this place for me. 
Fusion or not fusion, this place tries too hard to be high class/priced and is getting way out of place with its roots.
Too bad...
author: Lenny T.

description: Delicious but badly overpriced.  Many of the dishes are not traditional Cantonese dim sum, if that matters to you - though everything is tasty.  Clean classy surroundings but usually a long wait for very expensive fare that's no better than other options in the City.  If you can't get out to the Richmond district where the best classy dim sum places are, I'd suggest divey-er take-out places in Chinatown over YS.
author: Matt T.

description: Want to really give this place 4 stars but leaving it at 3 stars 'cause it's so pricey!  A lot pricier than going to some gourmet restaurants with a nicer atmosphere.  Food is good and for the most part we can find what we're looking for.  Usually if a tray hasn't come around...the servers will help track it down.
author: Mrs. D.

description:
When you live in SF, you tend to forget how good Yank Sing is. After you know that you can't just drive to go to Yank Sing (like me now), then you start writing good review about it coz you miss it so much. 

Yes, it's pricey. But I have had dim sum in Singapore & Hong Kong; which probably the capital of dim sum according to "my Lonely Planet", and I have to say that Yank Sing could be ranked up there with some of the best dim sum on the planet.

On my last recent trip home to SF, I decided that I had to fill this belly with little steamed goodies from Yang Sink. My generous sis decided that she wanted to treat me and ended up paying $40/person for breakfast. Ha!

Some of my favourite must-have here are shrimp dumpling (allergy, the hell with ya), scallop dumpling, sticky rice, chicken porridge, peking duck and of course their Shanghai dumpling..which you can't really order it to go unless you order extra on the side then decide that you can't finish it....long story, but I had to do this trick when I wanted to take some to go. Don't forget to use their special chili sauce that you can even purchase to take home and some yummy hot tea served in a cool looking tea-pot...and there you go, all your lunch money for 3 days go into Yank Sing.
author: Levy O.

description:
When having dim sum, it is very important to me that all the dishes are piping hot.  Lukewarm doesn't cut it in my books!

All of their dishes always arrive at the table hot.  I love the regulars, har gow, fried turnip cake, steamed dumplings, don tot, and chicken feet.

Prices are on the high side, but the quality of the food makes it worth it.
author: Sharon S.

description:
Solid, basic dim-sum place where you feel comfortable taking your mom out to lunch.

I especially like the fact that you can enjoy dim-sum in a clean environment.  The authentic dishes are served quickly by ladies maneuvering their carts in a seasoned manner.  I have to say again, SOLID.
author: Yu T.

description:
I've gone to Yank Sing about 1/2 year ago. It was my first time. My tip: get there early because you know how parking can get in SF. (more about that in a bit) We got seated in the large atrium area inside of One Rincon on a weekend. It had a nice feel to it. It was also not as noisy as your typical Chinese eatery. 
The tea and the teapot was great. The teapot was clear and large so you can see what's in it. I've heard that teapot from this place has been in some art museum. The tea was light and just right for me. 
The dim sum here are pretty good. I often dim sum in Monterey Park and this is on the higher end of the quality scale. It is a bit on the pricey side but I thought it was worth it.
Upon leaving, the car garage is very confusing. You also have to park in 90 degree formats. Make sure you get a spot that you can easily move out  afterwards. I scratched my car from a short turn radius on the curb. I would park outside and rather feed the meters. If it wasn't for this, I would've given it five stars.
author: Pete S.

description: This is the best dim sum in SF I've ever been to. Since I was a kid till now, I've gone here. Love it. Always loved it and would go back for more. I use to wait in line with the family for 1 1/2 hours but it was way worth the wait and by the time we started eating I completely forgot about how long we waited. One of the finest places to eat dim sum.
author: Ryan C.

description: I love Yank Sing.  They have some of the best dim sum, especially the duck.  They have extremely friendly staff, especially for an asian restaurant.  The atmosphere is nice but casual.  Expect a wait, this is a very popular place and very much worth it.  Yank Sing is on the pricey side, especially for dim sum.
author: Andrea B.

description:
Good but not anywhere near the $5 lunch category. Go to You's if you want cheap!

The xlbs are worth the trip. taste bonanza. seasame balls were yum too!
author: Elsa E.

description: First thing I did when I landed in San Francisco (I live in Seattle) was drop off my bags and go straight to Yank Sing.  My parents go to SF quite frequently and recommended this restaurant as one of the their favorites.  We have good dim sum in Seattle, but nothing compares to Yank Sing.  The carts came around quickly, the place was clean and I will be returning here again!
author: Carol W.

description: When the reservations system (meaning whoever answers the phone and takes down your reservation) works, this place is great.  The food is good and fresh, and the place is clean and service is usually decent (for a dim sum place).  However, the worst case scenario involves their not getting your reservation down, a parking garage nightmare, and waiting for a while even though you had a reservation and confirmed it.
author: B. Y.

description: Yummy varieties and fresh as can be. I personally do not recommend going between the hours of 12 & 1 PM when it's lunchtime crazy so I go early (around 11 as is the Chinese tradition) or after 1-1:30. You can't go too late however as they will have run out of some of the popular items. I personally like the small seating alcove just to the right of the main entry. You get good, regular service there and the noise is at a bearable level. I've returned there every time I'm in the city.
author: Lee S.

description: Yank Sing is a decent place for dim sung but expect average food and expensive prices.  Our waiters were great as they ordered items that we wanted but weren't on their carts, but they could be sometimes pushy as they offered us food right when we were seated.  The place was clean, but the food was not the best I've ever had; eveything was warm, but I felt our items didn't pack enough punch.  I might try Yank Sing again but probably not anytime soon.
author: Shannon W.

description:
Well, it was not cheap, but it temporarily cured my homesick

I like the Rincon Center location better because it reminded me of the dim-sum places in Taipei. It is much more fun to order my food from the carts as they pass by. Even though it is not truly authentic Cantonese dim sum, it is good enough for my homesick Chinese palate, and it is clean and consistent enough for my American friends. 

Food: The steam dumplings (Xiao-Long-Bao) are the must-haves, and the most dim-sum items are very good, too. Keep in mind that this is not a cheap restaurant and the "specials" can easily break a bank. Unless you really really want the specials, I will stay away from them--most of those are American versions of Chinese food anyway. 

Parking: Although they validate parking (free on weekends, $4 on weekdays), the parking spots are limited and the garage is difficult to get around. If you have a full-size or larger vehicle, street parking may be a better option.
author: S M.

description: I have been coming here since i was a little kid, thanks to my momma i was introduced to good Dim Sum at a young age. Only problem now is my expectations are too high! Everywhere else i go i just miss Yank Sing. Thank you for never letting me down and for all the memories! Ill be back soon.
author: Sarah F.

description:
Big fan! Definitly not a date place. Great for a quick business lunch. Excellent dim sum - must try their house specialy with the broth INSIDE the dumpling. It's like a burst of flavor explosion in your mouth.

Fast and friendly service, prices are a little on the high side, but their special house dumplings are SOOOO worth it!

 Park underground for validated tickets.
author: A.L. S.

description: My family and I always go to dim sum so I have been to many places in LA and SF.  We love trying new places and went to Yank Sing on Father's Day.  It was a pleasant surprise as it was not complete chaos, the service was great, and the food delicious.  Favorites were: the egg custard (one of the best I've had at dim sum restaurants), mushroom dumplings, standards like ha gow and xu mai, the ribs, the cabbage slaw, and the soup dumplings (served with spoons to make eating them easier!).  The service was fantastic - condiments on table, requests delivered within minutes, tea and water constantly filled (clear tea pot so server can see when you need more water = genius), and they changed out our plates!  Ambiance was nice as it's in an atrium so it feels like you are eating outside, but it's not stuffy or too loud. Yank Sing is well worth it!
author: Katharine L.

description:
The overall 3.5 stars is right.  The first time I was here the dim sum was to die for.  The second time around I think the baby broccoli died.  I love baby broccoli and always manage to order it at a dim sum restaurant.  But the baby broccoli this time was a baby no more.  It was old, cold and limp.  

The others that we had: ha gow, siu my, sahn jook & bbq pork buns weren't as succulent or savory either.  

But I give 4 stars because the interior is clean, the ladies pushing the carts are friendly and just keep on smiling (usually an anomaly in Chinese/dim sum restaurants) even though it seems they don't comprehend a word you are saying.  I just point and they give me what I want.  Also dining in the atrium is impressive and I would be proud to take anyone here. 

Yank Sing, please don't let your patrons down!  We may come back after simmering.
author: Dy R.

description:
We went to Yank Sing and it was exactly as I expected: good but not superior dim sum in an environment that won't scare off non-intrepid eaters.

We ended up spending about $100 for 3 people -- yikes -- and we definitely had plenty of food. I wouldn't seek it out again, nor would I wave people off trying it; it's certainly convenient and a good place to get weekend lunch in the downtown zone when not a lot of places are open.
author: anita c.

description:
Same review as the one on Stevenson in terms of food-- excellent dim sum, love it!! The cod is so tender and delicious with the somewhat thick sweet soy sauce. Service wise, this is very touristy so I normally take people who have not been to YS here instead of the other one, mostly because Rincon center has a nice "waterfall", and it has seating that is outside of the carpeted area and it feels like some classy cafe inside an upscale mall and is also more relaxing. 

A note on the timing, the best time is to be able to get there and sit down after 12pm. Food is only lukewarm before noon and after 1:30pm.
author: T L.

description:
Ok seriously, dim sum shouldn't be this expensive! it shouldn't!!! The ambiance is kinda cool with the waterfall coming from the ceiling just outside, but it isn't THAT nice compared to say 888 in socal that costs a third of the price. Anyway, the price only knocked one star off for me cause I didn't pay when I went. =P

And yea, ok...the food was really good. well, at least the xiao long bao were definitely worth it and so was this salad thing I never got at dim sum before. mmmm...xiao long bao. I am semi-obsessed with them.
author: Minh-Chi T.

description:
I LOVE this place but be warned this place is expensive for dim sum.  Whenever I go to San Francisco I always come here at least once.  They have a nice selection and the service is pleasant.  The portions are slightly bigger than other places but does not justify the higher price.  This is a refined dim sum eatery.

Oh, don't forget to try their chili pepper sauce with your dim sum because it rocks and takes the dim sum to a whole other level.
author: henry h.

description: I love the shanghai dumplings here.  The eggplant was really good too.  Everything is good.  I also like this place over other dim sum places because the dishes and utensils are clean.  Slightly dirty stuff won't stop me but I sure do appreciate clean stuff.  I will never say no to Yank Sing. Just need a good size group of people to go with so we can have a lot of variety.  Oh, the chinese broccoli was unexpectedly cold.
author: Larry L.

description:
Two words:

Soup dumplings.  

So sick.  So sick.

1 star off for the fountain in the middle that never looks like it has water in it.
author: Justin H.

description: Personally I think this place has good dim sum but the ratings are a bit overrated. Yank Sing's food contains high levels of MSG and makes me sleepy after... Food quality and service is great compared to other Chinese restaurants. I believe Yank Sing is catered towards Westerners and not authentic Chinese folks. You should check out these other restaurants suggested by my friends: http://bit.ly/74aehe for authentic Chinese food in SF's Chinatown. Go to Yank Sing and the other restaurants and see for yourself.
author: Captain G.

description: Yank Sing is a place to which I would definitely take my family and know they would enjoy. The dim sum selection is awesome with lotus rice being my favorite. To seasoned dim sum eaters, some of the dishes may not be quite as savory as desired. However, it's an all around fine place to dine.
author: Evelyn B.

description:
I used to hate this place when I worked in the Financial District in 2000/01.  The food was OK, but it certainly didn't warrant the cost.

I'd have given it a 2 back then.  I recently went to a wedding banquet there, and the food was actually very good.  Nevermind that I didn't have to pay for anything, but I was pleasantly surprised.  But I can't assume that they food/service at a banquet is the same as the every day service and food.  Therefore, I bump it up to a very tenuous 3.
author: Dave K.

description:
We actually just had our company party here, and for that I'd have to say it was great.  The staff and event coordinator were wonderful and extremely attentive.  I'd say go with a customized menu and ask about dishes you haven't personally had before (and don't worry about leftovers - Yank Sing will pack them up for you).  Other than that, the space was beautiful.  We had the whole restaurant to ourselves, got to host a successful party (on a budget) and everyone had a fabulous time.

ADDENDUM: recently had lunch/dim sum here with a friend.  Beware.  It adds up!!  $40 for lunch is, umm, not what I usually spend...but this is what happens when you're hungry and haven't seen a friend for ages (like, since high school) and end up obliviously nodding to the cart ladies while engrossed in your walk down memory lane.  Oops. Another order of shu mei?  Oh well, it's not like we didn't eat it...
author: M. H.

description:
Good Deem Sum! I guess a couple of things took away its fifth star. First water service took a half an hour. Although we ordered maybe fifteen minutes since our seating, I didn't get my much needed water for another fifteen minutes. The soft drinks came relatively quicker though. Secondly, you don't know what the prices of the items are. We just pretended we were stamp collectors on our ticket thing but we were absolutely surprised our meal cost $400!!! The duck alone was $107 for 24 pieces. 

The food is great. I really like the shanghai dumplings which is won ton soup in a dumpling! I was really surprised how they did that. The crab claws (which my friend is peer pressuring me to write about) were pretty innovative. It was shredded shrimp wrapped around an open crab claw and then breaded. Nicely executed. On the same note, the orange jello was just as impressive. Basically on real orange peels they had orange Jell-o shaped as if when we cut the orange into slices it wasn't filled with the flesh of an orange, but bright orange Jell-o! The expensive duck was good, too. I am not sure if you could eat the paper on the bottom of the duck bun, but if you can't I would prefer to have it taken off before serving it. Also, the sticky rice was soft and gooey like I like it! 

The Rincon center is a nice place and I hear it functions as a food court when Yank Sing doesn't take over the whole central atrium on weekends. There is also this cool rain water fall coming from the ceiling. You can totally imagine Britney Spears performing in the center, dancing it the water, whipping her hair around. 

Anyway, super surprised when we got the bill. I wish we got to see a menu beforehand. At least I would be able to learn the names of things, too. All in all, very good dim sum, in a crowded place as is expected. Not a cheap thrill. The free validated $10 parking was a bonus for the drivers though. Park in the underground parking lot. Great for wedding receptions. (Hahha, I don't know that, but they were setting up for some reception right before we were leaving.) -Matt
author: Matthew C.

description:
Holy Shit!!!
Most impressed with the setting.
The food was decent.
The service was pretty damn good.
More details later.
author: Kione E.

description:
Hadn't been in years, and it seems they have cut way back in the variety.  Still, 7 of the 8 dishes we got were super fresh and wonderfully succulent and tasty.  (Turnip cakes were nasty tho.  Big Lantern in the Mission has the BEST turnip cakes if you're craving those.)

Everything else was as good as ever, and the taro root one (my fave) was actually better than normal with mushrooms and greens as well as the normal small bits of pork.  Super good.
author: Melanie C.

description: Very good dim sum.  it would be 5 stars but it's very expensive.  Try the bass, it's their best dish.
author: Kenneth M.

description:
As a first time dim sum-eater, I definitely want to try it again. I recommend this place, *especially* if you are not paying. It feels a bit closed in/claustrophobic, which can be hard on a gorgeous day (I feel like the idea of dim sum would fit better in a more open eating space, with windows or something). Anyway, good food, helpful (although they can be pushy, and frowny if you say no) servers, and fun lazy Susan (who doesn't love those?). 
It's a great place for a business lunch. Otherwise, I'd find another dim sum destination with more atmosphere... maybe that's just me.
author: Anika K.

description:
Hands down the best dim sum in the city. Hands down the most expensive dim sum. You won't walk out of there spending less than $30-60 depending on how hungry you are. 

Is it worth it? Only if you appreciate dumplings made with high quality ingredients, well-crafted and artfully wrapped one-by-one. Each dumpling is exquisite. 

Of course there are other places you can enjoy dim sum. I also agree that this place is great for out-of-towners.

The weekend crowd is a long wait, but lunch seemed totally do-able without a reservation.
author: Thanya S.

description:
Good, if i didn't have to take a second mortage out on my home to eat there. 3.5* would be perfect for Yank Sing - the food is great quality and fresh, but the prices are from 2016 and the service is less than desirable (not that i expect great service for dim sum). Honestly though, i can't bring myself to come here again, when there are far better places for reasonable prices around (ton k, city view, etc). 

$8.60 for one (yes one slice) piece of duck, a few slices of scallion, a bit of hoisin sauce and a pancake - who are they kidding, I'm not p-diddy. Since I am not p-diddy and generally have to wait in lines, i'd rather wait 1hr in d-city or on geary, than go back to Yank Sing. I miss their other location - what a terrible turn for the worse they've taken. 

Their teapots are now the main attraction, but i know where to buy them at source - Jenaer Glas
author: Mike C.

description:
Um, overpriced, fancy, Americanized dim sum.  Yet, can any dim sum ever really be bad?  It fits a purpose, if you have out of town visitors who would die in a dim sum place filled with Asian people then this is your answer or people from out of town who heard how wondeful the presentation is here.  Which is why I ended up there last April, with my friend and her friend from LA.  

But if you have friends who don't mind mingling with the natives then take them somewhere else, you can eat 3 times as much for the same price.  I do give them the extra star for service, and the fact that it's super clean and they do have a few dishes you can't get many places.  

But some of the noodles were dry, and the seafood portions smaller than elsewhere.  Again, it fills a need for certain occasions, like that friend visiting from Nevada that has never had Asian food.
author: Denise B.

description:
Our company just moved next door to the Rincon Center and there are plenty of food options in the area. Thus far we've tried 8 or 8 of them and the only one I'd return to is Yank Sing.

I'm not generally into Dim Sum. My taste in foods tends to revolve around vegetarian dishes and chicken breast. I never eat anything that still even remotely resembles the animal it once was (chicken feet...ewe!)

I managed to fill my tummy with things that were super yummy and without spending a fortune.

They even have a takeout window next door where I was able to get a tasty chicken salad, a snapple & one of those yummy dessert almond balls for $6. My friends burrito from next door cost more than that!
author: Heather P.

description:
I've been twice in the last month. One of the great ways to spend a Saturday morning is to get out to the Farmer's Market at the Ferry Building and have a relaxing morning shopping to fill the larder, have a cup of coffee and head over to Yank Sing for an early lunch.

I like sitting at the bar. The service is right there. As the carts roll around we just grab what we like. The Shanghai Dumplings, the Steamed Pork Buns, the Chicken Fun Gwor and the Potsticker (Wor Tee) are all amazing. The salad is delicious as well and serves two perfectly. 

The price is a bit high but the quality is also high. Good service, available parking (at least on Saturday) all add up to a great experience.
author: Gary C.

description:
My favorite dim sum in the bay area. The wait can speak for itself, but don't get caught up in that because the wait is definitely worth it-- and it's usually not as long as it looks anyway. The Hong Kong style dumplings are definitely a favorite. Lots of healthier dim sum options such as spinach dumplings are also available. You really can't go wrong as everything is out of this world delicious. 

Oh, and do yourself a favor and order the chrysanthemum tea.
author: Jon N.

description:
Its good if the boss is paying and you're with a group of 6+ fidi's from out of town who need a fancy cultural experience to put on their expense reports. 

Yummy walnut prawns, pork buns always a must, sesame balls could be better, and the bill can go to someone else.
author: Liz S.

description:
Our good friends held their wedding reception in the pavilion. As a vegetarian, I was concerned because they ordered the entirely seafood menu...
Imagine my surprise when out came some vegetarian dumplings just for me! The rest of my table was drooling! Then I got rice, 2 side dishes, and egg rolls in a Bento Box. People came to our table just to see what I was getting.
The service was very attentive and polite - practically unheard of at Chinese restaurants.
author: JaM W.

description:
I must preface this review by saying that I have never personally paid for a meal here.

That being said, the dim sum here is pretty darn tasty.  I know that it is really expensive, and I would probably never come here if I actually had to pay for the meal myself.  But if your parents are in town and want to take you out, or if your work is going to pay for it, this place serves yummy dim sum with high quality seafood.  

My only real complaint is that some of the servers come around with trays of dishes that have nothing to do with dim sum, or even Chinese food for that matter.  And boy do they push these dishes hard!  The lady with the miso glazed sea bass pushed the dish like she was getting commission (hey, maybe she was).  It is strange for me to see miso sea bass and chicken satay at a dim sum hall.
author: Dana H.

description:
Yank Sing rocks.  The JOB catered from here today and as usual the food was superb.  I love all their dim sum items, special shout out to the shrimp dumpling and spring rolls.  The fried rice is also very yummy.  They also made us a pretty killer cesar salad, go figure.  I love this place and I know its pricey but I didn't have to pay today.  And I say all this considering the food was luke warm since it had been delivered who knows when...

Oh and for those looking for a nice wedding venue with awesome food, this is it.  My brother had his reception here and the food and service was great.  The fountain is also beautiful where they set up the banquet tables.
author: La C.

description: Great Dim Sum! Been Here several times and enjoyed every time! Great Service and Highly Recommended! Of all of my experiences with Asian restaurants in the Bay Area, this is one of the best!
author: Donovan R.

description: The dim sum lived up to its reputation.  The ha gao was plump and delish.  Interestingly, they even turn not-traditionally-dim-sum foods into dim sum too.  I fear it's gonna be one of those once a year if that places due to the high price.
author: Mike S.

description: Went here over the weekend with some friends. I loooove finding new places I know I'll be back to. This is one of them. Great dim sum. Little on the pricey side, but you get what you pay for. Quality was great and very friendly staff. It's right by Embarcadero so perfect for lunch or Sunday brunch like us! :)
author: Rouz E.

description: Amazing dim sum place in the heart of SF.  I love this restaurant as it was very nice to see multi-culturism enjoying a popular Chinese cuisine.  Quality of dim sum was fantastic here, the service was quick and accommodating (unlike your traditional dim sum restaurant).  The only disappointment was the Shui Mai which was not juicy as it should be.  Otherwise, very high quality and worth the money.
author: Victor W.

description:
I might be a bit biased, but this is the best Dim Sum place in the SF Bay Area...

Here's why...
We had our wedding reception here, so we get the VIP treatment everytime we visit.  The food is really spectacular, but definitely on the pricey side.

However, if you get the dan-tat (egg custard dessert), the cost is well worth it.  Make sure you request it fresh from the kitchen...makes a world of difference!


Myths:
1.  Dim Sum restaurants are dirty.  False, this is probably one of the only ones that are not.  You can tell by looking at a cup of water and not see lipstick residue.

2.  Dim Sum ladies always pass you by with the item you want and won't return.  False, the staff all have earpieces, so they can quickly summon the cart you're looking for.


Must Haves:
-  Shanghai Dumplings are their forte.  They are definitely the best I've had in the states.  The only ones better are in Taiwan:)

-  Dan-tat

-  Anything else with either mustard sauce or their house made chili sauce mixed with soy sauce.  Spicy.

KN
author: Kevin N.

description:
A fairly upscale restaurant.  My friend took me here for dim sum since we work in the area.  As for the quality of the food, I was pretty surprised.  

We had ngau cheung (which is beef wrapped in those fat chow fun noodles), pai gwut (pork spare ribs), and foil wrapped chicken, all of which were pretty tasty. 

During the lunch hour, it was pretty crowded and loud, but, the restaurant has a nice ambiance to it.  I'd definitely go there again, and i've already recommended it to multiple people.
author: Casey F.

description:
This place is great! I always take out of town guests here for a special treat. The Shanghai Dumpling always blows everyone away. 

If you go on the weekend - make a reservation or show up before Noon - otherwise you will have to wait. 

Rincon Center is very impressive on the weekends - the entire lobby is filled with tables, with carts of hot steaming goodness whizzing around it is quite a site..and lots of fun people watching! 

The dumplings are great and the fried green onions with peanut sauce is one of my favorites. The sheer variety of dumplings is what keeps me coming back for more - some day I will have tried them all.
author: Chris B.

description:
The dim sum here is great.  Reminds me a bit of Hong Kong... besides the hefty price.  Most of the dishes here are great.  From traditional to the fancy, their dim sum provides satisfaction for everyone :)

I will say there are places in the Bay Area that are better for the value.  If you're a big eater, just be careful.  I've eaten light here for about $35 person and hit more than $80 per person when hungry and ordering a couple of their high-end items. The wife was not happy... not because of the price but because of my big belly at the end of the meal :)
author: Bernard M.

description:
So.. I try to from time to time separate the quality of food from the price that is paid....  but this place makes it really tough to do.

The service is good... the food is actually pretty good quality too... but it's expensive!!!

So I also need to come to the realization that people might pick a nice Chinese place to eat at... for dim sum, to take clients to, to write off on the company dime......  this is that kinda place... nice tables, pretty good service, nice setting, well lit, and an impressive bill to go along with the food....

Peking Duck for dim sum!!!  I don't even wanna know how much.  

Again.. it's kinda tough for me to completely objectively review this place because a good portion of me goes to dim sum or chinese food for comfort food and because it's cheap... and this place isn't cheap.
author: Eric K.

description:
This was the first dim sum place i was taken to in the city, and man, I always love this place.  Who cares if it's overpriced....i know it's clean, staff can probably speak english, and the food probably isn't made in sweatshops.

Prepare to drop some dough, but if you're not stingy, you'll enjoy this place.  They have some of the best xiao long baos too (steamed pork dumplings....or something)!
author: Tadd L.

description:
Gotta say it was really quite good dim sum.  I know, it's very polished and cleaned up and caters as much to Chinese people as it does to the "gweilos," but the food was very good.

Usually the true test dish of a dim sum place is Xiao Long Bao - the steamed Shanghainese pork dumplings.  These bite sized morsels need to be served hot, with skin that's not so thin or overcooked that it "breaks" if you pick it up, but not so thick that it requires extra chewing.  Ideally, you want it so that you can see the sack barely holding the juice in and the thing pops and then melts in your mouth.  Yank Sing xiao long bao met the test and passed, squirting pork juice and all.

Char Siu Bao and Har Gow were also quite good, though I felt the Shumai was only so-so.  Loved the sweet tofu dessert with a hint of ginger - very refreshing and soothing.

The bill was surprisingly expensive.  I guess they gotta pay for that real estate.  So not a cheap weekend brunch option, but definitely a mouth-watering one.
author: Eric T.

description:
I love love love this place for Dim Sum.  Forget about the rest.  This is truly the best.  High quality food, stellar staff who are fluent in English, Mandarin, & Cantonese.  Plus, they serve up the best Xiao Lung Bao in SF.  

I would give it 5 stars, but it breaks the bank each time I eat here.
author: Nancy G.

description:
The fried Taro things were the realness. The lettuce wraps were great, as was pretty much everything else except these steamed sparerib things that were kind of gross.  Oh - the Shanghai dumplings (I think it was Shanghai) were awesome, with a ginger sauce. They're all soupy inside and you eat them out of a spoon. So good.

I was there with my parents around 1pm on a Sunday and the service sucked. None of the carts approached us and i had to flag down a waiter who brought a menu, and then screwed up our order.

But still, great Dim Sum.
author: Josh K.

description:
OK so I admit that I first heard of this place on TV (plugs!) on the Food Network.  But come on, it looked SO good. I had to have it!  I've been dying to try dim sum but each time I head to a Chinatown near me, I freeze and suddenly don't know what to do or what to order. Clearly, I needed a little guidance, even if it came from Rachael Ray - OK YOU GOT ME!  We were watching her Tasty Travels San Francisco show - had it programmed on my Tivo since we were going to the bay area.  We used to like her a long time ago, but now she's just annoying....but that's another story.

Anyway, so we get to Yank Sing when it opened and there was already a mob of people waiting to get in first.  I honestly can't remember the names of everything that we had, all I know is that it was damn good - all the dumplings, fried stuff, everything.  We ate so much (just us two) that I was miserable for the next couple of hours, but it was a great experience. 

The only thing is that it's pretty pricey.  Being that we were on vacation, we threw caution to the wind.....but then the bill came....$80!!!  Good thing I stuffed my face because I practically didn't have to eat the rest of the day.

Bottom line, if you're cool with paying beacoup bucks for dim sum, this is the place for you!
author: Ruth L.

description:
I love the dim sum at Yank Sing.  The first time I ever had dim sum was at Yank Sing and I am thus forever spoiled.  A few 'musts' you have to order: 
-Shanghai dumplings 
-sesame balls 
-pork siu mye 
I really could go on, but I had those three last week and I could eat them again right now!  Yum!  
Even at lunch in the middle of the week there is a wait, so be prepared for that.  It is also a bit pricey, but well worth it!
author: Lauren H.

description:
Yank Sing is a really nice, upscale dim sum restaurant. It has a huge main dining room and many more tables in its spacious atrium. The quality of the dim sum is first rate. And they probably serve the most extensive selection in NorCal. They also serve tea in artistic glass teapots, which can be purchased for $29.95 each. Based on ambience and quality and variety of food, Yank Sing is arguably the best dim sum restaurant in the bay area. But it's also easily the most expensive by a significant margin. I think this place is worth the trip if you're in SF, but there are plenty of other great dim sum places all over the bay area.

I should also point out that no matter how elegant or grand the decor may be at a dim sum restaurant, if it's popular, it will always be super noisy and super hectic. That's just the nature of our dining culture.
author: Yb W.

description:
Came here for lunch and I always leave pretty satisfied.  

A friend and I had dim sum.  We ordered the following:  spinach dumplings, shrimp dumplings, steamed pork bun, and shreaded cabbabe salad.  All items were good and we finished the whole thing.  

The great thing about dim sum is the quick service.  It really allows you to get in and out in a jiffy.  

This place is a really ritzy place and is quite pretty.  Otherwise, i'm not too partial about this spot.  I've had better dim sum in the past, and i've also had worse.  I guess a lot of people rant and rave about this place, but i don't get it.  It's good, but it isn't "to die for".
author: Brenda H.

description:
Note to self - don't bring your nine year old here when she's hungry.  Why?  You'll end up with a dim sum bill for $250.00 (including tip).  Worth every penny.

Yank Sing is an old favorite  - my family and I probably come here a few times a year.  

Today's feast included

Har Gau
Shu Mai 
Rice Noodle with Shrimp
Shanghai Dumpling
Braised Tofu
Chicken with Mushroom (dumpling, not the stuffed mushroom)
Sticky rice in Lotus leaf
Shrimp Toast
Crab Claw
Fried Shrimp
Spring Roll
Shrimp with Bacon
Minced Chicken in Lettuce Cup
Honey Walnut Salad
Potstickers
Sesame Ball

Too full and had to pass on the Sea Bass, Peking Duck, & the stuffed Mushrooms.  I don't know if they still serve the Chinese Chicken Salad - but their version was very good.

I am sure there are a lot of other cheaper and tastier dim sum places - but for the whole package - Yank Sing is my favorite.

I can always count on the Har Gau to full of shrimp - they don't skimp and it is not full of bamboo shoots.  The shrimp is clean (I can't tell you how many times I've eaten har gau where the shrimp's intestinal track is not removed and I get a mouth full of grit) and fresh.  Yank sing also has the "right" amount of dough.  A lot of dim sum places have really thick wrappers - so there dim see appear to be big, but the end result is just a gooey mess.
author: Sabrinasmom S.

description:
This place should be 4 stars at a minimum.  It is a rip-off when compared to the Dim Sum in China town but no one can deny the quality.  The special, soup dumplings, are the best I've had anywhere.  Better than Din Tai Fung in Taiwan, better than Joe Shanghai in NYC and better than anywhere in SF.  They are expensive, maybe $2 bucks each, but worth it.  

Sea-bass -solid
Potstickers - yes it's not very adventurous but amazing with the hot mustard
Peking Duck - amazing, skin is crispy, bun wrap is soft and delicious
Jasmine Tea - a rip off but great...nice tea pot as well

Make a reservation on the weekends to avoid what is sometimes a 20 minute wait.  If you want something that you can't find in the carts, they will call in the order for you.
author: Dan Y.

description: Hands down the best dim sum in SF. If you've never been here you have to come. This is the place to recommend to your friends visiting from out of town. I recommend the shanghai dumplings, scallop dumplings, mini peking duck with buns, steamed BBQ pork buns, shrimp and leek dumplings, sharkfin dumplings...you can't miss with the dumplings. They come by with the carts and you can just pick what looks good to you. They come in small portions so you can try a little of everything. The mango pudding is wonderful for dessert. Also the fried white turnip cake is really good too.
author: Sue R.

description: I came here for a wedding, and the food was really good considering the size of the party and amount of food they had to prepare.  We came back the next morning to try the dim sum and loved it! The one with snow peas was really yummy and the one with scallops had to be my favorite.  I saw their bbq pork buns on food network, so of course I tried those too. They did not disappoint!  For 4 of us, it was $100 but well worth it.  Definitely gonna be back!
author: Chrystel J.

description:
I have been going to Yank Sing for probably the past 15 years and it is always a great experience. It is definitely my favorite spot for Dim Sum, hands down! And in a city that has literally dozens of good Dim Sums restaurants I feel this is saying alot.

Many of the reviews on yelp gripe about the price, and yes it is definitely on the more expensive side. However when it comes to Yank Sing I think you definitely get what you pay for. The selection is fantastic, the food is always fresh and the service is terrific!! I have been to many Dim Sum restaurants in my life, and Yank Sing has their method down better than anyone! No matter how busy they are, the food is constantly coming out of the kitchen and you rarely go more than a few minutes without some cart coming up to you with different selections to choose from. Or, one of the best things about Yank Sing is that if you don' t see what you want you just have to tell whoever you see and they will relay your order back to the kitchen. Many of the staff members, servers, and managers walking around have radio's that they can talk to each other and facilitate your order for you. It is an incredibly efficient system!

Again, I have had Dim Sum at many, many places and Yank Sing definitely ranks #1 to me. Yes, you can find cheaper in the city. However cheap does not always mean good. I don't think there is another place that has as much to offer, provides a clean and pleasant environment, offers great service, etc.

I have never had a bad experience at Yank Sing and always leave happy and full. To me it is worth EVERY penny!
author: Nick J.

description: was there for lunch.  the service was good and fast, but the prices are unjustified... its just not that good.  how can you charge $13 for crab claw??? there is hardly any crab in it!  can get better food for the price elsewhere.
author: Yana F.

description: Not a whole lot needs to be said about this place. Hands down the best dim sum in the COUNTRY, yes I said it, the country. I grew up in Boston and have been eating dim sum since I was in my mothers belly. Ive had it in New York, Boston, Paris, LA, and nothing comes close to this place. I've been coming here for years now it is always delicious. Even if your are only in the city for a day or two, this is a must. Yank sing is amazing.
author: Hunter S.

description: Ok,ok,ok.... Dim Sum doesn' t get any better than this. Yeah I know, there are a lot of dim sum spots in the City, but Yank Sing is the BEST they've been doing this a long time!  I've been a fan of Yank Sing since I was a kid growing up in the city! The food is consistantly good. From the siu mai to the Peking Duck. The food just kept coming, yup its a little pricey but you definately get what you pay for! There were 3 of us today and we polished off about $150.00 worth of dim sum. Thats a lot of dim sum. The service is absolutely spot on,  they even stopped to sing happy birthday for us...that was too funny ask me sometime n Ill tell you the story! The Chrysanthemum Tea was especially inviting on this cool rainy San Francisco day!
author: Romy N.

description: Are you kidding me?!  $80 for 2 for lunch?!  LMAO!  Way over priced!  Don't get me wrong, I don't mind paying good money for great food, but it's dim sum and it was nothing special!  I ordered what i always order and I've had way better!  Plus, a chiliean sea bass dish.   The chilean sea bass was horrible!  The worst chilean sea bass I've ever had.  My bill normally comes out to less then $25 for 2 ppl (without chilean sea bass) when I eat in Rosemead or Monterey Park.  Never again!
author: Sunny A.

description: Good dim sum. I came with a Chinese colleague and we both enjoyed it. I even tried the chicken feet (great flavor, fussy bones). I would recommend the duck.
author: Micah B.

description: Yank Sing is THE place to be for Sunday brunch. Who would have guessed? It was good that my group of 9 had reservations or we would have been waiting a while. We sat in the middle of the Rincon lobby, enjoying the different plates. They didn't come around too often and when the bill came, we were surprised at the high price for little food, but overall the food was good and the staff was friendly.
author: Julia S.

description: One of my favorite places to take friends visiting from out of town. I recommend the Siu Mye and their Shanghai Dumplings. Yum!
author: Chuck F.

description:
I've been here a few times and, yes, it is pricey, but as long as you know what you're getting yourself into, you won't be disappointed. This is some of the best dim sum I've had. I'm from Hawaii and am spoiled when it comes to good dim sum and chinese food (in my opinion) and my parents are very picky. We go here every time we visit the city and I just went back with my friends this past weekend for my birthday road trip. For three people, we spent $60 with tip (three sodas, hot tea, 7 dishes). My favorites were the shanghai dumplings, bean curd role, and sticky rice wrapped in a tea leaf. My only gripe is that you have to PAY for hot tea here. I've never been to any Chinese restaurant where I've ever had to pay for hot tea but other than that it was great. 

Also, you should note that I went here at an off time (Friday 1PM) so they really took care of us. I've also been here when it's extremely busy and you have to wait half an hour to 45 minutes to get a seat and that's always irritating but it goes to show you that people like it. I personally like it better with less people. I could actually hear my companions and I didn't feel rushed.
author: Lauren D.

description: Mediocre at best. Can't imagine how it rated high. Not one dish could we say was even very good and we tried enough of them.  Lunch for 2 was 102 dollars. Don't mind paying for good food but plan dry and all tasting about the same no way. The best thing was the soy sauce. And we had to ask for water!  Makes me wonder how the heck they got the "taj Mahal of Dim Sum" certainly couldn't be because of the food.
author: Ki E.

description:
Some of the best and safest(I'll explain this later) dim sum I've ever tasted.  I love dim sum and I've eaten it in china town in New York and SF.  This was some of the best I've had.  The reason for 4 stars instead of 5 was that it was very expensive and a little on the cold side.  They were very busy during my visit but they had a constant flow of carts the entire lunch.  That might have contributed to the luke warmness of all the food.

As per the safeness of the food.  I've had a lot of dim sum and everything usually is very good.  Usually at the typical dim sum restaurant I have this feeling of uncertainty.  The food is usually pretty greasy. I did not get that feeling at Yank Sing.
author: R M.

description: I have many faves but I never miss out on the shrimp dumplings and egg tarts. But whenever I go there they never seen have the orange jello that they have advertised in their pamplet.
author: EmmettsGuRL C.

description:
this review is solely based on the take out section.

they are fast and it is quality chinese food. i enjoy getting a small soup (m, tu, & th - shrimp wonton and w & f - hot & sour) and 1-2 bbq steamed pork bun/s. and sometimes i'll treat myself to an egg custard. the food is just the right portion and i'm not afraid of yank sing pulling a faux pas.
author: Marjie T.

description: What I really like about this place is the decor and atmosphere.  However, the dim sum was hit or miss, mostly miss.  The Shanghai dumplings and loh mei gai (sticky rice in lotus leaf) were highlights for me, but simple things like xiu mai and steamed spare ribs in black bean sauce didn't look or taste right.  On top of that, the specialty dishes are pricey and didn't look fresh.  They also forgot to bring the tea we asked for.  The price was a whopping $37 per person.  I have no problem paying for good food, but the food, unfortunately, did not come close to matching the price.
author: Cindy F.

description:
Great place for dim sum. Delicious and authentic dishes.

It's a more upscale place for dim sum, and that is reflected in the price, but I think the quality of the food is worth the price they charge. I love dim sum because there are so many dishes the choose from! 

I don't come here too often because I don't live in San Francisco, but it is worth the drive for me to come from San Jose!
author: Stephanie P.

description:
Best dimsum - hands down - in SF/Bay Area.

Yes, it's pricey, but here's what you get for your money: awesome quality dimsum, great selection, English-understanding staff, very clean premises. Whoever runs this restaurant has their act together - the manager taste tests each selection prior to distributing it to the patrons for quality assurance on a daily basis. While this place is constantly bustling, the restaurant has a lot of square footage, I've never had to wait too long for a seat.

Tip: Make sure to sit inside the restaurant and not in the outdoor section - even if it means waiting an extra 10/15 minutes. You'll get more immediate and wider selection that way ;)

* Parking's also a cinch: park inside the Spear Street garage and get your ticket validated from YS.
author: Joyce S.

description:
Great quality dim sum, tasty and not over steamed.  I would even go so far and say the dim sum is comparable to the Crystal Jade in Singapore (for those in the know), the taste and texture of the har gau is just right.  

The service and setting is very good. The outdoor seating area is perfect to get some fresh air whilst stuffing your face.

Minus 1 point for being pricey.  Definately one for those special occasions.
author: Teresa T.

description:
This could possibly be the most expensive dim sum place in SF.  I would give it 3 1/2 stars, but alas, you know how yelp works.

The food is great.  It's white-washed just enough (not too genuine, but not so washed out that it's like panda express) to make everyone at the table happy.  For those of looking for the real thing, they do have chicken feet.  The service is FAST.  The cart ladies are usually friendly.  The carts come around at regular intervals, and you are rarely left sitting there waiting and hungry.

Two negatives: expensive!  We ate so pretty modestly and it still ended up like $60 for 2 people.  $60 for 2 people!  

Second, the wait.  Come early or you will end up waiting forever.  I remember this one time, my friends and I had reservations and we still ended up waiting 30 minutes.
author: SpaAddict K.

description:
Went to Yank Sing for a wedding reception this weekend, and got some gosh darn good Chinese food.  I'd have to say that the smoked duck was amazing.  The Chilean sea bass, tender and very flavorful.  The scallops in the scallops, shrimp, broccoli, and snow pea dish, oh so yummy.  The noodles, great.  I'm going to hell for eating shark fin soup, just just had to try it.

Jeeze that smoked duck was good.
author: Adrian L.

description:
This place is great! Over the T-Day holiday, we took the kids to do the full tourist thing in SF. After taking the water taxi over from Jack London Square, we started our day with a little dim sum at Yank Sing. Wifey and I used to eat here all the time when we lived in the Bay and we've had a hankering for it ever since. They did not disappoint. The carts were whirlin' around the place servin' up tasty morsels. We lucked up and walked in right before the crowd so we sat immediately.  While our table was right at the entrance, it was still in the courtyard and the natural light and falling water make for great views/atmosphere. The staff was great with the kids and made sure we got everything we wanted and more. This was the first time the kids had Dim Sum and now they, too are hooked. 
I don't know if we just missed the place too much or what, but this place rocks.
author: kyle d.

description:
If you're looking for Americanized Dim Sum, you'll find it here.  They offer all sorts of dim sum dishes that you won't see in typical Chinese restaurants, and the items that are familiar to you will likely have an American twist to them.  You'd think this would be a bad thing, but it's actually amazingly delicious!! It is, however, also amazingly expensive.  A meal with 3 of your friends could easily get up to $100+.  If you can't handle paying that much for dim sum, don't come here.  But if you're looking for something interesting and different, and all that money is weighing you down, you should definitely come here!!

This is definitely a place worth trying at LEAST once.

And if you're looking to have a wedding here, they have four different set menus to pick from, and are fairly flexible about substitutions.
author: Mikolo R.

description:
Yank Sing has good food, clean facilities, and polite English-speaking waitstaff (try finding *that* anywhere else serving dim-sum).

The problem with the Spear St. location is that the kitchen is smaller; they don't serve the full dim-sum menu (for example, they don't serve the tsang-fen noodles). The food is fine, but stick with the Rincon Center location.

-1 star for not having tsang-fen, for sub-par xiao-long-bao, and for being expensive - $100 for 4! (you gotta pay for the clean polite English-speaking atmosphere) - to be fair, we did have some of the non-dim-sum entree selections (sea bass, etc.).
author: Rob T.

description:
I love eating Dim Sum. It's one of my favorite weekend events and weekday meals if I have the time. Most of the dim sum you find here you can find in Chinatown only this place is way more pricey. Expect to pay at least $30 for a meal if you dine in. I would take the money you save by not eating here and take a taxi down to Chinatown and eat at Gold Mountain or New Asia. 

Yank Sing is more for the weekday Corporate foodies. One thing I did like about this place is the Peking Duck.
author: Vanessa C.

description:
Yes, this is very "banana" dim sum but the quality is good and so is the service.

Yes, it is somewhat expensive for dim sum -- but it's in the FiDi .. so expected.  I took a couple of co-workers here .. lunch for 3 was $75.
author: Spicy T.

description: Soooo expensive for what you get. I treated some out of towners to lunch here because I've been wanting to try YS for a while, and figured it's cleaner and is more aesthetically pleasing than most dim sum places.  Service was very good but the prices are absolutely ridiculous! Lunch for the three of us was $100 with tip, and when I returned to the office I realized I was still hungry.  We ordered the usual dumplings but I found the sauces on lots of the items to be too sweet. My favorite item was probably the soup dumplings, which was surprising to see on the menu because dim sum places don't usually have them.  The chicken feet were disappointing, and overall I found the portions to be tiny (for example they have a roast duck item but if you order one serving you get a small dumpling with duck meat in it - not a plate of duck!). I wouldn't come back here again as there's so many other good dim sum places in the Bay Area that are more reasonaby priced, like Koi Palace/Garden and Mayflower.
author: Bella L.

description: Overpriced.  Overpriced.  Overpriced.  I've had so much better.  I see all the Asian people eating there and I think, Why??  The food is not that good.
author: Kris S.

description: This is an interesting place for dim sum.  I think it's great for non-asians because it's clean, in a nice location, and there's parking.  But if you really like dimsum or want delicious, authentic dimsum at a good price, this is not the place for you.  My homie and I spent $75 here together for a dimsum lunch.  That's crazy!  In fact, thats CWAZY??!  We were distracted by the honey cod, which was flaky and delicious but cost $20 bucks.  That's a LOT for a dimsum dish.  The soup dumplings are good, the quality of dimsum is good, but I feel that you have to pay close attention or you'll end up spending wayyy too much for brunch.
author: Terry K.

description:
Yank Sing...the best place on earth for a Dim Sum! 

We've been to this place years ago and only decided to go again because of Food Network's "The Best thing I Ever Ate" episode.  The baked pork buns were mentioned so we decided to go.  

We got there around 11:15 and we were seated right away.  Food carts started rolling to us as soon as we were seated. Everything was so delicious and we were really enjoying the food...until my son saw hair (almost like a baby's hair) embedded on top of a dumpling he was about to eat. GROSS! so I told one of the waiters right away and my first thought was he would probably just take it and ignore it altogether. Boy was I wrong...he told his manager and he apologized and replaced the order right away! Now that's what I call service! Yes we found hair but I'm sure every restaurant has those. It's how they took care of the incident is what impressed me!  So everything was fine and we continued to enjoy our lunch. All the waiters and ladies pushing the carts were very friendly. If we didn't see a certain dumpling that we wanted they call each other thru their headsets and within seconds, they're there for you. 

The baked Pork Bun was okay...nothing to really rave about.  I would say the best thing I ever ate is their fried soft shell crab!!! It's the bomb! It was my favorite back then and it still is!!!  

So, for the 4 of us (my kids 10 & 14) plus hubby...the bill came out to $76.00...not bad! We satisfied our craving for great dim sum. Hubby is thinking of doing dim sum at least once a month! I have no problem there...
author: Maria K.

description: My first Dim Sum I have ever had. It was a great experience and made me love it! It is now added to my top 10! The only thing I didnt like was how fast everything came. I felt like I had to eat everything right away. Next time I will take my time and let the carts pass and wait for them to come again.
author: Seanna S.

description:
I love taking people here from out-of-town. Especially if they are not very adventurous in their food preferences. Even my dad liked it, loved it, actually. The food is so good that they are bound to enjoy themselves.  The shanghai dumplings, shrimp dumplings, Peking duck, bean curd it is all great. I think, maybe, I've had better Shanghai dumplings and shrimp dumplings, etc. at other places in they city, but never this quality all in one place. This is my favorite dim sum place in the city. 
The only downfall is the wait can be long and it can be expensive. Which is why we usually only come here when we have guests, for the dim sum experience at its best!
author: Kathleen Y.

description:
yank sing you stink

all Ingredients are fresh, but taste were average. 

We had pretty much all carts could offer, nothing was extraordinary. 

nice place over priced
author: S S.

description: Xiao long bao (ginger pork royal dumplings), their signature dish was very good. The rest of the dim sum was above par but I've never had to pay $$$ for dim sum so I didn't think the price was worth the amount given.  We got maybe 6 dim sum dishes and paid over $80... Next I'd rather find a good hole in the wall place and pay a bit less.  I think its because it's located in Rincon Center and within a "nice" mall area thus we paid their "rent".
author: Nghi L.

description:
YUM, but holy crap the prices are nuts here. Fast service, nice variety of dim sum, and everything I've had (generally the seafood items) is fresh and flavorful. But, did I mention holy crap, the prices? Just track your orders via the menu they leave on the table, otherwise you'll be a bit shellshocked when you get the bill. It's so easy to just choose and eat without thinking. Save room for dessert: the coconut "cream" (it's actually the egg custard in the middle) roll is really freaking good, and not too pricey when compared to the other dishes. Even though I love dim sum and live in SF, I end up here maybe 2-3x/year, mainly prohibited by the cost.

P.S. If you park in the garage, be sure to get your ticket validated and use the machine by the elevator before you leave.
author: Pop L.

description: The best dim sum I have had in years.  Great service.  The dishes are diverse and yummy.  It is a bit more expensive than I wound anticipate, about $25 per person with moderate eaters.  It was worth the tasty treat.
author: Rebekah W.

description: Came with a couple of friends last sunday around 10:30 am. The food was ok. Some good, some not so good. There was nothing spectacular to talk about regarding the flavor of all the dim-sum and there was not a lot of dim-sum being cirulated.
author: Maria H.

description:
Ahh the famous Yank Sing.  I finally got a chance to come here on someone else's dime, but even for free, I didn't think the dim sum was superb compared to great places like HK Flower Lounge and Koi Palace.  The food was good, 4 stars, but I'm docking a star for how expensive the place is.  Roughly $30/person without ordering that much food, compared to somewhere like "Old Place" in Oakland which is $9/person with too much food, and the quality is only 0.5 star lower than Yank Sing (3.5 stars or so).  

and no matter what, DON'T get the Mango Pudding.  It's pretty atrocious.
author: Kryzak K.

description: The Dim Sum on Christmas Day!  Fresh, tasty, non-oily, and the service was friendly and prompt.
author: Rebecca B.

description: A friend of mine introduced me to this place and I am in love with the variety of dim-sum they serve...delicious!!
author: Priti P.

description:
I used to love Yank Sing and recently returned one Sunday after a hiatus of several years.  But I realized something as I sat among the tourists, reviewing my $75 bill for two (and we didn't eat much) and sucking the last of my Yank Sing lemonade through a straw from its jumbo, Las Vegas-style glass: Yank Sing has jumped the shark's fin dumpling.   No specific complaints, but I'll stick to Ton Kiang.

Or so I've been told.  Due to San Francisco's discriminatory and unfair health regulations, I am not actually allowed to enter this restaurant.
author: spot d.

description:
When you
-want to be treated like a human being while eating good dim sum 
-would like to hear a thank you (instead of getting a dirty look) after declining a dim sum cart lady's offers
-want to eat in a clean environment
-want refined dim sum with fresh ingredients

Not when
-an extra $20 per person will break the bank
-you want to order everything that is offered

Like other Yelpers, I have wondered why I am paying close to $35 per person for a dim sum lunch when there are other dim sum joints that are half the cost. After years of internal debate I have recently come to the conclusion that it is worth the extra $15-$20 (per person) one pays at Yank Sing.
The problem is that while there are better dim sum out there, it seems to come at a cost - dirty teapots, smelly waiters/waitresses, one hour waits, herding customers like cattle. Any place where the hosts greets me with a smile, waiters and push cart ladies that thank me on the way out even though they may not have serviced my table, and the quality of dim sum is more refined and delicate can have my extra $20 - god knows I have spent more on less.
author: Joe L.

description:
Superb decor (I'd rather sit inside though) = good for business meal / bring parents. I mean you know something is up when they bring the tea in a transparent fancy vessel (I thought it was cool haha)

The dimsum is actually very decent, refined (as you would expect for the target audience, you pay heftily as well). I've read about how they have a lot of weird items but they have most regular items as well

Stand out
- seabass (do get it, although it is $13.50)
- soup dumplings / xiao long bao (make sure you don't get one that's been out for a while)
- shrimp rice noodle rolls / ha cheong fun
- turnip cakes / lo bak go

No go
- that orange jello dessert, granted I don't do jello

With Harbor Village gone, this is a solid place but the lack of Chinese patrons just doesn't sit well with me (they seem to have a lot of tourists so it is one of those places)
author: xo x.

description:
Having been told by co-workers and friends that this is one of the top 2 dim sum places in SF, I had to give it a try. Just so happened I brought along two experts to check out the goods: my parents. 

The verdict: moms and pops approve. They enjoyed every bite as did I. We marveled and cooed as we gorged on the signature Shanghai Dumplings (xiao long bao) and sat back amazed at the various dishes that were being pumped out of the kitchen. We ordered a whole mess of stuff and out of all of them my parents were somewhat disappointed in only two: the chinese broccoli and the chicken feet. Both a bit skimpy on the portion especially the broccoli. They thought the chicken feet lacked flavor, I for one don't do feet so defer to them for the thumbs up or down.
