We took a leisurely approach to the meal starting around 10:30 and leaving around 12:30. The place was packed by the time we left, so good thing we got there early. Not even a faulty fire alarm during our meal was enough to drive us or other diners from their food. 

Which is saying a lot especially when you get the bill. My parents pretty much gasped but quickly rationalized the price with their sated appetite and overall enjoyment. That soon didn't last as they then launched into immediate mathematical calculations and comparisons of other dim sum places in Vegas and Ocean Star in L.A. At least they now have a story of spending 90 bucks for 3 people to share with their friends. Ouch...bring that pocketbook if you do decide to eat here. Though expensive, it's worth it.
author: vivian h.

description:
Oh, man, does this place rock!
Everytime I'm in the city, it's gotta be weekend dim sum brunch at Yank Sing. They run that place like a well-oiled machine, and the dim sum is delicious. I love the "shrimp balls." They pop in your mouth.
author: amanda b.

description:
I cheated on Ton Kiang today and went over to Yank Sing for dim sum. It was what i remembered - pretty high quality dim sum but 50-100% more costly than other places. 

They do validate parking for rincon center so park without fear.
author: hunter w.

description:
Along with Hong Kong East Ocean in Emeryville, Yank Sing has the best tasting dim sum in the bay area.  Their dumplings are amazing.  No views like at East Ocean but the restaurant is very nice and much more upscale than you're traditional dim sum place.

Also the service is good, not faster but certainly more civil (dare I say it... western?) than at East Ocean.  And the waiters speak more consistent English and will actually speak to white people.

The downside is the price.  You can easily break $30 per person here.  But if you like those dumplings as much as I do, it could be worth it once in a while, but 4 out 5 dim sum trips I'll go to East Ocean.

At least they validate parking so that lessens the sting a bit.

3.5 stars rounded up because I'm feeling nostalgic for those dumplings right now.
author: Vince R.

description:
Ok, the dim sum is generally of a higher quality than most places, however, there are 2 dim sum joints in the LA area that have levels of quality that are close but are at least half if not one quarter the price.  For the prices this place charges, I would expect nothing but perfection which it was not.  

First the shiao lung baos that people keep raving about are far from the best I've ever had.  The outer skin in NOT as delicate as the one's from Din Tai Fung in Taipei, and the meat quality is horrible.  I was spitting out hard little pieces of cartilage/bones from a couple of my baos.  The juice inside was very good though.

Their har gows were also less than spectacular.  Again, the outer skin was not as delicate as some other places I've been to.

The rest of my meal was at the 5 star level.

The place is very clean, service is fast and friendly.

The total lunch bill for 2 people was $80 not including drinks. 

Overall, I would say food is 4.5 stars, service 4 stars, decor 3 stars, value 3 stars thus a total composite score of 3.625 which I rounded up to 4 stars.
author: Walt C.

description:
What really puts Yank Sing above its peers are is service.  The food is good.. good quality and very good variety/selection.  Tea is good too.   People say you can find better food but I'll be honest and say that's pretty hard to find, especially with the depth you have here and consistently good quality across all the dishes.

I was lucky I guess also in that I came later on a Sunday, just after the peak.  We had no wait at all, yet there was still plenty of activity and the carts were constantly coming by.   By the way, Yank Sing is one of the few places remaining that can afford to still run with carts (vs. menu), I think in large part to the huge amount of space they have, especially on weekends overflowing into the indoor mall courtyard.  The fact that they use carts alone makes it a better choice for novices (being able to see the dishes).  It's great for experts too, being able to judge the dish first before committing to buy it!

People complain the price was high, but I didn't think it more than I expected.
author: David B.

description:
Still the best place in SF for dim sum in my opinion.  Every time someone tells me about some other place I get excited only to come away disappointed after trying it.
I agree it's over priced, but more than that, something is missing since they moved from the Battery Street location some years ago.  It's not the same, yet I haven't found anything better.
author: Kara H.

description:
my tummy is always happy after i came here. so this is my long overdue review. i've been going to yank sing since what 8-10 years ago?!? i can't believe i never did review for them. 
i like to eat inside ( area after the glass door & the yanksing front desk) rather than outside (it's still indoor but outside yanksing) bcs outside feels more like a food court.
there is something about yanksing that makes me feel special after eating dim sum here.
i'm a vegetarian, so i always ask them to bring vegetarian stuff. I like the peashoot steam dumpling & also the spinach and some other vegetarian stuff. oh i also like that salad purple cabbage with lemon sauce and walnut. yumm...
the food here is made really fresh and clean and i always can taste that, & that what makes me to come back here all the time.
price is a lil pricey, but hey it's worth it, you've to spoil yourself at least once a week to really appreciate yourself as a worthy being in the universe. :D
to me i will always come back here. the service is standard good, staff are friendly, and i will always come back!!
author: Ms C.

description:
the food is great , the service was on par but the dim sum was way to over priced. 
sorry but i wont be back .
author: eric d.

description: The dim sum here is expensive, but I think it's worth it.  The restaurant is clean, service is good, and the wait staff speak English.  Personally, I prefer the steamed dishes, such as the shrimp dumplings and pork buns, to the fried stuff.  Other than the price, the only other drawback is the long wait for a table.  The space next door has a counter for take out orders.
author: Arthur C.

description: best dim sum i've had in san francisco. enough said.
author: Mia M.

description: Very Good dim sum in good location; Had mum tea; baked char siu bao; steamed pork dumplings; make their own chili sauce; best steamed Chinese broccoli I ever had; soft-shell  crab; downside was cost- very expensive for dim sum; if you want cheaper, go to Chinatown
author: Phil G.

description: This is one of our Must Stop whenever we are in SF area.  I understand the wait and the line gets crazy long sometimes but I believe you will walk out happy afterward.  The servers are very good and efficient.  The only down side is the parking.  Parking at the Rincoln Center is a test of ones patients.  The parking lot attendants are not the most courteous people you have ever met nor do they really care how long it takes to get your car back.  But the dim sum at Yank Sing make the trip worth it, every time.
author: Grace Y.

description: Fast and furious. I came here with a group of friends, after the longest walk through town ever. We needed food, water and beer...fast. Yank Sing did not disappoint. The dishes were fresh, nicely made and very fast. The Honey Sea Bass was incredible...except for the price. We had a beautiful chunk of Sea Bass, approx 4 x 3..and it was $19.00!! The only problem with this place is that you are inundated with food in a frenzy...and it doesnt allow you to keep track of the price. So, after a nice lunch for 4..you are looking at a bill of $200.00!! It really felt like a racket. Too bad, it takes away from an otherwise seamless experience.
author: kathleen s.

description: Had lunch w/neice who drove down from Napa. This was her suggestion. Clean. Great service. Easy parking. Best dishes for me were the sticky rice, shanghai dumplings and deep fried taro. Normally don't care for chinese broccoli, but this one was tender and not stringy. I feel it was a little pricey for dim sum.
author: Patti S.

description: This place is reaallly good, but there are small portions and prices are too high for a casual meal.
author: Lan N.

description: It's expensive. Very. So is Gary Danko, but you know what? People don't bitch about that. You know why? Because it's really, really good. So is Yank Sing - they are really, really good at what they do, but for whatever reason, lots of people cant give them credit. I guess because it is POSSIBLE to get good dim sum cheap, though not easy in san francisco, in my experience. In any case, yank sing does just about everything it does very, very well, and the xiao long bao are to die for . So it's expensive, yes. And white people go there, yes. But if it's really good dim sum you are after, suck up these minor inconveniences and go to Yank Sing.
author: Erica W.

description:
5-stars for wedding banquet
these guys consistently cook great chinese food for large parties - they have a great menu that goes from cheap to super-expensive and allows you to choose the food based on your budget...it's a gorgeous location especially with the waterfall - have been to several wedding banquets here!

3-stars for dim sum
come here for their shanghai dumplings - delicious - the only problem is they don't have a large variety of the other dim sum and not to mention it's pretty expensive - however, if you're in the mood for high quality dim sum in a super-clean environment this is the place to go - if you're looking for variety and value - go to chinatown...this isn't the place for you...
author: Andrew T.

description: This place has good food, but it's so expensive! It's really better off to go to C-town and find a better place that serves dim sum!
author: Cristina D.

description: Excellent dim sum, but a bit over priced... Make sure to get the sui mai.
author: Josh E.

description: Yes, it's expensive, crowded and you could get dim sum for half the price some where else. Oh and yes, parking is difficult. Don't care, love this place. It's impressive. Not every dish is out of the park but the ones that are great are really great. Love the sea bass, egg tarts, sesame ball, pork shu mai. Duck is good. Service is good. Everytime I go, I am happy.
author: Debbie O.

description:
For the food I would give it four stars, but the location, and invariable wait even with reservations, and availability of other dim sum places make this on the low end of mediocre.  

Maybe a nice place for dim sum for people not familiar with the city and not into atmosphere who don't care if it is overpriced?
author: Heidi P.

description:
A fabulous Dim Sum spot.  Very good service when compared with other Chinese restaurants.  A bit on the expensive side but cleanliness, service, location and unique items make it worth the extra few bucks.  Dim Sum lunch for 5 was $130 but that included food directly from the kitchen and dessert.  

Custard tarts hot and flaky, yummmmy (ask for them from the kitchen) - Peking Duck cart was wonderful.  The best Shanghai dumplings this side of the Pacific.

We had 12:30pm reservations on Sunday, was seated at 12:45pm.  Wait was 1 hour without reservation, which I highly recommend.  Free validated parking.
author: Beautiful B.

description:
Hubby's Review:

A nice place for dim sum.  The quality is definitely up there with the best.  They always have something new to trot out.  I really like their Shanghai dumplings...scrumdelish!  The servers are nice and professional.  Other places the dim sum ladies would glare at you and give you the stink eye if you were to be so bold as to decline their offerings.  Not here...I suppose they probably get a verbal brow beating from the manager if that was the case.  The place could use a little sprucing up though...it's starting to show it's age.  That's always the case with Chinese restaurant...no upkeep whatsoever.   I guess the only drawback (and why Wifey and I are not here on a regular basis) is the price.  It's a bit pricey for "touch heart" items.
author: Mr. and Mrs. L.

description:
They have the best Shanghai Dumplings I've ever had in bayarea so is the only dim sum dish my dad approved in San Francisco City (trust me, you have no idea how picky my dad is in terms of food) but unfortunately that's about it, all the other dishes are really not that outstanding. it is very pricey, but you do sorta get what you pay for. The decor is exquisite, the service is professional and friendly. 
There is usually a long line during peak time and I do like the way they treat it: give you a walky talky so you can walk around and keep in touch with the latest availability. And YES, I ended up having lunch at the place next to it because I was very hungry once.......
author: Shiqi Y.

description:
Although a bit pricey as far as dim sum goes, I love this place.  My personal favorite for many years.  I feel the quality and the selection of the dishes cannot be found elsewhere easily.  The staff is courteous and professional, servers are friendly and knowledgeable.  I wish there were more locations!  (probably my only gripe)

I would highly recommend this place.
author: Miss F.

description:
We just moved to the bay area from East Coast and were sightseeing in SF. We found this place by accident, we parked in the basement of this building. We saw a lot of people waiting, and since it's almost lunch time, we decided to give it a try. 

At first I was very impressed with their tea & teapot. It's very good quality, but of course you have to pay for it, later on I found they charged almost $10 for the tea for 4 people ( 2 adult & 2 kids). The food was good quality, the place was clean and the service was ok but I was so shocked when I saw the bill. It was almost $80. We did not ordered a lot since we all had some breakfast. (If we ordered like what we usually do, I believe it would be easily over $120.) We go out for dim sum quite a lot. And I've never had such a huge bill for dim sum. 

I would give the food a 4 star but the price would be a 1 star, so average 3 star.
author: Pearl K.
Teddy S.

description: The best dim sum I have had in over 15 years since Yuen Yung closed in Menlo Park!  Everything that we tried was over-the-top delicious!  A big selection for our vegetarian daughters; lots of seafood for me, and pork for the hubby.  Such a fun experience as you select from the carts of steaming hot delicacies!  We had the shrimp dumplings, the spinach and the mushroom dumplings, vegetarian rolls, steamed pork buns, potstickers, soup dumplings (incredible!), stir fried snap peas, spring rolls, sesame balls and mango pudding....to name a few.  The space is large and a little noisy (unless you request the carpeted dining room); but with the enormous glass ceiling to floor waterfall, it really is a fun spot!  We could converse just fine, and I always love a white table cloth w/ paper for my impromptu design ideas.  Service was excellent!  I can't wait to go again!
author: Leslie R.

description: More like "Yank The Wallet Right Out Of My Pocket". What kind of douchery is a $30 dim-sum meal for ONE PERSON? Screw you moneybags financial district jerks.
author: Vic W.

description:
I think they make the best Xiao Long Bao in the Bay Area.  The skin is thin but won't break when you pick up with chopsticks.  Not like other places who use aluminum cups to hold the juices in because they can't make the skin right.  I think it's one of their more expensive items -about $12 for six.

The shrimp dumpling was delicious - large chunks of shrimp and it tasted fresh.

The sweet rice in lotus leaf was so good that we had to order more.  Ratio of stuffing to rice was excellent.  The sauce was flavorful.  This is a typical dish my parents order for every dim sum outing and even they said it's the best they've had in SF.

The jook with thousand year egg and pan fried chicken bun were good. 

Fried crab claw was okay; nothing memorable.  It's about $12 for two claws. 

Not so good:  spinach dumpling, mushroom dumpling, and beef rice roll.  Definitely not a fan of the spinach though the mushroom was okay. The beef rice roll as okay too, just didn't have much flavor.

I must say, this is THE most expensive dim sum I've had for standard items.  $40/person.  Worth it if you consider it doesn't have the long line, takes reservations, has the best ambiance (can talk without shouting across the table) and validated parking for three hours on weekends.
author: D C.

description:
expensive (compared to chinatown shops).
saltier (compared to chinatown shops).
overcooked (compared to chinatown shops).

see where im getting at?

their chili dipping sauce is surprisingly good though, famous i heard.

but their bbq pork buns were unworthy: two buns per order, too much dough, uninspired pork filling.
author: Ethan L.

description: Great food, validated parking, excellent service and atmosphere. I am not an expert on Dim Sum but I really liked this place. Only 4 of 5 since I rarely give 5 stars unless spectacular. I WILL return!
author: Barry F.

description:
we've been going here for years and it's always been a bit pricy but worth it - our last experience tho was really sad
our phone reservation (they no longer use opentable) had disappeared
1 of the annoying things about their dim sum is that they bring around 'special' dishes that are WAY more expensive - but you don't find that out until they bring the check
we were charged a mystery $39 and when we asked what it was for (since we had only had the standard siu mai etc.), they said there was a problem with the system and they got a '6' when the system input a '3' - they halved the $39, but we never did find out what it was supposed to be for - since our guest was right there at the table, we gave up fighting, but they definitely overcharged us significantly
it was sunday during chinese new year's, so the place was packed and there was a wait even with the hostesses honoring our lost reservation - but the bill issue had nothing to do with the crowd
sadly, i think our days of going to yank sing are done!
author: Nancy M.

description: Good but as dim sum goes, expensive.  Probably won't go back and will opt for more reasonably priced dim sum in SF.
author: Dwight B.

description: This is the best dim sum place we have been to in the city because of the service.  The dimsum tastes healthy and void of the oily mess that typically makes me tired after a meal of "little hearts".   P.S.  Their variation of the turnip cake is the tastiest I've ever had.
author: Love P.

description: I've been coming to Yank Sing since the 1970s.  The food is still good despite the high prices.  You will not leave hungry!!!  Everything is delicious!!!!
author: Morgan A.

description: If you want to pay triple the cost for dim sum in then eat here. We got 5 dishes cost $70. Ate in Chinatown next day and got better dim sum, more dishes for $20. The dim sum was very Americanized. The servers attacked our table with three carts before we could get our coats off. I know my dim sum and this is not the place to go. D. Chin Louisville KY
author: Douglas C.

description:
Went for Sunday afternoon dim sum in early August 2010.

Great variety of fresh-from-the-kitchen finger foods but not all of them are necessarily light or mild. Food generally tasted very flavorful and the service although rushed was efficient. 

One thing they lacked much of are desserts. They had some custards and seemingly only 1 or may be 2 different fresh fruit items.
author: Marc P.

description: Such overpriced chinese food that isn't even good.
author: Nancy L.

description: The food is good, not spectacular.  My favorite is the honey glazed roast pork.  While most other Chinese restaurants are pretty standard, the roast pork here seems to have been cooked longer than the standard.  The flavor penetrates almost all the way through.  Bang for your buck, this is not the place.  For a dim sum house its pretty expensive, but you get cleanliness and service.  There's a waiter/host there, I think his name is Kent.  He actually "re-freshened" our egg custard dish, realizing that we ordered it earlier and he wanted us to experience it warm (I order these early since I'm never sure when they are going to run out).  I was floored.  I've never had anyone re-fresh my dim sum.  Service is definitely a 5 star because of that.
author: David H.

description: Went there for lunch its good food but priced decently. The servers come by often with the carts and plenty of options.
author: Pranav C.

description: Was visiting SF for my 30th and desperately wanted good dim sum (coming from the DC area) Yank Sing definitely hit the spot! We tried most dishes we've never seen before. They had this vineagrette salad with shredded purple cabbage and toasted walnut that we all enjoyed. So funny all 4 girls had our teapot refilled 4 times because it was that GOOD granted we also wanted to make up for the $7 for tea =). Overall, dim sum was good but pricey. The most expensive I've seen for dim sum but I think was worth it. You know how some places you go are pricey but leaves you unsatisfied? Yank Sing satisfied me.
author: Ngoc L.

description:
Breaks my heart to write a 3 star review for a place that I once considered to be the best dim sum in SF.  

Never for the price averse crowd, Yank Sing used to have delicious and unique creations such as "Lobster Dumplings", "Crab Dumplings", etc..  I for one, did not mind shelling out $10+ for an order of either one, but now, those delicious creations are gone, and all they have are the ubiquitous har gow, siu mai and friends.  Normal dim sum, but priced higher than it should be.   

Its pretty funny, but those that dine here know that some of the servers here peddle "Special Dishes", or as I like to call them, "White Man's Trap".  Do any of us come to dim sum to eat "Chinese Chicken Salad", or "Roast Chilean Sea Bass"?!  Pass please......
author: Eric K.

description: The Best Dim Sum on the West Coast but Hakkasan will give Yank Sing some serious competition.  Yank Sing is great for hearty delicious traditional Dim Sum.  Hakkasan is spectacular for inventive, delicate, delicious and "modern" Dim Sum.  If you go to both, you will have had the best Dim Sum America has to offer.  SF is sooooo lucky to have both!
author: Bill M.

description: I love pretty much any dim sum, and this place is way more expensive than others.  Really the only reason this place stands out is their shanghai dumplings.  OMG these are a delicious broth explosion...just let them cool down first!
author: Maureen K.

description: Great dim sum! I love the shanghai dumplings, but be careful, its hot as hell inside, and don't let the soupy juicy goodness squirt to your face, because it will hurt. Use a spoon and bit a little hole on the edge and suck out the soup. I like to go early so its not so crowded. Service is great, even with hundreds of people eating at one time, they managed to keep the service level up. Its a little pricey and little bit too touristy for me..but overall, its my top choice of dim sum place to go in San Francisco.
author: Wendy C.

description:
OK, I love, love, love Yelp because I get a lot of different perspectives on the same establishment. But.... it cracks me up when people go to an expensive establishment and complain that "OMG! It is expensive!" Yank Sing costs a lot of money, they don't claim to be cheap. And they serve the best Dim Sum in San Francisco. If you have a penchant for greasy, limp Har Gau, then this is not your place. If you prefer a place where your number is called out in cantonese, then this is not your place. The atmosphere is more office park than China Town.

I would prefer a little more attentiveness to clearing plates and keeping the teapot filled but otherwise Yank Sing is better than any Dim Sum I have had in Hong Kong or out in the Avenues. I suggest you save it for a special treat. And, they take reservations! Don't wait an hour for a table, call thirty minutes before you get there. You may have to wait five minutes or so but it beats waiting with the tourists.
author: Stuart H.

description:
Ask anyone in SF where to go for dim sum and they immediately say "Yank Sing"... after hearing this from approximately a million unrelated people I decided it was time to give it a shot...

My friend and I beat the rush by arriving before 11:00 am on a Saturday and were seated in the atrium immediately (with no reservation).  Within seconds of being seated we were giving our tea order and enjoying instant access to the delicacies on the numerous carts rolling past.  As a pesce-veg there were plenty of options... veg filled spinach dumplings, fried tofu, Chinese broccoli, shiitake mushroom dumplings... I even tried the shrimp & chive and scallop & cilantro dumplings... everything was soooooo good.  The Rincon Center location has a pleasantly airy ambiance and the indoor water feature made dim sum, a potentially frenetic dining experience, somehow soothing...

We rolled out of there, fat and happy, $60 for the two of us.  I now join the millions of people gladly recommending Yank Sing to people for dim sum in SF...
author: Daniele M.

description:
I was first taken to this restaurant by my godparents for a celebration on the day after New Years. The line was practically through the entire Rincon Center. BUT, we actually were seated rather quickly (20 minutes or so). The only reason I was willing to wait was my company's rave reviews for the place.

Turns out, they were right. The food was amazing! They are incredibly organized (have many different carts with each dish, synced by headsets). Very easy to be served everything you want in literally, a few minutes. While it is pretty damn pricey, the experience/meal is well worth it!
author: Alex T.

description:
Extremely overpriced. A huge ripped off. 
My friend highly recommended it so I gave it a try. The line was huge but 70% were non-Asian. I was told the wait would be over an hour so we decided to get the To-Go. I was speechless when I found out the "Har Gaw" was $6.5, one sticky rice was $5.4 and the shrimp "Cheung Fun" was $8. Who paid that price for dim sum?  I guessed I just did. I was hoping they must be exceptionally tasty. When I saw the portion of the food and finally taste them. I was so mad that I decided to sign up on yelp and put some sense to people who gave this place 4-5 stars. They are simply serving 1-2 stars quality food but paying 4-5 stars rent. Rincon center in FiDi.  Come on, the food is just mediocre. With that price tag, it makes it ridiculous. Go a little further and try the Hong Kong Lounge. Much better food, huge portion and better price. I still can't believe that the cheung fun is $8. Outrageous. Absolutely wont be back.
author: Gladys W.

description: LOVE this place.  it's so delicious and the shanghai dumplings are so good.  we love to bring any visitors to SF here.  we even know people who swear by the dim sum here and claim that it's better than hong kong, though i doubt that's really true.
author: Libbi J.

description: Overpriced for over-rated DIM SUM. Ended up spending over a bill for 4 people to eat. Only thing worth mentioning was their Shanghai dumplings which is comparable to Din Tai Fong in taiwan/LA. Other than that, dim sum is nothing different than places like Great Eastern for a fraction of the cost. I can see why half the restaurant is all business or foreigners.
author: Patrick M.

description: Best dimsum. No tummyaches. No headaches afterwards. Everything tastes fresh. Everything looks beautiful. No one screaming in my face something I don't understand.
author: Sandy H.

description: I have to say, it's the best Shanghai Dumpling in town!! Love the dim sum there and love the environment!  Also try their baked sea bass!
author: Jacky L.

description:
Indeed,

at my heart's desire...

So my first outing for Dim Sum and this is the place my sister's friend, Mrs. Pauline bring us to. Yeah, some of you say, same plate and quality but a higher price tag. Well to a novice, the food was enjoyable, and after all, the company is what matters the most, right ?

So, we initially sit and chat to catch up while we let the green tea brew and simmer in the presentable glass pot. Pauline says we should have tea first and then we'll proceed to eat at our hearts desire. So while sis and Pauline speak, I look about at all the variety of Dim Sum items being thrown about, well not literally but, you get what i mean. Pauline just keep deflecting attempts of cart pushers pimping out noodle wrapped goodness. It was like she was the gate keeper and these carts weren't quite yet invited to our tea party.

So after a few minutes of talk and tea sipping, (which was an eternity for me) she let's the first barrage of items through.

BAM(catapult sound, 1st volley) 
- Steamed BBQ Pork Buns
- Shrimp Dumplings
- Pork & Shrimp Siu Mye

The words of my eloquent friend Rick W. echoed in me head, "Wow....wow, woooow"

 - The Buns, just tore apart and offered a savory tasting of sweetened Pork. 
 - The Shrimp was just a straight, no B.S. ball of ground shrimp, no joke, all business. Beyond satisfying, I tell ya.
 - The P & S Siu Mye was a piece of heaven sent via a thin noodle scroll ala Ten Commandments.

BOOM (2nd volley)
- Seu Lung Pau
- Seaweed wrapped fried Tofu w/ chives (no direct name, so I'm told)
- Sea Bass

 - The S.L. Pau was interesting...I busted my first one, it was left for dead with all it's liquids left unappreciated at the bottom of the basket. But my 2nd attempt was a success ! Paired with ginger sauce that just accentuated all the inner savoriness. We had 2 servings of this, btw. 
 - The Seaweed Tofu was a crunchy surprise that actually tasted like, meat. It was definitely a welcome change to the pallet. 
 - The Sea Bass was braised in a sauce that I couldn't really I.D. It was a little salty that gave way to rich sweetness. The piece of steamed fish was beyond tender and paired well with the sauce. 

As we were beginning to feel the end of the battle was at hand and it seemed that victory was in reach. Reinforcements came.

WHACK (3rd volley)
- Stuffed Crab Claw
- Lotus Leave Steamed Rice
- Sesame Balls
- Custard Tarts
- Sweet Buns

 - The Stuffed Claw caught my eye a few rounds ago, and I was able to snatch it this time around. Honestly, it was one of the better things I had this afternoon. I was seriously enjoying everything, but this was one of the highlights ! The combination of fried ground crab and shrimp was popping with flavor. That, paired with the red sweet and sour sauce has permanently etched a wrinkle in me brain for further longing in the future.
 - The Steamed rice was a nice compliment to the previous tastings. The rice was infused with pork in a great sauce. 
 - Sesame Balls seemed to be what my sister was waiting for. Yes, it was good but didn't really float my boat.
 - The Custard Tarts, on the other hand, had me at hello. I got my first piece and quickly jumped on my second in no time. Mrs. Pauline saw my eagerness for them and offered this advise, "Stop b.s.'n with the tart, and go for what's important, THE CUSTARD !!" Oooooh yeeeeeah, right on, thanks....slurrrrrp. 
 - The Sweet Buns were alright, she never called back or answered my texts (shoulder shrug)

I have to say my first outing at Deem Sum was a success ! I thoroughly enjoyed the outing, the food, and the company. I do hope that my follow up visit at other spots stay the course and keep me happy and longing for these little surprises in wicker baskets. Thank you again, Mrs. Pauline, Te mereces un diez !
author: chico f.

description: The Shanghai Soup Dumplings are absolutely incredible!  I have never described any food as being almost better than sex, but these little gems did indeed make my eyes roll back...tender, thin wrappers, unctuous broth, kurobuta pork filling...Ooooo, and with perfectly seasoned vinegar and slivered ginger.  And the Sea Bass was pure decadence and worth every penny...perfectly carmelized, juicy and tender.  We started 2013 here and loved it so much we went back the next day for lunch before heading home, priced be damned!  Go!  At least once!  And ask for Xiao Jian as your head server.  She is wonderful.
author: Taunya B.

description: Very good dim sum but be prepared to pay for it. I heard from a Chinese friend that there are some specialty dishes that you can not get elsewhere in SF. Very special place to go to once in a while. Note: Not many vegetable dishes available, well at least what my server could offer. I still give it 4 stars though! BTW, very good tea and service. Very tasteful atmosphere and good service.
author: Don J.

description: Bring your wallet - good dim sum and service but very pricey and considerably more than the dim sum restaurants in Chinatown.  Some dishes not found in other dim sum restaurants but most of fare fairly standard.  Servers also a little aggressive particularly the ones who carries the trays as will almost place the dishes on your table and then asking if you would like the dish or not.  Servers with push carts do not do this.  To impress someone or for a special occasion, bring them here - otherwise head to Chinatown or Clement Street.
author: Charlie W.

description: Having eaten dim sum for most of my life, I'm a very harsh critic when it comes to this subject matter. YS's dim sum is made very meticulously.. each one having a presentation value and uniformity. Taste is very good, with never an emphasis on being too overpowering. I asked myself why the dim sum was so neat and small.. then it dawned on me. The restaurant caters towards non-asians mostly.. where size and value are set aside for aesthetics and taste.
author: Alan N.

description: Best dim sum in the area. Just because a Chinese restaurant isn't cheap and dirty doesn't mean it's not good. Yes, it's a little on the high side in terms of prices, but it's not crazy expensive. And the food quality reflects the price. If you're concerned about cost, the trick is don't order any of the specials. Especially the cabbage salad thing. I don't get that one.
author: Fred D.

description:
What a HUGE disappointment. It looks like they've jacked up their prices while the food has lost its luster.  Not as good as I remember it. 

Annoying factor...as many folks have mentioned, as soon as you sit down - .coat not even off - you are accosted by waitstaff offering plates of food.  They were literally trying to place things on our table while I had to block them with my hands. Everything seemed rushed. I've been to many other dim sum restaurants where you can just relax and enjoy the experience. 

The food really wasn't even all that good. You can get comparable dim sum, if not better, at MANY other places in San Francisco.  So not returning here for a long time.

Pluses:
Fun place to take visiting out of towners so they can experience a San Francisco tourist spot...

Minuses:
Way too EXPENSIVE for the quality and quantity
Over eager waitstaff
Not very friendly hostesses
author: rosie t.

description:
This has to be one of the best places in the city for big group feasting.  I've been here a few times and have had a blast each time.  The food is great and the atmosphere is as good as it needs to be.  

Thanks Yank Sing!
author: Ivan S.

description:
I don't get excited over food, but I always get excited for Yank Sing. 

I love the instant gratification as soon as you sit down and the food is literally dropped at your table (god bless those carts with all the steamer baskets).

I love how the servers use headsets to find a dish that isn't on her/his cart - A++++ for customer service. Because of this same jovial customer service with a smile, I also don't get quite the guilt trip here when I say "no thank you" for the dishes I'm not interested in - can't say that for other dim sum places where those same declines will warrant a dirty look shot back in my face. 

I love how your empty plates/baskets/bowls get whisked away as soon as the food's been finished off of them.

BUT what I really, really, really love the most... are those black napkins. Call me simple, but Yank Sing is my happy place.
author: jcie k.

description:
This place is great and rates 4 stars.  It is more expensive when compared to the Dim Sum in other locations in the City but buyer beware.  You get what you pay for.  

If you are going on the weekend, make a reservation.
author: Michele W.

description: Good quality dim sum.  Haku, crystal shrimp dumplings, egg tarts, peking duck, cheon fun all tasty.  However, A tad over priced for dim sum. This place gets packed with locals and tourist alike during peak hours.  Sometimes you will just have to wait a bit. If you can't wait, just get dim sum to take out here and enjoy eating the food, on the nearby waterfront.
author: Ka C.

description:
Mmm mmm mmm I like me some dim sum and den some.  Dim sum is a contact sport that's always better with a large group, both because its more fun and you can sample a wider variety of dim sum.  Yank Sing has a perfect formula, serving delicious varieties while the carts, servers, and host negotiate their way between the tightly packed tables in a well-choreographed dance.

The setting is, well to me, kind of odd.  The restaurant has a space at the ground floor of a building in the financial district, but their tables also fill the center courtyard.  The courtyard is dominated by a huge fountain which is pretty but still there's something about it that feels exposed.

The dim sum though is delicious.  Whenever we get dim sum my friends and I always find ourselves scoping out the carts, trying to figure out what they have before they hit our table so we can agree on just how much we want to get.  Definitely order more than you think at each pass, you'll never know when that dim sum is going to get back into rotation.  That does however assure you that everything is fresh.  Do be prepared to be there a while so leave yourself a cushion of time if you have plans afterwards.

My favorites are the xiao long bao, char siu bao, shrimp har gow, shrimp and scallop dumplings, and peking duck.  Peking duck in individual dim sum servings?  Yes, please!! I ask them to slather it with more hoisin sauce and extra green onions and oh that tidbit of food with the crisp duck skin, lush duck meat, and tang from the sauce and onions is a little piece of heaven.  

Yank Sing is on the higher end of the price range for dim sum and I hate how I never really know how much I'm paying until the end especially since with dim sum you do tend to order with your eyes versus your stomach.  I think the price tag is worth it though for the clean digs, decent service, and delicious food.  It looks like there's a take-out service they do next door, next time I may just get the dim sum to go and save the hassle of waiting and the price tag mystery.  Somehow though I think it would cheapen the whole dim sum experience though because the carts and anticipation waiting for them is what dim sum's all about.
author: C C.

description: My review is specific to having a wedding banquet here.  I had mine in the restaurant space for 100 people and it was great.  I had considered R&G because of the food but I'm SO glad I went with Yank Sing.  It was much prettier inside and Vera was great to work with.  The wedding reception went off without a hitch and my guests commented how good the food was (and how much there was).  I did the traditional 10 course Chinese banquet.  They don't normally serve dinner here so I highly recommend the trial tasting so that you know what you're going to get.  I also think the inside space can be decorated well and for anyone who is considering this place, it's a great option if you don't like the Atrium.  All in all, very happy with the wedding reception, the open bar, and the service.
author: Tiffany C.

description: Surprisingly bad dim sum in a city known for it's Chinatown.  Every dish was not good-all right.  The two exceptions were the Peking Duck and the Scallion Cake/Dumpling (fried and soo good).  Skip crab fingers, shrimp dumplings, chicken shumai, fried chicken, chicken in foil, any pretty much anything else.  Every dish that the servers recommended were terrible.  The dessert of mango pudding and sesame balls were disappointing.  It gets pretty crowded during lunch hours.  Not everything is available during the weekday; we asked for Chinese congee and we were told that it is only available during the weekend.  The service was excellent and they kept our water glasses full and continuously changed our plates.  Expect to spend roughly 40.00 a person for a good sampling of bad dim sum.
author: Lisa H.

description: Pricey but probably some of the best dim sum in the city!
author: Alex M.

description: There are a lot...and I mean a lot of Chinese Restaurants in San Francisco.  Yank Sing is a cut above the rest. There are two of these in SF.  This one of the two is located inside a large building which contains an indoor waterfall falling from the roof of the atrium. Perfect for romance, for a family get together, for a dinner with a friend or friends...just name the scenario...it fits well. The Dim Sum is gorgeous - their Blackend Cod to die for (and I really hate dislike eating fish). The Dim Sum is brought round on trolleys - the traditional  way of Dim Sum dining. The food is brought round in an endless fashion so no need to over indulge.  The restaurant is vast and the service overall excellent. If you go to SF do go to this place.
author: Agi K.

description: "so fresh and so clean" its expensive and done very well. I would try "2 go" during the weekdays - then go on a weekend and watch that paper disappear... "crab claws"
author: Rodel B.

description:
though pricey, this is my favorite dim sum place, hands down.  since moving to Los Angeles, i've had daydreams, dreams, and serious cravings for Yank Sing dim sum.  so whenever i'm back up for family visits in northern Cali, i beg and plead to come here at least once.  

my favorite dish is the Shanghai Dumplings (Xiao long bao) -- a MUST try on your next visit.  i've tried to find another dim sum place that serves these (in southern Cali), and am still on my quest.  a close second for my favorite is the Peking Duck.  i'd come here for those 2 dishes alone.  other dim sum dishes here are also excellent.  overall, the food is delicious, and definitely worth it to try this place at least once!
author: Lisa I.

description: The stars are for the variety and quality of the dishes.  For a party of three, the bill came to be over $140.  I was not expecting this as we never checked out the list of prices that was on the table.  The sea bass was I believe $19.  However, the quality of the food was high, and my mouth still waters for the Shanghai dumplings.  If you're on a budget, be cautious!!!
author: dublin a.

description:
I've been to Yank Sing a few times prior to this experience, and thought the food was good though over priced (the pork soup dumplings are probably the stand out). I went recently for lunch one Friday; had the shrimp dumplings, the pork soup dumplings, the lotus-wrapped sticky rice. What I did not expect was getting violently ill a couple of hours after eating. In fact, I got so sick that I had to go straight home, leaving most of my personal belongings at work. 

What I expected even less, though, was the reaction of the restaurant. I called and spoke to the manager. Instead of getting an apology, or a refund for the meal - which most restaurants at this price point readily offer - he repeatedly asked me to supply a doctor's note. I expressed that I was very disappointed in the restaurant, and he passed my note on to someone in the corporate office, who did leave me a voicemail but was never available when I tried to call back.

Asking me to provide a doctor's note after I literally had to run out of the office hoping not to be seen by any of my coworkers was adding insult to injury. Did Yank Sing really think I would make such a story up, so that I could miss meetings and find myself in a potentially embarrassing situation at work?

Every other restaurant would offer at least an apology and offer of refund. As I see it, they can keep the $48, but they have lost me as a customer.
author: A W.

description: This is the best Dim sum that I had . I am giving 4 star because service can be improved because the price is on higher side  . Sesame balls are amazing .
author: Latha A.

description:
The food is good but terribly overpriced. We ordered tea, six (yes 6!) dim sum small dishes and two desserts. The total: $105!

We are not going back because the prices are too high.
author: M M.

description: All I can say is GINGER PORK!  My favorite Dim Sum place in NCAL.  Located in a beautiful building, the Rincon Center, it is close to the SF Marina where you can walk off all the food you just ate.
author: Rayne S.

description:
The dim sum here was pretty good. They are definitely way more expensive than anywhere you could possibly go in Chinatown. They're also way cleaner and more polite than anywhere in Chinatown. If you want to keep an eye on how much you're spending, take a gander at the menu list. There are items that are actually quite reasonable, and others that are ridiculous. I don't get why people are complaining about the carts coming around as soon as you sit down. This happens at every dim sum restaurant. It's like a bakery. They don't wait for you to come and THEN bake your food. Regardless, none of my food was cold.

Park in the garage--they validate: $4 off the first 2 hours. We weren't there for more than an hour so parking was free for us.

Bottom line:  If you can deal with loud pushy people, go to Chinatown and get some really delicious, cheap and authentic dim sum. Nothing beats it when it comes to taste. But if you want a nice dining experience, and have some $ to spend, come here and enjoy.
author: Camille C.

description: While downtown, its one place to go for descent dim sum - plus it has validated parking. Reduce rates M-F. Free on Weekends. This one place I call some of the Dim Sum - Americanized.
author: Johnson H.

description: There are no shortage of Dim Sum places in northern California but only this restaurant offers the cart experience and a wide selection of dishes done with impeccable precision. There are over one-hundred items listed on the menu and almost all of them are perfectly crafted and cooked, even the shaomai which in most places is treated as an after-thought gets a done right. The wait on weekends can be horrific and the prices are certainly on the high-side but for the quality and service there is no comparison.
author: Vaska R.

description:
The quality of the food is high, but so are the prices. Beware of the uber-expensive specialty dishes--you'll know these because they push them on you extra enthusiastically. They often encourage you to order one or two portions (I think the walnut prawns are $15/plate), so that can get pricey fast.

A note for families: there's not a changing table in the entire Rincon Center--not in Yank Sing's restaurant or anywhere else. It's a nightmare if you have a kid in diapers, and when I asked why they didn't have a changing table, they said it would have interfered with the "design" of the restroom. 

I'll tell you what interferes with the experience: seeing a mother change her kid on the bathroom counter!
author: Jennifer T.

description: went back despite my best instincts, and was pleasantly surprised. service was much more efficient, food was as tasty (and as pricey) as ever. the shanghai dumplings are really the only reason to eat here, and even then I'm not sure the price tag is worth the effort. compared with other dim sum joints, though, it IS tops in ambience and parking.
author: Sasha R.

description: Yanker my wanker this place rules
author: Lane S.

description: Perfect sticky rice and BBQ pork buns. I've eaten here for 10 years and it remains consistent and great. Their deluxe vegetable has perfect mushrooms and tofu.
author: p B.

description: Get the baked pork buns best thing on the menu by far
author: Ashley A.

description: Their Veggie steamed dumplings are off the charts.  Mushroom, snow peas etc.  You will walk away the happiest person.  I would guess there is no place better in the world for steamed dumplings.  Too pricey but excellent!
author: Daisy D.

description: Soo tasty! Had shanghai dumplings and they were great.Very friendly service. Waitresses were patient enough to explain what's inside the dumplings which is very atypical experience in a dim sum restaurant.
author: Ekin G.

description:
For a place that does not remotely resemble a Shanghainese dumpling shack, the xiao long bao (XLB) blows everything else that I've ever tasted in various specialty restaurants out of the water.  Look out for the carts that have bigger bamboo steamers, those are the ones that you need to focus all your attention to and reserve a space in  your stomach for.  The XLBs are out of this world.

The other dim sum choices were just as phenomenal.  I'll be honest - I'm the type that keeps ordering the same thing everywhere.  So it doesn't matter if I go to the upscale Yank Sing or the ghettolicious Wing Lee Bakery in Inner Richmond, I would end up ordering the same thing: Lo Mai Kai (sticky rice wrapped in lotus leaf), Phai Quat (steamed pork spare ribs), Char Siew Paw (bbq pork buns), deep fried crab claws, and sweet tofu dessert.  

The distinguishing factor was the quality of the food and service - everyone that thinks that they need to put up with rude non-English speaking waiters and two-hour wait to have quality dim sum can all go to  Koi Palace and fight it out.  For the mere mortals like me, it's nice to know that there's always Yank Sing.
author: Ange L.

description: Best dim-sum in the city of SF, but expensive even for the quality.  I'm surprised that there isn't more competition in this city but until a comparable contender arises, we'll be going here regularly.
author: Platform Universe S.

description: I just went here for dim sum for the 2nd time and this time, it was almost perfect. This is by far the best dim sum we've ever had. The steamed pork buns and shanghai dumplings are a must try. The service is better than most typical dim sum places. The only negative is the price which can easily run $80 for 2. Our bill was $100 for 2 and we didn't eat more than usual. Given that, I still think the place is worth the price and would come back again.
author: nik t.

description: GREAT DIM SUM in THE BAY AREA! It's just like Ten Ten's dim sum but 5 times better. It's really pricey though. When my family and I went a year ago, there were about 6 of us, and we spent more than $200 on dim sum! WTF!? But it is worth it, the ambiance is great, the service is better than Ten Ten's, and the fried taro puffs are delicious! The shrimp and pork shumai are really good too, but I think the fried taro puff was my favorite. If you're a high-roller and don't care about spending money, then Yank Sing is a great place to go! It's not in Chinatown though!
author: Danica R.

description:
do not come here at lunch with two people!  the wait is an eternity because they seem to let other parties with more people ahead of you.

our food was ok, nothing special. i would rather go to south seafood on irving.

i will say, however, that they have the best fried rice in the city.
author: Josie M.

description: Tasty with good ambiance.  Very busy and very expensive.  Delicious XLB but the pork ribs were only average.
author: Ankur P.

description: I think my lasting impression was "so expensive." It was good but again all I can think is "so expensive." It's dim sum. Those sesame balls were awesome though. So expensive.
author: m t.

description: The dim sum is average, it's not worth of price. The siumay is kinda dry, the chicken feet is good. Overall is not really great as I thought.
author: Edwin S.

description:
SAVE YOUR MONEY!!! TERRIBLE DIM SUM...TERRIBLE SERVICE

 This is the worst service AND dim sum I have ever had!

We arrived at 2:30pm.. We didn't know at the time that the restaurant close at 3:00pm, but they eagerly seated us anyway.  As we waited and waited for carts to roll around..which we really didnt see. Apparently this day was extra special because they were celebrating a servers birthday...A SERVERS birthday. As we were waiting for carts to come by our table, which there was only 2 carts that were parked at the entrance to the kitchen..It appeared we got whatever was leftover, However, we did noticed all this food being brought out to a table where all the servers were sitting down to.  As we waited for 20 minutes for a different cart we had to just flat out ask a server that was walking by for at least some rice.  The server blurted out we have no rice.  Kitchen closed. (mind you there was a HUGE pot of rice sitting on the servers table) so here we were...eating 2 plates of OVERPRICED dim sum (we found that out after we paid our bill, because you don't get to see the prices as your are ordering.  You get these cute little punches in your card). Very disappointing as we only picked this restaurant because of  the first few yelp reviews we should have kept reading.  

My advise to travelers...Save your money and go to Chinatown which is only 5 minutes away. The people there actually apreciate your business!
author: April G.

description:
Always a great experience. The steamed pork buns and the Shanghai soup dumplings are the best I've had. Consistent too: every visit they are excellent.

A pleasant surprise on my most recent meal: an interesting combination of lotus root and ground chicken, served with a sweet sauce. Very tasty. I was also impressed by the shumai and the fresh spinach dumplings.

The efficiency of the staff on a busy Sunday afternoon is awe-inspiring. I still can't get over the fact that the staff uses walkie talkies to coordinate carts and radio special requests into the kitchen. Almost before we sit down a server asks for our drink order, and then the carts begin swarming our table. This is a food paradise.

If I had to nitpick, it would be that the food comes too fast. Especially with two people, it is easy to wind up with way too much food. And the hot tea goes bitter quickly: ask for an extra teacup to place the leaves to prevent over-steeping.
author: Matt B.

description:
Disappointed after all the hype my co-worker gave the place.

Beautiful lobby with the waterfall.  I hear you can get tables out there on the weekend.

Foodwise....ewww....I had the classics of Dimsum
 - Xiao lum bao ( not bad, not great but not terrible )
 - Har gow ( bad...dry, salty, and hard )
 - Siu mai ( dry and hard )
 - Nai wang bao ( not terrible but I've had far better )
 - Char siew bao ( looked bad but my friend seemed to like it )
 - Softshell crab ( oily and oversalted. )

I've gone to takeout counters that had superior dimsum for a fraction of the price.  Kim Lee in Milpitas if you ever head out that way is a wonderful place to pick up dim sum.  Cheap and wonderful piping hot dimsum.
author: Taz D.

description: This place is only open for lunch and their dim sum IS really good! But also super expensive, the bill for the four came out to $100... for dim sum... wth! Seems like a lot of people rave about the xiao long bao here... it's good but it's not that good... didn't really catch my attention. Generally all the food is very good and the service is super fast, I guess that's how they can have such high throughput at this restaurant. We had a reservation coming here which is something I definitely recommend. They have parking underneath which they validate. Also, their egg tarts at their to go window are cheaper than eating at the tables.
author: Susan L.

description:
Yuck Sing.
Yes, that's what I call it.
I just don't like to see such a impolite person who drags around the stack of food on wagons between tables.
I just don't like the system.
I know it's a Chinese thing to serve in China but ........
I like to get order by a waitress or waiter who has a good mannered, so I'll have a moment to talk to my gust.
it's just too busy the wagon goes around.
I don't know. I think I am bitching only because the service was not really good.
I understand that they have to sell what ever in the wagon but don't be so aggressive.
I did not like seeing aggressive, rude and very uncooperative ill-mannered Asian waitress.
By the way,
Who gets the tip?
Do the waitress get paid by commission?
It's like Chinese version of Benihana, maybe?
Yank Sing is only popular for Yuppie-Americans.
I don't know.
It's very pricy, food is ok but the service sucks.
I would rather go to a small place for Dim sum.
Yuck Sing!
author: Nobu K.

description: The chung fung is AMAZING.  I love the bbq pork version but my family always eats the shrimp, too.  This has some of the best dim sum I've ever had, even compared to Leicester Sq in London.  I look for other dim sum places in SF to rival their Shanghai Dumplings, but I'm hard pressed to do so.  Shanghai Dumpling King is closest... but not quite.  I love the red vinegar dipping sauce, too, and I end up dipping other dumplings in it since they are so generous with the amount  The setting is also fun, though a little noisy at times.  Peking duck is incredibly tasty and I love the hoisin sauce they give with it - not watered down at all.  Now, if it weren't all *quite* so expensive, it'd get five stars.  Love it!
author: Moocher Y.

description: There's an extra star based on history.  Yank Sing and I go way back to their Kearny Street location.  I was going there before I met Alan.  Now that's history.  I love their current location and today we had a chance after we ate to wander the first floor and admire the murals and the artifacts on display.  We took BART in to meet a friend from New Zealand, someone we met when we stayed at her B&B last October.  She was here for a conference and leaves today for Phoenix.  Yank Sing seemed like a good choice because she was staying at a downtown hotel.  Service was very good, from the man who brought us our tea and water after we were seated, to the women bringing the carts around.  The food wasn't as good as the food we've had in the past, though.  The Chinese broccoli was in a sauce that was thinner and more astringent than the usual sauce.  It was left unfinished, which never happens.  Alan's favorite baked BBQ pork buns were huge and doughy.  Though the filling was good, the bread to filling ratio was too high.  The wrapped sea bass was a standout.  It was fabulous.  Peking Duck was fine, not exceptional.  The other assorted dishes ranged from good to 'eh'.  Company was great, as was the tea, a tasty fermented green tea whose name I forget, but I find my dim sum jones unsatisfied.
author: Toni M.

description: Fantasitic food, and atmosphere. Service is good, and the price - though not value - does reflect the other highlights of the place . A definite lunchtime destination, handy for all kinds of funky transportation choices.
author: Steve J.

description:
This is one of the worst dim sum experiences ever.  My family is from Hong Kong, so we know what authentic dim sum should taste like.  We do NOT mind paying for food when it's delicious.  But gosh, the dim sum at this place was VERY DISAPPOINTING.

We could tell right off the bat with the har gow (shrimp dumplings) and siew mai (pork dumplings), what any good dim sum restaurant should aspire to make as best as possible since these are the most traditional/typical dim sum dishes.  They were horrible!  The skins on every one of the har gow and siew mai were thick and hard!  I haven't eaten any worse dim sum in the bay area ever before!!  Then, there was the chai siew bao (bbq pork buns) - they didn't do it right!  They used yeast in making it!  We do NOT EVER USE yeast in authentic steamed chai siew baos!  This is horrible.

All the dishes were horrible - the only saving grace for this place is the nice ambiance.  I can't even give good review to the wait staff  who were so pushy (trained to make a lot of money for the restaurant which by the way, charges exorbitant prices for things that are usually very cheap at most dim sum places) that who literally placed dishes on our table without us ordering.

This is my worst dim sum experience ever.  It's unbelievable, actually shocking, to see so many good reviews on Yelp regarding this place.  If you care about quality dim sum, I highly recommend two places: 1. Koi Palace in Daly City, or 2. Asian Pearl in El Cerrito.
author: Stella S.

description: I have been coming here for 15 + years and it never dissapoints and I always look forward to my next trip.  I used to live in North Beach and would walk down Grant street looking for cheap Dim Sum.  Of course I found it, and it was tasty but the environments were always lacking and on occasion i would lose my appetite.  I pay for Yank Sing because its immaculate, even the bathrooms are spotless.  The food is fresh and expertly prepared, I think I'll go tomorrow.
author: Kevin M.

description: I never trust a dimsum place that is teeming with whities. Yank Sing is no exception. I've been here twice, always left feeling...eh. I mean, the dimsum is fine, but I'm spoiled when it comes to Asian food (considering I was Taiwanese in my last life). Selection -- strictly for honkies. Unimpressed.
author: China Z.

description: This is THE PLACE for dim sum in san Francisco, but it comes with a high price. valet parking is free anyway.
author: Lanh T.

description:
The only place I regularly go for dim sum lunch. We go there on weekends, and always have a great experience. It's usually quite busy, but the service is still prompt and cheerful. The food is fresh and flavorful, without being overpowered by soy, salt or peppers.

I've never had anything there I didn't like, but here are the ones I get over and over: 
Shanghai Dumplings...I was skeptical the first time (soup filled dumpling?), but now we get an order or two every time.
Schezuan Chicken...gotta get something spicy.
Chicken Bun...a subtle and delicate flavor
Black Cod...always perfectly flaky and juicy, with a nice mild flavor.
author: dennis g.

description: This is the highest quality Deem Sum you will find.  Though somewhat pricey, you get what you pay for.  And what you pay for here is the freshest ingredients, transformed into amazing Deem Sum.  Any time we are in the Bay Area, we always eat here.  Note: they DO NOT put MSG in their food, so all those of us who are sensitive to this one time staple of Chinese cooking can enjoy everything on the menu.
author: Andrea C.

description: Best dim sum in the city. If you think otherwise, don't talk to me, I will get heated. Favorite dishes include the szechuan chicken, pea tendril dumplings, mango pudding, and - of course - the steamed pork buns. Even writing about this food is satisfying. It will cost you a pretty penny, though, but that is what greatness costs. Suck it up, pass on that extra eighth you were thinking about, and get here.
author: Beatrix K.

description:
whats up with charging so goddamn much for dim sum!?!?! yeah... i guess it was pretty good, but not THAT good. ive had dim sum at places just as good and for half the price... no joke.. half.

so im sitting there munchin when a waitress comes up with a small plate in her hand and asks: "sea bass?"

i thought to myself... 'are you F*ing retarded!?' first off, theres no sea bass at dim sum so why are you trying to pimp it out to me like im not asian. second, who the hell eats a slab of seared sea bass at 11 in the morning anyway? if youre reading this, and you do eat sea bass at 11 in the morning, and i see you on the street... remind me to slap you.
author: N. B. K.

description: I don't understand the facination with this place.  Your butt barely hits the chair and you are bombarded with offerings shoved upon you and they get mad when you turn one down.  Not relaxing whatsoever.  Then when you are done and ready to pay and get out of there, you are ignored.  Did I mention overpriced?
author: e w.

description:
I think the biggest downside to this place is the price.  6 pieces of potsticker was something like $8.  I strongly believe that one single potsticker should never be more than $1, no matter how good it is!  The two of us ordered 3 small dishes and 1 dessert and the total was $42.  I'm used to going to dim sum places and stuffing myself silly and walking away for no more than $20 / person and having lots of leftovers.  I've never had to be concerned with the prices at dim sum, but this place definitely had me checking the price of every item carefully.

However, aside from the high price, it's a fun place to eat.  The food is better than average compared to all the other dim sum places I've been.  If someone else is paying, I may consider going back!
author: L C.

description: Talk about brain fade. I wanted dim sum real bad when I got off bart  today. I was going to make the trek out to Ton Kiang and then I had an epiphany. YANK MUTHAF@CKIN SING is right here.  Sweet. I'll go in slam some dumplings right off the bat and pull more food as it goes by. I did some serious grubbin. My bill at the end obviously reflected my gluttonous eating habits. I figured they would YANK my SING and give me a "HAPPY ENDING" for those prices. I did unbutton my pants but only because my fat a$$ got all bloated-n-sh!t.
author: santiago g.

description: Love how the minute you sit down you get rushed by the servers with different carts of dim sum.This is what fast food is all about. It's good quality dim sum, but you pay for what you get. Nothing here is inexpensive. We came here with a party of 4 - got about 12 items and the bill came out to about $180.
author: johanna a.

description: Sometimes I feel like the ladies with the carts are yelling at me here when they rush up and rattle off what they have, impatiently waiting for a "yes" or "no" on their selection of pork buns and dumplings. Some people say it is a cultural difference, but I still feel as if I may snap under the pressure sometimes. I could do without the anxiety, but I still like the dim sum here. I know there is better dim sum, but I think Yank Sing is doing alright, and I like trying new things each time.
author: J F.

description: I've eaten in many of the best dim sum places in Hong Kong, and IMHO Yank Sing is better than all of them.  I have eaten here countless times, and it is consistently excellent.  Order the steamed, not the fried.  The only problem is the price, which is really expensive. Just took my niece here for her birthday and two of us spent $70,.without alcohol. They take reservations, and have free validated parking on weekends. (At these prices, they should.)
author: Robert R.

description: I'm Chinese myself and a lover of dim sums. This place has great customer / waiter service (much better than other dim sum places). The food is average to below average, while being very overpriced. If you want a nice place for a business lunch, this place would be ok but if you're looking for good food, visit other dim sum restaurants.
author: Mary Y.

description: The word that best describes this food is "greasy". The paper bag was pretty much translucent with grease by the time I got my takeout back to the office. So very foul.
author: Alison B.

description:
If I have to spend the second half of the day napping under my desk in a food coma, I want it to be because I spent my lunch hour here. It's impossible not to walk out of this place 5 pounds heavier then when you came in. Those devilish cart pushers with their taunting assortments of fried foods wheeling their way by you every 5 minutes until, before you know it, you've had at least one of everything on the stupid cart. Damnit! I told myself I wasn't going to do that this time!! And on top of the fried food, there's the dumplings, the lettuce wraps, the duck, the wine, the desserts... Oh, the dim sum heaven that is Yank Sing! AND even though this has to be the most popular lunch spot in the financial district they somehow, as if by magic, always seat me almost immediatley. Does this happen to everyone or do Yank Sing and I simply have a glorious unspoken bond that makes me super special and immediatley seatable? Either way... I love it here. Would eat here all the time if my wasteband and wallet allowed.

The only reason I'm giving it 4 stars is because it is not open for dinner. I understand that many, if not most, fidi establishments shut down and go home at 5 with everyone else in the area BUT it would be totally possible for this place to rock the dinner scene. And I would be there opening night, chopsticks in hand, ready to party! Cross my heart and hope to die. But *sigh* if not, I'll continue to gorge myself over lunch and sacrifice my productivity to the coma. I'm that dedicated to the dim sum.
author: Taylor E.

description: three stars you say? simple- food is great but tourist expensive...limited variety is my issue here... plus? people who do not know dimsum will find the english speaking staff user friendly,  there are no offals or other unusual things to put off the novice, the room, the patio on weekends and kitchen are as clean as this kind of place gets! so this is the place for out of towners and expense accounters.... if you are local try Koi Palace,mayflower, or hong kong seafood...
author: Ricote F.

description: Really good dim sum (especially the Shanghai dumplings), but I think they use MSG in at least some of their dishes. I wish this wasn't the case because I really enjoy their food.
author: Lynn F.

description: We took my mom and my bf's mom here for a nice Thanksgiving lunch together. It was their first time meeting, so I was hoping for all to go smoothly. Luckily, it did and they got along just fine. I'm wondering if the delicious dim sum or our perfect table or the pleasant atmosphere played a part in it. Cuz we all know that good food makes people happy. So kudos to Yank Sing for the fabulous time. Hands down, this was the best dim sum I have tasted thus far AND the best service I've received having dim sum. We shall be back!!!
author: Anne E.

description: Terrible service. I don't understand the hype...i've been to a lot of dim sum places ,and the only way in which this place stands out is the price.
author: j d.

description: Yank Sing has a really nice ambiance.  It's in a pretty building with a pretty atrium area right outside the restaurant.  The food is first class, and so is the service.  The teapots are these cute little things made out of clear glass.  However, oy!  aiiiyaaah! donnerwetter!  Sticker shock!  We were so lucky to have relatives who insisted on treating us to dim sum here.  I don't know if we would come back, unless we won the California Lottery, but you have to play in order to win, and we live in Hawaii anyway.  I used to like it better in its earlier days on Battery Street.  It was pricier than dim sum in Chinatown, but not like it is now.  I'm still giving it four stars, because it was delicious, classy, and I know a lot of you young Yelpers are loaded, as in making the big bucks.  So if you have the desire for some quality dim sum in an upscale, clean restaurant, then this would be my recommendation for dim sum in San Francisco.
author: Norm G.

description: Great food.  They best dim-sum you can get in the city.  You pay more here but expect it.  Location, location, location.  Great shanghai dumplings.
author: Choister C.

description: I love, love dim sum, and I love Yank Sing.  Some of my favs: Har Gau, Coconut Cream Roll, yum, and Sesame Balls to name a few.
author: Jessie B.

description:
THIS PLACE IS A BLAST!!! 

Highly recommend. Its a buffet-on-wheels!!!! 

I saw this restaurant on Food Network regarding the dim sum and the staff at the Marriott recommended it as well when asked what it was like. 

I do not remember fully all the food we got, I just remember we kept ordering and ordering more and more. The three of us just kept eating and trying as much as we could. From dumplings to pot stickers the food just kept coming. 

The staff too was very nice and accommodating. I will be returning here on my next visit to San Fran. 

They need one of these in Orange County, CA!!!!!
author: Kristen E.

description:
I'm definitely a fan here :)
I wouldn't recommend all the entrees, but their dim sums are excellent.
It gets annoying once in a while with all the servers constantly asking you if you want this or that, but the dim sums are just too delicious! Delicious enough to make me go back. 
However, don't eat the entrees there. I've ordered pecking duck, some kebob that i don't remember the exact name, and orange chicken. All of there were just blah and they are much more expensive than the dim sums. Not wort it!
Just enjoy the dim sums! You'll love it
author: jenny c.

description: It is great food. Everything is reliably good, but it's not the most authentic Chinese food. Its also a tad pricey for dim sum but it is also no hole in the wall. Overall it's great!
author: Jesse C.

description:
xiao long bao. that's all you need to know.

YUM-O.

Best dim sum place in the city. HANDS DOWN. Ignore all the haters - this place always has a line...which means the food is GOOD. DUH.
author: Ceana K.

description: The dim sum here is excellent but the prices do suck!  The bill for 2 was $80 and my girl doesn't even eat that much!  I have to say that I did have a good experience and everything that we had was fresh and delicious.  Chinatown is not that far away but decided to come here since it was 2 blocks away from the hotel.  I would come here again but not as often as I would like to.
author: Chris L.

description: Super polite greeters, servers and waitresses.  They had soup dumplings which are my current crush.  Everything from the shumai to the pork buns tasted so much better than what I'm used to.  Time to hit the gym...
author: Harry T.

description:
3.5 stars

I visited Yank Sing for lunch this Wednesday with a coworker/friend for her birthday. We walked in and were promptly seated (at the bar). Place was packed. 

The service here is pretty quick, but pushy. To someone having never been to this type of eatery before, the servers with the carts reminded me a lot of those little Mexican kids in Tijuana: "Chiclets!? Chiclets!?" Umm, hello! You already asked me three times if I wanted Tofu! Stop interrupting our conversation. 

Items ordered:

+ Pot Stickers were good. Little greasy.
+ Steamed Pork Buns were good. Best pork ever? I don't know.
+ Chicken Buns (?) were also yummy, but there were more veggies than chicken.
+ Spring Rolls were standard.
+ Peking Ribs (?). Took 20 plus minutes before this plate was delivered. By that time, we had already ordered the Sesame Balls, so we refused the ribs. Owell. I'm sure they were peddled off to another table.
+ Sesame Balls for dessert. I'd rather have frosting than bean paste.
+ Jasmine Tea. No thanks. Tasted like watered down potpourri, only worse.


Bill was $48. 

I'd return, but only in a large group.
author: Mike P.

description: the place is great and good for inviting people to there , however, the price is a little bit high.
author: Zed S.

description:
another co-worker's b-day and it's rock paper scissors for yank sing or palamino's.  mostly because it's close to work and because it's close to work.  i like how we keep up the surprised look each time we yell out, "surprise!!!!!"

well, it's the sushi boat phenomena of watching food roll by and snatching it.  kind of like urban hunting and gathering.

but it's fast and works for big groups.  they have different kids of dim sum that you can select and savor.  from veggie dumplings to shrimp or pork, the crab claws (delish!), chicken lettuce cups, and taro root dumpling (yum!).  

then you get that sluggish food coma feeling coming on - even the diet coke or tea doesn't cut the heavy feeling.  the solution is a quick sugar jolt from dessert like mango pudding or the egg custards though i personally head to starbucks a half block away for my caffeine fix.

yes, it may be a little pricey but...it's close to work.
author: Anh V.

description:
Eh...This place is run of the mill dim sum with suspect service and lame location.  I always get the impression they are trying to rush me out the door even when the joint is empty.  Plus the only decent thing is their pork bun.  The main detractor is this place is way more expensive than better dim sum places in the city.  

Try Shanghai dumpling King in outer richmond or anywhere in Chinatown for a better dim sum experience.
author: Jerry T.

description: The food is that good, I only wish that the price was lower.  Honestly, there is a cart of heavenly dumplings as soon as your butt hits the chair, before you get water!  Still wonderful.
author: tim w.

description: We've been eating at this place for years, and it's pretty consistent.  My only issue is to pace myself - I usually eat too much.
author: Steve B.

description: Stopped in for some dim sum and noodles, service was quick, dim sum cart was OK with not a very big selection, cart girls seemed pushy on you to take things you don't want, food was good but seemed on the very pricey side from what I'm used to. Doubt if I'd ever go back. I will go on the search for a better dim sum at a more reasonable price. Almost 100 dollars for 2 adults and a child for just dim sum and 3 bowls of noodle soup
author: Ronnie F.

description: Yeah yeah yeah, the dim sum prices are a rip-off, it's highway robbery, yadda yadda yadda but I love it here.  Coworkers and I went for our holiday lunch five years ago and we've returned each year since to keep w/ the tradition.  It's just chichi fun y'know?  Sure you can get cheaper elsewhere and sometimes better stuff like the bbq pork bun, but YS has a really cool variety of steamed dumplings and delicacies the run of the mill dim sum restaurants don't.  The service is also better than the average dim sum place -- they change out your plate...doesn't that deserve some props? -- it's super clean, they validate parking in the garage at the corner AND they take reservations...for dim sum!  Come on -- What other dim sum place does that?  That alone is worth shelling out a few extra clams isn't it?  They have a to-go area off to the side of the restaurant too.
author: Jeannie C.

description:
not impressed.  especially after eating at koi palace yesterday.  

dishes were not quite "right" and definitely lukewarm - helllllllo bacteria?

some examples of not quite "right" - 
har gow had overdone shrimp and not quite enough dough - so the chewy factor wasnt there.

fried tofu was not hot and not cold - i think it was supposed to be a hot dish that had cooled to lukewarm,and the tofu wasnt very fresh and had a weird texture...

potstickers - nice flavor, but lukewarm.

and still, it was $111 for lunch before tip for 3.  bah, i'd like my food at temp for such prices!
author: Dora F.

description: Yank Sing is overpriced and over-rated. The dim sum is ok, and the prices are crazy! Dim sum for 4, and we were not even stuffed, was over $100! I won't mind spending the money if the dim sum was good. But for medicore food, no way. I guess I should not expect much from a dim sum place in FiDi....
