author: Charlotte T.

description: A very good place to take out-of-towners or someone with an expense account.  The food is quite good.  It is very expensive and they kind of rush you.  I give 5 stars for the food but remove one for the rushed service.
author: Jorah N.

description: To me, this is a very americanized dim sum place.  The ONLY dish that passes my standards is the Lotus leaf glutinous rice.  Their BBQ pork bun is the worst I've ever had, yuck!!!!
author: Jaquelina L.

description: No joke. I got food poisoning the night after I ate there for lunch. The food was terrible to begin with...
author: Riz N.

description: Being Chinese and growing up in SF, I can say that I have been to my fair share of Dim Sum restaurants.  I would say Yank Sing ranks in my top 10 Dim Sum places.  Yank Sing is a very clean with a tasteful decor, something a lot of Dim Sum places lack.  There is a wide variety of unique dishes to choose from, though some of them aren't traditional dim sum dishes, they are intended to appeal to more of an American crowd.  As with most chinese restaurants if you want service you need to flag someone down.  The staff isn't going to check up on your periodically like at most other restaurants, just part of the Chinese culture.  For newcomers to the dim sum dining experience or those looking for something other than just shumai and hargow,  I highly recommend this place.
author: Chris Y.

description: Not worth it for the price. It's a sanitized/non-greasy/high-class version of dim sum.
author: Joy C.

description: My lovely friend introduced me to some dim sum frisco style and I must say I was impressed.  She knew how much I liked their yank sing hot sauce,  so where better to take me to than its birthplace.    You can see their special hot sauce enclosed in a glass display case like a cartier display at a jewelry store.  While the rest of the crowd waited to be seated, I was drawn to this like it was my hot sauce mecca.  I had to bow down and pay my respect, this great sauce has given so much life to my daily dishes.....anyways, on with the dim sum.   Well, a lot has been said about Yank Sing both good and bad.  I agree with most of the sentiments.  Yes it was a zoo, yes it was expensive. But the service was attentive, and the xiao long bao was cooked to perfection.  Oh how I long for the xlb!   No words can describe it, you just gotta make your pilgrimage to this place and try it for yourself.
author: Mike K.

description: this place is really really really good. Come here on the company dime or if you are on a date with someone you actually have no intention of sleeping with because let's face it ,this is a sodium and grease nightmare and you will explode after you eat here. fun atmosphere
author: Lauren V.

description:
It's hard to justify the prices for what you get.  The quality is decent, but not mind-blowing.  There are lots of good Dim Sum places in San Francisco.  Charging a premium for them elicits high expectations.  

$50 out the door for a modestly portioned lunch for two?  It's hard to be a fan of that when there are numerous better bargain alternatives.
author: Stephen N.

description:
After reading several reviews about this place, I decided it was time to finally dip into some dim sum. In fact, it was my first dim sum experience and I'm not sure how I will keep from becoming addicted. It was, in short: fabulous. 
I tentatively made reservations for New Year's Day and naturally, I was concerned that the already high noise level would be beyond tolerable or that the carts would just roll past us-- onto tables with customers buying the more expensive items (yes, prices do vary significantly). Yes, it was noisy-- think large wedding party...that's how loud-- but as soon as you have your first bite, you'll forget all about the decibel rating.
Upon entering, I immediately notified the host that one of us was a vegan and this seemed to help things along quite a bit. Even when our plates were empty, I could grab just about anyone in uniform to send us the vegetarian carts. These folks are ready for busy and they are as attentive as can be-- possibly more so than waiters at a conventional restaurant. The amount of organization and coordination that a large business like this requires will leave you dumbfounded. Certainly, the walkie-talkies help them pull it off!  
The variety was almost overwhelming at times but the mystery of the items you didn't have a chance to throw down will keep you coming back. I was surprised that the wait staff gladly stopped in their tracks to point things out and explain them to us. All it took was a glance in their direction and they were at table-side. Turning things down didn't seem to wipe the genuinely warm smile from their faces. Okay, so their ability to speak English was a bit on the challenged side-- but they more than made up for it with efficiency, expedience, and above all, friendliness. Despite the hustle and bustle and being against a back wall, we were content with our glass pot of tea-- which never went dry or cold. 
Of course, given the expense of this place, you will need to keep an eye on the card they set on the table. It will be difficult, I assure you. Without a doubt, you'll find yourself saying, "Wait! What's that? Okay, I'll try it. One more...okay two more"...and by the time you know it, you've racked up a 100+ dollar bill. 
The only bit of advice I have is to fill those empty belly gaps with lots of hot tea and don't take any long breaks in between plates-- after all, the longer you wait, the more tempting the unknown or old favorites start to look. 
Bon appetit! Oh, wait, that's French. I'll work on my Mandarin for the next dim sum review...although, I really don't see a reason to look any further.
author: OKAY O.

description: I seriously do not understand why people love this place so much. Seriously. This place has compromised their cooking so it meets the western palate so much that  I don't know if I'd classify this place as authentic Chinese.  This place is about two steps away from mimicking Panda Express. All of their dumplings are second rate and any place that actually goes around with a "Chinese Chicken Salad" can not call itself authentic. Not worth the wait. Not worth the price.
author: Jennifer S.

description: This place was WAYYYYYYY way way way way too expensive for dim sum.   When I mean expensive, I mean $22- fried-rice expensive.  The only item I enjoyed here was the xiao long bao, aka steamed pork dumplings.  Oh and the chili sauce.  But otherwise, the standard dim sum dishes are miniscule and tasted no different than all the other dim sum places in chinatown and clement street.
author: Tokki M.

description: Okay, THIS is the best place to take visiting tourists for the weekend brunch experience they'll never forget. We love Yank Sing (and Ton Kiang out on Geary, too). Stuff yourself!
author: Jenni O.

description: Although the standard (and more often than not, correct) reaction to SF places that are super popular with out-of-towners is suspicion, Yank Sing proves the exception to the rule.  Yes, there are better dim sum places in the Bay Area.  Yes, Yank Sing is expensive.  But for your money, you get great food, a clean restaurant, and very friendly service.  For those of you that view surliness as part of the essential dim sum experience, Yank Sing is not your go-to place, but for everyone else (especially if someone else is paying), you could do a lot worse.  It's definitely one of my favorite places to visit when I have a hankering for dim sum.
author: Ty D.

description: One of my favorite  places to eat in San Francisco. I enjoy bringing out of towners to Yang Sing.  I love just about everything--Peking Duck--not so much, but I am in love with the cabbage salad and all the dumplings--especially their signature dish--the Shanghai Dumplings--the ginger sauce it comes with--yum yum. Even if you are not a fan of  "Chinese" food, you need to give Yank Sing a try.
author: Deborah S.

description: I think this is the best dim sum restaurant in the City.  But you pay a price for it.  The deep fried tofu wrapped in seaweed is both unique and tasty.  It is not immediately available when the restaurant opens, so you may have to order it special.  The har gow, shiu mai and other classic dim sum dishes are well prepared and not greasy, which you often find in other places.  Our favorite dish [which you have to order special] is the deep fried seaweed wrapped tofu.  Can't be duplicated anywhere else.  A must try.  I would definitely go there for special occassions.
author: Dale S.

description: I'm giving this place 4 stars purely for their Shanghai Dumplings (aka soup dumplings).  It's expensive for dim sum, but again, the Shanghai Dumplings are worth trying.
author: Mark K.

description: My favorite dim sum place in the whole world.    Have eaten at many other dim sum joints in SF and nothing comes close.   Sea bass here is to die for (although not a sustainable seafood choice).  Make a reservation as its always busy.
author: Evelina K.

description:
We had our wedding banquet here in the Atrium, and the event was as close to perfect as we could have hoped!  We initially worked with Joy, the banquet coordinator (who no longer is there).  She was detailed and organized, but my wife and I felt like she was not as invested in our event as a coordinator could have been.  When she left, we started working with Vera instead, and it was such a breath of fresh air.  Vera was prompt in responses, was very warm, and gave great suggestions and advice in assisting us with our planning.  Vera communicated with us in detail, and kept us in the loop as our day got closer.

The servers were very polite and on par with what we have experienced as guests at previous weddings.  Our guests were impressed at the level of service that Yank Sing provides, and the comfortable feel of the Atrium.  (We had an inkling that this would not be the case inside other restaurants that are known for high table turnovers)

If you book at Yank Sing for your banquet, you are allowed 1 full tasting.  What this means is that they serve you all 8 courses, with enough to feed 10 people.  This was an awesome experience, as you can bring your families out to have a trial run at the food you will NOT be eating during your wedding (yes, as much of a wannabe food snob and glutton that I am, I had no appetite for food on the wedding day.)  

I have 2 complaints about Yank Sing (although a lot more could have gone wrong!):
1) The Peking Duck on our wedding day was soggy, which was a vast difference from the crispy duck we tried at our tasting.  Sure, there were ~30 tables to cook for, but those that know, Peking duck is absolutely disgusting when soggy!

2) The Veuve Cliquot champagne that we had put aside for our cake/champagne popping was there, but once we poured out our half glasses, the champagne was nowhere to be found!!  We only hope that a saavy underage cousin or alcoholic friend was able to enjoy the bubbly.

Make no mistake about it, you will definitely pay a premium to have a wedding banquet here.  If you are looking for a nice atmosphere feel, consider the Atrium.  And if you are looking for higher quality Chinese banquet food, this is definitely a great place that you should consider.  We ended up shelling out an arm, a leg, and a kidney or two for this place, but we have absolutely no regrets, as our wedding pictures looked spectacular with the Atrium surroundings and lighting.  The food and overall feel made our dinner such a better experience for our special day.  Much, much better than being cooped up in an inside restaurant venue with too many poles and beams in the way.
author: Pick S.

description: I like dim sum but don't eat that much of it.  I'm not the girl who will drive out of the way in some random China town to get the best dim sum.  So I'm not an expert...however, this dim sum was super tasty. The service was good.  The one dumpling where you pour in a red vinegar/ginger sauce, the fried shrimp (as best as I can describe it), the leaf with the rice/pork inside, and duck sandwhich were especially good.  Make reservations!
author: Jane L.

description: I come damn nearly every weekend. Yeah it's a bit pricey (especailly compared to places in Chinatown that are just as good), and yeah you can't swing a dead cat without hitting a tourist, but the food is so damn good you can forgive them for that. The staff is friendly and the lettuce wrap chicken makes me want to die. But what happened to the green beans? They used to be everywhere on the carts but now they have acheived tray status? What gives?
author: Jackie I.

description:
yeah so its not like your typical hole in the wall chinese establishment in the city ( which by the way I love to support) but here and Yank Sink offers you quick service and a delectable display of dim sum and much much more

green beans
I love their cabbage salad with pecans/walnut 
signature shanghai
and peking duck sanwhich in mini white rice bun
deelish
I try not to start off with a lot of friend dupplings
start with steamed dumplings first
love the red vinagar and ginger sauce

not a place to go if you love DUCK
made the mistake of spending 20 plus dollars for four thin slices of roasted duck... I would head to china town to buy a whole duck for half that cost... otherwise delicious
Great place to take friends, business associates, family when your hungry
author: mio F.

description: Wow, outrageous prices!!  I came here a few years ago with a larger group and don't remember paying $8-10 a dish for dim sum.  But this time it was just me and the hubby, and boy, did we curse ourselves for coming here.  I mean, the food is tasty and the service is fine, but OMG I have never paid more than $3-4 each for dim sum.  And that is usually for the high end C items!  Made me totally regret the second helping of chicken feet that I had. The bill came out to over $80 and we were barely full.  I had to grab some fast food later to compensate.  Sucks.
author: Robin W.

description: I've never been disappointed with the food or the service.  It's more on the expensive side (I've never gotten out of there for less than $40 or $50 per person) so we usually get a group to go here for special occasions only.  the one on Spear street is a more leisurely paced dim sum.  the one on Stevenson is smaller and a bit faster.  I like the duck, there is a rice and meat dish in leaves (can't think of the name) that is very good, the dumplings and pork buns, the custard desserts, the lettuce wraps... all are good.
author: Nedra D.

description: In my opinion the tastiest dim sum in the bay area. Great tea too that comes in beautiful clear glass teapots. They have many more vegetarian options than other dim sum restaurants, so even my veggie friends like coming here. It is a bit more expensive than other dim sum places, but so worth it!
author: Cindy F.

description: Are you kidding me?  As someone from Hong Kong and Vancouver who grew up with the good ol Cantonese tradition of having (tasty) dim sum every weekend, I was very disappointed by the quality, selection, and outrageous prices here.  The prices are a good 4X what it would be to go to a normal dim sum restaurant, and they even try to get you to buy additional dim sum to go to maximize their profits!  The building is nice enough, but the setting is all you're paying for, and that in itself is not worth it to me.  The dim sum itself is mediocre and when I was there (father's day 2007) most of the traditional dim sum dishes were not available.  Instead they made up their own original "dim sum" dishes for which they can charge absurd prices.  What a disappointing experience.
author: Adrienne L.

description: One of the best dim sum places I have ever tried. I've been to dim sum in LA, Toronto and New York, and so far this beats them all. It's definitely a lot more pricey. About twice as much. I usually pay $30 bucks for two people but expect to pay $60-$70 at this place. The food is great and the amount of options are endless. They are constantly coming around with the carts and servers and always on the look out to serve you. This really surprised me at first because I was expecting the standard dim sum service which is rude, horrible, and rush rush 'get you out so we can make more money and bring more people in only to get them out too'. This place was definitely an exception. It was very clean, very organized and very very  yummy!
author: L L.

description:
San Francisco staple Dim sum place.
Yes, I know there are cheaper places in the city for plain old hargow and siu mai but I still enjoy coming here.

Unique over-priced rolls with excellent duck.
Yes, it's worth the splurge once in a while and ONLY if you make a reservation inside.
Don't complain about long waits and bad service on Sunday at 12pm!
People, this is a busy Chinese restaurant on the weekend!
author: Faisal M.

description: We were extremely happy with our late brunch there until we saw our bill. Up to 120 USD for 2 people. Yeah, we two could definitely eat a lot, but this bill is way over our expectation. In New York, for that much of dim sum, normally it's about 60 dollars. Maybe it's the beauty of no competition? Their food is very well made and delicious and the waitress and waiters are all very friendly compare with the ones working in the dim sum places in New York. Well, I guess that's why they charge us so much? That place is so popular in SF, it's still almost full when we went there around 3 pm on Sunday, one hour before their close time. One memorable dish is their BBQ Pork, very very very good. Go for it!!!
author: Vicki Z.

description: Great for dim sum lunch take out.  Over priced to eat it in the restaurant though it's good.  I'm not crazy about their other lunch options (like black bean chicken) but it works in a pinch.
author: Kiki R.

description: Just ate Yank Sing for a wedding banquet.  The peking deck was great and everything else was decent enough.  I liked the environment of the rincon center.  There's this cool ass water flooring.  Definitely nice feel to it but not a place for the economically challenged.
author: Van N.

description: BEST DAMN XIAO LOONG BOWS EVER. Everything else here is good but nothing compares to their xiao loong bows. Other restaurants should look, taste, and listen. These are JUICY, these are savory, these are worth killing people for. If you are a tourist, go to Yank Sing as soon as they open (10:30am) and order as many of these as you can eat (I think they cost $12 an order though, so bring your credit card). If those ladies with their dim sum carts try to tempt you with har gows or lettuce wraps, scowl at them and wave them away. Concentrate on your xiao loong bows... you will never eat anything better.... unless of course, you can afford a trip to Shanghai... in which case you will disregard this review as bologne.
author: L. M.

description: Overrated, not authentic and pricey Chinese food. It earns 2 stars because of its clean toilet.
author: Ervinna L.

description: This place is one of the most over-rated dim sum restaurants in SF.  It's very clean, and the atmosphere is comfortable, but most dishes are just okay.  The price vs. quality is what earns this place two instead of three stars from me.  Very pricey for dim sum.  Please....I will drive and wait in the extremely long lines at Koi Palace or my secret spot in San Mateo or Milpitas for higher quality dim sum at more reasonable prices. If you must eat dim sum in SF, drive out to Clement St.
author: Gregory C.

description:
hands down, my favorite dim sum restaurant in the bay area.  they cater to the non-asian folk, but i can't get enough.  the stuffed crab claws and cream cheese won tons are awesome.  and the more traditional dim sum items like turnip cakes are brilliantly executed as well.

their "2 go" counter is quick and convenient too.  if only i worked closer ...

only bad part about it?  maybe the wait.  but definitely the parking.  the engineer who designed that underground garage must have graduated at the bottom of his class.
author: spiff e.

description: Had a wonderful experience here with my cousins. Went on a Sunday afternoon and was pretty crowded, we waited about 1/2 hour before being seated in the atrium with the great view of the fountain. The jasmine tea was excellent and we really enjoyed the shrimp shumai, soup dumplings, chicken, pork buns, snap peas, and especially dessert: sesame balls (a first for me, yum!) and fruit. I would definitely come here and bring others.
author: Linda B.

description: While I LOVE the take out, I had the WORST experience with the Restaurant on Jan 3rd. The food was cold, the staff was rushed and pushy. Dim Sum for 3-people, 2 of which are teens...should not have cost $75.00!! Excuse me? Never got a price sheet that would have been IDEAL.  We only  had 4 different items, won ton soup and a dessert.  I would recommend heading to Clement Street and get great Dim Sum for MUCH MUCH less...
author: SF N.

description: On the one hand it's great that this place exists, because I've never had better dim sum.  On the other hand, as compared to any other dim sum place it's so goddamn expensive that it's not even funny, so it's not cool that they are so pushy with the items when you have no idea what they cost.
author: Adam Z.

description: Yang Sing...what a great please when are super hungry and/or don't have a lot of time on your hands and want to eat delicious food or a combination of all 3. Perfect place for large parties plus Yank Sing is a very kid friendly restaurant too. Now, I am going to try to remember all the amazing all small size bites my dinning companion and I had. We were there for lunch on this day. Here we go:  potstickers, wongtong soup, shrimp dumplings, Peking spareribs, bacon wrapped prawn, steamed rice rolls and a couple more of yummy items.- No wonder I end it up so full. I just noticed the long list of items we had while I was making my review. ups!!  Now, back to Yank Sing, the place was sooo busy (weekend)  they basically extend the tables all the way outside the main dinning room and around the fountain.
author: Ernesto C.

description: Good dim sum, nice atmisphere, but real $$$ so it gets 3 stars for 3 dollar signs
author: Michael M.

description: We eat there this morning. Three of us went, food was really good and the service was excellent. I loved sitting right next to the fountain that falls from about 100 feet above the floor. We eat a standard amount nothing over the top but my jaw dropped when the bill came. $136 for three of us with no booze. There is no menu or prices posted anywhere. I've eaten other places that were just as good with twice the number of people for half that amount. If your going to eat here be prepared to shell out the big bucks. Thank god the parking was free.
author: Baron S.

description:
We have enjoyed the dim sum here for lunch a few times and this week we were in the mood for something different than our usual lunch spots.
Let me start with 2 notes:
For those that say the restaurant is pricey, you know that before you go if you look at the reviews/menus online. And you are in SF...this isn't Panda Express.
Service being aggressive....the dim sum service ( or service in any traditional Chinese restaurant)..can be aggressive...there are millions of mouths to feed in that country.  But service can be aggressive anywhere. You have a mouth, speak up and politely slow down the service if you want to relax and dine at a leisurely pace.

We enjoyed the ha gau (shrimp dumplings....2 orders) as we always do. Huge, suculent portions of shrimp lightly seasoned in a paper thin wrapper served steaming hot. The seafood basil dumplings not quite as good a bit bland.  The sea bass in honey soy sauce was outstanding..a huge, flakey, moist chuck of pure white sea bass in a very light honey soy sauce. Nothing masked the delicious flavor of the fish. Our favorite dish of the afternoon. My husband enjoyed the Peking duck....me not. Hence, 1 star off for the duck....my opinion and taste buds. The only Peking duck on earth I have ever loved and devoured was in Beijing. I felt this was gamey and a bit greasy, yet overcooked and the buns were dry and flavorless. However, eggplant being one of my very favorite veggies...the eggplant with hunan sauce was excellent. Not sweet or cloying, not processed blood red sauce, light, nicely dressed and steaming hot, fresh made and brought to the table. Definitely enough food for a satisfying lunch. Agreement on the tea pot.....puddles are formed on the table at each pouring, but the tea is very tasty. The table cloth and napkins also concur with regard to the tea.

Parking is not easy anywhere in SF, a part of the dining adventure. A cheap eat, not, but how often do you wake up and say....let's have good dim sum....not every day or even every week. So when you have the craving, need your dim sum fix, this is an excellent place to satisfy the palate in a nice room with efficient and pleasant service.  And it is still cheaper than a ticket to China.
author: MICHAEL AND VERNA M.

description:
Star #1: i love dim sum and this place is within walking distance of my apt in South Beach

Star #2: the dim sum and service are really good! 

Why the stars stop there: the bill was $80 for 2 people!!! 

I mean, seriously. I've had amazing dim sum at lots of other places and have never spent more than $25 even when I've said left super full.

I just cannot justify $80 for what is the equivalent of chinese fast food. It's too bad I won't be going back, because it's a great place!
author: Chrissy S.

description: I wanted to get a review in while the experience was still fresh. Expect an update focused on the menu items eventually. First, I will state that the first time it was a banquet and the menu was preselected by the hosts. Therefore I cannot offer an opinion on their dim sum, etc.  However, I will say that it was a five star experience. The one and only five star experience I've had in a Chinese-American restaurant. The waitstaff was extremely attentive. They circulated through the crowd and kept our wine glasses full without having to flag them down. The food was not the greasy American Chow Mein, fried rice, and sweet and sour stuff that many people think represents Chinese food but in actuality was invented by cooks in mining camps during gold rush days as a way to get rid of garbage. The food was exquisite and served with flair. We were refreshed with clean plates between courses and the next course wasn't presented until the waiter had asked us if we were ready. That was the key to the service -- the wait staff never dumped a plate and walked off. They brought it fresh from the kitchen when we were ready. The portions weren't so huge that takeout boxes were left at the table. If we had extra, the waiter, after asking if we'd like to take it home, carried it off and packed it up for us. Ambiance was great; facilities were great;. parking and the Embarcadero BART station were close and convenient. I do know that  it's expensive -- the most expensive Chinese restaurant I've ever been too anywhere in the world but as the old saying goes: You get what you pay for.  I did bring some out of town guests here once to "show off" and they weren't  disappointed.  I'll do a review of their specific menu items the next time I eat here (provided I can increase my home equity line and can afford it).  This is definitely not the place for a casual dinner or lunch but  for special occasions.
author: Robert H.

description: Yank Sing is by far the best Dim Sum we've had in the Greater Bay Area. Our first try at dim sum was about 15 years ago at Pearl City Seafood Restaurant in Chinatown - good stuff. We heard about Ton Kiang on Geary - also good.  But for consistent quality, variety, cleanliness and great service, nothing compares to Yank Sing. It's true, be prepared to spend some money here, it's not cheap. The offerings are fresh, original, tasty and full of variety. Be sure to get reservations, as the wait during the prime lunch hour can sometimes be long. Our first experience with Yank Sing was at the original site on Broadway. We've been to Rincon Center. Our favorite is the smaller place on Stevenson - great friendly staff who come over to say hello every time we are there. Can't beat it!
author: Vickie G.

description:
I've been going to Yank Sing for years. Before I moved here it was the must visit destination each trip. While the food is still really good, the service is inconsistent. Maybe this is because they are so popular, and can churn and burn through so many customers, service is not a priority. I'm not naive, I don't expect stellar service, especially at dim sum....but I do expect the trolleys to come by at least more than once every 10 minutes. 

Our experience today:

Went late to Yank Sing (1:30 pm) when dim sum service was winding down (yes, yes, I know, not the best time to go). We were seated on the far side of the atrium,  which I generally don't mind. Problem was, most of the people in our section were finishing up their meals, so the trolley servers just decided that our lone table wasn't worth carting their goods over to. To our waitress' credit she kept asking us what we'd like to have and getting it for us, while also telling us that she kept telling them to come over, but they wouldn't do it. The thing is, I wanted to see the food on the trolley and choose my dim sum, dammit, not wait for her to return every 5 minutes and take our next dim sum order. I was hungry, I wanted to spend money and I was not happy. I've never had this problem there and so 30 minutes into our lunch, when I demanded to be moved to another section, the trolleys finally started appearing en masse. 

The icing on the cake was the broiled fish we requested when we were initially seated. We kept being told by our server that it was coming and that the kitchen was preparing it special for us since they had already run out for the day. 30 minutes later, no broiled fish. 45 minutes later, no broiled fish. Exactly 1 hour later, with the check paid, doggie bag in tow and walking out the door,  the broiled fish arrived.  Too late. 5 stars for the killer dim sum. Minus two stars for today's exasperating experience.
author: Suepattra M.

description: I have been coming to Yank Sing with my family for over 15 years, starting at the old Battery Street location and then continuing on here at Rincon Center. In a city with hundreds of Chinese restaurants, we could easily go elsewhere, but we keep coming back because it is just so good. The food is absolutely delicious, the servers are attentive, and the carts never stop coming (though sometimes it's hard to get the cart you want). We always end up stuffing ourselves because there are so many wonderful options--the stuffed mushrooms and the snow-pea shoot dumplings are especially good--but we always manage to save a little room for an egg custard tart at the end.
author: Katie I.

description:
I love the idea of Dim Sum: small plates of food so you can try a variety of different dishes, the ability to see what you're getting before you order it, plus just the experience of food drifting by and having the option of pointing to it, asking for it and eating it within seconds. The only problem is that I don't eat seafood or fish of any kind (I'm not allergic, but I just don't like it) and at most dim sum places I've been to that makes it hard to enjoy my meal. I've been to several dim sum places around the bay area and Yank Sing is by far my favorite. With other dim sum places I've tried, there would only be 2 or 3 non-dessert items that I could even eat, and while I could see that my seafood-loving dining companions were enjoying themselves, the quality of the dishes I got was mediocre.

Yank Sing is the only dim sum place I've found (in the bay area) that has a terrific selection of creative dishes that don't have seafood (there are good vegetarian options also). For this I am happy to pay more, and I usually do, because Yank Sing can get expensive: For a full dim sum lunch we usually pay about $20 a person and sometimes more. The bill is in Chinese so unless you can read Chinese you won't be able to figure out which items cost what, which can be confusing. Most of the regular items cost between $2.50 and $4 but some specials (xiao long bao for example) can cost $6-7. Also, sometimes you will ask for an item from a cart and they'll hand you the plate but what they don't tell you is that what they've given you is actually a "double order" (this almost always happens with spring rolls) so you're actually charged twice as much as a regular item. If you like Yank Sing but think it's too expensive the best thing to do is decide in advance what you want to get  and stick to it - avoid impulse shopping! Another way to enjoy Yank Sing food on the cheap is the Yank Sing 2 Go lunch specials on weekdays.

My absolute favorite here are the chicken mushroom dumplings - they have perfect translucent wrappers and a delicious filling (water chestnuts and snow peas giving it a slight crunch). Other favorites include green onion cakes with peanut sauce, xiao long bao (pork soup dumplings, which i think of as 'the ship in a bottle of chinese cooking'), sweet rice dumplings, shitake mushroom dumplings, spring rolls and pork buns. They serve Peking Duck by the slice, which is a nice way to try it. They have a lot of dessert choices - the coconut rolls are great. I've also enjoyed the custard tarts and sesame balls. Some items are only available on the weekends.
author: Lila T.

description: We used to go here for nice family dinners all the time when I was a kid. Amazingly good food. Kinda pricey though.
author: Josh O.

description: Mmmm, very tasty dim sum. As said, it's not cheap, but it's high quality and well worth the extra money. Amazing steamed pork buns and the sesame balls are also stellar. Overall, I wasn't disappointed with anything I tasted, but next time, I think I'll accept the plates a little slower to pace out the meal. It's hard to resist when they are constantly offering you tasty little plates. Not somewhere I'll go every weekend, but great for a special weekend lunch.
author: Rose K.

description: Good for when you want to take out of town guests to a nice, low risk, dim sum place.  Expensive.  I liked the Shanghai dumplings.  I'm guessing they inherited much of the Harbour Village diners.  Too busy on weekends.
author: Ken and Yuri Q.

description: I must not know my Dim Sum because there is way less 5 stars than I would have thought. Came up from San Diego this weekend for my dads bday and we went here. We were seated quickly and immediately I was attacked  by hundreds of arms pushing pot stickers, steamed dumplings, rice noodles, and cha siu baau at me. The bloody mary was great really strong too. I would recommend it to anyone. so try this place out.
author: Michael M.

description: I've been here three times over three years and have never been as impressed as I was the first time. Of course I was younger, had never had dim sum, and had perhaps less refined taste, but the last two times I remember being somewhat disappointing. Most of the food is really good and my favorites were a sea bass something and the mushroom dumplings. Buuuuuut...the servers spoke often way too fast for us to understand or remember which dish was what and some of the food had gone all room-temperature by the time it reached our table.
author: charlotte c.

description: One of my standard business lunch spots. You have to exercise control not to be overwhelmed with too many dishes at once, not only because aerobic eating is no fun, but also because the food gets too cold.  Not to mention having too much of a hit to the wallet.  But the food's delicious.  And the soup dumplings are one of my favorites, as in, dream about them favorites.  (Hey, some people dream about soup dumplings.  I don't think that's weird.  At all.  Too much.)
author: Laurel B.

description: You will find some of the best tasting dim sum here, along with some of the highest prices. The original Broadway location of this restaurant was a family destination for many who came from out of town to visit Dai Fow (the Big City) for many years. Then, they moved to Sansome, then to Rincon Annex and their prices have moved up each time. Admittedly, they have more complex flavors than most and I have yet to find Fun Gaw as good, but my ancestors would be rolling in their graves if I spent 3-4 times the amount I would at other places.
author: Arlene C.

description: This is the best dim sum in town.  its pretty fancy and pricey but being right in the middle of the FiDi district.  Obv the service was fast as with any real dim sum place.  They come by trying to sell to you like they are on commission (are they?), and many of the dishes are claimed as the best by the servers which was amusing.
author: Tom K.

description: The food is yummy but the prices are way too expensive for dim sum. The ambiance is nice -- I do like the rincon atrium..it's beautiful. The service is not bad either. They have the cutest little tea pots!! But seriously, it's too costly for dim sum...
author: Pika C.

description: Like everyone says Yank SIng is way too expensive for dimsum. But I just can't stop going there because food is too good. My favorite is shao long bao, the Shanghai soup dumplings. I usually eat at Yank Sing on the first Sunday after the payday. My wife and I spend about $80 including a couple of bottles of Tsing tao.
author: Hide S.

description: I love Dim Sum. My family and I used to go to the ones in Oakland Chinatown and the quality has significantly gone down. So, for the past 3 years, we've been dining at the location by Rincon Center in SF. Best advice I can give is to make reservations. They even take SAME DAY reservation!! You'd see me ordering hargaw and chicken feet. For dessert: my favorite egg custards. Yumm!! Lastly, this'd be good for large groups so the cost can be split.
author: Josephine D.

description: This is for Yank Sing 2 Go - right next to the main restaurant and in the Rincon Center.  First, I love the space in the Rincon Center and especially the fountain.  Second, YS2G is quick, reliable, clean, cheap and veggie-friendly.  I especially love the grilled eggplant!
author: Jeremy S.

description: Very good dim sum, great variety, really good quality, I really like the place and take my out of town friends and family there all the time! Would give it 5 stars if the price were more reasonable...
author: David J.

description: I've been to Rincon Annex for lunch many times during lunch hour with all the other worker bees downtown. It's a fine place to have a quick lunch, but going there on a weekend is a real downer, in the same way that the downtowns of large American cities are a drag: devoid of human activity, they feel empty and heartless, and there's no question they are ugly. In terms of ambience, eating at Yank Sing is like eating at a shopping mall - that is, one that has no actual shops to shop at. We had ample time to experience this, too, since had reservations for 11:30 and weren't seated til 12:10, a situation that we found especially frustrating since there were TONS of empty tables in front of our noses.  The food was only moderately good, they dumped all the dishes on our table in our first ten minutes (as if to get rid of us), and to top it all off, it was wildly overpriced: my friends and I spent $160 for a totally normal amount of dishes. Since Chinatown is relatively close, I would HIGHLY recommend skipping this dum sum (sic) experience.
author: Gina A.

description: Overhyped, overpriced, mediocre dim sum.  We took out of town guests and the service was fair, but the disappointment was the fact that the were out of our favorite items.  We ordered the items and we sat and waited for them and we weren't told that they out for 15 minutes.  I much prefer eating in Chinatown.
author: Mai E.

description: Used to be located on Battery, don't know what the location is like now on Spear, but when I took my lady there about seven years ago, it was a very enjoyable atmosphere with lots of hustle and noise, cart service seemed pretty regular and the food was high quality. Price was about what I'd expect for the quality but expect to spend $60 for a nice lunch.
author: Trish T.

description: Delicious food, quick service, nice staff, can't beat it. I was in China town in SF last weekend eating Dim Sum on Jackson and it didn't even compare to this place! You pay for the clean restaurant I guess.
author: Elizabeth B.

description:
Wow has this place slipped.
Very expensive, small tasteless morsels.
Try Fook Yuen in Millbrae if you are not too embarassed to say it.
author: K O.

description:
I use to go to Vancouver often just for the superb dim sum.  The dim sum you simply can not find any where else except Hong Kong.  Walking into Yank Sing, I felt like I am in Vancouver again.  Yet, not the quality of Dim Sum.  The soup dumplings is very good, considering I am a native Shanghais and know what  good soup dumpling tastes like.  If I go next time, i will simply just order soup dumpling only.  
Other dim sum are not memorable yet decent.  There are not something you could not find in anywhere else, you can have same kind of stuff in Richmond or sunset, but Yank Sing is more pleasant place to dine in.  The service is better than any other Chinese restaurant, and the place is one of the cleanest Chinese restaurant you can find in the city.
author: Josephine J.

description: Cannot complain about the food here, I take all my friends from Europe to this place and they love  Dim Sum. The food is  excellent, but I really only go here when I know somebody else picks up my  tab - it is that expensive (I do get sticker shock). I'd give it a 5 star, but I had the real deal in Hong Kong, so this is as good as it gets in the Bay Area, but not that close to what I can get in HK.
author: Sylvia K.

description: Pricey, but oh so good! We drive from the South Bay to go here. But only when our money is burning a hole in our pocket, or when my parents offer to pay!
author: Stacy M.

description: I felt like I was in an Asian market being hussled by merchants  when we first got there. I hadn't even sat down when I was being asked what I wanted to drink and women pushing salads and other foods infront of me. But aside from all that the food was amazing. My favorites were the Chicken Dumplings and  the Szechuan Chicken, but everything was good. We left with full tummies and big smiles on our faces.
author: Melinda Q.

description: The best dim Sum Ever. Very Delish! I love the chickens and the crabs. If you are in San Francisco tru this place.
author: Monica S.

description: Went here a week ago based on all the hype, top 100, James Beard award, etc.  It's an easy walk from Embarcadero BART, so quit whining about parking.  It's a lovely, upscale location and setting, and I could not believe how CLEAN everything was.  I'm Chinese (ABC) and am chronically embarrassed by how Chinese purveyors have no sense of cleanliness. Showed up at 11:30 on a Monday with no reservations, and there were lots of empty tables.  Got a great table and the food started arriving immediately, hot and fresh.  The soup dumplings were topnotch; everything else was as good as I've had at dozens of dim sum joints around the East Bay (my hometown). I shared one order each of soup dumplings, sticky rice packet, har gow, shiu mai, sesame balls, crab claw shrimp croquettes, taro root dumpling, for which I would have paid around $30 to $40 at any other place.  The bill came to $65 before tip.  The service was uncharacteristically friendly, efficient and polite, which  I thoroughly enjoyed, but I wish I didn't have to pay $30 extra for service and cleanliness.  Will not be returning.
author: W L.

description: Awesome dim sum especially Shanghai Dumplings. Pricey but $ well spent. Hope to take a friend for lunch.
author: Bernard B.

description: Excellent dim sum, and yes, not a cheap meal if you eat in. I am a regular though at their takeout counter (Yank sing 2 go) at  the Stevenson St. location. While the take out menu is limited, the food is the same excellent quality at an affordable price.  Where else can you get a filling tasty lunch downtown for under $5?  Service is usually very quick, and you can eat there under the covered patio and watch the folks eating full service for a whole lot more $$$.
author: Tom C.

description: I would give the food and location here 5 stars but for me the food here is outrageously overpriced, costing 2 or 3 times as much as places with comparable food/decor in NY Chinatown and Flushing.
author: H T.

description: 3 for food, 5 for service...  High brow atmosphere with well mannered staff.  Great place for a business lunch.  However, I couldn't justify a $7 cheung fun which I didn't find exceptional- there are plenty of better authentic dim sum places in the Peninsula for people who truly appreciate authentic Cantonese-style dim sum.
author: Pink P.

description: Very good Dim Sum, but I've had better and cheaper. But NOT from a cleaner kitchen. A little known fact about me, I get lazy, I walk through the Yank Sing's kitchen to get to Ozumo/ my gym/ through the block. Figuring, "Hey, it's okay, I'm Chinese." It's definitely clean.
author: Jean W.

description:
Although pricey, Yank Sing is one of my preferred spots for dim sum (mostly because it's clean).  There is a second, smaller location on Stevenson Street which I prefer to go to on weekends.

Food:  3 stars.  My friend and I tried a ton of dim sum (about $85 worth).  We had the pork sui mye, shrimp dumplings, spinach dumplings, peking duck, Shanghai dumplings, Mandarin dumplings wih chives, crab dumplings, honey-glazed sea bass, crab cakes, sesame balls, and custard tarts.  Although there are some interesting, creative items to choose from, the standard fare (shrimp dumplings, pork sui mye, Mandarin dumplings with chives) were nothing special.  The highlight is the Shanghai dumplings.  You get about 7-8 dumplings served piping hot in a bamboo basket.   After letting them cool down for a bit, put one in your spoon, pour some vinegar on top, and let the rich flavors explode in your mouth.  The peking duck is also amazing.  Although the portions are small, there is absolutely no fat in the duck meat.  Make sure to add a lot of hoisin sauce to the bun and eat it all like a sandwich.  Worst of the bunch were the crab cakes, which had a slightly hard exterior and just no oomph in the flavor.  

Service:  4 stars.  The servers are really attentive here and call out the dim sum in English (the majority of the clientele is non-Asian).  They're also helpful in getting you items that you're not seeing on the carts passing by.  We had to do that for our dessert (sesame balls and custard tarts), which was cool because our server gave us the option of ordering just 2 pieces of each.

Atmosphere:  4 stars.  This is a good place to take someone who has never tried dim sum before.  The place is well-maintained and clean and the food is fresh.  Just don't take an Asian person here, they may complain about the prices.  

Hits:   Shanghai dumplings, peking duck, creative fare.

Misses:  Crab cakes, prices.

If You Like This Place, You'd Probably Like:  Koi Palace, Ton Kiang, City View Restaurant
author: Keith C.

description: We tried this place because my favorite dim sum place (Ton Kiang) was too busy. The placed was packed and the service was great. We tried the pork ginger soup dumpling and my mouth is watering just thinking about it. The walnut shrimp, spinach dumplings and taro root were also amazing. I would give 5 stars but it was pretty expensive for dim sum.
author: Tiffany L.

description: The dim sum here are rather good, but not so much better than other places. It is more decorative, but the selection is very small. Actually only the pork soup buns were impressive. I would just get the buns to go to taste the essence of their dim sum.
author: Lance C.

description: Considering how pricey Yank Sing was, I'd give it a 3.5 max. The service was great and the ambiance was relatively relaxing, but the food was only above average, but not exceptional.  I have to say, this was one of the most expensive dim sums I've had - $50 for 2.  Yikes!
author: Jeannie L.

description: Yes, it is true Yank Sing's Shanghai Dumplings (Xiao long bao) is the best but everything here just taste fresh. I've gone to other dim sum places and even though some were good, it just didn't compare to my Yank Sing. I make it a point to visit this place at least once a month (typically on a payday since it is pricey but oh so worth it). Oh dang it, I want some now. Let me see if I can find someone who will be willing to pay for their share at Yank Sing. Hehehe...
author: Anna P.

description: Although the dim sum here is pretty good.. it is definately OVERPRICED. My boyfriend and I racked up a $90 dollar bill for lunch (tax and tip included)! The service was just mediocre. We had to ask multiple times for water, a box, egg custards, and sauce--all on different occasions. I normally don't mind paying a little more for good food and great service, but I was not impressed for the amount we paid.
author: Emily C.

description: Some dishes are good (dumplings with shrimps) but not the others (like potstickers).  Dishes vary in quality and taste.... so if you want stability and more reasonable price, go somewhere else like Fu lam mum.
author: J R.

description: Vegetarians who love dim sum will really enjoy Yank Sing.  Once you inform the first server that you're interested in the vegetarian dishes, they kindly send over the veggie carts throughout your meal.  Yummy and pretty dishes.  Very clean.  On weekends, there is free parking with validation in the Rincon parking garage.
author: Mona O.

description: Went this sunday for Dim Sum with my family who was visiting.  We loved it.  Food was great and the selection was never ending.  Yank Sing was not so heavy with the seafood - there were many different options for us who did not eat seafood.  Would go back again.
author: Doreen D.

description: I thought this place was fairly good.  The honey coated shrimp w/ walnut stuff was pretty tasty.
author: Chaz N.

description:
Wonderful!!
Tried a bunch of dishes, loved the walnut honey shrimp, the chicken buns, mushroom dumplings, and the the spicy chicken. 
Place is expensive, we spent 120 for 4 people, but we got a ton of food and it was worth the money.
author: Hope S.

description: I've been here twice, the second time to give it a chance for redemption.  But honestly their dim sum did not impress me, which I expect at those inflated prices.  It felt a lot like "Boutique Dim Sum", ie you pay a bit more for the nicer than usual atmosphere and the sterile looking pretty little morsels, but in the end it's all packaging.  The actual food is middle of the road, you can get tastier and heartier and joyfully messier dim sum at most restaurants in Chinatown.  The only standout about this place is their Yank Sing XO and chili sauces; be sure to try some on their condiment trays.  If you like it, they sell the stuff in jars at the restaurant or at your local Ranch 99.
author: Momu T.

description: food was good..but extremely overly priced.  My friend and I ordered 9 small dim sum dishes and it cost us $69.00.  She had one serving of peking duck and when they say it's for one serving, they mean it.  They gave her a small piece (1 piece) of  duck with a bun and some scallions for $5.95.  I could have bought a whole duck for under $10 in Chinatown.  She also ordered 1 order of fried crab balls.  That was $10.95.  Crazy!!  Would not go there again for the price of the food.  Restrooms were shared with other places in the complex and it was dirty.
author: Suzanne C.

description:
The most efficient dim sum around.  Ton Kiang has more variety and equal or better quality, but no place will tend to your needs better.

The Shanghai buns are terrific, the Lobster as dragon is both different and delicious other dishes are as expected,

The radio communication among the staff assures you of getting anything available immediately (or close).

Also like the proximity to the Ferry Building and availability of parking.
author: T T.

description: Pricey, but worth the duckets every once in a while considering most dim sum is utterly forgetable.  Dishes are remarkably nuanced and the peking duck alone is well worth the visit.  Long waits hint at it's greatness, again cost is the only downside...
author: beltrand a.

description: I've eaten at this location a handful of times and while Yank Sing isn't the barometer with which I judge other Dim Sum places, its definately good. I don't say that for the variety, but more for the quality and consistency of the food. I've eaten at maybe 15-20 other places, and I also like some of the crazy take-out steamtable places out in the Richmond that have no english names;  Yank Sing is a place where you take your parents or out of town guests who want some easy SF dimsum.
author: Tom S.

description: Went there for a wedding banquet and was very impressed with the service. They moved like a well-oiled machine. Food came out non-stop without long breaks. There was 3-4 waiters/waitresses serving our table. The food was also delicious and tasty albeit on the pricey side.
author: Shep T.

description: I went here with my husband when we were just dating. He had gone here with coworkers and was raving about it. I had never had dim sum before, but it was really enjoyable, and the food here is SO good- definitely not like the Chinese food you get back east where I'm from. After going to Yank Sing, no other dim sum even comes close. The only thing to watch out for is that it adds up FAST.
author: Taylor S.

description: The best dim sum I have ever had!  Not so greasy and the service was incredible for a place that serves dim sum.  They were very attentive and even had crispy duck for a dim sum dish.  Minus two stars for the arm and leg they charge you.  I'll probably stick to the local chinatown places and settle for the little to no service for good dim sum.
author: Cee L.

description: Despite some of its better reviews, I thought this place was fairly average for Dim Sum.  I went here with a large group and we were helped pretty quickly.  Their champagne (special house) dumplings were pretty good but I didn't like the way they served their peking duck (with a roll, boo).  Their other items were pretty much avg.  If you go, def. try the house dumplings, everything else is pretty good but not amazing.
author: Chris S.

description: I had never had dim sum before so I didnt know what to expect, but I loved it! Both the food and the service were great. There was no shortage of food or waiters coming by with more. Better yet, they weren't pushy with the food; if you said no then they moved on to the next table. The restaurant was packed and there was a line, but well worth! The only down fall is that it was on the expensive side.
author: Aan N.

description: so,  i was going to the city with my wife and have never had dim sum before i thought it would be wise to  read all the reviews. I picked yank sing due to the fact everyone agreed it was clean ( a must for me) I thought the food was great and really enjoyed be able to see and pick the food on the carts. The food was hot and had plenty of choices. Everyone also stated the cost would be high, our total was $60, a bit high for lunch, but to me was well worth it. I plan on going back but for dinner and plan to bring the kids as well.
author: James B.

description: Damn them! Whenever I go here (and that's pretty rare because the bill gets big), they always bring me things I don't want first! Don't they realize that I just want the fried stuff? Bring me the potstickers, the spring rolls, the crab cakes. Yes the pork buns are good, but when I'm craving dim sum, all I really want is the stuff that's really bad for me. :) For some reason they always come after six other little carts full of things I don't want pass by. Don't get me wrong, the duck is excellent and a lot of the items I can't identify, but ordered to tide me over until the potstickers came were downright delicious. It is just that I don't like being tortured. :) The atmosphere works for business lunches. It might be that is in Rincon and Rincon has a very corporate feeling more than the restaurant itself though. Worth going to once in a while.
author: Jordan M.

description:
Harsh reviews?  Man, looking through some of the reviews people are pretty harsh. Ok, granted this is the most expensive dim sum place I've ever been to. $70 for 2 people. I normally spend about $40 for 2 people. Hey...I eat a lot, what can I say?  They're location is clean and no strange smells.  Not your traditional authentic chinese dim sum place.

That being said...Yank Sing is probably my favorite dim sum place. Forget the price and just go by taste for a minute. Every time I've been there, the food has been hot and fresh. Of course I went on the weekend which usually is busier so the food is more fresh. So usually I order the following:

The hargow (steamed shrimp dumplings) & shumai (steamed pork dumplings) are your typical dimsum fare.  The rice noodles wrapped shrimp were cooked perfectly. Sometimes the rice noodles come out under cooked so they're a little too chewy or overcooked so they're too soft and jelly like. The steamed pork bun & the baked pork bun were cooked perfectly. The baked bun had a nice glaze on top that matched perfectly with the bbq pork instead. It was a pocket of surprises. 
But the lettuce wrap chicken with plum sauce is pure bliss. The combination of the chicken with the water chestnuts, fried noodles, (and I think rice) topped off with the plum sauce. Man. That's food orgasmic. It's the sauce I think. I just love that sauce.  The chinese broccoli was nice and crunchy but not too chewy. The green beans with pork were delectable, a good balance to all the meat dishes. 
For dessert I had the sesame seed ball and the almond ice cream. The almond ice cream is so nice. It has a light flavor of almond. I had to order 3.  =)

The wait is usually long on the weekend. Plus parking is a whole other mess.  But once you go in, it's nice. Cool fountain too dripping from the ceiling. I think it's a good date restaurant.
author: Michael W.

description: Oh sweet, sweet soup dumplings, how I miss you. And the tender short ribs, and the shu mai, and the fabu jasmine tea....AND! It rains inside!
author: Angelina M.

description: I must say that I am the most impatient person when I am HUNGRY and I tend to overdramatize my pangs of hunger and start using words like "dying for...," "CRAVING," "jonesing..."  you get the picture.  That is why I love the concept of dim sum.  This Yank Sing offers all the usual colorful little plates and bamboo boxes of shrimp, scallops, chicken feet, and it is pretty tasty.  The only thing I didn't like was the airport-mall-like quality within this prime-real-estate-embarcadero location.  What a waste not to have windows taking in the hustle and bustle of the financial district, the bay bridge, and the beautiful light of the day! I would rather go to Harbor Village...
author: Jaena G.

description: These are those dim sum places you go to for conventional dims sums and some seem fusioned with our California taste.  The ladies that come around are nice and always say the items in English and explain what each thing is.  My last visit, I ordered a few (you won't find these anywhere else) dim sum- an Avocado Curry chicken dish, some Jimica salad with walnuts, some not honey smoked Sea Bass, and a coconut custard dessert.  If you're not feeling adventerous, the Hargow and shumai, is prepared the way they should be: plumpy, juicy and not tasting like it's from yesterday.  A dessert you need to try is the Green Tea pudding!
author: Jason A.

description: 2/20/08: Dim sum lunch for two, no reservations which meant a 10-15 minute wait. The xiao liong baos (small steamed dumplings) are AWESOME - our order came out piping hot and filled with steam sauce inside. We dumped $52 for dimsum, alittle steep but nothing extraordinary for downtown SF. I don't think I would complain if the view was better (instead of looking into a food court).
author: Jesse W.

description: This was my first time ever trying Dim Sum.  If we have these restaurants in Houston, I've never heard about them.  I think people are too busy wolfing down all the ribs and hot wings and steak to think about a lil ol' Dim Sum place.  So if you're wondering, I liked the food.  The thing that sticks out in my mind most, we're the servers.  I swear if anybody is reading this now and actively looking for the next big reality show, this place is it.  The servers have to work on commission because they peddle these dishes as if they're lives absolutely depended on it.  I didn't witness any altercations, but there's definitely potential drama if a servers tries to ease in on somebody's territory.  Like I said, the dishes I tried were quite tasty.  I didn't care for the tea or desserts but you can't win them all.  This is a fun place for a group...especially if someone else is paying.
author: LaSha G.

description:
The best xiao long bao!  And everything else is made to perfection as well.  
Very pricey, but the service is great.  I know that I am going to love everything I order, and their dim sum menu is vast.  Hard to find a place so reliable in quality.
author: Lulu B.

description: Came here for dim sum couple times. The food is great. I love the sea bass. Nothing to complain abt the food. As for service, well, I didn't have much expectation.
author: Joanne X.

description: I dunno...the place is good, but *fancy* dim sum just ain't my thang. Dim sum is all about drinking too much the previous night, and stuffing yourself the next morning. Or going with family and friends, and eating and chilling. Although Yank Sing is good, it's just a little too posh for my tastes.
author: Peter S.

description: Love the food and love the service -- I went to eat by myself and was offered no fewer than 25 different delicious items.  Though I obviously couldn't try everything, the ones I did were quite good.  As for the pricing though, I'm sure I would have been shocked by the bill -- as it is, they're clients of mine so they refused to let me pay and sent me off with packages of food to take to my family, including my Chinese stepmother who swears they have the best dim sum in San Francisco.
author: Casey S.

description: Did you know that the dimsum here is frozen.  If you get beyond that, the food is awesome.  We have been going here since 1995 and have never been let down.  I dont like some of the specials like the sea bass.  Stick with the traditional items and you will be happy.  The food quality has generally dropped over the years while the prices have gone up.  However, YS remains the premier DimSum provider int he BA.  BTW, the pepper noodles on a hot plate are very very good and so are the deserts.
author: A K.

description: I tried the to-go version.  LOTS of food.  Okay taste.  I wasn't blown away, but I would probably eat it again.  A-OK
author: Bree W.

description: My new favorite dim sum place in San Francisco!  Great dim sum in the Rincon Center.  There was a 20-minute wait for a table and it was very expensive for dim sum compared to Chinatown, but the dim sum was some of the best I've had.  There was this wonderful dim sum that they called their specialty of the house that was a dumpling filled with soup (that was a great sensation, popping this dim sum in your mouth and having this savory warm soup filling your mouth....mmmmm).  The only thing was that our bill for 5 people came to $99 (that was including a tip).  That's a lot for dim sum, in my opinion.  Despite that, we'll go back, because it was really good.
author: Meg T.

description: same dim sum but twice the price, apparently Michelin don't know what is a good Chinese dim sum, try Asian Pearl or Koi palace.
author: R T.

description: God damn this place is expensive.  If you eat at a normal dim sum place I usually spend between $30 to $40 for me and skinny cow.  If it were myself and my fat friends we would spend $30 to $40 each.  So if I took a fat friend with me we would be paying close to $60 to 80 per person.  Worth it.  No.  But the experience was good.   They have some off the menu items that I stole from the table next to me.  Everyone in this place looks rich.  Too bad I look homeless.  Suckaz.  The secret menu item to order here is the pistachio ice cream pie.  OMFG its amazing.  I asked the waitress if it was made in house she laughed and said no.  Chinese dont make no pistachio ice cream pie.  stupid me.  The ice cream pie had almond flavor ice cream on a bed of chocolate gram cracker crust topped with pistachios.  OMFG I think it was one of the best things I ate this year.  I want to order one for thanksgiving and christmas but I can't find it.  I will have to call them for the bakery.  I would only go back for this item.  I can forgo the dim sum.
author: Fatty A.

description: Not much I can say that hasn't already been raved about, both here and in professional reviews. Don't miss the Shanghai xiao-long-bao: easily the best of any dim sum restaurant I've been to in the states, and rivals much of what I've had in Asia. Aside from seasonal fish specials, generally stay clear of dishes being carried around on trays--stick to the carts if you don't want your bill to come out unexpectedly high.
author: Felix H.

description: Dumplings galore!!! I love the variety of dumplings. Higher quality dim sum than the average but is considered overpriced for dim sum. It's the fancy, clean-up kind. Nice atmosphere and pleasant service. As my BF always comments, "Oh they all speak English here." Unhuh. They do and they small talk with you, unlike many other Chinese dim sum places. The food in general is good but I'm overly focused on the dumplings and egg custard tart to care about the other stuff so I can't comment too much on the rest of the dishes.  Oh but my mom says it's not authentic or worth it so I guess it depends on what kind of experience/meal you are looking for that morning.
author: Royce L.

description: Super services and ambiance, and the best traditional Shanghai Xiao Long Bao in the city, I am a fan; the rest of dim sum choices are more like a 3 1/2 stars.  Complimentary 3 hour parking on weekends and holidays.
author: J S.

description: Of all the places I have tried, this is like the Class A chinese dimsum; elegant and yummy dimsum I have ever tasted but pricey!!
author: cecille p.

description: Incredible food!!! I don't usually care for Chinese food, but then my boyfriend dragged me here kicking and screaming. I'm so glad he did. Everything we ordered was superb. The dim sum was light and delicate rather than overly seasoned and heavy. I've been back countless times and the food is consistently great. Prices are slightly high especially for lunch (generally around $60-$70 for two people). I just can't come as often as I would like. Which is probably a blessing...
author: Ariana B.

description: Excellent dim sum and great service. The prices, though, are screamingly outrageous. I've been to Yank Sing a number of times, and I'm always thrilled with the food and revolted by the bill. Not that it keeps me away, but it does knock the happiness factor down a notch or two. Maybe I'll search for a dim sum cooking class...until then, I'll just stash my lunch money away for a quarterly visit to the temple of soup dumplings and sesame balls.
author: J. C.

description: I often leave dim sum feeling like I want to roll on home.  I leave here after a huge meal and don't feel over stuffed.  The ladies come around with the carts and I sawear they work on commission because they are eager to unload the goods on the wagons.  You can get pretty much any dim sum standard here.  I don't know the names of things, so I won't insult anyone by trying, but everything is good and not terribly greasy.  Would recommend.
author: apple r.

description:
I was in San Francisco for business and had a free day, so I had the opportunity to check out this place on a Sunday morning - on my one free day, and I was impressed. Great food, impeccable service. Awesome. 

I will admit this was my first time to have Dim Sum, so it was special for me. I have had Dim Sum several times since at locations in other cities, etc. and all fall way short. 

They have set my expectations very high, and I have come to the conclusion that they are a very special restaurant.
author: Sam G.

description: Yank Sink 2 go is pretty decent. The veggie delight special with the eggplant is yummy. Although, the rest of it just tasted like normal Chinese food. I think the full menu inside is better, but I don't feel the urge to check it out. I like my Chinese to be greasy and unhealthy, don't try to mask it up as a "fresh" Chinese. Just stick to what you're good at, frying everything and clogging my arteries.
author: Dustin S.

description: Really really good dim sum, maybe not the most authentic and not the best value but the food itself is really really good.
author: Debbie Y.

description: Same song, same verse. A l'il bit louder and a l'il bit worse.
author: Rene D.

description:
iit's a good place for sure. I personally had great service (for a chinese restaurant)  

I had barely sat down and by the time I had put my napkin on my lap, I had three dishes in front of me. If you are a dim sum fiend like me, that's a good thing. If you want to take your time and not feel pressured, then maybe it'll be overwhelming.

Onto the food:

I had rather high expectations and was happy that everything I had was of good quality. Spectacular quality? Eh. I was a tad disappointed because this is San Fran, after all. The siu Mai (steamed pork dumpling) was above average, though honestly I thought the shrimp to pork ratio was too high. The har cow (steamed shrimp dumpling) was good, but the skin was a tad too thick (still way above average, but i'm comparing this to the Peninsula Hotel in Kowloon - I told you I was a dim sum fiend)  the Char siu bao (steamed bbq pork bun) was actually mediocre and totally skippable. Other reviewers seem to enjoy it, however. The Shanghai dumplings are an A minus. Or perhaps an A. Let's be honest, very few places do this dish well, and this is up there. Personally I enjoy Din Tai Fong's better (if you live in the LA area or in various locations in China)  theirs are better but these are still quite good.

If you want to just ask for a dish, they will gladly get it for you. If you want some hoisin sauce which is not at the table, they will also gladly get it. In general, this is spectacular service for a dim sum place. Many people pushing the carts at other restaurants couldn't care less what you do or do not get. Here, they seem to care.

Price: pricey. It was more expensive than I was expecting. Instead of of 4.50 or 5.00 for a dish, it was more like 6.50.

I will say that I haven't been to too many SF dim sum places, but I would like to think you can get better 'value' elsewhere. However, if you want fresher food and better quality (though not always better tasting, though in many cases it is)  then this place is a good bet.
author: Mark L.

description: My uncle always wants to meet me here for dim sum; hey, as long as he's paying, I'm showing up. Always consistent, never that interesting. I have yet to leave thinking that Yank Sing is fantastic. Good, but super pricey. It isn't just that it is expensive; it is that Yank Sing just doesn't seem like a great value -  not the food, not the service, and certainly not this oddball location.
author: Lindley E.

description: Well, if it was all about the PORK BUN, it would be a 5+++ all the way. I guess if you are going to have dim sum, you cannot eat only PORK BUNS. The other items are pretty good. THe ONe Rincon building is a beautiful setting for DIM SUM. THere is even takeout for those spur of the moment PORK BUN cravings. Typical day time dim sum on the weekend has about a 45 minute wait. THe waiters and staff do not come around frequently enough nor do they go in a set pattern to make sure that they hit your table. YOu will often see carts come out and go back in without ever seeing what is on them. Darn DIM SUM CONSPIRACY. I have had to ask every time I was there for the char siu balls. I will still go here any day! Their PORK BUNS are the best I have ever had.
author: Jennifer P.

description: Yank Sing delivers dim sum in a fancy way, though unfortunately, fancy also means expensive. Everyone has mixed opinions about this place with worse opinions coming from those footing the bill, but if you're looking for good ethnic food where you can take finicky types who might not want to try something new but will be impressed by your worldliness, this is a great option. I definitely recommend getting some peking duck and small dragon buns or whatever they're called in English.
author: Michael G.

description: Four stars for the food alone.  Aside from maybe the sea bass, coleslaw, and bacon-wrapped shrimp and scallions, pretty typical dim sum though with good quality comparable to that of Harbor Village, but then that's just me not letting go of what's no longer there.  Twice visited and twice forked up a huge bill, almost twice more expensive than its worth for a party of three.  Those fusion selections, the Peking duck skins, and them modern contemporary tea pots do not justify the exorbitant tab.  At least they were nice enough to cover parking.  Moments like this make me wish I still work for a company that lets me turn in expense reports.
author: Erick ..

description: Yes, it is way overpriced, and hit or miss. But you cannot go wrong with the veggies and the old stand bys. I know what I like here & I just wait until it comes around. Or we order what we know we want and go from there. If you like dim sum in a nice environment and you have $$ burning a hole in your pocket, Yank Sing is the place for you.
author: Colleen B.

description: Came here for lunch one day and ordered the Yank Sing Express: a spring roll, potsticker, steamed pork bun, and chow mein--LOTS of chow mein. All in all, not bad, but very greasy. The chow mein tasted great at first, but I think my stomach was simply desperate. After a few minutes I realized was an oily mess I'd gotten myself into. I probably won't go here again; for noodles, I'll stick to the Long Life Noodle Co. across the street.
author: Patrick G.

description: I was craving dim sum and it was late in the afternoon...  No other dim sum place I'd rather go than Yank Sing at that hour.  I mean, even at its not so fresh, you know it'll still be tasty.  So we dashed over as quick as we could, easily found a parking spot and walked in.  This was about 3:30 on Sunday.  We had eaten and paid our bill by 4:00.  The most efficient meal ever.  Our bill was over $50 for the two of us so I can't say anything positive about the prices, but the 2 orders of Shanghai Dumplings were well worth it.  With Yank Sing, you get what you pay for.  I'm never dissatisfied.
author: Lisa C.

description: As Asian as I am - I think this is one of the best dim sum places in the city!  Busy as all hell during the lunch rush - but well worth it!  The shrimp dumplings and other dumplings (how do you translate Chinese words to English...) were pretty decent - as were the cha siew baos (Chinese BBQ pork buns). YUM.  And the best part of dim sum - is when you're full, you stop ordering!  It's a little weird that they literally put the plate on your table, before they ask you if you want it or not.  Friendly staff - but just bit pushy. I guess that's how you get your business!  Definitely will be back for more! MmMMmmmmm
author: Lisa L.

description:
fairly overpriced dim sum, but it's definitely good!
my parents enjoyed it; (they are koreans who do not like to eat anything other than homecooked korean food) so this says a lot!
get the dumplings (shrimp, pork, whatever) they're all pretty good!
author: J K.

description: The dim sum is pretty, but the flavors are bland.  On a positive note, this is probably the cleanest restaurant I've seen for dim sum and I would probably take non-foodie people here.  Someone once told me that many SF law firms use Yank Sing to cater their events, despite the mediocre food, because the staff speaks English.  But what good is an English-speaking staff if the food turns people off dim sum?
author: Diana C.

description: Went here a couple of days ago with my bf.  Overall, the food was OK.  The soup dumplings were the BEST thing on the dim sum carts.  All the other traditional choices; pork dumpling, shrimp dumpling, shrimp ho fun were alright.  We had about 8-10 different options, but the bill was shocking!!!!  $80 with tip for 2 people!!!  That's craziness.  We later went to dinner that night and got appetizer, entrees, and dessert to share for nearly the same cost.  If I do head back to San Fran, I don't think I'm going to choose this place again, even if it does have good soup dumplings.
author: Cindy H.

description: Best dim sum I've ever had.  Yeah, it's full of tourists and expensive but I was a tourist who was brought here by a local.  C'mon, the place is gorgeous and service is great.  And afterwards, you can roll on over to the Ferry House to walk it off.
author: Chad K.

description: Way over-priced. But good dim-sum. Nice when the company gets catering from here, but that's about all on YS.
author: Fish F.

description:
we walked in about an hour before they were closing, so i am sure if we came in earlier we would have had more options and a better experience. 

we sat down and ordered traditional tea, the tea had a hint of floral. the first waitress came around with the dumpling cart, we chose the schezuan dumplings which were delicious, the next cart we chose mushroom, spinach, and scallop dumplings. you would think that was enough but we also had the spring rolls which were quite good especially with the sweet sauce served with it. of course my bf had to ask for an order of the Peking Duck. it was his first time at a Dim Sum Restaurant and being from NYC, we have way better Dim Sum here..

Overall, this place was good but the bill was a lot! the Spring rolls, schezuan dumplings are definitely worth a whirl!
author: melissa b.

description: Great food but my advice is to eat inside rather than the fountain area unless you are nowhere near closing time.  We made a reservation and told them we wanted to eat inside and instead we were given an outside table right next to all the dirty dish bins.  As closing time drew near, they started to break down all the extra tables so it was very noisy.  They also stopped bringing out carts of food by 2:45 even though they were still seating new customers inside.  Fresh plates were never changed out though anything we ordered from the menu came very quickly.
author: love d.

description: Some of the best dim sum ever!  My family has been going to this place ever since it was a small hole in the wall in Chinatown.  Since then the business has boomed, but the food has remained spectacular.
author: Brian L.
