description: In all fairness, the dim sum was good but the super outrageous prices in turn will cost them a star.
author: Ikeb I.

description:
VERY overpriced. Nice Restaurant. But ridiculously expensive. 
But it was really good dim sum. I think this is where all the white people go for dim sum bc their too scared to go to the real dim sum places on clement and in Chinatown...
The staff at  Yank Sing are hella nice and attentive vs the Rude, pushy in your face..

But i would never go back, I'll just go on Clement...to one of there many  dim sum  rest. that wont robbed your wallet.  ( I did go back and it was still really good dim sum) hahaha

I just cant get enough of the sesame balls!

Shanghai Dumpling - A Yank Sing signature dish of minced Kurobuta Pork, scallion and ginger wrapped and steamed in its own aromatic broth is also my favorite!!!

A funny commentary during our brunch:
" all the waitress looks like Asian porn stars..with the the red lipstick and there long hair and there Chinese high slit outfits".. " yea dood they do... hahahah"  " I would push them wearing high stiletto highs...they would definitely sell more dim sum..Loafers aren't really that hot with that outfit."
author: JK K.

description: The food is good but it's very pricey. Also I'd say that quite a bit of it is not what most Chinese would call 'authentic'. I only go here on someone else's suggestion and if it's their dime. Because otherwise I would just rather take a walk to Chinatown. For a CHinese joint, they can't be beat for cleanliness though. Though I have no idea what their Health dept. rating is.
author: cyndi L.

description: Non-greasy dim sum is not Chinese dim sum.  So granted, if you like non-oily food this is the place to be (and if you wanna shell out 3x what you can spend in Chinatown).  But for cheapos like me, I like paying $10, being stuffed full garlic and chives, and wiping the grease off my fingers at the end.
author: Francis L.

description: The dim sum and banquet style dishes were excellent.  Prices are high, but the food is fresh, tasty and delightfully good.
author: Lisa C.

description:
yank sing gets 4 stars and not 5 because it's so expensive... 

i swear the soup dumplings have crack in them - they are SO good and so addictive, i can't stop thinking about them and my mouth is watering just yelping about them because they are SO yummy and lip-smack worthy.

ahem.

yeah, try out the soup dumplings. and the custard buns. yum.
author: dj z.

description: went here for a wedding its a quite a nice place.  Food is very good especially thier mango pudding.  The service is first class and they really deserve the rave reviews from the sf cronicle.
author: Stevezee C.

description:
OK, this place serves great dim sum, makes you pay through the nose, gets seriously dinged for all the right reasons, yet is CLEAN and allows patrons to linger.  I love Yank Sing; it's a weird experiment to upscale Chinese food from the depths of America's obsession with cheap fastfood.  (San Francisco arguably has a greater percentage of solidly "authentic" and quality Chinese, but say Chinese and try not to evoke take-out.)  Whether take out or in-restaurant, where else do you go for a meal of ginger scallion lobster, steamed fish, spring rolls, and sizzling beef, all for $25?  C'mon!  

Stars for the good food -- soupy dumplings, turnip cakes, pork spareribs, etc. Problem is, the restaurant struggles with fun food, essentially the stuff popular with the tourists that it can't give up (my friend LOVES the lettuce cups filled with minced pork topped with duck sauce...where the HELL did that come from?). You just want to take it by the neck and shout, NO!!  WCYD?  In the meantime, service needs serious quality control.  On this last occasion the cart ladies assiduously avoided us until I convinced a friend of the old lady technique, that is, to run up directly to the cart and finger their baskets of goodies until the lady acknowledges you to make you go away.  He mastered the technique quickly, and I think the beer got him off to a good start. Meanwhile, the tea ladies ply-ed us with a limitless supply of cold and hot tea. I had a full glass but she insisted I disregard the old glass and try the "fresher" one.  Gees.  

I do detest the perennial wait at YS, and the absence of chicken feet, tongue, gizzards, tripe, and whatnot that reflect the ingenuity and reality of Chinese food. (Note: serve it up in a French restaurant and get charged 5x for 1/2 the portion.)  But think rent and location, think clean and bright, think tasty, and think of your first-time guests. This is definitely a place to introduce most folks to dim sum and to good Chinese. When they're hooked, THEN you can take them to the corners of Chinatown which involve sidestepping the mashed cabbage leaves and minced chicken on the sidewalk.  Baby steps.
author: Conifers J.

description: Yum Yum Dim Sum. Yes, it's a bit crowded on the weekends, Sunday especially, and the wait, well, the wait isn't cool if you're hungry, but by god, the food is GOOD! We take the French contingency here every time they visit and they just love it!
author: Kelly R.

description: It would be 5 stars if it was about 40% cheaper.  You ARE getting incredibly attentive service, hot food brought to you every nanosecond, validated parking, and a great selection of dishes.  Also, there is a nice sweet desert dish they serve -- some sort of doughy sesame dumpling filled with lotus that stands out.
author: Tim G.

description: I'm giving this place 4 stars off the bat just because this is hands down the best tasting dim sum in the city (I think.) The service has always been pretty good and the setting is beautiful, as well as accessible. I won't lie, however, my father and I hate their parking garage (so tiny!) However, you get free ticket validation from the restaurant, so kudos to you, Yank Sing.
author: Jonathan L.

description:
high class dim sum?!?! 

this is probably the best dim sum ive had! im 100% chinese and live in rowland heights (little chinatown)... so ive had my share of dim sum. 

first things first, you park downstairs in a super tight structure. take the elevator up to the restaurant. its not a normal looking dim sum place that's for sure. i probably would have gotten lost if i was by myself :o)

all the greasy flavors were there... minus a lot of the actual grease! they have the traditional ladies pushing carts by each table. what i liked most was how we didnt have to wave down the lady just to get the har gao & siu mai cart!!! that's a first. the service i would give an A+. the waiters and waitresses work like theyre in sales! they offer plates of food directly to your table (with a smile), making you say "hell, i'll take it all!!!"

i wish they had a yank sing in so cal. for now, ill be at hong kong palace. hopefully they dont burn down again :oT
author: Tammie H.

description: I hate Dim Sum, so this review is SOLELY for the salad. Shredded cabbage, some tasty vinegarette, and candied walnuts. MMMMMM!!!
author: Carson H.

description: It's pricey for dim sum and sometimes you may wait an hour.  But the service is always great and the food consistent.  The Shanghai dumplings are the only thing that I come here for...that and all those Asian weddings.  Their dumplings are some of the best that I've ever had both here and in China. Not to be missed.
author: Kimmie N.

description:
my husband is from HONG KONG and my in-laws are CHINESE... we all consider this the BEST DIM SUM in SF!!

for those of you who say it is not AUTHENTIC, then maybe you have only been to MAINLAND CHINA or are only familiar with certain regions of dim sum cuisine. 

this is certainly not greasy like two yelpers claimed. although the veg dishes on the carts are served cold (which is a bit of a turn off). we now order our veg from the kitchen, so it arrives pipping hot. 

the SHANGHAI DUMPLINGS are spot on. 

YES- yank sing is PRICEY, however you are paying for QUALITY and white linen. be prepared to pay a minimum of $28 p/person drinking only tea. if you want a cheaper tab then go somewhere on clement or in the burbs.
this is no corner joint, and there is a reason they cater traditional weddings.
author: SF U.

description: The few vegetarian pieces they have are pretty good but chances are if you are veggie, you will leave this place hungry within the hour.
author: Jerry S.

description:
Can you say...Dim Sum rip off? Yes you can. You will feel that way once see your bill & walk out after the meal. So only go if you're using the Company's expense account, then it's Dim Sum at it's Finest. 

Why 3 stars?

1: Hands down on the Shanghai soup dumpling (XiaoLoanBao) (5 stars!!) The best in North Ca I have to say! Thin wrapper with tons of soup/juice inside! That is all I really come for. But $13 for 6 of them in a tiny basket. I order two baskets, then I bounce. 
2: Great service!! I'm impressed. Everyone there speaks English, (of course Chinese) from the waiter to the Cart pushing ladies! They are friendly & answers your questions & even help you order the food when it's not in their Cart & the waiter is not around. Everyone deserves to be tipped at 20% cause they are truly at your service. VERY RARE at a Chinese restaurant...even Koi Place doesn't have this top-notch service. 
3: Free validated parking on the weekends. Nice atmosphere. Lots of variety, some I've never seen before at other places - so it's great to try; such as Spinach dumpling & lots of vegetarian options - Curry Corner & lots of Tofu Wrap & Almond or Mango Ice Cream Cake slice. (Yummy)

why negative 2 stars:
1. HELLA expensive. every tiny dim sum dish is $9-15 bucks and there's no way you can find out the price; there's no menu or anything by the door. Just karts where you point & order. Unless you ask verbally to the Kart Pushers. 
2: As a Dim Sum pro, I know my dim sum and the Ha Gow & Sui Mai & some of the other "Gow" (dumpling in Cantonese)  was steamed too dry, it look & taste dehydrated. 

Overall, 70% of the Dim Sum is really good (4-5 stars) comparable to Koi Palace but the price is ridiculous.
author: Yum Y U M.

description:
The dim sum here is second to none.  As my 2 year-old might say, this is num num dim sum.

I recently investigated the Yank Sing 2 Go and I've been very impressed.  I can pick up a Phoenix for less then $7 - it's the same great quality and it's more food than I can eat (well - almost).
author: Matt S.

description: A good dim sum place.  Although not 100% Chinese or Cantonese authentic, kind of a little Fusion but still a great place to enjoy.  A place to invite your friends especially Non-Chinese.  Service is relatively good but the price is very 'HIGH'.  I go there like once every 2 months to enjoy the nice 'waterfall' and the various varieties of dim sum.  Expect to spend $40 & up (Depends on what you eat) for 2.....
author: P. C.

description: this was my first dim sum experience and although i thought the experience itself was fun, i definitely left feeling hungry and $26 poorer. the service, however, was impeccable and the chicken dumplings happened to be delish. the restaurant was beautiful, but i would've fully preferred a kitschy (and reasonably-priced) place in the middle of chinatown any day!
author: Laurie L.

description:
I love Yank Sing.  The dim sum is great and they have a full bar.  I would've given them 5 stars but service can be slow at times and they need more bathrooms to handle their capacity (2 stalls for 200+ people is kind of weak).   On the plus side the bathroom and the restaurant are both very clean.  It's best to call ahead to make a reservation since even with a reservation you're looking at a 5-10 minute wait.  There's generally a 20-25 minute wait without a reservation.

BBQ Pork Buns - tasty and filling.

Chicken Lettuce Wraps - Yummy and refreshing.

Ginger pork Shanghai dumplings  - one of their best dishes.  The perfect amount of ginger blended with pork in a nice steamy, juicy dumpling.

BBQ Pork rice noodles - My favorite dish hands down.  I generally order two plates for myself.

Peking duck - perfectly cooked.  Moist juicy duck with a crispy skin stuffed in a bun.  Perfection.  My second favorite dish.

Potstickers - mediocre, dime a dozen.

Chicken Satay - tasty.

Bacon wrapped shrimp - c'mon did I need to say anything after bacon?  I had you at bacon.

Chicken mushroom dumpling - meh

Sesame ball - fine but nothing special

They have a nice selection of teas as well as a full bar.  They actually mix a really good cocktail (smooth, goes down easy). 

I usually go with a group of friends and it runs us about $35 each with tax & tip for multiple servings of 7 different dishes with a round of drinks.  Pretty good deal for a smorgasboard if you ask me.
author: Ginger K.

description: I went at lunchtime for dim sum and had a wonderful experience. The service was prompt, food fresh, and prices reasonable for the Financial District. The linen napkins were a nice touch!
author: Virginia S.

description: I like dim sum!  Unfortunately, even though the food is good, Yank Sing only gets one star from me.  The reason is that it is so way overpriced!  I get that dim sum they charge for tea ... some times, but way overcharge for tea that I did not even ask for or want to drink?  There are many other places to get really good dim sum in San Francisco.  If you skip this place, trust me, it will be okay.
author: Jack M.

description: This is still my favorite Dim Sum place ever..I have tried several others in the Bay Area and I still love this place..The Chicken Salad is excellent, I love the hot mustard in the dressing, the Peking Duck is crispy and good, the best shrimp and chicken and mushroom dumplings I have ever had, finally I love the hot custards(they melt in your mouth) and the little orange jellos for dessert.. I have also ordered the crispy chow mien from their menu and it has been superb.
author: Dee D.

description: If you are hungry and want to eat a lot of v good dim sum..go here! My butt had barely hit the seat when 4 carts of food came rolling up..when you are hungry its hard to not order everything! Highlights of the feast included the scallops and the chicken mushroom dim sum.
author: Not M.

description: Get there before noon, get a table by the kitchen, and grab every cart that goes by. Ask, "What is that?" to everything. The later you go the less comes out, and what does seems reheated. The less familiar dishes are best, like the sauteed greens, cabage walnut salad, unfamiliar dumpings, mango pudding. I like the meaty bits, spare ribs and foil chicken things. The basic potsticker and chicken salad could have come from any boring place. Get out your wallet, cause you're going to pay big.
author: J. R.

description: The dim sum at Yank Sing is probably pretty close to excellent.  The skin for dumplings is thin.  The ingredients are as fresh if not fresher than other places.  The meat is not overcooked.  Not too much oil.  The Xiao Long Bao is almost as good as the ones from Shanghai.  The service is a notch above most dim sum places.  I don't mind paying a little more.  Not sure you can find the same quality dim sum for less in the States.
author: Shum S.

description:
yeah the dim sum is really good. yeah the ladies in the carts came by with extra panache and super frequency. but really, do you want to pay $45 a person for dim sum? no exaggeration. $45 for breakfast and there was no caviar.

so, i answer for you. NO.

oh, and the wait is stupid. i guess making a reservation helps but i felt so claustrophobic even with the seating spilling out into the atrium i wanted to run away. i was so pissed i waited for an hour, determined to get my damn table. there are other places that are comparably good and 1/2 the cost.
author: monkey l.

description: I don't know.  I'm not sick like I was after eating dim sum in the real china town, but my expectations were higher for more variety and interesting dishes.
author: Lindsay T.

description: Just ok.....not sure what all the hoopla is about. It is definitely better than most dim sum places....but not awesome. I did like the Sea Bass, but found the dumpling so so and you can find better pot stickers pretty much anywhere.
author: Adrienne G.

description: Great tasting food, but the atmosphere (think Rincon food court) leaves a lot to be desired, so one less star.  I used to work for the Battery Street location in '91, when I was just a young pup, and havent really had a sit down meal at Yank Sing since.  The quality is still top notch and they improved their vegetarian and sea food selections.  And who isnt addicted to the coconut rolls (you can get these to-go from the take-out side)?  Dim sum is always better with a group so you can experience a larger variety of dishes.  Be prepared to drop about $65/person, but this includes your morning booze.
author: brewgirl b.

description: Probably the most expensive dim sum in the city, and worth every penny.  All the standard shrimp dumplings, pork dumplings, pork and duck buns etc etc are delicious, and their shanghai dumplings are just amazing.  I also love their coleslaw salad with the candied walnuts, and the peking duck is pretty crispy and tasty also.  We go for Sunday brunch occasionally and I swear every time there are more and more tables taking up that building lobby.  First there used to be a few tables outside the restaurant, then they started going around the fountain, and now they're going down the lobby to the opposite side of the building.  You go, Yank Sing!
author: cecilia g.

description: Yum-o!  This is one of my fave dim sum places in the Bay Area.  It is on the pricey side but so is everything else in that area.  Don't be discouraged by the line because you'll get in eventually and service moves pretty fast.  Try the pork noodle rice noodles (topped with an amazing sweet soy sauce) and the scallop siu mye; however, everything is pretty good so just be adventurous and don't be surprised at the bill!
author: Courtney B.

description:
we came here last saturday for dim sum... 
it was a nice location... very close to the ferry building...
dim sum was very fresh and good. but for some reason, it didn't taste spectacular.... the presentation was nicer than the taste... or maybe my expectation was set too high. 

it is a place to take someone that doesn't eat dim sum too often to impress them with the ambiance and presentation.

not sure if i'll come back, but good to know for out of town guests and non-traditional chinese people...
author: kiko v.

description: The dining room is giant and it fills up fast. It's pretty loud & chaotic. The service is good, but also a bit chaotic since they are swinging by the table frequently and trying to push all the different dishes on you. If you're okay with a little bit of chaos, then you'll like it here. The food was tasty, and surprisingly there were enough vegetarian options. I didn't pay for it, so I can't rate the experience for the value. I'd return only with a group, but never for a place to have a quiet conversation or dinner date.
author: Stumbalina b.

description: The food is great, and the locations are nice. The food is served via waiters who come around with carts, instead of menus, so you see the food before you buy it. Overall, a great restaurant, and I've been coming here with my family and friends for years.
author: Zach H.

description: Awesome dim sum, some of the best I have ever had.  I highly recommend for any yum cha craving yelpers!
author: Grover G.

description: We went here because it was highly recommended. It was good. The variety was not as large as I was led to believe.  But the food was good.  The service was so-so.  They put down another order of shrimp wrapped in noodles after i told them no because we still have an order on our table.  The food was a bit on the pricey side for dim sum.
author: Phil V.

description: One of best places for Dim Sum in the city. I have been there at least 9 times and I still give it 5 stars. If you sit inside, you can get first crack at the trays as they roll out of the kitchen.  The outside seating in the atrium is nice too, but your faaar from the kitchen kid.
author: Mark P.

description:
awesome food and great service. a bit on the pricey side so this is not the place for you if you are on a budget. 

try the soup dumplings. they are amazing - both taste and price.
author: Emily Y.

description: Sensational soup dumplings. Went on a Sunday for brunch with a reservation (which is highly recommended, because it got crowded around noon very fast). Been anxious to go again! The whole experience is borderline whimsical -- it's housed inside a mall by the Embarcadero (that was otherwise entirely empty and closed down when I went), the tables outside the restaurant (which is still inside the mall) are adjacent to an interior waterfall and well-lit (ceiling windows let in daylight), and you can both order from the kitchen as well as pick and choose a varied selection of dim sum from the circulating trolleys being carted around by friendly waitresses. By the time we left, we were pleasantly stuffed (at a shockingly good price!), both the inside and outside tables were full, busy, and happy, and there was a great vibe going!
author: G. J.

description: this place is hit or miss.  the misses can be really bad.  so i decided not to go back because my last experience was so miserable.
author: Young P.

description: Thought the food was great until the bill came.  This place is way overpriced for Dim Sum.  Party of 5 racked up a $200 bill in the blink of an eye - for lunch, yet!  Outrageous!  The broth in the soup dumplings was not tasty at all.  I don't recommend this place for the average dim sum lover.  Perhaps being able to write the meal off as a business expense is worth it.  The place was certainly packed with what looked like business folks.
author: W D.

description: Good, not great, dim sum that's uninspired and fairly ordinary.  I'm amazed that this place is so busy on weekends when there are so many other great dim sum options in the area!
author: Marcus C.

description: If you and a friend are big eaters be prepared to slap down the Credit Card.  I'd say $120 for two.
author: Justin C.

description: High end dim sum - great selection and they keep on coming!  A little high priced, but great food.  They're in a atrium-style food court building which has a cool water fountain from above.
author: Lance F.

description: I'm new to eating dim sum and Yank Sing is the best yet. The food is great along with excellent service, it's over price but the portions are good.  If you're not on a budget don't worry about it.
author: Edward M.

description: Oh Yank Sing...I love to hate you and hate to love you.  You make me wait 25 minutes for a table and I endure it.  I wait and wait for the chance to devour your tasty dumplings and buns.  Your food, location, cleanliness, open courtyard, and service make me come back for more each time but I always end up eating cereal for the rest of the week to make up for such a costly meal.  Woe is me.
author: Nina L.

description: This is the tastiest dim sum I've had in town.  That said, it's hard to justify going here when one can get 98% as good food for 1/3 the price at places like Good Luck Dim Sum in the Richmond.  It was fun to go once, but I don't think I'll go back.  They do validate parking, so keep that in mind.  Also, their staff is great, very speedy and helpful.
author: April G.

description: this place is awesome for dim sung and pork bun -everythng is good and has indoor and covered patio seating
author: Jared D.

description: You may a little bit of a premium, but this is a most civilized way to eat and enjoy dim sum.  Food is very consistently good and there's always a crowd eager to dine here.  Staff isn't pushy - pushing food on you either.  Can always count on a good experience here.
author: Michael Y.

description: Absolutely amazing. Best dim sum I've ever had. Expensive, but more than worth it.
author: S. R.

description:
Solidly OK food.  Nice place to go for a special lunch but not the best dim sum of my life....and definitely not one that warranted the $83 price tag for TWO people.  Good dim sum, even really good dim sum should not cost more than $25 per person

Warning - the sea bass is $16, the duck is about $10 for two slices, and the shanghai dumplings are $10 = all of these are WAYYY overpriced.  Good but overpriced. Stay away unless you're stuck in the Financial District and willing to spend about $30-40 per person.
author: Christina D.

description: A place loved by white people but not even on the radar for Chinese people.  Why?  Because the dim sum is average at best, not authentic at all, and priced 2-3x what you'd pay elsewhere just because they can get away with it since - if you haven't figured it out by now - they only target the white folks.
author: P B.

description: A good high-end Chinese restaurant for both sit-down and to-go! Love the Shanghai dumplings - one of the best in the bay area!! yummmmmy~
author: Amada S. W.

description: I love a YANK SING! Especially because when you pick up the shrimp dumplings with your chopsticks and the wrapper doesn't fall apart and then the shrimp falls out. I have never had that happen here. Anyway, love a stick rice as well! The atmosphere is cool too!
author: Sean A.

description: I did not know this place was famous. I did a Private Placement offering there with a firm I was at. I remember not eating all day because I didn't want to seem like a pig in front of my date. When he left (sigh of relief) I took my first bite of their shrimp and I almost passed out. I guess it is expensive but make your date or company pay lol. WOW so good.
author: Pink G.

description: Yes, this place is overpriced but hey it's still quite good quality stuff.  You can taste the delicacies of some of the items.  I liked the more exotic dim sum rather than the typical har gow, siu mai.  However, the rice noodle is excellent. The skin is very thin and tastes great. Be careful of the check. For 4 person it can easily totals 100 and you might still leave hungry.
author: Julie L.

description: Five stars for service, three for food, thus the 4 star rating.  The service is absolutely fantastic.  I am so accustomed to being ignored and bullied by wait staff at Chinese restaurants that probably any place where I didn't get spit on would be great, but the service here is really above average.  They clean away your plates quickly, make eye contact and smile and are hyper attentive to your needs.  As for the food, good but not great dim sum and very expensive.  They even charge for the tea.  Atmosphere and location are very nice, plus free parking in the garage.
author: e c.

description: Good dim sum but they need to work on the seating arrangement.  For the price of the food, they should be able to accommodate customers with better seating place, not seating people to close to each other.  Service is normally pretty good.  If you would like certain food, you can ask any of the server that roll the cart and they will call their co-worker to bring the food to your table.  OTHER THAN THE SEATING ARRANGEMENT, we like this place.
author: Pikachu P.

description: I'm really torn between giving them 3 or 4 stars. Hands down this is the best dim sum place I've ever been to. It is also the ONLY dim sum place that my dear Chinese food-hating husband actually enjoyed. The food offerings are familiar, most of your dim sum standbys will be present, but executed at a much higher degree than anywhere else. The peking duck and soup dumplings were the highlights of our meal, but everything we had was outstanding. The problem is the price. $50 a person for lunch. Granted, the five of us put away an impressive amount of food, but it really was just too much money for dim sum. Maybe once I'm not a student I won't have as much of a problem dropping $100 for lunch, but for now, as much as I'd like to, I just can't justify going back.
author: Sarah K.

description:
I love this place! I've eaten at almost ALL dim sum places around the Bay Area! NONE can beat Yank SIng! I remember when I was younger, I didn't really like Yank Sing because it wasn't as rich and fatty like the siu myes at most places, but now I'm in LOVE. I think its because I was so used to the taste of the Chinatown dim sum, and when I tried Yank Sing, it was really weird for me.
   But now, when I eat dim sum else where, I always compare them to yank sing.  I guess because Yank Sing's dim sum is more fresh and healthy because I don't taste as much fat in the dumplings compared to Chinatown dim sum or even Koi Palace dim sum. People bash their small portions, but I like small portions because I get to put it all in my mouth at once to savor all the flavor. When a piece of dim sum is too big, it gets messy. Just like eating sushi rolls. Smaller is better.
 I also love the service here as well. The hostesses are a lot nicer than any hostesses you meet in other Chinese restaurants. Managers actually come by and ask how things go. And my teapot is never empty! I love YANK SING. Too bad, its so expensive. But its situated in the Financial District, what do you expect?
author: Nancy L.

description: I have had a LOT of dim sum in my life and I was ready to hate this place with a passion because it is a well known tourist restaurant. This place turned out to be very good!  It might cost more than other dim sum houses but I think it's worth it.
author: Jay A.

description:
Ok, let me just set this review up.  Since moving to SF, my hubby & I have dined here at least 1x/wk.  No exaggeration!   I'm also comparing the dim-sum quality to top places I've eaten in NY (Joe's Shanghai) Hong Kong, Shanghai, Beijing and Sydney (which has excellent yum cha places)

Excellent items:
Xiolóngbo - Shanghai soup dumplings
Char-su rice noodles
Egg tart - flaky light crust and egg custard filling.
Seafood basil steamed dumpling
Scallop steamed dumpling
Sweet tofu

Yes it is expensive, but it is totally worth it.  Don't worry to waste your time/$ on the shrimp dumplings because 1)  they are not that good and 2) they actually priced at a premium compared to the other dumplings.
author: Julie G.

description: So very overrated.  The dim sum is fine, but not worth the prices nor the long waits.  I do like that it's clean and has a nice atmosphere.  But nothing spectacular.
author: Eric C.

description: Great Dim Sum place!  The selection is good and the food is fresh and well prepared.  Four star because it's too pricey; you are paying for the location and decor, but you can get similar in "hole in the wall" authentic places at half to 2/3 the price.  Still, this is a nice place with good food, and good place for business dim sum.
author: Katherine T.

description: dim sum for those who don't like chicken feet.
author: Annie S.

description:
This is by far my favorite dim sum place in the bay area....and I have been to quite a few. Be prepared though to pay premium prices. I decided to have a Sunday funday there recently, and between two people eating on a hangover plus a bottle of sparkling wine to help ;) it cost us each about $70.  The service for food is extremely quick since they roll by carts with all the food on it, though sometimes it can take a while to get a drink. This is one of the places I take people from out of town if I have the chance. 

My favorite items here, if you only want a sample are the Shanghai Dumplings (dumplings wiith broth that tastes almost like wonton soup in a sac..mmm), the Mandarin Dumplings w/Chives (shrimp chive and cilantro dumpling), and they have the best steamed pork buns.
author: Rachel H.

description: This place is definitely the best place to have brunch if you want dim sum. This restaurant does not have a menu and the food is brought to you in a cart. They usually have special plates each day such as the "say chern" chicken and various Chinese vegetables. My favorite dish is the Shanghai steam dumplings. This place is usually packed with people during lunch hours, but  is definitely worth the wait.
author: jon j.

description:
best chinese food in the bay area, if you get:

xiao long bao
seafood basil dumpling
scallop sui mai
a piece of peking duck
author: Dustin E.

description:
good service and food.
my king was impressed by dim sum as i wanted to wipe out his bad greasy dim sum experience in las vegas.
author: Lady O.

description: I came here with a group of friends not knowing it would be an upscale dim sum restaurant. Most of the items we tried were good but the Peking duck we had wasn't fresh or crispy at all. I'd give that dish a 1 star. The turnip cake was pretty good. It had pieces of shrimp and meat..very tasty! The service was better than most other dim sum restaurants I've been to but i don't think I'd come here again. I'm sure there are other dim sum restaurants just as good at a more reasonable price. This was by far the most expensive dim sum I've ever had. I wasn't even full and when we split the tab.. it came out the be around $40 per person (tip included). If you don't mind paying a lot more for a little more attentiveness then come here. Remember it's downtown and parking is a little tricky.
author: Janice B.

description: I remember when dim sum was cheap eats and it still can be; but just not here. On weekdays its a nice little restaurant, but on weekends they take over 3/4 of the food court outside. They seem to do this without any drop off in food quality too. It's a great place to take the out-of-towners and just a short stroll to the ferry building too.
author: Art S.

description: Food is great along with excellent service, however a bit over price to go to lunch. Food portions are good. Yumy if not on a budget
author: Eric T.

description: I'd give Yank Sing five stars, but it was a little pricey.  However, the food was so tasty!  The fried tofu wrapped in a ribbon (if you will) of seaweed was delicious as well everything else we had.  We went on the recommendation of a friend and the concierge at our hotel.  If we ever make it back to San Francisco, we will defniitely be going back.  Yum, yum, dim sum!
author: Nicole A.

description:
Hands down, the place you need to eat dim sum!  Every bite is a bite of heaven. Yes, its expensive, but it is well worth it. Let me explain why Yank Sing is worth the money to eat here.  Kids, I have eaten at many dim sum restaurants over the years - LA, NY, SF, HK.  The best dim sum is obviously in Hong Kong, but Yank Sing is the closest thing you'll find to true HK dim sum in this area.  Dim sum is the bread and butter of this restaurant.  They do not do dinner here except for wedding banquets.  This restaurant has also been handed down generation to generation. The owner has had to learn how to make and perfect each and every dish.  The cooking was not outsourced to some independent chef. I agree, there are dishes served here during dim sum that are only for dinner, but whatever, they are appealing to the masses, not just the chinese. The quality and taste of the dim sum here is amazing...second to none.  Even the tea served is a higher quality.  Other dim sum restaurants may be very good but this a notch above.  Let me remind you, you get what you pay for.  

1.  Taro root puff is very good - too many other places have made a good puff but is disgusting when it tastes like ammonia - YUCK
2.  XLB (Xiao Long Bao / Little Dragon Dumpling / Pork Dumpling) is the specialty of the house - perfect bite size, texture and thinness of the dumpling is right, soup inside is tasty, pork inside does not taste overcooked or old
3.  Onion cake/doughnut -  a little chic with the peanut sauce, but delicious
4.  Mushroom dumpling - yummy goodness

If you are use to the hole in the wall dim sum place then Yank Sing is not for you. Call me a foodie, but I cannot even fathom paying 1/2 the price for even 3/4 the quality of food served here.  Its like shelling out money to buy an Accord when really you should just go ahead an pay for the Lexus GS .  This is the kind of place that the mainstream middle class families in HK would be eating at.  Good quality, good flavor, good service, and clean.  If you are willing to settle for cheap dim sum then you are totally missing the point... in chinese, dim sum means to touch the heart - not preserve the wallet.  And Yank Sing touches my heart so much that I feel giddy inside.
author: D G.

description: We went to this place for lunch after Bay to Breakers since we were all famished and this is the closest decent place from my friend's house. When we got there, it was packed since bay to breakers and it's Sunday @ 2 p.m. Dimsum was in full effect in this place. The location and ambiance of this restaurant was very nice. It has that elegance and fancy effect like a true upscale restaurant. We had to wait for 15-20 minutes to get seated and I was tempted to just do a to go since it will probably faster and also cheaper. Anyway, we stayed and got seated. We were greeted by someone who asked for what we wanted to drink and the drinks/water arrived quickly (which is a plus for me I've been to tons of dimsum places and they never really give us water that fast). We ordered mostly seafood, fried, steamed, vegetables, pork shumai, and egg custard tarts. We had about 10-15 mini plates different things but the only thing that stood out for me was the crabcakes since it's flavorful and meaty. The rest are the same if not less than in comparison to all the dimsum places I've gone to (that aren't this pricey). For all the order we paid about $145 + tip. I feel like it's quite absurd on how expensive it was considering I usually go to dimsum with 8-10 people and our bill only comes to $200 for 15-20+ mini plates. It was a good experience but I won't go back there again for dimsum since it's too pricey and they don't have a lot of sauce that compliment their fried dumplings--they didn't have that mayo dip for the shrimpballs/crab claws.
author: Precious S.

description: Love this place. The food may seem really, really expensive compared to the ones you could find in Chinatown, but for some reason we have yet to find another dim sum place that can match the quality. My Chinese best friend loves the place and we can run the bill nearly over $100 just between the two of us because the food is really that good. If you can, see if you can nab those BBQ ribs they sometimes have floating around, (it's one of those specials they carry around..not inside a cart) because it's good. Also, their eggtarts are lovely too...they're my favorite :)
author: kate d.

description: A wild fun time.  Excellent dim sum and just a raucous rollicking scene.  Without a reservation we were seated very quickly at a busy lunch time.  And were immediately accosted by servers pushing their wares.  The food was uniformly excellent.  We particularly enjoyed the red slaw with walnuts, the chicken dumplings, and the chinese broccoli.  Desert was nice as well (some kind of egg custard pastry).
author: Ken S.

description: I love Yank Sing, as does my whole family. The great thing is they have so many chicken and vegetarian options, instead of the mostly fish dumplings found at many dim sum restaurants. I love the snow pea leaf dumplings and the chicken and mushroom dumplings. The basil seafood are also great. The mango iced tea and the pistachio ice cream cake are delicious also.
author: Annie H.

description: After reading other yelp reviews, I had high expectations of this place. I expected the dim sum to be worth the expensive price ($30-40 per person); however, I was a bit disappointed. It started out bad when we were told that there was a 45 minute wait for a party of 2. This is pretty ridiculous considering it was 1 pm during the middle of the week, which isn't typically a popular time to eat dim sum. After an hour of waiting, we finally got seated. The wait staff was quick to bring carts around and there was a lot to choose from. Most of the dishes were standard and can be found at any dim sum restaurant. The more unique dishes were more expensive. Overall, the food was good, but it wasn't better than some of the dim sum places in Chinatown that serve these dishes for half the price. Expect decent food and a pleasant atmosphere at Yank Sing, but it seems like this place caters to American business people and tourists over Asians, which isn't usually a good sign in my opinion. Take a walk to Chinatown and experience a more authentic dining experience for a fraction of the price. On the other hand, if you're stretched for time on a lunch break from work or want to see celebrities like Dennis Haysbert (pretty awesome to see him walk in) then this might be your place. And if you decide to go, make sure you order the soup dumplings (xiao long bao)
author: Chenwu L.

description: dont live up to its hype.... i dunno why everyones saying its the best dimsum...? the place is pretty clean..and OH YEAH over priced!.. not to mention the service was pretty bad...
author: Lisa C.

description: The price is not great, but wow the Dim Sum.  Out of all the dim sum places I have been this was THE best.  Very busy, so the food is all very fresh.  They had plenty of carts out and there a lot of choices.  The Shanghai dumpling is very good.  None of the dim sum was oily or any other bad quality to it.  It all looked fantastic.  My mom really enjoyed it.  When she is out here again we will go eat here again.  It is a good idea to get there early .  It gets a pretty big line.  I like it when they are sitting outside too.  The waterfall is nice...
author: Leaf B.

description: Great Great dim sum! Although I paid much more than I expected,but it's worth (for most of the items). maybe I won't go there again simply because I'm a poor gal,but this place is memoriable, yummy and clean.
author: zoe w.

description: Honestly, I have no clue what at least the stuff I ate was, but there was nothing I didn't like.  Perhaps this can be credited to the people I was with, lucky for me they knew a thing or two about dim sum and took care of ordering.  I won't claim to be a dim sum expert by any means, but the fact that I didn't feel yucky afterwards was a first for me in my dim sum eating history.  The chicken lettuce cups were fantastic, all of the little dumplings and pockets were great with some spicy chili sauce, and who knew I liked turnips so much??  The service was pretty good, but they forgot our dessert order.  As far as the atmosphere, it felt pretty hectic during the lunch rush, but we were sitting towards the front.  If you have more than a few people (at least for lunch) make reservations.  I'll definitely be back, but probably for dinner.
author: kristal p.

description: Nothings beats the dim sum at Yank Sing.  The signature Shanghai dumplings are filled with the most wonderful ginger-infused pork.  Might I kindly warn everyone about the hot broth inside the dumpling.  The seating inside the Rincon center is a bit odd, but inside it is lively with the carts whizzing around the room.  A reservation might be helpful if you would rather not wait.  I'm certainly will be back again.
author: Becky G.

description: I'm no Asian food expert, but I know how to handle my chop sticks.  The dim sum was eclectic, delicious, and reasonably priced.  The 10-minute wait was fine (we luckily caught the tail end of the lunch rush), and the bustling atmosphere was a bit distracting but acceptable.
author: steven k.

description: what a way to spend Christmas--but the lines are out the door--the best dim sum, ever, but best not to go on Christmas.....go for the Shanghai dumplings, but it's all great.
author: Vicki L.

description: i'm not sure how anyone can give this less than 4 starts...for that it deserves 5 from me to compensate.   everything is right about the food.  maybe a little pricey, but go work harder and you won't mind the cost...
author: Jason S.

description: I'm torn about this place.  Would give it 3.5 stars, 5 for food, 2 for being mugged.  Overall, food was excellent, fresh, not greasy.  But, the cost was outrageous.  Four adults and 6 year old girl, two beers, Sunday dim sum = $195 with tip, and I paid it.  My guess was that it was going to be about $50 less than that.  We did not order exotic items and we did not stuff our faces.  We had basic far: Ha Gau, Pork Buns, Chinese Broccoli, Taro Root, Su Mai, etc.  The special things were a little duck, shrimp and green onion wrapped in bacon - very tasty, and a shredded cabbage salad with walnuts.  The latter was my favorite dish - it was new to me and so fresh and tasty.  No complaints about the food, at all, but I can't be spending this kind of money on dim sum.  I'd rather go one of the many other solid places in the Bay Area that charge half or even less.  The atmosphere was cool for kiddies with the water fountain, but a little weird and mall-like.
author: Joe P.

description: Bustling dim sum place.  Many types of delicious dim sum to choose from.
author: John c.

description:
Having lived in Canada, I've been spoiled by the abundance of good and cheap dim sum... and besides, I worked in a dim sum restaurant between HS and university, so, I do know my stuff. After moving to the Bay Area from Singapore, I went on a crazy hunt for the best "xiao loong baos" (shanghainese dumplings) here and I was deeply disappointed until I had them at Yank Sing. Call me a "xiao loong bao" connoisseur, where I would actually debate with my friend, Eric long distance on whether the ones from Crystal Jade's were better than Din Tai Fung's, and of course, he would always pull his, "I've lived in Shanghai, so I know better.. and I was from Hong Kong" rationale. They are still not as good as Crystal Jade or Din Tai Fung in Singapore, but it was a close second.

Anyhow, Yank Sing is high on my list for dim sum in SF. The ones in Ctown are basically crap. "Dim sum" translated to English (not literal) means "precious delicacies" (the literal translation would mean "touch heart" -- eh?) and Yank Sing's dim sum embodies that. They are done with the right touch of flavor and aint soaked in grease like some of the other places.

The proper way of having dim sum (or yum cha that translates to "drink tea") in Hong Kong (or even across ctowns in Canada) is where you sit for hours, have a sip of tea, a few morsels, chat with your friends and read the papers. So, it's great that at Yank Sing, you dont have to yell over your food to have a decent conversation and the wait staff are always courteous and efficient.

Dining there isnt cheap, and some of my friends do not believe in paying that kind of price for chinese food. However, I'm a firm believer of paying for value, and I don't mind paying $25-$30/person for good dim sum. When I brought my parents who were visiting, they, of course had a sticker shock and kept comparing the prices to those in Canada, and the size of the dumplings, which were smaller than what they would get in Canada. Oh well, go figure why Canadians are like the size of their dumplings there!
author: Evelyn L.

description:
Three stars because the food was really tasty but the service was meh and the prices were meh. It's expensive, plain and simple. $65 dollars for two people. 

Another down side, if the servers brought a cart to our table and we politely said no thank you to whatever they were serving, it was like they would get pissed that you said no to their cart and would scamper off. excuse me? i cannot eat it all, thank you. 

For dessert we got this sesame covered ball and we couldn't understandn what two waiters said was in it so we tried one or two and left the rest sitting there. it's weird to not know what you are eating!

Otherwise, really really great food!
author: Quincy J.

description:
This is by far the best Dim Sum I have had here in San Francisco and I have tried many different places.

The presentation is excellent. The food is fresh and hot every time.
My favorite is the duck and walnut & cabbage salad.

I would give them  5 stars however the prices are steep allowing for a 4 star rating.

The last time I ate there the restaurant was evacuated due to a false fire alarm. The staff told us it happens all the time...
author: Ziggy P.

description: I could eat dim sum ("deem sum") everyday, all day.  So this review might be a bit skewed.  There's just something so rewarding about pointing at dumplings and such as it's toted around on carts.  Pork buns and Potstickers ("Wor Tee") and Peking Duck!  Oh my!  The service CAN be slow but if carts are flyin' by and you're not seeing your faves feel free to alert one of the waitresses and she'll radio HQ on her walkie talkie and it'll be right out!  I guess my one gripe would be the amount of time it takes to get seated sometimes.  But don't be silly, it's well worth it!!  Hao yun (good luck)!!!
author: Johnny P.

description:
I had to agree with one of the reviewer that if I can give it a no star I would do so. First my disclaimer, I am a Cantonese so I may be critical at what's considered as good dim sum. 

This is my first time there since there are friends coming out of town and want to have dim sum in SF. It seems appropriate to bring the out-of-towner to the "The Bay Area's Most Popular" Restaurants according to Zagat 2008. It may be the most popular but it definitely not worth the drive from South Bay and the $$$. We paid $30 per person which echo one of the reviewer that is the avg price. The thing is that we still come out hungry. I am so furious and vow never to go back. 

There are several awards mentioned in there website. I am not sure those people knows what dim sum is...hmm...now when I think about it they just said it is popular. Never mentioning it is good dim sum.

The food there is mediocre at best. I had much better dim sum in S.Bay (ABC, May Flower or HK Villa).  If you want closer to the city, there is East Ocean across the bridge in Emeryville or Koi Palace in Daly City. The steam BBQ bun there is not even authentic. The bun is not even made with the right flour and is not moist but wet like soaked in water. It does not crack on the top and does not taste like the traditional steam BBQ bun. 

The one thing I may say good about is probably the decor and the water fountain for kids. The service is probably better than average relative to other dim sum places.

However, I would steer clear of it if you want authentic dim sum at a reasonable price. I would give it a 3 stars if I paid $10 per person and come out full.
author: Denny Y.

description: I don't usually go for dim sum but this was good.  I had been there once before with my father when I was a child and this time with my brother.  I have no clue exactly what we at but the things that I called "Broth Balls", which were like a dumpling with the broth inside, were very tasty.  The spring rolls and Pot stickers were very good.  Service is...Odd and it is very crowded but good food.
author: Amy P.

description: best Dim Sum I've had in the city.  But it does seem fairly "authentic" and may not appeal to those with truly Americanized taste buds.
author: Rex S.

description: If you're looking for authentic dim sum, this is not the place. Chicken skewers and grilled fish for $20 bucks was among the items wheeled around. The food was really good. Both my hubby and son liked it. But the prices really turned us off. Too expensive for breakfast. The bill was over $110 for two adults and a 4 yr old.
author: Trina K.

description: What can I say that i surmise has not been already said... This place is a gem, in a seemingly abandoned gaudy mall no less.  The shanghai dumpling the shanghai dumpling, if you get nothing else.  It is like a giant savory gusher.  It is served on a spoon with a little ginger and vinegar and when you slide it into your mouth and bite it bursts with all of its searingly hot soup and pork glory.  One of the most magical and surprising bites of food I've had.  The fried items can be a bit hit or miss for me but there is plenty offered here.  Some might argue that it is not as authentic as what you can find in Chinatown.  But I rebuke saying that I have tasted my fare share of authentic and this is the most diverse and clean flavored dumplings of anywhere I have found, Los Angeles included.  The Honey walnut cabbage salad is another mistakenly ordered delight, a cool crisp counterpoint to the doughyness of dumpling after dumpling.  The miso glazed sea bass is the most expensive item on the 'deem sum' menu but something not to be missed.  The jasmine tea a great addition to the meal and they sell it for just 5 dollars a bag a great memento to take with you.  I will be back soon and in turn tell everyone I know :)
author: Max S.

description:
Food - excellent
Service - average 

Good dim sum, however, a little pricey.
author: Phi N.

description: It doesn't get much better than this for Dim Sum. This place is a recent James Beard Foundation award recipient, which is kind of a big deal. My first experience with Yank Sing was a luncheon here while attending a business training course at one of the suites located at Rincon Center last year. Being 1/2 Chinese and eating my fair share of the stuff, I was impressed. I made reservations for lunch on Chinese New Year this year with the gf while celebrating our anniversary, and not only was the food as good as I remembered, the service was outstanding considering there was easily over 400 ppl there. Unfortunately there was one other thing that was outstanding, and that was the bill. Since the first time I ate there, my instructor picked up the tab (for our table of 6) and I had no idea how much anything cost. As some of the other Yelpers here have pointed out, Yank Sing is quite expensive and our bill between the both of us was about $100. Still, we really enjoyed our meal and were treated first class. I definitely won't be making the trip up from SJ regularly, but I will return at some point for those delicious soup dumplings.
author: Trevor P.

description: The food here is ordinary, not bad and nothing special. But.....the prices are OUTRAGEOUS!  Don't get me wrong, I love to splurge on a good meal but this was definitely not worth it.  The plates average about $10 a pop....yes, even the sesame balls (4 pieces).  I will try a place in China town next time.
author: G A.

description: My favorite dim sum place in the bay area! Their selection is limited but the items they offer are very very good.  I tend to judge dim sum places on how well they do the old favorites.  They do not disappoint with their lotus wrapped sticky rice, shanghi xiao lung bao, and shieu mai.   Their har gao (shrimp dumpling) in particular has a generous filling and thin translucent skin that has the correct texture, which I cannot find in the bay area.  For something sweet, the sesame balls are very good and their egg tarts are excellent!  Their tea selections are high quality with delicate and clean flavor.  Most complaints I've heard of stem from the expense and the feeling that they are not authentic (catering to more American tastes). But if it's good, who cares? Does a dim sum place have to be rude and dirty to be authentic?!  A quick tip to ease the expense: the items walked around  (ie red cabbage salad, honey walnut prawn, honey glazed sea bass) tend to be the most expensive items.  The items in the bamboo containers tend to be less expensive.
author: Will W.

description: Fun gourmet dim sum restaurant. Food is always good but the service can be slow. baked bbq pork roll , peking duck and the dumplings are fantastic. my mouth is watering thinking about the food we had
author: ryan s.

description: Saying that we spend about $30.pp, we never look at a menu or ask the price. I know it could be alot lower. We just order what ever looks and sounds good. That averages out to $30. I hate to see people down grade this restaurant due to price. The quality of the food is so good that it is worth it. You can see the prices if that is important and order accordingly. Also, expensive compared to what?Looking at various menus for other types of food, it is very easy to spend and equal amount and then dislike the meal. Like I said we have been coming for years and will continue to do so and recommend it to others.
author: Kathy L.

description: A lot of selections. All are very good and fresh. Environment is clean. Service is good and patient. The price is about twice that of other similar food level chinese dim sum restaurant in Chinatown.
author: Veronica D.

description: This is the best dim sum place that I have found in SF so far. Quality is superb and the dim sum is not greasy. Rincon center validates parking for up to 3 hours if you eat here. I've only ate here twice and both times was a pleasure. It's a bit on the pricey side and I have only dined here when I had visitors in town. My visitors loved it!
author: K P.

description: over price dim sum.not bad though.these kinda places are mostly for the white ghost
author: Avery H.

description: My husband and I went to Yank Sing late-morning on a Sunday.  We waited only about ten minutes before being seated in the indoor courtyard.  I don't have much to add that has not already been said in other positive reviews.  The carts came quickly and with more than enough choices to keep us happy, the jasmine tea was good (and we liked the large glass teapots), our water and tea was refreshed quickly when needed, the two items we ordered from the menu arrived quickly, the 'cart servers' were friendly and explained the food items quite adequately.  Yes, our bill for two people was $86.00, but we knew beforehand that Yank Sing was not cheap, and we tried a good number of items (including sea bass and walnut prawns, which were more expensive choices).  We enjoyed our meal at Yank Sing very much, no complaints at all.  So for MoRe than enough great food, good variety, fresh tea and prompt friendly service, I don't find $43.00 per person to be at all unreasonable.  We will return on our next visit to San Francisco.
author: Pamela S.

description: We ate lunch here on vacation this summer, and didn't know what to expect when we walked in.  We were given a table and a menu, but didn't really need the menu because waitresses walk around to show you the dishes they have and ask if you want any.  If you want one, they mark your ticket.  I would have appreciated more visible prices, but we figured some of it out from the menu, and the bill seemed fair at the end, because we all thought the food was delicious and we were stuffed!  It was a little on the pricey side, but as tourists in San Francisco we had a hard time finding spots that weren't.  There were plenty of fried foods, and some not fried, but none of it seemed greasy or made us feel gross.  I don't eat fried food too often, but I hope to visit this place again next time we can make it to San Francisco!  The dumplings were fantastic, and there was a fried tofu that was delicious!
author: Michelle M.

description: excellent dim sum. the sesame balls could be better but overall, pretty solid.
author: Banjot C.

description: I haven't visited Yank Sing for perhaps ten years or so, since I now live in Southern California. I remembered it as generally being the best all around dim sum available although always expensive. Still, you get what you pay for, no? On this trip, there were six of us for lunch and I was the host. Since it was MLK day, and since we were on the late side for dim sum, we were seated without a wait and the prompt cart service immediately started. As I remembered, the food was very, very good, not perfect (some of the dishes weren't very warm, and the skin of the Peking duck wasn't crisp) but still, lovely and inventive dishes, many of them unique to Yank Sing, perhaps even the lovely Jasmin tea, and overall, quite the exceptional dining experience that I had hoped for. Then I got the check! It's my fault for not looking at the prices first, but come on! $30+ a head for Dim Sum! I really like the restaurant, but this isn't Paris, and these prices are unjustifiable in today's economy. Very sadly, I won't be back.
author: Howard C.

description: I went to Yank Sing 2 go and was dissapointed for the weekly specials they had (Black Pepper Beef).  No side salad included (Shredded carrots and vegetable).  Too many celery and few beef.  Love the pot sticker though....."too pricey for 2 go item".
author: ILuvZumba T.

description: ok- the food is good, and the service is great, the carts come by constantly and they explain the food beautifully. And, I love the shanghai soup dumplings. But the place is totally, totally over priced, over crowded, and the center courtyard, where we sat, has negative ambiance. Our bill was ridiculous for the food we got.
author: s b.

description: Food is good, though not spectacular, but moreover WAY too expensive for dim sum. $112 (after tip) for 4 people. I'm a sad panda.
author: Sha Sha C.

description: My first experience with Dim Sum and I have to say I went away quite satisfied.  The hubby and I traveled to the city on BART, got off at Embarcadero and took a nice stroll to this restaurant in Rincon Center.  Boy were we glad we got reservations as the inside dinning room and atrium (for lack of a better word to describe it) space were packed with hungry people eating and hungrier people waiting to be seated.  I was a little worried about time even with our reservation since we were seeing Wicked after lunch but we got in right at our reservation time (how do they do that?) and before I could even take off my coat and put my purse on my chair a server with a cart was asking if I wanted shrimp dumplings.  We were ambushed by servers with carts and could only  manage to say no to a few things.  We had shrimp dumplings, eggrolls, potstickers, to name a few and their signature Shanghai dumplings that were recommended by a friend.  Litttle dumplings filled with a broth and topped with vinegar and ginger.  Really good!  It can be confusing and hard to say no but definitely be choosy and be aware that some of the more entree type dishes will be quite more expensive (take a look at that skinny menu they give you, the other side has drinks).  We were stuffed and happy about 30+ minutes after being seated.  The bill was a bit pricey but I can't complain about the service or dishes so I would say it was worth it.  Just make those reservations and you will enjoy the experience!
author: Laura T.

description: Bring snooty New York acquaintances here to impress them, but also bring your good friends, because the food is nothing short of amazing.  The chicken and mushroom dumplings are some of my favorite food of all time, and the egg-y custard tarts are the stuff of cholesterol-filled dreams. If you get hot-and-sour soup, share it, because the portion is just too large for one normal human if you still want to be able to try the steamed pork buns, chicken-stuffed mushrooms, siu mye, delicately spiced cold snap peas and irresistible sesame balls. While you are waiting for your table (which you inevitably will if you arrive after 11 am) check out the WPA murals of San Francisco's history in the lobby of the (attached) historic post office, and also the display of 1906 earthquake photographs and "artifacts" (read: bits and bobs of melted stuff).  Oh, reservations are a must on the weekends -- and you'll wait anyway. My only quibble is with the location itself, which, with the exception of the old post-office, is quite high-tech and weird, with various impersonal, unpleasant, or at least really unusual architechtural features, including a four-story waterfall falling from the ceiling indoors -- I understand that people actually live there, which I just don't get.
author: Jude F.

description: Yang Sing! Best Dim Sum in SF, a little over priced compared to other dim sum places but the quality and service is exceptional! I could use a pork bun right now!
author: Mishi S.

description: Dim Sum here is great.  It can get expensive incredibly quickly though as carts and carts pass by with you finding yourself hard to resist asking for a plate of everything.  Come with lots of people so you get to experience all the wonderful dishes that they have to offer here.  I can't recommend this place enough.
author: Jake J.

description: It may be expensive, but it is also the best dim sum I have ever had. A hearty lunch portion will cost you at least $20 a person. I highly recommend reservations as both locations can be packed 7 days a week. Service is quick once seated. Be sure to go with several people so that you can try many different things. The seafood in their dumplings is always fresh, which makes all the difference. I recommend this place to everyone I know looking for a good dim sum place.
author: heather v.

description: not sure what the hype is about, sure the dim sum atmosphere is fun and food is okay, but not as great as people may think it is...i'm asian and have eaten at many dim sum places in sf, ca, and other countries..brought parents and grandmother to try this place and some items were very salty and some were cold...i'm not a picky eater as us asians don't waste any part of the animal..i can deal w/ the behavior and personality of servers- used to it, but surprised food isn't as impressive as it's cracked up to be.
author: Beignet W.

description: Extremely over priced although the service is pretty good.  The food is catered more towards Americans than the real authentic Hong Kong dim sum.
author: Mary L.

description:
And this is why i love yank sing. They make all the normal stuff but they make it special. The chaung feung shrimp rice noodle. With tender non sticky noodles, large pieces of shrimp and the chives inside. The little crunchy veggie added a zest of life into the roll
The soup dumplings were good and unique as always. They didnt break as u picked them up and were very yummy, since there is soup inside they are piping hot when u eat them.
The tea, while 2 dollars a person is actual tea and served in a pretty pot
Then take the shrimp roll cake, which they added crab too. The two flavors worked very well together but still had seperate flavor to them. Fried to perfection and a great clash between the traditional dim sum and a crab cake
The char sui bao, which i might have ordered the wrong one had a good amount of filling and the filling was very yummy. You got a good contrast of flavors twin the two.
The schezuan chicken in appetizer size looked amazing. 6 dollars. So a bit expensive but would have been perfect if there had been two of me. Lots of chiles, lots of sauce but just enough to coat the meat and leave none on the plate
The peking duck. Served in a single serving hit the spot, small and yummy. The sauce was incredibly light which some might find ideal but i love the strong and heavy sauce they make for it. Right amount of fixins and served with a puffy bun instead of a pancake but still very tasty.
They didnt have the sugarcane shrimp which was disappointing. But i am stuffed already
Dude they do half orders of stuff thats awesome. It isnt for everything but most of the fried things. 
Wow the shrimp toast was perfect. The shrimp itself was a little stiff and compact but the toast was very porous and easy to bite through, so awesomely yummy
author: H B.

description: I'm all about paying for a good meal, but this is ridiculous.  My husband and I went to a fabulous dinner at Le Colonial, 500% better than my dim sum lunch here for the same price and we had a bottle of wine, 2 entrees and an appetizer at Le Colonial.  The dim sum was good until we got the bill of $75 for a freaking LUNCH with tea!  At that point our whole day was ruined b/c we just ate ourselves into debit.  The night before at Le Colonial was supposed to be our "nice" meal, we didn't plan on spending over $50 for a meal for the rest of our trip, so you can imagine our disbelief at our bill.  What bothers us most is our mistake of going there.  We had lunch the day before at The Stinking Rose and loved it, so we thought about going again for lunch.  Stupid us for deciding to go to Yank Sing instead to try something different.  Our rational was that the Stinking Rose was a little pricey and that there was no way that Chinese food could be that much.  Well we were tragically wrong.  I will never ever ever go to Yank Sing again nor will I recommend anyone to go either.  With Chinatown so close, why would you.  I'd say that we learned our lesson.
author: Krista L.

description: I give this place 3.5 stars.  I definitely had reservations about coming here because this is definitely yuppified dim sum.  However the place is clean and the service is pretty good for a Chinese restaurant.  As for the food they offer the standards which are done pretty well.  The xiao long bao are the best I've had in the Bay Area and if there are better please let me know because this place is damn expensive.  Back to the dumplings, there was jsut the right amount of broth and the skin was thin but sturdy.  The vinegar was also just right.  This is a definitely an item you must order.  We had about 50 of them.  The most off the beaten path item I saw were the chicken feet which to me are a dim sum staple.  You won't find tripe, duck tongue or beef brisket.  This is were they lose stars.  I don't mind the prices so much becuase like I said it's clean and service is decent.  Full bar too.  Don't sit outside.  You are better off waiting for a table inside since the kitchen is inside.
author: goldberg d.

description: SO delicious!  Everything was really, really tasty, if expensive.  But it's worth the money, because it is super fresh and the dumplings and wrappers are perfect, not gluey or anything.  I went at a Sunday lunch and so I was patient, because they were really packed. The only things that lowers the rating are that I was once given a dish that had been out too long and was cold -- but after I ate one of the mushroom caps stuffed with chicken they came back and gave me an extra hot plate of them -- and that they don't make you aware of the prices up front. I would have chosen differently if I had known how much some of the dishes cost (one special, a shrimp and walnut salad, cost over $10. yikes!).  But I would definitely come here again.... especially if i was someone else's treat!
author: Tina S.

description: it's true: when the bill came my eyes popped out of my head. $100 for 3 of us? i was expecting something like $50-$60. it was good and all, but i'll think twice before returning. ton kiang is better i think, but i suspect they use MSG since i always leave feeling like i'm the verge of a panic attack. the service was very good and the setting is nice, but YOWZA. i'll stick with good luck dim sum in the meantime, which costs about $8 to feed 2.
author: Mary V.

description: Mediocre cafeteria quality food for those who are scared of the real thing.
author: Anonymous M.

description: the atmosphere is great, it's clean, and very popular, but it is overrated and expensive.  they were trying to be innovative with some of their dishes like the pea sprout dumplings, but i'm not a fan.  i will stick to the traditional favorites elsewhere.
author: Big e.

description: The price at Yang Sing is ridiculous, however I still give it a 2-star as its Northern dumplings are quite decent, although the Southern dimsum dishes are really lackluster.  But for that price, I would take a cab ride to Koi Palace and still would be ahead!
author: Name L.

description: would've given them 5 satrs, but it just seems a little too pricey for some dim sum. other than that definitely great food and you can really tell they take the time and effort to dishing out the good dim sum. the favoritle has to be the shanghai dumplings with it's wonderful filling and soup inside. their egg custards are super good and normally i don't like these thing cuz they're too eggy, but they seem to do wonders with these things. also they have a great atmosphere, and would recommend sitting in the atrium section where it's more open and you can enjoy the indoor waterfall.
author: Chris O.

description: dimsum is yumyum!  yes, expensive but you get what you pay for in food, service and cleanliness.  plus, it would probably average out the gas i'd guzzle on the way to millbrae's fook yuen.
author: Kimby T.

description: I've only been to a few of San Francisco's many dim-sum restaurants, but  I can safely say that I would choose any of them, or even a swift kick to the face, over the dim sum I have had in, say, downtown Oakland.  For a chinese restaurant, this place is fairly elegant and upscale, being located in the modern Rincon Center and extending out into its fancy shmancy atrium lobby, surrounded by fountains, marble floors, planter boxes under a very high glass ceiling.  As far as the food, it is of excellent quality and a wide variety of different items is offered, including the usual seafood dumplings, but some unusually scrumptuous flaky curry chicken pastries and baked pork buns, to a few items that, to my eyes anyhow, appear at least inedible and at worst like something from Sinclair's poultry rendering plant.  But I won't fault this restaurant for that because its all part of the culture of chinese food.  Fun for Sunday brunch, it is quite pricey though.
author: Rick H.

description: great dim sum (probably the best ive had), but overly priced! i think i spent double for the same amount of food i would normally order. but i absolutely LOVED the fact that they serve peking duck with steamed buns for dim sum.. sealed the deal for me. oh, and all the waiters speak fluent english.. that was quite a surprise.
author: Nancy L.

description: dim sum here is seriously....HELLA GOOD!  i recently came here with my girl jenn and just scarfed down everything in sight!  one dish that really just did a dance in my mouth was the yank sing special dumpling.  they don't have it on the cart, so you need to ask for it.  don't miss out on this dish that makes your tastebuds go happy happy.  the only drawback is that it's rather expensive for dim sum, but in my opinion well worth it. great food and a classy enviroment....cheers!
author: joseph p.

description: Great service - the waiters and dim sum cart ladies speak English and aren't rude (or roll their eyes at you) when you turn down what they have in their cart.  In fact, even if you say no they say thank you before walking to the next table!  Far more superior service from what I'm use to from dim sum restaurants.  I really enjoyed my lunch here, but they are super pricey.  Their dishes average about 3x more expensive.  Quality of food is good but some dishes I've tasted the same or better elsewhere such as the pork and shrimp dumplings and definitely the shanghai dumplings.  The one dish that I was really impressed with was the shrimp rolls - whole shrimps rolled in shrimp paste....4 or 5 to an order.  While I enjoyed eating here, I don't think I'd come back because I know I can get the same food elsewhere without emptying my wallet.  $70+ for 2 ppl for lunch...
author: Amy T.

description: Coming from the east coast I was quite impressed. A little expensive for dim sum but it's great! I love me some good dim sum...eheheh
author: Kate K.

description: My first time at Yank Sing was about 10 years ago.  I had just moved to the Bay Area.  I wasn't impressed then.  Mainly it was because this place seem to strive hard for that high-end look.... plastic steamer, designer tea sets.  I've been back to eat here once or twice since then.  One time I was too sick to appreciate what I was eating.  Another time I purchased to go.  A couple of weeks ago I came back to give it another try.  This time I sat with 11 other people.  They had gone back to the bamboo steamers apparently.  The tea sets still the designer ones.  But the food WAS EXCELLENT.  I especially loved the STEAMED CHICKEN DUMPLINGS.  It was so flavorful.  It looked like chicken instead of gray cardboard colored glob, tasted chickeny, and few sprigs of herbs.  I wanted more but they ran out.  I also loved the XIAO LONG BAOS.  Here is coming from a not red meat eater, folks.  I am generally a healthy food eater.  I do make rare exceptions.  Why?  Simply because I love food.  This xiao long baos was so juicy and the skin thickness was just right and the pork inside didn't seem to have that "pork smell" I dreaded.
author: A T.

description: I've been coming here since I was a kid (the old location back on Battery St.). I absolutely love, love, love their dim sum. It has gotten a little bit kitschy in more recent years (they have received tons of press). Now getting a table on a Sunday for dim sum, is kind of a nightmare, with tons of tourists, but It is certainly worth the wait. My favorites are the: Phoenix Shrimp (deep fried giant piece of shrimp perfection, must be dipped in the sweet & sour sauce), Steamed Pork buns (filled with shredded pork goodness), the Ha Gau (best shrimp dumpling you'll ever eat, has a nice crunch inside from the bamboo shoot tips, and their potstickers fill the fried void but aren't the best I've had. I love their scallop dishes too, they are a bit pricey. Be forewarned anything that they walk around with that isn't on the carts is at least $10 & up. Those definitely add up after awhile, and you leave the place questioning your $100 bill for lunch for 2. You also leave this place hungry after a few hours, which is kind of a bummer. Also you must try their mango pudding, my sister & I always fight over it and can never share it. If you're in a hurry I recommend the take out/to go area which is great if you just want a snack or are on your lunch break.
author: Kristy H.

description: The quality of the dim sum is good, but very pricey.  I sometimes find the servers too "rehearsed" to sell from the carts; like listening to used care salespeople.  However, for an upscale experience when money is not an issue, I would recommend this restaurant.
author: Mark L.

description: It's far better than some of the truly greasy crap you can get.  I've had their catered food too and truly always spot on.
author: Misti L.

description: I'm visiting from Oregon and found this place online. I'm from Hong Kong and I crave dim sum all the time.  This is a well run place with great service BUT it comes with a price and a hefty one at that!  I have never had a more expensive dim sum lunch until now. I don't know what people are raving about. The food, though fresh, is just above average. The Shanghai dumplings were just OK, I have certainly had much better.  I had a Lotus wrapped Chicken, a bean curd wrap, a chive dumplig and a Shanghai dumplings; my friend had a bowl of congee and the bill was $39.  REALLY!  I could have a lobster lunch for much less. San Francisco must be full of rich people or there is no better dim sum place in town 'cause this place is packed with a waiting list.  Make sure you look at the prices before you order anything because I did not. There is nothing worse than leaving a restaurant feeling ripped off and that's exactly how I felt.
author: Michael P.

description:
definitely among the best 'fancy dim sum experiences' in san francisco.  what i mean is, if you want to sit and pick expensive delicious food off of trays as they are pushed past you on carts, then this is one of the better places to go.  unfortunately, you really do pay for the experience- so don't come too hungry, or at least be aware of how quickly your bill is adding up....
