the food is good though, and the experience is unique. 

i really like pork buns and shrimp dumplings like as a quick breakfast or midday snack instead of fast food options or other alternatives.  at these times, i steer clear of yank sing and head to the inexpensive dim sum shops in the rickmond, the sunset and chinatown where the food is as good or better at a fraction of the cost.  the trade offs are you usually stand in line at a counter and order what you want to go (in my mind, these are positive trade offs overall).
author: Jay J.

description: Would be a 5-star review if it wasn't so expensive to eat here.  The food tastes great, but so pricey!  Hard to justify when there are many decent dim sum places just minutes away in Chinatown or down in Clement.  It's just really hard to justify an average of $30-$40/person bill for a dim sum!!!
author: Maria D.

description: The service is impeccable. All the staff members speak excellent English. You do not need to chase down a cart to get the freshest dim sum. The carts go around pretty fast, and if you tell them what you want, the cart with your desired items will come to you pretty quickly.  This isn't the Saturday/Sunday morning family dim sum experience where people are rude, everyone is screaming in Chinese, and people run around with their tickets to get what they want.  The food is very delicious!!! -- 5 starts. Minus one star for the price.  Dim sum isn't supposed to be fancy food, but it is here.  Minus another star for the fact that this isn't the most authentic dim sum experience. It's a good place to take your business clients or dim sum virgin in-laws you want to impress.  I take my team members, who had their first dim sum experience at Yank Sing with me, for lunch from time to time. They really like it.  I enjoy coming here for a work-week lunch, but for the real weekend dim sum experience, I'm staying far away from fi-di.
author: Su K.

description: really good super quick dim sum. you have to be a pretty decisive person to eat here as servers are fast and ready to serve you nearly everything on their cart. the dumplings are juicy and delicious.
author: Liz R.

description: Great place to experience once in your lifetime.  Barbecue pork bun is good.  Loved the cabbage walnut salad...dressing was light and not too vinegary.  Peking duck is good, but 1 small piece cost over $5. Shu mai is not as greasy as other places.  Everything wonderfully prepared.  Caucasians can order for themselves.  Service is great.  But just be prepared to pay.  And I would've preferred to sit in the courtyard for the beautiful waterfall at Rincon Center.  It is beautiful.  So don't go as early as I did at 10:30AM on Sunday, because they weren't seating in the courtyard yet.
author: J J.

description: love the dim sums at Yank Sing! the servers roll around different carts full of various dim sums, fried goodness, veggies, peking duck, lettuce wraps, soups... i like that you can just start eating right when you get seated (i'm impatient). :) my fav are shanghai dumplings (i'm drooling just thinking about it), the lettuce wraps and peking duck. it can get crowded during weekends so i recommend making a reservation... and i'm knocking off one star because they need a better system for cart rotations... sometimes the stuff i have to wait a long time for the stuff that i want (and even start waving my arms to flag it down) but the stuff that i don't want circle around my table a gazillion times.... but other than that, this is  great place for a nice weekend dim sum brunch. :)
author: Lucy C.

description:
good dim sum, but just not worth the price.

compared to KOI PALACE, the dim sum here is about similar quality i would say.  but things run 2-3x more expensive here, compared to koi palace.  also the service and ambiance are not quite what i expected.  sure they give you tea in fancy glass pot, the staff are friendlier than most other dim sum places, and the bathroom is very clean.  but otherwise it's a pretty ordinary place in terms of service and ambiance, compared to some places i've been to in hong kong.

for the two of us, the total was a whopping $75 plus tax.  we ordered one each of har gau, chicken mushroom dumpling, xia long bao, cabbage salad, mandarin shrimp dumpling, shrimp w/ walnuts, phoenix shrimp and shrimp mousse toast.  everything was good, except for the latter two.

also, i personally prefer ordering off the menu to carts.  here you order off the carts, whereas at koi palace it's off the menu.  i feel that i can plan better and also enjoy my meal more (rather than looking around for the next cart all the time) by ordering off the menu.  sometimes food also tends to be fresher off the menu, but that's not so much of an issue here... carts come around very often and all our food tasted fresh.
author: Greg H.

description: I must first start out by saying that I am Chinese and consider myself a food connoisseur. I love food!!!. I saw this place on the travel channel and thought I just have to go there. After going, I must say I am very disappointed. I rated this restaurant poorly not because the food was horrible, but because for what I paid, I did not get the quality of dim sum that I was charged for. For 2 people, I paid $80! Dim sum is not supposed to be expensive. The har gow, sui mai, and chicken feet were good. The shrimp rice noodle was NOT good. Had an odd flavor. I think for people who do not know dim sum very well, they will think this restaurant is very good, but it is not. There is a reason it is not in Chinatown, because if it was, it would never make it. My recommendation: Don't waste your money. Go somewhere else, pay half the price, and be completely satisfied. PS Fried rice was $20!!! That should have been my first hint to leave.
author: Kelly P.

description: Everytime I've been here I am absolutely floored, and I some how manage to eat $60+ worth of dim sum, on my own. Definitely wear your elstic waistband skirt if you go here, and try not to go when you're starving because you'll just keep pointing at everything that walks by. hmmm maybe thats why they make you wait so long to get seated? I dont know.. Ive either gotten sat right away or waited 45 minutes, but the food is so good that my annoyance usually melts right away, especially since you can eat as you're sitting down into your chair while 3 dim sum tray holders hover around you. It's great :) my fav is the goldfish shaped shrimp dumplings (you have to order seperately). they dont taste any diff from their other shrimp dumplings, but theyare so cute!!! yes.. im a sucker for my food looking like animals (ie caterpillar rolls). also their chicken buns and chicken and mushroom dumplings are my fav.. i can go on and on. It's not your rustic china town dim sum, but it's definitely good. I could eat here everyday :-D   oh one thing is that they tend to not have certain dishes some days, so if theres a particular dish you crave, you might need to ask them for it. i went this past sunday and they had all kinds of stuff I've never seen them bring out before!! didnt know how to handle the change!! it was still REALLY good though!
author: Marina K.

description: tasty, yes, but way too pricey for fried dumplings and spring rolls...
author: Jill k.

description:
go there once a week. if were't for the price, it deserves 5 star.

we always start with the dumpling and also finish with another order of dumpling.

favorites are:
shanghai dumpling (best in SF, much less oily than most place)
snow pea leaf dumpling
shrimp dumping
shummai
string bean
sweet sour chicken

what to avoid:
peking duck.
author: Yi S.

description: Just went here for a friends birthday lunch yesterday. Made reservations and was seated right away (friendly and sweet host). Unfortunately, my friends and I were seated in the front corner room (Try to sit in the middle of the dining room area if you can). The same ladies with the same food kept passing us to the point where we could pinpoint exactly what they had in their carts. Our waiter hawked us so we were a bit uncomfortable but  I'm sure he was  making sure we got everything we wanted and needed. Food was decent but I've had much better (a bit overpriced as well). The best dish for me was the xiao long bao [ shanghai dumplings ] with vinegar/ginger sauce. I was able to slip to the waiter that it was my friends birthday and after our check, the waiter and manager came out to sing happy birthday to my friend (the first time ever in my entire life a Chinese restaurant sang happy birthday...well, in English) and brought egg tarts with a candle in one of them. The staff is very friendly and the location is very nice as well but if you want authentic (or as close as possible) Chinese dim sum, you might want to try going to Chinatown. Remember, they validate! $4 for two hours I believe. I think the parking garage charges $6 / 30 minutes.
author: Christina Y.

description: Like the Chinese figure skating pair in the Torino Olympics... I couldn't give Yank Sing the 5 star rating cause of the dismount (on that one jump where the chick landed on her knees...).... wait...I'm falling off the subject here.  Anyhow, yeah, the dismount after eating here... is the bill, and that usually gets a bit steep.. actually way steep.  Compared to the hidden jewels of Clement St.  But like other reviewers, the food is exceptional.  The Shanghai dumplings (just how to they get that soup in there and make it spiral up so nicely??!?!) are superb, and the shu-mai.... almost 'tastes' healthy.   And what other dim sum place do you know of where it's high-tech enough that the Chinese servers wear the headset/earpieces.... "Uh, yeah... I need a chow fun in sector 8, and fish balls in sector 9... over!"....  One nice benefit... the free complimentary parking underground on the weekends.... makes for one less thing to fight for when going here.  But be smart.... "Friends don't let friends go to Yank Sing on the weekend without a major credit card or a reservation!".
author: Dale K.

description: I have very fond memories of this place because this was the first dim sum place I tried. My mom took me here when I was 5 and from then on, I was hooked. Our family would come back here frequently over the years, and I have had many a lovely meal here stuffing myself with my parents and sisters. However, over the past 9-10 years or so, the prices have risen more and more, and I think the quality of the dim sum has suffered some. Also- its not very authentic, although their dishes are very creative, its Chinese food geared towards tourists. I appreciate the fact  that the dim sum here has minimal grease and seems to use fairly high quality meats and seafoods, but come on- $5 for a plate of 4 tiny har gao! I went here with a friend that lived in the Rincon towers one morning, and we did not eat a whole lot and spent about $30 each, which I thought was ridiculous. This is a place I would probably take non chinese clients or coworkers to, but with all the great dim sum places in the area, I wont be coming here of my own accord, though the memories here are endless.
author: Manali K.

description: I really like Yank Sing.  The food is good, the service is efficient (the waitstaff speaks decent English) and the place is nice and clean.  I usually feel a little uncomfortable eating dim sum at most places unless I'm with a Chinese friend, but guay-lo can get by just fine here.  The restaurant even proudly displays their health code score of 100 because it's probably the only Chinese restaurant in the country that did so well.  I just love the dim sum carts  (I've been trying to get one of my friends to push a cart and dress like a dim sum wench for Halloween for years).  So many of the smaller places don't have them.  It's nice to see what you're getting before you order.  Also, the waitstaff here isn't as aggressive as at many other places.  Honestly, how many times do I have to say no to chicken feet!  They also have a huge variety, including some higher-end non-traditional dishes like the deep-fried soft-shell crab.  I also really like the deep-fried crab claw.  I typically focus on the seafood stuff, like various shrimp dumplings but pretty much everything I've had has been good.  It's also nice that they offer peking duck by the slice.  Many of my Chinese friends don't like this place because it's rather pricey for dim sum, but I don't mind spending $30 - 40 pp for good quality and service.  They also take reservations.
author: Saw T.

description:
having only been here for a chinese wedding banquet, this was my first encounter with their dim sum service.  it certainly didn't seem like the economy was hurting when we entered at 1PM on a thursday and found a packed house.

this place is leaps and bounds cleaner and friendlier than 99% of all dim sum establishments... in fact, it's probably one of maybe two places where i'm not inclined to first sterilize my chopsticks with scalding, hot tea before using them.

we only ordered a few plates including xiao long bao (which was pretty juicy), har gao (which was on par with anywhere else), some pea spout dumplings (which were surprisingly flavorful and reminiscent of din tai fung in LA), and a few other dumplings that have fallen from memory.

food all in all was decent and as fellow yelpers have mentioned, noticeably more expensive.  it's worth an occasional visit especially if you're bringing out-of-town guests, etc. who might otherwise be appalled by the questionable sanitary standards at the majority of chinatown establishments.
author: joyce h.

description: Yum! This place was very good. Their special, beef deem sum, was my favorite. Some stuff was kinda odd, like chicken foot. Its right in side a office building with a cool fountain.
author: John A.

description: well I went to this place and I am semi Americanized and A non-asian to boot. I went there from the get go.what do you want me to do,repeat the same 60 million compliments. no I will not. I will say that I have Had clients(international)that consistantly lunch at yang sing. I do not recall going to the new location,I must of,I just dine out so often it can become a blur if not a bore like obamma. Go to yang sing. OH there is a nearby place that serves a soup,clam? I wont even write about it,you taste it,you go to heaven. When I find out the name of the place we where at by my X attorney glutton Roman emporer living style freind , I will let you know where. Words do not cannot describe. see,I have the looks,he has the brains and  He is   a connysewer! This glutton is happily married so don't think your gonna get a free clam or somthing. His housekeeper tried to use 'brujeria' on him to take his money. It did not work. How I found out is another story. I'm listening to coast to coast am radio 560 on the dial and here is maralyn manroe singing happy birthday Mr. president. I knew a samoan girl who used to sing it to me in the same way.I wish she was here singing it to me
author: OSEPH E.

description: Dimsum to a next level is thier moto.  It was pretty good but not $$ good.  I sometimes get dimsum in chinatown in the morning for breakfast, and I love inexpensive dimsum better.
author: Su Kyeong K.

description: i didn't think it was anything extraordinary and it was more expensive than what i am used to. that aside, everything was fresh and how i expect it to taste and the service was straight up as fast as it gets. i definitely wouldn't go out of my way for it though.
author: Matt R.

description: It's fun to go here with a lot of people so you can order a variety of items, but it's quite pricey. Everything is delicious except their desserts.
author: Molly B.

description: Excellent flavors, and the experience is fun!  Like most dim sum, waiters come around with several plates on a cart, and you get to pick which ones look good.  The risk is that you don't notice how much you've ordered.  I think that's partly why so many people think it is expensive.  If you order a "normal" amount of food, as in two or three plates per person, it will be very reasonable.  I like that this place is clean and friendly, and I love taking out of town guests here for an experience of the great Chinese cuisine in San Francisco.
author: Leah D.

description: The dim sum here is decent but the service is definitely excellent.  Everyone on staff spoke English and attentive, something you don't expect from a dim sum restaurant.  For dim sum, they served a lot of dishes you'd find during a chinese banquet wedding, such as sea bass and deep fried crab claws.  This probably explains why this place is so expensive.  For two, our bill came out to $80 before tax and tip.
author: Helen V.

description: not the best dimsum you can get in the bay area. still, they have something others don't: Good service and clean floor. go for experience
author: Angie Y.

description: Their dimsum is really good but kinda pricey.  Service is ok compared to other dims sum restaurants.  I lke going to Yank Sing because the place looks clean and the dimsum is tasty compared to other dimsum places.
author: Cj P.

description: Don't get me wrong, great dim sum but why are places like City View in an alley the edge of Chinatown  1/2 the price and about the same service and quality?
author: Antony E.

description: wow...if you are looking for good dimsum here is the place to go...if there is anything that you cannot take in your diet, they are more than accommodating and willing to make it then and there....so don't be shy to ask...my favorite is their chicken and mushroom fried buns...oh my goodness, is it heavenly...i think i could eat 20 of them if my appetite would allow...also..make sure you try their famous aluminum wrapped chicken...it is just delish and no one around makes them better than them...just make sure you add a dab of their mustard with each bite...for those who like spicy....a jar of their homemade chilli sauce is a perfect gift to bring to friends who love spicy sauce.
author: Mee-stique K.

description: Yank Sing is by far my favorite "special occasion" dimsum restaurant in the Bay Area.  So, why only 4 stars? Two words-- THE PRICE.  As most of the other reviewers have said, for your Sunday-dimsum-with-the-family dishes you could do better price wise.  However Yank Sing  does have innovative / special occasion dimsum like their peking duck, and not your typical minced meat (squab maybe?) in lettuce leaf, fusion dumplings, to name a few.  To get your money's worth, keep away from the typical dimsum fare and be adventurous.  That's where Yank Sing shines.  I travel to Asia time and again, and find that Yank Sing could be considered your typical "fine dinning" Chinese restaurant out there.  So keep that in mind when paying your tab (great food without the jet lag).  For families with small children and restless adults who can't keep still, the wanna be waterfall outside is a good entertainment factor when they get bored.
author: Marissa M.

description: I took away a star because of the long wait on the weekends and high prices.  The food itself is da bomb.  There's so much variety, and I love the chili paste.
author: LT B.

description:
I have to admit...I've never had Dim Sum before Yank Sing. So I can't comment on its authenticity, on the service, on the price, or anything in comparison to other Dim Sum. 

What I can say is that it was totally overwhelming, delicious, and hella expensive all at once. But it was so worth it!

I munched on tofu, scallop dumplings, scallop/taro fried things, sea bass , and some sesame dessert thing. My boyfriend ate some of this with me, but also ate some pork dumplings and pork/taro. The dumpling sauce was bright red and filled with ginger, so you know it was one of my favorite parts of the meal. The scallops were tender and delicately flavored, especially in the dumplings. Wasn't as hot on the fried taro, but I thought it was pretty traditional, so I gave it a try. The sesame dessert was wonderfully chewy, not too sweet, and served as a fine finale to the meal. Sorry I don't know the real names of any of the dishes. It was fast and furious. Carts kept coming, dishes kept piling, I'd ask what something was and it would be on my table. I was delighted and confused all at once. But by the end of the meal, I knew how to use the spoon for the dumplings and that you can use your hands for the taro things, and even though my right hand is so messed up from bass playing and designing, I even got the chopsticks going right for a bit. It was a great lunch. The most expensive of my life, but an adventure....though I wondered if they staff there totally hated me by the end. I made a mistake in not ordering tea...how could I mess that one up? But if I ever make it back there (it seems possible), I will be sure not to forget some pu-erh.
author: lisa s.

description: Yank Sing is the palace of Dim Sum.  Strictly gourmet, high quality dumplings of the gods.  Not the down home variety.  Pricey and quite worth it.  On the steamed side Seafood Basil, Lobster and Shrimp/Chive are rocking.  The Duck Taco and chunk of Chilean Sea Bass are special.  Fried Tofu with seaweed is hearty veggie eats.  The classic pork buns killing.  Gai lan and Snow Pea leaves are a nice green, leafy accoutrement.  You can ask servers with the carts to call on their radios for other requested buns.  The Rincon location is the place.
author: Lo F.

description: Not the best dimsum in the SF area, but it certainly comes close. Expensive and difficult to get into, but still better than most dimsim places. Nothing in Chicago even remotely compares.
author: Arjun C.

description: Love this place. Very interesting set up. Went with a group of friends. We all loved it! .  I've tried other dim sum places, and I always compare them to Yank Sing. Yank Sing Rocks!
author: Jean D.

description: My husband and I had our wedding ceremony & banquet at Yank Sing.  We visited a lot of different venues before finding Yank Sing.  We accidentally discovered Yank Sing one Saturday morning as they were setting up for a wedding ceremony in the atrium and we immediately knew that this was where we wanted to get married because the site was gorgeous, especially the skylight roof and fountain.  Plus, there is free parking for your guests (nearly unheard of in San Francisco!) and we'd be indoors and protected from the elements.  However, we were concerned about whether the food and the service would pass the ultimate test of our parents.  Joy Li, our Yank Sing coordinator, arranged for us to have a tasting and our parents and bridal party were extremely impressed with the delicious food and the excellent service and could not stop raving about it!   Since we lived in Sacramento, Joy made time to meet with us regularly after work, late in the evenings and on weekends to help us customize our wedding ceremony & banquet.  She was a pleasure to work with and did a detailed and exceptional job.  On the day of our wedding, the food came out on time and was hot and delicious.  The staff were very attentive and polite.  Even the bathrooms were extremely clean and stocked all evening.  After our wedding, our friends and family all told us how much they loved the food and thought the service was so much better than at other Chinese restaurants.  They loved it so much that my brother later got married here as well.  Even though we live 2 hours away, my husband and I will still occasionally drive to Yank Sing on the weekends just to have Dim Sum because they have the best Dim Sum in the city.  We have such fond memories of our wedding day, thanks to everyone at Yank Sing.   We love Yank Sing and highly recommend it.  In fact, I've been drooling while writing this review, just thinking about the food!
author: Quyen K.

description: I had lunch with two friends here recently. What I like about dim sum is the minute you sit down the carts of dim sum start coming around so you never really look at a menu (or prices). Although we had a delicious lunch, we were shocked when we got the bill, $158.00!!! I have never had such expensive dim sum in my life. We do know we wont eat there again. For that price we would of gone to a more high end restaurant.
author: karen c.

description: Simply put, this is the BEST dim sum in san francisco. The dim sum is high quality and the restaurant is very clean. YES, you do pay a premium, but there is no other dim sum restaurant that is comparable to Yank sing. The ONLY downfall to the food is the COST, which should NOT be a determining factor when rating it.
author: Michael S.

description: I don't get the people complaining about this place being too expensive and paying $40/person for lunch. What are you people eating? I came here with 2 girlfriends and we STUFFED ourselves with  2 orders of Shanghai dumplings, pork buns and various seafood dim sum. Out total bill before tip was $60 for 3 people. We did not order any drinks, just had water and tea. Anyway, best dim sum I have tried anywhere. I'm not claiming to be the dim sum expert, but I know when food is good and when it's bad, and this is damn good. If I could live off their baked pork buns, I would.
author: I W.

description: Over-priced and just ok (agreeing with another yelper).
author: T D.

description: This place is totally overrated. Although I have no problem with the price (I'll admit it's a tad pricey), it was the overall quality of the food I was disappointed with. I was expecting something a lot better than what you'd get in Chinatown but was completely underwhelmed.  Some of the dishes were a little cold and probably made the rounds one or two times before they came to us, and others like the duck were tasteless.
author: Lincoln P.

description: hot spot with great dim sum....except of course the prices....very very expensive.....4 of us..150 with tip...
author: kat r.

description: Absolutely love this place!  When I worked in SF, my friends and I would come here often for lunch.  Now that I live in the South Bay, I only get to eat here about once or twice per  year.  The dim sum is so tasty and is the best of any that I have tried elsewhere.  The prices are expensive, but it is worth the visit when you are in the mood for dim sum.
author: Rosie P.

description: So at least twice a year, I go to a wedding banquet at Yank Sing.  The banquet food ranges from decent to above average.  Banquets can be both inside the restaurant or outside in the atrium.  Inside the restaurant is very intimate, and the outside can handle up to 300-400 guests.  The service is really great, especially if your good buddy decides to have open bar!  I have been here for dim sum, and as take out as well.  Very good stuff...
author: Ian L.

description:
just had seereeous deem sum at yank sing. highlights included top notch xiao long bao, some select sticky rice and a peking duck cart. thats right, they give you a piece of duck, slice of skin, greens, a steamed bun and sauce - and you make your own peking duck sangwich.

while eating deem sum han solo is not ideal - and i've done it a bunch in the US, the UK and China - this was a truly remarkable respite from the june gloom. dark skies when i entered turned to sunshine upon my exit, stomach full of succulent pork, luscious dumplings and delectable don tat. 

baller.
author: Dr. A.

description: I had my wedding at Yang Sing. Actually my wife force me to have it there. I was shocked at the prices at first but when I saw  what the other restaurants were charging , Shit , they was all about the same price. Only after going to a few weddings after mine did it appreciate how beautiful and fancy Yang Sing was. The service too was first class.  Very Professional. Like most guys I don't pay attention to these things but Its pretty obvious that Yang sing is the place for your wedding if you decide not to go cheap. I'm glad  I had mines there
author: tung t.

description: My daughters and I went for lunch at the 101 Spear St. location. I found the service attentive, the food carts numerous with a large variety of dim sum. I did not like the taste or the cost! I've tasted much better dim sum at other locations throughout the bay area.  The bill came and I nearly died! OMG! Over $100 for 8 dishes, dang. I am a American-Chinese born and raised SF, and I have never paid such an outrageous price for a tea lunch. Have I been hibernating? I will never go to Yank Sing again, nor will I recommend it.
author: Gerry P.

description: Went here a few months back after hearing and reading about this joint's creative dim sum spin....the only dish that was impressive and well worth the effort was their shanghai dumpling.  If you are asian...or experienced asian shark fin soup broth drinker , you would know this is the bomb the minute the broth hits your tongue.  Unbelievably rich, smooth, buttery...it's all about the broth.  I had to be shown how to eat this dumpling...with a soup spoon.  Now the rest of the food...really, it's just good  dim sum.  My theory about dim sum, after a few dishes at any dim sum house, the food flavor starts tasting the same:  pork, beef, chicken, shrimp or scallops.  Might as well throw everything together and make a stir fry rice/paella/gumbo....Is it just me?  Really over priced and come on, it's in financial district.  I don't mind paying for the over price...but it's got give value for the over price.  Hate paying for someone's rent.
author: Quynh P.

description: not a fan - this place definitely does not cater to the chinese crowd... they serve a lot of dishes that are not traditionally served for dim sum.  the food is very medicore at best.  it's completely over priced, but it's clean.
author: Michelle H.

description: how rare is a clean chinese restaurant -- with good service? the waiters brought us more tea without us having to ask for it.  we asked for water -- it came within 5 minutes.. refills were prompt without us having to ask.  this has NEVER happened to me in a chinese restaurant EVER.  the bathroom was so clean, you could eat in it.  it smelled like flowers!  there was even a bathroom attendant handing out towels and wiping the sinks down (there were only two stalls).  it took me a while to get over the shock of the great service you can get in a chinese run establishment.  that in itself was priceless.  on top of this, i thought the dim sum was pretty good despite other people's reviews saying it was bland.  I'd say the standard fare  (har gao, rice rolls, char siu bao, lo bak go) is equal to koi palace or mayflower.  they also had a wide selection of dishes that i've never seen before.  the foil chicken was amazingly flavorful.  another added bonus was that we didn't have to wait for a table.. they take reservations unlike koi palace.  this place was so big, though i don't think you'd have problems getting a table if you come before 11:30.  the restaurant itself is pretty nice and the rain fountain thing in the middle of rincon center is pretty cool.  parking is also free with valiidation on the weekends.  granted we didn't pay the bill, but if it came out to about 30 or 40 bucks a head, the cleanliness alone made it worth it.  we've been to excellent tasting dirt cheap places in chinatown, but after a friend found a bug in their food, they could give away their food for free and we'd never eat there again.
author: Waynele Y.

description: by far the best dim sum in the city thou they are more pricey then most of the citys dim sum  joints
author: nick g.

description: yeah, it's pricey...yeah, you can find dim sum cheaper elsewhere...yeah, there's usually a wait.  but seeing four huge motha dan tats in front of me which melts in ur mouth, yum.  i heart yank sing.
author: M R.
